Title: Grand challenges for design and manufacturing
Source title: ICMA 2004 - Proceedings of the International Conference on Manufacturing Automation: Advanced Design and Manufacturing in Global Competition
Affiliations: Stanford University, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Prinz, F.B., Stanford University, CA, United States
Abstract: As a whole, our society faces a number of challenges. Ranking highly among them are the steadily increasing accumulation of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere and the potential climactic changes associated with generating power needed to heat our homes, to drive our automobiles and to fly aircraft. As engineers we can contribute significantly towards making our world more livable by minimizing the damage to our environment. The School of Engineering at Stanford is active in helping to better understand and design the fundamentals of the next generation of power systems. We are addressing techniques to realize the coming of the 'Hydrogen Economy'. Developing means for hydrogen production, hydrogen storage and hydrogen utilization are just a few examples of projects we are exploring. Recent advances in micro and nano technology have allowed our students and faculty to participate in the realization process for future hydrogen fuel cell systems. Energy is just one of our targeted social needs. Another grand challenge we confront responds to the fact that, statistically, we will live longer than previous generations. To afford the cost inherent in living longer, we need to stay healthy and to work longer in our factories and offices. Retaining our mobility, being able to walk at all stages of our life, represents one primary issue we need to address. We have established research to better understand a broad range of questions including what it takes to delay the onset of diseases such as osteoarthritis. We are exploring design and manufacturing environments that are suited to realize next generation medical systems. In many instances such systems resemble concepts and metrics well known in today's production systems. © Professional Engineering Publishing 2004.
Index Keywords: Aircraft; Automation; Automobiles; Carbon dioxide; Climate change; Disease control; Environmental engineering; Standby power systems; Hydrogen economy; Hydrogen storage; Medical systems; Nano technology; Social needs; Earth atmosphere

Title: Antistatic finishes for control and efficiency
Source title: International Dyer
Authors with affiliations: Holme, I.
Abstract: Antistatic agents are widely used spin finishes and lubricants to achieve high measure of control over textile processing and to prevent static discharges. Static discharges under certain conditions can generate sparks that may have sufficient energy to ignite explosive materials and gases. Antistatic agents are chemicals that are applied to the surface of fibers, filaments, yarns to control the propensity of the textile materials to accumulate static electricity. The control can be achieved either by decreasing the generation of the electrical charge or by increasing the electrical conductance of the textile fibers. To get the highest efficiency, antistatic finish must be present on the fiber surface so that the fiber-surface conductivity is increased. The diffusion of antistatic finish into the body of the fiber must be prevented, or atleast retarded, otherwise, on storage, the efficiency of the antistatic finish will gradually decrease. Yarnsoft-GS (Sarex) is a pseudocationic softner and lubricant with an antistatic action, specially developed for application to cotton yarn, both in package and hank form.
Index Keywords: antistatic property

Authors: Wasiak T., Kavanagh J., Bellemore J.
Title: Development and implementation of the waste diversion program at MDS Nordion's cobalt operations facility
Source title: Annual Canadian Nuclear Society Conference
Authors with affiliations: Wasiak, T.; Kavanagh, J.; Bellemore, J.
Abstract: Historically, the MDS Nordion (MDSN) Cobalt Operations Facility sent solid waste for disposal to Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd.'s Chalk River Laboratories (AECL-CRL). A large portion of this waste was not contaminated. Because this non-contaminated waste originated in the "active area" of the MDSN facility, it was routinely disposed of as low-level active waste. In 2002, MDSN undertook an initiative to develop and implement a more sophisticated and more economical waste management program. The Waste Diversion Program (WDP) ensures continued environmental and public protection, and reduces the demand on Canada's limited capacity for storage of radioactive material and the associated operating costs. The goal of the WDP is to reduce the volume of waste currently being shipped to AECL-CRL's Waste Management Operation as low-level active waste. The presentation discusses key elements of both the development and the implementation of WDP. It focuses on the following areas: The regulatory environment surrounding the waste disposal issues in Canada and abroad. Methods used by MDSN for determination of radionuclides. which could be present in the facility. Choice of equipment and calculation of individual alarm levels for each identified radionuclide. Key elements of the practical implementation of the program. CNSC Regulatory approval process. The bottom line - dollars and cents. The primary objective of the WDP is to ensure that only waste, which meets regulatory requirements, is diverted from the solid active waste stream. This has been successfully accomplished in MDSN's Cobalt Operations Facility. The objective of the presentation is to share the knowledge and experience obtained in the development process, and thus provide a guideline for other nuclear facilities interested in establishing similar proactive and cost effective programs.
Index Keywords: Contamination; Costs; Laws and legislation; Radioisotopes; Regulatory compliance; Waste management; Non-contaminated waste; Nuclear facilities; Waste diversion program; Radioactive waste disposal

Authors: Shen K., Chu L., Yang T.
Title: Supporting cluster-based network services on functionally symmetric software architecture
Source title: IEEE/ACM SC2004 Conference, Proceedings
Affiliations: Dept. of Computer Science, University of Rochester, United States; Ask Jeeves Inc., University of California, Santa Barbara, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shen, K., Dept. of Computer Science, University of Rochester, United States; Chu, L., Ask Jeeves Inc., University of California, Santa Barbara, United States; Yang, T., Ask Jeeves Inc., University of California, Santa Barbara, United States
Abstract: Server and storage clustering has become a popular platform for hosting large-scale online services. Elements of the service clustering support are often constructed using centralized or hierarchical architectures, in order to meet performance and policy objectives desired by online applications. For instance, a central Executive node can be employed to make efficient resource management decisions based on a complete view of cluster-wide resource availability as well as request demands. Functionally symmetric software architecture can enhance the robustness of cluster-based network services due to its inherent absence of vulnerability points. However, such a design must satisfy performance requirements and policy objectives desired by online services. This paper argues for the improved robustness of functionally symmetric architectures and presents the designs of two specific clustering support elements: energy-conserving server consolidation and service availability management. Our emulation and experimentation on a 117-server cluster show that the proposed designs do not significantly compromise the system performance and policy objectives compared with the centralized approaches. © 2004 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Cluster computing; Energy conservation; Network services; Peer-to-peer computing; Resource management
Index Keywords: Cluster computing; Network services; Peer-to-peer computing; Resource management; Computer software; Decision theory; Energy conservation; Performance; Servers; Telecommunication networks

Authors: Lorencez C., Redden D., Round G.
Title: An optimized three-stage unit cooldown
Source title: Annual Canadian Nuclear Society Conference
Affiliations: Performance Engineering, Pickering NGS 'B', Ontario Power Generation, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Lorencez, C., Performance Engineering, Pickering NGS 'B', Ontario Power Generation, Canada; Redden, D., Performance Engineering, Pickering NGS 'B', Ontario Power Generation, Canada; Round, G., Performance Engineering, Pickering NGS 'B', Ontario Power Generation, Canada
Abstract: A numerical model of the Cover Gas (Helium) in the D 2O storage tank has been developed to understand the phenomenon and propose a modification of the cooldown evolution to avoid the use of thermalcycles. In PNGS 'B', the D 2 storage tank is pressurized with a Cover Gas (Helium) to ensure that a pressure higher than 45 kPa(g) exists at the suction of the pressurizing pumps. A D 2storage tank level of 2.1 m should not be exceeded prior to performing a heat transport system (HTS) cooldown. More coolant is not needed since the contribution to the hydrostatic head is negligible and the D 2O inventory in the storage tank is enough to compensate for the change in coolant density from 265°C to 40°C.

Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium Conference Record

Abstract: To clarify the potential of LuAP:Ce and LuYAP:Ce scintillators of new generation the mechanisms of the energy transfer from the matrix to the cerium ions and competing relaxation channels were investigated using VUV luminescence spectroscopy for the crystals provided by different producers using different growth techniques. With temperature being one of the ways to control the light yield of these crystals, effect of temperature was studied for different excitation energies. Anomalous temperature dependence of the luminescence light yield under VUV excitation was analyzed. New intrinsic luminescence band was observed in all of the crystals and energy transfer from it to cerium ions was demonstrated. New luminescence band in the IR peaking around 750 nm was detected, its origin and effect on the scintillator performance is discussed. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Cerium; Crystal growth; Energy transfer; Luminescence; Lutetium compounds; Phosphors; Quantum theory; Relaxation processes; Storage rings; X rays; Excitation energy (EE); Quantum yield; Relaxation channels; X ray excitation; Crystal impurities

Title: A multiple approach to rainwater as a renewable resource
Source title: Proceedings of the 2004 World Water and Environmetal Resources Congress: Critical Transitions in Water and Environmetal Resources Management
Affiliations: Sweete Water Research Institute Incorporated, 1181 SW 158th Ave., Pembroke Pines, FL 33027-2247, United States
Authors with affiliations: Burnham, G.S., Sweete Water Research Institute Incorporated, 1181 SW 158th Ave., Pembroke Pines, FL 33027-2247, United States
Abstract: A multiple approach to rainwater harvesting as a renewable source of water is discussed. Rainwater harvesting is the diversion of small amounts of water, typically of very high quality, from one segment of the hydrologic cycle to another by collection and storage. It is the natural machine, powered by heat energy reaching Earth from the sun and the Earth's force of gravity. The same water has moved from the ocean to the atmosphere to land and back to seas and over again for all the Eons. The introduction of rainwater harvesting in water management includes the important considerations that it i a high quality source safe from contamination and independent of the current water net.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Clouds; Condensation; Distillation; Gravitation; Hydrology; Meteorology; Potable water; Renewable energy resources; Direct-product-profit (DPP); Hydrologic cycle; Rainwatar harvesting; Water management; Rain

Title: Soda glass capillary plate gas detector
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium Conference Record
Affiliations: Information and Cell Function, PRESTO, JST, Tokyo 103-0028, Japan; Department of Physics, Faculty of Science, Yamagata University, 1-4-12 Kojirakawa, Yamagata 990-8560, Japan; Electron Tube Division, Hamamatsu Photonics K.K., Shizuoka 438-0193, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tokanai, F., Information and Cell Function, PRESTO, JST, Tokyo 103-0028, Japan, Department of Physics, Faculty of Science, Yamagata University, 1-4-12 Kojirakawa, Yamagata 990-8560, Japan; Atsumi, T., Electron Tube Division, Hamamatsu Photonics K.K., Shizuoka 438-0193, Japan; Gunji, S., Department of Physics, Faculty of Science, Yamagata University, 1-4-12 Kojirakawa, Yamagata 990-8560, Japan; Okada, T., Electron Tube Division, Hamamatsu Photonics K.K., Shizuoka 438-0193, Japan; Sakurai, H., Department of Physics, Faculty of Science, Yamagata University, 1-4-12 Kojirakawa, Yamagata 990-8560, Japan
Abstract: A new capillary plate (CP) has been developed for a hole-type micropattern gas detector. The plate consists of a bundle of fine soda-glass capillaries of 100 μm in diameter with a uniform length of 1 mm. The electrodes on the surfaces of both ends were coated with Inconel metal. It is similar to the conventional CP, except that the glass is not lead glass, but soda glass. The main advantages compared to the lead-glass CP are the low surface resistivity and the low background properties. The soda-glass CP gas detector was operated with a gas mixture of Ar(90%) + CH4(8%) + TMA(2%) using 5.9 keV X-rays. We successfully obtained the energy spectrum and the accumulated image for the 5.9 keV X-rays. We report on the characteristics of the new soda-glass CP and the background properties of both the soda-glass and lead-glass CPs. We also describe the outlook on the future development of an optical gas photomultiplier with the soda-glass CP. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Capillarity; Crystal structure; Electrodes; Glass; Imaging systems; Microstrip devices; Optical image storage; Photomultipliers; X ray crystallography; Capillary plates (CP); Optical gas photomultipliers; Soda glass; Surface resistivity; Gas detectors

Authors: Protić D., Stöhlker T., Krings T., Mohos I., Spillmann U.
Title: Two-dimensional microstrip germanium detector for X-Ray spectroscopy of highly charged heavy ions
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium Conference Record
Affiliations: Forschungszentrum Jülich GmbH, Institut für Kernphysik, 52425 Jülich, Germany; Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 64291 Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Protić, D., Forschungszentrum Jülich GmbH, Institut für Kernphysik, 52425 Jülich, Germany; Stöhlker, T., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 64291 Darmstadt, Germany; Krings, T., Forschungszentrum Jülich GmbH, Institut für Kernphysik, 52425 Jülich, Germany; Mohos, I., Forschungszentrum Jülich GmbH, Institut für Kernphysik, 52425 Jülich, Germany; Spillmann, U., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, 64291 Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: New possibilities are opened utilizing position-sensitive germanium detectors in the X-ray spectroscopy of highly charged heavy ions at GSI-Darmstadt. The recent experiments revealed the need for two-dimensional strip detectors with their inherent advantages concerning spectroscopy and imaging capabilities as well as polarization sensitivity. For the first prototype a germanium diode (70 mm × 41 mm, 11 mm thick) with a boron implanted contact and an amorphous Ge contact was prepared. A 128 strip structure on an area of 32 mm × 56 mm with a pitch of 250 μm on the front contact (implanted) and 48 strip structure with a pitch of 1167 μm on the rear contact (amorphous Ge) are realized with the help of plasma etching. The detector is mounted in a cryostat which will enable any orientation of the detector in respect to a photon source. The results of laboratory tests and first applications at the ESR storage ring in Darmstadt are presented. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Diodes; Electric potential; Germanium; Heavy ions; Photons; Plasma etching; X ray spectroscopy; X rays; Atomic transitions; Energy resolution; Microstrip germanium detectors; Temperature testing; Radiation detectors

Title: Modelling of the multipart steam turbine in matlab environment
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Systems Science
Affiliations: Department of Control Engineering, Czech Technical University in Prague, Karlovo namesti 13, 121 35, Prague 2, Czech Republic; Honeywell Prague Laboratory, Pod vodarenskou vezi 4, 182 08, Prague 8, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Cepák, M., Department of Control Engineering, Czech Technical University in Prague, Karlovo namesti 13, 121 35, Prague 2, Czech Republic; Havlena, V., Honeywell Prague Laboratory, Pod vodarenskou vezi 4, 182 08, Prague 8, Czech Republic
Abstract: The electricity is one of the most important technical discoveries. It represents the base material essential for each human activity and it should be hard to imagine the contemporary world without this phenomenon. How the electrical energy demand rises up, new power-producing equipments are built. Expect the nuclear and water power plants, the thermal ones belong to the most widespread in the world. They constitute very complex systems with the steam turbine as a basic unit in which the transformation of the steam thermal energy to the prime mover mechanical power takes place. Controlling this conversion, the considerable savings can be obtained. But the control algorithm should be simulated on the system model at first and only the successful results should enable its applicability in the industry. This paper describes the development of the mathematical model of the backpressure and condensing multipart turbine and the implementation of the other energetic components in MATLAB environment. The next purpose is the testing of the designed models in the SIMULINK tool. The comparison of the data provided by the models with the real data represents the last goal.
Author Keywords: Identification; Mathematical model; Simulation; Steam turbine
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Costs; Electric energy storage; Geothermal power plants; Mathematical models; Multivariable control systems; Back pressures; MATLAB environment; Steam thermal energy; Throttling valves; Steam turbines

Authors: Drouhin F., Gross L., Vintache D., Marchioro A., Paillard C., Ljuslin C., Mirabito L., Verdini P.G.
Title: The CERN CMS tracker control system
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium Conference Record
Affiliations: Université de Haute-Alsace, Mulhouse, France; Institut de Recherches Subatomiques de Strasbourg, Batiment 21, 23 rue du Loess, F67037 Strasbourg Cedex, France; Institut de Recherches Subatomiques de Strasbourg, France; European Organization for Nuclear Research, Geneva, Switzerland; Institut de Physique Nucléaire, Lyon, France; Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Pisa, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Drouhin, F., Université de Haute-Alsace, Mulhouse, France, Institut de Recherches Subatomiques de Strasbourg, Batiment 21, 23 rue du Loess, F67037 Strasbourg Cedex, France; Gross, L., Institut de Recherches Subatomiques de Strasbourg, France; Vintache, D., Institut de Recherches Subatomiques de Strasbourg, France; Marchioro, A., European Organization for Nuclear Research, Geneva, Switzerland; Paillard, C., European Organization for Nuclear Research, Geneva, Switzerland; Ljuslin, C., European Organization for Nuclear Research, Geneva, Switzerland; Mirabito, L., Institut de Physique Nucléaire, Lyon, France; Verdini, P.G., Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Pisa, Italy
Abstract: Due to the high integration level of the experiments planned for the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) of the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN), the data acquisition and the control systems need complex developments both in hardware and software. The purpose of this paper is to describe the control system of a sub-detector of one of the CERN experiments, the Tracker of the Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS). The CMS Tracker control system is based on dedicated hardware and software. The hardware is based on the Front End Controller (FEC), an interface board that hosts token rings for the communication with the Control and Communication Unit (CCU) modules. These in turn contain dedicated I/O channels for the front end readout and control chips. The software is built in layers: one device driver, a C++ dedicated application program interface (API) plus a database for the storage of all the information needed for the front end electronics. This system will also be adopted in some other CMS sub-detectors. © 2004 IEEE.
Author Keywords: ASIC; Control System; Oracle Database; Software

Wiedenmann, W., Department of Physics, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, United States; Wielers, M., University of Victoria, Vic., Canada; Zobernig, G., Department of Physics, University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, United States
Abstract: The ATLAS Trigger system is composed of three levels: an initial hardware trigger level (LVL1) followed by two software-based stages (LVL2 trigger and Event Filter) included in the High Level Trigger (HLT) and implemented on processor farms. The LVL2 trigger starts from LVL1 information concerning pointers to restricted so-called Regions of Interest (ROI) and performs event selection by means of optimized algorithms. If the LVL2 is passed, the full event is built and sent to the Event Filter (EF) algorithms for further selection and classification. After that, events are finally collected and put into mass storage for subsequent physics analysis. Even if many differences arise in the requirements and in the interfaces between the two HLT stages, they have a coherent approach to event selection. Therefore, the design of a common core software framework has been implemented in order to allow the HLT architecture to be flexible to changes (background conditions, luminosity, description of the detector, etc.). Algorithms working in the Event Filter are designed to work not only in a general purpose or exclusive mode, but they have been implemented in such a way to process given trigger hypotheses produced at a previous stage in the HLT dataflow (seeding concept). This is done by acting in separate steps, so that decisions to go further in the process are taken at every new step. An overview of the HLT processing steps is given and the working principles of the EF offline algorithms for muon reconstruction and identification (MOORE and Muld) are discussed in deeper detail. The reconstruction performances of these algorithms in terms of efficiency, momentum resolution, rejection power and execution times on several samples of simulated single muon events are presented, also taking into account the high background environment that is expected for ATLAS. © 2004 IEEE.
Author Keywords: ATLAS; Event Filter; HLT; Muons
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computer hardware; Computer simulation; Computer software; High energy physics; Spectrometers; Event filters; High level triggers (HLT); Muons; Regions of interest (ROI); Trigger circuits

Abstract: This experimental study investigated the sensitivity of 0.22 μm to 0.13 μm CMOS-based SRAMs to single event upsets (SEUs) induced by thermal and fission neutrons (energies below 6 MeV). Results showed that both supply voltage and type of component model can have significant impact.

The test equipment is described, as well as the specific test methodology developed. Some results of an SEU-like fault injection campaign preliminary to the radiation test are also presented.

Authors: Kumar S., Liu T., Sreekumar T.V., Uchida T., Zhang X., Park Y.-B.
Title: Polymer/carbon nanotube composites: Challenges and opportunities
Source title: International SAMPE Symposium and Exhibition (Proceedings)
Affiliations: School of Polymer, Textile and Fiber Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0295, United States; Faculty of Engineering, Okayama University, Okayama 700-8530, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, S., School of Polymer, Textile and Fiber Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0295, United States; Liu, T., School of Polymer, Textile and Fiber Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0295, United States; Sreekumar, T.V., School of Polymer, Textile and Fiber Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0295, United States; Uchida, T., School of Polymer, Textile and Fiber Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0295, United States, Faculty of Engineering, Okayama University, Okayama 700-8530, Japan; Zhang, X., School of Polymer, Textile and Fiber Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0295, United States; Park, Y.-B., School of Polymer, Textile and Fiber Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0295, United States
Abstract: Due to their exceptional mechanical, physical, thermal, optical, and electrical properties, carbon nanotubes and especially single wall carbon nanotubes are playing a critical role in the development of high-performance polymer composites. Polymer/carbon nanotube composites are processed into films, fibers, and bulk composites with significant mechanical and physical property enhancements. Single wall carbon nanotubes have high specific surface area, which can be further increased in activated carbon/single wall carbon nanotube composites. Such composite systems are promising candidates for supercapacitor applications. While single wall carbon nanotubes offer outstanding opportunities in materials development, many of the predicted properties can be achieved only if the nanotubes are well dispersed, exfoliated, and oriented in the polymer systems of interest. Currently, research is in progress addressing these issues in conjunction with the processing and characterization of polymer/carbon nanotube composites.

This approach is illustrated with results of SEU sensitivity characterization for two SRAMs obtained from particle accelerator and laser test. Title: Real-time performance management in pulp and paper
Source title: Technical Papers of ISA
Affiliations: OSIsoft, San Leandro, CA 94577, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stockford, D., OSIsoft, San Leandro, CA 94577, United States
Abstract: The importance and key elements of real-time performance management (RtPM) systems that enable real-time business intelligence for pulp and paper manufacturers to continuously improve their operation are discussed. The key elements of an RtPM system are automated data and events connectors, networked data storage, business analytic and hierarchical data modeling. It helps to monitor global production data in real-time and can be correlated with enterprise information. Key performance indicators can be set up to monitor operations targets in real-time triggering immediate corrective actions when they go out of target range.

Title: Range security sensors powered locally with the Nighttime Solar Cell™
Source title: Proceedings of the First Conference on Sustainable Range Management - 2004
Affiliations: Parise Research Technologies, Suffield, CT 06078, United States; Villanova University, Villanova, PA 19085, United States
Authors with affiliations: Parise, R.J., Parise Research Technologies, Suffield, CT 06078, United States; Jones, G.F., Villanova University, Villanova, PA 19085, United States
Abstract: The Nighttime Solar Cell™ is a clean, silent, inexhaustible source of low-wattage electric energy for powering remotely located electronic devices such as infrared, motion, vibration, emissions, etc., sensors and/or video monitoring to ensure the security and integrity of the Range periphery. This solid state device works on the simple principle of a thermoelectric generator operating in the temperature difference that exists between the ambient or surrounding temperature (nominally 290°K) as the thermal source and deep space at approximately 4°K as the thermal sink. Thus the Nighttime Solar Cell™ produces electric power continuously at night, and during the day utilizing one of several modes, depending on whether photovoltaic cells are used, reducing or eliminating the need for on-site electrical energy storage or power source maintenance. A thermal model has been developed from fundamental laws that predict the device can produce up to an estimated 17 W/m 2 as a remote electric power source, depending on site location. Several simple benchscale prototype cells have functioned well under all weather conditions. Field studies must now be performed with prototypes that have all the design attributes of the thermal model to demonstrate the usefulness of this reliable nighttime/daytime energy source. The Nighttime Solar Cell™ is a direct energy conversion device that utilizes aerospace technology for use in a military application: Range Management. This research provides a unique opportunity to supply remote power packs for Range sensors and security.
Index Keywords: Hot junctions; Range security; Range sensors; Remote electric power sources; Electric energy storage; Electric generators; Electronic equipment; Infrared radiation; Military applications; Photovoltaic cells; Sensors; Thermoelectricity; Solar cells

Authors: Dyer C.S., Clucas S.N., Sanderson C., Frydland A.D., Green R.T.
Title: An experimental study of single event effects induced in commercial SRAMs by neutrons and protons from thermal energies to 500 MeV
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: Space Department, QinetiQ Cody Technology Park, Farnborough, Hampshire GU14 0LX, United Kingdom; Engineering Department, Lancaster University, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dyer, C.S., Space Department, QinetiQ Cody Technology Park, Farnborough, Hampshire GU14 0LX, United Kingdom; Clucas, S.N., Space Department, QinetiQ Cody Technology Park, Farnborough, Hampshire GU14 0LX, United Kingdom; Sanderson, C., Space Department, QinetiQ Cody Technology Park, Farnborough, Hampshire GU14 0LX, United Kingdom; Frydland, A.D., Space Department, QinetiQ Cody Technology Park, Farnborough, Hampshire GU14 0LX, United Kingdom; Green, R.T., Engineering Department, Lancaster University, United Kingdom
Abstract: Irradiations have been performed, with neutrons and protons over a wide particle energy range, on six different commercial-grade 4-Mbit SRAM parts from the manufacturers Hitachi, Toshiba, Mitsubishi and Samsung. At energies above 20 MeV the SEU cross-sections are similar for protons and neutrons. While the proton cross-sections fall off rapidly below this energy, the neutron cross-sections at 14.5 MeV are close to the proton plateau values. Four of the devices show significant thermal neutron SEU cross-sections and in two cases these exceed the higher energy plateau values. The most modern of the parts tested is susceptible to latchup from both protons and neutrons.

Authors: Romero M., Martínez D., Zarza E.
Title: Terrestrial Solar Thermal Power Plants: On the verge of commercialization
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: Plataforma Solar de Almería, CIEMAT, Avda. Complu tense, 22, E-28040, Madrid, Spain; Plataforma Solar de Almería, CIEMAT, Apdo 22, E-04200, Almeria, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Romero, M., Plataforma Solar de Almería, CIEMAT, Avda. Complu tense, 22, E-28040, Madrid, Spain; Martínez, D., Plataforma Solar de Almería, CIEMAT, Apdo 22, E-04200, Almeria, Spain; Zarza, E., Plataforma Solar de Almería, CIEMAT, Apdo 22, E-04200, Almeria, Spain
Abstract: Solar Thermal Power Plants (STPP) with optical concentration technologies are important candidates for providing the bulk solar electricity needed within the next few decades, even though they still suffer from lack of dissemination and confidence among citizens, scientists and decision makers. Concentrating solar power is represented nowadays at pilot-scale and demonstration-scale by four technologies, parabolic troughs, linear Fresnel reflector systems, power towers or central receiver systems, and dish/engine systems, which are ready to start up in early commercial/demonstration plants. Even though, at present those technologies are still three times more expensive than intermediate-load fossil thermal power plants, in ten years from now, STPP may already have reduced production costs to ranges competitive. An important portion of this reduction (up to 42%) will be obtained by R&D and technology advances in materials and components, efficient integration schemes with thermodynamic cycles, highly automated control and low-cost heat storage systems.

Title: Possibility for spin flip in high energy electron rings
Source title: IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium Conference Record
Affiliations: Faculty of Mathematics and Physics, University of Ljubljana, Slovenia; Jožef Stefan Institute, Ljubljana, Slovenia
Authors with affiliations: Stres, Š., Faculty of Mathematics and Physics, University of Ljubljana, Slovenia; Pestotnik, R., Jožef Stefan Institute, Ljubljana, Slovenia
Abstract: In a high energy electron ring the spins of electrons become spontaneously polarized via the emission of spin-flip synchrotron radiation. By employing a radio frequency radial dipole field kicker, beam polarization can be reversed (i.e. spin flip can be obtained) over many turns. A model which couples three dimensional spin motion and longitudinal particle motion was constructed to describe non-equilibrium spin dynamics in high energy electron storage rings. Effects of stochastic synchrotron radiation on the orbital motion in the accelerator synchrotron plane and its influence on the spin motion are studied. The main contributions to the spin motion, the synchrotron oscillations and the stochastic synchrotron radiation, have different influence on the spin polarization reversal in different regions of the parameter space. The results indicate that polarization reversal can be obtained in high energy electron storage rings with significant noise even with relatively small strengths of disturbing magnetic field. © 2004 IEEE.
Author Keywords: High energy electron ring; Polarization reversal; Spin flip; Spin motion
Index Keywords: Betatrons; Damping; Electromagnetic wave polarization; Electrons; Magnetic fields; Oscillations; Phase space methods; Relativity; Synchrotron radiation; Synchrotrons; Vectors; High energy electron rings; Polarization reversal; Spin flip; Spin motion; Electron ring accelerators

Abstract: A pocket-size gamma-ray spectrometer has been developed. It uses a large volume (2 cm3) CdZnTe coplanar-grid detector to achieve good detection efficiency and energy resolution. The spectrometer is completely self-contained. It includes pulse processing electronics, multi-channel analyzer, data storage, LCD display, keypads, USB interface, and rechargeable battery. Custom software was created for spectrum acquisition, storage, and display. The power consumption of the spectrometer is 120 mW when active, allowing 2 days of continuous operation on a full battery charge. © 2004 IEEE.

Title: pAnti-scale valves
Source title: Technical Papers of ISA
Affiliations: Stainless Valve Co., Monroe, NC 28110, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lindenbeck, D.A., Stainless Valve Co., Monroe, NC 28110, United States
Abstract: In power generation, mining, food industry and pulp manufacturing there are valve applications where the standard valves used do not function satisfactorily. When scale is formed on the moving elements of ball valves or gate valves the consequence is either blocking of the valve movement or damage to the valve seats and consequent leaking through the valves. A development of anti-scale valves was carried out in 1995, which lead to a good performance in pulp manufacturing. Later the same principle was used in the food industry. The most impressive application was in mining, where standard valves had to be exchanged every two weeks, whereas the Anti-Scale valves are in operation now for three to four years without any need for refurbishment. The increased production by eliminating downtime has paid many times already for the investment in the valves. Copyright 2004 by ISA - The Instrumentation, Systems and Automation Society.

Title: Nuclear fuel cycle centres - An old and new idea
Source title: Proceedings of the 29th World Nuclear Association, WNA Annual Symposium 2004
Authors with affiliations: McCombie, C.; Chapman, N.
Abstract: In the 1950s, the IAEA charter itself allowed centralized plutonium storage and management. The fuel cycle was truly international during the 1960s and 1970s, with services such as uranium production and enrichment, fuel fabrication, reprocessing and reactor supply being carried out in a limited number of countries and sold to others. To restrict further weapons development, whilst allowing peaceful use of nuclear energy, the Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT) was conceived, including inspection rights in non weapons states. In addition to implementing multinational disposal projects, siting strategies and timescales, the international community could also support more specific, limited initiatives.
Index Keywords: Arsenals; Fuel storage; Nuclear reactors; Plutonium; Security systems; Uranium; Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT); Nuclear arsenals; Nuclear Fuel Cycle; Safe disposals; Nuclear fuels

Title: Global nuclear energy: A GE perspective
Source title: Proceedings of the 29th World Nuclear Association, WNA Annual Symposium 2004
Authors with affiliations: White, A.
Abstract: The emergence of nuclear energy as a future energy source all over the world is described. The US nuclear power generation has enjoyed a record decade since the early nineties, establishing record production levels in 2002, average industry capacity factors greater than 90% since 2000, generation costs down by 38%, and industry safety measures that have improved by over 65% since 1992. In China, the plans for an installed base of 35GW by 2020 are well publicized and Western industry interest in the potential of this market is high. Further underlining the Asian lead in the development of new nuclear plants, the 31 nuclear plants are being built globally, with 58% of them being in Asia.
Index Keywords: Electric power utilization; Gas emissions; Laws and legislation; Nuclear industry; Nuclear power plants; Nuclear reactor licensing; China; Global nuclear energy; Spent fuel storage; US; Nuclear energy

Title: A feedback controlled carbon nanotube based NEMS device: Concept and modeling
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Electronic and Photonic Packaging, EPP
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60208-3111, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ke, C., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60208-3111, United States; Espinosa, H.D., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60208-3111, United States
Abstract: A switchable carbon nanotube based nano-electromechanical systems (NEMS) device with close-loop feedback is examined. The device is made of a conductive multi-walled carbon nanotube (MWNT) placed as a cantilever over a micro-fabricated step. A bottom electrode, power supply and a resistor are also parts of the device circuit. The pull-in/pull-out and tunneling characteristics of the device are investigated by means of an electro-mechanical analysis. The model includes the concentration of electrical charge, at the end of the nanocantilever, and the van der Waals force. Finite kinematics accounting for large deformations of the cantilever is also included in the modeling. The result shows that the device has two well-defined stable equilibrium positions as a result of the tunneling and the incorporation of a feedback resistor to the circuit. The potential applications of the device include NEMS switches, random-access memory (RAM) elements, logic devices and electron-counters. Copyright © 2004 by ASME.

Title: Revolution in the distribution (use of the technology power line communication in the transmission of data, voice and images)
Source title: 2004 IEEE/PES Transmission and Distribution Conference and Exposition: Latin America
Affiliations: AES Eletropaulo, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Pimentel, P.R.S., AES Eletropaulo, Brazil; Baldissin, A., AES Eletropaulo, Brazil; César, L.S., AES Eletropaulo, Brazil; Framil, R.R., AES Eletropaulo, Brazil; Pascalicch, A., AES Eletropaulo, Brazil
Abstract: Technology development caused a real revolution inside the Electric Power Distribution industry. The significant news came from the solution knows as Power Line Communication (PLC) or Broadband Over Power Line Communication (BPL) as solution for data, voice and images transmission transported by the electric grid. This new technology which is already in Brazil in several commercial trials, will uprising all services from electric power distribution companies thanks to a data transmission that will allow services, such as remote reader, automated motorized switches in medium tension, connection and reconnection services, grid supervision, load management, halt frauds, etc. Also this technology permit services as high speed Ethernet, digital telephony, videoconference and video surveillance, and residential automation, adding value to the infrastructure electric grid. In this way one of the most attractive business will be the additional revenue that came from multimedia services, which will produce resources to build up the own distribution companies services. This paper will address to the technology status, will present several business trials geared by AES Eletropaulo in your electric grid and its results as well as its regulatory framework in Brazil. © 2004 IEEE.

Title: Automatic restoration system
Source title: 2004 IEEE/PES Transmission and Distribution Conference and Exposition: Latin America
Affiliations: S and C Electric do Brasil
Authors with affiliations: Ohara, A.T., S and C Electric do Brasil; Takiguchi, C.S., S and C Electric do Brasil
Abstract: The reduce of the DEC (Equivalent Duration for Set of consumers) and the FEC Frequency Equivalent for Set of Consumers) index is a requesting of ANEEL (National Agency of Electrical Energy) that are making the brazillian utilities look for new automation technologies in distribution system, which help them to make their system more reliable without the need to reserve or route the additional capacity. This article will describe an automatic restoration system, with peer-to-peer communication and distributed intelligence, which dinamically tracks the system conditions (phase currents and voltages) and quickly restore unfalted circuits. In radial and open loop circuits using switches or sectionalizers alone, customer downstream of a fault are left without power. Using controls with local intelligence in each point of switching and the peer-to-peer communication between these controls, the system can determine the location of the fault, which alternate circuit will handle this load and which switches should operate. The automatic restoration system acts locally before breakers and reclosers lock out, and require no central monitoring or control. During storms or major system events, this system keeps as many customers in service as possible, freeing personnel to deal with other problems while minimizing Customer Minutes Outages © 2004 IEEE.

Authors: Chhabra J., Kushalnagar N., Metzler B., Sampson A.
Title: Demo abstract: Sensor networks in intel fabrication plants
Source title: SenSys'04 - Proceedings of the Second International Conference on Embedded Networked Sensor Systems
Affiliations: Intel Research and Development, 2111, NE 25th Avenue, Hillsboro, OR, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chhabra, J., Intel Research and Development, 2111, NE 25th Avenue, Hillsboro, OR, United States; Kushalnagar, N., Intel Research and Development, 2111, NE 25th Avenue, Hillsboro, OR, United States; Metzler, B., Intel Research and Development, 2111, NE 25th Avenue, Hillsboro, OR, United States; Sampson, A., Intel Research and Development, 2111, NE 25th Avenue, Hillsboro, OR, United States
Abstract: The deployment of large-scale sensor networks in industrial environments presents technical challenges in achieving ease of deployment, flexibility in operation, and overall commercial viability. Sensor deployments are characterized by non-uniform placement of nodes, intermittent node connectivity, and the aggregation and reliable transfer of a large amount of data as networks scale to larger and larger sizes. Operation challenges include efficiently utilizing battery powered nodes, dynamically selecting sample periods and equipment clusters of interest, integrating with existing sensing and analysis infrastructure and easily correlating faults identified by the sensor network back to key factory operations and equipment. Commercial aspects involve returning value to the organization with hardened network nodes and reliable network operation that easily justifies the sensor network deployment and operating costs. We will demonstrate a sensor network in the ultra-pure water facility of an Intel fabrication plant, including details on the fab vibration application, the hardware nodes, and the heterogeneous wireless network. The fab vibration application uses vibration analysis to predict and correct equipment failures before fab operations are impacted. The ultra-pure water facility has a diversity of pumps and metal infrastructure both in a gymnasium size room and in an outside open air area that require 51 nodes with 201 vibration sensors. Data samples of 6K bytes are taken periodically from each vibration sensor, forwarded to a central server, measured for velocity, spike energy, acceleration, and displacement, analyzed with FFTs and trend analysis, and compared against expected profiles. When the analysis detects vibration variations outside of normal operating parameters, the affected equipment is scheduled for preventive maintenance, and repairs are made during normal down times. The hardware nodes for the fab vibration application include battery-powered motes (Figure 1(a)) and line-powered gateways. The motes are powered by four C Cell batteries, use a 900 MHz transceiver, and support an RPM (Reviolutions per Minute) sensor and up to six vibration sensors. The gateways contain both a 900 MHz transceiver and a 2.4 GHz transceiver running 802.11b to bridge the sensor radios to the 802.11 network. Both motes and access points use heavy metal housings and are hardened for industrial use. Motes and gateways self configure into a heterogeneous wireless network on power up. Motes form an ad hoc network and cluster to gateways. Gateways form an ad hoc 802.11b overlay network and provide high-capacity data transport allowing us to scale the network. One of the gateways is connected to the corporate network through Ethernet. The motes are cycled through planned sleep and wake periods to alternately conserve power and perform vibration data acquisitions. Motes send the data to the gateways where it is aggregated and ultimately forwarded to a server for analysis and storage. Our demonstration includes the display of actual vibration data with real time updates from an Intel fab, together with hands-on samples of gateways, motes, vibration sensors, and RPM sensors used in the deployment. Overview of the network topology and physical deployment is also shown along with the key network technologies developed and used to run the vibration application. We also discuss current learnings from the deployment and future work.
Author Keywords: Predictive maintenance; Sensor networks; Vibration analysis
Index Keywords: Fabrication; Pumps; Transceivers; Vibration measurement; Metal infrastructure; Sensor networks; Wireless networks; Sensors

Title: Power generation in Brazil and demands for water resources
Source title: 2004 IEEE/PES Transmission and Distribution Conference and Exposition: Latin America
Affiliations: Poli PEA, Sao Paulo University, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Monteiro, S.J., Poli PEA, Sao Paulo University, Brazil
Abstract: Water and energy are critical to the economy in development countries. In Brazil, a narrow band with the amount of electricity production and hydraulic projects become this strong relation still more. A remarkable driver, sustainability, makes new investments strategies in financial projects. This paper summarizes currents experiences and points the future ones for the water management in power systems. It also displays the challenges and restrictions of the environment regulation regarding water resources, exposing some of the policies to rule conflicts in water demands. © 2004 IEEE.

Title: Geographical information system for management and maintenance of substation equipments and subtransmission lines
Source title: 2004 IEEE/PES Transmission and Distribution Conference and Exposition: Latin America
Affiliations: Departamento de Engenharia de Energia e Automação Elétricas, University of São Paulo (USP/GAGTD), Brazil; Departamento de Engenharia de Energia e Automação Elétricas, Escola Politécnica, Universidade de São Paulo (USP/ GAGTD), Brazil; EPUSP, PEA, GAGTD - Grupo de Automacao da Geracao, Transmissao e Distribuicao de Energia, Brazil; EPUSP, PEA, GAGTD, Brazil; Eletropaulo Metropolitana, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Leal, A.G., Departamento de Engenharia de Energia e Automação Elétricas, University of São Paulo (USP/GAGTD), Brazil; Jardini, J.A., Departamento de Engenharia de Energia e Automação Elétricas, Escola Politécnica, Universidade de São Paulo (USP/ GAGTD), Brazil; Magrini, L.C., EPUSP, PEA, GAGTD - Grupo de Automacao da Geracao, Transmissao e Distribuicao de Energia, Brazil; Masuda, M., EPUSP, PEA, GAGTD, Brazil; Jardini, M.G.M., EPUSP, PEA, GAGTD, Brazil; Loureiro, P., EPUSP, PEA, GAGTD, Brazil; Fujimoto, F.T., Eletropaulo Metropolitana, Brazil
Abstract: The purpose of this article is to present the characteristics and results obtained from a data model development and implementation for georeferenced storage of equipments from substations and subtransmission lines, including their overhead and underground branches. This database will enable preventive, corrective, and emergency maintenance management of equipments, addressing operational and engineering departments' needs. In addition, it allows technical application integration, such as power flow and short-circuit calculations, and contingency analysis. In this project, applications were also developed to make inspections/ maintenance schedules available on hand-held computers. Created to fit every type of device, these schedules have to be filled and then transferred to the enterprise system. The system implemented, the pilot-project data survey methodology, the data modeling details, and some difficulties founded during this process are topics covered by this article too. © 2004 IEEE.

Title: Comparative evaluation of performance of a STATCOM and SSSC both integrated with SMES for controlling the power system frequency
Source title: 2004 IEEE/PES Transmission and Distribution Conference and Exposition: Latin America
Affiliations: CONICET, Institute de Energia Eléctrica, UNSJ, Av. L. G. San Martin 1109 (O), J5400ARL San Juan, Argentina
Authors with affiliations: Molina, M.G., CONICET, Institute de Energia Eléctrica, UNSJ, Av. L. G. San Martin 1109 (O), J5400ARL San Juan, Argentina; Mercado, P.E., CONICET, Institute de Energia Eléctrica, UNSJ, Av. L. G. San Martin 1109 (O), J5400ARL San Juan, Argentina
Abstract: Power systems security in case of contingencies is ensured by maintaining adequate "short-term generation reserve. This reserve must be appropriately activated by means of the primary frequency control (PFC). Nowadays, the new energy storage systems (ESS) are a feasible alternative to store exceeding energy for substituting the primary control reserve. In this way, it is feasible to combine this new ESS with power converter-based FACTS controllers. This allows an effective exchange of active power with the electric grid and thus enhancing the PFC. The current article presents the detailed models of power converter-based FACTS controllers with shunt and series connection to the utility system, i.e. Static Synchronous Compensators (STATCOMs) and Static Synchronous Series Compensators (SSSCs), both combined with SMES coils. Moreover, a three-level control scheme for these integrated systems is proposed and a comparative evaluation of performance of both controllers in the PFC is carried out. © 2004 IEEE.

Abstract: The present article aims at to study the viability of implantation of a solar water heating system in the Maternity School Assis Chateaubriand - MEAC -, one of the units of the Federal University of Ceará - UFC. With this, it is objectified to promote economy of electric energy and consequently of resources, allowing the best administration of the unit. The choice for the subject must the two factors mainly: first, the characteristic of the unit consumer, in which the water heating, destined to the bath of the babies, it is made from electric taps spread by diverse points of the construction; second, the characteristics of the state of the Ceará, which presents one high solar potential (insolation greater that 2,800 hours/year), available in every month, being worthless the climatic changes caused per the stations of the year. © 2004 IEEE.

Source title: AIChE Annual Meeting, Conference Proceedings

Abstract: The development of a model for hydrogen storage in carbon nanotubes was discussed. The molecular dynamics calculations were carried out for an armchair single-walled carbon nanotube (SWNT). The stabilization energy of a complex was calculated as a difference between the total energy of the complex and the sum of the energies of its constituent parts. The results show that a poisoning of SWNT by Co results in a total inactivation of the adsorption active sites, thus rendering the storage of hydrogen utterly unfeasible.

Title: The federal role in fuel-cell research and development
Source title: AIChE Annual Meeting, Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: National Science Foundation, Arlington, VA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Prentice, G., National Science Foundation, Arlington, VA, United States
Abstract: The role of federal government in recognizing the potential of fuel cells for widespread applications is discussed. Fuel cells have the potential to provide enviromentally-friendly sources of energy for transportation, portable, and stationary applications. The total federal support for fuel-cell development is to the order of $200 million per year, and much of this support is centered on PEM fuel cells with lesser amounts being devoted to DMFCs, SOFCs and other systems. The amount of funding allocate to hydrogen technology, with encompasses areas such as storage, production, and safety, is significantly higher.

Title: Rigorous modeling and experimental validation of mass, charge and energy transport in a DMFC polymer electrolyte membrane
Source title: AIChE Annual Meeting, Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Max Planck Institute Dynamics of Complex Technical Systems, Sandtorstrasse 1, 39106 Magdeburg, Germany; Process Systems Engineering, Otto-von-Guericke University Magdeburg, Universitätsplatz 2, 39106 Magdeburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schultz, T., Max Planck Institute Dynamics of Complex Technical Systems, Sandtorstrasse 1, 39106 Magdeburg, Germany; Sundmacher, K., Max Planck Institute Dynamics of Complex Technical Systems, Sandtorstrasse 1, 39106 Magdeburg, Germany, Process Systems Engineering, Otto-von-Guericke University Magdeburg, Universitätsplatz 2, 39106 Magdeburg, Germany
Abstract: The mass, charge and energy transport in a direct methanol fuel cell (DMFC) polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) was modeled and experimentally evaluated. DMFC has the advantage as a mobile source of electrical energy and its fuel - methanol is easy to store and handle. In the DMFC model, the supply channels and both catalysts layers are described as spatially concentrated volume elements, while both diffusion layers and the PEM are modeled as spatially distributed elements. The DMFC model analyzed yields good approximations to the experimental data with respect to mass transport for a variety of fuel cell operating conditions using only one single set of parameters.
Index Keywords: Catalysts; Fuel cells; Fuel storage; Methanol fuels; Parameter estimation; Polyelectrolytes; Polymeric membranes; Catalyst layers; Electrical energy; Polymer electrolyte membranes (PEM); Supply channels; Transport properties

Title: An energy landscape based mean-field theory for the thermal and mechanical behavior of confined amorphous materials
Source title: AIChE Annual Meeting, Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States; Department of Chemical Engineering, Institute for Theoretical Chemistry, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712, United States

Abstract: The use of an energy landscape based mean-field theory for the thermal and mechanical behavior of confined amorphous materials is discussed. One of the most pressing issues is that the density vibration and large surface-to-volume ratio characteristic of nanostructures can lead to thermodynamic, chemical, and mechanical limits of stability. The physical reasons for these differences are incompletely understood, which impacts negatively on the development of new materials and innovative processes for high resolution applications. Various ways to improve the approximations of the landscape based mean-field theory are also discussed.
Index Keywords: Cohesive forces; Mechanical dimensions; Molecular simulations; Nanoscale dimensions; Adhesives; Approximation theory; Computer simulation; Data storage equipment; Nanostructured materials; Optical resolving power; Optoelectronic devices; Protective coatings; Amorphous materials

Authors: Suppes G.J., White J.F., Yerrakondreddygari K.
Title: High pressure fuel processing in regenerative fuel cells
Source title: AIChE Annual Meeting, Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Missouri-Columbia, Columbia, MO 65203, United States
Authors with affiliations: Suppes, G.J., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Missouri-Columbia, Columbia, MO 65203, United States; White, J.F., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Missouri-Columbia, Columbia, MO 65203, United States; Yerrakondreddygari, K., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Missouri-Columbia, Columbia, MO 65203, United States
Abstract: Regenerative fuel cells are capable of operating in electrolysis or fuel cell modes. They can be used in applications much like batteries, only they weigh less and larger quantities of energy can be stored at relatively low costs through the use of large storage tanks. Whereas conventional fuel cells tend not to be as viable for operation at high pressures due to the costs and irreversibilites of compression of air to high pressures, regenerative fuel cells are capable of generating oxygen and hydrogen at the same pressure as the gas storage. Optimal operating parameters will typically mandate that fuel cell operation, electrolysis operation, and tank operation are all at the same pressure - the pressure will be the tank pressure and will depend upon the reserve of oxygen and hydrogen. Accordingly, the oxygen tank should be about one half the volume of the hydrogen tank so pressures remain the same as hydrogen/oxygen is consumed/generated. This paper reviews the use of regenerative PEM fuel cell technology in hybrid and electric vehicle applications.
Index Keywords: Fuel processing; Gas storage; Regenerative fuel cells; Stored hydrogen; Crude petroleum; Degrees of freedom (mechanics); Electric vehicles; Electrolysis; Oxygen; Sensitivity analysis; Fuel cells

Authors: Yamamoto A., Tatsumi M., Kitamura Y., Yamane Y.
Title: Improvement of the SPH method for multi-assembly calculations
Source title: Proceedings of the PHYSOR 2004: The Physics of Fuel Cycles and Advanced Nuclear Systems - Global Developments
Affiliations: Nagoya University, Furo-cho, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya, 464-8603, Japan; Nuclear Fuel Industries, Ltd., 950 Noda, Kumatori-cho, Osaka, 590-0481, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yamamoto, A., Nagoya University, Furo-cho, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya, 464-8603, Japan; Tatsumi, M., Nuclear Fuel Industries, Ltd., 950 Noda, Kumatori-cho, Osaka, 590-0481, Japan; Kitamura, Y., Nagoya University, Furo-cho, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya, 464-8603, Japan; Yamane, Y., Nagoya University, Furo-cho, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya, 464-8603, Japan
Abstract: In this paper, improvement of the SPH method (the improved SPH method) is proposed. The SPH method is commonly used in pin-by-pin mesh core calculations to reduce cell-homogenization error. The investigation revealed that the normalization condition of the SPH factor in the conventional SPH method is not appropriate for multi-assembly calculations in which different assembly types are adjacent. Since the conventional normalization condition does not incorporate flux discontinuity between assemblies, cell homogenization error in assembly peripheral region becomes larger. In the improved SPH method, the SPH factor is divided by an averaged "cell-level" discontinuity factor obtained in each fuel assembly. Though the SPH factor is somewhat changed from the conventional value, no additional homogenization parameters (e.g. discontinuity factor) is necessary in core calculations. Test calculations were carried out in a simplified one-dimensional slab and two-dimensional PWR colorset geometries. The calculation results showed that the improved SPH method effectively reduce the cell-level homogenization error especially in assembly peripheral region. Since we can easily implement the improved SPH method by slight code modifications, it can be a promising candidate of the cell-homogenization method for pin-by-pin core calculations.
Author Keywords: Generalized equivalence theory; Multi-assembly calculation; Pin-by-pin core calculation; SCOPE2; SPH factor; SPH method
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Data storage equipment; Magnetic flux; Mathematical models; Neutrons; Nuclear fuels; Parameter estimation; Generalized equivalence theory; Multi-assembly calculations; Pin-by-pin core calculation; SCOPE2; SPH factor; SPH methods; Nuclear energy

Title: Molecular modeling of hydrogen storage in carbon nanotubes: A combined molecular dynamics/ab initio orbital study
Source title: AIChE Annual Meeting, Conference Proceedings

Authors with affiliations: Pricl, S., Computer-aided System Laboratory - MO.S:E., Department of Chemical, Environmental and Raw Materials Engineering, University of Trieste, Piazzale Europa 1, 34127 Trieste, Italy; Coslanich, A., Computer-aided System Laboratory - MO.S:E., Department of Chemical, Environmental and Raw Materials Engineering, University of Trieste, Piazzale Europa 1, 34127 Trieste, Italy; Fermeglia, M., Computer-aided System Laboratory - MO.S:E., Department of Chemical, Environmental and Raw Materials Engineering, University of Trieste, Piazzale Europa 1, 34127 Trieste, Italy; Ferrone, M., Computer-aided System Laboratory - MO.S:E., Department of Chemical, Environmental and Raw Materials Engineering, University of Trieste, Piazzale Europa 1, 34127 Trieste, Italy; Paneni, M.S., Computer-aided System Laboratory - MO.S:E., Department of Chemical, Environmental and Raw Materials Engineering, University of Trieste, Piazzale Europa 1, 34127 Trieste, Italy; Romanel, F., Computer-aided System Laboratory - MO.S:E., Department of Chemical, Environmental and Raw Materials Engineering, University of Trieste, Piazzale Europa 1, 34127 Trieste, Italy
Abstract: Interest in hydrogen as an environmentally clean fuel has recently grown significantly in view of decreasing fossil fuel supply. One of the main proposed applications of hydrogen is its use as ecologically clean fuel in transportation. The results obtained from the application of both density functional theory-based and atomistic molecular dynamic simulations were presented to the study of chemi- and physisorption of hydrogen by single-walled carbon nanotube (SWNT), and of the effect exerted by the presence of CO, a well-known poison for fuel cell. The small number of H2 molecules sucked into the nanotube stays inside, and are organized in concentric rings, as are those outside the carbon tube. At 298 K, the rings are destroyed, the attractive energy of nonbonding interactions being too small to counteract the destruction caused by thermal vibration and diffusion. The potential energy of the SWNT/CO system is much lower than that of the corresponding hydrogenated system, indicating the stronger affinity of CO for the carbon tube. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the AIChE Annual Meeting (Austin, TX 11/7-12/2004).

Abstract: Results of tests of a nanosecond modulator with a peak output power of 3 GW at a 75-Ohm load are reported. The modulator has been designed for HPM applications. It comprises a type S-5N charging driver and a power compressor based on a pulsed forming line and a gas spark gap. © 2004 IEEE.

Title: Impulse electromagnetic interference generator

Abstract: Electromagnetic interference (EMI) related malfunctioning of equipment containing electronic control devices has become a serious problem these days, as it couples to wires and PCB's in the equipment, reflecting and resonating and then being amplified by an IC finally resulting in malfunction. In order to test and simulate the immunity of electronic circuits to an EMI environment, an Electrical Fast Transient/Burst generator has been developed which generates broadband interference spectrum in the range of 20MHz to 600MHz. The Burst Generator is mainly comprised of coaxial cables, pressurized spark gaps, a HV Power Supply, a terminating resistor and a TEM Horn which acts as load. For pulse sharpening, switching has been done at two stages. Depending upon the delay time of coaxial line, the width of the square wave pulse has been kept at 50ns. The total energy of the portable system is 34 Joules, and it weighs less than 50kg. In the presented paper we describe the system design, results of measurements and areas of further improvements in energy transfer efficiency. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Bandwidth; Electric fields; Electromagnetic waves; Electron beams; Energy storage; Energy transfer; Oscillographs; Signal interference; Switching; Bipolar pulser; Blumlein pulser; Electromagnetic interference generators; Electronic control devices; Spark gap capacitance; Electric generators

Authors: Lehr J.M., Bloomquist D.D., Corley J.P., Drennan S.A., Guthrie D.W., Harjes H.C., Hodge K.C., Johnson D.L., Maenchen J.E., McDaniel D.H., Struve K.W.
Title: SATPro: The system assessment test program for ZR
Source title: Conference Record of the International Power Modulator Symposium and High Voltage Workshop
Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, MS 1193, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Ktech Corp., Albuquerque, NM, United States; Titan Pulse Sciences Division, San Leandro, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lehr, J.M., Sandia National Laboratories, MS 1193, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Bloomquist, D.D., Sandia National Laboratories, MS 1193, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Corley, J.P., Sandia National Laboratories, MS 1193, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM, United States, Ktech Corp., Albuquerque, NM, United States; Drennan, S.A., Sandia National Laboratories, MS 1193, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM, United States, Ktech Corp., Albuquerque, NM, United States; Guthrie, D.W., Sandia National Laboratories, MS 1193, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM, United States, Ktech Corp., Albuquerque, NM, United States; Harjes, H.C., Sandia National Laboratories, MS 1193, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Hodge, K.C., Sandia National Laboratories, MS 1193, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM, United States, Ktech Corp., Albuquerque, NM, United States; Johnson, D.L., Sandia National Laboratories, MS 1193, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM, United States, Titan Pulse Sciences Division, San Leandro, CA, United States; Maenchen, J.E., Sandia National Laboratories, MS 1193, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM, United States; McDaniel, D.H., Sandia National Laboratories, MS 1193, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Struve, K.W., Sandia National Laboratories, MS 1193, PO Box 5800, Albuquerque, NM, United States
Abstract: In the mid-90's, breakthroughs were achieved at Sandia with z-pinches for high energy density physics on the Saturn machine. These initial tests led to the modification of the PBFA II machine to provide high currents rather than the high voltage it was initially designed for. The success of z-pinch for high energy density physics experiments insured a new mission for the converted accelerator, known as Z since 1997. Z now provides a unique capability to a number of basic science communities and has expanded its mission to include radiation effects research, inertial confinement fusion and material properties research. To achieve continued success, the physics community has requested higher peak current, better precision and pulse shaping versatility be incorporated into the refurbishment of the Z machine, known as ZR. In addition to the performance specification for ZR of a peak current of 26 MA with an implosion time of 100 ns, the machine also has a reliability specification to achieve 400 shots per year. While changes to the basic architecture of the Z machine are minor, the vast majority of its components have been redesigned. Moreover the increase in peak current from its present 18 MA to ZR's peak current of 26 MA at nominal operating parameters requires significantly higher voltages. These higher voltages, along with the reliability requirement, mandate a system assessment be performed to insure the requirements have been met. This paper will describe the System Assessment Test Program (SATPro) for the ZR project and report on the results. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Energy density; Peak load current; System assessment tests; Z-pinches; Data acquisition; Differentiating circuits; Electric generators; Electric power measurement; Energy storage; Fusion reactions; Particle accelerators; Particle beams; Pulse shaping circuits; Radiation effects; High energy physics

Authors: LeChien K.R., Gahi J.M., Kemp M.A., Benwell A.L., Elizondo-Decanini J.M., Struve K.W.
Title: Initial results from the University of Missouri Terawatt Test Stand
Source title: Conference Record of the International Power Modulator Symposium and High Voltage Workshop
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Missouri-Columbia, 349 Engineering Building West, Columbia, MO 65211, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, United States
Authors with affiliations: LeChien, K.R., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Missouri-Columbia, 349 Engineering Building West, Columbia, MO 65211, United States; Gahi, J.M., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Missouri-Columbia, 349 Engineering Building West, Columbia, MO 65211, United States; Kemp, M.A., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Missouri-Columbia, 349 Engineering Building West, Columbia, MO 65211, United States; Benwell, A.L., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Missouri-Columbia, 349 Engineering Building West, Columbia, MO 65211, United States; Elizondo-Decanini, J.M., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, United States; Struve, K.W., Sandia National Laboratories, Albuquerque, NM, United States
Abstract: The University of Missouri Terawatt Test Stand (MUTTS) is fitted with a 2.7 MV multichanneling laser triggered gas switch scaled from a 4 MV switch developed at Sandia National Laboratories. The long term goals of the research at MUTTS are to improve the multichanneling reliability and jitter of the switch when the electrode rings in the cascade section are either increased in number or in diameter. Multichanneling is important for two main reasons: 1) a reduction of electrode wear and 2) reduced inductance. The test facility provides a high voltage/high current test bed for a number of experiments that are easily scalable to large accelerators, such that, we expect the results to be directly applicable to the requirements of the Z and ZR accelerators. The first series of shots at MUTTS included dummy load and open load configurations to determine parasitic circuit elements. Diagnostics include monitoring the load current and Marx total current, voltage at the Marx output, load, and Marx trigger unit. Equivalent series resistance, series inductance, Marx capacitance, and shunt resistance were determined from these diagnostics. This is used to develop a first order circuit model of the energy storage section by comparison to experimental data. Characteristics of the scaled switch and initial pulsed power tests at the facility are presented. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Circuit elements; Electrode rings; Laser triggered gas switches; University of Missouri Terawatt Test Stand (MUTTS); Capacitance; Cascade control systems; Electric coils; Electric network analysis; Electric switches; Electrochemical electrodes; Electron ring accelerators; Energy storage; Laser applications; Magnetic fields; Gas sensing electrodes

Title: Li Ion technology for pulse power applications
Source title: Conference Record of the International Power Modulator Symposium and High Voltage Workshop
Affiliations: SAFT America, Cockeysville, MD 21030, United States
Authors with affiliations: Matty, T., SAFT America, Cockeysville, MD 21030, United States; Nechev, K., SAFT America, Cockeysville, MD 21030, United States
Abstract: Li Ion is a relatively new energy storage technology that has been developed and commercialized within the past 15 years for many products especially portable power. More recently further development has been undertaken to explore the high power capability of this technology. The results indicate that advanced products can provide very high power capability in excess of 12kW/kg. Rapid advances are also occurring to further improve this capability in anticipation of needs for Compact High Power Sources to power Lasers, DE and other advanced applications. With this new capability alternative direct drive concepts are now being developed to reduce system complexity, cost, size and weight. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Charge balance; Compact high power sources; Pulsed power sources; Unmanned aircraft; Aircraft; Electric charge; Electric impedance; Electric power systems; Energy storage; High power lasers; Lithium; Microwaves; Military vehicles; Ions

Title: The injection bumper system for LEIR
Source title: Conference Record of the International Power Modulator Symposium and High Voltage Workshop
Affiliations: AB Department, CERN, CH-1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Fowler, A., AB Department, CERN, CH-1211 Geneva 23, Switzerland
Abstract: To satisfy the ion beam luminosity requirements for CERN's future Large Hadron Collider (LHC), a small accumulator, the Low Energy Ion Ring (LEIR), is being built in the injector chain of accelerators. LEIR will use a combined longitudinal and transverse multi-turn injection scheme that requires a bumper system comprising four individually pulsed dipole magnets. The paper discusses the bumper system, in particular the power supplies that will produce a pulsed current linearly decreasing from 1.2 kA to zero in a time variable between 120 μs and 300 μs. Each power supply employs a primary discharge circuit, comprising a storage capacitor, an IGBT switch and the magnet load inductance, to establish the peak current, and a freewheel circuit in parallel with the magnet, comprising a diode and capacitor, to produce the linear current slope. A novel feature of the circuit is the use of a variable bias voltage on the freewheel capacitor, allowing continuous variation of the slope duration. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Diodes; Electric currents; Electric discharges; Electric power systems; Flywheels; Insulated gate bipolar transistors; Magnetic fields; Magnets; Large hadron colliders (LHC); Lower energy ion ring (LEIR); Pulsed currents; Pulsed dipole magnets; Colliding beam accelerators

Title: Flywheel charging module for energy storage used in high-voltage pulsed and multi-mode mobility hybrid electric military vehicle power system
Source title: Conference Record of the International Power Modulator Symposium and High Voltage Workshop
Affiliations: Optimal Energy Systems, Inc., 2560 West 237th Street, Torrance, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Swett, D.W., Optimal Energy Systems, Inc., 2560 West 237th Street, Torrance, CA, United States; Blanche IV, J.G., Optimal Energy Systems, Inc., 2560 West 237th Street, Torrance, CA, United States
Abstract: Optimal Energy Systems is currently designing and manufacturing flywheel-based energy storage systems that are being used to provide pulses of energy for charging high-voltage capacitors in a mobile military system. These systems receive their energy from low-voltage vehicle bus power (28 VDC) and provide output power at over 10,000 VDC without the need for DC-DC voltage conversion electronics. This energy conversion is accomplished through the use of OES-patented ultra-high-speed flywheel power module (FPoM) technology. In this paper, recent test data is presented for a prototype FPoM high-voltage capacitor charging source. Adaptation of the technology to energy storage for conceptual multi-mode mobility functions in a military vehicle design with electric propulsion and advanced electrical loads is described. Physical system design parameters are summarized for both the prototype FPoM hardware and conceptual hybrid electric vehicle application. Transient PSPICE electrical analyses and MSC/Nastran finite element analyses characterize operation and response in a conceptual high-rate pulsed power and multi-mode energy storage environment involving (i) regenerative braking, (ii) power peak leveling, and (iii) high-voltage capacitor charging. © 2004 IEEE.
