Title: Pulsed power electromechanics - Permanent magnets versus copper coils
Source title: Conference Record of the International Power Modulator Symposium and High Voltage Workshop
Affiliations: Center for Electromechanics, EME 133, 10100 Burnet Rd., Austin, TX, 78758, United States
Authors with affiliations: Davey, K., Center for Electromechanics, EME 133, 10100 Burnet Rd., Austin, TX, 78758, United States; Hebner, R.E., Center for Electromechanics, EME 133, 10100 Burnet Rd., Austin, TX, 78758, United States
Abstract: A number of emerging military systems operate using short, repetitive, high-power pulses. Rotating electromechanical machines incorporating inertial storage are natural candidates for supplying these high power pulses. The short duty cycle characteristic of these devices introduces an interesting physics trade off in the choice of field excitation. A quantitative comparison of permanent magnet machines to copper coil systems is performed on an equal weigh basis. The results indicate that copper coil based systems using exciters are superior to permanent magnet counterparts in pulsed applications of 20 s and less. The recommended use of copper coils becomes stronger when the issues of magnet life due to vibration, thermal cycling, and slot harmonic heating are considered. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Axial flow turbomachinery; Capacitors; Electric coils; Electric conductivity; Electric generators; Electric heating elements; Laser pulses; Magnetic fields; Permanent magnets; Thermal cycling; Axial flux generators; Field excitations; Magnetic energy; Rotary submarine launchers; Electromechanical devices

Authors: Dahlerup-Petersen K., Coelingh G.J., Kusnetsov N., Kazmin B., Vassilevski A., Kuper E., Medvedko A., Ovchar V.
Title: The CERN/LHC energy extraction switches and their arc detector system
Source title: Conference Record of the International Power Modulator Symposium and High Voltage Workshop
Affiliations: Accelerator Technology Department, CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; J.S.C. Uralelektrotyazhmash (UETM), Yekaterinburg, Russian Federation; Institute for High Energy Physics (IHEP), Protvino, Russian Federation; Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics (BINP), Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Dahlerup-Petersen, K., Accelerator Technology Department, CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Coelingh, G.J., Accelerator Technology Department, CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Kusnetsov, N., J.S.C. Uralelektrotyazhmash (UETM), Yekaterinburg, Russian Federation; Kazmin, B., Institute for High Energy Physics (IHEP), Protvino, Russian Federation; Vassilevski, A., Institute for High Energy Physics (IHEP), Protvino, Russian Federation; Kuper, E., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics (BINP), Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Medvedko, A., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics (BINP), Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Ovchar, V., Budker Institute of Nuclear Physics (BINP), Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: To extract the large amount of energy stored in the magnetic field of the LHC superconducting dipoles (8 chains with 1350 MJ each) and quadrupoles (16 chains with about 24 MJ each), opening switches will be used. The switches consist of an array of electro-mechanical D.C. breakers, specifically designed for this particular application. The opening process transfers the magnet excitation current from the array of eight breakers to the extraction resistors, rapidly de-exciting the magnet chain. The arcing behavior in breakers of the array has been studied. In order to facilitate the maintenance of the switches an arc detector has been developed. This paper describes the design of the extraction switches and presents the test results, obtained at the LHC pilot extraction facility. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Colliding beam accelerators; Electric arcs; Electric conductivity; Electric energy storage; Electric potential; Electromechanical devices; Networks (circuits); Resistors; Superconducting magnets; Energy extraction resistors; Magnetic chains; Quadrupole circuits; Superconducting dipoles; Electric switches

Authors: Ennis J., Yang X.H., MacDougall F., Seal K., Herbig J.
Title: High energy density capacitor characterization
Source title: Conference Record of the International Power Modulator Symposium and High Voltage Workshop
Affiliations: General Atomics Energy Products, General Atomics Electronic Systems, Inc., 4949 Greencraig Lane, San Diego, CA 92123-1675, United States; United Defense LP, Advanced Armament Systems, 4800 East River Road, Minneapolis, MN 55421, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ennis, J., General Atomics Energy Products, General Atomics Electronic Systems, Inc., 4949 Greencraig Lane, San Diego, CA 92123-1675, United States; Yang, X.H., General Atomics Energy Products, General Atomics Electronic Systems, Inc., 4949 Greencraig Lane, San Diego, CA 92123-1675, United States; MacDougall, F., General Atomics Energy Products, General Atomics Electronic Systems, Inc., 4949 Greencraig Lane, San Diego, CA 92123-1675, United States; Seal, K., General Atomics Energy Products, General Atomics Electronic Systems, Inc., 4949 Greencraig Lane, San Diego, CA 92123-1675, United States; Herbig, J., United Defense LP, Advanced Armament Systems, 4800 East River Road, Minneapolis, MN 55421, United States
Abstract: This paper will describe how film capacitors with energy densities of greater than 1 J/cc and suitable for millisecond discharge applications requiring limited life have been characterized. A variety of polymer films were tested in "model" capacitors storing and delivering hundreds of Joules of energy at voltages of 2-10 kV. Self-healing metallized film electrodes were utilized in these designs to achieve electric fields greater than 500 MV/m. Maximum operating voltage for short-term and long-term use was determined. Life tests were then performed with the goal of achieving at least 1000 charge/discharge cycles at maximum energy density. Degradation and failure of the capacitor samples was determined by measurements of capacitance and dissipation factor. Failure modes in continuous dc, normal charge/discharge pulse service, and short-circuit fault conditions were determined. Design modifications to increase life and energy density were made based on those analyses. Scale-up of the individual unit energy to 100 kJ is underway. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Capacitor characterization; Energy density; Polymer films; Voltage gradients; Capacitance; Dielectric films; Electric discharges; Electric potential; Electrochemical electrodes; Energy storage; Permittivity; Capacitors

Title: Critical component requirements for compact pulse power system architectures
Source title: Conference Record of the International Power Modulator Symposium and High Voltage Workshop
Affiliations: University of Missouri - Columbia, 303 Engr. Bldg. West, Columbia, MO 65211, United States; Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nunnally, W.C., University of Missouri - Columbia, 303 Engr. Bldg. West, Columbia, MO 65211, United States, Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, United States
Abstract: This paper discusses the architectures that can be employed in compact pulse power systems with the goal of identifying the critical components and parameters. Two design examples of compact, stacked Blumlein line pulse power systems are presented and the switch and storage parameters developed. The critical issues are determined in the context of these system designs to give guidance for future research and development activities. This paper also describes the investigation of applying high dielectric strength materials when employed in very thin sections in energy storage systems. These system design examples are compared with conventional approaches for pulse power systems and compact power conditioning systems goals. Finally, candidate switch technologies and energy storage technologies that have the potential to meet the compact pulse power system requirements are presented with future research and development requirements. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Capacitor volume; Charge voltage; Dielectric strength materials; Pulse power systems; Electric arcs; Electric conductivity; Electric impedance; Electric potential; Energy storage; Permittivity; Switching circuits; Electric power systems

Authors: Peterkin F.E., Anderson I.S., McQuage M.M., Pasour J.A.
Title: Versatile test environment for compact pulsed power system evaluation
Source title: Conference Record of the International Power Modulator Symposium and High Voltage Workshop
Affiliations: Directed Energy Technology Office, Dahlgren Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Dahlgren, VA 22448, United States; Envisioneering Inc., Dahlgren, VA 22485, United States; Mission Research Corp., Newington, VA 22122, United States
Authors with affiliations: Peterkin, F.E., Directed Energy Technology Office, Dahlgren Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Dahlgren, VA 22448, United States; Anderson, I.S., Directed Energy Technology Office, Dahlgren Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Dahlgren, VA 22448, United States; McQuage, M.M., Directed Energy Technology Office, Dahlgren Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Dahlgren, VA 22448, United States, Envisioneering Inc., Dahlgren, VA 22485, United States; Pasour, J.A., Directed Energy Technology Office, Dahlgren Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center, Dahlgren, VA 22448, United States, Mission Research Corp., Newington, VA 22122, United States
Abstract: This paper describes our efforts to develop a test environment that accurately approximates elements of several battery-driven Compact Marx Generator (CMG) systems currently in use, but which avoids the high-voltage and Electromagnetic Interference (EMI) issues of operating the actual CMG's. A triggering circuit, lumped capacitance, and load resistor housed in a cart filled with SF6 provide the necessary elements to represent the CMG. Two 20 kW AC-DC supplies were used to substitute for battery packs and furnished the medium voltage (hundreds of volts) required to drive the high voltage (HV) capacitor charging power supplies (CCPS). The prime motivation of this work is to explore rep-rate operation at tens of Hz and provide guidance for optimizing HV power supply settings and battery design. The test stand provides a unique testing environment for several applications. We report verification of the test bed operation using a well understood configuration of power supplies with well documented control and trigger systems. The performance of a series/parallel combination of multiple HV power supplies for rep. rate operation is also examined. Battery pack voltage droop effects on HV power supply calibration are described. We then discuss use of the test bed to explore the operating characteristics of a novel 100 kV (+/- 50 kV) capacitor charging power supply recently developed by North Star Research, Corp. (NSRC). © 2004 IEEE.

Title: A compact former of high-power bipolar subnanosecond pulses
Source title: Conference Record of the International Power Modulator Symposium and High Voltage Workshop
Affiliations: Propulsion Physics Laboratory, Soreq NRC, Yavne, 81800, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Yankelevich, Y., Propulsion Physics Laboratory, Soreq NRC, Yavne, 81800, Israel; Pokryvailo, A., Propulsion Physics Laboratory, Soreq NRC, Yavne, 81800, Israel
Abstract: The system comprises a nanosecond SOS-generator (see, e.g.,[1]) or the RADAN SEF-303 pulsed power source (see, e.g.,[2]) that charges resonantly a short pulse-forming line (PFL) through a decoupling inductor, a peaking SG, an active converter, a matched load and several built-in voltage and current probes. The active converter comprises two SGs (chopper and peaker), an additional Ins PFL and a secondary decoupling inductor for resonant charging of the second PFL. The peaking SG and active converter are set in one body and operate in N2 at pressure up to 6MPa. Weighing less than 10kg, the converter generates bipolar subnanosecond pulses having peak-to-peak amplitude up to 270kV on a 46.6Ω load at operation with Radan. The pulsewidth of each half wave of bipolar pulses on FWHM is 280ps at the rise time of the first half wave of about 160ps. The SGs' gaps can be regulated without system depressurizing (a technique adopted from [3]). Circuit analysis accounting for the distributed character of the components and numerous parasitic parameters is presented. Voltage measurement means, including several capacitive dividers, Rogowski coils, attenuators and connection cables, were time-domain calibrated using ultrafast high voltage solid-state pulsers. Waveforms probed at different locations of the pulser systems, from the SOS-generator and from the Radan to the load, are presented. The bipolar subnanosecond pulses had very stable rise, while the fall jitter was around 50ps. The experimental results are in fair agreement with the simulation. Pulsers were tested with a TEM horn antenna. An effective potential of about 900kV was obtained. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Bipolar integrated circuits; Electric attenuators; Electric coils; Electric converters; Electric inductors; Electric network analysis; Energy storage; Stresses; Switching; Bipolar subnanosecond pulses; Energy density; Power switching; Rogowski coils; Pulse generators

Title: Annual fluxes of energy and CO2 over a residential area in Tokyo
Source title: 5th Symposium on the Urban Environment
Affiliations: Tokyo Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan; Tokyo Institute of Technology, Dept. of Civil Engineering, 2-12-1 O-okayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo 152-8552, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Moriwaki, R., Tokyo Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan, Tokyo Institute of Technology, Dept. of Civil Engineering, 2-12-1 O-okayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo 152-8552, Japan; Kanda, M., Tokyo Institute of Technology, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The diurnal, seasonal, and annual fluxes of the energy and CO2 for a suburban surface in Tokyo were analyzed. The contributions of various surfaces such as garden trees, artificial materials, traffic, human activities and human exhalations to the meteorologically measured latent heat and CO 2 fluxes were studied. It was found that the CO2 flux was more than twice as large than in winter as it is in summer. The results show that the total of net radiation (Rn) is 2.36 GJ m-2 and the ratio of net radiation to solar radiation (Rn/S) is 0.50.

Box 2009, Oak Ridge, TN 37831-8206, United States; Jackson, A.J., BWXT Y-12, L.L.C, P. O. Box 2009, Oak Ridge, TN 37831-8233, United States; Nations, J.O., Oak Ridge National Laboratory, P. O. Box 2008, Oak Ridge, TN 37831-6050, United States; Wall, D.L., National Nuclear Security Administration, Y-12 Site Office, P. O. Box 2009, Oak Ridge, TN 37831-8009, United States; Whitaker, J.M., Oak Ridge National Laboratory, P. O. Box 2008, Oak Ridge, TN 37831-8050, United States
Abstract: The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) has been implementing international safeguards at the Oak Ridge Y-12 National Security Complex since September 1994. The inventory of highly enriched uranium, declared excess to U.S. defense needs, has remained static over the entire time period, but the application of safeguards has continually evolved. All of the original IAEA safeguards equipment and software has been replaced or upgraded. Containment and surveillance equipment installed by the IAEA has been replaced over time. New personnel representing both the IAEA and the facility have rotated through the program. Material handling procedures at the facility have been periodically reviewed and tweaked as necessary. Health, safety, and security requirements have continually been strengthened, especially in light of the events surrounding the World Trade Center disaster of September 2001. The performance of a remote monitoring field trial required a minor configuration change to the storage area itself. Site needs to utilize a portion of the original facility for other purposes resulted in a redefinition of the facility. The inspection notification process has continually been enhanced to improve timeliness. In summary, over the course of over 100 inspections conducted during the last 10 years, nearly every aspect of the inspection process has changed to some degree with one exception - the material itself.
Index Keywords: Inspection process; Nuclear materials; Safeguard equipment; Security requirements; Computer software; Inspection; Nuclear energy; Nuclear materials safeguards; Security systems; Uranium; Nuclear power plants

Authors: Bartlett W.D., Clark G.M., Konzek G.R., McRae L.P., Smith B.W.
Title: Iaea safeguards during plutonium stabilization at hanford's plutonium finishing plant
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th International Conference on Facility Operations: Safeguards Interface
Affiliations: Fluor Hanford Inc., United States; Fluor Government Group, United States; U.S. DOE Richland Operations Office, United States; Protection Technology Hanford, United States; Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bartlett, W.D., Fluor Hanford Inc., United States; Clark, G.M., Fluor Government Group, United States; Konzek, G.R., U.S. DOE Richland Operations Office, United States; McRae, L.P., Protection Technology Hanford, United States; Smith, B.W., Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, United States
Abstract: The Vault at the Plutonium Finishing Plan (PFP) became subject to the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safeguards beginning in 1994 as part of the U.S. excess fissile material program. The inventory needed to be stabilized and repackaged for long-term storage to comply with Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board Recommendation 94-1. In 1998, the United States began negotiations with IAEA to develop methods to maintain safeguards as this material was stabilized and repackaged. The Design Information Questionnaire was revised and submitted to the IAEA in 2002 describing how PFP would be modified to accommodate the stabilization process line. The operation plan for 2003 was submitted describing the proposed schedules for removing materials for stabilization. Stabilization and repackaging activities for the safeguarded plutonium began in January 2003 and were completed in December 2003. The safeguards approach implemented at the Hanford Site was a combination of the original baseline approach augmented by a series of five vault additions of stabilized materials followed by five removals of unstabilized materials. IAEA containment and surveillance measures were maintained until the unstabilized material was removed. Following placement of repackaged material (most from the original safeguarded stock) into the storage vault, the IAEA conducted inventory change verification measurements and then established containment and surveillance. As part of the stabilization campaign, the IAEA developed new measurement methods and calibration standards representative of the materials and packaging. The annual physical inventory verification was conducted on the normal IAEA schedule following the fourth additional/removal phase. Plant activities and the impacts on operations are described.
Author Keywords: Hanford; IAEA Safeguards; Plutonium; Stabilization
Index Keywords: Fissile materials; Plutonium finishing plan (PFP); Safeguard stocks; Stabilized materials; Calibration; Inspection; Inventory control; Nuclear energy; Nuclear materials safeguards; Plutonium; Scheduling; Nuclear power plants

Authors: Winzek B., Schmitz S., Vitushinsky R.
Title: Shape memory actuators in mobile robots for planetary surface exploration
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: Center of Advanced European Studies and Research (Caesar), Ludwig-Erhard-Allee 2, 53175 Bonn, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Winzek, B., Center of Advanced European Studies and Research (Caesar), Ludwig-Erhard-Allee 2, 53175 Bonn, Germany; Schmitz, S., Center of Advanced European Studies and Research (Caesar), Ludwig-Erhard-Allee 2, 53175 Bonn, Germany; Vitushinsky, R., Center of Advanced European Studies and Research (Caesar), Ludwig-Erhard-Allee 2, 53175 Bonn, Germany
Abstract: Shape memory alloy (SMA) actuators are able to transform thermal energy to mechanical energy. Since on several planets, the surface temperature changes drastically by the daily cycle of the sun, there is a huge amount of energy which can be used by robots without the necessity of large electronic energy storage systems. Driven by the daily temperature change of the atmosphere, spider-like robots can be realized with SMA composites as active joints and wheeled robots can be realized with SMA actuators that transfer their wave-like motion to the wheels by means of crankshafts. Different autonomous tools can be realized by SMA composites. They can be used to dig in the ground, to grip specimen or to clean solar panels. Therefore, in general, SMA composites are an appropriate mean to transfer heat energy to mechanical energy in rough environments.
Index Keywords: Bimetals; Composite materials; Energy storage; Energy transfer; Mobile robots; Planetary surface analysis; Planets; Shape memory effect; Stresses; Surface phenomena; Mechanical energy; Planetary surface exploration; Shape memory actuators; Thermal energy; Actuators

Title: 5th Symposium on the Urban Environment
Source title: 5th Symposium on the Urban Environment
Abstract: The proceedings contain 123 papers from the 5th Symposium on the Urban Environment. The topics discussed include: plans for the Madison Square garden 2004 (MSG04) tracer experiment in Manhattan; The urban heat island and temperature inversion measured by a temperature datalogger network in Phoenix during June and July 2001; urban modifications in mesoscale meteorological model and the effects on surface energetics; a model study on the effects of urbanization on the thermal and convective properties of San Juan, Puerto Rico; experimental determination of the turbulent kinetic energy budget within and above an urban canopy; and determination of the spatial and temporal distribution of population for air toxics exposure asses.

Title: On the quality assurance of surface energy flux measurements
Source title: 26th Conference on Agricultural and Forest Meteorology
Affiliations: University of Bayreuth, Department of Micrometeorology, Germany; University of Bayreuth, Dept. of Micrometeorology, D-95440 Bayreuth, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Mauder, M., University of Bayreuth, Department of Micrometeorology, Germany, University of Bayreuth, Dept. of Micrometeorology, D-95440 Bayreuth, Germany; Liebethal, C., University of Bayreuth, Department of Micrometeorology, Germany; Göckede, M., University of Bayreuth, Department of Micrometeorology, Germany; Foken, T., University of Bayreuth, Department of Micrometeorology, Germany
Abstract: The combination of three approaches such as determination of turbulent heat fluxes with their corrections and quality tests, footprint model based quality assessment for the turbulent heat fluxes, and methods to measure the ground heat flux was discussed. The turbulent heat fluxes were calculated as the covariance between the two high frequency time series of vertical wind velocity and a scalar temperature, measured at one point in time. The latent turbulent heat flux was increased due to the Moore and WPL correction, whereas the sensible heat flux was decreased as a result of the Schotanus correction. The three approaches of quality assurance for energy flux measurement have a significant impact on the results of energy flux measurements.

Abstract: Plasma parameters in ablative pulsed plasma thruster (APPT), a pulsed plasma thruster, was calculated. The individual pulse, the total charge of weight for a pulse and some other sizes have practically precisely coincided with experiment a curve of dependence of a current in a circuit from time, efficiency. The analysis of the received results show that the basic components of losses of energy are ohmic losses in a bringing circuit and the store of energy and loss of energy of radiation of plasma. The developed physical and mathematical model and its computer realization allow to track influence of variations of the various initial data on characteristics APPT.

Authors: Beringer J., Hutley L., Tapper N.
Title: Savanna fires and their impact on Net ecosystem productivity
Source title: 26th Conference on Agricultural and Forest Meteorology
Affiliations: School of Geography and Environmental Science, Monash University, Vic. 3800, Australia; Faculty of Education, Health and Science, Charles Darwin University, Darwin, NT 0909, Australia; School of Geography and Environmental Science, Monash University, Melbourne, 3800, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Beringer, J., School of Geography and Environmental Science, Monash University, Vic. 3800, Australia, School of Geography and Environmental Science, Monash University, Melbourne, 3800, Australia; Hutley, L., Faculty of Education, Health and Science, Charles Darwin University, Darwin, NT 0909, Australia; Tapper, N., School of Geography and Environmental Science, Monash University, Melbourne, 3800, Australia
Abstract: The impacts of fire on the surface radiation and energy balance of Australian savannas was investigated. The heat fluxes, moisture and carbon dioxide were measured over typical tropical savanna using the eddy covariance technique. The net ecosystem production (NEP) of the site including the losses from burning were +0.8 and +0.3 tC.ha-1 for the years 2001, 2002, 2003 respectively, indicating that in years with fire that ecosystem is a net source to the atmosphere. Enhanced biomass productivity of 30 to 60% after burning has been observed in some humid Savanna studies. Savanna management would be potential for increasing carbon storage in ecosystems by reducing fire frequency.

Authors: Koskelo M.J., Chapman J.A., Marsh J.D., Stevens S.W.
Title: Comparison of the performance of different uranium enrichment analysis codes using a range of detector types
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th International Conference on Facility Operations: Safeguards Interface
Affiliations: Canberra Industries, 800 Research Parkway, Meriden, CT 06450, United States; Canberra Industries, 1133-C Oak Ridge Turnpike, Oak Ridge, TN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Koskelo, M.J., Canberra Industries, 800 Research Parkway, Meriden, CT 06450, United States; Chapman, J.A., Canberra Industries, 800 Research Parkway, Meriden, CT 06450, United States; Marsh, J.D., Canberra Industries, 1133-C Oak Ridge Turnpike, Oak Ridge, TN, United States; Stevens, S.W., Canberra Industries, 1133-C Oak Ridge Turnpike, Oak Ridge, TN, United States
Abstract: This paper describes the results of a set of measurements carried out to assess the state of the practice of relative uranium enrichment measurements by gamma ray spectrometry and to compare a range of approaches by carrying out measurements on a set of uranium samples with known enrichments. Measurements made by a team from Canberra Industries were carried out using two detector/counting chain combinations. The data were collected in such a way as to allow it to be analyzed using different uranium enrichment analysis methods. The results obtained using different detector and enrichment analysis method combinations were compared with each other and with the known values for each sample. Results of these measurements show that in controlled experimental conditions the total uncertainty of reported enrichment is below the procedural upper reporting limit of ±20%. Measurements tend to be better with a BeGe detector over a coaxial detector.

Title: Regulator - Operator interface in NMPC&A: View from Russia
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th International Conference on Facility Operations: Safeguards Interface

Abstract: Paper provides review and assessment of the resent state orders and directives regulating nuclear materials control and accountability, physical protection of nuclear and radiological facilities. Principles and practical application of regulation at nuclear sites are discussed with the focus on a balance between operations performance and requirement of enhancing nuclear and radiation security. Tendency of strengthening supervision over NMPC&A through expanding inspection functions and volume is reviewed. Practical elements of the inspector - operator interface including a process of their communication, outcomes and follow up activities are presented. Results of inspections of NM accountancy and control and physical protection of nuclear materials and installations are reported. Sanctions are determined as a major tool of effecting an operator to follow regulation.

Title: An integrated power and propulsion system
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: Stork Product Engineering B. V., Czaar Peterstraat 229, 1018 PL Amsterdam, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Kwan, W., Stork Product Engineering B. V., Czaar Peterstraat 229, 1018 PL Amsterdam, Netherlands; Tuinstra, B., Stork Product Engineering B. V., Czaar Peterstraat 229, 1018 PL Amsterdam, Netherlands
Abstract: To reduce the cost of space missions, the idea of an integrated power and propulsion system (IPPS) has been raised. Key point of this concept is to launch water and convert this into hydrogen and oxygen, using solar power. These propellants can be used for attitude and orbit control as well as to generate electrical power through a fuel cell. The easy handling of water will greatly reduce the launch and preparation costs and enhance flexibility in comparison with the toxic monopropellants, while the system also promises mass reductions. These mass reductions are induced by the dual use of one component for various functions, like water for propulsion, energy supply and thermal control or tanks as propellant storage and structural components. An important design driver is the required total acceleration during the mission, which impacts the total system mass. Analyses indicate that with the present technology status a large weight reduction can be realized.
Index Keywords: Aerospace engineering; Launching; Orbits; Propellants; Storage (materials); Tanks (containers); Mass reductions; Propulsion systems; Proton exchange; Space missions; Propulsion

Authors: Antropov N., Diyakonov G., Lyubinskaya N., Orlov M., Popov G., Trubnikov P., Tyutin V., Yakovlev V., Isayev V., Pugatchiov Yu., Shelkov N.
Title: Correction propulsion system with ablative pulsed plasma thrusters for unified space platform "Vulcan"
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: Research Institute of Applied Mechanics and Electrodynamics of Moscow Aviation Institute (RIAME MAI), 5, Leningradskoye shosse, Moscow, 125080, Russian Federation; Research Institute for Electromechanics (NIIEM), 2, Panfilov Street, Istra-2, Moscow Region, 143500, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Antropov, N., Research Institute of Applied Mechanics and Electrodynamics of Moscow Aviation Institute (RIAME MAI), 5, Leningradskoye shosse, Moscow, 125080, Russian Federation; Diyakonov, G., Research Institute of Applied Mechanics and Electrodynamics of Moscow Aviation Institute (RIAME MAI), 5, Leningradskoye shosse, Moscow, 125080, Russian Federation; Lyubinskaya, N., Research Institute of Applied Mechanics and Electrodynamics of Moscow Aviation Institute (RIAME MAI), 5, Leningradskoye shosse, Moscow, 125080, Russian Federation; Orlov, M., Research Institute of Applied Mechanics and Electrodynamics of Moscow Aviation Institute (RIAME MAI), 5, Leningradskoye shosse, Moscow, 125080, Russian Federation; Popov, G., Research Institute of Applied Mechanics and Electrodynamics of Moscow Aviation Institute (RIAME MAI), 5, Leningradskoye shosse, Moscow, 125080, Russian Federation; Trubnikov, P., Research Institute of Applied Mechanics and Electrodynamics of Moscow Aviation Institute (RIAME MAI), 5, Leningradskoye shosse, Moscow, 125080, Russian Federation; Tyutin, V., Research Institute of Applied Mechanics and Electrodynamics of Moscow Aviation Institute (RIAME MAI), 5, Leningradskoye shosse, Moscow, 125080, Russian Federation; Yakovlev, V., Research Institute of Applied Mechanics and Electrodynamics of Moscow Aviation Institute (RIAME MAI), 5, Leningradskoye shosse, Moscow, 125080, Russian Federation; Isayev, V., Research Institute for Electromechanics (NIIEM), 2, Panfilov Street, Istra-2, Moscow Region, 143500, Russian Federation; Pugatchiov, Yu., Research Institute for Electromechanics (NIIEM), 2, Panfilov Street, Istra-2, Moscow Region, 143500, Russian Federation; Shelkov, N., Research Institute for Electromechanics (NIIEM), 2, Panfilov Street, Istra-2, Moscow Region, 143500, Russian Federation
Abstract: The low-orbit small unified space platform "Vulcan" is now developed in NIIEM. The unified space platform "Vulcan" includes the correction propulsion system with the ablative pulsed plasma thrusters. The propulsion system is designed in collaboration with RIAME MAI. The high-efficiency APPT of the next generation are developed in RIAME MAI. Such thrusters combine simplicity and reliability of the "traditional" pulsed thrusters with high thrust efficiency 25-40 % within the stored energy range of 50-100 J. Correction propulsion system of the platform "Vulcan" includes two 50 J thrusters APPT-50. It will be used for correction the orbit in altitude and inclination with 85 m/s characteristic velocity.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electrodes; Energy storage; Ohmic contacts; Orbits; Plasma applications; Space platforms; Ablative pulsed plasma thrusters (APPT); Correction propulsion systems (CPS); Stationary plasma thrusters (SPT); Unified space platforms (USP); Electric propulsion

Title: How is magnetic energy stored and released?
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: ESTEC-ESA, 2200 AG Noordwijk, Netherlands; Physics Department, 264 EPS Building, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59715, United States
Authors with affiliations: Régnier, S., ESTEC-ESA, 2200 AG Noordwijk, Netherlands; Canfield, R.C., Physics Department, 264 EPS Building, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59715, United States
Abstract: One key issue to understand the coronal heating problem is to know how magnetic energy can be stored and then released in a solar magnetic configuration. We focus our study on the existence of magnetic structures and topological elements that are associated with eruptive events in the corona. We first observe a twisted flux tube in active region (AR) 8151 which is associated with an eruption. The kink instability is the important mechanism to release the magnetic energy easily stored in a twisted flux tubes. And secondly we follow the time evolution of AR 8210 in which the complex topology and the photospheric transverse motions trigger some C-class flares. In AR 8210, two photospheric motions are considered as pre-flare phenomena: the clockwise rotation of the main sunspot and the fast moving parasitic polarity. Our observations imply that only the sunspot rotation is able to store a sufficient amount of magnetic energy to produce a detectable flare. The combination of photospheric motions and the existence of appropriate topological elements is also important for storage and release of magnetic energy.
Author Keywords: Flares; Magnetic energy; Magnetic fields; Sun: corona
Index Keywords: Aerodynamic heating; Current density; Electric currents; Magnetic flux; Magnetic storage; Sun; Topology; Vectors; X rays; Corona; Flares; Magnetic energy; Magnetic structures; Magnetic fields

Authors: Krichinsky A.M., Bereolos P.J., Bogard J.S., Lucero A.J., Meyers E.S., Scheffing C.S.
Title: Quantitative determination of U-233 in storage containers
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th International Conference on Facility Operations: Safeguards Interface
Affiliations: Nuclear Science and Technology Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL), United States; Advanced Integrated Management Services, Incorporated; Life Sciences Division, ORNL, United States; Western Research Institute, United States; Nuclear Science and Technology Division, ORNL, United States; North Carolina State University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Krichinsky, A.M., Nuclear Science and Technology Division, Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL), United States; Bereolos, P.J., Advanced Integrated Management Services, Incorporated; Bogard, J.S., Life Sciences Division, ORNL, United States; Lucero, A.J., Western Research Institute, United States; Meyers, E.S., Nuclear Science and Technology Division, ORNL, United States; Scheffing, C.S., North Carolina State University, United States
Abstract: Gamma photon emissions from 233U have been used to measure quantities of this fissile material directly -without prior knowledge of shielding provided by containers, of the contained material's characteristics, or of the distribution of material within the containers. Other emissions associated with 232U, a contaminant of 233U, were used to correct for attenuation by the linear regression of normalized emission intensities against an empirically determined function of photon energy. Measured values obtained using the technique indicate a bias of approximately +10% and an uncertainty of approximately ±15%. This method may be applied to quantifying other radioactive materials having an associated, broad spectrum of gamma photons (with energies from 0.2 MeV to 3 Mev) - as long as the relative intensities of these emissions are known.
Author Keywords: Gamma spectrometry; NDA; Uranium-233
Index Keywords: Gamma photon emission; Gamma spectrometry; NDA; Uranium-233; Gamma ray spectrometers; Gamma rays; Nuclear fuels; Photons; Radioactive materials; Radioisotopes; Uranium

Authors: Hordijk L., Gillespie B., Mayer R.L., Rollen H.Y.
Title: Characterising and declaring uranium in waste drums is not just putting it through a machine that automatically generates results
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th International Conference on Facility Operations: Safeguards Interface
Affiliations: Nuclear Energy Corporation of South Africa, Technical Support: Nuclear Operations Building P2400, Pelindaba, Pretoria, South Africa; Canberra Industries, 2425 Stevens Center Place, Richland, WA 99352, United States; United States Enrichment Corporation, Applied Nuclear Technology, 3930 US Rt. 23 S, Piketon, OH 45661, United States; Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Nuclear Science and Technology - Safeguards, MS-6050, 1 Bethel Valley Road, Oak Ridge, TN 37831-6050, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hordijk, L., Nuclear Energy Corporation of South Africa, Technical Support: Nuclear Operations Building P2400, Pelindaba, Pretoria, South Africa; Gillespie, B., Canberra Industries, 2425 Stevens Center Place, Richland, WA 99352, United States; Mayer, R.L., United States Enrichment Corporation, Applied Nuclear Technology, 3930 US Rt. 23 S, Piketon, OH 45661, United States; Rollen, H.Y., Oak Ridge National Laboratory, Nuclear Science and Technology - Safeguards, MS-6050, 1 Bethel Valley Road, Oak Ridge, TN 37831-6050, United States
Abstract: Since South Africa's signing of the Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT) and Comprehensive Safeguards Agreement in 1991, a section of the declaration related to drummed waste could not be verified by the IAEA for the past 12 years. The inability to verify the declaration was due to significant quantities of HEU and LEU waste material contained in waste drums (total of about 20,000 drums). This waste had accumulated from several uranium processes at NECSA (enrichment of HEU and LEU, fuel fabrication, etc), stored at various locations, without traceability, or known content. The material is in various waste matrixes and drum sizes. Measures had to be put in place to ensure all waste remains traceable (particularly when moving on site). The only way to resolve the IAEA declaration anomaly was to quantify the material in each drum by assaying it with a waste assay system. The Department of Energy (USA) made an IQ3 Waste Assay System, including a comprehensive support program, available to South Africa at the end of 2001. This ultimately led to the first two measured batches of HEU containing waste drums (total of about 85% of the total declared HEU) being presented to the IAEA in 2003. This paper gives an overview of this ongoing project. Included is the background, preparations (drum registration on a central database, traceability of drums, gathering of waste information for proper IQ3 measurement and result interpretation), calibrations and validations, technical difficulties/challenges (to ensure that various matrixes and drum sizes could be measured), result capturing and reporting, and IAEA method of verification.
Index Keywords: Assays; Fuels; Inventory control; Matrix algebra; Radioactive wastes; Storage (materials); Uranium; Fuel fabrications; International atomic energy agency (IAEA); Non-proliferation treaty (NPT); Waste drums; Nuclear materials safeguards

Authors: Fraser S., Monsberger M., Hacker V.
Title: Fuel cell power system options for Mars rovers
Source title: European Space Agency, (Special Publication) ESA SP
Affiliations: Christian-Doppler Laboratory for Fuel Cell Systems, Graz University of Technology, Steyrergasse 21, A-8010 Graz, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Fraser, S., Christian-Doppler Laboratory for Fuel Cell Systems, Graz University of Technology, Steyrergasse 21, A-8010 Graz, Austria; Monsberger, M., Christian-Doppler Laboratory for Fuel Cell Systems, Graz University of Technology, Steyrergasse 21, A-8010 Graz, Austria; Hacker, V., Christian-Doppler Laboratory for Fuel Cell Systems, Graz University of Technology, Steyrergasse 21, A-8010 Graz, Austria
Abstract: Mobile surface-bound mission elements will play a key role in advanced exploration of Mars. The challenging applications envisaged for robotic as well as manned surface rovers require new and innovative solutions for providing on-board power and propulsion. Fuel cells have been identified as very promising option for many of these applications. A number of different fuel cell power system options for Mars exploration vehicles have been investigated at the Christian-Doppler Laboratory for Fuel Cell Systems in a project funded by the European Space Agency. The focus was put on simulating two different types of power systems: firstly a small regenerative fuel cell system, and secondly a large primary fuel cell power system. Basic power system options for Mars rovers are discussed in this paper, along with the key issues in fuel cell design, being primarily the choice of fuel, the choice of fuel cell, and the fuel cell system balance of plant.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Fuel cells; Mobile robots; Polymers; Radioactivity; Radioisotopes; Robotics; Solar cells; Spacecraft; Spacecraft propulsion; European Space Agency; Fuel cell power systems; Mars rovers; Robotic rovers; Martian surface analysis

Title: Environmental issues to address at LNG/propane air plants
Source title: AGA Operating Section Proceedings
Authors with affiliations: Bradbury, L.C.
Abstract: LNG/propane air plants provide clean energy to business and consumers. There are a number of potential environmental issues to address in the construction and operations of these plants. A discussion on these issues for plant management to determine which ones exist that should be investigated by environmental professionals, presented at the AGA 2003 Operations Conference (Orlando, FL 4/27-29/2003), covers construction issues, e.g., environmental assessments, wetlands, and air emission permits; operational issues, e.g., air emissions and waste disposal; NPDES permits, e.g., water discharged from the operations of the plant; spill prevention control and countermeasures (use and storage of oil in excess of 1320 gal); PCB; and lead paint.

Authors: Cheng C., Liu Q.H., Massoud H.Z.
Title: Spectral element method for the schrödinger-poisson system
Source title: 2004 10th International Workshop on Computational Electronics, IEEE IWCE-10 2004, Abstracts
Affiliations: Electrical and Computer Engineering, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cheng, C., Electrical and Computer Engineering, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States; Liu, Q.H., Electrical and Computer Engineering, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States; Massoud, H.Z., Electrical and Computer Engineering, Duke University, Durham, NC 27708, United States
Abstract: The development of a fast spectral element method (SEM) with exponential accuracy for the self-consistent solution of the Schrödinger-Poisson system for the simulation of semiconductor nanodevices was presented. Gauss-Lobatto-Legendre polynomials were used to represent the unknown fields Schrödinger and Poisson equations. The spectral element method was first applied on an infinite quantum well under an external bias to solve the Schrödinger equation. It was observed that the spectral element method had an exponential accuracy. while the finite-difference method only had a 2nd order accuracy.

Title: Flash emissions from condensate tanks in natural gas gathering and processing systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Air and Waste Management Association's Annual Conference and Exhibition, AWMA
Affiliations: Duke Energy Field Services, LP, 370 17 Street, Denver, CO 80202, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ross, J.D., Duke Energy Field Services, LP, 370 17 Street, Denver, CO 80202, United States
Abstract: Duke Energy Field Services LP (DEFS) evaluated a practical method for estimating flash emissions at its natural gas gathering and processing facilities in New Mexico for air permitting and emission inventory purposes. For DEFS' facilities in New Mexico with low pressure separators (< 30 psig) and atmospheric storage tanks, flash gas emissions were estimated to typically be < 15 ton/yr. For these low pressure changes, the three estimation methods evaluated (VBE, E&P TANK, HYSYS) agreed well for a majority of the facilities sampled. For the purposes of air permitting and emission inventories, an emission factor was determined which could be used to estimate flash gas emissions for all DEFS' low pressure facilities in New Mexico. For facilities with higher pressure changes, more variability was shown between the three methods evaluated. This variability seemed to be strongly related to the composition of the pressurized liquid. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the AWMA 97th Annual Conference and Exhibition (Indianapolis, IN 6/22-25/2004).

Title: Control method considerations for DC-DC converters in power buffer aplications
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE Workshop on Computers in Power Electronics, COMPEL
Affiliations: Department of Elecrical and Compuer Engineering, University of Illinois at Champaign-Urbana, Urbana, IL 61801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Weaver, W.W., Department of Elecrical and Compuer Engineering, University of Illinois at Champaign-Urbana, Urbana, IL 61801, United States; Krein, P.T., Department of Elecrical and Compuer Engineering, University of Illinois at Champaign-Urbana, Urbana, IL 61801, United States
Abstract: The field population of power electronics loads continues to grow. Most such loads, including motor drives, computer power supplies, and even compact fluorescent lighting "isolate" the load dynamics from the utility grid. When isolated these loads enforce local constant power behavior, which can de-stabilize a weak power system. One method to mitigate the effects of constant power loads is the use of active dynamic power buffers. This paper reviews the power buffer concept, and presents dc-dc converter control methods and considerations to implement an active power buffer. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electric currents; Electric impedance; Electric loads; Electric power systems; Electric resistance; Energy storage; Stability; Transients; Interface devices; Power buffers; Power constraints; System transients; Power electronics

Title: A lightweight secure cyber foraging infrastructure for resource-constrained devices
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE Workshop on Mobile Computing Systems and Applications, WMCSA
Affiliations: School of Computing, University of Utah, United States
Authors with affiliations: Goyal, S., School of Computing, University of Utah, United States; Carter, J., School of Computing, University of Utah, United States
Abstract: Resource-constrained embedded and mobile devices are becoming increasingly common. Cyber foraging, which allows such devices to offload computation to less resource-constrained surrogate machines, enables new and interesting applications for these devices. In this paper we describe a surrogate infrastructure based on virtual machine technology that allows resource-constrainted devices to utilize a surrogate's compute, network, and storage resources. After describing the design of our surrogate infrastructure, we demonstrate how it can be used to support real-time speech recognition and a synthetic web services application. Using a surrogate reduces the response time of speech recognition by a factor of 200 while reducing the energy drain on the client device by a factor of 60. Using a surrogate reduces the response time and energy drain on the client by factors of 21 and 25, respectively, for the web services application. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Energy drain; Foraging infrastructure; Lightweight devices; Resource-constrained devices; Constraint theory; Cybernetics; Resource allocation; Speech recognition; Storage allocation (computer); Virtual reality; World Wide Web; Mobile telecommunication systems

Title: A new optimization method for CTMDP system-level power management techniques
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Microelectronics, ICM
Affiliations: University of Tehran, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Madani, N.M., University of Tehran, Iran; Masoumi, N., University of Tehran, Iran
Abstract: Dynamic Power Management (DPM) is a technique to reduce power consumption of electronic systems by selectively shutting down idle components. DPM encompasses a set of techniques that achieves energy-efficient computation by selectively turning off system components when they are idle. In this paper we survey several approaches to system-level dynamic power management and advantages and disadvantages of them. We used Continuous-Time Markov Decision Process to manage our systems and show how to modify buffer size of the system queue (SQ) and a technique by changing system provider (SP) parameters to reduce power consumption of the system. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Continuous time Markov decision process (CTMDP); Dynamic power management (DPM); Service providers (SP); Service queue (SQ); Buffer storage; Electronic equipment; Energy efficiency; Energy utilization; Heuristic methods; Linear programming; Local area networks; Markov processes; Problem solving; Regression analysis; VLSI circuits; Energy management

Authors: Guitton-Ouhamou P., Ben Fradj H., Belleudy C., Auguin M.
Title: Scheduling refinement and memory allocation for low power system
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Microelectronics, ICM
Affiliations: Laboratoire d'Informatique, Signaux et Systèmes de Sophia-Antipolis, Les Algorithmes Bat. Euclide 2000, route des Lucioles, 06903 Sophia-Antipos Cedex, France

Euclide 2000, route des Lucioles, 06903 Sophia-Antipos Cedex, France; Belleudy, C., Laboratoire d'Informatique, Signaux et Systèmes de Sophia-Antipolis, Les Algorithmes Bat. Euclide 2000, route des Lucioles, 06903 Sophia-Antipos Cedex, France; Auguin, M., Laboratoire d'Informatique, Signaux et Systèmes de Sophia-Antipolis, Les Algorithmes Bat. Euclide 2000, route des Lucioles, 06903 Sophia-Antipos Cedex, France
Abstract: Multimedia applications integrate more and more functionalities, and a huge capacity of memory is required; as a result power consumption increases and battery lifetime becomes a serious limitation. An other consequence is that the time to realize such systems becomes too long due to this growing complexity. In This paper some optimizations way to decrease power are presented. It focuses on refinement steps of schedules and system memory to reduce power consumption. In this paper we present a very promising technique to optimize the trade-off consumption/time for HW/SW codesign by applying; first the dynamic voltage / frequency scaling(DVS/DFS) technique; second an efficient method to found the best distribution of data between internal and external memories in order to decrease the global consumption. © 2004 IEEE.

Authors: Lee Y.-H., Nachman R., Hu S., Mielke N., Liu J.
Title: Implant damage and gate-oxide-edge effects on product reliability
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting, IEDM
Affiliations: Intel Corporation, California Technology and Manufacturing, RNB-3-24, 2200 Mission College Blvd., Santa Clara, CA 95052, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lee, Y.-H., Intel Corporation, California Technology and Manufacturing, RNB-3-24, 2200 Mission College Blvd., Santa Clara, CA 95052, United States; Nachman, R., Intel Corporation, California Technology and Manufacturing, RNB-3-24, 2200 Mission College Blvd., Santa Clara, CA 95052, United States; Hu, S., Intel Corporation, California Technology and Manufacturing, RNB-3-24, 2200 Mission College Blvd., Santa Clara, CA 95052, United States; Mielke, N., Intel Corporation, California Technology and Manufacturing, RNB-3-24, 2200 Mission College Blvd., Santa Clara, CA 95052, United States; Liu, J., Intel Corporation, California Technology and Manufacturing, RNB-3-24, 2200 Mission College Blvd., Santa Clara, CA 95052, United States
Abstract: This work investigated the effects of thin-gate oxide edge damage on logic product reliability. For this, we used different poly profiles to quantify the thin-gate oxide edge damage. Device/Process simulation was also conducted to explain the interaction of implant and poly shape with the gate oxide reliability. Poly with foot showed degraded oxide reliability, because it allows high-energy implant to penetrate through the edge of the gate oxide causing oxide damage and hence failures during product Burn-In. The problem is more pronounced on nMOST due to its stronger sensitivity to the voltage stress and the specific implant species as compared to pMOST. Circuit simulation was also conducted to characterize the circuit sensitivity on oxide leakage and to explain the observed product Burn-In fallout. ©2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Computer simulation; Current voltage characteristics; Electric fields; Reliability; Silicon; Static random access storage; VLSI circuits; Circuit simulation; Implant damage; Memory cell; Product reliability; Logic circuits

Authors: Ehssein C.O., Serfaty S., Griesmar P., Caplain E., Martinez L., Gindre M.
Title: Kinetic reaction monitoring of acidified milk gels with a quartz resonator: Effect of temperature and GDL quantities
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE Ultrasonics Symposium
Affiliations: (ECIME) Equipe Conception, Instrumentation et Modélisation Electronique of UCP, Cergy Pontoise, France; Laboratoire d'Imagerie Paramétrique, UMR CNRS 7623, Paris, France
Authors with affiliations: Ehssein, C.O., (ECIME) Equipe Conception, Instrumentation et Modélisation Electronique of UCP, Cergy Pontoise, France; Serfaty, S., (ECIME) Equipe Conception, Instrumentation et Modélisation Electronique of UCP, Cergy Pontoise, France; Griesmar, P., (ECIME) Equipe Conception, Instrumentation et Modélisation Electronique of UCP, Cergy Pontoise, France; Caplain, E., (ECIME) Equipe Conception, Instrumentation et Modélisation Electronique of UCP, Cergy Pontoise, France; Martinez, L., (ECIME) Equipe Conception, Instrumentation et Modélisation Electronique of UCP, Cergy Pontoise, France; Gindre, M., Laboratoire d'Imagerie Paramétrique, UMR CNRS 7623, Paris, France
Abstract: The behavior of weak gels during there formation particularly attracts attention of yoghurt factories. Our study is related to an acidified pre-heated milk gels formation fairly often used to product soft cheeses and yoghurts. These gel materials formations require a tight control of the kinetic reaction parameters. To achieve the measurement a thickness shear mode quartz resonator technique has been used in the MHz frequency range. This method is singularly effective to ensure a complete and reliable follow up of the viscoelastic parameters (the storage -G′- and the loss -G″- shear moduli) of gel materials. Using a suitable model this technique gives access to a new accurate characteristic time tvs (named viscoelastic time). This time corresponds to the instant from witch the material is no more a Newtonian liquid. Using the Arrhenius and modified Flory-Stockmayer relationships the activation energy is extracted from the study of the gelation process at different temperatures. The experimental results of the G′ and G″ moduli are discussed in this paper on one hand versus temperature, and on the other hand versus glucono-delta-lactone (GDL) added to milk © 2004 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Activation energy; Milk; Quartz; Rheology; Yoghurt
Index Keywords: Activation energy; Elastic moduli; Newtonian liquids; Quartz; Resonators; Rheology; Gelation time; Milk; Strain response; Yoghurt; Gels

Authors: Lin Y.-H., Chien C.-H., Lin C.-T., Chen C.-W., Chang C.-Y., Lei T.-F.
Title: High performance multi-bit nonvolatile HfO2 nanocrystal memory using spinodal phase separation of hafnium silicate
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting, IEDM
Affiliations: Institute of Electronics Engineering, National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu 300, Taiwan; National Nano Device Laboratories, 1001-1, Ta-Hsueh Rd., Hsinchu 300, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Lin, Y.-H., Institute of Electronics Engineering, National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu 300, Taiwan; Chien, C.-H., National Nano Device Laboratories, 1001-1, Ta-Hsueh Rd., Hsinchu 300, Taiwan; Lin, C.-T., Institute of Electronics Engineering, National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu 300, Taiwan; Chen, C.-W., Institute of Electronics Engineering, National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu 300, Taiwan; Chang, C.-Y., Institute of Electronics Engineering, National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu 300, Taiwan; Lei, T.-F., Institute of Electronics Engineering, National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu 300, Taiwan
Abstract: In this paper, we exploit a novel technique for preparing high density HfO2 nanocrystals with an average size < 10nm using spinodal phase separation of Hf-silicate thin film by 900°C rapid thermal annealing for nonvolatile memories. The density can be as high as 0.9-1.9times;10 12cm-2. Owing to the fact that HfO2 nanocrystals are well embedded inside SiO2 matrix and their sufficiently deep energy level, we, for the first time, have demonstrated superior characteristics of the nanocrystal memory in terms of considerably large memory window, high speed program/erase (1μs/0.1ms), long retention time greater than 108s for 10% charge loss, excellent endurance after 106 P/E cycles, negligible read/write disturbances and multi-bit operation. ©2004 IEEE.

Authors: Jin S., Yi J.-H., Choi J.H., Kang D.G., Park Y.J., Min H.S.
Title: Modeling of retention time distribution of DRAM cell using a Monte-Carlo method
Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting, IEDM

Abstract: A comprehensive Monte-Carlo method for the simulation of the data retention time distribution of DRAM cell has been developed using the current Green's function in the calculation of leakage current. The Monte-Carlo simulation results including the trap-assisted tunneling and the stress-induced bandgap narrowing models show that our model can explain the effects of the wide range of the bias, doping, and mechanical stress on the retention time distribution for both the main and tail parts of the cells. © 2004 IEEE.

Source title: Technical Digest - International Electron Devices Meeting, IEDM

Abstract: Characteristics of soft errors (SEs) in 90/130 nm CMOS circuits were comprehensively investigated by high energy neutron- and alpha-accelerated tests. Process dependence on SEs in latch circuits due to neutrons and alpha-ray were investigated. Error patterns in multiple-bit SEs in SRAMs and their impacts on ECC design were also discussed. ©2004 IEEE.

Title: On the design of memory with low energy consumption

Abstract: Data transfer intensive applications consume a significant amount of energy in memory access. The selection of a memory location from a memory array involves driving row and column select lines. The problem of energy efficient address assignment has been formulated as a multi-way graph-partitioning problem and solved with a heuristic. Our experiments demonstrate that the proposed methodology achieves row transition counts very close to the optimum. Furthermore, the proposed methodology is capable of handling access sequences with over 15*10 6 accesses in moderate time. ©2004 IEEE.

Title: US-PCS SAW duplexer using high-Q SAW resonator with SiO2 coat for stabilizing temperature characteristics
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE Ultrasonics Symposium

Abstract: We have successfully developed the SAW resonators with SiO2 coat, which have both high-Q characteristics and stabile temperature characteristics. We realized the SAW duplexer for the US PCS band (US-PCS) using these resonators. The frequency characteristics variation due to temperature change is usually taken into design consideration. However, in case of US-PCS duplexer, which has a difficult frequency allocation for the transmission (Tx) band and the reception (Rx) band. A temperature coefficient (TC) reduction technology is essential to realize the US-PCS SAW duplexer. Of course, this TC reduction technique should not deteriorate the filter characteristics, such as insertion loss. In this report, we explain the TC reduction technique using SiO2 layer and the US-PCS SAW duplexer employing these resonators. It shows the good performance over the temperature range -30°C to +85°C. ©2004 IEEE.

Authors: Apelbaum A.F., Perrut A., Chaput M.
Title: Orexin effects on the olfactory bulb activity as a model of sensory integration in relation to the internal state of the organism
Source title: Proceedings of Modelling and Simulation, MS'2004
Affiliations: CNRS UMR5020, Neurosciences and Systèmes Sensoriels, Université Claude Bernard Lyon 1, 50 avenue Tony Gamier, 69366 Lyon Cedex 07, France; EA 2032 Probabilités Combinatoires et Statistiques, Université Claude Bernard Lyon 1, 50 avenue Tony Gamier, 69366 Lyon cedex 07, France
Authors with affiliations: Apelbaum, A.F., CNRS UMR5020, Neurosciences and Systèmes Sensoriels, Université Claude Bernard Lyon 1, 50 avenue Tony Gamier, 69366 Lyon Cedex 07, France; Perrut, A., EA 2032 Probabilités Combinatoires et Statistiques, Université Claude Bernard Lyon 1, 50 avenue Tony Gamier, 69366 Lyon cedex 07, France; Chaput, M., CNRS UMR5020, Neurosciences and Systèmes Sensoriels, Université Claude Bernard Lyon 1, 50 avenue Tony Gamier, 69366 Lyon Cedex 07, France
Abstract: The central nervous system integrates information from sensory inputs and regulates different systems to maintain the organism in a state of equilibrium, homeostasis. Among many, is the energy homeostasis that is regulated through systems driving the animal to start or stop eating depending of its energy expenditure and storage. Animals such as rats are heavily dependent on their sense of smell to find and select appropriate food. The olfactory bulb (OB) is an intermediate level of the olfactory system receiving inputs from the olfactory receptors and transmitting them to higher brain structures. The OB is also a target for many higher brain centres regulating its activity through centrifugal pathways. It is therefore a first-choice structure for the modulation of the organism's ability to detect odours with a nutritional value, thus allowing the animal to find food. Indeed, several studies have shown that the OB activity is modulated by an alimentary odour in a hungry animal whereas it is not in a satiated animal. In this study, we have used a new approach to investigate the OB modulation in relation to the internal state of the organism. Orexin (ORX), a novel molecule, known to play an important role in regulating food intake and whose receptors are present in the OB, was applied directly on the OB while recording its activity. Results have shown that while the OB has a stable activity in control conditions when no odours are applied, a local administration of ORX modulates its activity in a majority of cells tested. This modulation is rapid (within a few seconds to a minute), reversible (the activity returns to a base level within minutes) and can be either an increase in activity or a decrease. While the mechanisms through which ORX could modulate the output of the OB are not yet understood, it remains a promising model to investigate how the internal state modulates the olfactory integration.
Index Keywords: Alimentary mechanism; Olfactory bulb (OB); Orexin effects; Sensory integration; Brain; Cells; Mathematical models; Molecules; Neurology; Sensors; Microorganisms

Title: Will et write or radiate: Inscribed matter vs. electromagnetic channels
Source title: Conference Record - Asilomar Conference on Signals, Systems and Computers
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ 08854, United States; Antiope Associates, 18 Clay Street, Fair Haven, NJ 07704, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rose, C., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Rutgers University, Piscataway, NJ 08854, United States; Wright, G., Antiope Associates, 18 Clay Street, Fair Haven, NJ 07704, United States
Abstract: We consider the energy requirements of information carriage using physical transport of inscribed matter and compare it to that using electromagnetic radiation when delivery delay beyond light transit time can be tolerated. Somewhat counter-intuitively, physical transport of inscribed matter is often more energy efficient than electromagnetic broadcast by many orders of magnitude over a wide range of scenarios - from chip-to-chip computer communications to interstellar signaling. In fact, the efficiencies are so enormous that it may even be more likely for initial contact by extraterrestrial civilizations to occur using physical artifacts - essentially messages in a bottle - than via electromagnetic communication. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electromagnetic channels; Electromagnetic communication; Electromagnetic message; Gaussian receiver noise; Bit error rate; Data storage equipment; Electromagnetic waves; Information theory; Light transmission; Microprocessor chips; Scanning tunneling microscopy; Signal processing; Communication channels (information theory)

Source title: AUVSI's Unmanned Systems North America 2004 - Proceedings

Abstract: The issues related to implementation of unmanned vehicles in future maritime battles, are discussed. It is understood that communication, energy storage, propulsion, command control and mission management, independent obstacle avoidance, navigation, and payloads are some of the technology gaps that are needed to be given attention for such future application. The issues related to the role of director of equipment capability during underwater effects, in an operation involving unmanned vehicles are also discussed. The issues related to development of cost-effective concept fulfilling different scenarios, and the role of research and development as de-risking concept in identifying cost drivers in concept demonstrations, are also discussed.

Abstract: In this paper, a new simple yet accurate model for determining power consumption of mux-based crossbar interconnects is introduced. Authors: Hu Q., Brockmeyer E., Palkovic M., Kjeldsberg P.G., Catthoor F.
Title: Memory hierarchy usage estimation for global loop transformations
Source title: Proceedings - Norchip
Affiliations: Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim, Norway; IMEC, Leuven, Belgium; Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Hu, Q., Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim, Norway; Brockmeyer, E., IMEC, Leuven, Belgium; Palkovic, M., IMEC, Leuven, Belgium; Kjeldsberg, P.G., Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Trondheim, Norway; Catthoor, F., IMEC, Leuven, Belgium, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: Major parts of the power dissipation for data dominated embedded systems is due to huge amounts of data transfers to and from large power consuming data memories. Global loop transformations play a crucial role in optimizing the memory accesses. By improving regularity and temporal locality of these memory accesses using loop transformations, data can be potentially stored closer to the datapath in smaller less power consuming memories. To steer the selection of which loop transformations to perform, high level memory estimation is used. In state of the art memory estimation techniques the mapping of data to different parts of the memory hierarchy are not considered since these decisions are made in later system design phases. However, estimates of these mapping decisions is crucial, since they greatly influence the consequences of different transformations. In this paper we propose a systematic methodology for hierarchical memory usage estimation which considers also future data mapping decisions for a memory hierarchy. The goal of the estimation is to evaluate global loop transformation decisions for different platforms and keep only the optimal decision (in terms of energy) for each platform. We demonstrate our methodology on a real- life multimedia video coder (QSD-PCM) which shows that for 1k layer one memory, a factor of 2 improvement in total energy can be achieved. ©2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Data storage equipment; Hierarchical systems; Mathematical transformations; Multimedia systems; Parameter estimation; Shape memory effect; Data reuse analysis (DRA); Data transfers; Global loop transformation; Incremental data; Embedded systems

Authors: Xiao Y., Zhu K.Y., Zhang C., Tseng K.J., Ling K.V.
Title: Stabilizing synchronization control of magnetic bearing-based flywheel energy storage systems
Source title: 2004 8th International Conference on Control, Automation, Robotics and Vision (ICARCV)
Affiliations: School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Nanyang Avenue, Singapore 639798, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Xiao, Y., School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Nanyang Avenue, Singapore 639798, Singapore; Zhu, K.Y., School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Nanyang Avenue, Singapore 639798, Singapore; Zhang, C., School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Nanyang Avenue, Singapore 639798, Singapore; Tseng, K.J., School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Nanyang Avenue, Singapore 639798, Singapore; Ling, K.V., School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Nanyang Avenue, Singapore 639798, Singapore
Abstract: With the advances of high strength/light weight composite material, high performance magnetic bearings, and power electronics technology, Flywheel Energy Storage Systems (FESS) are becoming an exciting alternative to traditional battery systems. One of the challenging problems of the FESS is to stabilize the rotor which is very sensitive to outside disturbances and plant uncertainties. In this paper, a stabilizing synchronization design of the FESS is proposed by incorporating cross-coupling technology into the optimal control architecture, which can be decomposed into two problems: a robust optimal control problem to improve the synchronization performance of the rotor in the radial directions and a stability problem. The control scheme is based on minimization of a new quadratic performance index in which the synchronization errors are embedded. Stability of the control scheme is investigated through Linear Quadratic Gaussian (LQG) optimal control technique. It is shown that with adequate control parameters the resulting control system can provide satisfactory synchronization performance, and the closed-loop stability can be guaranteed theoretically. Simulations on a compact and efficient flywheel energy storage system with integrated magnetic bearings demonstrate that the proposed approach is very effective to recover the unstable system when outside disturbances are present. © 2004 IEEE.

Authors: Karis T.E., Kim W.T., Jhon M.S.
Title: Spreading and dewetting in nanoscale lubrication
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME/STLE International Joint Tribology Conference, IJTC 2004
Affiliations: Hitachi Global Storage Technologies, San Jose Research Center, San Jose, CA 95120-6099, United States; Department of Chemical Engineering, Data Storage Systems Center, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213-3890, United States
Authors with affiliations: Karis, T.E., Hitachi Global Storage Technologies, San Jose Research Center, San Jose, CA 95120-6099, United States; Kim, W.T., Department of Chemical Engineering, Data Storage Systems Center, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213-3890, United States; Jhon, M.S., Department of Chemical Engineering, Data Storage Systems Center, Carnegie Mellon University, Pittsburgh, PA 15213-3890, United States
Abstract: This article critically reviews the fundamental scientific tools, as well as constructs cohesive schemes for potential applications, to molecularly-thin liquid film technology. Our focus is to understand the nanoscale dynamic behavior of thin lubricant films, related to the emerging field of nanotechnology, especially for achieving durability and reliability in the nanoscale devices. Our goal is to present a unified and hybrid description of perfluoropolyether (PFPE) experiment, mesoscopic interpretation, microscopic simulation tools, and molecular design tools available up to now. The experimentation and theory for the physicochemical properties of ultra- thin PFPE films are used to examine liquid film in the sub-monolayer to multilayer regime. Methods for extracting spreading properties from the scanning microellipsometry (SME) for various PFPE/solid surface pairs and the surface rheological characterization of PFPEs are examined. The interrelationships among SME spreading profiles, rheology, surface energy, and tribology, are given. Mesoscopic theories, including thermodynamics of evaporation and flow, stability analysis, microscale mass transfer, and capillary waves are introduced to describe thin PFPE film dynamics. Estimation of thin film viscosity enhancement from vapor pressure suppression by dispersion force is reviewed. The method for experimental derivation of lubricant spreading profiles from contact angles is summarized. The implications of capillary waves, or thermal fluctuations, at the surface of polymeric lubricant films are also discussed. The lattice-based, simple reactive sphere Monte Carlo (MC) technique for examining the fundamentals of PFPE dynamics is illustrated. An off-lattice based bead-spring MC model is also introduced to capture the detailed internal structure of the PFPE molecules, and the molecular dynamics method is implemented for a full-scale nanostructural analysis of PFPE ultra-thin films. By systematically tuning the endgroup strengths of PFPE, we examined the physicochemical properties for thin liquid films of the various PFPE/solid surface pairings. These tools accurately describe the static and dynamic behavior of ultra-thin liquid films consistent with experimental findings and thus are suitable for examining the fundamental mechanisms of lubrication in nanoscale devices. Application of the next generation head-disk interface design in information storage device is briefly considered. Copyright © 2004 by Springer Science + Business Media, Inc.

Abstract: This paper describes interface strategies for a Java co-processor (from now on JPU). The interface units are interchangeable, and share a common communication scheme towards the co-processor. The rst version of the interface is designed for single CPU and single co-processor environment. The other is for a network of multiple CPUs and co-processors. The co-processor does not need to know what kind of environment is is placed in, as all communication goes through the interface unit. This modularity of the design makes the co-processor more reusable and allows system level scalability. This work is a part of a project focusing on design of an advanced Java co-processor for Java intensive SoC applications. © 2004 IEEE.

Abstract: This paper reports design and evaluation results of a low-energy I-cache architecture, called history-based tag-comparison (HBTC) cache. The HBTC cache attempts to re-use tag-comparison results to detect and eliminate unnecessary memory-array activations. We have performed cycle accurate simulations, and have designed an SRAM core based on a 0.18 μm CMOS technology. As a result, it has been observed that the HBTC approach can achieve 60% of energy reduction, with only 0.3% performance degradation, compared to a conventional cache. Furthermore, we have also evaluated the potential of the HBTC cache by combining with other low-energy techniques. © 2004 IEEE.
