Title: Prediction of nano-scale wear - An analytical approach
Source title: Proceedings of the ASME/STLE International Joint Tribology Conference, IJTC 2004
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India
Authors with affiliations: Chowdhury, S.K.R., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India
Abstract: When two surfaces touch each other, intimate contacts occur at the tips of the asperities and adhesional interaction between the solids arising out of the surface forces becomes significant. This effect need be considered in MEMs, micro-machines, magnetic storage systems and other such situations where the surfaces are inherently smooth and loads are extremely low. Surfaces in these and many other tribological contacts may have sub-micron or even nanometric levels and the stochastic model for rough surfaces that typically applies to engineering surfaces is not suitable. The rough surface model in these circumstances must cover asperities ranging from nanometer to micrometer level and this essentially needs a fractal approach. The paper describes a theoretical study of adhesive wear at the contact between surfaces with nanometric level asperities at low loads using a fractal contact model and taking into account the surface forces. The model predicts wear between solids with wide range of material and surface properties. The results broadly confirm the experimental observation such as dependence of wear volume on normal load and also on adhesion due surface forces. Furthermore the fractal analysis gives a generalized solution and depending on the combinations of material and fractal parameters specific solutions, relevant to realistic situations may be arrived at. are obtained. Under certain parametric combinations high wear even under tensile load is predicted while near zero wear is expected for some another set of parameters. These predictions are certainly advantageous in the selection of surface and material properties in applications where loads are small and surfaces are ultra smooth. Copyright © 2004 by ASME.
Author Keywords: Adhesion; Adhesive wear; Fractal; Roughness
Index Keywords: Atomic force microscopy; Fractals; Interfacial energy; Oscillators (electronic); Surface roughness; Wear of materials; Asperity interactions; Magnetic storage systems; Pyramidal shape; Wear rate; Nanostructured materials

Authors: Bogy D.B., Gupta V., Juang J.-Y.
Title: Nanoscale stability and active control in hard disk drives
Source title: Proceedings of the 2004 International Symposium on Micro-NanoMechatronics and Human Science, MHS2004; The Fourth Symposium 'Micro-NanoMechatronics for and Information-Based Society' The 21st Century
Affiliations: Computer Mechanics Laboratory, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bogy, D.B., Computer Mechanics Laboratory, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Gupta, V., Computer Mechanics Laboratory, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Juang, J.-Y., Computer Mechanics Laboratory, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of California, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: To achieve the areal density goal in hard disk drives of 1 Tbit/in 2 the minimum physical spacing between the slider and disk must be reduced to less than 5 nm. At such low spacing new nanoscale forces act between the slider and disk, such as intermolecular and electrostatic forces, which must be taken into consideration. These forces can create dynamic instabilities in the flying head slider, which are detrimental to its ability to reliably read and write data. This paper reviews the recent trends in data densities and size reductions in hard disk drives, showing that the transition to nanoscale phenomena is about to occur. Simple evolutionary developments appear to no longer work for increasing the areal data density. Some of the various alternatives for overcoming these new problems for sub-5nm flying sliders are presented and discussed. We show the source and effects of the new short range forces and examine how various design parameters for air bearing sliders affect the instabilities. Then we present some alternatives to traditional flying head sliders, such as active control of PZT actuated flying sliders or contact interfaces for hard disk drives. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Degrees of freedom (mechanics); Electrostatics; Nanotechnology; Nonlinear systems; Optical properties; Permittivity; Potential energy; Controlled flying proximity sliders (CFP); Electrostatic forces; Flying height modulation (FHM); Intermolecular forces; Hard disk storage

Authors with affiliations: Eschbach, F., Intel Corporation, Intel Mask Operations, 3065 Bowers Ave, Santa Clara, CA 95054, United States; Selassie, D., Intel Corporation, Intel Mask Operations, 3065 Bowers Ave, Santa Clara, CA 95054, United States; Sanchez, P., Intel Corporation, Intel Mask Operations, 3065 Bowers Ave, Santa Clara, CA 95054, United States; Tanzil, D., Intel Corporation, Intel Mask Operations, 3065 Bowers Ave, Santa Clara, CA 95054, United States; Tolani, V., Intel Corporation, Intel Mask Operations, 3065 Bowers Ave, Santa Clara, CA 95054, United States; Toofan, M., Intel Corporation, Intel Mask Operations, 3065 Bowers Ave, Santa Clara, CA 95054, United States; Liu, H., Intel Corporation, Intel Mask Operations, 3065 Bowers Ave, Santa Clara, CA 95054, United States; Greenebaum, B., Intel Corporation, Intel Mask Operations, 3065 Bowers Ave, Santa Clara, CA 95054, United States; Murray, M., Intel Corporation, Intel Mask Operations, 3065 Bowers Ave, Santa Clara, CA 95054, United States; Villacorta, R., Intel Corporation, Intel Mask Operations, 3065 Bowers Ave, Santa Clara, CA 95054, United States
Abstract: The formation of photoinduced crystals and haze has become a challenge for 193nm photolithography high volume manufacturing (1-6). Extensive work has been performed to develop alternative to piranha chemistry for photomask cleaning processes in an attempt to eliminate the incidence of clean induced ammonium sulfate crystal formation (9-13). However, additional factors are impacting 193nm reticle optical quality. Sources of molecular contaminants such as environmental actors, outgasing from pellicle and reticle storage material can generate varieties of photoinduced crystals over the reticle useable lifetime (5-6). This paper will quantify and rank contributing factors for crystals generated under high energy UV exposure. A broad range of analytical and metrology techniques (FTIR, IC, TD-GC/MS, Inorganics impinger, AIMS™, KLA Starlight, UV 172nm) and improvements in technique sensitivity were developed in order to identify crystal structure, quantify photogenerated contaminants levels and assess wafer printability impact. Engineering systems aimed at minimizing organic and inorganic molecular contaminants levels will be suggested.
Author Keywords: Crystals; Pellicle; Photoinduced defects; Photomask cleaning
Index Keywords: Molecular contaminants; Pellicle; Photoinduced defects; Photomask cleaning; Ammonium compounds; Argon; Cleaning; Crystal growth; Crystal structure; Crystals; Degassing; Impurities; Photolithography

Authors: Yamamoto I., Aoki T., Tsukioka S., Yoshida H., Hyakudome T., Sawa T., Ishibashi S., Inada T., Yokoyama K., Maeda T., Ishiguro S., Hirayama H., Hirokawa K., Hashimoto A., Hisatome N., Tani T.
Title: Fuel cell system of AUV "Urashima"

Affiliations: Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology, 2-15 Natsushima-cho, Yokosuka, 237-0061, Japan; Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., 1-1-1 Wadasaki-cho, Hyogo-ku, Kobe, 652-8585, Japan; Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., 1-1 Akunoura-cho, Nagasaki 850-8610, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yamamoto, I., Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology, 2-15 Natsushima-cho, Yokosuka, 237-0061, Japan; Aoki, T., Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology, 2-15 Natsushima-cho, Yokosuka, 237-0061, Japan; Tsukioka, S., Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology, 2-15 Natsushima-cho, Yokosuka, 237-0061, Japan; Yoshida, H., Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology, 2-15 Natsushima-cho, Yokosuka, 237-0061, Japan; Hyakudome, T., Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology, 2-15 Natsushima-cho, Yokosuka, 237-0061, Japan; Sawa, T., Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology, 2-15 Natsushima-cho, Yokosuka, 237-0061, Japan; Ishibashi, S., Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology, 2-15 Natsushima-cho, Yokosuka, 237-0061, Japan; Inada, T., Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology, 2-15 Natsushima-cho, Yokosuka, 237-0061, Japan; Yokoyama, K., Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., 1-1-1 Wadasaki-cho, Hyogo-ku, Kobe, 652-8585, Japan; Maeda, T., Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., 1-1-1 Wadasaki-cho, Hyogo-ku, Kobe, 652-8585, Japan; Ishiguro, S., Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., 1-1-1 Wadasaki-cho, Hyogo-ku, Kobe, 652-8585, Japan; Hirayama, H., Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., 1-1-1 Wadasaki-cho, Hyogo-ku, Kobe, 652-8585, Japan; Hirokawa, K., Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., 1-1-1 Wadasaki-cho, Hyogo-ku, Kobe, 652-8585, Japan; Hashimoto, A., Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., 1-1 Akunoura-cho, Nagasaki 850-8610, Japan; Hisatome, N., Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., 1-1 Akunoura-cho, Nagasaki 850-8610, Japan; Tani, T., Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd., 1-1 Akunoura-cho, Nagasaki 850-8610, Japan
Abstract: JAMSTEC (Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology) and MHI (Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Ltd.) have been developing the AUV (Autonomous Underwater Vehicle) "Urashima" since 1998. Long-distance cruising AUVs generally need an AIP (Air Independent Propulsion) power source characterized by high- energy density and high- energy efficiency. Fuel cells are the preferred AIP power source for small underwater vehicles and PEFC (Polymer Electrolyte Fuel Cell) have been adopted for "Urashima". It is understood that one of the main themes with fuel cell is storing the hydrogen, the metal hydride storage has been adopted for "Urashima" as a safer method of storing the hydrogen. In summer of 2002 the AUV "Urashima" successfully completed an autonomous 132.5 km long-distance cruise using large capacity lithium-ion rechargeable battery. In the meantime, a Closed Cycle PEFC (Polymer Electrolyte Fuel Cell) system with a metal hydride hydrogen storage system was developed as an alternative AIP power source in order to extend "Urashima" 's cruising range. The lithium-ion rechargeable battery was replaced by the Closed Cycle PEFC system and this system became the main power source of "Urashima" in winter of 2002. "Urashima", with its new power source (the Closed Cycle PEFC system) achieved the world's first and deepest fuel cell power source dive in summer of 2003 and completed an autonomous cruise of 220 km in spring of 2004. In sea trials, the fuel cell system with metal hydride hydrogen storage system worked adequately and underwater fuel cell operation was verified. There were no problem in supplying power to the vehicle and supplying hydrogen to fuel cell system. "Urashima" will carry out the AUV world record 300km cruising at upcoming trial opportunity. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Energy efficiency; Fuel cells; Fuel storage; Lithium batteries; Polyelectrolytes; Secondary batteries; Hydrogen storage; Polymer electrolyte fuel cells (PEFC); Power sources; Underwater fuel cell operation; Remotely operated vehicles

Authors: Zachariah J.L., Hemmes K., Bouwmans I., Michels J.P.J., Schouten J.A., Janssen R.
Title: Moving towards hydrogen via natural gas: Implications for the Netherlands
Source title: International Gas Research Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Delft University of Technology, P.O. Box 2600, GA, Delft, Netherlands; University of Amsterdam, Van der Waals-Zeeman Institute, Valckenierstraat 67, 1018 XE, Amsterdam, Netherlands; Energy, Boslaan 7, 9301 KH Roden, Netherlands

Box 2600, GA, Delft, Netherlands; Michels, J.P.J., University of Amsterdam, Van der Waals-Zeeman Institute, Valckenierstraat 67, 1018 XE, Amsterdam, Netherlands; Schouten, J.A., University of Amsterdam, Van der Waals-Zeeman Institute, Valckenierstraat 67, 1018 XE, Amsterdam, Netherlands; Janssen, R., Energy, Boslaan 7, 9301 KH Roden, Netherlands
Abstract: In the Netherlands, the Greening of Gas project has been started to investigate the feasibility, from ecological, economic and technological perspectives, of adding hydrogen to the Dutch natural gas network as a means of reducing diffuse CO2 emissions and ultimately initiating a shift towards a hydrogen economy. A discussion covers a quantitative sketch of infrastructure implications of introducing hydrogen to the current natural gas network of the Netherlands; elements in the hydrogen supply chain, production-storage-transport, including issues such as the required network modifications and other consequences for the current infrastructure system, and new optimization strategies and evolving ideas to strengthen the arguments for this approach; and comparison of the proposed supply side chain with post combustion CO2 capture from the large energy producers as a means of highlighting the environmental benefits of this strategy. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 2004 International Gas Research Conference (Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada 11/1-4/2004).

Title: Simulation of cogeneration in single-family homes
Source title: International Gas Research Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: E.ON Ruhrgas AG, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Bonsen, C., E.ON Ruhrgas AG, Germany
Abstract: A simulation program was developed to evaluate the potential of CHP plants in single-family homes. Using a high time resolution, the program studies system operation and thus coverage of a home's heat and power requirements. The study is based on true 1-min values measured for the heat, water and power requirements in several single-family homes over a period exceeding 1 yr in each case. The program is suitable for simulating all relevant CHP technologies (fuel cells, internal combustion engines, Stirling engines, CHP plants with steam piston drives) in single-family homes, as a great number of parameters have been used to describe CHP plant components, boilers and hot-water storage facilities. For each minute of the year, the simulation program calculates the heat and power generated by the system and compares the values with the heat and power required. The values are added up for each day, each month and an entire year. With the high time resolution, it is possible to determine with adequate accuracy the share of the CHP power that can be used in the home, thus replacing power from the grid, and the share to be fed into the grid. Accurate determination of the own-consumption share is a major prerequisite for calculating the annual energy cost savings, which may be achieved with a CHP system compared to a reference system with central power generation and decentral heat generation using a condensing boiler. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 2004 International Gas Research Conference (Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada 11/1-4/2004).

Title: Experience from repairs of flooded hydro-generators
Source title: IMechE Event Publications
Affiliations: BRUSH SEM s.r.o., Plzen, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Turek, T., BRUSH SEM s.r.o., Plzen, Czech Republic
Abstract: In August 2002 the west part of the Czech Republic experienced rainfall comparable with the normal average annual rainfall within a few days. The extreme rainfall affected mainly the Vltava river, where there is a cascade of dams used for energy generation. The increased level of downstream water flooded almost all the hydro units on the river. Some of the generators (the highest unit outputs are 100 MVA) were flooded with a few meters of water. One of the units, a 53 MVA generator-motor installed in a deep cavern under the river, was flooded under a 25 metre water column for several weeks. Five generators were repaired from three flooded power stations. This paper deals with experience gained during repairs of these hydro-generators and during similar repairs of generators performed some time ago in Africa. The paper identifies the most problematic components and outlines a typical scope and sequence of repair. © BRUSH SEM s.r.o. 2004.
Index Keywords: Dams; Electric variables measurement; Floods; Hydroelectric power; Pumped storage power plants; Rain; Reservoirs (water); Rotors; Stators; Hydro-generators; Insulation resistance; Rotor winding; Stator winding; Hydroelectric generators

Title: The complete refurbishment of Culligran underground hydropower station
Source title: IMechE Event Publications
Affiliations: Weir Engineering Services, Alloa, United Kingdom; VA Tech Hydro, Vienna, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Erskine, A., Weir Engineering Services, Alloa, United Kingdom; Van Rooy, O., VA Tech Hydro, Vienna, Austria
Abstract: The Weir Engineering Services/VA TECH Hydro Alliance (VAWES) are engaged in the refurbishment of Scottish and Southern Energy's (SSE) Culligran Power Station in Scotland. No significant refurbishment has been undertaken since the station was commissioned over forty years ago. The project presents a number of unique opportunities for innovation and the paper explains; The technologies being used to improve efficiencies, reduce maintenance and prolong the life of the station The technologies employed in the re-design of the main unit - a Deriaz machine, unique in the U.K. The specialised techniques being employed to renew the runner chamber of the Deriaz machine The environmental considerations given that the station is located in a Site of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI) The laser scanning technology used to generate the station layout drawings How the project execution is optimised to maximise generation © Weir Engineering Services 2004.
Index Keywords: Approximation theory; Hydroelectric power; Laser applications; Preventive maintenance; Project management; Scanning; Turbogenerators; Hydropower stations; Laser scanning; Machine cross section; Storage reservoirs; Hydroelectric power plants

Title: Do you know ... a hawk from a handsaw, or a pressure vessel from a fan, (or why we need a technical fan specification)?
Source title: IMechE Event Publications
Affiliations: Lucite International UK Limited, Billingham, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Hutchings, A.A., Lucite International UK Limited, Billingham, United Kingdom
Abstract: A comparison of how the design, testing and maintenance of fans and pressure vessels are treated is presented. It is suggested that for significant fans some of the things are done with pressure vessels are also relevant to fans. The Pressure Equipment Directive (PED) for Pressure Equipment now delineates various categories of pressure vessels. Pressure Vessels typically retain the stored energy by the static stress field in the structure of the vessel.

Authors: Melis W.J.C., Cheung P.Y.K., Luk W.
Title: Scalable structured data access by combining autonomous memory blocks
Source title: Proceedings - 2004 IEEE International Conference on Field-Programmable Technology, FPT '04
Affiliations: Dept. of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Imperial College, Exhibition Road, London SW7 2BT, United Kingdom; Dept. of Computing, Imperial College, 180 Queen's Gate, London SW7 2BZ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Melis, W.J.C., Dept. of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Imperial College, Exhibition Road, London SW7 2BT, United Kingdom; Cheung, P.Y.K., Dept. of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Imperial College, Exhibition Road, London SW7 2BT, United Kingdom; Luk, W., Dept. of Computing, Imperial College, 180 Queen's Gate, London SW7 2BZ, United Kingdom
Abstract: Many hardware designs, especially those for signal and image processing, involve structured data access such as queues, stacks and stripes. This paper presents parametric descriptions as abstractions for such structured data access, and explains how these abstractions can be supported either as FPGA libraries targeting existing reconfigurable hardware devices, or as dedicated logic implementations forming Autonomous Memory Blocks (AMBs). Scalable architectures combining the address generation logic in AMBs together to provide larger storage with parallel data access, are also examined. The effectiveness of this approach is illustrated with size and performance estimates for our FPGA libraries and dedicated logic implementations of AMBs. It is shown that for two-dimensional filtering, the dedicated AMBs can be 7 times smaller and 5 times faster than the FPGA libraries performing the same function. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Abstracting; Computer architecture; Computer hardware; Data transfer; Digital libraries; Energy storage; Mathematical models; Program compilers; First-in-first-out (FIFO); First-in-multiple-out (FIMO); Last-in-first-out (LIFO); Processing in memory (PIM); Field programmable gate arrays

Title: The hydrogen economy and compressed hydrogen
Source title: IMechE Event Publications
Affiliations: Centre for Energy Policy and Technology, Imperial College London, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Hart, D., Centre for Energy Policy and Technology, Imperial College London, United Kingdom
Abstract: Increasing political interest in future energy supplies, combined with tightening environmental requirements and strong technology development, is leading to significant international activity in the use of hydrogen as a fuel. Hydrogen can be produced from a wide range of sources, with potentially low environmental consequences. It can be used in both transport and stationary energy applications. Hydrogen is already in some 200 test vehicles and 50 fuelling stations around the world, stored as gas at pressures of between 21 and 70MPa, or in liquid form, and dispensed rapidly into buses and cars. To ensure safety and performance targets can be met, technology developments in all areas are required, including production techniques, storage tanks, piping, valves, gauges, dispenser nozzles and safety and monitoring equipment. While some developments are incremental, entirely new concepts are also being brought into the market, and opportunities arise frequently in providing solutions to new problems. Hydrogen's properties as a very light gas, with small molecules and the potential to embrittle or otherwise react with certain materials, render this area fertile for both research and practical solutions. In the future, the use of hydrogen as fuel may be much more widespread, with concomitant opportunities for industry. © IMechE 2004.
Index Keywords: Biomass; Electricity; Energy storage; Environmental impact; Hydrocarbons; Natural gas; Oxidation; Piping systems; Societies and institutions; Hydrogen energy systems; Hydrogen properties; Renewable electricity; Stream reforming; Hydrogen fuels

Authors: Járdán R.K., Nagy I., Schendl N.
Title: Enhanced utilisation of solar radiation for the generation of electric energy
Source title: IEEE AFRICON Conference
Affiliations: Budapest University of Technology and Economics, Department of Automation and Applied Informatics, Hungary
Authors with affiliations: Járdán, R.K., Budapest University of Technology and Economics, Department of Automation and Applied Informatics, Hungary; Nagy, I., Budapest University of Technology and Economics, Department of Automation and Applied Informatics, Hungary; Schendl, N., Budapest University of Technology and Economics, Department of Automation and Applied Informatics, Hungary
Abstract: In the paper a system is proposed for converting an increased portion of the energy, obtained from solar radiation, into electric energy. The utilisation of solar energy can be made by photovoltaic (PV) cells to generate electric power directly and solar thermal (T) panels can be applied to generate heat power. In the system studied combined Photovoltaic/Thermal panels are connected to a heat/electric energy conversion unit that consists of a heat conversion and a turbine-generator-converter section, connected to the utility mains or a group of loads, while the electric power obtained from the PV part of the combined panels is converted to suitable form by a system consisting of a charge controller, a battery and a dc/ac converter. In the paper a part of the simulation studies, carried out to determine the energy balance in the PV section of the system is shown in detail. A block diagram developed for studying the energy balance and simulation results are presented showing the battery charge vs. time as well as the photovoltaic cell current and the battery current.
Author Keywords: Renewable energy sources; Simulation
Index Keywords: Charge controller; Electric energy; Heat power; Thermal panels; AC machinery; Computer simulation; DC machinery; Electric energy storage; Electric power generation; Energy conservation; Photovoltaic cells; Renewable energy resources; Solar radiation

Authors: Van Niekerk C.R., Van Schoor G., Pritchard J.F.
Title: Linear model of a closed three-shaft Brayton cycle
Source title: IEEE AFRICON Conference
Authors with affiliations: Van Niekerk, C.R.; Van Schoor, G.; Pritchard, J.F.
Abstract: A linear model of a closed three-shaft Brayton cycle is developed. The model is intended to give an understanding of the dominant dynamic behavior in a nuclear power system that utilizes a closed three-shaft Brayton cycle. The insights gained from the model can be used for system design as well as for the design of control algorithms. Linear models of the turbines and compressors are developed, followed by models of the shafts and the volumes inside the circuit Thereafter, the system equations are derived from the component models and put into state space format. Finally, a time domain comparison is made between the linear system model and the responses predicted by the thermal-fluid analysis software program, Flownex.
Author Keywords: Brayton cycle; Control design; Dominant dynamic behavior; Flownex; Linear model
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Brayton cycle; Energy storage; Mathematical models; Nuclear reactors; Time domain analysis; Control design; Dominant dynamic behavior; Flownex; Linear models; Nuclear power plants

Title: Model of a photovoltaic fuel-cell generator
Source title: IEEE AFRICON Conference
Authors with affiliations: Kheswa, E.F.M.; Davidson, I.E.
Abstract: Distributed generation (DG) system ranging in size from a few kilowatts up to 50 MW refers to a variety of small, modular power-generating technologies connected to the electric grid which combined with energy management and storage systems to improve the operation of electricity delivery systems. DG provides solutions to two long standing problems of power system operation: non-availability at all times of sufficient power generation to meet peak demands and the lack of capacity of existing transmission lines to carry all the electricity needed by consumers. Installing DG at or near a customer load can eliminate the need to upgrade existing transmission and distribution networks to handle the extra power requirement. The paper presents a model of the photovoltaic fuel generator (PVFC) for localized load management. Results obtained for dynamic and steady-state characteristics are presented and discussed. Photovoltaic systems employ direct current motors; therefore understanding of the system operation and the matching of the system components for a particular PV system, dc motor type, and load type are important factors of this system design. The performance of dc motor powered by PV generator connected the load, were analysed with respect to the transient (starting) and steady state operation. Since the PV generator is a non-linear and time dependent power supply with output that varies with the insolation (hourly and daily). In all cases the dc motor load is more compatible with the PV generator.
Author Keywords: Distributed Generation; Dynamic modelling; Fuel Cells; Hybrid Energy systems; Photovoltaic
Index Keywords: DC motors; Electric generators; Electric lines; Electric loads; Electric power distribution; Energy management; Fuel cells; Systems analysis; Distributed generation; Dynamic modeling; Hybrid energy systems; Photovoltaic; Photovoltaic cells

Authors: Ahmed T., Nagai S., Nakaoka M., Lee H.W.
Title: Two-switch auxiliary quasi-resonant DC link snubber-assisted voltage source three-phase V-connection soft-switching sinewave inverter with bidirectional soft-switching chopper for solar PV power conditioner
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)
Affiliations: Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan; Electric Energy Saving Research Center, Kyungnam University, Masan, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Ahmed, T., Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan; Nagai, S., Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan; Nakaoka, M., Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan, Electric Energy Saving Research Center, Kyungnam University, Masan, South Korea; Lee, H.W., Electric Energy Saving Research Center, Kyungnam University, Masan, South Korea
Abstract: This paper is concerned with a novel proposal of the utility AC interactive three-phase soft commutation sinewave PWM power conditioner developed for solar photovoltaic power generation system and parallel processing UPS with new type battery and super capacitor energy storage devices. The prototype of this power conditioner is composed of two quadrant soft switching PWM chopper with step-up and step-down voltage operating modes, three-phase V-connection soft switching PWM inverter incorporating a single two-switch auxiliary resonant DC link snubber into one phase of three-phase bridge legs with divided capacitors, and the three-phase utility AC power source grid. The operating principle of the proposed power conversion conditioning circuit and system including some unique features and based upon high-frequency soft switching sinewave PWM scheme is described and discussed. The operating performances; waveform quality and actual efficiency of cost effective utility interactive power conversion conditioning and processing circuit treated here are evaluated and discussed on the basis of experimental data. ©2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Power conditioner; Power conversion; Resonant snubbers; Snubber capacitors; Electrolysis; Electrolytic capacitors; Photovoltaic cells; Power generation; Pulse width modulation; Resonance; Voltage measurement; Electric inverters

Title: Does zero instantaneous reactive power guarantee zero reactive power under asymmetric voltage condition?
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)
Affiliations: Dept. of Electronics, Pukyong National University, 599-1 Daeyon 3-Dong, Nam-Ku Busan, South Korea; Virginia Polytechnic Institute, State University, Whittemore Hall, Blacksburg, VA 24061-0179, United States

Abstract: The instantaneous reactive power concept has attracted much attention since its proposal. It has been exclaimed that reactive powers can be compensated instantly without energy storage system under asymmetric voltage condition, which received doubts from some authors. However, theoretcal criticism has not been given clearly. In this paper, theoretical criticism and example are given to show that zero instantaneous reactive power does not mean zero reactive power under asymmetric voltage condition. © 2004 IEEE.

Abstract: This paper presents the loss model and characteristic comparison of a Three-Level converter and a Full-Bridge converter through the conduction loss analysis of power devices. It shows the main reason of efficiency diminution, comparing of a Full-Bridge converter with a Three-Level converter. Also, the loss analysis of each component and the various losses in the circuit are proposed in this paper. The result of the analysis is verified with 2.5 kW prototype. © 2004 IEEE.

Title: Design and FEM analysis of a flywheel energy storage system assisted by integrated magnetic bearings
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)
Affiliations: Center for Advanced Power Electronics, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, C., Center for Advanced Power Electronics, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore; Tseng, K.J., Center for Advanced Power Electronics, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore
Abstract: This paper presents a compact and novel flywheel energy storage system. The flywheel acts as the rotor of the drive system and is sandwiched between two disk type stators. Concepts of magnetic levitation and axial-flux PM synchronous machine are incorporated to assist the rotor-flywheel to spin and remain in magnetic suspension in the gravitational axis. Three-dimensional finite element method is applied for studying the flux linkage, induced voltage, levitation force and rotational torque of the system. The analysis results support the feasibility of the proposed system. © 2004 IEEE.

Authors: Rieche S., Petrak L., Wehrle K.
Title: A thermal-dissipation-based approach for balancing data load in distributed hash tables
Source title: Proceedings - Conference on Local Computer Networks, LCN
Affiliations: Protocol Engineering and Distributed Systems Group, University of Tübingen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Rieche, S., Protocol Engineering and Distributed Systems Group, University of Tübingen, Germany; Petrak, L., Protocol Engineering and Distributed Systems Group, University of Tübingen, Germany; Wehrle, K., Protocol Engineering and Distributed Systems Group, University of Tübingen, Germany
Abstract: A major objective of Peer-to-Peer (P2P) systems is the management of large amounts of data distributed across many systems. Distributed Hash Tables (DHT) are designed for highly scalable, self-organizing, and efficient distribution and lookup of data, whereby data is stored globally persistent. The range of values of the corresponding hash function is partitioned and each interval is assigned to a node of the DHT. Because the assignment of data to nodes is based on hash functions, one assumes that the respective data load is distributed evenly across all participating nodes. However, most DHTs show difficulties with load balancing as we will demonstrate in this paper. As a solution for this problem, we present a new and very simple approach for balancing stored data between peers in a fashion analogous to the dissipation of heat energy in materials. We compare this algorithm with other approaches for load balancing and present results based on simulations and a prototype implementation. This new algorithm improves the distribution of load in DHTs without requiring major changes of the DHTs themselves. In addition, we show that the fault tolerance of Peer-to-Peer systems is increased by the proposed algorithm. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Data load; Distributed hash tables (DHT); Peer-to-peer (P2P) systems; Thermal-dissipation; Algorithms; Computational complexity; Computer simulation; Data acquisition; Data storage equipment; Energy dissipation; Fault tolerant computer systems; Problem solving; Servers; Table lookup; Distributed database systems

Authors: Pérez J., Cárdenas V., Miranda H., Álvarez R.
Title: Compensation of voltage sags and swells using a single-phase AC-AC converter
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)
Affiliations: Centre de Investigación y Estudios de Posgrado, Facultad de Ingeniería, Zona Universitaria, Manuel Nava #8, 78290, San Luis Potosi, S.L.P., Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Pérez, J., Centre de Investigación y Estudios de Posgrado, Facultad de Ingeniería, Zona Universitaria, Manuel Nava #8, 78290, San Luis Potosi, S.L.P., Mexico; Cárdenas, V., Centre de Investigación y Estudios de Posgrado, Facultad de Ingeniería, Zona Universitaria, Manuel Nava #8, 78290, San Luis Potosi, S.L.P., Mexico; Miranda, H., Centre de Investigación y Estudios de Posgrado, Facultad de Ingeniería, Zona Universitaria, Manuel Nava #8, 78290, San Luis Potosi, S.L.P., Mexico; Álvarez, R., Centre de Investigación y Estudios de Posgrado, Facultad de Ingeniería, Zona Universitaria, Manuel Nava #8, 78290, San Luis Potosi, S.L.P., Mexico
Abstract: In this paper, a topology to compensate voltage sags and swells simultaneously in critical loads is proposed. It consists in a single-phase AC-AC converter in a matrix arrangement, which keeps a continuous regulation in the output voltage. The proposed scheme has the capability to compensate up to 25% voltage sags and 50% voltage swells. Energy storage devices are not required by the AC-AC converter and it is connected between the AC mains and the load by using a series transformer. One of the advantages of this topology is that taps for the coupling transformer are no necessary to change the polarity of the compensation voltage. A four step switching technique is used to drive the AC-AC converter switches, executing snubber-less operation. The reference signal is generated using single-phase d-q theory, obtaining a fast response time and high regulation. Simulation and experimental results of a 5kW capacity, 127V, 60Hz equipment are presented. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electric potential; Electric transformers; Energy efficiency; Voltage control; Converter analysis; Power operations; Voltage sags; Voltage swells; Analog to digital conversion

Authors: Yun M.-S., Lee W.-C., Suh I., Hyun D.-S.
Title: A new control scheme of unified power quality compensator - Q with minimum power injection
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, HanYang University, HaengDang Dong, SungDong Gu, 133-791, Seoul, South Korea; Department of Electrical Engineering, HanKyong National University, An-Sung, KyongGi Do, South Korea; Power and Industrial Systems R and D Center, Hyosung Corporation, Seoul, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Yun, M.-S., Department of Electrical Engineering, HanYang University, HaengDang Dong, SungDong Gu, 133-791, Seoul, South Korea; Lee, W.-C., Department of Electrical Engineering, HanKyong National University, An-Sung, KyongGi Do, South Korea; Suh, I., Power and Industrial Systems R and D Center, Hyosung Corporation, Seoul, South Korea; Hyun, D.-S., Department of Electrical Engineering, HanYang University, HaengDang Dong, SungDong Gu, 133-791, Seoul, South Korea
Abstract: Voltage sags are one of the most frequently occurring power quality problems challenging the power systems today. The Unified Power Quality Conditioner (UPQC) is one of the major custom power solutions that are capable of mitigating the effect of supply voltage sags at the load or Point of Common Coupling (PCC). A UPQC-Q employs a control method in which the series compensator injects a voltage that leads the supply current by 90° so that the series compensator at steady state consumes no active power. However, the UPQC-Q has the disadvantage that its series compensator needs to be overrated. Thus it cannot offers effective compensation. This paper proposes a new control scheme for the UPQC-Q that offers minimum power injection. The proposed minimum power injection method takes into consideration the limits on the rated voltage capacity of the series compensator and its control scheme. The validity of the proposed control scheme is investigated through simulation and experimental results. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electric impedance; Electric potential; Energy storage; Passive filters; Problem solving; Reactive power; Signal interference; Minimum power injection; Point of common coupling (PCC); Unified power quality compensators; Wide spread automation; Electric power systems

Title: Investigation of voltage dip restorer using square wave inverter
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)

Abstract: The concept of square wave compensation is studied for the application to the voltage dip restorer in this paper. Both single square wave and dual square wave are used in this analysis. Both methods have shown to have a fast dynamic response as compared to sinusoidal compensation. The dual square wave can also compensate for the zero-crossing and the distortion is small. Experimental results confirm the proposed method. © 2004 IEEE.

Authors: Kim J.-B., Park N.-J., Lee D.-Y., Hyun D.-S.
Title: A simple control scheme for DC output ripple voltage suppression in BIFRED with a small-sized energy storage capacitor
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, HanYang University, HaengDang Dong, SungDong Gu, 133-791, Seoul, South Korea

Abstract: This paper presents a technique to reduce the low frequency ripple voltage of the dc output in a BIFRED converter with a small-sized energy storage capacitor. The proposed pulse width control method can be effectively used to suppress the low frequency ripple appeared in the dc output and still shows generally good performance such as low THD of input line current and high power factor. Using the small-sized energy storage capacitor, it has better merits of low cost and small size than a conventional BIFRED converter. The proposed technique is illustrated its validity and effectiveness through simulations. © 2004 IEEE.

Authors: Schoellhammer T., Osterweil E., Greenstein B., Wimbrow M., Estrin D.
Title: Lightweight temporal compression of microclimate datasets
Source title: Proceedings - Conference on Local Computer Networks, LCN
Affiliations: University of California Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, United States; University of California, Idyllwild, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schoellhammer, T., University of California Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, United States; Osterweil, E., University of California Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, United States; Greenstein, B., University of California Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, United States; Wimbrow, M., University of California, Idyllwild, CA, United States; Estrin, D., University of California Los Angeles, Los Angeles, CA, United States
Abstract: Since the inception of sensor networks, in-network processing has been touted as the enabling technology for long-lived deployments. Radio communication is the overriding consumer of energy in such networks. Therefore, data reduction before transmission, either by compression or feature extraction, will directly and significantly increase network lifetime. In many cases, it is premature to begin implementing feature extraction techniques. Users do not yet understand in what forms interesting data will appear and consequently can't risk automatically discarding what they presume to be uninteresting. Moreover, computer scientists are only beginning to develop algorithms to collect spatially distributed features in situ. Even for the many application where all of the data must be transported out of the network, data may be compressed before transport, so long as the chosen compression technique can operate under the stringent resource constraints of low-power nodes and induces only tolerable errors. This paper evaluates a simple temporal compression scheme designed specifically to be used by mica motes for the compaction of microclimate data. The algorithm makes use of the observation that over a small enough window of time, samples of microclimate data are linear. It finds such windows and generates a series of line segments that accurately represent the data. It compresses data up to 20-to-1 while introducing error on the order of the sensor hardware's specified margin of error. Further-more it is simple, consumes little CPU and requires very little storage when compared to other compression techniques. This paper describes the technique and results using a dataset from a one-year microclimate deployment. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: In network processing; Lossless compression techniques; Microclimate deployment; Sensor networks; Algorithms; Data processing; Data reduction; Feature extraction; Program processors; Radio communication; Sensor data fusion

Title: A new minimal energy control of the DC link energy in four-wire dynamic voltage restorer
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)

Authors with affiliations: Hosseini, S.H., Tabriz University, Faculty of Engineering, Department of Electrical and electronics Engineering, Iran; Banaei, M.R., Tabriz University, Faculty of Engineering, Department of Electrical and electronics Engineering, Iran
Abstract: The quality of electrical energy supply such as voltage sag is becoming more important for sensitive loads. This paper deals with four-wire dynamic voltage restorer (DVR), which is a series device that generates an AC voltage and injects it in series with the supply voltage through an injection transformer to compensate the voltage sag. In this paper the techniques of correcting the supply voltage sag in a distribution feeder is presented. In addition, a new concept of restoration techniques is proposed to inject minimum energy based on given apparent power for DVR during compensation. Simulation results carried out by PSCAD/EMTDC, show that the proposed method could be minimizing the injection real power of DVR with given apparent power. ©2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Dynamic voltage restorer (DVR); Energy injection; Neutral wires; Voltage sags; DC machinery; Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electric potential; Electric wire; Power control; Pulse width modulation; Electric power systems

Authors: Liserre M., Klumpner C., Blaabjerg F., Monopoli V.G., Dell'Aquila A.
Title: Evaluation of the ride-through capability of an active-front-end adjustable speed drive under real grid conditions
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)

Orabona 4, 70125 Bari, Italy; Dell'Aquila, A., DEE, Politecnico di Bari, Via E. Orabona 4, 70125 Bari, Italy
Abstract: Better quality of the input currents, unity power factor and regenerative capability are not the only benefits of equipping an Adjustable Speed Drive (ASD) with an active front-end stage. Controlling the power inflow may enable also the reduction of the de-link energy storage, which will then lead to the replacement of the electrolytic capacitors with film capacitors, which have lower energy density meaning that the volume is similar, but will increase the ASD lifetime. In these circumstances, operation under unbalanced and distorted supply voltage as well as high dynamic operation of the ASD makes the control task more challenging. The aim of this paper is to investigate the ride-through capability of an ASD with active front-end under real grid conditions and in view of the minimum de-link storage. Experiments validate the theoretical analysis. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Adjustable speed drives (ASD); Control complexity; Grid currents; Real grid conditions; Capacitors; Electric current control; Electric energy storage; Electric inverters; Electric potential; Power control; Variable speed drives

Authors: Kinjo T., Senjyu T., Urasaki N., Fujita H.
Title: Output levelling of wind power generation system by EDLC energy storage
Source title: IECON Proceedings (Industrial Electronics Conference)
Affiliations: University of the Ryukyus, Japan; Chubu Electric Power Co., Inc., Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kinjo, T., University of the Ryukyus, Japan; Senjyu, T., University of the Ryukyus, Japan; Urasaki, N., University of the Ryukyus, Japan; Fujita, H., Chubu Electric Power Co., Inc., Japan
Abstract: Utilization of renewable energy are coming up from view points of environmental conservation and depletion of fossil fuel. However, the generated power from renewable energies is always fluctuating due to environmental status. Energy storage system is indispensable to compensate these fluctuating components. Energy capacitor system (ECaSS) connected an electric double-layer capacitor (EDLC) with power-electronics devices is useful for the compensation of fluctuating power since one is capable of controlling both active and reactive power simultaneously. This paper proposes the current-source ECaSS (CS-ECS), which consists of EDLC, buck-boost DC-DC converter, and bi-directional inverter. We have presented the control system for the active/reactive power control of CS-ECS, and have shown the effectiveness of CS-ECS through computer simulations for case of wind power generation system. ©2004 IEEE.

Authors: Sharmeela C., Uma G., Mohan M.R., Karthikeyan K.
Title: Multi-level distribution STATCOM for reducing the effect of voltage sag and swell
Source title: 2004 International Conference on Power System Technology, POWERCON 2004
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, CEG, Anna University, Chennai-600025, India
Authors with affiliations: Sharmeela, C., Department of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, CEG, Anna University, Chennai-600025, India; Uma, G., Department of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, CEG, Anna University, Chennai-600025, India; Mohan, M.R., Department of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, CEG, Anna University, Chennai-600025, India; Karthikeyan, K., Department of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, CEG, Anna University, Chennai-600025, India
Abstract: Multi-level power conversion has been receiving increasing attention in the past few years for high power applications. The unique structure of the multi-level Voltage Source Converter (VSC) allows it to reach high voltages with low harmonics without the use of transformers or series-connected, synchronised switching devices. The diode clamped multi-level VSC with simple configuration and control structure finds application as Distribution-STATCOM in custom power conditioners. This inverter has emerged as a solution for high power applications. The main purpose of the proposed diode clamped D-STATCOM is that it injects reactive power in shunt with a distribution feeder. It reduces the short-term voltage sags, swells and momentary interruptions. This paper presents the multi-level D-STATCOM configuration consisting of a five level voltage source converter, a DC energy storage device, a coupling transformer and associated control circuits. The control is based on sinusoidal PWM and only requires the measurement of the RMS voltage at the load point PSCAD/EMTDC simulation tool is used for modeling and simulation. Extensive simulation results are presented to verify the dynamic performance of multi-level D-STATCOM with two level D-STATCOM. © 2004 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Custom power; D-STATCOM; Multi-level inverter; PSCAD/EMTDC; SPWM; VSC

Title: A new operation framework of demand-side energy storage system cooperated with power system operation
Source title: 2004 International Conference on Power System Technology, POWERCON 2004

Abstract: Energy storage systems have increasingly been expected as a means of load leveling of the annual load factor in Japan. The demand-side energy storage system has the effects for not only improving load factor, but also for black out compensation or voltage sags. So it is expected to become wide spread in future. Then the authors proposed a method that the energy storage systems at customer side are used for a congestion relief on transmission networks. Consequently it is cleared in this paper that which kind of customers has the effect of relieving transmission line congestion. First of all, the authors determine the optimal configuration of energy system including energy storage system. By using an optimal power flow with unit commitment as an evaluation index of electric utility, this paper evaluates the possibility that gives cost merit to both the electric utility and the customer from economic point of view. © 2004 IEEE.

Authors: Ohtaka T., Uchida A., Iwamoto S.
Title: A voltage control strategy with NAS battery systems considering interconnection of distributed generations
Source title: 2004 International Conference on Power System Technology, POWERCON 2004
Affiliations: Waseda University, Japan; Central Research Institute of Electric Industry, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ohtaka, T., Waseda University, Japan, Central Research Institute of Electric Industry, Japan; Uchida, A., Waseda University, Japan; Iwamoto, S., Waseda University, Japan
Abstract: Recent years, some distributed generations such as energy storage systems or renewable energy sources have been introduced in distribution systems, and the voltage violation problem has been at stake by the reverse power flows from the load to the generator. In this paper, we consider NAS (Natrium Sulfur = Sodium Sulfur) battery systems to be utilized for not only energy storage but also power system control, and propose a new voltage control strategy in order to provide the proper sending voltage at distribution substations. First, the current flows at each distribution feeder are individually measured, and the sending voltage is calculated by using V-I characteristics which indicate the relationship between the sending voltage and the current flows at each distribution feeder. Next, active and reactive power outputs of the NAS battery system are determined by solving an optimal power flow calculation in order to realize the predetermined sending voltage. Numerical examinations have been carried out using a 52 bus example system model to verify the validity of the proposed method, and successful results have been obtained. © 2004 lEEE.
Author Keywords: Dispersed storage and generation; Energy storage; Load flow analysis; Voltage control
Index Keywords: Electric converters; Electric industry; Electric potential; Electric power system interconnection; Electric utilities; Energy storage; Voltage control; Dispersed storage and generation; Independent power producers (IPP); Load flow analysis; Power producer and supplier (PPS); Electric batteries

Authors: Naidu S.R., Mascarenhas A.W., Fernandes D.A.
Title: A software phase-locked loop for unbalanced and distorted utility conditions
Source title: 2004 International Conference on Power System Technology, POWERCON 2004
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Universidade Federal de Campina Grande, PB 58.109-970, Brazil; Area-1 (Industry) Department, Centro Federal de Educação Tecnológica de Pernambuco, Pesqueira, PE 55.200-000, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Naidu, S.R., Department of Electrical Engineering, Universidade Federal de Campina Grande, PB 58.109-970, Brazil; Mascarenhas, A.W., Area-1 (Industry) Department, Centro Federal de Educação Tecnológica de Pernambuco, Pesqueira, PE 55.200-000, Brazil; Fernandes, D.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, Universidade Federal de Campina Grande, PB 58.109-970, Brazil
Abstract: A software phase-locked loop (PLL) for custom power devices is described in this paper. The PLL uses the previous and current samples of the 3-phase utility voltages and separates them into the sequence components. The phase angle and frequency of the estimated positive sequence component are tracked by the first two stages of the PLL. The third stage estimates the parameter Δθ which is required by the first stage. Simulations of the performance of the PLL have been presented, as well as the performance of a dynamic voltage restorer incorporating the proposed PLL. The proposed PLL performs well under unbalanced and distorted utility conditions. It tracks the utility phase angle and frequency smoothly and also extracts the sequence components of the utility voltages. A DVR incorporating the PLL provides voltage support to sensitive loads and also acts as a harmonic filter. © 2004 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Dynamic voltage restorer; Phase detection; Phase-locked loop; Voltage sags
Index Keywords: Bandwidth; Computer simulation; Electric distortion; Electric inverters; Electric loads; Energy storage; Dynamic voltage restorer; Phase detection; Voltage sags; Voltage-source inverter; Phase locked loops

Title: Voltage sag and swell generator with series injected inverter for the KCPP
Source title: 2004 International Conference on Power System Technology, POWERCON 2004
Affiliations: LG Industrial Systems Co. Ltd., RandD Center, 533 HogaeDong, AynyangShi, KyungKiDo, 431-080, South Korea; Korea Electric Power Research Institute, Daejeon, South Korea

Ltd., RandD Center, 533 HogaeDong, AynyangShi, KyungKiDo, 431-080, South Korea; Jeon, Y.S., Korea Electric Power Research Institute, Daejeon, South Korea
Abstract: This paper proposes a new SSG (Sag and Swell Generator) with series injected inverter for the KCPP (Korea Custom Power Plaza), which is being constructed with the fund of the National Project in Korea. Main purpose of KCPP is to test and to evaluate several different kinds of high power CPD (Custom Power Device) under the several power disturbance conditions before installing it in real site. We can generate typical power disturbances such as sag, swell, over voltage, under voltage and voltage flicker by using the proposed SSG composed of series inverter, energy storage DC capacitor, rectifier and voltage clamp circuit. Also we can generate the distorted voltage waveforms and the phase jumping waveforms by controlling the series inverter. In this paper, three kinds of control methods for the proposed 2MVA SSG are given. Typical voltage sag and swell waveforms are implemented by adopting simple control method. Also the voltage flicker is generated by changing the amplitude of the injected voltage in random. Owing to the limited bandwidth of the proposed SSG, high frequency transient waveforms can be obtained by using the open loop control. The simulation and experimental results are given to verify the operation of the proposed SSG. Finally, conclusions will be given. © 2004 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Custom Power Devices; Power Quality; Voltage Sag; Voltage Swell

Authors: Sugihara H., Kawaguchi T., Tsuji K.
Title: A study on integrated control of home-cogeneration systems for contributions to power system operations
Source title: 2004 International Conference on Power System Technology, POWERCON 2004
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Graduate School of Engineering, Osaka University, Suita 2-1, Osaka, Japan

Abstract: In deregulated power systems, it is very important to make electricity demand more flexible in order to secure market-based system operation from power system operator's point of view. Also, as one of energy conservation technologies in Japanese residential houses, home-cogeneration systems such as gas engine-type and Polymer Electrolyte Fuel Cell-type (PEFC) is highly expected because exhausted heat of gas-engine or PEFC can be utilized for hot water demand. This paper assumes a new cooperation framework between cogeneration's owners and power system operator in order to attain more secure power system operation. In the cooperation framework, from cogeneration owner's point of view, the authors evaluate an influence of the integrated control of gas engine-type cogeneration systems on economic factor and energy conservation for cogeneration's owner. © 2004 IEEE.

Authors: Zhou F., Joós G., Abbey C., Jiao L.
Title: Optimal state control for CSI superconducting magnetic energy storage system
Source title: 2004 International Conference on Power System Technology, POWERCON 2004
Affiliations: McGill University, Montréal, Que. H3A 2A7, Canada; Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhou, F., McGill University, Montréal, Que. H3A 2A7, Canada; Joós, G., McGill University, Montréal, Que. H3A 2A7, Canada; Abbey, C., McGill University, Montréal, Que. H3A 2A7, Canada; Jiao, L., Tsinghua University, Beijing, 100084, China
Abstract: This paper discusses the design and analysis of the multivariable optimal state current source inverter control (feedback and feed-forward) for a superconducting magnetic energy storage system (SMES) for use in a wind farm. In optimal control, the control strategy is sought that gives the best control performance. High stability and robustness against parameter changes are two important advantages of optimal control. By using the method of translating three phase bilogic PWM signals to three phase trilogic PWM signal, EMTP-RV simulations show that trilogic PWM signals produced by this method can optimally handle stabilizing feedback signals. The AC side inverter has been modeled within the separated d-q-frame. This proposed method enables the independent control of the active and reactive components of the supply current vector, and thereby the ability to adjust the grid real power and reactive power through control of the SMES. Comparisons with a voltage source inverter SMES show that the current source inverter exhibits faster recovery of the wind farm voltage following a disturbance in the wind farm transmission line than voltage source inverter SMES. © 2004 IEEE.

Title: Multilevel dynamic voltage restorer

Authors with affiliations: Loh, P.C., Center for Advanced Power Electronics, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore; Vilathgamuwa, D.M., Center for Advanced Power Electronics, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore; Tang, S.K., Center for Advanced Power Electronics, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore; Long, H.L., Center for Advanced Power Electronics, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore
Abstract: This paper presents the implementation and control of a high voltage dynamic voltage restorer (HVDVR) for use in power distribution network to compensate for sags in utility voltages. The proposed HVDVR is implemented using a multilevel inverter topology with isolated dc energy storages, allowing the direct connection of the HVDVR to the distribution network without using a bulky and costly series injection transformer. A novel control algorithm, incorporating P+resonant and Posicast compensators, is also presented for controlling the HVDVR with perfect reference voltage tracking and effective damping of transient voltage oscillations at the instant of sag compensation. Lastly, simulation results are presented to verify the performance of the proposed multilevel HVDVR. © 2004 IEEE.

Title: Injecting power from a small wind turbine into a DC bus
Source title: 2004 International Conference on Power System Technology, POWERCON 2004
Affiliations: University of Sydney, NSW 2006, Australia; Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Turner, A.R., University of Sydney, NSW 2006, Australia; Sathiakumar, S., University of Sydney, NSW 2006, Australia; Lee, Y.S., Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Abstract: Wind energy is a dean and renewable alternative to fossil fuels. The bulk of currently available wind power is produced on large wind farms, which are operated by power companies. These wind farms use up vast amounts of space, and are usually located away from residential areas. One way to make better use of available land would be to allow institutions to install small windmills on their own properties. These small windmills would help to offset the load placed on the grid by the residence. A DC-DC converter for such application is presented which injects power from a small wind turbine into a site-wide DC bus. © 2004 IEEE.
Author Keywords: DC-DC power conversion; Maximum power tracker; Renewable energy; Windmill
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Electric utilities; Energy storage; Fossil fuels; Renewable energy resources; Solar energy; DC-DC power conversion; Maximum power tracker; Petrol station; Rotating blades; Wind turbines

Authors: Koeppel G., Geidl M., Andersson G.
Title: Value of storage devices in congestion constrained distribution networks
Source title: 2004 International Conference on Power System Technology, POWERCON 2004
Affiliations: Power Systems and High Voltage Laboratories, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology (ETH), Zurich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Koeppel, G., Power Systems and High Voltage Laboratories, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology (ETH), Zurich, Switzerland; Geidl, M., Power Systems and High Voltage Laboratories, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology (ETH), Zurich, Switzerland; Andersson, G., Power Systems and High Voltage Laboratories, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology (ETH), Zurich, Switzerland
Abstract: This paper investigates the value of storage devices in congestion constrained distribution networks. Subject of the investigations is a load which cannot be supplied with the desired security at all times during the day. It is analyzed what the requirements would be if a storage device would be installed at the load bus instead of network reinforcement To compare these two possible solutions, the implications on the load flow, including loss reduction and the possibility of local voltage control, are investigated. Furthermore the availability of a system with three lines is used to determine failure and repair rate requirements for a storage device. Finally some general economical considerations are outlined. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Congestion control (communication); Electric lines; Electric load management; Electric potential; Electric power distribution; Marketing; Problem solving; Congestion constraint distribution networks; Power quality; Storage devices; Supply reliability; Electric energy storage

Title: Ultracapacitor based ride-through system for a DC load
Source title: 2004 International Conference on Power System Technology, POWERCON 2004
Affiliations: Centre of Advanced Power Electronics, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Block S2, Nanyang Avenue, Singapore 639798, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Jayawickrama, Y.R.L., Centre of Advanced Power Electronics, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Block S2, Nanyang Avenue, Singapore 639798, Singapore; Rajakaruna, S., Centre of Advanced Power Electronics, School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Block S2, Nanyang Avenue, Singapore 639798, Singapore
Abstract: Ultracapacitor is an emerging energy storage device suitable for high-power, short-term applications. In this paper, a ride-through system for a DC load based on the ultracapacitors and a current-reversible buck-boost converter is analyzed. Compared to an equivalent battery operated converter in the boost mode with continuous inductor current, the control to output transfer function of the ultracapacitor-based converter has an additional right half plane zero located very close to the origin. As a result, the achievable bandwidth of the controller is very low and a steady-state error prevails in the load voltage if the controller is designed to operate in the stable mode. However, if zero steady-state error in the load voltage is desired, it can be achieved by operating the system with some degree of instability during the short period of disturbance. © 2004 IEEE.
Author Keywords: DC-DC converter; Ride-through system; Right Half Plane zero; Ultracapacitor
Index Keywords: DC-DC converter; Ride-through systems; Right half plane zero; Ultracapacitors; Bandwidth; Capacitors; Electric converters; Electric inductors; Electric potential; Matrix algebra; Transfer functions; Electric load management

Title: Power system stabiliser utilising Energy Storage
Source title: 2004 International Conference on Power System Technology, POWERCON 2004
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hung Hom, Hong Kong; Airport Authority, Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Sutanto, D., Department of Electrical Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hung Hom, Hong Kong; Tsang, M.W., Airport Authority, Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Abstract: This paper describes a power system stabiliser utilising energy storage. This is achieved by fast control of the charging and discharging of an Energy Storage System (ESS) to improve the stability of an electric power system. To demonstrate the capability of the proposed controller, dynamic and transient stability studies have been carried out for a single machine connected to an infinite bus system as well as for an interconnected multi-machine system. The simulation studies have included a detailed model of the generator including its excitation controller and governor, as well as a comprehensive ESS model, including the DC battery model and the switch operation associated with the power converter. © 2004 IEEE.

Authors: Arnold C.B., Kim H., Ollinger M., Sutto T.E., Piqué A.
Title: Manufacture of mesoscale energy storage systems by laser-direct write
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Princeton Institute for Science and Technology of Materials, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544, United States; Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Naval Surface Warfare Center, Dahlgren, VA 22448, United States
Authors with affiliations: Arnold, C.B., Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Princeton Institute for Science and Technology of Materials, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544, United States; Kim, H., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Ollinger, M., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States; Sutto, T.E., Naval Surface Warfare Center, Dahlgren, VA 22448, United States; Piqué, A., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC 20375, United States
Abstract: The development of micro power systems, on the mm size scale, is necessary for emerging technologies in small, portable micro-electronic device applications. Direct-write processes are used to produce the high-power, low-power, and recharging elements of such mesoscale micro power systems. Successful fabrication of alkaline and lithium based micro-batteries, micro-ultracapacitors, and dye-sensitized micro-solar cells are possible on various low processing temperature and flexible substrates using laser direct-write approaches that are ideally suited for the many different structurally complex electrochemical materials used in these systems. Increased areal energy density is realized by depositing thick layers > 10 μm, while maintaining patterns as small as 2 mm2. Micro-ultracapacitors exhibit high power densities > 250 mW/cm2, while primary alkaline microbatteries exhibit open circuit potentials of 1.5 V with high capacities and discharge currents up to 1 mA. Secondary LiCoO2 and LiMn 2O4 based microbatteries employing a novel nanocomposite solid-state electrolyte exhibit open circuit potentials > 4 V and have shown multiple recharging cycles without loss of capacity. Results of the different systems will be discussed with particular emphasis on the combination of elements to produce hybrid micro power systems.
Author Keywords: Laser direct write; MEMS; Micro power; Microbattery; Photovoltaics; Ultracapacitor
