Title: A selective boost equalizer for series connected NiMH battery packs
Source title: IEEE Workshop on Power Electronics in Transportation
Affiliations: Elec. and Comp. Eng. Department, Lake Superior State University, Sault Ste. Marie, MI 49783, United States; Electrical Engineering Department, University of Toledo, Toledo, OH 43606, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hande, A., Elec. and Comp. Eng. Department, Lake Superior State University, Sault Ste. Marie, MI 49783, United States; Stuart, T.A., Electrical Engineering Department, University of Toledo, Toledo, OH 43606, United States
Abstract: A unique selective equalization method has been developed to equalize nickel metal hydride (NiMH) battery packs. This technique uses a new selective boost equalizer that detects batteries either at a very low state of charge (SOC) or at an extremely high SOC. In this system a set of electromechanical relays is connected in a matrix to route boost current to the weaker batteries. A 32-bit microcontroller is used to control the relay switching, and the boost current is supplied by a separate boost charger. Once a weak battery is detected, it is scheduled for a specific boost tune by a special "round robin" algorithm. The equalizer was tested on a pack of twelve series connected 12V 93 ampere hour NiMH batteries. Test results show that the equalizer was able to re-balance an artificially unbalanced pack, and the capacity was increased by 27% within six charge-discharge cycles. The number of cycles required to re-balance the pack was significantly reduced by using the "round robin" algorithm. ©2004 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Batteries; Equalizer; Hybrid electric vehicle; Nickel metal hydride
Index Keywords: Battery management systems (BMS); Equalization techniques; Hybrid electric vehicles; Nickel metal hydride; Electric potential; Electric vehicles; Electrochemistry; Energy storage; Equalizers; Lithium batteries; Nickel compounds; Secondary batteries

Authors: Cho H.Y., Gao W., Ginn III H.L.
Title: A new power control strategy for hybrid fuel cell vehicles
Source title: IEEE Workshop on Power Electronics in Transportation
Affiliations: Ctr. for Advanced Vehicular Systems, Mississippi State University, Mississippi State, MS 39762, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cho, H.Y., Ctr. for Advanced Vehicular Systems, Mississippi State University, Mississippi State, MS 39762, United States; Gao, W., Ctr. for Advanced Vehicular Systems, Mississippi State University, Mississippi State, MS 39762, United States; Ginn III, H.L., Ctr. for Advanced Vehicular Systems, Mississippi State University, Mississippi State, MS 39762, United States
Abstract: A new power control strategy is proposed to improve fuel economy for hybrid fuel cell vehicles (FCVs) through the consideration of fuel cell system efficiency and battery energy management. In order to show power flows and the improvement of fuel economy due to the proposed power control strategy, an overall vehicle simulation is performed and analyzed. The simulation results are compared with the results of two fuel cell vehicles with different configurations and control strategies, namely, a semi-hybrid FCV and a non-hybrid FCV. The results demonstrate that the new control strategy can significantly improve fuel economy. In particular, for FUDS cycle, the fuel economy of the hybrid FCV with the new control strategy is increased by 7.36% with respect to the semi-hybrid FCV and 14.69% with respect to the non-hybrid FCV; for US06 cycle, the fuel economy is increased by 5.9% with respect to the semi-hybrid FCV and 7.27% with respect to the non-hybrid FCV. ©2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: AC motors; Electric vehicles; Electrochemistry; Energy management; Energy storage; Fuel economy; Polymethyl methacrylates; Power control; Fuel cell systems; Fuel cell vehicles (FCV); Hybrid electric vehicles (HEV); Hybridization; Fuel cells

Title: Ultra-capacitor augmentation of the vehicle electrical system to reset its power budget
Source title: IEEE Workshop on Power Electronics in Transportation
Affiliations: J-N-J Miller Design Services, PLC, Cedar, MI 49621, United States; VP, Technology Systems, Maxwell Technologies, Inc., San Diego, CA 92123, United States
Authors with affiliations: Miller, J.M., J-N-J Miller Design Services, PLC, Cedar, MI 49621, United States; Everett, M., VP, Technology Systems, Maxwell Technologies, Inc., San Diego, CA 92123, United States
Abstract: Average electrical burden in passenger vehicles, cars and light trucks, has escalated in recent years from 500 W to 700 W and higher. Year over year growth in electrical loads is now between 100W to 150W with no end in sight. OEM's maintain that a 14V electrical system can sustain such growth and moreover, that 14V electrified ancillaries are containable as well. With alternator technology now exceeding 3000W and currents above 200A it is incumbent upon the industry to evaluate means to reset the vehicle power budget. This paper argues that such power budget resetting may be realized economically using existing 14V alternator and battery technology but augmenting the vehicle charging system with a 28V ultra-capacitor module. The series connected battery and ultra-capacitor module provide regulated 42V for high power electrical loads leaving the base 14V system unchanged. © 2004 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Distributed modules; Ultra-capacitors; Vehicle power and propulsion technologies
Index Keywords: Amplifiers (electronic); Automobile transmissions; Capacitors; Electric power systems; Electric rectifiers; Electronic equipment; Energy storage; Power transmission; Distributed modules; Honda Motor Company (CO); Ultra-cpacitors; Vehicle power and propulsion techniques; Electric vehicles

Authors: Guastavino F., Ferrari P., Mariani M., Martini L., Matrone A., Ottonello L., Torello E.
Title: Partial discharges measurements performed on cryogenic joints
Source title: Annual Report - Conference on Electrical Insulation and Dielectric Phenomena, CEIDP
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Department, University of Genova, Genova, Italy; Ansaldo Ricerche s.r.l, Genova, Italy; Ansaldo-CRIS, Napoli, Italy; CESI S.p.A, Milano, Italy; Electrical Engineering Department, University of Genova, Via all'Opera Pia 11a, 16145 Genova, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Guastavino, F., Electrical Engineering Department, University of Genova, Genova, Italy, Electrical Engineering Department, University of Genova, Via all'Opera Pia 11a, 16145 Genova, Italy; Ferrari, P., Ansaldo Ricerche s.r.l, Genova, Italy; Mariani, M., Ansaldo-CRIS, Napoli, Italy; Martini, L., CESI S.p.A, Milano, Italy; Matrone, A., Ansaldo-CRIS, Napoli, Italy; Ottonello, L., Ansaldo Ricerche s.r.l, Genova, Italy; Torello, E., Electrical Engineering Department, University of Genova, Genova, Italy
Abstract: The Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) is based on a superconductive coil and it represents an ideal solution to store energy because the only losses are due to contact resistances and to the power used to maintain the low temperature. The current leads of the considered SMES, operating between room and liquid helium temperature, consist of a resistive and an High Temperature Superconducting (HTS) section. In this work the problems concerning the insulating system of the resistive section were investigated. These problems affect the copper wires insulating system and the aluminum nitride sheets interposed between two copper electrodes. A diagnostic tool based on partial discharges activity has been considered to obtain information about the resistive section insulating system and the aluminum nitride sheets status. Because of the whole insulating system of the resistive current lead was designed in order to guarantee 5 year of normal operation, accelerated electrical ageing tests were performed considering a more severe stress than the actual one applying a sinusoidal 50 Hz waveform; during the electrical ageing tests the signals relevant to partial discharges were acquired. The obtained results will be presented and discussed. ©2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Aluminum nitride; Copper; Cryogenics; Electric loads; Electric potential; Electric resistance; Electrodes; Helium; High temperature superconductors; Magnetic storage; Superconducting magnets; Wire; Copper wires; Cryogenic joints; Room temperature (RT); Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES); Partial discharges

Title: Improved angular velocity estimation for high performance sensorless PMSM
Source title: IEEE Workshop on Power Electronics in Transportation
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, Altoona College, United States
Authors with affiliations: Batzel, T.D., Department of Electrical Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, Altoona College, United States
Abstract: The permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) is increasingly playing an important role in electric propulsion systems due to its many advantages over competing technologies such as induction, reluctance, and dc motors. An encoder or resolver attached to the shaft of the motor typically supplies the feedback required for PMSM torque and velocity control. Many propulsion applications, however, cannot tolerate the use of these feedback devices because of reliability concerns in a harsh operating environment, space and weight limitations, and packaging issues. In this paper, a model-based sensorless PMSM drive strategy is presented with emphasis on an improved rotor angular velocity estimator. Through experimental results, the sensorless drive is shown to be robust to mechanical parameters and disturbances while providing the highly accurate rotor angle and velocity feedback that allows sensorless PMSM operation in high-performance vehicle propulsion systems. ©2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Angular velocity estimation; Permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSM); Rotor angle sensor; Vehicle propulsion systems; Electric drives; Electric propulsion; Energy storage; Error analysis; Induction motors; Permanent magnets; Rotors; Angle measurement

Title: Performance comparison of a fuel cell-battery hybrid powertrain and a fuel cell-ultracapacitor hybrid powertrain
Source title: IEEE Workshop on Power Electronics in Transportation
Affiliations: Ctr. for Advanced Vehicular Systems, Mississippi State University, Mississippi State, MS 39762, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gao, W., Ctr. for Advanced Vehicular Systems, Mississippi State University, Mississippi State, MS 39762, United States
Abstract: This paper studies two hybrid power systems for vehicle applications: a fuel cell-battery hybrid powertrain and a fuel cell-ultracapacitor hybrid powertrain. First, the characteristics of fuel cell, battery, and ultracapacitor as power sources are summarized. Then the configurations of the two types of hybrid fuel cell powertrains are presented. Finally, example hybrid powertrains are designed and simulated using ADVISOR. The simulation results indicate that ultracapacitors can more effectively assist the fuel cell to meet the vehicle power demand and help achieve a better performance and a higher fuel economy. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electric power systems; Energy efficiency; Energy storage; Fuel economy; Lithium batteries; Optimization; Resistors; Braking energy; Peukert's equation; Supercapacitors; Ultracapacitors; Fuel cells

Title: Dynamometer-based testing of a proof-of-concept fuel cell vehicle prototype
Source title: IEEE Workshop on Power Electronics in Transportation
Affiliations: University of Arkansas, Department of Electrical Engineering, 3217 Bell Engineering Center, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schupbach, R.M., University of Arkansas, Department of Electrical Engineering, 3217 Bell Engineering Center, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States; Balda, J.C., University of Arkansas, Department of Electrical Engineering, 3217 Bell Engineering Center, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States
Abstract: The work presented in this paper focuses on the Development of a 'proof-of-concept' fuel cell vehicle prototype using a dynamometer-based test bench. The main objective of this work is the validation of design ideas regarding the combination of two different energy storage devices (i.e., batteries and ultracapacitors) into an ESU for the power management of this vehicle. The implemented prototype is a simplified and scale-down version of the designed vehicle; however, the measured results show that the vehicle could greatly benefit from the combination of energy sources that are different in nature such as batteries and ultracapacitors. ©2004 IEEE.

Title: 8th IEEE Workshop on Power Electronics in Transportation, WPET 2004
Source title: IEEE Workshop on Power Electronics in Transportation
Abstract: The proceedings contain 23 papers from the 8th IEEE Workshop on Power Electronics in Transportation, WPET 2004. The topics discussed include: on-board power management; ultra-capacitor augmentation of the vehicle electrical system to reset its power budget; a R-Evolution in power electronics: from 'intelligent power' to 'super smart power' in automotive; an overview of cree silicon carbide power devices; temperature-dependent characterization of SiC power electronic devices; smart IGBTs for advanced distribution ignition systems; measurements of in-situ currents in a hybrid electric vehicle integrated power module using giant magnetoresistive sensors; and magnetic loss in AC motors in transportation.

Title: IPC driven dynamic associative cache architecture for low energy
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Conference on Computer Design: VLSI in Computers and Processors
Affiliations: Dept. of Elec. and Comp. Engineering, Iowa State University, Ames, IA 50011, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nadathur, S., Dept. of Elec. and Comp. Engineering, Iowa State University, Ames, IA 50011, United States; Tyagi, A., Dept. of Elec. and Comp. Engineering, Iowa State University, Ames, IA 50011, United States
Abstract: Existing schemes for cache energy optimization incorporate a limited degree of dynamic associativity: either direct mapped or full available associativity (say 4-way). In this paper, we explore a more general design space for dynamic associativity (for a 4-way associative cache, consider 1-way, 2-way, and 4-way associative accesses). The other major departure is in the associativity control mechanism. We use the actual instruction level parallelism exhibited by the instructions surrounding a given load to classify it as an IPC k load (for 1 ≤ k ≤ IW with an issue width of IW) in a superscalar architecture. The lookup schedule is fixed in advance for each IPC classifier 1 ≤ k ≤ IW. The schedules are as way-disjoint as possible for load/stores with different IPC classifications. The energy savings over SPEC2000 CPU benchmarks average 28.6% for a 32KB, 4-way, L-1 data cache. The resulting performance (IPC) degradation from the dynamic way schedule is restricted to less than 2.25%, mainly because IPC based placement ends up being an excellent classifier. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Cache architecture; Cycle times; Energy performance; Total processor energy; Approximation theory; Benchmarking; Computer architecture; Decoding; Energy efficiency; Optimization; Scheduling; Buffer storage

Authors: Park J.-W., Park G.-H., Park S.-B., Kim S.-D.
Title: Power-aware deterministic block allocation for low-power way-selective cache structure
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Conference on Computer Design: VLSI in Computers and Processors
Affiliations: CS, Yonsei University, 134, Shinchon-dong, Seoul, 120-749, South Korea; Processor Architecture Lab., System LSI Division, Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd., Giheung, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Park, J.-W., CS, Yonsei University, 134, Shinchon-dong, Seoul, 120-749, South Korea; Park, G.-H., Processor Architecture Lab., System LSI Division, Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd., Giheung, South Korea; Park, S.-B., Processor Architecture Lab., System LSI Division, Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd., Giheung, South Korea; Kim, S.-D., CS, Yonsei University, 134, Shinchon-dong, Seoul, 120-749, South Korea
Abstract: This paper proposes a power-aware cache block allocation algorithm for the way-selective set-associative cache on embedded systems to reduce energy consumption without additional delay or performance degradation. For this goal, way selection logic and specialized replacement policy are designed to enable only one way of set-associative cache as in the direct-mapped cache. Overall cache access time becomes almost the same as that of conventional set associative cache with accessing additional way selection logic. Because data array can be accessed without waiting for tag comparison, multiplexer delay can be removed totally. The simulation result shows that the proposed architecture can reduce a per access power consumption by 59% over conventional set-associative caches with average 0.06% of negligible performance loss. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computer simulation; Embedded systems; Energy utilization; Formal logic; Microprocessor chips; Natural frequencies; Block allocation; Cache structure; Data arrays; Performance degradation; Buffer storage

Title: Wireless sensor network for mobile surveillance systems
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Networked Embedded Syst. Department, TNO Phys. and Electronics Laboratory, Oude Waalsdorperweg 63, 2509 JG, The Hague, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van Dijk, G.J.A., Networked Embedded Syst. Department, TNO Phys. and Electronics Laboratory, Oude Waalsdorperweg 63, 2509 JG, The Hague, Netherlands; Maris, M.G., Networked Embedded Syst. Department, TNO Phys. and Electronics Laboratory, Oude Waalsdorperweg 63, 2509 JG, The Hague, Netherlands
Abstract: Guarding safety and security within industrial, commercial and military areas is an important issue nowadays. A specific challenge lies in the design of portable surveillance systems that can be rapidly deployed, installed and easily operated. Conventional surveillance systems typically employ standalone sensors that transmit their data to a central control station for data-processing. One of the disadvantages of these kinds of systems is that they generate a lot of data that may induce processing or storage problems. Moreover, data from the sensors must be constantly observed and assessed by human operators. In this paper, a surveillance concept based on distributed intelligence in wireless sensor networks is proposed. In this concept, surveillance is automatically performed by means of many small sensing devices including cameras. The requirements for such surveillance systems are investigated. Experiments with a demonstration system were conducted to verify some of the claims made throughout this paper.
Author Keywords: Security; Sensor networks; Surveillance; Unattended sensors
Index Keywords: Alarm systems; Data processing; Energy utilization; Feature extraction; Infrared devices; Military operations; Mobile computing; Optimization; Personnel; Security systems; Infrared cameras; Mobile surveillance systems; Sensor networks; Unattended sensors; Sensors

Authors: Chin Y., Sheu J., Brooks D.
Title: Evaluating techniques for exploiting instruction slack
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Conference on Computer Design: VLSI in Computers and Processors
Affiliations: Div. of Eng. and Applied Sciences, Harvard University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chin, Y., Div. of Eng. and Applied Sciences, Harvard University, United States; Sheu, J., Div. of Eng. and Applied Sciences, Harvard University, United States; Brooks, D., Div. of Eng. and Applied Sciences, Harvard University, United States
Abstract: In many workloads, 25% to 50% of instructions have slack allowing them to be delayed without impacting performance. To exploit this slack, processors may implement more power-efficient, longer latency pipelines or provide dynamically scaled pipelines using multiple clock domains. Issuing instructions with slack to slower pipelines can result in substantial power savings, with minimal performance loss. Considering both dynamic and static power dissipation, we found that by using longer latency pipelines the power of functional unit pipelines decreases by 20% to 55% with a performance impact of 0% to 3% for SPEC2000 and MediaBench workloads. Dynamic scaling reduces the performance loss in intense multimedia workloads by up to 2%, but achieves lower power savings. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Clock frequencies; Leakage power; Power dissipation; Power savings; Algorithms; Bandwidth; Data storage equipment; Decoding; Electric clocks; Electric potential; Electric power measurement; Energy efficiency; Metadata; Microprocessor chips; Multimedia systems; Personal computers; Scheduling; Servers; Program processors

Title: Low power test data compression based on LFSR reseeding
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Conference on Computer Design: VLSI in Computers and Processors
Affiliations: Computer Engineering Research Center, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712-1084, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lee, J., Computer Engineering Research Center, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712-1084, United States; Touba, N.A., Computer Engineering Research Center, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX 78712-1084, United States
Abstract: Many test data compression schemes are based on LFSR reseeding. A drawback of these schemes is that the unspecified bits are filled with random values resulting in a large number of transitions during scan-in thereby causing high power dissipation. This paper presents a new encoding scheme that can be used in conjunction with any LFSR reseeding scheme to significantly reduce test power and even further reduce test storage. The proposed encoding scheme acts as a second stage of compression after LFSR reseeding. It accomplishes two goals. First, it reduces the number of transitions in the scan chains (by filling the unspecified bits in a different manner), and second it reduces the number of specified bits that need to be generated via LFSR reseeding. Experimental results indicate that the proposed method significantly reduces test power and in most cases provides greater test data compression than LFSR reseeding alone. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Encoding algorithm; Power dissipation; Static compaction; Systems-on-chip (SoC); Algorithms; Computer graphics; Data compression; Electric power utilization; Encoding (symbols); Energy dissipation; Polynomials; Integrated circuit layout

Title: Low energy, highly-associative cache design for embedded processors
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Conference on Computer Design: VLSI in Computers and Processors
Affiliations: Computer Science Department, University of California, Irvine, United States
Authors with affiliations: Veidenbaum, A., Computer Science Department, University of California, Irvine, United States; Nicolaescu, D., Computer Science Department, University of California, Irvine, United States
Abstract: Many embedded processors use highly associative data caches implemented using a CAM-based tag search. When high-associativity is desirable, CAM designs can offer performance advantages due to fast associative search. However, CAMs are not energy efficient. This paper describes a CAM-based cache design which uses prediction to reduce energy consumption. A last used prediction is shown to achieve an 86% prediction accuracy, on average. A new design integrating such predictor in the CAM tag store is described. A 30% average D-cache energy reduction is demonstrated for the MiBench programs with little additional hardware or impact on processor performance. Even better results can be achieved with another predictor design which increases prediction accuracy. Significant static energy reduction is also possible using this approach for the RAM data store. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Cache design; Cache energy consumption; Embedded processors; Prediction accuracy; Benchmarking; Cache memory; Data storage equipment; Embedded systems; Leakage currents; Random access storage; Program processors

Authors: Puchner H., Xu Y.Z., Radaelli D.
Title: Advanced SEU engineering using a triple well architecture
Source title: ESSCIRC 2004 - Proceedings of the 34th European Solid-State Device Research Conference
Affiliations: Technol. R/D, Cypress Semiconduct., San Jose, CA 95134, United States
Authors with affiliations: Puchner, H., Technol. R/D, Cypress Semiconduct., San Jose, CA 95134, United States; Xu, Y.Z., Technol. R/D, Cypress Semiconduct., San Jose, CA 95134, United States; Radaelli, D., Technol. R/D, Cypress Semiconduct., San Jose, CA 95134, United States
Abstract: A triple well scheme has been implemented on an 18Mbit fast synchronous SRAM by using a high energy implant to evaluate its impact on the alpha-particle induced Accelerated Soft Error Rate (ASER). The device uses a single poly 0.15 μm CMOS process. The SER FIT rates have been measured from silicon with and without the triple well. In contrast to the historical literature, the measured FIT rate of the triple well silicon shows a significant degradation of the SER FIT rate. Detailed analysis of the bitmap for the flipped cells was employed to identify the degradation mechanism. It is found that the increase of the p-well resistivity and the effective contact tapping distance to the p-well is the main reason of the degradation. However, in the region of solid taps to both n-well and p-well, the FIT rate is close but still slightly higher than the FIT rate of the control wafers. In addition, a trade-off between the NMOS and PMOS region is identified using 2D numerical analysis. The results prove that an optimization of the well connections are needed for the triple well scheme and the SER improvement relies on the optimization of the tradeoff effect. For high energy particles, which can penetrate much deeper into the silicon substrate, the triple well is expected to be helpful to limit the charge collection. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Accelerated soft error rates; Charge collection; Flipped cells; Triple well architecture; Capacitance; Computer architecture; Error analysis; MOS devices; Silicon; Transistors; Random access storage

Authors: Alvarez L., Alanís E., Romero G., Martinez C., Lesino G.
Title: Interferometric measurement of temperature profiles inside a transparent solid
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Facultad de Ciencias Exactas, Univ. Nac. Salta, Consejo de Invest., 4400-Salta, Argentina; Facultad de Ingeniería, Univ. Nac. Salta, Consejo de Invest., 4400-Salta, Argentina; Facultad de Ciencias Naturales, Univ. Nac. Salta, Consejo de Invest., 4400-Salta, Argentina
Authors with affiliations: Alvarez, L., Facultad de Ciencias Exactas, Univ. Nac. Salta, Consejo de Invest., 4400-Salta, Argentina; Alanís, E., Facultad de Ciencias Exactas, Univ. Nac. Salta, Consejo de Invest., 4400-Salta, Argentina; Romero, G., Facultad de Ingeniería, Univ. Nac. Salta, Consejo de Invest., 4400-Salta, Argentina; Martinez, C., Facultad de Ciencias Naturales, Univ. Nac. Salta, Consejo de Invest., 4400-Salta, Argentina; Lesino, G., Facultad de Ciencias Exactas, Univ. Nac. Salta, Consejo de Invest., 4400-Salta, Argentina
Abstract: Electronic speckle pattern interferometry technique (ESPI) was applied to the determination of temperature profiles inside a solid block made of a transparent material. The block is a component of a scaled-model intended to simulate a solar energy storage-collector wall (Trombe wall) and its adjacent room. In order to obtain the speckle correlation fringes, a Mach-Zehnder interferometer was used, in whose object arm the model was put. By means of an electrical heater a constant heat flux is supplied through one of the wall faces, maintaining the opposed face at a constant temperature, until a steady state is reached. The temperature profiles for several intermediate states are determined by measurements on the corresponding speckle correlation fringes. The experimental results are compared with the analytical solutions of the differential equation of heat conduction, with the appropriate initial and boundary conditions.
Author Keywords: ESPI; Heat transfer; Speckle interferometry; Thermal storage wall

Authors: Guo Y., Chheda S., Koren I., Krishna C.M., Moritz C.A.
Title: Energy characterization of hardware-based data prefetching
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Conference on Computer Design: VLSI in Computers and Processors
Affiliations: Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA 01003, United States; BlueRISC Inc., Hadley, MA 01035, United States
Authors with affiliations: Guo, Y., Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA 01003, United States; Chheda, S., BlueRISC Inc., Hadley, MA 01035, United States; Koren, I., Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA 01003, United States; Krishna, C.M., Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA 01003, United States; Moritz, C.A., Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA 01003, United States
Abstract: This paper evaluates several hardware-based data prefetching techniques from an energy perspective, and explores their energy/performance tradeoffs. We present detailed simulation results and make performance and energy comparisons between different configurations. Power characterization is provided based on HSpice circuit-level simulation of state-of-the-art low-power cache designs implemented in deep-submicron process technology. This is combined with architecture-level simulation of switching activities in the memory system. The results show that while aggressive prefetching techniques often help to improve performance, they increase energy consumption in most of the cases. In designs implemented in deepsubmicron 100-nm BPTM process technology, cache leakage becomes one of the dominant factors of the energy consumption. We have, however, found that if leakage is optimized with recently-proposed circuit-level techniques, most of the energy degradation is due to prefetch-hardware related costs and unnecessary LI data cache lookups related to prefetches that hit in the LI cache. This overhead on the memory system can be as much as 20%. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Data cache; Data prefetching; Energy characterization; Memory systems; Computer aided design; Computer hardware; Computer simulation; Cost effectiveness; Data acquisition; Data storage equipment; Energy policy; Energy utilization

Title: Design and implementation of scalable low-power Montgomery multiplier
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Conference on Computer Design: VLSI in Computers and Processors
Affiliations: Multimedia Lab., SoC R and D Center, Samsung Electronics Co., South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Son, H.-K., Multimedia Lab., SoC R and D Center, Samsung Electronics Co., South Korea; Oh, S.-G., Multimedia Lab., SoC R and D Center, Samsung Electronics Co., South Korea
Abstract: In this paper, an efficient Montgomery multiplier is introduced for the modular exponentiation operation, which is fundamental to numerous public-key cryptosystems. Four aspects are considered: performance, power, reliability, and scalability. To increase performance, the architecture is based on the radix-4 Carry-Save Adder (CSA). To lower power consumption, we devised several effective techniques for reducing the spurious transitions and the Expected Switching Activity (ESA) of high fan-out signals. To achieve scalability, we implement a 4-fold nested loop for the whole data processing flow. It is compatible with the multiple-precision digit-serial arithmetic as well as the data transfer to/from an external memory. Lastly, to make sure that the arithmetic operation runs correctly without inducing data overflow error, we find out the optimum numbers of bits for all vectors appearing in the operation through a mathematical analysis and a logic simulation. In the evaluation of hardware implemented using 0.18 um CMOS standard library and 4 metal layers, area and current consumption are 59 K gates and 0.4 mA/MHz at 1.8 V supply voltage, respectively. The presented low power techniques save more than 20% of power consumed. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: CMOS integrated circuits; Computer simulation; Data processing; Data storage equipment; Data transfer; Electric potential; Energy utilization; Error analysis; Carry-Save Adder (CSA); Expected switching activity (ESA); Logic simulation; Metal layers; Multipliers; Computer aided design

Authors: Shin Y., Jung W., Chen Z., Nelson J.S., Kim H., Park J.
Title: Investigation of pit formation in multilayer optical storage disks using optical coherence tomography
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Chosun University, Gwangju, 501-759, South Korea; Beckman Laser Institute, University of California, Irvine, CA 92612, United States; Laser Imaging Laboratory, Chosun University, Gwangju, 501-759, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Shin, Y., Department of Physics, Chosun University, Gwangju, 501-759, South Korea, Beckman Laser Institute, University of California, Irvine, CA 92612, United States; Jung, W., Beckman Laser Institute, University of California, Irvine, CA 92612, United States; Chen, Z., Beckman Laser Institute, University of California, Irvine, CA 92612, United States; Nelson, J.S., Beckman Laser Institute, University of California, Irvine, CA 92612, United States; Kim, H., Laser Imaging Laboratory, Chosun University, Gwangju, 501-759, South Korea; Park, J., Laser Imaging Laboratory, Chosun University, Gwangju, 501-759, South Korea
Abstract: We propose a novel application of optical coherence tomography (OCT) to monitor pit formation in laser irradiated optical storage materials. A multilayer optical storage recordable compact disk, is composed of multiple layers, each of different structure. Disks were irradiated with a Q-Switched Nd:YAG laser with an energy of 373 mJ. Post-irradiated disks were evaluated by OCT and those images were compared with optical microscopy. Our results indicate that OCT is a useful instrument to investigate pit formation in multilayer optical storage disks and might also provide information to optimize optical memory technology.

Title: Classical imaging and digital imaging spectrophotometric techniques in cullets (glass fragments) sorting
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Dipto. Ingegneria Chim., M.M.P./M., Univ. Studi Di Roma La Sapienza, Via Eudossiana, 18, 00184 Roma, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Bonifazi, G., Dipto. Ingegneria Chim., M.M.P./M., Univ. Studi Di Roma La Sapienza, Via Eudossiana, 18, 00184 Roma, Italy
Abstract: Cullets optical sorting represents one of the oldest selection procedure applied to the field of solid waste recycling. From the original sorting strategies, mainly addressed to separate non-transparent elements (ceramics, stones, metal particles, etc.) from transparent ones (glass fragments), the attention was addressed to define procedures and actions able to separate the cullets according to their color characteristics and, more recently, to recognize transparent ceramic glass from glass. Cullets sorting is currently realized adopting, as detecting architecture, laser beam technology based devices. The sorting logic is mainly analogical. An "on-off" logic is applied. Detection is, in fact, based on the evaluation of the "characteristics" of the energy (transparent or non-transparent fragment) and the spectra (fragment color attributes) received by a detector after that cullets were crossed by a suitable laser beam light. Such an approach presents some limits related with the technology utilized and the material characteristics. The technological limits are linked to the physical dimension and the mechanical arrangement of the optics carrying out and in the signals, and with the pneumatic architectures enabling the modification of cullets trajectory to realize sorting, according to their characteristics (color and transmittance). Furthermore such devices are practically "blind" in the recognition of ceramic glasses, whose presence in the final selected material to melt, damage the full recycled glass fusion compromising the quality of the final product. In the following it will be described the work developed, and the results achieved, in order to design a full integrated classical digital imaging and spectrophotometric based approach addressed to develop suitable sorting strategies able to perform, at industrial recycling scale, the distinction of cullets both in terms of color and material typologies, that is "real glass" from "ceramic glass" fragments.
Author Keywords: Cullets sorting; Digital imaging based spectrophotometry; Glass recycling; Image analysis; Quality control
Index Keywords: Ceramic materials; Digital image storage; Energy utilization; Image analysis; Image quality; Quality control; Recycling; Waste utilization; Cullets sorting; Digital image based spectrophotometry; Glass fragments; Glass recycling; Spectrophotometry

Abstract: This paper describes a 3.3GHz low-swing single-ended LI cache bus in 1.2V, 90nm dual-Vt CMOS technology. Accurate RLCK-modeling of the interconnect topology has been conducted using a 3D field solver. A signal-swing reduction of 25% and efficient sense amplifier-based receiver are employed to reach 3.3GHz, 2.24mW operation at 1.2V, 110°C. 70% energy and 54% peak-current reduction is achieved over an optimized high-performance conventional dynamic cache bus scheme. The design is fully functional up to 6.1GHz operating frequency with a 54% eye opening. © 2004 IEEE.

Title: Auto-disturbance rejection controller in the wind energy conversion system
Source title: Conference Proceedings - IPEMC 2004: 4th International Power Electronics and Motion Control Conference
Affiliations: Electric Power College, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, Guang Dong Province, China
Authors with affiliations: Dong, P., Electric Power College, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, Guang Dong Province, China; Ye, G.-J., Electric Power College, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, Guang Dong Province, China; Wu, J., Electric Power College, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, Guang Dong Province, China; Yang, J.-M., Electric Power College, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, Guang Dong Province, China; Chen, Y.-R., Electric Power College, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou, Guang Dong Province, China
Abstract: This paper presents a controller for maximum wind energy capture of wind power system according to the theory of auto disturbance rejection controller (ADRC). The uncertainties in the torque of turbine and friction are both considered as the unknown disturbance to the system. The expending state observer can evaluate the unknown disturbance. With the nonlinear state error feedback control law, the disturbance can be compensated. The control law has only relationship with the reference and the output. So the control is simplified with fewer variables detected. The maximum energy capture is achieved through the design of tracking-differentiator. The feasibility, adaptability and robust of the control is testified by this result.

Authors: Chen J., Jiang X., Zhu D., Wei H.
Title: A novel uninterruptible power supply using flywheel energy storage unit
Source title: Conference Proceedings - IPEMC 2004: 4th International Power Electronics and Motion Control Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Bejjing 100084, China
Authors with affiliations: Chen, J., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Bejjing 100084, China; Jiang, X., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Bejjing 100084, China; Zhu, D., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Bejjing 100084, China; Wei, H., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Bejjing 100084, China
Abstract: A novel uninterruptible power supply (UPS) with a flywheel energy storage unit is presented. The UPS is composed of an AC/DC rectifier, a DC/AC inverter, a permanent magnet brushless DC motor, a motor converter and a flywheel energy storage unit. Firstly, main power circuit of the UPS and its flywheel energy storage unit are introduced. Then the control strategies of the flywheel charging/discharging and DC/AC converter are discussed in detail. In charging mode, the AC/DC rectifier and motor converter are used for brushless DC motor driver. In discharging mode, motor converter is for boosting the dc link voltage. In both modes, UPS can work in on-line or off-line mode. The flywheel energy storage unit, which takes place of the conventional chemical battery unit, has the advantages of free maintenance, long life and no pollution. Finally the experiment results testify the novel UPS has better character and dynamical response.
Author Keywords: Brushless DC motor; Flywheel; Intelligence control; Uninterruptible power supply

Then a comparative method is employed to obtain the detailed mathematical description of power loss and efficiency for the discussed soft-switching inverter circuit, and presents the power loss simplified models of inverter circuit and its power devices. At last, in a practical circuit, the analytic conclusions are verified by some related experiments.

Title: DC micro-grid based distribution power generation system
Source title: Conference Proceedings - IPEMC 2004: 4th International Power Electronics and Motion Control Conference
Affiliations: Mayway Labs. Co., Ltd., Yokohama 222-0033, Japan; Tokyo Institute of Technology, Meguro-ku, Tokyo, Japan

Abstract: This paper describes an autonomous-control method for a dc micro-grid system having distribution power generators. This system consists of following five generation and control units; a solar-cell generation unit, a wind-turbine generation unit, a battery energy-storage unit, a flywheel power-leveling unit, and an ac grid-connected power control unit. The proposed control method intended for suppression of circulating current detects only the dc grid voltage. Each unit could be controlled autonomously without communicating each other. This method brings high reliability, high-flexibility and maintenance-free operation to the system. Experimental results from a 10kW-prototype system verify the validity and effectiveness of the proposed control method.

Abstract: A novel phasor control scheme is developed for a SMES system to protect a critical load from momentary voltage sags. This system consists of a 0.3MJ superconducting magnet, a 200KVA IGBT-based current source converter and a 2. 5mH reactor inserted between power supply and load. To obtain a rapid response, the current vector PWM strategy is applied. Simulations and experiments are carried out to demonstrate the algorithm, and the results are presented.

Abstract: The paper discusses a bi-directional DC/DC converter for interfacing an energy storage device in an autonomous power system, which consists of wind turbines and diesel generation units. The operation condition variations, such as switching load, could cause significant dynamics in an autonomous system. An energy storage device can effectively increase the utilization of the renewable energy and improve the capability of dealing with dynamics. This paper studies a two-bridge type of power electronic system for interfacing an energy storage system that can provide the short-term power balance and smoothes the power variation. A control strategy is presented. The simulation results have demonstrated that the system can provide fast response to secure the system reliability and power quality.

Abstract: This paper deals with Maximum Power Point Tracking control of photovoltaic generators. Photovoltaic generation systems need Maximum Power Point Tracker (MPPT) because the output power depends on the operating voltage and current. The authors have proposed the MPPT employing line search algorithm with fibonacci sequence. Finding maximum power point is difficult when a photovoltaic array is partially shaded, because two or more maximum power points may appear. In this paper, the authors improve the proposed method in order to find the global maximum under the partially shaded condition. The improved algorithm has good performance in many experiments. In addition, the authors also mention that the compensation of the large output fluctuation caused by the proposed MPPT by using a wind turbine generator as a kind of flywheel energy storage.

The results of start-up and steady state condition indicate that the inverter rating is reduced fairly.

Abstract: This paper deals with the energy management of instantaneous electrical generation/ electrical storage power split in serie's Hybrid Electric Vehicle (HEV). This energy management is related to some rules that have been performed by state flow toolbox (ver 5) of Matlab 6.5 software. The efficient management of the powertrain of HEY requires the careful coordination of engine and other of ancillary power reservoirs such as batteries which performed by simulink and advisor 2002. The system is simulated to demonstrate the validity and the convenience of a qualitative approach instead of a deterministic one. It prepares a good environment for supervisory control of engine in this kind of hybrid systems. The simulation results confirm the feasibility and encourage more research toward an actual application.

Abstract: Storage of electric power is the most important technology. The novel technology is explained about the flywheel which used mechanical energy, and the superconductive magnetic energy storage (SMES) using magnetic energy. As for the flywheel, the stabilization of the pulsation in the wind-power generation is promising. Furthermore, the pump up operation using flywheel raises the efficiency of the wind-power generation. As for SMES, the idea of the electromagnetic force balanced coil which decrease electromagnetic force is shown. The problem of the high cost can be solved when it has SMES as a DC-L in the frequency change and BtoB interconnection facility.

Source title: Conference Proceedings - IPEMC 2004: 4th International Power Electronics and Motion Control Conference

Abstract: In a world where environment protection and energy conservation are growing concerns, the development of electric and hybrid vehicles (EV/HEV) has taken on an accelerated pace. The dream of having commercially viable electric/hybrid vehicles is becoming a reality. Electric and hybrid vehicles are gradually available in the market. This paper reviews the present status of electric and hybrid vehicles worldwide and their state of the art, with emphasis on the engineering philosophy and key technologies. The importance of the integration of technologies of automobile, electric motor drive, electronics, energy storage and controls, and the importance of the integration of society strength from government, industry, research institutions, electric power utilities and transportation authorities are addressed. The challenge of EV commercialization is discussed.

Abstract: There is demand for high-speed but light-weight flywheel system for energy and momentum storage. The applications range from replacements for batteries, uninterruptible power supplies and even in space satellites. This paper proposes a new design of a mechanically contactless flywheel system which should be both compact and energy efficient. The flywheel acts as the rotor of the drive system and is sandwiched between two disk-type stators. A combination of active and passive magnet bearings allows the rotor-flywheel to spin and remains in magnetic levitation. The design principles, mathematical model, control theory and simulation results are presented in this paper.

Title: Localization in wireless sensor network with mobile beacons
Source title: IEEE Convention of Electrical and Electronics Engineers in Israel, Proceedings
Affiliations: Honeywell Technology Solution Lab.
Authors with affiliations: Patro, R.K., Honeywell Technology Solution Lab.
Abstract: Sensor nodes in wireless sensor network have limited power, low memory and less processing capability. One of the primary requirements of localization algorithm is low power consumption. This paper presents a energy efficient localization algorithm for wireless sensor network with the help of moving beacons. It is different from other proposed localization algorithm; in the way sensors calculate their position. Four beacons move towards the node to be localized and form a square, being sensor node at the center. Sensor node calculates its position as centroid of the square after getting co-ordinate information from four beacons sitting at the edge of the square. Localized node and non-localized node can be distinguished by assigning a unique code to sensors in network. The computational requirement at the node is very low and it has flexible accuracy. © 2004 IEEE.

Under this control method the converter works with high power factor and constant output voltage. This converter reaches high frequency and high power factor with simple control circuit. Finally, the experiment result was given.

Abstract: Matrix-converter is three phase AC to AC direct converter which is absence of de-link capacitors for energy storage by using bi-directional switches. Like a conventional inverter, matrix-converter can control input waveform and power factor and can revive the electric power of load. Therefore, matrix-converter is superior to conventional Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) inverter. In this paper, we report a theoretical indirect modulation simulation result considering input voltage conditions.

Abstract: This paper presents a new simple Forward AC/DC converter with harmonic current correction and fast output voltage regulation In the proposed AC/DC converter, an extra winding wounded in transformer provides two major merits: The function of bulk inductor has been replaced by this extra back-feeding transformer winding hi the proposed converter and significant volume and weight in magnetic material can be saved. The voltage across bulk capacitor can be hold under 450v by tuning transformer windings ratio even though the converter operates in wide range input voltage (90v-265v/ac). This new converter complies with IEC 61000-3-2 under the load range of 200w and it has fast output voltage regulation.

Eng., Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore
Abstract: Mitigation of the impacts of source-side voltage disturbances through series voltage compensation technique is considered. The power quality enhancement technique is shown to result in phase shift on load terminal voltages. The effect of the phase-shift on the loads is then examined by taking the dynamics of the loads under the phase disturbance condition into consideration. The analysis permits an insight into the inherent characteristics of the load dynamics to be gained. A new method of introducing the phase shift is then proposed. The method balances the need for achieving acceptable load swings while maximizing the saving in the stored energy of the series Custom Power device.

Source title: 2004 2nd IEEE International Symposium on Biomedical Imaging: Macro to Nano

Northwest National Laboratory, United States; Budge, S.E., Dept. of Elec. and Comp. Engineering, Utah State University, United States
Abstract: Online control of living cell signal propagation experiments is being facilitated with field programmable gate array (FPGA) processing. The technology approach captures confocal fluorescence microscopy imagery in a manner that real-time, live-cell chemical signaling can be monitored during an experiment for extended time periods. The experiments obtain quantitative, spatial characteristics of the cell chemistry from the imagery through analysis, following a localized perturbation stimulus. The construction of a high-speed, confocal microscope provides simultaneous, two color image acquisition, at speeds of up to 30 fps, allowing near-real-time fluorescent resonance energy transfer and subsequent ratiometric, chemical signaling analysis. The FPGA provides real-time image processing hardware for observing adjustments of the microscope settings as the images are received, using real-time image registration and fusion algorithms displayed through a user interface. © 2004 IEEE.

Title: Power management strategy based on game theory for fuel cell hybrid electric vehicles
Source title: IEEE Vehicular Technology Conference
Affiliations: HEV/EV Battery Software and Controls, University of Michigan - Dearborn, Dearborn, MI, United States; Dept. of Elec. and Comp. Engineering, University of Central Florida, Orlando, FL, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gielniak, M.J., HEV/EV Battery Software and Controls, University of Michigan - Dearborn, Dearborn, MI, United States; Shen, Z.J., Dept. of Elec. and Comp. Engineering, University of Central Florida, Orlando, FL, United States
Abstract: In this paper, we present an integrated system approach based on game theory for automotive electrical power and energy management systems. We apply this approach to a case study fuel cell hybrid electric vehicle (FC-HEV) by using the Simulink-based simulator ADVISOR. The case study fuel cell vehicle is rated with 80kW peak and 25kW average propulsion power, and consists of a fuel cell stack, a battery pack, an ultra capacitor, and two 35kW induction motors. In this control strategy, the game 'players' are the individual power sources, and the 'strategies' of players are their alternating states. The objective of the players is to maximize their payoff, where the payoff is a function of the power-train efficiency and vehicle performance. Simulation results indicate that the optimal power and energy management strategy can improve both fuel economy and performance. © 2004 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Energy Management Strategy; Fuel Cell Electric Vehicle; Game Theory; Hybrid Electric Vehicle (HEV); Power Management Strategy
Index Keywords: Energy management strategies; Fuel cell electric vehicles; Hybrid electric vehicles (HEV); Power management strategies; Computer simulation; Energy management; Energy storage; Fuel cells; Fuel economy; Game theory; Induction motors; Electric vehicles

Title: An AC/AC direct power conversion topology having multiple power grid connections with adjustable loading
Source title: IEE Conference Publication
Affiliations: University of Nottingham, School of Electrical Engineering, United Kingdom; Aalborg University, Institute of Energy Technology, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Klumpner, C., University of Nottingham, School of Electrical Engineering, United Kingdom; Blaabjerg, F., Aalborg University, Institute of Energy Technology, Denmark
Abstract: Normally, a power converter has one supply port to connect to the power grid and one or multiple output ports to connect to AC loads that require variable voltage and variable frequency. As the trend on the energy market is towards deregulation, new converter topologies are needed to allow independent producers/consumers to connect to multiple distribution grids in order to optimise the electricity price, as this will vary during the day from one power distribution company to another one. It will be needed to have a load that can smoothly adjust the power consumed from each power grid in order to minimize the overall energy cost or in case of special applications, to improve the system redundancy. Also, having a generator that can simultaneously feed fractions of its power into multiple grids which are not coupled (different voltage, frequency, displacement angle) and continuously adjust these fraction power will be a necessary feature on a deregulated energy market. This paper presents a new topology of a power converter based on the Direct Power Conversion concept, which is able to connect to multiple grids and provide complete decoupling between without circulating power between the grids, adjust continuously the power sharing and provide sine-wave in and sine-wave out operation. Additionally, it minimizes the size of passive components and does not need electrolytic capacitors for energy storage, which has impact on increasing the converter lifetime. © 2004 The Institution of Electrical Engineers.
Author Keywords: Adjustable loading factor; Direct power conversion; Multiple power grid supply
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric loads; Electric network topology; Frequencies; Matrix algebra; Military applications; Pulse width modulation; Semiconductor devices; Vectors; Adjustable loading factor; Direct power conversion; Multiple power grid supply; Space vector modulation (SVM); Power converters

Abstract: In this paper, the impact of solar photovoltaic generators deep in a typical urban medium and low voltage distribution networks is examined. Abstract: In this paper, the steady-state analysis of the three-phase self-excited induction generator (SEIG) is presented. The three-phase SEIG with a squirrel cage rotor is driven by a variable-speed prime mover(VSPM) or a constant-speed prime mover (CSPM) such as a wind turbine or a micro gas turbine. Furthermore, a PI closed-loop feedback voltage regulation scheme of the three-phase SEIG driven by a VSPM on the basis of the static VAR compensator (SVC) is designed and evaluated for the stand-alone AC and DC power applications. The simulation and experimental results prove the practical effectiveness of the additional SVC with the PI controller-based feedback loop in terms of the fast responses and the high performances. © 2004 The Institution of Electrical Engineers.

Title: Two-stage interleaving network analysis to design area- and energy-efficient 3GPP-compliant receiver architectures
Source title: IEEE Workshop on Signal Processing Systems, SiPS: Design and Implementation
Affiliations: STMicroelectron.-Adv. Syst. Technol., 39, Chemin du Champ-des-Filles, 1228 Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Wellig, A., STMicroelectron.-Adv. Syst. Technol., 39, Chemin du Champ-des-Filles, 1228 Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: Interleaving is a key component of many digital communication systems where the encoded data is reshuffled prior to transmission to protect against burst errors. Coupled with multiplexing schemes such multi-stage subsystems achieve the necessary quality and flexibility to support a variety of different services. In 3GPP, a 2-stage multiplexing channel interleaver network is adopted. Its state-of-the-art implementation is both memory- and control-intensive, since the deinterleaving is done explicitly implying dedicated storage and processing units at each stage. In this paper, we show that the C-fold decimation property which characterizes typical block interleavers is preserved in 2-stage interleaving networks. Thus, the underlying architecture not only results in significant memory size and access rate reductions but also greatly simplifies control processing. A decline in memory size of up to 31% and in access energy of up to 54% has been observed for STMicroelectronics' 0.13 μm CMOS technology for various 3GPP Capability Classes. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Energy dissipation; Integer programming; Multiplexing; Routers; Signal encoding; Signal processing; Signal receivers; Throughput; Code composite transport channels (CCTrCH); Interleaving network analysis; Receiver architectures; Transmission time interval (TTI); Computer architecture

Title: Design and implementation of a DSP-based fuel cell/battery hybrid power source
Source title: IEE Conference Publication
Affiliations: University of Strathclyde, Dept. of Elec. and Electron. Eng., Institute for Energy and Environment, 204 George Street, Glasgow G11XW, United Kingdom

Eng., Institute for Energy and Environment, 204 George Street, Glasgow G11XW, United Kingdom; McDonald, J.R., University of Strathclyde, Dept. of Elec. and Electron. Eng., Institute for Energy and Environment, 204 George Street, Glasgow G11XW, United Kingdom
Abstract: Currently there is considerable R&D activity in the field of Fuel Cell (FC) technology as an efficient and clean power source for both stationary and transport applications. This paper describes the development of a fuel cell/battery hybrid power source for a stationary domestic power application, details the control systems underpinning this system and describes some preliminary experimental results. The authors believe that the fuel cell/battery hybrid power system is the most cost-effective solution for domestic power applications. This recognizes that a typical domestic power profile can have a peak to average power ratio of between around 9-15, and hence a fuel cell only system would significantly over-rate the fuel cell to satisfy peak power and consequently suffer from poor utilisation. The hybrid system avoids this by using battery power to meet instantaneous peak power and the fuel cell as a base load / battery charging element. The objective of this paper is to consider the power electronic interface from a fuel cell as a low voltage dc source, to a higher voltage storage battery and possible dc load, i.e dc/dc booster, and ultimately a dc/ac inverter for utility connection. This paper will describe the system design and experimental results over a 7-hour test period using a dc load profile only, monitored by an LF2407 digital signal processor(DSP.) © 2004 University of Strathcylde, UK.

Abstract: An effective approach for improving the fuel economy and reducing the emission of CO2 and other harmful pollutants from ICE vehicles is to employ a down-sized supercharged engine. However, supercharged ICEs exhibit a relatively low torque capability at low engine speeds. In order to overcome this problem, an electrical torque boost may be applied for short periods, whilst accelerating and changing gear. The paper describes the operational requirements of a torque boost system which employs a super-capacitor energy storage buffer, and considers the design and sizing of the electrical machine. © 2004 The Institution of Electrical Engineers.

Abstract: Minimising the energy consumption due to the data storage and transfer in data-dominated systems is critical for the design of embedded systems. Distributed memory organisations have been proposed as an efficient storage architecture alternative. However, the impact of interconnect overhead in these has been traditionally neglected, which is not acceptable anymore for Deep Sub-Micron technologies. In this paper we propose combining the exploration of the memory organisation with the one of the communication network and motivate its importance compared to the independent local explorations. This combined exploration can provide gains of 30% in the overall energy consumption of both the memory and its interconnection network design methodologies. © 2004 IEEE.

Abstract: Embedded memories are increasingly becoming more important components for SoC's (System on a Chip) as the silicon technology advances and SoC's get more complex. In addition, diverging SoC applications require wide range of different performance and specification for embedded memories; from very high bandwidth to ultra low power consumption. Abstract: The paper discusses the application of a kinetic energy storage system, based on a high-speed composite flywheel, to regulate the dc 3rd-rail voltage on a metro network. Practical results prove the principle of using energy storage in such an application, and demonstrate that the system fulfils the metro operator's objective. © 2004 Urenco Power Technologies Ltd, UK.

Authors: Nakamura M., Ahmed T., Hiraki E., Nakaoka M.
Title: A novel soft switching PWM sinewave converter with regenerative pulse current edge-resonant snubber power modules for distributed power supplies
Source title: IEE Conference Publication
Affiliations: Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nakamura, M., Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan; Ahmed, T., Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan; Hiraki, E., Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan; Nakaoka, M., Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan
Abstract: In this paper, a novel circuit topology of the active auxiliary edge resonant snubber suitable and acceptable for high power soft switching inverter and rectifier applications which includes some salient features as compared with conventional active auxiliary resonant commutation pole snubber is proposed newly. This resonant snubber circuit can minimize the switching power losses of power semiconductor devices (IGBTs), switching voltage and current surges, high frequency leakage currents to the heat sink in addition to the switching surge related electromagnetic noises in high power conversion conditioning and processing circuits on the basis of the voltage source type sinewave PWM inverter and voltage source sinewave PWM PFC converter as well as bi-directional PWM converter interfaced the battery energy storage system. This resonant snubber-assisted inverter and rectifier for high power conversion is described and discussed on the basis of soft switching transition and commutation operation of the voltage source type high efficiency pulse modulated inverter. The operation principle and operating characteristics of this active auxiliary snubber circuit are respectively described, together with the practical design procedure of this unique edge auxiliary snubber. Furthermore, the three-phase soft switching sinewave PWM inverter with the novel auxiliary active edge resonant bridge leg link snubbers treated here is implemented and discussed as compared with three phase hard switching sinewave PWM inverter, along with the practical evaluations bi-directional double converter for UPS system. © 2004 Yamaguchi University, Japan.

Title: Custom design of multi-level dynamic memory management subsystem for embedded systems
Source title: IEEE Workshop on Signal Processing Systems, SiPS: Design and Implementation
Affiliations: DACYA/UCM, Avda. Complutense s/n, 28040, Madrid, Spain; VLSI Center-Demokritus Univ., Thrace, 67100 Xanthi, Greece; IMEC, Kapeldreef 75, 3001 Heverlee, Belgium

Complutense s/n, 28040, Madrid, Spain; Poucet, C., IMEC, Kapeldreef 75, 3001 Heverlee, Belgium; Catthoor, F., IMEC, Kapeldreef 75, 3001 Heverlee, Belgium; Soudris, D., VLSI Center-Demokritus Univ., Thrace, 67100 Xanthi, Greece; Mendias, J.M.
Abstract: Modem embedded systems have to run new dynamic wireless network and multimedia applications. As a result, these systems must provide run-time memory management support to allow real-time memory de/allocation, retrieving and processing of data while very limited power supply is available. Thus, its implementation must be designed to combine high speed access, low power and large data storage capacity. This is only possible by an efficient use of the memory hierarchy available in the embedded systems. In this paper, we propose a new approach to design convenient dynamic memory management subsystems making profit of the multiple memory levels. It analyzes the logical phases involved in modern dynamic applications to effectively distribute the dynamically allocated data among the multi-level memory hierarchies present in embedded devices. We assess the effectiveness of the proposed approach for three representative real-life case studies of the new dynamic application domains (i.e., network and 3D rendering applications) ported to embedded systems. The results accomplished with our approach show a very significant reduction in energy consumption (up to 40%) over state-of-the-art solutions for dynamic memory management on embedded systems with typical cache-main memory architectures while respecting the real-time requirements of these applications. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Architectural design; Cache memory; Data processing; Electric power supplies to apparatus; Energy utilization; Hierarchical systems; Multimedia systems; Storage allocation (computer); Wireless telecommunication systems; Memory management; Memory subsystems; Power supply; Storage capacity; Embedded systems

Source title: IEEE Workshop on Signal Processing Systems, SiPS: Design and Implementation
Affiliations: Philips Research Laboratories, Eindhoven, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Engin, N., Philips Research Laboratories, Eindhoven, Netherlands
Abstract: A scalable, programmable turbo decoder architecture is presented in this paper. The starting point is a comparison of the existing techniques on basis of scalability, area and power consumption. The results from these comparisons lead to a hybrid technique on which our architecture concept is based. The architecture is consisting of clusters each of which is a VLIW architecture. The upsizing is possible by adding a cluster and dividing the two data memories in banks. The window size is chosen according to the number of banks to prevent the conflicts. At the end of the paper, a short evaluation of the architecture is presented. © 2004 IEEE.

Authors: Yap H.T., Schofield N., Bingham C.M.
Title: Hybrid energy/power sources for electric vehicle traction systems
Source title: IEE Conference Publication
Affiliations: Dept. of Electron. and Elec. Eng., Univeristy of Sheffield, Mappin Street, Sheffield, S1 3JD, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Yap, H.T., Dept. of Electron. and Elec. Eng., Univeristy of Sheffield, Mappin Street, Sheffield, S1 3JD, United Kingdom; Schofield, N., Dept. of Electron. and Elec. Eng., Univeristy of Sheffield, Mappin Street, Sheffield, S1 3JD, United Kingdom; Bingham, C.M., Dept. of Electron. and Elec. Eng., Univeristy of Sheffield, Mappin Street, Sheffield, S1 3JD, United Kingdom
Abstract: Electric vehicles are set to play a prominent role in addressing the energy and environmental impact of an increasing road transport population by offering a more energy efficient and less polluting drive-train alternative to conventional internal combustion engine (ICE) vehicles. Given the energy (and hence range) and performance limitations of electro-chemical battery storage systems, hybrid systems combining energy and power dense storage technologies have been proposed for vehicle applications. Further, in recent years, fuel cell systems have also been proposed as a potential energy carrier, and the most suitable alternative likely to displace petroleum based fuels during the first half of this century. Whilst there are many technical and resource management issues associated with the displacement of petroleum fuels for transportation, and the commensurate supply infrastructure requirements, this paper will discuss some of the application issues associated with the implementation of hybrid energy/power sources for electric vehicle traction systems. Results from two case studies based on the combination of an electro-chemical storage battery and fuel cell energy sources with a supercapacitor peak power buffer will be presented to illustrate the benefits of on-board source hybridisation for urban road vehicles. It will discuss the simulation models and highlight design optimisation for energy efficiency and storage mass/volume of such systems when connected in hybrid configurations. © 2004 The Institution of Electrical Engineers.
Author Keywords: Electric vehicle; Hybrid configuration; Modelling; Simulation

Authors: Gramegna G., Franciotta M., Mandara V., Bellantone N.G., Vaiana M., Paparo M., Losi M., Das S., Mattos P.
Title: 23mm2 Single-chip 0.18μm CMOS GPS receiver with 28mW-4.1 mm2 radio and CPU/DSP/RAM/ROM
Source title: Proceedings of the Custom Integrated Circuits Conference
Affiliations: STMicroelectronics, Catania, Italy; STMicroelectronics, Agrafe, Italy; STMicroelectronics, Noida, India; STMicroelectronics, Bristol, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Gramegna, G., STMicroelectronics, Catania, Italy; Franciotta, M., STMicroelectronics, Catania, Italy; Mandara, V., STMicroelectronics, Catania, Italy; Bellantone, N.G., STMicroelectronics, Catania, Italy; Vaiana, M., STMicroelectronics, Catania, Italy; Paparo, M., STMicroelectronics, Catania, Italy; Losi, M., STMicroelectronics, Agrafe, Italy; Das, S., STMicroelectronics, Noida, India; Mattos, P., STMicroelectronics, Bristol, United Kingdom
Abstract: A 23mm2 0.18μm CMOS GPS Receiver with ARM7-DSP-64kRAM-256kROM and a 28mW-4.1mm2 Radio has been integrated. The SoC GPS receiver, connected to an active antenna, provides latitude, longitude, height with 3m rms precision with no need of external host processor in [-20,80]°C temperature range. The Radio draws 17.5mA from a 1.6V-1.8V voltage supply, takes 11 pins of a VFQFPN68 package and needs just a few passive for input match and one crystal. Measured Radio performances are: NF=4.8dB, Gp=92dB, Image Reject> 30dB, -112 dBc/Hz @ 1MHz offset phase noise. Though linearity and ruggedness of GPS Radio have been made compatible with co-existence of microprocessor, its silicon area and power consumption is aligned with state-of-the-art stand-alone CMOS GPS Radio. The one reported here is the first ever Radio successfully embedded into a single-chip GPS receiver requiring no external host to achieve satellite tracking and position fix with a total die area of 23 mm2. © 2004 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Bandwidth; CMOS integrated circuits; Global positioning system; Random access storage; ROM; Signal receivers; Spurious signal noise; Image rejection; Signal energy; Single chips; Temperature range; Microprocessor chips

Authors: García-Gil R., Espí-Huerta J.M., De La Calle R., Maset E., Castelló J.
Title: Four-quadrant AC-DC matrix converter with high-frequency isolation
Source title: IEE Conference Publication
Affiliations: LEII, Electronics Engineering Department, University of Valencia, Spain; WICO, S.L., Spain
Authors with affiliations: García-Gil, R., LEII, Electronics Engineering Department, University of Valencia, Spain; Espí-Huerta, J.M., LEII, Electronics Engineering Department, University of Valencia, Spain; De La Calle, R., WICO, S.L., Spain; Maset, E., LEII, Electronics Engineering Department, University of Valencia, Spain; Castelló, J., LEII, Electronics Engineering Department, University of Valencia, Spain
Abstract: A novel four-quadrant AC-DC reduced matrix converter with high frequency isolation is proposed and analyzed in this paper. This power converter is intended to feed the low-energy correction magnet of a particle accelerator. The selected topology consists of a bidirectional three-phase to one-phase cycloconverter and a bidirectional active rectifier. Main features of this power converter are the ability to regenerate energy back to the utility, unity power factor at the mains and high-frequency isolation. The size and weight of the converter is reduced since there are no large reactive components for energy storage and because isolation is achieved through a high-frequency transformer. Experimental and simulated results of a 1.5 kW, 20kHz prototype proof the performance of the proposed topology. © 2004 The Institution of Electrical Engineers.

Authors: Pamukchieva V., Szekeres A., Todorova K.
Title: Photo-induced changes of the optical constants of chalcodenide Ge 19Sb1Te80 films
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Institute of Solid State Physics, 72, Tsarigradsko Chaussee, 1784 Sofia, Bulgaria
Authors with affiliations: Pamukchieva, V., Institute of Solid State Physics, 72, Tsarigradsko Chaussee, 1784 Sofia, Bulgaria; Szekeres, A., Institute of Solid State Physics, 72, Tsarigradsko Chaussee, 1784 Sofia, Bulgaria; Todorova, K., Institute of Solid State Physics, 72, Tsarigradsko Chaussee, 1784 Sofia, Bulgaria
Abstract: In this work a preliminary study of the influence of light illumination on the optical constants of chalcogenide thin films with non-stoichiometric Ge 19Sb1Te80 composition is presented. Films of Ge19Sb1Te80 with a thickness of ∼1 μm were deposited onto glass substrates by vacuum thermal evaporation of parent glasses. The as-deposited films were exposed to light by using a 500 W HBO mercury lamp. The optical constants of the films, before and after their illumination, were evaluated from the ellipsometric measurements in the spectral range of 300-820 nm. It has been established that illumination of the films leads to a decrease of the refractive index in the studied spectral region, while a slight increase of the extinction coefficient in the 600-800 nm range is observed. For the given film composition the optical bandgap energy of 0.76 eV reduces to 0.62 eV. The film structure shows a very slow recovery expressed in the increase of bandgap energy toward its initial value. The observed decrease of the bandgap energy after illumination is indicative that the film structure undergoes rearrangements upon exposure to light leading to the effect of photodarkening.

Title: Facet oxidation and degradation of AlGaAs/GaAs pulsed laser diodes
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Natl. Institute of Materials Physics, P.O.Box MG7, Magurele, Bucharest, Romania; METAV SA, Zapada Mieilor Str., No 16-18, Bucharest, Romania; Department of Physics, Ovidius University of Constanta, RO-8700, Constanta, Romania

Institute of Materials Physics, P.O.Box MG7, Magurele, Bucharest, Romania; Vasile, E., METAV SA, Zapada Mieilor Str., No 16-18, Bucharest, Romania; Ciupina, V., Department of Physics, Ovidius University of Constanta, RO-8700, Constanta, Romania
Abstract: Oxide films grow in atmosphere as a result of oxidation reaction and mass transport of the element through the oxide film. In most III-V compounds (as GaAs) semiconductor oxides of Ill-element and V-element are formed individually. The AlGaAs/GaAs laser diodes were exposed to facet oxidation at mirror surfaces in normal environmental conditions for a storage process. It was observed a decrease of optical output power in the early stage of experiment together with a constancy of the ratio P/P(0) for the long time term (month). We suggest the development at the mirror laser facet of a natural oxide film as Ga 2O3 and GaAsO.. We present a SEM (Scanning Electron Microscopy) image of a natural oxide film grown in atmosphere at the surface of AlGaAs as laser facet, as well as a picture of a facet oxidation of a laser device. The EDS (Electron Dispersion Spectrum) of a natural oxide put into evidence the O (Kα) signal. Dielectric coating using Al2O 3 and a-Si layers protected a part of laser devices, and at the mirror surface a reflectivity of 70% in the emission range of the laser (890nm) was measured. The emitted power for dielectric coated devices was constant, so the rapid degradation process was slowed down.
Author Keywords: Dielectric coating; EDS analysis; Laser diodes; Oxide film; SEM image
