Authors: Banks D., Skarphagen H., Wiltshire R., Jessop C.
Title: Heat pumps as a tool for energy recovery from mining wastes
Source title: Geological Society Special Publication
Affiliations: Holymoor Consultancy, Chesterfield, Derbyshire, United Kingdom; Båsum Boring AS, Nydalen, Oslo, Norway; Bldg. Res. Establishment Ltd (BRE), Garston, Watford, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Banks, D., Holymoor Consultancy, Chesterfield, Derbyshire, United Kingdom; Skarphagen, H., Båsum Boring AS, Nydalen, Oslo, Norway; Wiltshire, R., Bldg. Res. Establishment Ltd (BRE), Garston, Watford, United Kingdom; Jessop, C., Bldg. Res. Establishment Ltd (BRE), Garston, Watford, United Kingdom
Abstract: Heat pumps extract heat energy from a low-temperature source and transfer it to a higher temperature sink, usually via a closed loop of volatile 'refrigerant' fluid in a compression/expansion cycle. They can be efficiently used for space heating (and cooling), extracting heat from seawater, rivers, lakes, groundwater, rocks, sewage, or mine water. Electrical energy powers the heat pump's compressor. The ratio of total heat output to electrical energy input, called the coefficient of performance, typically ranges from 3.0 to 6.0. The use of mine water for space heating or cooling purposes has been demonstrated to be feasible and economic in applications in Scotland, Canada, Norway, and the USA. Mine water is an attractive energy resource due to: (1) the high water storage and water flux in mine workings, representing a huge renewable enthalpy reservoir; (2) the possibility of re-branding a potentially polluting environmental liability as a 'green' energy resource; and (3) the development of many mine sites as commercial/industrial parks with large space heating/cooling requirements. The exothermic nature of the pyrite oxidation reaction (> 1000 kJ/mol) implies added benefits if closed-loop systems can harness the chemical energy released in mine-waste tips. An appreciation of geochemistry also assists in identifying and solving possible problems with precipitation reactions occurring in heat pump systems. © The Geological Society of London 2004.
Index Keywords: energy resource; heat transfer; mine waste; waste management; Harness

Title: Arming UK industry for nuclear decommissioning opportunities
Source title: Engineering Technology
Affiliations: UKAEA Windscale Adv. Gas Reactor, Cumbria, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Benest, T., UKAEA Windscale Adv. Gas Reactor, Cumbria, United Kingdom
Abstract: In 1998, the United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority (UKAEA) and its contractors started a project to remove the core and pressure vessel of the Windscale Advanced Gas-cooled Reactor. The principal systems conceived to undertake the remote work comprised five components. The first component is a Remote Dismantling Machine (RDM) to deploy tools to dismantle the high dose components. Second is a remotely operated manipulator, suspended from a mast that extends below the RDM. The third includes a wide range of decommissioning tools, connected to either the manipulator or a 3 ton capacity hoist. The fourth component is a recovery and transport system to remove the dismantled sections. The fifth is a waste route through which to move the components, sort them, take assay mesurements, pack them in suitable containers, and treat them for disposal or storage. Currently, the project is in the eighth of ten campaigns.
Index Keywords: Decommissioning (nuclear reactors); Gas cooled reactors; Manipulators; Pressure vessels; Project management; Radioactive wastes; Reactor cores; Societies and institutions; Decommissioning systems; Remote dismantling machine; Technological test bed; United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority (CO); Nuclear industry

Authors: Rochelle C.A., Czernichowski-Lauriol I., Milodowski A.E.
Title: The impact of chemical reactions on CO 2 storage in geological formations: A brief review
Source title: Geological Society Special Publication
Affiliations: British Geological Survey, Kingsley Dunham Centre, Keyworth, Nottingham NG12 5GG, United Kingdom; BRGM, Avenue Claude Guillemin, 45060 Orleans cedex 2, France
Authors with affiliations: Rochelle, C.A., British Geological Survey, Kingsley Dunham Centre, Keyworth, Nottingham NG12 5GG, United Kingdom; Czernichowski-Lauriol, I., BRGM, Avenue Claude Guillemin, 45060 Orleans cedex 2, France; Milodowski, A.E., British Geological Survey, Kingsley Dunham Centre, Keyworth, Nottingham NG12 5GG, United Kingdom
Abstract: The sequestration of CO 2 in the deep geosphere is one potential method for reducing anthropogenic emissions to the atmosphere without a drastic change in our energy-producing technologies. Immediately after injection, the CO 2 will be stored as a free phase within the host rock. Over time it will dissolve into the local formation water and initiate a variety of geochemical reactions. Some of the these reactions could be beneficial, helping to chemically contain or 'trap' the CO 2 as dissolved species and by the formation of new carbonate minerals; others may be deleterious, and actually aid the migration of CO 2. It will be important to understand the overall impact of these competing processes. However, these processes will also be dependent upon the structure, mineralogy and hydrogeology of the specific lithologies concerned and the chemical stability of the engineered features (principally, the cement and steel components in the well completions). Therefore, individual storage operations will have to take account of local geological, fluid chemical and hydrogeological conditions. The aim of this paper is to review some of the possible chemical reactions that might occur once CO 2 is injected underground, and to highlight their possible impacts on long-term CO 2 storage. © The Geological Society of London 2004.
Index Keywords: carbon dioxide; carbon sequestration; chemical reaction; climate change; greenhouse gas; underground storage

Authors: McDonald S., Pan T., Ziaie B.
Title: A magnetically driven PDMS micropump with micro-ball valves
Source title: Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology - Proceedings
Affiliations: Institute of Technology, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States; Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States
Authors with affiliations: McDonald, S., Institute of Technology, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States; Pan, T., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States, Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States; Ziaie, B., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States, Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, MN 55455, United States
Abstract: In this paper, we present a novel robust PDMS membrane micropump with two one-way micro-ball valves for biomedical applications. The actuating membrane is driven by magnetic force of two miniature permanent magnets. The micropump consists of two PDMS layers, one holding the micro-ball valves and actuating chamber and the second holding the top magnet and covering the chamber and microvalves. A simple approach is used to fabricate a high performance micro-ball valve using an embedded Teflon microtube. A small DC motor (6mm in diameter and 15mm in length) with two permanent magnetic discs (NdFeB) mounted on its shaft is used to actuate the membrane-mounted magnet This configuration yields a large pumping rate with very low power consumption. Maximum pumping rate of 260μL/min was achieved at the input power of 21 mW, the highest pumping rate reported in the literature for micropumps at such power consumption.

Title: Scooting toward the future?
Source title: Diesel Progress North American Edition
Authors with affiliations: Geske, D.M.
Abstract: Vectrix Corp. has developed its first methanol fuel cell hybrid electric scooters, in conjunction with Parker Hannifin, and plans to introduce it in February 2006. The 16 kW electric scooter builds of a gasoline-powered scooter, providing an emission-free vehicle that features an ultra-quiet electric motor. The 16 kW hybrid scooter is powered by a Protonics Inc. methanol fuel cell that provides continuous power to a nickel metal hydride battery. The scooter is also equipped with Parker tubing and fittings, fuel cell stack seals and endplates, air compressor, air filter and solenoid valves. The scooter would be the first fuel-cell powered vehicle that is working to develop and commercialize zero emission platforms for two-wheel vehicles since 1996.

Authors: Kascak P., Jansen R., Kenny B., Dever T.
Title: Demonstration of attitude control and bus regulation with flywheels
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: University of Toledo, Toledo, OH, United States; NASA Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH, United States; QSS Group Inc., Cleveland, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kascak, P., University of Toledo, Toledo, OH, United States; Jansen, R., University of Toledo, Toledo, OH, United States; Kenny, B., NASA Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH, United States; Dever, T., QSS Group Inc., Cleveland, OH, United States
Abstract: A flywheel energy storage device stores energy in a rotating mass. These devices can be used to perform the same function as traditional chemical batteries. In terms of the energy storage function, a flywheel system has significant advantages over chemical batteries: length of life, energy density, power density, and the capability of deep depth of discharge. Also, flywheels can be used to control the attitude of the spacecraft. This paper describes an experiment using two flywheels to simultaneously regulate a DC bus and provide single axis angle regulation on an air table. Models of the mechanical and electrical systems are developed, and simulations are run, then compared to experimental results. The correspondence of the simulations and experiments shows the sufficiency of the modeling of subsystems.

Authors: Agbossou K., Kélouwani S., Anouar A., Kolhe M.
Title: Energy management of hydrogen-based stand-alone renewable energy system by using boost and buck converters
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: Inst. de Rech. sur l'Hydrogene, Univ. du Quebec a Trois-Rivieres, PO Box 500, Trois-Rivieres, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Agbossou, K., Inst. de Rech. sur l'Hydrogene, Univ. du Quebec a Trois-Rivieres, PO Box 500, Trois-Rivieres, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada; Kélouwani, S., Inst. de Rech. sur l'Hydrogene, Univ. du Quebec a Trois-Rivieres, PO Box 500, Trois-Rivieres, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada; Anouar, A., Inst. de Rech. sur l'Hydrogene, Univ. du Quebec a Trois-Rivieres, PO Box 500, Trois-Rivieres, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada; Kolhe, M., Inst. de Rech. sur l'Hydrogene, Univ. du Quebec a Trois-Rivieres, PO Box 500, Trois-Rivieres, Que. G9A 5H7, Canada
Abstract: Electrolytic hydrogen offers a promising alternative for long-term energy storage of renewable energy (RE). A stand-alone RE system based on energy storage in the form of hydrogen has been developed at the Hydrogen Research Institute and successfully tested for automatic operation with an in-house designed control system and power conditioning devices. In this system the excess energy with respect to load demand is sent to the electrolyzer to produce hydrogen which, when properly stored, is available to the fuel cell to produce electricity when there is insufficient wind and solar energy with respect to load requirement. The RE system components have substantially different voltage-current characteristics, and they are integrated through the designed and developed power conditioning devices on a DC bus, which allows power to be managed between input power, energy storage and load. The DC-DC buck and boost converters are connected for power conditioning between the DC bus and the electrolyzer, and between the fuel cell and the DC bus, respectively. With respect to the energy level at the DC bus and the control strategy, the controller sends the conditioned signal (duty ratio) to the digitally controlled DC-DC converters for on/off operation, thus controlling the power flow to the electrolyzer and from the fuel cell. The converters' control is based on a chopper multiphase switching technique, which reduces the harmonics levels and ripples with a simple additional filter. The simulated and experimental results of the boost and buck converter operations are compared. Also the effect of duty ratio with respect to the number of cells in the converters has been studied for harmonic reduction. It has been found that the designed and developed DC-DC converters and the control system give effective power flow control with automatic operation of the system under different load conditions and with intermittent inputs from wind turbine generator and photovoltaic array.
Author Keywords: DC-DC converters; Energy storage; Hydrogen; Multiphase switching; Power system; Renewable energy
Index Keywords: Dc-dc converters; Electrolytic hydrogen; Multiphase switching; Proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC); DC machinery; Electric converters; Electric power systems; Energy storage; Fuel cells; Photovoltaic cells; Renewable energy resources; Switching; Hydrogen

Authors: Goodman A.S., Bradley K.J., Wheeler P.W.
Title: Evaluation of the single sided matrix converter driven switched reluctance motor
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)

Abstract: This paper introduces the Single Sided Matrix Converter as a novel variant of the conventional bi-directional form. It may be used to apply both positive and negative voltages to a load, from a multiphase sinusoidal supply, but can only supply unidirectional current. This greatly simplifies the problem of safe commutation encountered with the conventional Matrix Converter. Potential applications of this new converter are considered, with simulation results provided for driving a Switched Reluctance Motor. Analysis of the supply currents highlights the problem with 'pulsed power' motors when no energy storage element is employed. The advantage is a reduction in size of the power converter.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Capacitors; Computer simulation; DC motors; Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electric windings; Harmonic analysis; Reluctance motors; Switching systems; Thyristors; Voltage control; Waveform analysis; Matrix converters; Switched reluctance motor (SRM); Three-phase supply; Thyristor bridges; Power converters

Authors: Václavík J., Novák M., Richter A., Zissis G.
Title: Aspects of energy consumption in large lighting systems
Source title: Conference Record - IAS Annual Meeting (IEEE Industry Applications Society)
Affiliations: KEL - FM, Technical University of Liberec, Hálkova 6, 461 17 Liberec, Czech Republic; CPAT University of Toulouse, 3 118 rte de Narbonne, 310 62 Toulouse cedex 4, France
Authors with affiliations: Václavík, J., KEL - FM, Technical University of Liberec, Hálkova 6, 461 17 Liberec, Czech Republic; Novák, M., KEL - FM, Technical University of Liberec, Hálkova 6, 461 17 Liberec, Czech Republic; Richter, A., KEL - FM, Technical University of Liberec, Hálkova 6, 461 17 Liberec, Czech Republic; Zissis, G., CPAT University of Toulouse, 3 118 rte de Narbonne, 310 62 Toulouse cedex 4, France
Abstract: This paper deals with our study of optimal design of large lighting systems with many fluorescent lamps. Major problems in large lighting systems with luminaries equipped by standard electromagnetic ballasts are inducted current oscillations. Those oscillations occur under normal operating conditions because of presence of good-quality resonant circuit formed by parasitic net inductance and compensation capacitors of luminaries. Current oscillations causes power loses and can cause malfunction of power grid. Paper contains results from comparison of four basic layouts of large lighting systems with electromagnetic ballasts. For analysis and verification of this problem was used mathematical model of lighting system and measurements on real systems.
Author Keywords: Electomagnetic ballast; Electro-magnetic compatibility; Lighting systems; Power consumtion parameters
Index Keywords: Electro-magnetic compatibility; Electromagnetic ballasts; Power consumption parameters; Electric lamps; Electromagnetism; Energy storage; Energy utilization; Fluorescence; Oscillations; Lighting

Authors: Krumrey M., Scholze F., Ulm G.
Title: High-accuracy X-ray detector calibration at PTB
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Phys.-Technische Bundesanstalt, Abbestraße 2-12, 10587 Berlin, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Krumrey, M., Phys.-Technische Bundesanstalt, Abbestraße 2-12, 10587 Berlin, Germany; Scholze, F., Phys.-Technische Bundesanstalt, Abbestraße 2-12, 10587 Berlin, Germany; Ulm, G., Phys.-Technische Bundesanstalt, Abbestraße 2-12, 10587 Berlin, Germany
Abstract: Many experiments in X-ray astronomy require absolutely calibrated detectors. Calibrations can be performed in the Radiometry Laboratory of the Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt (PTB) at the electron storage ring BESSY II in Berlin. This synchrotron radiation source can be operated as primary source standard, providing a calculable spectral photon flux for the calibration of energy-dispersive detectors like Si(Li), HPGe or cryogenic STJ detectors. All detectors including non energy-dispersive devices like semiconductor photodiodes can be calibrated with monochromatized synchrotron radiation of high spectral purity against a primary detector standard, mainly a cryogenic electrical substitution radiometer, in the photon energy range from the UV up to about 60 keV with relative uncertainties of 1 % or less. By using pencil beams, the homogeneity of the detector responsivity and the response function can be investigated, also for pixel detectors.
Author Keywords: Detector calibration; Primary standard; Synchrotron radiation
Index Keywords: Astrophysics; Calibration; Chromates; Detectors; Ionization; Radiometers; Silicon; Synchrotron radiation; Bending magnet radiation; Detector calibration; Electron storage rings; Primary standard; X rays

Title: One step closer to fuel cells in autos
Source title: InTech
Abstract: The use of nanoporous materials for storing and releasing hydrogen to produce energy is discussed. The new technology has the potential to be used to make hydrogen-powered automobiles competitive with traditional vehicles. The technology was developed by researchers from the universities of Newcastle upon Tyne and Liverpool in the UK. In the method, gas is injected at high pressure into the tiny pores of 10-9 meters in size in specially designed materials to give a dense form of hydrogen. Then the pressure within the material is reduced in order to store the captured hydrogen safely. heat can then release the hydrogen as energy, on which a car could run.
Index Keywords: Automotive fuels; Environmental protection; Fuel cells; Gas emissions; Gas fuel storage; Greenhouse effect; Nanostructured materials; Porous materials; Hydrogen powered automobiles; Hydrogen storage; Nanoporous materials; Hydrogen fuels; Automobiles; Fuel Cells; Greenhouse Gases; Hydrogen; Pollution Control; Porous Materials; Storage

Authors: Ozatay E., Zile B., Anstrom J., Brennan S.
Title: Power distribution control coordinating ultracapacitors and batteries for electric vehicles
Source title: Proceedings of the American Control Conference
Affiliations: Nuclear Engineering Department, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Pennsylvania Transp. Institute, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ozatay, E., Nuclear Engineering Department, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Zile, B., Nuclear Engineering Department, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Anstrom, J., Pennsylvania Transp. Institute, United States; Brennan, S., Nuclear Engineering Department, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States
Abstract: Electrical energy storage is a central element to any electric-drivetrain technology - whether hybrid-electric, fuel-cell, or all-electric. A particularly cost-sensitive issue with energy storage is the high replacement cost of depleted battery banks. One possibility to ease the power burden on batteries and fuel cells is to use ultra-capacitors as load-leveling devices. The high power density of ultra-capacitors allows a significant reduction in the power fluctuations imposed on the remaining electrical system; however, the same ultra-capacitors have a very low energy density and therefore must be used sparingly and with coordination. A control strategy for coordinated power distribution is a central issue for ultracapacitor-supported systems. Toward this end, several control methods are implemented on an electric vehicle equipped with a battery/ultracapacitor system with the goal of improving battery life and overall vehicle efficiency. A particular goal is to obtain both a peaking load control and a frequency-weighted coordination between capacitor and battery in order to mitigate transients in the battery current demand. A key control design issue is that the control objectives vary with respect to vehicle velocity, driver's power demand, and state-of-charge of both the batteries and ultracapacitors. Ultracapacitor, hybrid-electric vehicle, control.
Index Keywords: Current load; Energy density; Hybrid-electric vehicle; Ultracapacitor; Actuators; Costs; Electric vehicles; Frequency domain analysis; Fuel cells; Passenger cars; Project management; Sensitivity analysis; Steering; Systems analysis; Capacitors

Title: Suppression of torsional vibrations in rotor shaft systems by a thyristor controlled device
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Max-Planck-Inst. F. Plasmaphysik, EURATOM Association, Boltzmannstr. 2, D-85748 Garching, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Sihler, C., Max-Planck-Inst. F. Plasmaphysik, EURATOM Association, Boltzmannstr. 2, D-85748 Garching, Germany
Abstract: Torsional vibrations and resonances can cause problems in many applications of electrical machines ranging from industrial drives to large synchronous generators. The paper presents examples for torsional resonances measured in the IPP experimental power supply, an isolated power system based on flywheel generators. After a routine check of these synchronous machines, damage to a coupling of one rotor shaft system was revealed which can only be explained by an electromechanical resonance, itself excited by active power transients from thyristor converter loads. Once the coupling was repaired, a novel power electronic device for damping the torsional vibrations was developed. The power circuitry of the device consists of a six-pulse thyristor bridge which is connected to a magnet coil acting as a buffer storage of magnetic energy. The thyristor converter is feedback controlled with the measured first natural frequency of the shaft assembly. Thus, only little damping power is needed which results in a compact converter design. Up to now, two thyristor controlled devices were applied on different synchronous machines in more than 2000 dynamic load cases. Since they work demonstrably reliable and do not require modifications to the existing control or drive system, applications to special-purpose industrial drives are presently investigated.
Index Keywords: Control systems; Damping; Dynamic loads; Electric drives; Rotors; Shafts (machine components); Synchronous machinery; Thyristors; Vibration measurement; Magnetic energy; Rotor shaft system; Torsional vibration; Torsional stress

Title: Integrated magnetic BIFRED converter with lower intermediate capacitor voltage
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Grainger Pwr. Electron./Motor D.L., Elec. Pwr. and Pwr. Electron. Center, Illinois Institute of Technology, Chicago, IL 60616-3793, United States
Authors with affiliations: Aboulnaga, A.A., Grainger Pwr. Electron./Motor D.L., Elec. Pwr. and Pwr. Electron. Center, Illinois Institute of Technology, Chicago, IL 60616-3793, United States
Abstract: The Boost Integrated Flyback Rectifier/Energy storage DC/DC (BIFRED) converter is mainly used to achieve a high input power factor and input-to-output isolation. The use of this topology is limited because of the high DC bus voltage on the internal-energy storage capacitor and consequentially high voltage stress on the primary side semiconductors. This paper presents a modified integrated magnetic BIFRED converter topology, namely bi-flyback converter, with lower voltage stress. Moreover, the magnetic integration of the magnetic components reduces the overall cost, weight, and packaging size. Simulation results as well as experimental versifications for basic and modified topologies are presented.
Author Keywords: Bifred converter; Integrated magnetics; Voltage stress
Index Keywords: BIFRED converter; Discontinuous conduction mode (DCM); Integrated magnetics; Voltage stress; Capacitors; Electric transformers; Energy storage; Inductance measurement; Magnetization; Power supply circuits; Voltage control; Voltage measurement; Waveform analysis; Electric converters

Authors: Zhang C., Tseng K.J., Xiao V., Zhu K.Y.
Title: Model-based predictive control for a compact and efficient flywheel energy storage system with magnetically assisted bearings
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Ctr. for Advanced Power Electronics, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore; Division of Control, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, C., Ctr. for Advanced Power Electronics, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore; Tseng, K.J., Ctr. for Advanced Power Electronics, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore; Xiao, V., Division of Control, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore; Zhu, K.Y., Division of Control, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore
Abstract: A compact and efficient flywheel system is proposed in this paper. The flywheel acts as the rotor of the drive system and is sandwiched between two disk-type stators. A combination of active and passive magnet bearings allows the rotor-flywheel to spin and remains in magnetic levitation. It is a multi-variable, nonlinear, and sensitive system. The conventional PID controller is not effective for such a system operating at very high speed. To achieve better control performance, a novel model-based predictive control (MPC) approach is introduced. The MPC method can pre-ca leu late the system behavior, and can be robust against model-mismatching and unexpected dynamics. The simulation results have been obtained and compared with the conventional PID control. The results show that the stability, sensitivity and robustness of the MPC approach are superior to PID control for the proposed flywheel system.
Index Keywords: Flywheel energy storage systems (FESS); Model based predictive control (MPC); Phase currents; Rotational motion; Computer simulation; Flywheels; Magnetic bearings; Permanent magnets; Predictive control systems; Proportional control systems; Stators; System stability; Energy storage

Title: Energy storage on board of DC fed railway vehicles PESC 2004 conference in aachen, germany
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Bombardier Transportation, Mannheim, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Steiner, M., Bombardier Transportation, Mannheim, Germany; Scholten, J., Bombardier Transportation, Mannheim, Germany
Abstract: The proposed energy storage on board of a DC-Railway vehicle leads to a big step in the reduction of consumed energy. Up to 30% energy saving are expected in a light rail vehicle, at the same time reducing the peak power demand drastically. In addition, with the energy storage an operation without catenary could become reality, which was successfully demonstrated with the prototype light rail vehicle driving with switched off pantograph. This prototype vehicle is in passenger operation since September 2003, the implemented software is optimised on energy savings and first experience is very promising.
Index Keywords: Braking energy; Energy costs; Light rail vehicles; Braking; Energy storage; Energy utilization; Induction motors; Kinetic energy; Railroad cars

Authors: Mazumder S.K., Acharya K., Pradhan S.K., Hartvigsen J., Von Spakovsky M.R., Haynes C.
Title: Energy buffering techniques for load transient mitigation of solid-oxide fuel cell (SOFC) power conditioning system (PCS)
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Lab. Ener. and Switching Ener. Syst., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Illinois at Chicago, Chicago, IL, United States; Cerametec, Inc., Salt Lake City, UT, United States; Energy Management Institute, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Viriginia Tech, Blacksburg VA, United States; Georgia Tech, Atlanta, GA, United States

Syst., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Illinois at Chicago, Chicago, IL, United States; Hartvigsen, J., Cerametec, Inc., Salt Lake City, UT, United States; Von Spakovsky, M.R., Energy Management Institute, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Viriginia Tech, Blacksburg VA, United States; Haynes, C., Georgia Tech, Atlanta, GA, United States
Abstract: Differences in the response times of a solid-oxide fuel cell (SOFC) and its power-electronics subsystem (PES), and that of the balance-of-plant subsystem (BOPS) cause low-reactant conditions near the SOFC electrodes during load transients. Because the BOPS cannot instantaneously provide enough fuel to the SOFC, load transients have a detrimental effect on the performance and durability of the fuel cell. To alleviate the degrading effects of load transients on the performance and durability of SOFC stacks (SOFCSs), we investigate the effectiveness of two energy-buffering devices (namely, a battery and a pressurized-hydrogen-storage tank).
Index Keywords: Balance of plant subsystem (BOPS); Energy buffering techniques; Load transient mitigation; Power conditioner systems (PCS); Buffer storage; Electric loads; Energy efficiency; Gas fuel storage; Hydrogen; Power electronics; Transients; Solid oxide fuel cells

Authors: Destraz B., Barrade P., Rufer A.
Title: Power assistance for diesel - electric locomotives with supercapacitive energy storage
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Swiss Federal School of Technology, CH - 1015 Lausanne, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Destraz, B., Swiss Federal School of Technology, CH - 1015 Lausanne, Switzerland; Barrade, P., Swiss Federal School of Technology, CH - 1015 Lausanne, Switzerland; Rufer, A., Swiss Federal School of Technology, CH - 1015 Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: Diesel - electric traction is a well established technology in railways systems, mainly for lines with a low traffic potential. In those conditions, the choice of a diesel powered locomotive is due to the reduced costs compared to the infrastructure cost of a standard electric train. The main inconvenience of the diesel technology is the primary energy source: oil resources are not infinite, prices are difficult to forecast and CO 2 production increases global warming. It's therefore important to develop new strategies to increase the energy efficiency of a diesel - electric train. To reach that goal, a system with supercapacitive energy storage will be proposed in this paper. The production and exploitation costs of the proposed system will be studied in more detail. The proposed solution will reduce diesel consumption and therefore also CO 2 and other pollutant emissions while being economically viable.
Index Keywords: Energy density; Energy flows; Energy sources; Power assistance; Braking; Capacitors; Diesel engines; Energy dissipation; Energy storage; Pollution; Diesel locomotives

Authors: Tsuno K., Shimizu T., Wada K., Ishii K.-I.
Title: Optimization of the DC ripple energy compensating circuit on a single-phase voltage source PWM rectifier
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Tokyo Metropolitan University, 1-1, Minamiosawa, Hachioji, Tokyo, 192-0397, Japan; Department of Electrical Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1, Ookayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo, 152-8550, Japan; Toho Zinc Co., Ltd., Toho Technical Center, 387, Fujioka, Gunma, 375-0005, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tsuno, K., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tokyo Metropolitan University, 1-1, Minamiosawa, Hachioji, Tokyo, 192-0397, Japan; Shimizu, T., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tokyo Metropolitan University, 1-1, Minamiosawa, Hachioji, Tokyo, 192-0397, Japan; Wada, K., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tokyo Institute of Technology, 2-12-1, Ookayama, Meguro-ku, Tokyo, 152-8550, Japan; Ishii, K.-I., Toho Zinc Co., Ltd., Toho Technical Center, 387, Fujioka, Gunma, 375-0005, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents parameter optimization of the compensating circuit for the reduction of the DC ripple energy on a single-phase voltage source PWM rectifier. In the single-phase PWM rectifier, it is well known that a power pulsation with twice the utility frequency is contained in the output power. In a conventional PWM rectifier, electrolytic capacitors with large capacitance have been used in order to smooth the DC voltage. However, lifetime of those capacitors are shortened by the power pulsation with twice utility frequency. The authors have been studied two kinds of DC ripple compensation circuits, such the authors call an inductive storage method and a capacitive storage method, those enable to transfer the ripple energy appeared on the output DC capacitors into the energy in an additional inductor and additional small capacitors. Hence, extension of the lifetime of the converter can be expected because the small film capacitor substitutes for the large electrolytic capacitors. Moreover, the inductance and capacitance region in which the DC ripple energy can be compensated completely and the overall dimensions of the energy storage devices are shown. Finally, experimental results of compensation characteristics on both the steady state and transient state are discussed.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electric potential; Electric power systems; Electrolytes; Energy management; Optimization; Capacitive storage; Power pulsation; Ripple energy compensation; Single phase voltages; Electric rectifiers

Title: Novel protection strategy for current interruptions in IGBT current source inverters
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Christian-Albrechts-University, Kiel, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Haberberger, M., Christian-Albrechts-University, Kiel, Germany; Fuchs, F.W., Christian-Albrechts-University, Kiel, Germany
Abstract: A novel protection strategy against dc link overvoltages in IGBT current source inverters caused by current interruptions is presented. The proposed concept consists of two steps - a fast passive voltage clamp and actively turned on freewheeling paths across the dc link terminals. To implement this strategy, an electronic circuit was developed and successfully tested. The protection circuit is completely independent from normal inverter operation, has no effect on the CSI behaviour and can be realized at low cost.
Index Keywords: Protection strategy; Terminals; Voltage clamp; Voltage source inverters (VSI); Control system analysis; Electric currents; Electric inverters; Electromagnetic compatibility; Energy storage; Semiconductor materials; Switching; Insulated gate bipolar transistors

Authors: Park S.J., Kang B.B., Yoon J.P., Cha I.S., Lim J.Y.
Title: A study on the stand-alone operating or photovoltaic/wind power hybrid generation system
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Dept. of Electrical Eng., Dong-Shin University, South Korea; Dept. of Computer Eng., Nambu University, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Park, S.J., Dept. of Electrical Eng., Dong-Shin University, South Korea; Kang, B.B., Dept. of Electrical Eng., Dong-Shin University, South Korea; Yoon, J.P., Dept. of Electrical Eng., Dong-Shin University, South Korea; Cha, I.S., Dept. of Electrical Eng., Dong-Shin University, South Korea; Lim, J.Y., Dept. of Computer Eng., Nambu University, South Korea
Abstract: Photovoltaic energy and wind energy are very in constant depending on the season, time and extremely intermittent energy sources. Because of these reasons, in view of the reliability the solar and the wind generation system have many problems(energy conversion, energy storage, load control etc.) comparing with a conventional power plant. So, in order to solve these existing problems, hybrid generation system of photovoltaic and wind power, which combines wind power energy and solar energy to have effect of supporting each other, was suggested. But, hybrid generation system cannot always generate stable output with weather condition, auxiliary generation apparatus that uses elastic energy of spiral spring to hybrid generation system was also added for the present study. And it may confirm that power was continuously provided to load by storing energy obtained from generating rotary energy of spiral spring generates in small scale generator.
Index Keywords: Elastic energy; Hybrid energy; Photovoltaic energy; Wind power energy; Electric loads; Photovoltaic effects; Reliability; Solar cells; Solar energy; Wind power; Electric power generation

Title: Experimental results of the current-source active power filter with a new control delay compensation method
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Institute of Power Electronics, Tampere University of Technology, P.O.Box 692, FIN-33101 Tampere, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Salo, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Institute of Power Electronics, Tampere University of Technology, P.O.Box 692, FIN-33101 Tampere, Finland; Tuusa, H., Department of Electrical Engineering, Institute of Power Electronics, Tampere University of Technology, P.O.Box 692, FIN-33101 Tampere, Finland
Abstract: In this paper an experimental results for a new control system of the current-source active power filter is presented. The control system includes a simple method for compensating the sampling and calculation delays of the digital control system. The compensation in the proposed method is achieved using the regular LC filter of the active power filter as an energy storage for load currents and no additional components is needed in the main circuit Furthermore, the calculation power demand of the compensation method is very low and is therefore suitable for single-chip microcontroller implementations. The proposed control system is realized using a 32-bit Motorola MPC555 microcontroller.
Index Keywords: Control delay compensation; Current-source active filter (CSAF); Feedforward control; Voltage-source active filter (VSAF); Closed loop control systems; Digital control systems; Electric inductors; Electric power systems; Energy storage; Microcontrollers; Active filters

Title: Mitigation of voltage swells by static series compensator
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Dept. of Electric Power Eng., Chalmers University of Technology, SE-41296 Gothenburg, Sweden; Institute of Energy Technology, Aalborg University, DK-9220 Aalborg East, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Awad, H., Dept. of Electric Power Eng., Chalmers University of Technology, SE-41296 Gothenburg, Sweden; Blaabjerg, F., Institute of Energy Technology, Aalborg University, DK-9220 Aalborg East, Denmark
Abstract: Swells and overvoltages can cause overheating, tripping or even destruction of industrial equipment such as motor drives and control relays. This paper investigates the possibility of employing the Static Series Compensator (SSC) to mitigate voltage swells/overvoltages. In the case of voltage swells, active power may be drawn from the grid into the energy-storage capacitor (ESC) of the SSC, depending on the load current and the SSC impedance. This active power may overcharge the ESC. Two possibilities to overcome this situation are explored in this paper: 1) if the dc-voltage of the ESC is lower than a predetermined voltage level, the active power is employed to charge the ESC to this voltage level; 2) otherwise, the overvoltage protection of the SSC must operate. This paper also applies an overvoltage protection scheme based on a combination of a dc resistor with a chopper and the valves of the SSC. The design of the dc resistor is discussed. A 10 kV SSC experimental setup is exploited to carry out experiments in the case of balanced and unbalanced voltage swells at the grid side.
Author Keywords: Power Quality; Series-Connected Converters; Voltage swells
Index Keywords: Dc resistors; Energy-storage capacitors (ESC); Static series compensator (SSC); Algorithms; Capacitors; Choppers (circuits); Electric currents; Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electric relays; Electric utilities; Energy storage; Industrial electronics; Resistors; Valves (mechanical); Overvoltage protection

Title: New energy-storage unit for heavy-duty vehicles encompassing cold-weather starting
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: University of Arkansas, Department of Electrical Engineering, 3217 Bell Engineering Center, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schupbach, R.M., University of Arkansas, Department of Electrical Engineering, 3217 Bell Engineering Center, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States; Balda, J.C., University of Arkansas, Department of Electrical Engineering, 3217 Bell Engineering Center, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States
Abstract: A Standard Light Ignition (SLI) battery, the vehicle energy storage element, must deliver maximum energy and maximum power. These design requirements are self-excluding; consequently, compromises must be made in the battery design. Increasing energy demands of the vehicle electric accessories are moving this technology towards its limits. New SLI battery designs are not providing the required energy density and cold cranking capabilities (i.e., maximum power) at temperatures as cold as -40°F. This paper explores a solution that uses an ultracapacitor pack in parallel with the starter motor and a unidirectional dcdc converter recharging the pack from the service battery. This dc-dc converter allows optimal charging of the pack. The service battery could contribute a portion of the starter motor power using the converter. Lastly, load leveling of the vehicle electric accessories, and hence improved voltage regulation, can be provided to the vehicle power system at a cost by adding to the converter the bi-directional power flow feature.
Index Keywords: Electric systems; Heavy-duty vehicles; Optimal charging; Ultracapacitors; Capacitors; Charging (batteries); Electric motors; Starters; Vehicles; Weather modification; Energy storage

Authors: Ghosal S., Kosut R.L., Ebert J.L., Porter II L.L.
Title: Multiscale modeling and control of RF diode sputter deposition for GMR thin films
Source title: Proceedings of the American Control Conference
Affiliations: SC Solutions, Inc., Sunnyvale, CA 94085, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ghosal, S., SC Solutions, Inc., Sunnyvale, CA 94085, United States; Kosut, R.L., SC Solutions, Inc., Sunnyvale, CA 94085, United States; Ebert, J.L., SC Solutions, Inc., Sunnyvale, CA 94085, United States; Porter II, L.L., SC Solutions, Inc., Sunnyvale, CA 94085, United States
Abstract: Radio frequency (RF) diode sputtering is widely used for depositing Giant Magneto-Resistive (GMR) thin films for multilayers, spin valves, and spin-dependent tunneling (SDT) devices used in data storage, computer memory, etc. However, the thin films thus produced often show unacceptably high variation in GMR properties from wafer to wafer. This paper describes a modeling and control effort that was undertaken for improving run-to-run repeatability. A multiscale input-output model was developed for the primary physical phenomena in the deposition process - gas flow, plasma discharge, sputtering, and atom transport. The model predicts the deposition rate, the energy distribution of sputtered atoms, and their sensitivity to deposition conditions such as power, working gas type, pressure, gas temperature, and electrode spacing. Simulations with this model were used to determine the process parameters to which the wafer properties have the maximum sensitivity. Experiments were performed to determine the relative importance of these parameters. Based on the results, a controller was designed to regulate the time-integrated target bias voltage. Implementation of the controller reduced wafer-to-wafer variation of GMR properties by over 50%. Additionally, application of control to SDT wafers led to improvement and optimization of the process.
Index Keywords: Multiscale modeling; RF diodes; Spin-dependent tunneling (SDT); Diodes; Giant magnetoresistance; Magnetoresistance; Optimization; Random access storage; Sputter deposition; Thin films; Control systems

Title: Power factor correction in single phase AC-DC conversion: Control circuits for performance optimization
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Inst. de Telecomunicacoes, Instituto Superior Técnico, Lisboa, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Anunciada, V., Inst. de Telecomunicacoes, Instituto Superior Técnico, Lisboa, Portugal; Borges, B., Inst. de Telecomunicacoes, Instituto Superior Técnico, Lisboa, Portugal
Abstract: AC-DC conversion with power factor correction may use several well known power circuits (boost, half-bridge and full-bridge), or some single stage converters, in the case of switch mode power supplies. All of them present the same control problem: an accurate control of the input current and the simultaneous control of the voltage across the energy storage capacitor. The control of the voltage at the storage capacitor presents a high response time or a reduced gain, in order to avoid a significant distortion of the input current, with a dominant harmonic at the double of line frequency. In the case of switch mode power supplies, the storage capacitor is designed to perform a required stand-on time and, consequently, is bulky and expensive. This paper presents a survey of the more recent pulse width modulators used in the PFC circuits, namely UCI modulators and the design objectives of those control circuits and their main limitations. It is also presented a new technique for capacitor voltage sampling that permit an important reduction of the response time of the voltage regulators. The stability conditions for PI regulators with sampled feedback are presented. Experimental results obtained with a full-bridge single stage converter are also presented.
Index Keywords: Control circuits; Power factor correction; Proportional controllers; Capacitors; Electric network topology; Electric potential; Integrated circuits; Modulators; Natural frequencies; Optimization; Perturbation techniques; Fuzzy sets

Authors: Liu F., Klumpner C., Blaabjerg F.
Title: A robust method to improve stability in matrix converters
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Department of Automation, Wuhan University of Technology, China; School of Electrical Engineering, University of Nottingham, United Kingdom; Institute of Energy Technology, Aalborg University, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Liu, F., Department of Automation, Wuhan University of Technology, China; Klumpner, C., School of Electrical Engineering, University of Nottingham, United Kingdom; Blaabjerg, F., Institute of Energy Technology, Aalborg University, Denmark
Abstract: The last few years witness a high interest in the use of matrix converter technology in AC/AC power conversion. This paper is focusing on its stability issues. It analyzes the instability reason and reveals that the harmonics interaction of its input current and input voltage is the main cause of instability. The matrix converter stability can be improved by decoupling its input current with the input voltage. A modulation strategy is presented that satisfies the idea. The difference of the strategy compared with the traditional one only concerns on the definition of the reference angle for the input current vector. A matrix converter model that takes the switching behavior and effects related with the digital implementations into consideration is developed for evaluation of the strategy. The simulation results show that the proposed strategy can highly improve the matrix converter stability. It is simple in implementation and the algorithm is robust. Experimental results are presented to verify the conclusions.
Index Keywords: AC/AC power conversion; Detection errors; Input current vector; Matrix converters; Algorithms; Computer simulation; Damping; Electric commutation; Electric currents; Electric inductors; Electric potential; Energy storage; Harmonic analysis; Modulation; Power converters; Resistors; Robustness (control systems); Stability; Switching; Topology; Electric converters

Authors: Koot M., De Jager B., Kessels J.T.B.A., Heemels W.P.M.H., Van Den Bosch P.P.J.
Title: Energy management strategies for vehicle power nets
Source title: Proceedings of the American Control Conference
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Technische Universiteit Eindhoven, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Eindhoven, Netherlands; Department of Electrical Engineering, Technische Universiteit Eindhoven, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Eindhoven, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Koot, M., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Technische Universiteit Eindhoven, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Eindhoven, Netherlands; De Jager, B., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Technische Universiteit Eindhoven, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Eindhoven, Netherlands; Kessels, J.T.B.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, Technische Universiteit Eindhoven, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Eindhoven, Netherlands; Heemels, W.P.M.H., Department of Electrical Engineering, Technische Universiteit Eindhoven, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Eindhoven, Netherlands; Van Den Bosch, P.P.J., Department of Electrical Engineering, Technische Universiteit Eindhoven, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Eindhoven, Netherlands
Abstract: In the near future a significant increase in electric power consumption in vehicles is to be expected. To limit the associated increase in fuel consumption and exhaust emissions, smart strategies for the generation, storage/retrieval, distribution, and consumption of the electric power can be used. This paper presents a case study on controlling the vehicle power net using knowledge of the driving pattern to minimize fuel use, by generating and storing extra energy only at the most suitable moments. For this purpose, both off-line and online optimization methods are developed and tested in a simulation environment. Results show a reduction in fuel use, even without an accurate prediction of the drive cycle.
Index Keywords: Engine speed; Online optimization methods; Vehicle power nets; Computer simulation; Energy management; Exhaust gases; Fuel consumption; Ground vehicles; Internal combustion engines; Optimization; Control systems

Authors: Mitova R., Crébier J.-C., Aubard L., Schaeffer C.
Title: Integrated driver supply with JFET as a "linear" regulator
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Lab. d'Electrotechnique de Grenoble, France
Authors with affiliations: Mitova, R., Lab. d'Electrotechnique de Grenoble, France; Crébier, J.-C., Lab. d'Electrotechnique de Grenoble, France; Aubard, L., Lab. d'Electrotechnique de Grenoble, France; Schaeffer, C., Lab. d'Electrotechnique de Grenoble, France
Abstract: Nowadays MOSFET components are widely used in power converters. They are subjected to increasing requirements: electrical performances, integration, smaller volume and price. The integration process offers the possibility to reduce the price and the volume of these devices and in the same time to add some useful functionalities like sensors for protection and control. This paper presents a solution to integrate the gate driver supply. The main advantage is the energetic autonomy of these devices. This is a parallel circuit that will take the energy available across the power switch while it is in the OFF-state. This circuit contains a JFET and one storage capacitor. The triode-like JFET characteristics permit to use it like a regulator of the self-supply circuit. We present the possible integration of JFET with the main power switch (MOSFET). The two devices are integrated within the same die; they share the same voltage termination and follow the same technological process. The circuit analysis of the structure is provided using numerical simulations.
Index Keywords: Electrical performances; Gate driver supply; Integrated driver supply; Linear regulators; Capacitors; Computer simulation; Electric potential; Junction gate field effect transistors; MOSFET devices; Networks (circuits); Switching; Electric current regulators

Authors: Van Der Broeck H., Wendt M.
Title: Alternative sustain driver concepts for plasma display panels
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Univ. of Applied Sciences Cologne, Philips Research Laboratories Aachen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Van Der Broeck, H., Univ. of Applied Sciences Cologne, Philips Research Laboratories Aachen, Germany; Wendt, M., Univ. of Applied Sciences Cologne, Philips Research Laboratories Aachen, Germany
Abstract: Plasma Display Panels (PDP) are used in large flat TV sets today. Although plasma displays show high performances their use is still restricted to high-end professional applications because of high cost. A large part of the cost is caused by the electronic which covers the whole backside of the panel. Almost three quarter of the electronic is related to sustain drivers. These drivers provide the panel with high frequency AC voltages of about +/- 175V. Because of the energy stored in the electrode capacitance and the high repetition frequency, sustain drivers in PDP consist of transistor H-bridges and energy recovery circuits. These energy recovery circuits are based on resonant topologies, which are formed by the parasitic capacitances of the panel and discrete chokes. Ideally all energy, repetitively stored in the capacitance of the panel, can be recovered. However, the required MOSFETs, the chokes and the PCB connections cause voltage drops, which damp the oscillation, leading to hard-switching operation in the sustain driver units applied today. The paper thus describes the topology and the fundamental operation of standard sustain drivers and it proposes two alternative solutions. Both solutions allow real zero voltage switching. The first alternative sustain driver concept only uses another control scheme, which can be easily installed in the present hardware. The second new concept uses split auxiliary DC voltages for the resonant commutation. The two DC voltages are adapted to perform a complete resonant commutation of the panel voltage with the lowest current. This solution needs a small buck and a small boost converter to be designed for continuous power flow. Since up to 8 sustain driver units are operating in parallel at the same DC link voltage, the required buck and boost converter can be used for all sustain driver units. Prototypes of the standard and the alternative sustain drivers have been built and successfully tested.
Index Keywords: Boost converter; Plasma display panels (PDP); Professional applications; Sustain drivers; Electric commutation; Electric converters; Electric potential; Electrodes; Energy storage; Resonance; Television; Transistors; Plasma display devices

Title: Optimized feed forward control of a STATCOM with limited energy storage capability for flicker compensation
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: SEG GmbH and Co. KG, Krefelder Weg 47, 47906 Kempen, Germany; VDE, Ruhr-University Bochum, Inst. Elec. Ener./Pwr. Electronics, 44780 Bochum, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Wrede, H., SEG GmbH and Co. KG, Krefelder Weg 47, 47906 Kempen, Germany; Staudt, V., VDE, Ruhr-University Bochum, Inst. Elec. Ener./Pwr. Electronics, 44780 Bochum, Germany
Abstract: Flicker is a totally stochastic variation in the mains voltage which affects ligthing sources and is also a power quality problem for both power suppliers and industrial process manufacturers. Currently the main cause of customer complaints due to light flicker is the voltage fluctuation generated by arc furnaces, which often represent the largest single load of an electric power utility. Because of cost efficiency the energy storage capability of static synchronous compensators (STATCOM) for the mitigation of voltage flicker can still only be small compared to the energy taken by an arc furnace during one period of the line voltage. This leads to high demands on compensation strategies. In this paper different feed forward control structures of a STATCOM with limited energy storage capability for flicker compensation are discussed and assessed by simulations based on voltages and currents measured at an arc furnace.
Index Keywords: Energy storage capability; Feed forward control; Flicker compensation; Static synchronous compensators (STATCOM); Computer simulation; Electric arcs; Electric conductance; Electric furnaces; Feedforward neural networks; Flickering; Energy storage

Title: Mainstream memory technologies in deep submicron
Source title: Proceedings of the Mediterranean Electrotechnical Conference - MELECON
Affiliations: Linkoping University, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Natarajan, S., Linkoping University, Sweden; Alvandpour, A., Linkoping University, Sweden
Abstract: Ideal characteristics of any universal memory technology should be to meet the performance of a SRAM, density as in DRAM and non-volatility (like Flash). Flash memories have been dominant in the non-volatile race based on relatively standard silicon design processes. Memory dominance on SoC's continues to increase and hence tomorrow's high quality SOC's require high quality memory today. The emerging mainstream memory technology should be (1) a universal memory (2) a process solution (3) suitable for the SoC market. This paper will discuss a few emerging memory technologies that are being researched today.
Index Keywords: Carbon nanotubes; Electric field effects; Electric resistance; Flash memory; Magnetoresistance; Semiconducting silicon; Electrical energy; Ferroelectric memories; Mainstream memories; Random access storage

Authors: Ferdowsi M., Emadi A., Telefus M., Davis C.
Title: Pulse regulation control technique for BIFRED converter
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Grainger Pwr. Electron./Motor D.L., Elec. Pwr. and Pwr. Electron. Center, Illinois Institute of Technology, Chicago, IL 60616-3793, United States; Iwatt Corporation, 90 Albright Way, Las Gatos, CA 95032, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ferdowsi, M., Grainger Pwr. Electron./Motor D.L., Elec. Pwr. and Pwr. Electron. Center, Illinois Institute of Technology, Chicago, IL 60616-3793, United States; Emadi, A., Grainger Pwr. Electron./Motor D.L., Elec. Pwr. and Pwr. Electron. Center, Illinois Institute of Technology, Chicago, IL 60616-3793, United States; Telefus, M., Iwatt Corporation, 90 Albright Way, Las Gatos, CA 95032, United States; Davis, C., Iwatt Corporation, 90 Albright Way, Las Gatos, CA 95032, United States
Abstract: Pulse Regulation control scheme is presented and applied to BIFRED converter operating in discontinuous conduction mode (DCM). In contrast to the conventional control techniques, the principal idea of Pulse Regulation is to regulate the output voltage using a series of high and low power pulses generated by the current of the input inductor. In this paper, analysis of BIFRED converter operating in DCM is presented. The basic idea of Pulse Regulation as well as the estimation of the output voltage ripple is introduced. Experimental results on a prototype converter are also demonstrated.
Index Keywords: Boost Integrated Flyback Rectifier/Energy Storage DC-DC (BIFRED); Discontinuous conduction mode (DCM); Power conveters; Power pulses; Capacitors; DC machinery; Electric conductivity; Electric current distribution; Electric potential; Energy storage; Inductance; Magnetization; Power electronics; Electric converters

Title: Single-stage power-factor-correction converter using tapped inductor
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Kyushu University, 6-10-1 Hakozaki, Higashiku, Fukuoka 812-8581, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Jin, C.F., Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Kyushu University, 6-10-1 Hakozaki, Higashiku, Fukuoka 812-8581, Japan; Ninomiya, T., Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Kyushu University, 6-10-1 Hakozaki, Higashiku, Fukuoka 812-8581, Japan
Abstract: This paper proposes a single-stage PFC converter using a tapped inductor. This converter operates in the continuous-conduction mode (CCM), taking the advantage of decreasing the high-frequency current ripple and reducing the size of an EMI input filter. Furthermore, using the leakage inductance in the tapped inductor, the line-current distortion is suppressed and the number of components can be also reduced. The effect of some circuit parameters on the line-current harmonics and the voltage across the energy-storage electrolytic capacitor are examined. In our experiment, the line current complies with the international regulations of IEC61000-3-2 Class D. Also, a high efficiency of 87% is obtained for the output of 15V/6A.
Index Keywords: Circuit parameters; Discontinuous conduction mode (DCM); High-frequency components; Tapped inductor; Electric conductivity; Electric converters; Electric currents; Electric inductors; Electric network analysis; Electrolytic capacitors; Electromagnetic fields; Harmonic analysis; Pulse width modulation; Power electronics

Title: Integration of energy storage with a doubly-fed induction machine for wind power applications
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: McGill University, Montréal, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Abbey, C., McGill University, Montréal, Canada; Joós, G., McGill University, Montréal, Canada
Abstract: The doubly-fed induction machine has been shown to be a popular choice for wind power generators due to the desirable features of variable speed operation, reduced converter size and the ability to control the real and reactive output power. For this topology, reactive power compensation can be supplied from both the supply side and rotor side converters and thus has the potential to provide voltage support Addition of an energy storage element on the dc link can help to improve transient stability of the system as well as enable a greater level of control over the real power output. The storage element can be used to smooth the generator's power output by injecting real power under low wind conditions and storing energy during high wind conditions. The design of the proposed system and the control is presented and its feasibility is supported using its representation in EMTP-RV.
Index Keywords: Doubly-fed induction generators (DFIG); Peak power point tracking; Voltage source converters (VSC); Voltage supports; Electric converters; Electric generators; Electric potential; Electric windings; Energy storage; Reactive power; Rotors; Asynchronous machinery

Title: Control of inverter-based distributed generation used to provide premium power quality
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Kasteelpark Arenberg 10, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Macken, K.J.P., Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Kasteelpark Arenberg 10, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: Previous work has demonstrated that inverter-based distributed generation has large potential to provide premium power quality. This paper reviews how solutions for some of the key technical issues might be formed. More specifically, distributed control and microgrid ride-through control are discussed. Two specific examples are included to complete the discussion.
Index Keywords: Control loops; Electronic interfaces; Power quality; Resonance frequency; Approximation theory; Capacitors; Electric currents; Electric potential; Electric power systems; Energy storage; Inductance; Power generation; Resonance; Electric inverters
