Authors with affiliations: Miliani, E.H., Lab. Rech. Electron. E./S.A. INRETS, L2ES - UTBM, Bat. F, Rue Thierry MIEG, 90010 Beifort Cedex, France; Depernet, D., Lab. Rech. Electron. E./S.A. INRETS, L2ES - UTBM, Bat. F, Rue Thierry MIEG, 90010 Beifort Cedex, France; Kauffmann, J.M., Lab. Rech. Electron. E./S.A. INRETS, L2ES - UTBM, Bat. F, Rue Thierry MIEG, 90010 Beifort Cedex, France; Lacaze, A., Power Alstom, 3 Avenues des trois chênes, 90000, Beifort Cedex, France
Abstract: The aim of this paper is to design a control for a matrix converter which interfaces a power generator to a passive charge. Matrix converters, which are direct power electronic converters, are able to provide important benefits such as bidirectional power flow and great potential for size reduction. On the other hand, the complexity of the matrix converter topology makes the study and the determination of suitable control strategies a difficult task. A matrix converter is used as an alternative concept to avoid the need for a gearbox upstream the generator in an electrical energy production process. This work also includes a real-time control of the matrix converter, control scheme and experimental results are presented too.
Author Keywords: Active generator; Matrix converter; Mechanical gearbox
Index Keywords: Active generator; Matrix converter; Mechanical gearbox; Power flow; Cost accounting; Electric commutation; Energy storage; Switching; Thyristors; Topology; Electric converters

Title: The horizon in predictive energy storage control
Source title: Proceedings of the American Control Conference
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Technische Universiteit Eindhoven, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Enidhoven, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: De Jager, B., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Technische Universiteit Eindhoven, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Enidhoven, Netherlands
Abstract: Energy saving storage control in power conversion systems is considered. Savings are achieved by operating the power converters in efficient operating points, meeting the desired power output with an energy storage device. Predictions of the future desired output and conditions are used, with the largest gain for an infinite prediction horizon. This is not realistic: predictions for the far future are unreliable. So, it is of interest to know the performance degradation due to a finite horizon. This paper presents a guideline for the horizon length, using an interpretation of the characteristics of the optimal solution for a stylized problem, that will give performance close to the infinite horizon one. Characteristics of the active constraints determine the desired horizon. When avoiding active constraints covering the full horizon, the horizon can be reduced to the smallest possible one.
Index Keywords: Constraint theory; Control systems; Electric loads; Functions; Parameter estimation; Power converters; Scheduling; Demand; Incremental costs; Supply; Energy storage

Authors: Jun L., Xu D., Cheng K.W.E.
Title: A novel current source converter array with swapping of module control signal
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China; Department of Electrical Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Authors with affiliations: Jun, L., College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China; Xu, D., College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China; Cheng, K.W.E., Department of Electrical Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong, Hong Kong
Abstract: A current source converter array designed for superconducting magnetic energy storage system was investigated. This array is controlled by modulation-signal phase-shifting SPWM method. The DC side current of each converter module of the converter array can balance automatically at the unity power factor, but unbalanced seriously with the decrease of input power factor. In addition, the DC side current unbalancing causes higher distortion of the AC input current. Swapping of the gating signal of each converter module in same row is introduced to average the DC side currents. The harmonics of the AC currents is reduced while the DC side currents are balanced. 2×2 array and 2×4 array are studied in the experiments.
Index Keywords: Control signals; Converter arrays; Gating signals; Power capacity; Arrays; Energy storage; Harmonic analysis; Modulation; Phase shift; Switching; Electric converters

Authors: Georgakis D., Papathanassiou S., Hatziargyriou N., Engler A., Hardt Ch.
Title: Operation of a prototype microgrid system based on micro-sources equipped with fast-acting power electronics interfaces
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: National Technical University, Athens (NTUA), Greece; Inst. F. Solare E., Kassel, Germany; SMA Regelsysteme GmbH, Niestetal, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Georgakis, D., National Technical University, Athens (NTUA), Greece; Papathanassiou, S., National Technical University, Athens (NTUA), Greece; Hatziargyriou, N., National Technical University, Athens (NTUA), Greece; Engler, A., Inst. F. Solare E., Kassel, Germany; Hardt, Ch., SMA Regelsysteme GmbH, Niestetal, Germany
Abstract: The paper presents experimental results from the operation of a prototype Microgrid system, installed in the National Technical University of Athens, which comprises a PV generator, battery energy storage, local load and a controlled interconnection to the LV grid. Both the battery unit and the PV generator are connected to the AC grid via fast-acting DC/AC power converters. The converters are suitably controlled to permit the operation of the system either interconnected to the LV network, or in stand-alone (island) mode, with a seamless transfer from the one mode to the other. The paper provides a technical description of the system components and the control concept implemented, along with extensive measurement results which demonstrate its capability to operate in the aforementioned way.
Index Keywords: LV networks; Micro-sources; Microgrid systems; Power electronic interfaces; Electric batteries; Electric power system interconnection; Energy storage; Installation; Pulse width modulation; Reactive power; Voltage control; Power electronics

Authors: Stark B.H., Mitcheson P.D., Miao P., Green T.C., Yeatman E.M., Holmes A.S.
Title: Power processing issues for micro-power electrostatic generators
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Imperial College London, London SW7 2BT, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Stark, B.H., Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Imperial College London, London SW7 2BT, United Kingdom; Mitcheson, P.D., Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Imperial College London, London SW7 2BT, United Kingdom; Miao, P., Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Imperial College London, London SW7 2BT, United Kingdom; Green, T.C., Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Imperial College London, London SW7 2BT, United Kingdom; Yeatman, E.M., Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Imperial College London, London SW7 2BT, United Kingdom; Holmes, A.S., Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Imperial College London, London SW7 2BT, United Kingdom
Abstract: For various monitoring and sensing applications it is desirable to power the electronics by scavenging energy from any locally available source. A prototype generator for low frequency (human body) motion has been developed using a micro-machined (MEMS) implementation of an inertial generator based on a moving-plate capacitor. The prototype generates pulses of 300 V on a 10 pF capacitor. This paper examines the design of a circuit and mosfet device to convert this energy to a low voltage. Because of the very small charge involved, the effect of leakage and parasitic stored charge are important. A silicon-on-insulator design is proposed and is examined through physics based finite-element simulation. The overall effectiveness of the generation process is shown to be composed of several terms which are functions of system parameters such as generator flight time, device area and circuit inductance. It is shown that device area is a compromise between leakage current, charge storage and on-state voltage. It can, for a given generator and inductance, be optimised to provide the maximum energy yield.
Index Keywords: Charge storage; Maximum energy yield; Power processing issues; Sensing applications; Capacitors; Electric currents; Electric potential; Electrostatics; Finite element method; Microelectromechanical devices; Monitoring; MOSFET devices; Networks (circuits); Electric generators

Title: Prototype development progress toward a 500 kV solid state Marx modulator
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Menlo Park, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Leyh, G.E., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Menlo Park, CA, United States
Abstract: Recent advances in IGBT and SiC technology have made possible a range of solid-state modulator concepts that were unthinkable a decade ago. Power densities and speeds of pulsed-power circuits have increased dramatically due to the commercial introduction of fast, multi-kilovolt IGBT silicon and SiC diodes featured in PCB-style packages. A solid-state modulator concept that stands to benefit considerably from recent IGBT and SiC breakthroughs is the Marx configuration - where an array of stacked modules generates high-voltage output pulses directly from a low voltage DC supply. The Marx scheme avoids the large, inefficient and costly magnetic cores inherent in standard modulator designs, resulting in a considerably simpler, cheaper and more compact mechanical solution. The main disadvantage to this approach is that the individual cells in a Marx bank must float at high voltages during the pulse, complicating the distribution of power and timing signals. This paper examines in closer detail the practical advantages and pitfalls of a solid-state Marx configuration, and explores a design approach with emphasis on performance, wall-plug efficiency, cost of manufacture, availability and ease of service. The paper presents electrical diagrams, mechanical CAD layout and preliminary prototype test data.
Index Keywords: Cell control; Inductive isolators; Marx bank; Voltage transformations; Capacitors; Computer aided design; Electric currents; Electric fields; Electric potential; Energy storage; Insulated gate bipolar transistors; Silicon compounds; Modulators

Title: 35 KW ultracapacitor unit for power management of hybrid electric vehicles: Bi-directional DC-DC converter design
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: University of Arkansas, Department of Electrical Engineering, 3217 Bell Engineering Center, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schupbach, R.M., University of Arkansas, Department of Electrical Engineering, 3217 Bell Engineering Center, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States; Balda, J.C., University of Arkansas, Department of Electrical Engineering, 3217 Bell Engineering Center, Fayetteville, AR 72701, United States
Abstract: The work presented in this paper focuses on the design of a half-bridge dc-dc converter for the power electronics interface of energy-storage units for a fuel-cell sport utility vehicle. Several design options are explored; namely: single stage vs. multiple interleaved stages, and continuous vs. discontinuous conduction mode. These design options are weighed against the design goals of minimum cost, high efficiency at low output power levels, and minimum volume and weight to allow for high integration. Special emphasis is given to the impact that the wide input voltage requirements (i.e., from 150 V to 270 V) has on the component stresses.
Index Keywords: Converter design; Hybrid electric vehicles; Ultracapacitors; Capacitors; Computer software; Electric inductors; Electric potential; Fuel cells; Systems analysis; Electric vehicles

Authors: Nowak M., Hildebrandt J., Luniewski P.
Title: Converters with AC transformer intermediate link suitable as interfaces for supercapacitor energy storage
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Inst. Contr. and Indust. Electron., Warsaw University of Technology, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Nowak, M., Inst. Contr. and Indust. Electron., Warsaw University of Technology, Poland; Hildebrandt, J., Inst. Contr. and Indust. Electron., Warsaw University of Technology, Poland; Luniewski, P., Inst. Contr. and Indust. Electron., Warsaw University of Technology, Poland
Abstract: The paper considers a problem of construction, control and design of converters designed as interfaces between supercapacitor energy storage battery with maximal voltage not higher than 100 V and DC link with voltages corresponding to standard grid voltage (over 600 V). The main feature of this type of converters is the presence of an intermediate AC medium frequency link with transformer permitting the direct voltage fitting. Two types of the converter are investigated showing advantages and disadvantages of both solutions. As more promising the solution with voltage type intermediate DC link on low voltage side has been analyzed and tested in details. The matching of DC capacitance with AC- stray inductance together with proper phase synchronization of DC power controlling converter with AC link voltage permit to obtain a better power factor of DC/AC/DC converters and lower capacitor current, which improved efficiency ensuring the good dynamic. The investigation of the converter circuit and its control is done with the use of exact simulation model and verified on laboratory bench with MOS and IGBT converters and ferrite core transformer.
Index Keywords: Electronic interfaces; Energy storage batteries; Power reserve; Supercapacitors; Capacitors; Electric batteries; Electric potential; Electric transformers; Energy storage; Energy transfer; Natural frequencies; Synchronization; Electric converters

Authors: Pytel S.G., Hoenshel A.S., Lu L., Santi E., Hudgins J.L., Palmer P.R.
Title: Cryogenic germanium power diode circuit simulator model including temperature dependent effects
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of South Carolina, 301 South Main Street, Columbia, SC 29208, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Nebraska, 209N WSEC, Lincoln, NE 68588-0511, United States; Department of Engineering, University of Cambridge, Trumpington Street, Cambridge CB2 1PZ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Pytel, S.G., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of South Carolina, 301 South Main Street, Columbia, SC 29208, United States; Hoenshel, A.S., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of South Carolina, 301 South Main Street, Columbia, SC 29208, United States; Lu, L., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of South Carolina, 301 South Main Street, Columbia, SC 29208, United States; Santi, E., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of South Carolina, 301 South Main Street, Columbia, SC 29208, United States; Hudgins, J.L., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Nebraska, 209N WSEC, Lincoln, NE 68588-0511, United States; Palmer, P.R., Department of Engineering, University of Cambridge, Trumpington Street, Cambridge CB2 1PZ, United Kingdom
Abstract: Cryogenic testing and physics-based device modeling of a germanium (Ge) power diode for power electronic applications has been conducted. Static and inductive load testing of a 10 A, 250 V Ge diode has been performed with temperatures ranging from ambient (∼ 300 K) to liquid nitrogen (77 K). The device was modeled using the Fourier-series-based solution approach for PvN diodes. The Fourier solution was used in the development of a temperature-dependent physics-based model that can be run using simulation software packages such as Virtual Test Bed (VTB) or PSPICE™. This model has proven to be extremely accurate when applied to silicon based power diodes and similar results have been obtained for the cryogenic Ge diode. Formulas for the temperature dependency of Ge physical parameters, such as mobilities, intrinsic carrier concentration and ionized impurity concentration, are extracted from published data and implemented in the model. Since very limited data is available for the temperature dependence of carrier recombination lifetime, its temperature dependence is extracted from experimental data. Interest in Ge power devices and reliable circuit simulator models is driven by low temperature applications such as deep space exploration, medical diagnostics, and superconductive energy storage.
Index Keywords: Power electronic applications; Simulator models; Superconductive energy storage; Temperature dependent; Carrier concentration; Computer simulation; Energy storage; Fermi level; Fourier transforms; Mathematical models; Networks (circuits); Simulators; Diodes

Authors: Xiong Y., Chen D., Yang X., Hu C., Zhang Z.
Title: Analysis and experimentation of a new three-phase multilevel current-source inverter
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China
Authors with affiliations: Xiong, Y., College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China; Chen, D., College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China; Yang, X., College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China; Hu, C., College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China; Zhang, Z., College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, 310027, China
Abstract: Multilevel converter technology has been mainly used for voltage-source inverters (VSP s) by now. But with the development of the superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) technology, superconducting inductors can be used as higher efficiency energy storage elements, the application of current source multilevel inverters (CSI' s) in power systems will be more and more popular. A new kind of three-phase multilevel CSI topology is presented in this paper. The new multilevel CSI' s synthesize the staircase current wave from several levels of balance inductor currents. The switching strategy that can ensure equal current division among the branches and current harmonics reduction is presented. A three-phase 6-level CSI and a three-phase CSI using the new topology are discussed by the simulations. An experimental prototype of a three-phase 6-level CSI has been built to practise the proposition in the paper.
Index Keywords: Current division; Harmonics reduction; Multilevel converters; Staircase current; Computer simulation; Electric converters; Electric currents; Electric inductors; Energy storage; Synthesis (chemical); Topology; Electric inverters

Authors: Klumpner C., Wheeler P., Blaabjerg F.
Title: Control of a two-stage direct power converter with a single voltage sensor mounted in the intermediary circuit
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: University of Nottingham, Sch. of Elec. and Electron. Eng., Nottingham, NG7 2RD, United Kingdom; Aalborg University, Institute of Energy Technology, Aalborg East, DK-9220, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Klumpner, C., University of Nottingham, Sch. of Elec. and Electron. Eng., Nottingham, NG7 2RD, United Kingdom; Wheeler, P., University of Nottingham, Sch. of Elec. and Electron. Eng., Nottingham, NG7 2RD, United Kingdom; Blaabjerg, F., Aalborg University, Institute of Energy Technology, Aalborg East, DK-9220, Denmark
Abstract: Controlling a converter requires not only a powerful processors but also accurate voltage and current sensors and fast and precise analogue-digital converters, which increase the cost per kW of the assembly, especially in the low power range. A matrix converter requires less transducers than a back-to-back Voltage Source Converter because of the inherent direct power transfer which doesn't require a control loop of the dc-link voltage to balance the power of the rectifier and the inverter. On the other hand, two-stage Direct Power Converters (DPC) also perform direct power conversion as the matrix converters but in two stages (AC/DC/AC) without using energy storage in the intermediary circuit. They also offer the possibility to reduce the number of switches compared to the standard single-stage matrix converter. This paper presents a new method to control a two-stage DPC providing sine-wave in sine-wave out operation while using a single voltage sensor mounted in the intermediary link between the rectification and the inversion stages and the information of the sign of the input line-to-line voltages, which is needed anyway for the safe-commutation of the rectification stage.
Index Keywords: Direct power converters; Intermediary circuits; Voltage sensors; Diodes; Electric network analysis; Electric power systems; Sensors; Switches; Voltage measurement; Electric converters

Authors: Pei X., Zhang K., Kang Y., Chen J.
Title: Prediction of common mode conducted EMI in single phase PWM inverter
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Huazhong Univ. of Sci. and Technol., Wuhan, Hubei Province, China
Authors with affiliations: Pei, X., Department of Electrical Engineering, Huazhong Univ. of Sci. and Technol., Wuhan, Hubei Province, China; Zhang, K., Department of Electrical Engineering, Huazhong Univ. of Sci. and Technol., Wuhan, Hubei Province, China; Kang, Y., Department of Electrical Engineering, Huazhong Univ. of Sci. and Technol., Wuhan, Hubei Province, China; Chen, J., Department of Electrical Engineering, Huazhong Univ. of Sci. and Technol., Wuhan, Hubei Province, China
Abstract: In PWM inverter system, the high dv/dt and di/dt due to the fast switching of IGBT could bring serious EMI issues. Based on the study of mechanisms on common mode conducted electromagnetic interference (CM EMI) associated with a single phase PWM inverter, the origin and propagation path of CM EMI noise are highlighted. Compared with buck converter, a simple equivalent circuit is proposed to study the CM EMI. The parameters of passive element are measured by experiment and Fourier transform of the voltage source in equivalent circuit is performed. Time and frequency domain analysis is conducted to obtain CM current waveforms and noise spectra in 10KHz-30MHz frequencies. The simulated CM EMI waveforms are compared with the actual experiments to verify the validity of the proposed model.
Index Keywords: Common mode currents; Motor drive systems; Theory analysis; Time domain simulations; Capacitors; Electric inductors; Electric inverters; Electric potential; Electric transformers; Electromagnetic compatibility; Energy storage; Fourier transforms; Natural frequencies; Pulse width modulation; Waveform analysis; Signal interference

Authors: Haddad W.M., Huit Q., Chellaboina V., Nersesov S.G.
Title: Vector dissipativity theory for discrete-time large-scale nonlinear dynamical systems
Source title: Proceedings of the American Control Conference
Affiliations: School of Aerospace Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0150, United States; Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of Missouri, Columbia, MO 65211-2200, United States
Authors with affiliations: Haddad, W.M., School of Aerospace Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0150, United States; Huit, Q., School of Aerospace Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0150, United States; Chellaboina, V., Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of Missouri, Columbia, MO 65211-2200, United States; Nersesov, S.G., School of Aerospace Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0150, United States
Abstract: In analyzing large-scale systems, it is often desirable to treat the overall system as a collection of interconnected subsystems. Solution properties of the large-scale system are then deduced from the solution properties of the individual subsystems and the nature of the system interconnections. In this paper we develop an analysis framework for discrete-time large-scale dynamical systems based on vector dissipativity notions. Specifically, using vector storage functions and vector supply rates, dissipativity properties of the discrete-time composite large-scale system are shown to be determined from the dissipativity properties of the subsystems and their interconnections.
Index Keywords: Nonlinear dynamical systems; Vector dissipavity; Vector storage functions; Discrete time control systems; Dynamics; Energy dissipation; Functions; Mathematical models; Mathematical operators; Matrix algebra; Problem solving; Nonlinear systems

Title: Advanced Drive Systems
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: SEMIKRON Elektronik GmbH, Nuremberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Tursky, W., SEMIKRON Elektronik GmbH, Nuremberg, Germany; Beckedahl, P., SEMIKRON Elektronik GmbH, Nuremberg, Germany
Abstract: Advanced Drive Systems are DC to 3 phase AC conversion systems and consist of all components necessary to supply a load with electrical energy in the requested quality and quantity [1] [2]. The integration technology for Advanced Drive Systems is shown for systems with DC voltages from 30 V to 900 V and power levels from 15 kW to 250 kW. The main functional blocks of the presented Advanced Drive Systems are: power semiconductor switches in three phase inverter configuration, DC link with the storage capacitors, sensors for current, temperature and voltage, gate driver hardware for the switches, controller hardware, bus interface, power supply for the electronics, common housing for the whole system and cooling [3]. Due to its proven high reliability, SKiiP-technology has been chosen for the mechanical construction. New solutions for the layout of bus bars and DC link are demonstrated which allow ultra low inductance. A parasitic inductance of <1nH for the MOSFET half bridge has been realized.
Index Keywords: Electric measuring bridges; Electric potential; Electrical engineering; Inductance; Integrating circuits; Power control; Semiconductor device manufacture; Switching circuits; AC conversion system; Advanced drive system; Bus interface; Controller hardware; Power converters

Title: A novel three-phase Three-Port UPS employing a single high-frequency isolation transformer
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: ETH Zurich, Power Electronic Systems Laboratory, ETH Zentrum / ETL H22, Physikstr. 3, CH-8092 Zurich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Zhao, C., ETH Zurich, Power Electronic Systems Laboratory, ETH Zentrum / ETL H22, Physikstr. 3, CH-8092 Zurich, Switzerland; Kolar, J.W., ETH Zurich, Power Electronic Systems Laboratory, ETH Zentrum / ETL H22, Physikstr. 3, CH-8092 Zurich, Switzerland
Abstract: A three-phase PWM rectifier and a three-phase PWM inverter are coupled via two four-quadrant full-bridge converter cells and a high-frequency isolation transformer. By employing a third transformer winding and further full-bridge cell battery energy storage is incorporated into the power transfer between rectifier and inverter resulting in a Three-Port UPS concept. The phase shift control of the power flow between the ports is analyzed for square-wave operation of the full-bridge cells. Furthermore, the utilization of the degrees of freedom of the system control, i.e. the extension to duty cycle control for optimizing the system behavior is discussed and control laws ensuring minimum overall system losses are derived. Finally, a control-oriented converter model is proposed and the decoupled control of the power flow of the ports is treated briefly. All theoretical considerations are verified by simulations using PSIM.
Index Keywords: Decoupled control; Full-bridge converter cells; Power flow; Power transfer; Electric batteries; Electric converters; Electric currents; Electric potential; Fuel cells; Harmonic analysis; Parameter estimation; Phase shift; Pulse width modulation; Signal systems; Solar cells; Uninterruptible power systems; Electric transformers

Authors: Klumpner C., Liserre M., Blaabjerg F.
Title: Improved control of an active-front-end adjustable speed drive with a small dc-link capacitor under real grid conditions
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: University of Nottingham, Sch. of Elec. and Electron. Eng., University Park, NG7 2RD Nottingham, United Kingdom; Politecnico di Bari, Dipartimento di Elettrotecnica, Via E. Orabona 4, 70125 Bari, Italy; Aalborg University, Institute of Energy Technology, Pontoppidanstradae 101, DK-9220 Aalborg East, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Klumpner, C., University of Nottingham, Sch. of Elec. and Electron. Eng., University Park, NG7 2RD Nottingham, United Kingdom; Liserre, M., Politecnico di Bari, Dipartimento di Elettrotecnica, Via E. Orabona 4, 70125 Bari, Italy; Blaabjerg, F., Aalborg University, Institute of Energy Technology, Pontoppidanstradae 101, DK-9220 Aalborg East, Denmark
Abstract: Active front-end topologies will be widely used in the future and among them especially the two-level PWM rectifier, due to the need to improve the quality of the input currents and the robustness against grid disturbances of Adjustable Speed Drives (ASDs). Another expectation is that electrolytic capacitors will be replaced by film capacitors in order to increase the ASD lifetime, but as this has lower energy density, the dc-link capacitance is expected to decrease. In these circumstances, operation under unbalanced and distorted supply voltage as well as high dynamic operation of the ASD makes the control task more challenging. This paper discusses problems related to the ASD dc-link both in respect to its stability (under regeneration as well as in the case of constant power absorbed by the inverter stage) both also in respect to the dc voltage ripple generated by the grid unbalance and made more severe due to the small dc-link storage. To mitigate the latter problem it is proposed to pre-compensate the dc-link voltage reference signal considering the real grid voltage. Experiments show that the system handles successfully unbalance situation even with a small dc-link capacitor.
Index Keywords: Adjustable speed drives (ASD); Electrolytic converters; Grid voltage; Voltage supply; Electric inverters; Electric potential; Electric rectifiers; Electrolytic analysis; Pulse width modulation; Robustness (control systems); Capacitors

Authors: Nagai S., Nakanishi R., Tuchiya Y., Ahmed T., Nakaoka M.
Title: Two-switch auxiliary resonant DC link snubber-assisted three-phase V-connection ZVS-PWM inverter with two quadrant ZVS-PWM chopper
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Power Supply Division, Sanken Electric Co. Ltd., Saitama, Japan; Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nagai, S., Power Supply Division, Sanken Electric Co. Ltd., Saitama, Japan; Nakanishi, R., Power Supply Division, Sanken Electric Co. Ltd., Saitama, Japan; Tuchiya, Y., Power Supply Division, Sanken Electric Co. Ltd., Saitama, Japan; Ahmed, T., Yamaguchi University, Yamaguchi, Japan; Nakaoka, M., Power Supply Division, Sanken Electric Co. Ltd., Saitama, Japan
Abstract: This paper is concerned with a novel proposal of the utility AC interactive three-phase soft commutation sinewave PWM power conditioner. The prototype of this power conditioner is developed for solar photovoltaic power generation system and parallel processing UPS with new type battery and super capacitor energy storage devices, which is composed of two quadrant soft switching PWM chopper with step-up and step-down voltage operating modes, three-phase V-connection soft switching PWM inverter incorporating a single two-switch auxiliary resonant DC link snubber into one phase of three-phase bridge legs with divided capacitors, and the three-phase utility AC power source grid. In addition, the operating principle of the proposed power conversion conditioning circuit and system including some unique features is described and discussed, which is based upon high-frequency soft switching sinewave PWM scheme. Furthermore, the operating performances; waveform quality and actual efficiency of cost effective utility interactive power conversion conditioning and processing circuit treated here are evaluated and discussed on the basis of experimental data.
Author Keywords: Soft switching PWM; Two quadrant chopper V-connection inverter; Two-switch auxiliary resonant DC link snubber; Utility AC interactive power conditioner
Index Keywords: Soft switching PWM; Two quadrant chopper V-connection inverter; Two-switch resonant DC link snubber; Utility AC interactive power conditioner; Computer simulation; Electric rectifiers; Electric utilities; Energy storage; Evaluation; Pulse width modulation; Switching; Electric inverters

Authors: Senjyu T., Kinjo T., Uezato K., Fujita H.
Title: Analysis of terminal voltage and output power control of wind turbine generator by series and parallel compensation using SMES
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: University of the Ryukyus, Okinawa, Japan; Chubu Electric Co., Inc., Aichi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Senjyu, T., University of the Ryukyus, Okinawa, Japan; Kinjo, T., University of the Ryukyus, Okinawa, Japan; Uezato, K., University of the Ryukyus, Okinawa, Japan; Fujita, H., Chubu Electric Co., Inc., Aichi, Japan
Abstract: In recent year, the generating power from renewable energy sources is coming up. Particularly, wind turbine generator (WTGs) is attractive because of its advantages such as, pollution free, no fuel cost, abundantly available in nature etc. However, the generated power and the bus voltage is always fluctuating and it mainly depends on the wind speed. A superconducting magnetic energy storage(SMES) unit is capable of controlling both the active and reactive power simultaneously and quickly. In this paper, control systems for active/reactive power simultaneous control and voltage control of the series and parallel compensator using SMES is proposed. It is show through simulations, that the controlling sequence of charging and discharging of the SMES coil effectively damps out the tie-line power oscillations and WTG's terminal bus voltage fluctuations.
Index Keywords: Power oscillations; Reactive powers; Voltage fluctuation; Wind energy conversion; Asynchronous generators; Electric fault currents; Electric inverters; Electric potential; Energy storage; Oscillations; Superconducting devices; Switching; Wind turbines

Title: Weighted least square estimation algorithm with software phase-locked loop for voltage sag compensation by SMES
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhu, X., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Jiang, X., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China
Abstract: A Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) system is developed to protect a critical load from momentary voltage sags. This system is composed of a 0.3MJ SMES coil, a 150KVA IGBT-based current source inverter and a phase-shift inductor. In order to compensate the load voltage effectively whenever a source voltage sag happens, it is crucial for the signal processing algorithm to extract the fundamental components from the sample signals quickly, precisely and stably. In this paper, an estimation algorithm based on the weighted least square principle is developed to detect the positive- and negative-sequence fundamental components from the measured ac voltages and currents. A software phase-locked loop (SPLL) is applied to track the positive-sequence component of the source voltage. Simulations and experiments are carried out to demonstrate the algorithms. The results are presented.
Author Keywords: SMES; Software phase-locked loop; Voltage sag; Weighted last square principle
Index Keywords: Software phase-locked loop; Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES); Voltage sag; Weighted least square principle; Algorithms; Computer simulation; Electric currents; Energy storage; Least squares approximations; Phase locked loops; Voltage measurement

Title: A new dc-dc converter structure for power flow management in fuel-cell electric vehicles with energy storage systems
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Univ.̀ Degli Studi di Genova, Dipartimento di Ingegneria Elettrica, Via all'Opera Pia, 11a, 16145 Genova, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Marchesoni, M., Univ.̀ Degli Studi di Genova, Dipartimento di Ingegneria Elettrica, Via all'Opera Pia, 11a, 16145 Genova, Italy; Vacca, C., Univ.̀ Degli Studi di Genova, Dipartimento di Ingegneria Elettrica, Via all'Opera Pia, 11a, 16145 Genova, Italy
Abstract: Modern fuel cell based electric vehicles should use energy storage devices such as batteries or supercapacitors to guarantee load leveling, assuring braking energy recovery and good performances in transient operations. To this end, converters with bi-directional power flows are needed to connect the accumulators to the dc-link of the motor drive system. In this paper, a new conversion structure for the bi-directional interfacing of two dc voltage sources with a higher voltage dc-link is presented, where only three controllable power electronic switches are needed and where the only limit is that the sum of the two dc voltages must be lower or equal than the motor drive dc-link voltage. The analysis of the converter structure, the control and modulation systems that have been developed and the obtained results are reported.
Index Keywords: DC voltage sources; Energy recovery; Fuel cell vehicles (FCV); Supercapacitors; Capacitors; DC motors; Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electric switches; Fuel cells; Power control; Power converters; Power electronics; Electric vehicles

Authors: Azzopardi S., Vinassa J.M., Woirgard E., Zardini C., Aucouturier J.L.
Title: What can be the optimum IGBT structure under UIS operation?
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: IXL, CNRS UMR5818, Universite Bordeaux 1, 351 Cours de la Libération, 33405 Talence Cedex, France; RAVEL Reseau Aquitain Vehicules E., 8 place des Quinconces, 33080 Bordeaux Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Azzopardi, S., IXL, CNRS UMR5818, Universite Bordeaux 1, 351 Cours de la Libération, 33405 Talence Cedex, France; Vinassa, J.M., IXL, CNRS UMR5818, Universite Bordeaux 1, 351 Cours de la Libération, 33405 Talence Cedex, France; Woirgard, E., IXL, CNRS UMR5818, Universite Bordeaux 1, 351 Cours de la Libération, 33405 Talence Cedex, France; Zardini, C., IXL, CNRS UMR5818, Universite Bordeaux 1, 351 Cours de la Libération, 33405 Talence Cedex, France; Aucouturier, J.L., IXL, CNRS UMR5818, Universite Bordeaux 1, 351 Cours de la Libération, 33405 Talence Cedex, France, RAVEL Reseau Aquitain Vehicules E., 8 place des Quinconces, 33080 Bordeaux Cedex, France
Abstract: For inductive load, UIS conditions occur when the freewheeling diode in parallel with the load has just been destroyed. The energy stored in the inductor can not disappear instantaneously, hence, the associated transistor is submitted to high voltage and high current simultaneously. Based on previous studies, we analyze and try to sum up what can be the optimum IGBT structure for UIS operation. The influence of the device voltage rating, the buffer layer (punch-through and non punch-through) and the carrier lifetime (fast and ultra fast) are investigated by the help of intensive measurements. Simulation results allow to point out the main drawback of the punch-through structure.
Index Keywords: Non punch through (NPT); Punch through (PT); Unclamped inductive switching (UIS); Voltage drop; Charge carriers; Computer simulation; Electric energy storage; Electric inductors; Power electronics; Semiconductor device structures; Semiconductor diodes; Insulated gate bipolar transistors

Authors: Li R., Pottharst A., Fröhleke N., Böcker J.
Title: Analysis and design of improved isolated full-bridge Bi-directional DC-DC converter
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Inst. Pwr. Electron. and Elec. Dr., University of Paderborn, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Li, R., Inst. Pwr. Electron. and Elec. Dr., University of Paderborn, Germany; Pottharst, A., Inst. Pwr. Electron. and Elec. Dr., University of Paderborn, Germany; Fröhleke, N., Inst. Pwr. Electron. and Elec. Dr., University of Paderborn, Germany; Böcker, J., Inst. Pwr. Electron. and Elec. Dr., University of Paderborn, Germany
Abstract: A novel isolated full-bridge DC-DC converter with bi-directional power flow is proposed in this paper. By adding auxiliary active clamping circuits to both bridges, zero-voltage and zero-current-switching are achieved to improve the performance of the bi-directional PWM converter. The switches are controlled by phase shifted PWM signals with a variable duty cycle. The principle of operation is analyzed and simulated. Experimental results of a 3 kW 50 kHz prototype are presented.
Index Keywords: Clamping devices; Computer simulation; Electric potential; Energy storage; Phase shift; Resonance; Buck converters; DC-DC converters; Duty cycle; Zero-current-switching; Electric converters

Title: Intermediate circuit capacitor-current in inverters for uninterruptible power supplies without transformer
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Matsushita Electronic Component GmbH, Zeppelinstr. 19, 21337 Lüneburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Patt, M., Matsushita Electronic Component GmbH, Zeppelinstr. 19, 21337 Lüneburg, Germany
Abstract: In recent years the undisturbed electrical power supply became very important, because of the increasing automation [1]. A protected electrical power supply is possible by using a static Uninterruptible Power Supply (UPS), because its electrical energy is stored in a dc-link intermediate circuit, connected with a battery. An important cost factor and power loss producer is the usually inserted line frequency output transformer. The elimination of the transformer causes a changing of the circuit topology and a riising of the dc-link voltage. It is possible to omit the transformer by connecting the ground wire of the load to the centre point of the dc-link capacitor. The dc-link voltage has to be higher than the sum of the peak value of the sinusoidal output voltage and the voltage drop of the output filter inductance at maximum load (e.g. Ud=800 V) [2]. A second cost factor is the dc-link capacitor. Its reactive power capacity becomes bigger compared to conventional UPS because the low-frequency load current flows through the centre point of the dc-link capacitors. This is an essential and an expenditure property [3]. The centre of the paper is the analysis of the dc-link capacitor current in different topologies. In the first part of the analysis the current-loading of a two and a three level voltage source inverter will be described. In the second part of the paper a three phase two-level and a three phase three level-inverter will be compared.
Index Keywords: Current flow; Dc-link capacitors; Sinusoidal voltage; Capacitors; Electric batteries; Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electric transformers; Networks (circuits); Uninterruptible power systems; Electric inverters

Title: Hydrogen: An open book
Source title: Chemical and Engineering News
Abstract: A review of the article, "The Hype about Hydrogen", published in the 10/11/2004 issue of Chemical & Engineering News, has a number of mischaracterizations. The review claim that Romm's estimates of hydrogen costs are biases. Gasoline hybrids are approximately an energy efficient as hydrogen fuel cell vehicles. They claim that Romm identifies many near- and mid-term opportunities for reducing carbon emissions, but stops short of suggesting how one might proceed. The review also relies on sources that tend to the high side of the cost range in the literatures, and often cites only the highest cost case in referenced studies. A letter advocates hydrogen as a secondary energy source, grouping it together with electrical batteries and other media designed for energy storage. It also puts forward that the review does not sufficiently delineate the central problem of hydrogen as a fuel; that hydrogen is not a primary source of energy.

Authors: Zoka Y., Sasaki H., Yorino N., Kawahara K., Liu C.C.
Title: An interaction problem of distributed generators installed in a MicroGrid
Source title: Proceedings of the 2004 IEEE International Conference on Electric Utility Deregulation, Restructuring and Power Technologies (DRPT2004)
Affiliations: Graduate School of Engineering, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, 739-8527, Japan; Department of Electrical Engineering, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, 739-8527, Japan; Department of Electrical Engineering, UMIST, Manchester M60 1QD, United Kingdom; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Washington, Seattle, WA 98195-2500, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zoka, Y., Graduate School of Engineering, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, 739-8527, Japan; Sasaki, H., Graduate School of Engineering, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, 739-8527, Japan; Yorino, N., Department of Electrical Engineering, Hiroshima University, Higashihiroshima, 739-8527, Japan; Kawahara, K., Department of Electrical Engineering, UMIST, Manchester M60 1QD, United Kingdom; Liu, C.C., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Washington, Seattle, WA 98195-2500, United States
Abstract: This paper investigates an interaction problem that might be induced from various kinds of distributed generators installed in a MicroGrid. One of the most important features of MicroGrid is islanding operation. MicroGrid does not include large central generators and all distributed small generators have to share all loads existing in the MicroGrid. In this case, undesirable mutual oscillation problem might appear when MicroGrid goes into islanding mode. In this paper, MicroGrid itself and several types of distributed generator are modeled by using Matlab/Simulink. A typical case is simulated and examined by using the developed model.
Author Keywords: Dispersed storage and generation; MicroGrid; Power distribution control; Power distribution system
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Electric fault currents; Electric loads; Electric power distribution; Energy storage; Installation; Mathematical models; Dispersed storage; Microgrids; Power distribution control; Power distribution systems; Electric generators

Title: Defining optimal production capacity in a purely hydroelectric power system
Source title: Proceedings of the 2004 IEEE International Conference on Electric Utility Deregulation, Restructuring and Power Technologies (DRPT2004)
Affiliations: University of Iceland, Department of Electrical Engr., Reykjavik, Iceland; Power Systems Research, Mercados de Ener. and COPPE-Sistemas, UFRJ, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Hreinsson, E.B., University of Iceland, Department of Electrical Engr., Reykjavik, Iceland; Barroso, L.A., Power Systems Research, Mercados de Ener. and COPPE-Sistemas, UFRJ, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
Abstract: The conventional definition of system and plant firm capacity, in a thermally dominated power system, is often simply the installed MW adjusted by plant availability. A hydro dominated system requires an entirely different and expanded definition due to the complex interactions resulting from temporal reservoir operational decisions. In this paper several economic definitions of capacity are presented and analyzed based on the need for this concept in the operation and expansion of hydro dominated systems.
Author Keywords: Firm energy; Hydroelectric-thermal power generation; Optimal design; Optimal project sequencing
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric power distribution; Electric power generation; Energy utilization; Game theory; Optimization; Project management; Firm energy; Hydroelectric-thermal power generation; Optimal design; Optimal project sequencing; Hydroelectric power plants

Authors: Wu J.-G., Liu J.-Y., Duan D.-W., Niu H.-P., Xie L.-F., Li W.-Y.
Title: Research on operation reserve capacity in power market environment
Source title: Proceedings of the 2004 IEEE International Conference on Electric Utility Deregulation, Restructuring and Power Technologies (DRPT2004)
Affiliations: Sch. of Elec. Eng. and Information, SiChuan University, ChengDu 610065, China
Authors with affiliations: Wu, J.-G., Sch. of Elec. Eng. and Information, SiChuan University, ChengDu 610065, China; Liu, J.-Y., Sch. of Elec. Eng. and Information, SiChuan University, ChengDu 610065, China; Duan, D.-W., Sch. of Elec. Eng. and Information, SiChuan University, ChengDu 610065, China; Niu, H.-P.; Xie, L.-F.; Li, W.-Y.
Abstract: In power market environment, the first goal of suppliers and consumers is to maximize their profits, respectively. It is a key problem to determine a reasonable reserve capacity that directly influences the price of electricity energy. However, the price is fluctuating with the change of load, so it is necessary for a rational consumer to determine the price of interruption. In this paper, elastic interruptible load is considered as a part of operation reserves. Methods of Operational Research are used to determine operation reserve capacity. Based on system operation reserve costs, compensation costs of load shedding, and history records of reserve capacity probability, optimal storage theory is used to establish a mathematic model which is solved by decision matrix. The proposed approach is applied to a six-bus test system to testify it feasible and economic. The results show that the approach provides a winnable frame for both suppliers and demanders.
Author Keywords: Decision matrix; Interruptible load; Operation reserve; Power market
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Costs; Decision making; Electric loads; Mathematical models; Operations research; Probability; Decision matrix; Interruptible loads; Operation reserve; Power market; Electric industry

Title: Selecting the location and the capacity of SMES for on-line steady state security assessment of power systems
Source title: Proceedings of the 2004 IEEE International Conference on Electric Utility Deregulation, Restructuring and Power Technologies (DRPT2004)
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China
Authors with affiliations: Zifeng, L., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China; Yong, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China
Abstract: On-line steady state security monitoring and assessment of power systems based on SMES is a new application of SMES technologies. The location of SMES device is quite important. In the paper, an algorithm to calculate sensitivities of eigenvalues to loads is proposed, and the influences of the generator damping on the movements of eigenvalues are analyzed. Afterward, the steps of selecting the location of SMES as a disturbance source and the method of selecting the capacity of SMES are proposed. The movements of frequency response curves at measured buses with the variations of loads of the EPRI-36 buses system are used to prove the validity of the selected location and capacity.
Author Keywords: Modal analysis; Power System Security; Power System Steady State Stability; Sensitivity analysis; Superconducting Magnet Energy Storage
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Buses; Damping; Eigenvalues and eigenfunctions; Modal analysis; Natural frequencies; Sensitivity analysis; Superconducting materials; Power system security; Power system steady state stability; Superconducting magnet energy storage; Voltage currents; Electric power systems

Title: FACTS devices in deregulated electric power systems: A review
Source title: Proceedings of the 2004 IEEE International Conference on Electric Utility Deregulation, Restructuring and Power Technologies (DRPT2004)
Affiliations: Iran Univ. of Science and Technology, Tehran, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Kazemi, A., Iran Univ. of Science and Technology, Tehran, Iran; Andami, H., Iran Univ. of Science and Technology, Tehran, Iran
Abstract: The changing nature of the electricity supply industry is introducing many new subjects into power system operation related to trading in a deregulated, competitive market. Commercial pressures on obtaining greater returns from existing assets suggests an increasingly important role for dynamic network management using FACTS devices and energy storage as an important resource in generation, transmission, distribution and customer service. This paper presents the influences of FACTS devices on deregulated electric power systems and their technical and economical benefits.
Author Keywords: Deregulation; Electric network restructuring; FACTS; Optimal power flow(OPF); Placement

Title: An application of mobile agent for power flow control of open electric energy network
Source title: Proceedings of the 2004 IEEE International Conference on Electric Utility Deregulation, Restructuring and Power Technologies (DRPT2004)
Affiliations: Graduate School of Engineering, Mgmt. of Sci. and Technol. Dept., Tohoku University, Sendai 980-8579, Japan; Graduate School of Engineering, Department of Electrical Engineering, Tohoku University, Sendai 980-8579, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Furukawa, K., Graduate School of Engineering, Department of Electrical Engineering, Tohoku University, Sendai 980-8579, Japan; Saitoh, H., Graduate School of Engineering, Mgmt. of Sci. and Technol. Dept., Tohoku University, Sendai 980-8579, Japan
Abstract: This paper proposes an application of mobile agent technique to power flow control of future power systems in competitive environments. " Open Electric Energy Network (OEEN)" which has been proposed by the authors is one of the future power networks [1]. The major function of OEEN is to maintain energy balance with respect to bilateral transactions so as not to cause line overloading. In order to achieve the function, many storage devices are distributed in the network, and which are controlled by a management system named as Power Router. The Power Router acquires information about bilateral transactions and power flows through a communication system to make a charge-discharge schedule of storage devices. The mobile agent discussed in the paper supports the information acquisition and the charge-discharge scheduling of storage devices, and which is called Power Router Support Agent (PRSA). We also discussed about another mobile agent to manage many storage devices in OEEN, and which is called Storage Device Management Agent (SDMA). The mobile agent is a kind of computer program which can deal with some works ordered by its user and also move within computer networks such as Internet[6].
Author Keywords: Mobile agent; Power flow control and energy storage
Index Keywords: Electric loads; Energy storage; Functions; Power control; Scheduling; Software agents; Energy balance; Mobile agents; Open electric energy network (OEEN); Power flow; Electric power systems

Title: System blackouts: Description and prevention
Source title: Proceedings of the 2004 IEEE International Conference on Electric Utility Deregulation, Restructuring and Power Technologies (DRPT2004)
Affiliations: KEMA T and D Consulting, United States
Authors with affiliations: Novosel, D., KEMA T and D Consulting, United States
Abstract: Various aspects about the prevention of system blackouts are discussed. Blackouts are caused by a sequence of low probability disturbances interconnection agreements, availability of reactive support, and lack of coordinated responses among control areas. Fundamental upgrades, such as improved real-time monitoring, diagnostics and training for system operators were suggested for prevention of major blackouts. Preventing major blackouts would require a combination of long-term investments in the transmission systems and improvement in public policy. Research and developments on applications of new technology such as energy storage and superconductivity may also be beneficial for blackouts.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Data processing; Electric generators; Electric lines; Electric loads; Equipment; Maintenance; Monitoring; Outages; Voltage control; Communication infrastructure; Control devices; System blackouts; Voltage instability; Electric power systems

Authors: Iamnitchi A., Ripeanu M., Foster I.
Title: Small-world file-sharing communities
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE INFOCOM
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, University of Chicago, Chicago, IL 60637, United States
Authors with affiliations: Iamnitchi, A., Department of Computer Science, University of Chicago, Chicago, IL 60637, United States; Ripeanu, M., Department of Computer Science, University of Chicago, Chicago, IL 60637, United States; Foster, I., Department of Computer Science, University of Chicago, Chicago, IL 60637, United States
Abstract: Web caches, content distribution networks, peer-to-peer file sharing networks, distributed file systems, and data grids all have in common that they involve a community of users who generate requests for shared data. In each case, overall system performance can be improved significantly if we can first identify and then exploit interesting structure within a community's access patterns. To this end, we propose a novel perspective on file sharing that considers the relationships that form among users based on the files in which they are interested. We propose a new structure that captures common user interests in data - the data-sharing graph - and justify its utility with studies on three data-distribution systems: a high-energy physics collaboration, the Web, and the Kazaa peer-to-peer network. We find small-world patterns in the data-sharing graphs of all three communities. We analyze these graphs and propose some probable causes for these emergent small-world patterns. The significance of small-world patterns is twofold: it provides a rigorous support to intuition and, perhaps most importantly, it suggests ways to design mechanisms that exploit these naturally emerging patterns.
Index Keywords: Data-sharing graphs; File-sharing communities; Small-world patterns; System performance; Buffer storage; Graph theory; Optimization; Probability; Resource allocation; World Wide Web; Network protocols

Title: Impact of modeling accuracy on predictive optimal control of active and passive building thermal storage inventory
Source title: 2004 Winter Meeting - Technical and Symposium Papers, American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers
Affiliations: Dept. of Architectural Engineering, University of Nebraska, Lincoln, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liu, S., Dept. of Architectural Engineering, University of Nebraska, Lincoln, United States; Henze, G.P., Dept. of Architectural Engineering, University of Nebraska, Lincoln, United States
Abstract: This paper evaluates the impact of modeling accuracy on the model-based closed-loop predictive optimal control of both passive building thermal capacitance and active thermal energy storage (TES) systems to minimize utility cost. The following guidelines have been derived: for an internal heat gain-dominated commercial building, the deviation of building geometry and zoning from the reference building only marginally affects the optimal control strategy; reasonable simplifications are acceptable without loss of cost savings potential. Building construction characteristics determine the building passive thermal storage capacity. Zone temperature setpoints are affected more than TES operation by this construction mismatch, and a loss of cost savings potential is found in some cases. It is advisable to make sure the construction material is well modeled. Zone temperature setpoint profiles and TES performance are strongly affected by mismatches in internal heat gains, especially when they are underestimated. Since they are a key factor determining the building cooling load, efforts should be invested to keep the internal gain mismatch as small as possible. Efficiencies of the building energy systems have no direct impact on building cooling load, but they affect both zone temperature setpoints and active TES operation because of the coupling of the base chiller and the TES chiller. Relative efficiencies of the base and TES chillers will determine the balance of operation of the two chillers. Mismatch in this category may be significant. To avoid critical modeling mismatch, system identification techniques may be useful in improving the modeling process.
Index Keywords: Chillers; Modeling process; Thermal energy storage (TES); Zone temperature; Buildings; Closed loop control systems; Computer simulation; Cooling; Costs; Inventory control; Mathematical models; Heat storage

Authors: Van Looy R., Kenjeres S., Hanjalic K., Al Bataineh K., Hollander E., Colenbrander G.
Title: CFD analysis of the mixing behaviour of a stable stratification in a cylindrical tank with a side-entry mixer
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Department of Multi Scale Physics, Delft University of Technology, Lorentzweg 1, 2628 CJ Delft, Netherlands; Shell Global Solutions Intl. B.V., Shell Res. Technol. Ctr., Amsterdam, Badhuisweg 3, 1031 CM Amsterdam, Netherlands

Ctr., Amsterdam, Badhuisweg 3, 1031 CM Amsterdam, Netherlands; Colenbrander, G., Shell Global Solutions Intl. B.V., Shell Res. Technol. Ctr., Amsterdam, Badhuisweg 3, 1031 CM Amsterdam, Netherlands
Abstract: Blending of liquids with different densities is often performed by the oil industry. Side-entry mixers are frequently used to homogenize the contents of storage tanks. Normally, empirical correlations are used to determine the mixing time of these mixers. The objective of the work, discussed in this paper is to establish the potential of CFD in determining these mixing times. A buoyancy extended standard k-ε model has been used to model the mixing behaviour in a tank containing two miscible liquids of different density, which are stratified before the mixer is switched on. The agreement with the experiments was not good: the model in some cases underestimated the mixing time by an order of magnitude. In another attempt, LES technique was used to model this problem. The agreement with the experiments became better but still the mixing time in the low Froude number range was seriously underestimated. Work is in progress to refine the LES simulations.
Author Keywords: CFD; Cylindrical Tank; k-epsilon; LES; Mixing; RANS; Side-entry mixer; Stable Stratification

Authors: Braun R.J., Klein S.A., Reindl D.T.
Title: Considerations in the design and application of solid oxide fuel cell energy systems in residential markets
Source title: 2004 Winter Meeting - Technical and Symposium Papers, American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers
Affiliations: UTC Fuel Cells, United Technologies Company, South Windsor, CT, United States; Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Wisconsin, Madison, United States; Dept. of Eng. Prof. Development, Madison, United States, Industrial Refrigeration Consortium, Madison, WI, United States
Abstract: This paper examines aspects of fuel cell system design for application in stationary residential markets. The development of fuel cell systems for sub-10 kW stationary applications involves consideration of sizing, fuel processing, operating point selection, fuel cell operating capabilities, system integration, and load management strategies. Each of these considerations is discussed, and strategies are presented for matching the electrical and thermal energy demands of a residence with a solid oxide fuel cell power system. Efficiency considerations for configuring fuel cell, DC-to-AC inverter, and electrical energy storage components for conditioning of DC power generated by the fuel cell stack are also given. Recommendations are made on the potential opportunities for solid oxide fuel cells in small-scale stationary power applications.

Authors: Zhu Q., Shankar A., Zhou Y.
Title: PB-LRU: A self-tuning power aware storage cache replacement algorithm for conserving disk energy
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Supercomputing
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, Univ. Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL 61801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhu, Q., Department of Computer Science, Univ. Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL 61801, United States; Shankar, A., Department of Computer Science, Univ. Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL 61801, United States; Zhou, Y., Department of Computer Science, Univ. Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Urbana, IL 61801, United States
Abstract: Energy consumption is an important concern at data centers, where storage systems consume a significant fraction of the total energy. A recent study proposed power-aware storage cache management to provide more opportunities for the underlying disk power management scheme to save energy. However, the on-line algorithm proposed in that study requires cumbersome parameter tuning for each workload and is therefore difficult to apply to real systems. This paper presents a new power-aware on-line algorithm called PB-LRU (Partition-Based LRU) that requires little parameter tuning. Our results with both real system and synthetic workloads show that PB-LRU without any parameter tuning provides similar or even better performance and energy savings than the previous power-aware algorithm with the best parameter setting for each workload.
Author Keywords: Cache Management; Disk Storage; Power Management

Title: Fuel-cell APUs: A step toward all-electric cards
Source title: Machine Design
Authors with affiliations: Kren, L.
Abstract: The features of solid-oxide fuel cell (SOFC) auxillary power unit (APU) by Delphi Automotive Systems for use in automobiles are discussed. Delph's APU is sized to generate 5 kW of electrical power at 42Vdc. The APU replaces alternators and work with the engine on or off, a plus for military, worksite, and recreational vehicles that need autonomous electrical power. SOFC are used in APU as they have a high fuel-to-electric conversion efficiency and are compatible with conventional hydrocarbon fuels such as gasoline, methanol, natural gas, and diesel fuels. SOFC make electricity from fuel and oxidant gases in an electrochemiacl processes that takes place across an ion-conducting, ceramic membrane.

Title: Welding plutonium storage containers
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Westinghouse Savannah River Company, Aiken, SC 29808, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hudlow, S.L., Westinghouse Savannah River Company, Aiken, SC 29808, United States
Abstract: The outer can welder (OCW) in the FB-Line Facility at the Savannah River Site (SRS) is a Gas Tungsten Arc Weld (GTAW) system used to create outer canisters compliant with the Department of Energy 3013 Standard, DOE-STD-3013-2000, Stabilization, Packaging, and Storage of Plutonium-Bearing Materials. The key welding parameters controlled and monitored on the outer can welder Data Acquisition System (DAS) are weld amperage, weld voltage, and weld rotational speed. Inner 3013 canisters from the Bagless Transfer System that contain plutonium metal or plutonium oxide are placed inside an outer 3013 canister. The canister is back-filled with helium and welded using the outer can welder. The completed weld is screened to determine if it is satisfactory by reviewing the OCW DAS key welding parameters, performing a helium leak check, performing a visual examination by a qualified weld inspector, and performing digital radiography of the completed weld. Canisters with unsatisfactory welds are cut open and repackaged. Canisters with satisfactory welds are deemed compliant with the 3013 standard for long-term storage.
Index Keywords: Pinholes; Rotational speed; Weld voltage; Welding parameters; Data acquisition; Electric potential; Helium; Plutonium; Porosity; Radiography; Welding; Containers

Title: A human power conversion system based on children's play
Source title: 2004 International Symposium on Technology and Society, ISTAS '04 Globalizing Technological Education
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Tulane University, New Orleans, LA 70118, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pandian, S.R., Department of Electrical Engineering, Tulane University, New Orleans, LA 70118, United States
Abstract: A new method is proposed for harnessing of human power based on children's play in playgrounds and public places, on devices such as the seesaw, merry-go-round, and swing. When large numbers of children play in a playground, part of the power of their play can be usefully harnessed resulting in significant energy storage. This stored energy can then be converted to electricity for powering basic, low-power appliances such as lights, fans, communications equipment, and so on. The method provides a low-cost, low-resource means of generation of electricity, especially for use in developing countries. The paper discusses the basic theory behind the method. Results of experiments on a laboratory prototype compressed air human power conversion system using a teeter-totter are presented to illustrate the practical effectiveness of the proposed method.
Index Keywords: Economic development; Environmental pollution; Human power conversion systems; Playgrounds; Communication systems; Consumer electronics; Developing countries; Electricity; Energy storage; Energy utilization; Fans; Global warming; Power generation; Renewable energy resources; Solar energy; Wearable computers; Wind power; Direct energy conversion

Title: The effect of reduced design margin on the fire survivability of ASME code propane tanks
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Queen's University, Kingston, Ont., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Birk, A.M., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Queen's University, Kingston, Ont., Canada
Abstract: The design margin on certain unfired pressure vessels has recently been reduced from 4.5 to 4.0 to 3.5. This has resulted in the manufacture of propane and LPG tanks with thinner walls. For example, some 500 gallon ASME code propane tanks have had the wall thickness reduced from 7.7 mm in 2001 to 7.1 mm in 2002 and now to 6.5 mm in 2004. This change significantly affects the fire survivability of these tanks. This paper presents both experimental and computational results that show the effect of this design change on tank fire survivability to fire impingement. The results show that for the same pressure relief valve setting, the thinner wall tanks are more likely to fail in a given fire situation. In severe fires, the thinner walled tanks will fail earlier. An earlier failure usually means the tank will fail with a higher fill level, because the pressure relief system has had less time to vent material from the tank. A higher liquid fill level at failure also means more energy is in the tank and this means the failure will be more violent. The worst failure scenario is known as a boiling liquid expanding vapour explosion (BLEVE) and this mode of failure is also more likely with the thinner walled tanks. The results of this work suggest that certain applications of pressure vessels such as propane transport and storage may require higher design margins than required by the ASME.
Author Keywords: BLEVE; Design margin; Fire exposure; Pressure vessel
Index Keywords: Design margins; Fire exposure; Fire survivability; Overpressure protection; Boiling liquids; Codes (standards); Failure analysis; Fire protection; Pressure vessels; Propane; Structural design; Valves (mechanical); Tanks (containers)

Title: Pressure indication of 3013 inner containers using digital radiography
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Westinghouse Savannah River Co., United States
Authors with affiliations: Hensel, S.J., Westinghouse Savannah River Co., United States
Abstract: Plutonium bearing materials packaged for long term storage per the Department of Energy Standard 3013 (DOE-STD-3013) are required to be examined periodically in a non-destructive manner (i.e. without compromising the storage containers) for pressure buildup. Radiography is the preferred technology for performing the examinations. The concept is to measure and record the container lid position. As a can pressurizes the lid will deflect outward and thus provide an indication of the internal pressure. A radiograph generated within 30 days of creation of each storage container serves as the baseline from which future surveillance examinations will be compared. A problem with measuring the lid position was discovered during testing of a digital radiography system. The solution was to provide a distinct feature upon the lower surface of the container lid from which the digital radiography system could easily track the lid position.
Index Keywords: Container lid position; Digital radiography; Inner containers; Plutonium bearing materials; Containers; Nondestructive examination; Packaging; Plutonium alloys; Pressure effects; Stainless steel; Storage (materials); Welding; Radiography

Title: Residual stress testing of outer 3013 containers
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Affiliations: Savannah River Technology Center, Westinghouse Savannah River Company, Aiken, SC, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dunn, K.A., Savannah River Technology Center, Westinghouse Savannah River Company, Aiken, SC, United States
Abstract: The Department of Energy (DOE) Complex is packaging plutonium (Pu) containing materials for eventual storage at various sites in the complex. The Pu materials are packaged according to the DOE 3013 standard which outlines general requirements relevant to the planned DOE activities to stabilize Pu materials, package them in 3013 containers, and place them in long-term storage until future facilities are available to convert these materials to other forms. Container sections of the 3013, in both the as-fabricated condition as well as the closure welded condition, were evaluated per ASTM standard G-36-94, an aggressive testing procedure using boiling MgCl2 solution to reveal the relative stress corrosion cracking susceptibility of a material. Significant cracking was observed in the bottom half of the as-fabricated can near the base-to-can fabrication weld. This observation indicates that sufficient residual stresses exist to provide the stress component necessary for stress corrosion cracking in the as fabricated 3013 container. Additionally, cracks were observed in both the lid and the body of gas tungsten arc welded and laser beam closure welded containers as a result of this test technique. The presence of cracks in both of the closure welded container samples tested indicates that significant residual stresses are inherent in the closure welding process regardless of the closure weld method.
Index Keywords: Department of Energy (DOE); Plutonium oxides; Stress-corrosion; Surveillance program; Crack initiation; Degradation; Electric discharge machining; Plutonium; Pressurization; Stress corrosion cracking; Temperature measurement; Residual stresses

Abstract: A current limitation of NIR imaging is the lack of sufficient tumor-to-tissue contrast due to the nonspecific delivery of the dye to the tumor. Utilizing one of the most important cancer signatures, the overexpression of glucose transporters (GLUT), we have developed a series of 2-deoxygiucose conjugated NIR dyes (NIRF-2DGs) to enhance tumor selectivity. This uptake mechanism was confirmed in vitro by confocal microscopy on various cancer cells. Following intravenously administration to animals, NIR-2DGs were selectively accumulated in the tumor compared to the surrounding normal tissue as observed by ex vivo and in vivo fluorescence imaging techniques.

Title: Materials in support of a newly emerging hydrogen infrastructure
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP

Abstract: There is an ever-increasing need to explore the use of hydrogen as a renewable energy source. Attendant to this expansion is the need to evaluate the currently used materials for the transport and storage of hydrogen to meet these needs. Historically, most pipelines were constructed using various carbon steels. Carbon steels are susceptible to hydrogen embrittlement, high ductile to brittle transition temperature, and hydrogen induced cracking. Other materials evaluated include austenitic stainless steel, aluminum, nickel alloys and fiber reinforced composite materials.
