Title: Special report: Downstream construction projects on the rise
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Authors with affiliations: Stell, J.
Abstract: The number of downstream oil and gas processing projects has steadily increased over the last 4 yr, according to Oil & Gas Journal's Worldwide Construction Survey. A discussion covers projects in the refining sector, e.g., CB&I Howe-Baker's (Tyler, TX) licensing and engineering contracts with ConocoPhillips for five new hydrogen plants, Suncor Energy USA's expansion projects for a steam methane reforming unit and a distillate hydrotreater and plans to build a HDS unit, and Clough Ltd's completion of Interoil's 32,500 bpd grassroots refinery at Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea; projects in the petrochemical sector, e.g., Dow Chemical's ethylene expansion projects in Freeport, TX, ExxonMobil and PDVSA's agreement to build a $2.5 billion world-class petrochemical plant in the eastern Venezuelan state of Anzoategui, and Petrochemical Industries Co's (Kuwait) plans for two new projects in Shuaiba, including a p-xylene and a new benzene plant; projects in the gas-to-liquids sector; gas processing projects, e.g., ExxonMobil Middle East Gas Marketing Ltd's gas sweetening and NGL recovery project in Ras Laffan, Qatar, that is currently under construction, Snamprogetti SPA's construction on a 6.6 billion cu m/yr gas sweetening, dehydration, and dew point control project in Libya; and an LPG import and underground storage terminal at Visakhapatnam; sulfur recovery projects, e.g., Black & Veatch Pritchard Inc's project that will recover sulfur from refinery acid gas using two 225 ton/day Claus trains, a tail gas treating unit, and a sulfur degasser; and pipeline projects, e.g., Valero LP's two products pipeline construction projects planned for Texas, and an approved legislation to provide a $18 billion federal loan guarantee to support the proposed 3500-mi Alaskan pipeline.

Title: Measuring the summer effect on onp deinking in asia-pacific region
Source title: Asian Paper - New Applied Technology Conference
Affiliations: Akzo Nobel, Eka Chemicals, 1775 West Oak Common Courts, Marietta, GA 30062-2254, United States; Recycled Fibre Chemicals, Eka Chemicals Inc., Akzo Nobel Company, No. 14 Jalan Anggerik Doritis 31/135, Kota Kemuning, 40460 Shah Alam, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Haynes, R.D., Akzo Nobel, Eka Chemicals, 1775 West Oak Common Courts, Marietta, GA 30062-2254, United States; Lam, O.H., Recycled Fibre Chemicals, Eka Chemicals Inc., Akzo Nobel Company, No. 14 Jalan Anggerik Doritis 31/135, Kota Kemuning, 40460 Shah Alam, Malaysia
Abstract: Since 1998 the "summer effect" has been investigated under lab conditions and measured at an industry scale in six different benchmarking studies covering North America, Europe, and the Asia-Pacific region. The "summer effect" is a period during the summer months when mills experience a loss in brightness due to accelerated aging of the ink. The extent to which a newsprint deinking operation losses brightness is a function of ambient temperature, furnish, type of ink carrier, pulping energy, and mill design. The Asia-Pacific region has unique problems with the "summer effect" due to long transient times from Europe and North America of furnish, the higher use of color ink in local furnish, and the high recovery of ONP with low to no generation of virgin fiber. This paper examines these problems based on a region wide collection of samples bi-weekly from 2001 to 2002.
Index Keywords: Effective residual ink concentration (ERIC); Pulper chemistry; Storage temperatures; Summer effects; Benchmarking; Color; Deposition; Fibers; Ink; Paper; Pulp; Thermal effects; Deinking; Color; Deinking; Deposition; Fibers; Ink; Paper; Pulps; Thermal Analysis

Title: Transportation: EU plans expansion of natural gas-import network
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Authors with affiliations: Leblond, D.
Abstract: Plans are being developed for the upgrade and expansion of the EU's energy network. The improved network is a prerequisite to an effective European energy market, while the successful opening of gas and electricity markets requires a major increase in interconnections between national networks. The Trans-European Energy Networks program includes the 10 new central and eastern European countries that joined the EU. The program identifies the missing links and bottlenecks on the electricity and gas networks and the priority items that need upgrading. These include the new transit routes needed to diversify supplies and reduce dependence on individual third countries. The new infrastructure is expected to take 5-10 yr from planning to entry into service, costing as much as €28 billion for both gas and electricity infrastructure. The EU has already agreed upon five natural gas priority projects, e.g., project NG1, which involves installation of a new pipeline to deliver Russian gas to the UK and North Central Europe; project NG2, a new gas pipeline to diversify supply routes from Algeria and increase capacity through Spain, Italy, France, and other EU countries; project NG3, which improves links in the southeastern EU that would open up new Caspian Sea region imports through Turkey, Bulgaria, Hungary, Romania, and Austria; project NG4, which is the construction of LNG terminals in France, Spain, Portugal, and Italy; and project NG5, which provides underground storage in Spain, Portugal, Italy, Greece, and the Baltic Sea region.

Title: The effect of oxygen plasma treatment on the surface energy of exfoliated graphite and the mechanical properties of graphite nanocomposites
Source title: Technical Paper - Society of Manufacturing Engineers
Affiliations: Compos. Mat. and Structures Center, Dept. of Chemical Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48842, United States
Authors with affiliations: Walden, D.H., Compos. Mat. and Structures Center, Dept. of Chemical Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48842, United States; Drzal, L.T., Compos. Mat. and Structures Center, Dept. of Chemical Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48842, United States
Abstract: Wetting of composite filler by a polymer matrix is essential to obtaining adhesion and optimal composite performance. The ability to probe the surface for chemical functionality and acid-base interactions is valuable for matching fillers with the appropriate matrix. In this study, the surface energy of exfoliated graphite nanoparticles was determined via wicking measurements using water at varied pH followed by analysis using the Washburn equation. The surface energy provided the basis for determining the work of adhesion and the dispersive and acid-base interactions. This wicking process was also applied in order to evaluate chemistry changes induced on the surface of exfoliated graphite by an oxygen-plasma treatment. The work of adhesion has its highest value at larger values of pH as a result of the acidic functional groups added to the exfoliated graphite by oxygen-plasma treatment. Analysis of XPS data indicates that the primary functionality added to the surface comes from hydroxyl groups. However, carbonyl and carboxyl groups are also present. The effect of the time between oxygen plasma treatment and surface chemical condition was also studied in this research. It was determined that the work of adhesion decreases with time when the oxygen plasma treated graphite is stored in air. After 24 hours the work of adhesion stabilized over the period in which it was evaluated. The decrease in work of adhesion reflects chemical changes that occurred with storage in air. XPS analysis shows that there is an increase of 140% carbonyl functionality and a 22.4% decrease in hydroxyl functionality associated with these temporal changes. Since carbonyl groups are less reactive with basic solutions than hydroxyl groups, the work of adhesion was lowered. Surface chemical changes were correlated to mechanical properties of composites made with oxygen plasma treated graphite reinforcement.
Author Keywords: Composite filler; Graphite nanocomposites; Polymer matrix; Surface energy
Index Keywords: Composite fillers; Oxygen plasma treatment; Polymer matrices; Adhesion; Interfacial energy; Nanostructured materials; Oxygen; pH effects; Plasma applications; Plastics fillers; Reinforcement; Surface treatment; X ray photoelectron spectroscopy; Graphite

Authors: Sadaghdar M., Iniewski K., Syrzycki M.
Title: 11-Bit floating-point pipelined analog to digital converter in 0.18μm CMOS
Source title: Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering
Affiliations: School of Engineering Science, Simon Fraser University, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Sadaghdar, M., School of Engineering Science, Simon Fraser University, Canada; Iniewski, K., School of Engineering Science, Simon Fraser University, Canada; Syrzycki, M., School of Engineering Science, Simon Fraser University, Canada
Abstract: In many integrated sensor systems applications where signals of high dynamic range have to be sampled with a good precision, large dynamic range non-uniform Analog to Digital Converters (ADC) are often a preferred solution. Using the floating-point compression technique increases the dynamic range of the ADC and reduces the number of output bits, thus helping to reduce the data transmission bandwidth and storage memory. The pipelined structure of the ADC reduces the number of components and therefore, the power consumption to a low 50mW level, while keeping the high sampling rate equal to the clock speed of up to 10 Msample/sec. The peak signal to noise ratio of the conversion is 48dB. This project is done in CMOS 0.18μm technology.
Author Keywords: ADC; Floating-point ADC; Non-uniform ADC; Pipelined ADC
Index Keywords: Floating-point ADC; Non-uniform ADC; Pipelined ADC; Analog to digital conversion; Bandwidth; Energy utilization; Integrated circuits; Mathematical models; Resistors; Signal to noise ratio; CMOS integrated circuits

Title: Nanotechnology based energy generation from thermal radiation
Source title: Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Diduck, Q., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY, United States; Margala, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Rochester, Rochester, NY, United States
Abstract: This paper presents a novel thermal to electrical energy conversion technique that utilizes black body radiation. We have mathematically modeled this conversion technique in order to determine a design methodology as well as provide a means to evaluate the performance of specific designs. The main principle of operation of the conversion technique is in utilizing microscopic waveguides in combination with specialized rectifying structures, called ballistic diodes. These structures, when properly combined, enable DC power generation using switching supply techniques. This is achieved by treating the infrared radiation as a high frequency AC source. This conversion methodology is now possible due to the fact that ballistic rectifiers are much smaller (∼200nm) than a wavelength of thermal energy radiation (∼18μm). We have shown that it is possible to obtain voltages on the order of 0.02 volts from one wave-guide, while using rectifiers that are only 14% efficient. Furthermore, we have shown that it is possible to extract 90% of the available energy within 10μm of depth of the wave-guide structure (assuming a wave-guide opening of 3μm x 9.4μm). We have observed that power densities on the order of tens of watts per cubic centimeter are theoretically possible using this technique. In addition, we address the limitations of this methodology with respect to current technology and future manufacturing techniques.
Author Keywords: Ballistic Diodes; Energy Generation; Power; THz Electronics
Index Keywords: Bandwidth; DC power transmission; Diodes; Electric rectifiers; Energy management; Energy storage; Nanotechnology; Power generation; Temperature control; Waveguides; Ballistic diodes; Design methodology; Energy generation; THz Electronics; Heat radiation

Title: Dynamic economic dispatch in restructured power systems considering transmission costs using genetic algorithm
Source title: Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering
Affiliations: Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Hosseini, S.H., Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Iran; Kheradmandi, M., Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Iran
Abstract: Over the past decade, the power industry in many countries around the world has been undergoing massive changes to introduce competition. In power systems under transmission open access, an optimal schedule of generation of units to satisfy the demand at the minimum production and transmission costs with consideration of system operation constraints is an important issue. In this paper, a method for centralized economic dispatch in deregulated power systems is presented. The considered constraints are minimum and maximum power generation of units, capacity of transmission lines and ramp rate limits. Genetic algorithm is used to solve a nonlinear objective function. Simulations are performed on IEEE 30-bus test system and the results are analyzed and commented.
Author Keywords: Economic Dispatch; Genetic Algorithm; Ramping Constraints; Restructuring
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Competition; Computer simulation; Deregulation; Electric energy storage; Electric generators; Optimization; Sensitivity analysis; Standby power systems; Cross-border trades; Economic dispatch (ED); Ramping constraints; Restructuring; Electric power plants

Authors: Vlahovic B., Filikhin I., Suslov V.M., Wang K.
Title: Numerical simulation of electronic properties in quantum dot heterostructures
Source title: 2004 NSTI Nanotechnology Conference and Trade Show - NSTI Nanotech 2004
Affiliations: Department of Physics, North Carolina Central University, Durham, NC 27707, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vlahovic, B., Department of Physics, North Carolina Central University, Durham, NC 27707, United States; Filikhin, I., Department of Physics, North Carolina Central University, Durham, NC 27707, United States; Suslov, V.M., Department of Physics, North Carolina Central University, Durham, NC 27707, United States; Wang, K., Department of Physics, North Carolina Central University, Durham, NC 27707, United States
Abstract: A confined structure in all three dimensions leads to carrier's discrete energy level spectrum in quantum dots. This property has profound impact on many applications, such as single electron transistors, quantum dot laser, high efficiency photovoltaic cells, information storage etc. A finite element method is utilized to model the residual stress distribution. The effect of residual stress on the electronic and optical properties is studied. This is accomplished by incorporating both the valence subbands and the strain-induced potential field into Sehr dinger equation. A finite-difference method was applied to solve the equation system. The density of states is obtained from the spectrum of the eigenstates. The discrete eigenstate distributions for both with and without residual stress are compared. The effect of the quantum dot size and geometry to the energy state distribution is discussed.
Author Keywords: Electronic State; Numerical Modeling; Quantum Dots; Residual Stress
Index Keywords: Discrete energy; Electronic state; Equation system; Valence subbands; Computer simulation; Eigenvalues and eigenfunctions; Electron energy levels; Finite element method; Hamiltonians; Heterojunctions; Mathematical operators; Photovoltaic cells; Residual stresses; Transistors; Semiconductor quantum dots

Title: Application of temperature fuzzy self-tuning PID controller in a resistance furnace
Source title: Proceedings of 2004 International Conference on Machine Learning and Cybernetics

Abstract: Aiming at the complicated system of calcining the workpieces in the resistance furnace,this paper presents the method of using fuzzy self-adaptive PID controller to improve controlling accuracy of the resistance furnace. It improves system response, makes function more steady and lowers the using of energy and original material. It also lowers waster rate, and calcinned workpieces are good in function. The trial results indicate that the control system has the good application value.

Title: Manufacturing effects on data retention of nonvolatile memory devices
Source title: Circuits Assembly
Affiliations: Data I/O Corp.
Authors with affiliations: Hirsch, K., Data I/O Corp.
Abstract: The need to verify the data retention of nonvolatile memory (NVM) devices to establish a quality procedure for monitoring data retention in production is discussed. Thorough estimation of the NVM device reliability, necessited the inclusion of thermomechanical and temperature-humidity effects. It is observed that the effect on data retention by soldering NVM devices after programmed is negligible.

Title: Hydrogen - Tomorrow's fuel
Source title: Chemical Engineering Progress
Authors with affiliations: Hirsch, R.
Abstract: The use of hydrogen as a fuel for the very long-term future is discussed. In internal combustion engines, H2 burns without emissions of CO 2, particulates and SOx. In fuel cells, H2 fuel can be converted to electric power at attractive efficiencies with negligible emissions. H2 is an energy carrier and not a fuel that occurs in nature. When measured against petroleum-based fuel systems in the near-term, it is well established that H2-fueled systems have large economic barriers to overcome.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Combustion; Electricity; Functions; Internal combustion engines; Probability; Problem solving; Electric storage; Energy carriers; Energy transition; Fuel production; Hydrogen

Title: Huntsman slams pricing system
Source title: Chemical Market Reporter
Abstract: Peter Huntsman, president of the Huntsman companies has called for renewing pricing system of natural gas. The call to renew pricing system is made due to a 25 percent price increase in recent trading. It is pointed out that the gas prices in the US are higher and more volatile as compared to the rest of the world, despite of the highest storage of natural gas. The company has called the congress members to look into the gas pricing and consider the much needed corrections in the gas pricing policy.
Index Keywords: Commerce; Customer satisfaction; Energy policy; Gas fuel storage; Industrial economics; Natural gas; Huntsman (CO); Natural gas pricing; Pricing system; Costs

Title: Specifying desiccant dehumidifiers
Source title: HPAC Heating, Piping, AirConditioning Engineering
Affiliations: Advantek Consulting Inc., Melbourne, FL, United States
Authors with affiliations: West, M., Advantek Consulting Inc., Melbourne, FL, United States
Abstract: The features of desiccant dehumidifiers, used for lower-dew-point applications, such as frozen-food display, plastics production and records storage, are discussed. Active desiccant dehumidifiers require an external heat source for regeneration, while passive units exchange moisture and heat between fresh- and exhaust-air streams. Active desiccant units are most cost-effective when they use low-grade heat for regeneration. Desiccant systems are most beneficial where thermal energy is readily available, the price of electricity is high and the sensible-load fraction is low.
Index Keywords: Dehumidifiers; Direct-expansion (DX) hot gas; Heat generation; Sensible heat ratio (SHR); Cooling; Cost effectiveness; Electricity; Energy conservation; Heat transfer; Project management; Turbines; Water treatment; Heating

Title: News: Funding, demo for regenerative fuel cell
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: Distributed Energy Systems has won a Small Business Innovative Research contract from the US Army Missile Defense Agency (MDA), to continue development of lightweight regenerative fuel cell technology for high-altitude airships. The company's subsidiary, Proton Energy Systems, is to receive funding from the Connecticut Clean Energy Fund to design, build and conduct a 2-yr demonstration of a 5 kwe Regenerative Fuel Cell (RFC) for a telecoms site in the southwest of the state. The $750,000 Phase II contract from the MDA is to demonstrate a multi-kwe-capable, closed-loop hydrogen-oxygen RFC, and continues work completed in the first phase. This RFC can generate pressurized hydrogen and oxygen electrochemically, without mechanical compression. MDA plans to apply this technology for energy storage for high-altitude airships. The Phase I contract demonstrated key lightweight components for electrochemical cells. Proton Energy's Hipress™ solid-state electrolysis cell stack design makes possible efficient compression of hydrogen and oxygen at > 210 bar.

Title: News: Palcan storage for Indian trike trial, BC scooters
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: British Columbia (BC)-based Palcan Power Systems has sold a rare-earth metal hydride (REMH) hydrogen storage system to Bharat Petroleum Corp. Bharat plans to test the low-pressure (< 100 psi, 7 bar) storage system in three-wheel and small vehicle configurations. The Institute has also commissioned Palcan for Integrated Energy Systems at BC's University of Victoria (IESVic), to prepare and supply two scooters for comparative research. The scooters for IESVic will be tested using the same driving cycles on the institute's specialized test equipment utilizing mathematical models and research software. One scooter will be a commercially available battery electric scooter, while the second is similar but employs a 1 kwe PalPac PEM fuel cell power module and hybrid energy storage subsystem.

Title: Canwest Propane: Canwest Propane's newest terminal delivers the winning conditions for B.C. market expansion. New rail terminal. New energy
Source title: Propane Canada
Abstract: Located in Surrey, British Columbia, first rail terminal opened by Canwest Propane Ltd officially opened for business on 11/1/2004. The facility sits on 4.5 acres of land. A Canadian National Railway Co rail track runs alongside the site, where six, 300,0000-gal storage tanks are located. In excess of 60 million L/yr of propane will be distributed from the terminal, to Vancouver Island, the Lower Mainland, and the US Pacific Northwest. Canwest is looking for incremental growth on Vancouver Island, with a rising population and more people heating their homes with propane.

Title: Solar-powered circulation replaces copper sulphate in controlling algae
Source title: Water and Wastewater International
Authors with affiliations: Sullivan, E.
Abstract: The role of solar-powered aeration technology Solarbee®, developed by Pump Systems, Inc., (PSI), in controlling algae is discussed. This technology is a floating, self-contained system that provides continuous forced circulation and prevents the formation of blue-green algae blooms. The ability of this technology to effectively eliminate blue-green blooms by maintaining surface water turbulence rather than copper sulfate has been well documented. The Eaglewood Water district is also considering the installation of SolarBee units in potable water storage tanks.

Authors: Janapsatya A., Parameswaran S., Henkel J.
Title: REMcode: Relocating embedded code for improving system efficiency
Source title: IEE Proceedings: Computers and Digital Techniques
Affiliations: Sch. of Comp. Science/Engineering, University of New South Wales, Sydney, NSW 2052, Australia; Department of Computer Science, University of Karlsruhe, Karlsruhe, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Janapsatya, A., Sch. of Comp. Science/Engineering, University of New South Wales, Sydney, NSW 2052, Australia; Parameswaran, S., Sch. of Comp. Science/Engineering, University of New South Wales, Sydney, NSW 2052, Australia; Henkel, J., Department of Computer Science, University of Karlsruhe, Karlsruhe, Germany
Abstract: The memory hierarchy subsystem has a significant impact on performance and energy consumption of an embedded system. Methods which increase the hit ratio of the cache hierarchy will typically enhance the performance and reduce the embedded system's total energy consumption. This is mainly due to reduced cache-to-memory bus transactions, fewer main memory accesses and fewer processor waiting cycles. A heuristic approach is presented to reduce the total number of cache misses by carefully relocating selected sections of the application's software code within the main memory, thus reducing conflict misses resulting from the cache hierarchy. The method requires no hardware modifications i.e. it is a software-only approach. For the first rime such a method is applied to large program traces, and the miss rates and corresponding energy savings are observed while varying cache size, line size and associativity. Relocating the code consistently produces superior performance on direct-mapped cache. Since direct-mapped caches, being smaller in silicon area than caches with higher associativity (for the same size), cost less in terms of energy/access, and access faster, using direct-mapped instruction cache with code relocation for performance-oriented embedded systems is recommended. A maximum cache miss rate reduction from 71% down to less than 1% is achieved, with energy reductions of up to 63% with only a small increase in main memory size. © IEE, 2004.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Cache memory; Codes (symbols); Heuristic methods; Hierarchical systems; Semantics; Storage allocation (computer); Cache allocation; Code relocation; Heuristic code placement; Embedded systems

Title: OSEA 2004 final exhibition preview: Exhibitors: Changing the way we do things
Source title: PetroMin
Abstract: Sea Steel's novel pile installation tool, Fast Frame, continues to set new standards in reducing offshore installation times for floating production, storage, and offloading vessel moorings, riser base, and initiation piles. Notable recent successes include Technip Offshore Canada Ltd's Husky White Rose Project, Stolt Offshore AS's Statoil Kristin Development, and the Technip Offshore Norge on the Statoil Åsgard Project. The main functions of Fast Frame are activated using the free energy from the driven pile or by gravity as the frame is lifted from the seabed. No remote hydraulic or electrical power systems are necessary from the support vessel. The new compact 36FFX uses gravity to operate its functions, acting like a flat pack that opens up on contact with the seabed ready for operation.

Title: Powerful presence
Source title: Electronic Product Design
Authors with affiliations: Breslin, T.
Abstract: The latest range of power supply models developed by power supply manufacturers are presented in Electronica 2004 in Munich. Medical system power supply manufacturer, Condor introduced 25 new products in form of single and multiple output models. The models include: GPMP600 range of 600/700W supplies for high power medical systems and the GNTM30 [30W] and GNTM60 [60W] for next-generation medical systems. Agilent Technologies also offers three programmable power modules to the N6700, which can be mixed and matched to meet system requirements for aerospace/defence, consumer, computers and peripherals. The company's virtual channel capabilities simplified the process of paralleling.
Index Keywords: Biomedical equipment; Electric potential; Electric power system interconnection; Electric power systems; Electronics packaging; Energy storage; Parallel processing systems; Product development; Virtual reality; Agilent Technologies (CO); Condor (CO); Glassman (CO); High power medical systems; Power supply models; Electric power supplies to apparatus

Title: Waste issue dominates nuclear scene
Source title: Power Engineering (Barrington, Illinois)
Authors with affiliations: Zink, J.C.
Abstract: The need to develop new and improved nuclear technologies by the nuclear industry, in order to dispose off wastes and hazardous materials, is discussed. Nuclear industry would now get a reimbursement from the government for its excess onsite spent fuel storage costs since the Department of Energy (DOE) reneged its contract. The reimbursement money will not come from the nuclear waste fund, but from government's general fund. This will mean that nuclear utilities' payments for permanent waste disposal would be used for that specific purpose and will not be used to pay DOE's management problems.
Index Keywords: Contracts; Environmental protection; Geological repositories; Hazardous materials; Industrial waste disposal; Laws and legislation; Project management; Public policy; Radioactive wastes; Regulatory compliance; Standards; Department of Energy (DOE); Nuclear Energy Institute (NEI); Nuclear utilities; Nuclear Waste Technical Review Board (NWTRB); Nuclear industry

Title: The NAS solution
Source title: PEI Power Engineering International
Affiliations: Amer. Elec. Pwr. Service Corporation, OH, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nichols, D., Amer. Elec. Pwr. Service Corporation, OH, United States
Abstract: Viable solutions offered by NAS technology to utilities to the challanges of load-levelling and power quality through energy storage is discussed. It is observed that Power Quality (PQ) problems are caused by brief momentary power variations lasting less than seconds, and long-term outage. It is observed that with an appropriate thermal management, the NAS battery can deliver pulse power for durations of tens of minutes with trade-offs on the number peak shaving cycles. NAS battery posseses excellent energy and power density, high electrical efficiency, long life, and a pulse power capability.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric load management; Electric potential; Electric power systems; High temperature effects; Power generation; Problem solving; Project management; Power quality; Pulse power; Storage devices; Thermal management; Energy storage

Title: Hydrogen energy systems - Concepts and practical applications
Source title: Refocus
Affiliations: Carter Burgess, Inc., 777 Main Street, Fort Worth, TX 76102, United States
Authors with affiliations: Berndt, D., Carter Burgess, Inc., 777 Main Street, Fort Worth, TX 76102, United States
Abstract: The various concepts and practical application of hydrogen energy systems are discussed. In a hydrogen economy, an ideal concept is to use electricity from renewable energy resources alone to electrolyze water and break it down into into its components of hydrogen and oxygen. Hydrogen can be stored as a compressed gas, and it can be stored at temperatures low enough to liquefy the gas, or it can be absorbed into a solid. Hydrogen can be used make electricity through fuel cells, engine generator sets or gas fired steam turbines. A hydrogen based economy has the potential to provide energy security to the world for at least the next millenium.
Index Keywords: Electric power generation; Environmental impact; Gas emissions; Global warming; Natural gas; Renewable energy resources; Waste heat; Wind power; Hydrogen economy; Hydrogen fuel cells; Hydrogen storage systems; Nitrogen emissions; Hydrogen fuels

Title: A better way to ensure plant safety
Source title: Control (Chicago, Ill)
Affiliations: ICE-Pros, Inc.
Authors with affiliations: Verhappen, I., ICE-Pros, Inc.
Abstract: The increasing use of Intrinsic Safety, a protection standard adopted around the world, in the US is discussed. One factor in the increased use of IS techniques in the US was the adoption of Zones in the most recent edition of the National Electrical Code (NEC) and the Canadian Electrical Code (CEC) in Canada. IS operates on the principle of ensuring that energy level of a circuit is always kept at a low and safe enough level, including a safety factor, to prevent the ignition of any available fuel and oxidizer. IS systems are designed using either the 'Systems Approval' or the more common 'Parametric; approach.

Title: Atomic layer deposition of dielectrics and electrodes for embedded-dram capacitor cells in 90 NM technology and beyond
Source title: Proceedings - Electrochemical Society
Affiliations: Crolles-2 Alliance, Philips Semiconductors, 850 Rue Jean Monnet, Crolles, France; Crolles-2 Alliance, STMicrolectronics, 850 Rue Jean Monnet, Crolles, France; Crolles-2 Alliance, Motorola, 850 Rue Jean Monnet, Crolles, France; CEA-LETI, Rue des Martyrs, Grenoble, France
Authors with affiliations: Gerritsen, E., Crolles-2 Alliance, Philips Semiconductors, 850 Rue Jean Monnet, Crolles, France; Jourdan, N., Crolles-2 Alliance, STMicrolectronics, 850 Rue Jean Monnet, Crolles, France; Piazza, M., Crolles-2 Alliance, STMicrolectronics, 850 Rue Jean Monnet, Crolles, France; Fraboulet, D.; Monsieur, F., Crolles-2 Alliance, STMicrolectronics, 850 Rue Jean Monnet, Crolles, France; Damlencourt, J.F., CEA-LETI, Rue des Martyrs, Grenoble, France; Martin, F., CEA-LETI, Rue des Martyrs, Grenoble, France; Mazaleyrat, E., Crolles-2 Alliance, STMicrolectronics, 850 Rue Jean Monnet, Crolles, France; Barla, K., Crolles-2 Alliance, STMicrolectronics, 850 Rue Jean Monnet, Crolles, France; Bartlett, G., Crolles-2 Alliance, Motorola, 850 Rue Jean Monnet, Crolles, France
Abstract: An overview is given on the use of ALD deposition technologies for high-k dielectrics and electrodes in MIM capacitors for embedded-DRAM in 90 nm technology and beyond. ALD-Al2O3 and ALD-HfO2 dielectrics have been evaluated together with MOCVD-Ta2O5 for capacitors targeted at EOT < 18 Å. Improved leakage performance was obtained through control of the dielectric/electrode interface. This includes the use of ALD-Al2O3 as a thermo-dynamic and electronic barrier between Ta2O5 and electrode and the use of ALD-TiN as electrode material. ALD-Al2O3 and ALD-HfO2 both give good leakage performance and stability with temperature, with HfO2 offering most robust capacitance performance for next generation erhbedded-DRAM processes.

Authors: Finney W.F., Morris M.D., Wallace J.M., Kohn D.H.
Title: Ultrastructural elastic deformation of cortical bone tissue probed by NIR raman spectroscopy
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-1055, United States; Department of Biologic, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-1078, United States; Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2099, United States
Authors with affiliations: Finney, W.F., Department of Chemistry, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-1055, United States; Morris, M.D., Department of Chemistry, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-1055, United States; Wallace, J.M., Department of Biologic, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-1078, United States, Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2099, United States; Kohn, D.H., Department of Biologic, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-1078, United States, Department of Biomedical Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2099, United States
Abstract: Raman spectroscopy is used as a probe of ultrastructural (molecular) changes in both the mineral and matrix (protein and glycoprotein, predominantly type I collagen) components of murine cortical bone as it responds to loading in the elastic regime. At the ultrastructural level, crystal structure and protein secondary structure distort as the tissue is loaded. These structural changes are followed as perturbations to tissue spectra. We load tissue in a custom-made dynamic mechanical tester that fits on the stage of a Raman microprobe and can accept hydrated tissue specimens. As the specimen is loaded in tension and/or compression, the shifts in mineral P-O4 ν 1 and relative band heights in the Amide III band envelope are followed with the microprobe. Average load is measured using a load cell while the tissue is loaded under displacement control. Changes occur in both the mineral and matrix components of bone as a response to elastic deformation. We propose that the mineral apatitic crystal lattice is deformed by movement of calcium and other ions. The matrix is proposed to respond by deformation of the collagen backbone. Raman microspectroscopy shows that bone mineral is not a passive contributor to tissue strength. The mineral active response to loading may function as a local energy storage and dissipation mechanism, thus helping to protect tissue from catastrophic damage.
Author Keywords: Biomechanics; Bone; Raman
Index Keywords: Biomechanics; Crystal lattices; Crystal structure; Crystallization; Deformation; Perturbation techniques; Proteins; Raman spectroscopy; Tissue; Collagen backbone; Cortical bone; Raman microprobe; Ultrastructural elastic deformation; Bone

Title: Odor binding protein as probe for a refractive index-based biosensor: New perspectives in biohazard assessment
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering

Castellino 111, 80131- Napoli, Italy; Campopiano, S., Seconda Università di Napoli, Dipto. di Ingegneria dell'I., Via Roma, 29, 81031- Aversa, Italy, INFM, Naples, Italy; Cennamo, N., Seconda Università di Napoli, Dipto. di Ingegneria dell'I., Via Roma, 29, 81031- Aversa, Italy; Zeni, L., Seconda Università di Napoli, Dipto. di Ingegneria dell'I., Via Roma, 29, 81031- Aversa, Italy, INFM, Naples, Italy
Abstract: The odor-binding proteins (OBPs) are abundant low-molecular weight soluble proteins, which are secreted by the olfactory epithelium in the nasal mucus of vertebrates. These protein reversibly bind odorants with dissociation constants in the micromolar range. For this reason, they are good candidates as biological elements in the development of biosensors. Vertebrate OBPs belong to the lipocalin superfamily. Even if the members of this superfamily display low sequence similarity, all of them show a conserved folding pattern, that is an 8-stranded β-barrel flanked by an α-helix at the C-terminal end of the protein chain. The β-barrel defines a central apolar cavity, called calyx, whose role is to bind and transport hydrophobic odorant molecules. The detection of hazard exposure is becoming a priority in the third millennium, and OBPs are good candidates for detecting traces of explosive molecules in different environments such as luggage's storage rooms and public places. In this context, the measurement of refractive index of odor-binding protein in absence and in presence of odorant molecules have been performed in order to assess its usefulness as a probe for detection of hazardous agents. The work is instrumental to explore the possibility to realize a biosensor where the concentration of searched for substances is analyzed as a variation of the protein refractive index by means of suitable optoelectronic devices.
Author Keywords: Biohazard; Biosensors; Odor-binding proteins; Refractive index measurements
Index Keywords: Binding energy; Biosensors; Dissociation; Hydrophobicity; Odor control; Optoelectronic devices; Refractive index; Biohazard; Folding pattern; Odor-binding proteins (OBP); Refractive index measurements; Proteins

Authors: Paz A.C., Acevedo J.M., Gandoy J.D.
Title: Density measurement in automotive batteries by means of optoelectronics sensors
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Dep. Electronics Technology, Univ. of Vigo, Lagoas-Marcosende, 36200 Vigo, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Paz, A.C., Dep. Electronics Technology, Univ. of Vigo, Lagoas-Marcosende, 36200 Vigo, Spain; Acevedo, J.M., Dep. Electronics Technology, Univ. of Vigo, Lagoas-Marcosende, 36200 Vigo, Spain; Gandoy, J.D., Dep. Electronics Technology, Univ. of Vigo, Lagoas-Marcosende, 36200 Vigo, Spain
Abstract: Lead-acid batteries are an energy storage system used in automotive sector, electric traction, communication remote control, etc. In all of this applications, and specially in remote control, is interested to know, among other variables, the electrolyte density. This measurement allow us to manage a battery or a set of batteries. In this work we present an optoelectronic sensor developed for the measurement of the lead-acid electrolyte density. The sensor has an optical emitter-receiver pair, two plastic optical fibers and the electronic circuit. One fiber is used like a reference in order to minimize the possible common mode errors, due temperature, power supplies, etc. The other fiber is the sensitive fiber and the measurements are taken with it, the functioning principle is an U bend configuration which allows losses due the refraction to the surrounding liquid, this losses depends on the liquid density (electrolyte density). Several tests were done with different conditions and different charging and discharging strategies, the results demonstrate the validity of this technique for the lead-acid electrolyte density measurement with a good stability in the time.
Author Keywords: Automotive; Battery; Density; Electrolyte; Optical fiber
Index Keywords: Electrolytes; Fiber optic sensors; Light emitting diodes; Optical fibers; Photodetectors; Automotive batteries; Electrical isolation; Electrolyte density; Optoelectronic sensors; Optoelectronic devices

Title: General interest: Market changes shape N. American gas spending needs
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Authors with affiliations: Tippee, B.
Abstract: Investment requirements for natural gas infrastructure in North America will be amplified by market changes beyond the 33% consumption growth expected through 2020. Energy & Environmental Analysis Inc (EEA) studied the strong future growth in gas demand for electric power generation and increasing reliance on production from frontier areas and imports of LNG. Projecting growth in US gas demand to 29.7 tcf in 2020 from 21.5 tcf in 2003, the study predicts electric power generation will account for 67% of the increase, followed by residential uses 14%, commercial and industrial 8% each, and other uses. To supplement North American production, the INGAA study says LNG imports will have to leap from 475 bcf in 2003 to > 6.6 tcf in 2020. That growth will require construction of 10 terminal and expansion of the four existing facilities. The study assumes construction of two terminals on the East Coast, seven on the Gulf Coast, and one on the West Coast. EEA notes that new pipeline capacity will be needed from frontier basins and to accommodate growing imports of LNG. Additional pipeline infrastructure will be needed to accommodate expected increases in LNG receiving capacity, which will exceed 11 bcf/day. EEA projects installation of > 45,000 mi of regional and interregional pipeline in North America through 2020 to meet gas demand growth. About 7000 mi of the new pipeline will be for Alaskan and Mackenzie Delta gas destined for the US Lower 48. EEA expects requirements for new compression associated with the pipeline installation to total 7.8 million hp. About 75% of the new compression will be for new pipelines, 50% for the Alaskan Mackenzie Delta projects. Replacement compression will account for 17% of the projected requirement and storage projects the remainder.

Title: Quick takes: EnBridge Energy Partners LP's...
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: Enbridge Pipelines (Ozark) LLC will build 2.3 million bbl of crude oil tankage at its Cushing, OK, storage terminal. Construction of four 575,000-bbl tanks and associated facilities makes up the company's $28 million Cushing Terminal expansion project, which is to begin later in 2004. The tanks and facilities are expected to be in service by yearend 2005. The Cushing terminal is part of the company's Midcontinent Liquids System, Enbridge completed its acquisition of the crude oil system in March 2004.

Authors: Jansson P.M., Tisa J., Kim W.
Title: Undergraduate research and innovation: Inexpensive remote campus power monitoring via student designed and manufactured system
Source title: ASEE Annual Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Electrical and Computer Engineering, Rowan University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jansson, P.M., Electrical and Computer Engineering, Rowan University, United States; Tisa, J., Electrical and Computer Engineering, Rowan University, United States; Kim, W., Electrical and Computer Engineering, Rowan University, United States
Abstract: An inexpensive remote campus power monitoring system for core buildings designed by engineering department's students was discussed. The components of this device were structured in such a way that all data capture and storage was done internally and could only be viewed through a device connected via RS-232. It was also observed that this power monitoring device could store several electrical line parameters that will collect important energy and power characteristics of a building. The overall market for this device was found to be single and three-phase commercial and industrial facilities that desire energy and power quality measurements in reducing costs related to wasted electricity.

Title: Pseudoelasticity: Experimental observations, thermomechanical modeling, and identification of the material parameters
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Institute of Mechanics, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Kassel, Mönchebergstr. 7, 34109 Kassel, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Helm, D., Institute of Mechanics, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Kassel, Mönchebergstr. 7, 34109 Kassel, Germany
Abstract: In a certain temperature range, NiTi and other shape memory alloys show the so-called pseudoelastic effect. In the present study, the pseudoelasticity of NiTi is experimentally investigated in tension tests on thin-walled tubes. The observed phenomena are modeled within the framework of continuum thermomechanics regarding a geometric linear theory. The model is based on a free energy function in order to represent the occurring energy storage and release effects. Additionally, evolution equations for internal variables, like the inelastic strain tensor and the fraction of martensite, are introduced. The proposed system of constitutive equations represents the observed history-dependent material behavior. To identify the material parameters, the theory of neural networks is applied.
Author Keywords: NiTi; Parameter identification; Pseudoelasticity; Shape memory alloys; Thermomechanical modeling
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Data acquisition; Dilatometers; Free energy; Identification (control systems); Mathematical models; Neural networks; Thermomechanical treatment; NiTi; Pseudoelasticity; Tension tests; Thermomechanical modeling; Shape memory effect

Title: Autophagous structure-power systems
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering

Box 441340, Ft. Washington, MD 20749, United States
Abstract: Novel autophagous (self-consuming) systems combining structure and power functionalities are under development for improved material utilization and performance enhancement in electric unmanned air vehicles (UAV's). Much of the mass of typical aircraft is devoted separately to the functions of structure and fuel-energy. Several methods are proposed to extract structure function from materials that can also serve as fuel for combustion or as a source of hydrogen. Combustion heat is converted to electrical energy by thermoelectric generation, and hydrogen gas is used in fuel cells to provide electrical energy. The development and implementation of these structure-fuels are discussed in the context of three specific designs of autophagous wing spars. The designs are analyzed with respect to mechanical performance and energy storage. Results indicate a high potential for these systems to provide enhanced performance in electric UAV's.

Title: Micromechanical model for ferroelectric and ferroelastic single crystals
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: LPMM UMR CNRS 7554, ENSAM CER de Metz, Technopole Metz 2000, 4, rue Augustin, Fresnel, 57078 Metz Cedex, France

Abstract: This paper examines the switching process occuring in ferroelectric and ferroelastic single crystals under electromechanical loadings. Ferroelectrics undergoing a cubic to tetragonal phase transition are considered. The single crystal energy has three origins: elastic, electric and the incompatibilities of the spontaneous strain and electric displacement fieds between domains. The stress and electric fields fluctuate and present jumps at the domain walls. As a consequence, they induce electro-elastic interaction energy. Thus, it involves dissipation that the present work aims to capture through a micromechanical approach.
Author Keywords: Ferroelastic; Ferroelectrics; Single crystals; Switching

Title: Modelling and design of ferroelectric beam actuators
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Engineering, University of Cambridge, Trumpington St., Cambridge, CB2 1PZ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Huber, J.E., Department of Engineering, University of Cambridge, Trumpington St., Cambridge, CB2 1PZ, United Kingdom
Abstract: A non-linear bimorph device is proposed, in which the strain accompanying ferroelectric switching is used to drive curvature of a bilayer of ferroelectric material. An analysis of the proposed device suggests that a curvature about an order of magnitude greater than that readily obtained by conventional piezoelectric bimorphs is possible, whilst the peak tensile stresses in the device are comparable with those in conventional devices. The curvature achieved by the device upon poling is calculated approximately by using an analytical approach with idealized material behaviour. Two potential designs for the poling electrodes are suggested, and numerical calculations are used to optimize these designs.

Title: Instrumentation and evaluation of commercial and homemade passive solar panels
Source title: ASEE Annual Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: University of Maryland Eastern Shore, Princess Anne, MD 21853, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yilmaz, E., University of Maryland Eastern Shore, Princess Anne, MD 21853, United States
Abstract: The purpose of this project was to compare water-heating capacities of a commercial passive solar panel and a home designed passive solar panel. The home made solar panel consisted of six, 10 ft long parallel, 1/2 in. diameter PVC pipes with two headers and with no insulation. Both panels were placed on the east side roof of the author's house, therefore they received solar radiation during part of the day. The instrumentation consisted of seven thermocouples and a computer data acquisition system. Two identical, 20-gallon plastic tanks, one tank on each panel, were used for water storage. Two sets of comparative measurements were carried out. For the first set, the PVC solar panel pipes were white; for the second set, the PVC solar panel pipes were painted in black. For the white PVC system the maximum water temperature in the tank was slightly lower than the commercial solar panel tank water temperature. For the painted PVC system, the maximum water temperature in the tank was slightly higher than the commercial solar panel tank water temperature. In conclusion it can be stated that a simple homemade six-pipe, black PVC solar panel is superior to an expensive commercial solar panel. Although water tanks were not insulated, water temperatures in them have reached to about 100 deg-F in September. Such a system may be incorporated into one of the MET courses as a laboratory exercise to demonstrate basic principles of passive solar heating, calculation of heat losses, optimization, manufacturing techniques, creativity, etc.
Index Keywords: Instrumentation; Solar panels; Water heating; Data acquisition; Heat losses; Heat pipes; Heating; Optimization; Polyvinyl chlorides; Thermal effects; Solar energy

Authors: Sim A., Gu J., Shoshani A., Natarajan V.
Title: DataMover: Robust terabyte-scale multi-file replication over wide-area networks
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Scientific and Statistical Database Management, SSDBM
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Natl. Laboratory, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sim, A., Lawrence Berkeley Natl. Laboratory, United States; Gu, J., Lawrence Berkeley Natl. Laboratory, United States; Shoshani, A., Lawrence Berkeley Natl. Laboratory, United States; Natarajan, V., Lawrence Berkeley Natl. Laboratory, United States
Abstract: Typically, large scientific datasets (order of terabytes) are generated at large computational centers, and stored on mass storage systems. However, large subsets of the data need to be moved to facilities available to application scientists for analysis. File replication of thousands of files is a tedious, error prone, but extremely important task in scientific applications. The automation of the file replication task requires automatic space acquisition and reuse, and monitoring the progress of staging thousands of files from the source mass storage system, transferring them over the network, archiving them at the target mass storage system or disk systems, and recovering from transient system failures. We have developed a robust replication system, called DataMover, which is now in regular use in High-Energy-Physics and Climate modeling experiments. Only a single command is necessary to request multi-file replication or the replication of an entire directory. A web-based tool was developed to dynamically monitor the progress of the multi-file replication process.
Index Keywords: File transfer protocols (FTP); Mass storage system (MSS); Multi-file replication; Web-based tools; Automation; Computer simulation; Error analysis; Network protocols; Robustness (control systems); Wide area networks; World Wide Web; Data reduction

Authors: Fenton S.S., Ramani V., Fenton J.M.
Title: Active learning of chemical engineering principles using a solar panel / water electrolyzer / fuel cell system
Source title: ASEE Annual Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Connecticut, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fenton, S.S., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Connecticut, United States; Ramani, V., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Connecticut, United States; Fenton, J.M., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Connecticut, United States
Abstract: Modules are described that provide experimental/analytical investigation of traditional chemical engineering concepts within the framework of a solar/hydrogen renewable energy cycle. Module lessons cover photovoltaics, thermodynamics, stoichiometry, characteristic current-voltage curves/efficiency, kinetics and transport. A self-contained solar panel / electrolyzer / gas storage containers / polymer electrolyte fuel cell (PEFC) device along with separately purchased (or borrowed) spotlight, power supply, multimeters, and decade resistors are used for all experiments. The experiments are of short duration (15-50 minutes), simple, and produce data that can be analyzed by/used to verify traditional chemical engineering relations (given a few supplemental electrochemical engineering equations). The equipment used in the modules is inexpensive, simple to operate, safe, portable and commercially available. Ideally, this will permit multiple "systems" to be purchased and used simultaneously by students, providing a truly hands-on small group experience. Modules can be used at all levels of the undergraduate curriculum (freshman through senior) and can be used in multiple classes (Freshman Engineering, Intro to Chemical Engineering, Thermodynamics, Kinetics, Transport, Laboratory Practice, and Electives) to illustrate appropriate material. Figure 1 contains a concept map linking modules to concepts within the curricula that are addressed in this paper. Use of the modules can be preceded by classroom discussions of the hydrogen economy, its projected political, social, and environmental impacts (both locally and globally) and/or the challenges associated with converting to such an economy. The modules can also be modified for use at the pre-college level for a wide variety of projects and/or simple in-class or public demonstrations.
Index Keywords: Convective flows; Hydrogen economy; Multimeters; Water electrolyzers; Chemical engineering; Environmental impact; Fuel cells; Photovoltaic cells; Stoichiometry; Students; Thermodynamics; Learning systems

Abstract: Attempts to develop a Wireless Health Advanced Mobile Bio-diagnostic System (abbreviated as WHAM-BioS) have arisen from the need to monitor the health status of patients under long-term care programs. The proposed WHAM-BioS as presented here was developed by integrating various technologies: nano/MEMS technology, biotechnology, network/communication technology, and information technology. The biochips proposed not only detect certain diseases but will also report any abnormal status readings on the patient to the medical personnel immediately through the network system. Since long-term home care is typically involved, the parameters monitored must be analyzed and traced continuously over a long period of time. To minimize the intrusion to the patients, a wireless sensor embedded within a wireless network is highly recommended. To facilitate the widest possible use of various biochips, a smart sensor node concept was implemented. More specifically, various technologies and components such as built-in micro power generators, energy storage devices, initialization processes, no-waste bio-detection methodologies, embedded controllers, wireless warning signal transmissions, and power/data management were merged and integrated to create this novel technology. The design methodologies and the implementation schemes are detailed. Potential expansions of this newly developed technology to other applications regimes will be presented as well.

Title: Modern lab experiments for chemical engineering
Source title: ASEE Annual Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Chemical Engineering Department, North Carolina State University, Raleigh, NC 27695-7905, United States

Abstract: We describe new experiments developed, and installed, to bring our chemical engineering laboratory into the 21 st century. These additions are: (1) Compact disc write and re-write systems (2) Fluidized bed polymer coating (3) Hydrogen fuel cell and hydrogen storage (4) Photocatalytic water purification (5) Rapid prototyping via ink jet printer (6) Silicon wafer oxidation These new experiments collectively allow introduction of topics which are modern, yet not routinely covered in traditional chemical engineering laboratories. The experiments described are relevant to energy storage and utilization, polymer coating of consumer and microelectronics products, water purification, laser-driven material transformations for information storage, semiconductor circuit fabrication, and computer-aided solid prototype synthesis.

Abstract: The direct conversion of solar energy info chemical energy leading to the production of renewable and non-polluting fuels remains a great and fascinating challenge for this century. Among various interesting reactions, the splitting of water into hydrogen and oxygen by visible light is potentially one of the most promising ways for the photochemical conversion and storage of solar energy. A discussion on new mixed metal oxide semiconductor photocatalyst that shows significant activity for photochemical hydrogen production from water under illumination with either UV or visible light covers details of synthesis, characterization and activity of the novel catalysts. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 228th ACS National Meeting (Philadelphia, PA, 8/22-26/2004).

Authors: Di Bella F.A., Chamarra III A.
Title: Optimizing thermal energy storage for cogeneration applications: A faculty and engineering technology student collaboration using excel
Source title: ASEE Annual Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Northeastern University, Mechanical Engineering Technology, Boston, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Di Bella, F.A., Northeastern University, Mechanical Engineering Technology, Boston, MA, United States; Chamarra III, A.
Abstract: This paper has a two-fold purpose. Not only does it solve a significant engineering problem and present a solution for the optimization of thermal energy storage for use in cogeneration systems applications but it also identifies the importance of one-on-one faculty -student research and it how excel software can overcome the need for higher-level mathematics. The problem is a familiar one to the engineers who must determine the optimum size of a thermal storage system that is not too large or too small for a customer's thermal demand while matching it with the correct cogeneration system size (kwe). The problem's solution however becomes an opportunity to enlist the help of an undergraduate student to help solve a fairly complicated problem. This pedagogy is seen as critical and necessary to the education of the engineering technology student; building self-confidence in his/her analytical skills to solve the problem via a "simple" spreadsheet that would otherwise require calculus and optimization techniques. No sooner has the student followed and contributed to the solution's methodology that he realizes that he has actually used a probabilistic method in its solution: The Monte Carlo Method, a term that perhaps would frighten the student if revealed earlier but now becomes a part of his solutions "tool box". This paper reports on the pedagogy of this collaboration as well as the useful results that were obtained.
Index Keywords: Calculus; Cogeneration systems; Engineering technology; Probabilistic methods; Computer software; Heat storage; Mathematical models; Monte Carlo methods; Optimization; Problem solving; Spreadsheets; Students; Technology transfer; Engineering education

Title: This price isn't right
Source title: Professional Engineering
Authors with affiliations: Hibbert, L.
Abstract: The factors leading to higher gas prices in the UK are discussed. It is found that 30% of the rise is due to high oil prices in Europe. The system impacts on the UK when the country needs to import gas during the winter months. The main causes of rising gas prices in the UK is suggested to be the impact of rising oil prices, declining production from UK gas fields and market sentiment.

Title: Induced defects in carbonaceous materials for hydrogen storage

Eng., Pennsylvania State University, 120 Hosler, University Park, PA 16802, United States
Abstract: The use of hydrogen as an energy carrier will require a means by which to transport and store hydrogen, yet no existing technology meets the performance requirements established by the DOE. Hydrogen storage reports in carbon-based materials vary widely; however, recent reports suggest that defects introduced during synthesis or heat treatment lead to an expanded graphite lattice and enhanced hydrogen storage in graphitic materials. The efficacy of certain a priori pretreatment methods to induce defects in graphitic materials and to expand the graphite lattice was studied. The extent of hydrogen uptake for carbon materials with induced defects was presented, and the results were used to test the hypothesis that defects lead to increased hydrogen storage. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 228th ACS National Meeting (Philadelphia, PA, 8/22-26/2004).

Title: Estimated performance of photovoltaic irrigation systems under different operating conditions
Source title: National Radio Science Conference, NRSC, Proceedings
