Authors with affiliations: Zekry, A.A., Faculty of Engineering, Ain Shams University, Egypt; Elgendy, M.A., Desert Research Centre, Egypt
Abstract: The photovoltaic pumping (PVP) is one of the more promising applications of renewable sources in the energy supply of agricultural process. However, the implementation of PVP systems is still scarce especially because the lack of standard criteria relating the involved variables such as meteorological parameters, PV panels characteristics and pump performance. In this work, the effects of meteorological parameters, pump selection and tilt angle variation on the PVP system performance are studied using the SICADT (Solar Irrigation Computer Aided Design Tool) simulation program developed by the authors. This study is accomplished utilizing a standard PVP system comprised of a PV array, an inverter and a submersible electric driven centrifugal pump. This system can be used for pumping the subterranean water in North Sinai region for drip irrigation network.
Author Keywords: Drip irrigation - 2; Performance - 3; PV pumping - 1
Index Keywords: Computer aided design; Costs; Electric potential; Electricity; Energy storage; Irrigation; Meteorology; Motors; Solar energy; Drip irrigation; Maximum power point tracking (MPPT); Photovoltaic pumping; Solar pumping; Photovoltaic effects

Authors: Harkins P., McComb D.W., MacKenzie M., Craven A.J.
Title: ELNES of titanate perovskites - A probe of structure and bonding
Source title: Institute of Physics Conference Series
Affiliations: Dept. of Physics, University of Glasgow, G12 8QQ, United Kingdom; Dept. of Materials, Imperial College London, London SW7 2AZ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Harkins, P., Dept. of Physics, University of Glasgow, G12 8QQ, United Kingdom; McComb, D.W., Dept. of Materials, Imperial College London, London SW7 2AZ, United Kingdom; MacKenzie, M.; Craven, A.J., Dept. of Physics, University of Glasgow, G12 8QQ, United Kingdom
Abstract: The oxygen K-edge of a range of perovskite (ABO 3) materials has been investigated using electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS), where A = Ca, Sr, Ba, Pb and B = Ti, Zr. These substitutions strongly affect the ferroelectric properties of the materials as the bonding and symmetry present in each unit cell is altered due to the increasing size of the cations and the stresses that result. These alterations also affect the electronic structure of the materials, which has been modelled using band structure and multiple scattering methods in order to interpret better the EELS data.
Index Keywords: Density functional theory (DFT); Full width half maximum (FWHM); X-ray absorption near edge structures (XANES); Zero-loss peak (ZLP); Band structure; Chemical bonds; Electron energy loss spectroscopy; Ferroelectricity; Oxygen; Positive ions; Random access storage; Stresses; Structure (composition); Thin films; Transmission electron microscopy; Perovskite

Title: A doubly-fed induction machine and energy storage system for wind power generation
Source title: Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering
Affiliations: McGill University, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Abbey, C., McGill University, Canada; Joós, G., McGill University, Canada
Abstract: Renewable energy sources have recently received increased attention due to concerns about the environment and the search for alternate energy sources. Wind power has become the most important source of renewable energy in many countries, and has been shown to effectively complement central generation. However, good power quality of distributed generators is of vital importance, and for this reason independent control of the real and reactive power is desirable. In addition, there has been an increasing demand for alternative energy sources to behave like conventional generators, whereby their output power is deterministic. Wind energy is an inherently stochastic system and therefore, external measures must be used to overcome the fluctuations in the generator's energy production as a result of the wind's dynamics. This presentation deals with the modeling and simulation of a doubly-fed induction machine as a wind power generator. The ability of the system to provide independent control of the real and reactive power is demonstrated. The incorporation of a battery or other energy storage device in the dc link enables temporary storage of energy and therefore, the ability to provide smooth output power, which is both deterministic and resistant to wind speed fluctuations. The power electronic converters directly control the machine and act as the interface between the storage system and the grid. This allows full control over voltage characteristics as well as real power generation. Simulations of the system in EMTP-RVshow that the design is feasible.
Author Keywords: Doubly-fed induction generator; Energy storage; Power electronics; Wind energy
Index Keywords: Doubly-fed induction generators; Voltage characteristics; Wind energy conversion systems; Electric converters; Electric potential; Electric power generation; Energy storage; Power electronics; Renewable energy resources; Stochastic control systems; Wind power; Wind turbines; Asynchronous machinery

Authors: Warot B., Imrie J., Petford-Long A.K., Sharma M., Anthony T.C.
Title: Amorphous ferromagnetic layers for magnetic tunnel junctions
Source title: Institute of Physics Conference Series
Affiliations: Department of Materials, University of Oxford, United Kingdom; HP Labs, Palo Alto, United States
Authors with affiliations: Warot, B., Department of Materials, University of Oxford, United Kingdom; Imrie, J., Department of Materials, University of Oxford, United Kingdom; Petford-Long, A.K., Department of Materials, University of Oxford, United Kingdom; Sharma, M., HP Labs, Palo Alto, United States; Anthony, T.C., HP Labs, Palo Alto, United States
Abstract: Magnetic tunnel junctions are being actively studied for use as single cells in magnetic random access memory (MRAM). For MRAM application purposes, a narrow distribution of the switching fields of the cells is required. Amorphous ferromagnetic layers used as sense layers in the junctions are predicted to improve the uniformity properties. In this article, we report the results of transmission electron microscopy studies of the crystalline structure of CoFeB and CoFeHfNb ferromagnetic layers, known to be amorphous. The results show the influence of the underlayer and emphasise the importance of deposition order on the crystallographic structure of the layers.
Index Keywords: Amorphous materials; Coercive force; Crystalline materials; Crystallography; Deposition; Electron energy loss spectroscopy; Ferromagnetic materials; Heat transfer; High resolution electron microscopy; Layered manufacturing; Magnetoresistance; Random access storage; Surface roughness; Switching; Transmission electron microscopy; Amorphous ferromagnetic layers; High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM); Magnetic tunnel junctions (MTJ); Precision ion polishing system (PIPS); Tunnel junctions

Authors: Shimizu I., Sekiya T., Iida K., Imanishi Y., Kimura M., Nishizawa J.
Title: Over 55kV/μs, dv/dt turn-off characteristics of 4kV-static induction Thyristor for pulsed power applications
Source title: IEEE International Symposium on Power Semiconductor Devices and ICs (ISPSD)
Affiliations: NGK Insulators Ltd., 2-56 Suda-cho, Mizuho, Nagoya 467-8530, Japan; Shizuoka University, 3-5-1 Johoku, Hamamatsu 432-8011, Japan; Semiconductor Research Institute, Kawauchi, Aoba, Sendai 980-0862, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Shimizu, I., NGK Insulators Ltd., 2-56 Suda-cho, Mizuho, Nagoya 467-8530, Japan; Sekiya, T., NGK Insulators Ltd., 2-56 Suda-cho, Mizuho, Nagoya 467-8530, Japan; Iida, K., NGK Insulators Ltd., 2-56 Suda-cho, Mizuho, Nagoya 467-8530, Japan; Imanishi, Y., NGK Insulators Ltd., 2-56 Suda-cho, Mizuho, Nagoya 467-8530, Japan; Kimura, M., Shizuoka University, 3-5-1 Johoku, Hamamatsu 432-8011, Japan; Nishizawa, J., Semiconductor Research Institute, Kawauchi, Aoba, Sendai 980-0862, Japan
Abstract: Over 55kV/μs, high voltage rise-up rated pulses have been successfully applied between the anode to the cathode of the 4KV/300A Static Induction Thyristor (SIThy) at turn-off actions by applying the Induction Energy Storage (IES) circuit invented in 2002. SIThys were broken when the high dv/dt value, over 2kV/μs, is applied forward between the anode and the cathode at the turn-off action by the conventional opening switching technique. We simulated the electric field strength inside of the SIThy on the IES circuit; consequently the electric field applied in front of the n-emitter at the turn-off action is absolutely low. This is considered to be the reason of the high tolerance for "turn-off dv/dt" of SIThys on the IES circuit.
Index Keywords: Anodes; Capacitance; Cathodes; Computer simulation; Electric energy storage; Electric fields; Semiconductor junctions; Induction energy storage (IES); Pulsed power applications; Static induction thyristors; Thyristors

Title: Impact of cache optimization techniques on energy management
Source title: Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering
Affiliations: American University, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates; V-Cube Technology Corp., Fremont, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sagahyroon, A., American University, Sharjah, United Arab Emirates; Karunaratne, M., V-Cube Technology Corp., Fremont, CA, United States
Abstract: Due to the wide spread of mobile computing and as we approach the scaling limits in CMOS circuits, issues such as heat dissipation and power management are emerging as critical aspects in memory systems design. Microprocessors, typically, come with one or more levels of cache. Caches are geared toward extremely high throughput and fast switching, thereby require great attention in power management to avoid malfunction or performance degradation. Historically, architectural alternatives had aimed at improving cache performance by: reducing the miss rates, reducing the miss penalties, and the time to hit the cache. These alternatives include techniques such as increasing the data block size, use of victim caches, higher associativity and of course compiler optimization. In this work, we examine the impact of these techniques on the energy requirements of the memory system. Each performance optimization technique will be analyzed in relation to how it impacts the overall energy dissipation of the memory system. We will use two measures: average-memory- access-time (AMAT) which is the average latency per memory reference and average-memory-access-energy (AMAE) which is the average energy dissipated per memory reference to investigate performance and power tradeoffs for each optimization technique.
Author Keywords: Average-Memory-Access-Energy; Average-Memory-Access-Time; Cache Performance Optimization
Index Keywords: Average-memory-access-energy; Average-memory-access-time; Cache performance optimization; Energy-aware compilers; Bandwidth; CMOS integrated circuits; Energy dissipation; Energy management; Optimization; Power electronics; Random access storage; Buffer storage

Authors: Sidhu M.S., Alllson B.J., Dumont G.A.
Title: Multivariable averaging level control
Source title: Control Systems, Preprints, Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, UBC, 2356 Main Mall, Vancouver, BC V6T 1Z4, Canada; Pulp and Paper Res. Inst. of Canada, 3800 Wesbrook Mall, Vancouver, BC V6S 2L9, Canada; Honeywell Process Solutions, 500 Brooksbank Ave., North Vancouver, BC V7J 3S4, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Sidhu, M.S., Department of Electrical Engineering, UBC, 2356 Main Mall, Vancouver, BC V6T 1Z4, Canada, Honeywell Process Solutions, 500 Brooksbank Ave., North Vancouver, BC V7J 3S4, Canada; Alllson, B.J., Pulp and Paper Res. Inst. of Canada, 3800 Wesbrook Mall, Vancouver, BC V6S 2L9, Canada; Dumont, G.A., Department of Electrical Engineering, UBC, 2356 Main Mall, Vancouver, BC V6T 1Z4, Canada
Abstract: Today's process plants are becoming highly integrated through the increased use of material and energy recycle streams. While the introduction of recycle streams helps to increase efficiency and minimize waste, it also leads to increased coupling between process variables, and thus more difficult control problems. One such example is coupling between storage (surge) vessels contained in recycle loops. Coupled surge tanks can be found in pulp screening operations. The main purpose of these tanks is to buffer changes in material (or energy) flow between the various unit operations within a process by allowing the tank levels to vary within limits. This is usually referred to as averaging level control. The averaging level control problem for a single tank has been extensively dealt with in the literature. However, for a coupled system of multiple tanks, a single-input single-output control strategy is no longer sufficient to provide good control performance. Hence, a multivariable control strategy is required. In this paper we will present various controller designs for the multivariable averaging level control problem. For obvious safety and economic reasons, the tank levels must never be allowed to overflow or become empty. Thus the main emphasis of this paper will be on the design of control laws that explicitly account for process constraints, such as constrained Model Based Predictive Control (MPC). Simulation results comparing the various controller design techniques will be presented.
Index Keywords: Model based predictive control (MPC); Multi-input multi-output (MIMO); Multivariable control; Algorithms; Computer simulation; Constraint theory; Energy conservation; Optimization; Problem solving; Pulp; Screening; Control systems; Control Systems; Energy Conservation; Pulps; Screening

Title: Sakhalin II: Facing the challenge of meeting customer needs in a changing LNG market
Source title: 14th International Conference and Exhibition on Liquefied Natural Gas
Affiliations: Sakhalin Ener. Investm. Company Ltd.
Authors with affiliations: Calitz, A., Sakhalin Ener. Investm. Company Ltd.; Mercer, H., Sakhalin Ener. Investm. Company Ltd.
Abstract: This paper analyses changing LNG market trends, including economic downturn in the Asia Pacific market in late nineties, pressure for de-regulation creating uncertainty for customers used to long-term supply deals, a demand for more flexibility to cater for seasonality and shorter term contracts etc. In addition, the development of tenders and short term trading has added a new dimension to the LNG business creating a more commodity-style market. New markets are emerging on the US West Coast and Mexico with very different structure and characteristics to the Asia Pacific market. The size of the Sakhalin II development as a greenfield project has meant that no-one customer can provide the total volumes required to fill the two trains. Sakhalin Energy has met the challenges by developing a portfolio of customers with LNG supplies tailored to meet individual customers with diverse requirements. In order to deliver these requirements, Sakhalin Energy has developed models to test the deliverability of the portfolio and the operational and commercial implications.
Index Keywords: Contracts; Investments; Marketing; Natural gas well drilling; Offshore oil well production; Project management; Commodity-style markets; Drilling platform; Floating storage; Offshore development; Liquefied natural gas

Authors: Kusagawa M., Hamatani E., Sakamoto Y., Takubo M., Ogawa E., Ikeda K., Emi H.
Title: A fully optimized cascaded LNG cold energy utilization system
Source title: 14th International Conference and Exhibition on Liquefied Natural Gas
Affiliations: Osaka Gas Co., Ltd., Osaka, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kusagawa, M., Osaka Gas Co., Ltd., Osaka, Japan; Hamatani, E., Osaka Gas Co., Ltd., Osaka, Japan; Sakamoto, Y., Osaka Gas Co., Ltd., Osaka, Japan; Takubo, M., Osaka Gas Co., Ltd., Osaka, Japan; Ogawa, E., Osaka Gas Co., Ltd., Osaka, Japan; Ikeda, K., Osaka Gas Co., Ltd., Osaka, Japan; Emi, H., Osaka Gas Co., Ltd., Osaka, Japan
Abstract: Osaka Gas Co., Ltd. has initiated a project to develop the world's first energy optimizing system based on the LNG cryogenic energy cascade process. This project is being conducted at an industrial complex, which consists of an oil refinery and a petrochemical plant, located adjacent to Osaka Gas's LNG receiving terminal, and it aims to improve environmental protection and achieve energy conservation. The LNG cryogenic energy cascade process utilizes LNG's cryogenic energy effectively by exchanging cold energy sequentially in multiple temperature stages ranging from low temperatures to normal temperature. There have previously been very few LNG cryogenic energy utilization systems capable of supplying cold energy for three or more applications within a single industrial complex. The project system is designed to provide LNG cryogenic energy for (1) separation of light hydrocarbons produced as a byproduct in the oil refining process (-100°C level; an energy source to separate olefm used as a raw material of polymer products at the petrochemical plant), (2) liquefaction of carbon dioxide produced as a byproduct in the manufacture of hydrogen (-55°C level), (3) low-temperature storage of normal-temperature butane (-8°C level; making it possible to balance seasonal demand-and-supply fluctuations), and (4) chilling of water used to cool the intake air for gas turbines (10°C level; also effectively utilizing electricity and steam resulting from improved gas turbine efficiency). The technology developed in this project aims to boost the competitiveness of the industrial complex as a whole.
Index Keywords: Cryogenics; Electric power utilization; Electricity; Energy conservation; Gas industry; Gas turbines; Hydrocarbons; Liquefied natural gas; Optimization; Petrochemical plants; Petroleum refineries; Oil refinery; Oil refining processes; Osaka Gas Co (CO); Energy utilization

Title: Optimization of Skikda LNG plant operation using a mixed non-linear programming model
Source title: 14th International Conference and Exhibition on Liquefied Natural Gas
Affiliations: S.-TRC-RTH-Hassi R'mel - Algeria, BP 87, Hassi R'mel - Laghouat 03300, Algeria
Authors with affiliations: Ainouche, A., S.-TRC-RTH-Hassi R'mel - Algeria, BP 87, Hassi R'mel - Laghouat 03300, Algeria
Abstract: Algeria is one of the largest worldwide exporters of liquefied natural gas. LNG plants are characterized by their relatively low number and very high investment and operating costs. The high operating costs of this type of facilities are mainly due to the fuel consumption of liquefaction plants which in stable operating reaches about 15%. In presence of important fluctuations of the demand, the energy consumption increases in a significant manner. These fluctuations are owed to the nature of the market evolution characterized by the confirmation more and more important of the spot market. In this context there is place to define an approach to optimize LNG plant operation taking into account: All the susceptible actions to assure the maximal flexibility of the system (LNG plant, LNG storage, port); The random nature of deliveries toward LNG tankers; The stocks level of LNG; The different possibilities of regulation of the liquefaction unit (stop of one or several liquefaction trains, recycle or operating at partial load). For this, a non-linear programming model with mixed variables was implemented enabling to minimize the whole of energy and maintenance costs as well as assuring the delivery of all the required LNG amounts. An application of the model developed on the Skikda plant GL1K will be given.
Index Keywords: Costs; Energy utilization; Gas fuel storage; Liquefaction of gases; Liquefied natural gas; Maintenance; Mathematical models; Nonlinear programming; Optimization; Flexibility; Liquefaction plants; Maintenance costs; Natural gasoline plants

Authors: Chu Y., Hicks L.C., Lu N.
Title: China's first LNG import terminal
Source title: 14th International Conference and Exhibition on Liquefied Natural Gas
Affiliations: China National Offshore Oil Company, Tower B, Offshore Petroleum Bldg., No.1 Industry Rd 2, Shekou, Shenzhen 518067, China; BP, Devon House, 979 King's Road, Quarry Bay, Hong Kong, Hong Kong; Guangdong Yudean Group Co. Ltd., Fengyuan Building No.1-3, Guangzhou, Guangdong 510008, China
Authors with affiliations: Chu, Y., China National Offshore Oil Company, Tower B, Offshore Petroleum Bldg., No.1 Industry Rd 2, Shekou, Shenzhen 518067, China; Hicks, L.C., BP, Devon House, 979 King's Road, Quarry Bay, Hong Kong, Hong Kong; Lu, N., Guangdong Yudean Group Co. Ltd., Fengyuan Building No.1-3, Guangzhou, Guangdong 510008, China
Abstract: China's first LNG import terminal in Guangdong Province provides an important study in the requirements for the creation of a new gas business in an area with little gas infrastructure but a high demand for clean and efficient energy supplies. It sets a new industry marker for the rapid development of a complete gas chain, and through its innovative LNG supply requisition has revolutionized LNG pricing in the Asia-Pacific trade. To meet the growing demand in Guangdong province, and to provide a timely alternative to the predominantly coal-fired power industry, the project was required to develop rapid and cost effective delivery of LNG. With power generation comprising approximately 60% of the initial gas demand, careful coordination with the developing IPPs was necessary. Effective engineering and commercial structures were needed to ensure a reliable facility capable of delivering competitively priced gas to both power and LDC customers. With this objective, the Guangdong LNG Joint Executive Office was established in 2001, and separate competitive processes were undertaken to solicit a foreign partner to provide technical expertise and investment in the terminal, as well as for the supply of LNG. The project has now begun construction of a LNG regasification facility with two 160,000-m3-storage tanks and a pipeline network extending approximately 360 kilometres to serve customers in the Pearl River Delta and Hong Kong. This paper presents the significant findings and conclusions of the collaborative work carried out by the Sino-foreign team, addresses the key issues of the technical challenges and commercial development, and discusses the potential impact for newly emerging gas markets including LNG pricing implications for the Asia-Pacific market.
Index Keywords: Coal; Cost effectiveness; Customer satisfaction; Gasification; Marketing; Natural gas pipelines; Power generation; Coal-fired power industry; Commercial structures; Liquefied natural gas import terminal; Pipeline markets; Liquefied natural gas

Title: Development of suction and discharge valves using non-metallic valve plates for BOG compressors
Source title: 14th International Conference and Exhibition on Liquefied Natural Gas
Affiliations: Toho Gas Co., Ltd., 19-18 Sakurada-cho, Atsuta-ku, Nagoya 456-8511, Japan; Ishikawajima-Harima Heavy I.C.L., 1, Shin-Nakahara-cho, Isogo-ku, Yokohama 235-8501, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yoshida, K.S., Toho Gas Co., Ltd., 19-18 Sakurada-cho, Atsuta-ku, Nagoya 456-8511, Japan; Iwawaki, S., Ishikawajima-Harima Heavy I.C.L., 1, Shin-Nakahara-cho, Isogo-ku, Yokohama 235-8501, Japan
Abstract: BOG that evaporated in LNG tanks, are typically pressurized using reciprocating compressors and used as the energy source. Since BOG are low temperature, stainless steel materials are used for the suction and discharge valve plates in the reciprocating compressors, but since there is wear due to the contact between the valve plate and valve seat, valve plates must be replaced periodically, and inspection for the valve and adjustments are necessary. Since durability has been improved in recent years, resins have come into use for suction and discharge valve plates in reciprocating compressors in normal temperature ranges, but they have not been used at all in low temperature ranges because of the brittleness of resins. In this instance resin materials with cryogenic properties have been selected, the valve structure improved to alleviate impact forces, and suction and discharge valves made of resin valve plates at low temperatures developed for the first time. Therefore, valve plates with durability approximately twice that of conventional stainless steel valve plates have been realized. The resin valve plates have the following effects compared with conventional stainless steel valve; inspection and maintenance cost reduction: approximately 30% with improvement in durability power required by compressors reduction: approximately 2.4% with improvement in sealing ability lowering operating noise: approximately 4% by avoiding metal contact (contact metal and resin). The suction and discharge valves made of resin valve plates are new technology and can be used by factories with same kinds of facilities both domestically and overseas.
Index Keywords: Compressors; Cryogenics; Durability; Fuel tanks; Gas fuel storage; Inspection; Resins; Valves (mechanical); BOG compressors; Discharge valves; Nonmetallic valve plates; Liquefied natural gas

Authors: Yu R., Tai T., Hsieh A., Cheng A., Tseng I., Tsai M., Tong H., Lee J.J.
Title: Considerations for using low dielectric constant material as re-passivation layer on 300mm wafer bump process and manufacturing benefits of Flip Chip package
Source title: Proceedings of the IEEE/CPMT International Electronics Manufacturing Technology (IEMT) Symposium
Affiliations: Adv. Semiconductor Engineering, Inc., Nantze Export Processing Zone, Kaohsiung 811, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Yu, R., Adv. Semiconductor Engineering, Inc., Nantze Export Processing Zone, Kaohsiung 811, Taiwan; Tai, T., Adv. Semiconductor Engineering, Inc., Nantze Export Processing Zone, Kaohsiung 811, Taiwan; Hsieh, A., Adv. Semiconductor Engineering, Inc., Nantze Export Processing Zone, Kaohsiung 811, Taiwan; Cheng, A., Adv. Semiconductor Engineering, Inc., Nantze Export Processing Zone, Kaohsiung 811, Taiwan; Tseng, I., Adv. Semiconductor Engineering, Inc., Nantze Export Processing Zone, Kaohsiung 811, Taiwan; Tsai, M., Adv. Semiconductor Engineering, Inc., Nantze Export Processing Zone, Kaohsiung 811, Taiwan; Tong, H., Adv. Semiconductor Engineering, Inc., Nantze Export Processing Zone, Kaohsiung 811, Taiwan; Lee, J.J., Adv. Semiconductor Engineering, Inc., Nantze Export Processing Zone, Kaohsiung 811, Taiwan
Abstract: Major improvements over the last four years have removed and reduced many of these barriers with the transition from 150mm, 200mm to 300mm process wafers; wafer Bumping is growing in importance with the increasing use of Flip Chip package; the challenge to increase yields becomes greater as each wafer value rises dramatically. The 300mm processing will increase emphasis on maximizing yields and minimizing scrap costs. Polyimide Film has many outstanding properties, such as low dielectric constant, a high thermal resistance, and high chemical resistance, so it was used as dielectric or passivation layer in IC device. Recently lithographic technique with the advantage of patternability leads the traditionally non-photo PI promoting into photo-sensative polyimide (PSPI). This paper describes using Photo-Sensitive Polyimide on 300mm wafer printing bump process and shows the results that spin-coating process, definition of curing degree and optical property of polyimide. The solder bump surface and bump shear are good due to properties of Photo-Sensitive polyimide, the polyimide surface is free from any damage because of good thermal ability and chemical resistance. Flip Chip used in laminate package like PBGA and CSP BGA to replace wire bonding as interconnection has become major trend in the assembly industry. But unlike well-known failure mode of wire bonding package, flip chip package with external solder ball as electrical interconnection present a extremely different failure mode with wire-bonding package from a point of view in process and material. In this study, one 16mmx16mm 3000 I/O SnPb wafer bumping using screen-printing process was explored including the effects of reflow times, high temperature storage life (HTSL) and temperature cycle test (TCT) on bump shear strength. Furthermore, the qualified wafer bumping is assembled by flip chip assembly with specific organic build-up substrate, then is subject to precondition and temperature cycle test to observe the effect on SnPb bump protection and solder joint life. Various failure modes in the flip chip package like solder and UBM and so on, will be scrutinized with SEM. And finally, best material combination will be addressed to make the flip chip package success.
Index Keywords: Chemical resistance; Energy dispersive spectroscopy; Heat resistance; Passivation; Permittivity; Scanning electron microscopy; Shear strength; Flip chip packages; High temperature storage life (HTSL); Photo-sensitive polyimide (PSPI); Temperature cycle test (TCT); Flip chip devices

Title: Medieval siege engines - Educational tools for QRM
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th International Conference on Quality, Reliability, and Maintenance, QRM 2004
Affiliations: Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rhoten, R.P., Oklahoma State University, Stillwater, United States
Abstract: By 900 A.D. military engineers had developed relatively sophisticated siege engines, including the catapult, onager and trebuchet. These devices provide an excellent "test bed" to teach the basic concepts of Quality, Reliability and Maintenance. The objective of this work is to show how the selection of performance measures is an important part of such education.
Index Keywords: Accelerometers; Competition; Energy storage; Maintenance; Metric system; Optimization; Parameter estimation; Performance; Potential energy; Projectiles; Reliability; Torque; Educational tools; Lagrangian equations; Quality, reliability and maintenance (QRM); Siege engines; Quality assurance

Authors: Saitoh T.S., Yoshimura A., Yamada N.
Title: An evaluation of future energy conversion systems including fuel cell
Source title: Advances in Transport
Affiliations: Grad. Sch. of Environmental Studies, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Yanmar Co. Ltd., Japan
Authors with affiliations: Saitoh, T.S., Grad. Sch. of Environmental Studies, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan; Yoshimura, A., Yanmar Co. Ltd., Japan; Yamada, N., Grad. Sch. of Environmental Studies, Tohoku University, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents a comparison among various vehicles when using fossil fuels and renewable energy. In the case of using fossil fuel, we compared 5 key factors among the fuel cell electric vehicle (FCEV), internal combustion engine (ICE) vehicle (gasoline or diesel), battery-powered and hybrid vehicles. Comparison factors are cruising range, carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions, waste heat rejection, air pollutants and noise. According to this comparison, hybrid, battery-powered and fuel cell electric vehicle have better potentials than ICE vehicles. In the case of utilizing renewable energy, EV will become the mainstream among various vehicles. In addition, FCEV will play an important role until that age. Moreover, we designed a high efficiency FCEV from the viewpoint of fuel effective utilization. This vehicle not only has fuel cell, but also various energy utilization and storage systems, for example, battery, flywheel and PV cell. This vehicle has excellent fuel economy more than 100km/liter. The proposed FCEV will be very promising to mitigate urban and global warming, and to conserve fossil fuel consumption. Further, the effect of the introduction of the above environment compatible vehicles into urban area will be discussed by 3-D heat island simulations.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Electric vehicles; Energy conversion; Energy utilization; Flywheels; Fuel consumption; Gasoline; Global warming; Fuel cell electric vehicle (FCEV); Internal combustion engine (ICE); Renewable energy; Urban environment; Fuel cells

Title: Water- Its role in nature, for man and technology
Source title: Proceedings of the 5th International Conference on Quality, Reliability, and Maintenance, QRM 2004
Affiliations: University of Rostok, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hopp, V., University of Rostok, Germany
Abstract: Water is a vital nutriment, it is the most important storage, converter and transporter of energy in nature and technology .Fresh water is a precious resource. Only 2,65% of the world's water is not salty, and of that nearly three quarters are locked up in the icecaps and glaciers. About 70% of this water is used in agriculture to grow the food and fibres on which human society depends. It takes 2000 tons of water to grow a ton of rice and some 1000 tons of water to grow one ton of wheat. Nevertheless there is a water crisis today. But the crisis is not about having too little water to satisfy our needs. It is a crisis of such bad water management that billions of people - and the environment This paper records the contemporary crisis in water resources and outlines the global situation as it affects the resources in the future.
Index Keywords: Dams; Desalination; Energy conversion; Energy storage; Environmental impact; Glaciers; Hydroelectric power; Ice; Irrigation; Project management; Rivers; Water resources; Desalination equipment; Hydroelectric power stations; Water management; Wheat; Water

Title: Ningbo - A new sustainable city for China
Source title: Advances in Architecture Series
Affiliations: HASSELL Pty Ltd., Melbourne, Australia; HASSELL Ningbo Urban Des. C., Australia
Authors with affiliations: Edmond, R., HASSELL Pty Ltd., Melbourne, Australia, HASSELL Ningbo Urban Des. C., Australia
Abstract: This paper describes the winning entry in the international competition for the planning of the expansion of the city of Ningbo, China, for 350,000 people on a 4000ha site; and the design of its new Centre by HASSELL, with engineering consultant Hyder in late 2002. Shortlisted competition entrants included Obermayer from Germany, Kurokawa from Japan and the Beijing Planning Bureau. The winning scheme blends traditional Chinese practices in sustainable farming, aquaculture and soil and water management evolved over four millennia; with 21st Century technologies; to create a city which is sustainable to a degree greater than most contemporary cities. At the same time, the new city design embodies urban design qualities rarely found in contemporary Chinese cities, and compliments a fine city building tradition which spans 4000 years. ESD components are woven throughout the fabric of the new city. The largest parks and waterbodies accommodate storm and wastewater treatment and storage for recycling, and sustainable energy generation from wind and wastes; the smaller urban canals and waterways provide drainage and water distribution into wetlands for cleaning. The ESD agenda for the new Ningbo will reduce externally supplied water and energy requirements by half that of a conventional city, while providing a physical environment equivalent to the most advanced contemporary cities. The concept includes a comprehensive public transport system, which minimises incentives for growth of private vehicles and energy use, by providing an excellent standard of service. HASSELL is continuing its involvement with detail design of the project through the Shanghai and Hong Kong offices of the firm.

Authors: Kawaguchi K., Suzuki E., Kondo H., Matsumura H., Ichino T.

Abstract: The amount of CO2 exhaust from automobiles is still increasing in the world. Therefore, a drastic innovation of traffic policy and technology is needed. We have designed and manufactured a new-concept flywheel battery system with sliding bearings, using tribology and traction control technologies, for a hybrid electric vehicle (HEV). The results of vehicle running tests show more than 80% energy efficiency of the whole flywheel battery system including the auxiliary units. We are studying an innovative HEV intermodal transport system using this flywheel. One main feature of this transport system is the movable cyber-expressway using jumbo trains. The effect of jumbo trains that substantially cut the CO2 emission from automobiles is discussed when they are integrated with a new concept of road traffic in an intelligent transport system (ITS).

Abstract: Pigs are stunned by means of electrical current or carbon dioxide in order to avoid pain during debleeding to death. This is important from the point of view of animal welfare and meat quality. The latter is linked to the first: meat from animals that do not experience stress and pain before and during slaughter, is tastier and more tender. The electrical stunning process is not perfect as sometimes carcass exhibits damages. Researchers try thus to improve stunning methods in an experimental way: several groups of animals are stunned using different stunning currents and electrode positions, after which results are compared. A project has been started with the goal of optimising the electrical energy storage during stunning. In this paper we will describe the steps used to better characterize the knowledge of pigs electrical properties and present some results.

Abstract: In the design of computer enclosures, it is very critical to implement some techniques of prediction of radiated fields in relation to cavity resonances and aperture excitation early on. Magnetic field probe based Dipole Moment Method is recommended since it can be implemented without the presence of the actual aperture in the enclosure. It depends upon the magnetic field excitation at the location of the proposed aperture and the polarizability of the aperture which can be calculated given the orientation and the dimensions of the proposed aperture. However the limitation of tins method starts when the length of the aperture begins to approach resonance. This paper presents the work done to extend this method to include resonating apertures in conjunction with resonating enclosures.

Authors: Rosner R., Almog Y., Moffie M., Schwartz N., Mendelson A.
Title: Power awareness through selective dynamically optimized traces
Source title: Conference Proceedings - Annual International Symposium on Computer Architecture, ISCA
Affiliations: Microprocessor Research, Intel Labs., Haifa, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Rosner, R., Microprocessor Research, Intel Labs., Haifa, Israel; Almog, Y., Microprocessor Research, Intel Labs., Haifa, Israel; Moffie, M., Microprocessor Research, Intel Labs., Haifa, Israel; Schwartz, N., Microprocessor Research, Intel Labs., Haifa, Israel; Mendelson, A., Microprocessor Research, Intel Labs., Haifa, Israel
Abstract: We present the PARROT concept that seeks to achieve higher performance with reduced energy consumption through gradual optimization of frequently executed code traces. The PARROT microarchitectural framework integrates trace caching, dynamic optimizations and pipeline decoupling. We employ a selective approach for applying complex mechanisms only upon the most frequently used traces to maximize the performance gain at any given power constraint, thus attaining finer control of tradeoffs between performance and power awareness. We show that the PARROT based microarchitecture can improve the performance of aggressively designed processors by providing the means to improve the utilization of their more elaborate resources. At the same time, rigorous selection of traces prior to storage and optimization provides the key to attenuating increases in the power budget. For resource-constrained designs, PARROT based architectures deliver better performance (up to an average 16% increase in IPC) at a comparable energy level, whereas the conventional path to a similar performance improvement consumes an average 70% more energy. Meanwhile, for those designs which can tolerate a higher power budget, PARROT gracefully scales up to use additional execution resources in a uniformly efficient manner. In particular, a PARROT-style doubly-wide machine delivers an average 45% IPC improvement while actually improving the cubic-MIPS-per-WATT power awareness metric by over 50%.
Index Keywords: Bandwidth; Computational complexity; Energy utilization; Optimization; Reusability; Scheduling; Decoders; Microarchitectural techniques; Power density; Transistor density; Computer architecture

Regenesys launched its lithium ion batteries and chemical storage system that are capable of producing electricity in any weather condition. Abstract: Factor analysis of wood furnish and TMP pulp quality data identified two wood-related factors explaining pulp quality variations. These were wood freshness, indicated by potential brightness, and the ease of application of energy to the wood, indicated by higher tear strength. Wood freshness, giving higher brightness and lower bleach chemical consumption was higher in winter periods, probably because of wood storage conditions. Easier application of energy occurred in the summer.

Abstract: The short and long term solutions, which help to put coal on a level with other technologies, are discussed. Major improvements in CO2 emission from pulverised coal fired power plant are possible by improvement in generation efficiency, either via new plant or upgrade of existing plant and by substituting a fraction of the coal with biomass, biomass being CO2 neutral. Abstract: The features of dimming HID lamps, which can produce significant energy savings and increase user flexibility, are discussed. HID lighting systems consume about 12% of all lighting loads in the commercial sector, 31% in the industrial sector and 87% in all outdoor stationary applications, which averages out to 17% of all electric energy consumed by all lighting systems in the United States. Dimming can be employed in HID lighting systems to save energy and enable the space to adapt to different uses, ambient conditions and time of day. HID lamp dimming can reduce electric utility operating costs through an occupancy-based strategy, daylight harvesting and scheduled peak demand reduction.

Title: Soft errors' impact on system reliability
Source title: EDN
Affiliations: Cypress Semiconductor, United States; Memory Products Division of Cypress Semiconductor, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mastipuram, R., Cypress Semiconductor, United States, Memory Products Division of Cypress Semiconductor, United States; Wee, E.C., Cypress Semiconductor, United States
Abstract: The impact of soft errors on system reliability in memory devices are discussed. Single-event effects (SEE) are associated with the change of states or transients in a device that energetic external radiation particles induce, and soft errors that are predominantly caused by external radiation are also known as single-event upsets (SEU). The four common sources of SEY are low-energy alpha particles, high-energy cosmic particles, thermal neutrons, and poor system design. The different approaches for reducing the soft-error rate (SER) include system-level changes, process changes, circuit hardening, and design hardening.
Index Keywords: Energetic external radiations; Single-event effects; Data storage equipment; Neutrons; Radiation; Systems analysis; Error analysis

Title: EMBARC: An efficient memory bank assignment algorithm for retargetable compilers
Source title: Proceedings of the ACM SIGPLAN Conference on Languages, Compilers, and Tools for Embedded Systems (LCTES)
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, School of Engineering, University of Virginia, 151 Engineer's Way, Charlottesville, VA 22903, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hiser, J.D., Department of Computer Science, School of Engineering, University of Virginia, 151 Engineer's Way, Charlottesville, VA 22903, United States; Davidson, J.W., Department of Computer Science, School of Engineering, University of Virginia, 151 Engineer's Way, Charlottesville, VA 22903, United States
Abstract: Many architectures today, especially embedded systems, have multiple memory partitions, each with potentially different performance and energy characteristics. To meet the strict time-to-market requirements of systems containing these chips, compilers require retargetable alogrithms for effectively assigning values to the memory partitions. The EMBARC algorithm described in this paper is the first algorithm to attempt to realize a comprehensive, retargetable algorithm for effective partition assignment of variables in an arbitrary memory hierarchy. It supports a wide variety of memory models including on-chip SRAMs, multiple layers of caches, and even uncached DRAM partitions. Even though it is designed to handle such a range of memory hierarchies, EMBARC is capable of generating partition assignments of similar quality to algorithms designed for specific memory hierarchies. We use a large range of benchmarks and memory models to demonstrate the effectiveness of the EMBARC algorithm. We found that EMBARC can achieve 99% of the improvement of a dedicated algorithm for cacheless systems without SRAM. Also, for cacheless systems with SRAM, EMBARC generated the optimal partition assignment for benchmarks that were simple enough to hand-generate an optimal partition assignment. As further proof of EMBARC's generality, we also show how EMBARC can be used to generate partition assignments for a memory hierarchies with two on-chip caches that can be accessed in parallel.
Author Keywords: Embedded Systems; Partition Assignment; Retargetable Compilers
Index Keywords: Memory partition; on-chip caches; Partition Assignment; Retargetable Compilers; Algorithms; C (programming language); Embedded systems; Java programming language; Mathematical models; Static random access storage; Storage allocation (computer); Program compilers

Title: An analytical throughput model for bulk data transfers over wide area networks
Source title: 2004 IEEE International Symposium on Cluster Computing and the Grid, CCGrid 2004
Affiliations: XIOtech Corporation, Eden Prairie, MN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Simitci, H., XIOtech Corporation, Eden Prairie, MN, United States
Abstract: This paper presents an analytical queuing network model for bulk data transfers over long distances. Large scale scientific applications like climate modeling and high energy physics generate huge amounts of data that needs to be replicated across long distances for collaboration purposes. In addition, businesses need to copy critical data to remote sites for disaster recovery. The performance of these kinds of applications depends on the latency of the link due to the physical distance between the sites. The model presented in this paper uses the most prominent characteristics of remote data transfer applications and simplifies the performance prediction. This study shows that the overall throughput is mostly determined by the latency of the link, bandwidth of the link, number of round trips required for each I/O operation, and the number of simultaneously active I/O operations (asynchronous window size). Through laboratory and field experiments, we show that the model is capable of approximating the performance of remote data transfers within a very small error range.
Index Keywords: Data backup; Data migration; Disaster recovery; Distributed caching; Bandwidth; Buffer storage; Data acquisition; Data storage equipment; Metropolitan area networks; Network protocols; Wide area networks; Data transfer

Abstract: A 64-state Viterbi accelerator fabricated in 1.2V, 90nm dual-Vt CMOS technology is described for 2GHz operation and fastest reported 500Mbps data rate (1Gbps decode for 1/2 rate codes). Novel radix-4 add-compare-select circuits and low-energy traceback register file techniques enable 40mW total power at 1.2V, 2GHz, and scalability to 5mW at 0.7V, 216MHz (for 802.11a wireless baseband).

Authors: De Bus B., De Sutter B., Van Put L., Chanet D., De Bosschere K.
Title: Link-time optimization of ARM binaries
Source title: Proceedings of the ACM SIGPLAN Conference on Languages, Compilers, and Tools for Embedded Systems (LCTES)
Affiliations: Electronics Department, Ghent University, Sint-Pietersnieuwstraat 41, 9000 Gent, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: De Bus, B., Electronics Department, Ghent University, Sint-Pietersnieuwstraat 41, 9000 Gent, Belgium; De Sutter, B., Electronics Department, Ghent University, Sint-Pietersnieuwstraat 41, 9000 Gent, Belgium; Van Put, L., Electronics Department, Ghent University, Sint-Pietersnieuwstraat 41, 9000 Gent, Belgium; Chanet, D., Electronics Department, Ghent University, Sint-Pietersnieuwstraat 41, 9000 Gent, Belgium; De Bosschere, K., Electronics Department, Ghent University, Sint-Pietersnieuwstraat 41, 9000 Gent, Belgium
Abstract: The overhead in terms of code size, power consumption and execution time caused by the use of precompiled libraries and separate compilation is often unacceptable in the embedded world, where real-time constraints, battery life-time and production costs are of critical importance. In this paper we present our link-time optimizer for the ARM architecture. We discuss how we can deal with the peculiarities of the ARM architecture related to its visible program counter and how the introduced overhead can be eliminated to a large extent. Our link-time optimizer is evaluated in two tool chains. In the Arm Developer Suite tool chain, average code size reductions with 14.6% are achieved, while execution time is reduced with 8.3% on average, and energy consumption with 7.3%. On binaries from the GCC tool chain the average code size reduction is 16.6%, execution time is reduced with 12.3% and the energy consumption with 11.5% on average. Finally, we show how the incorporation of link-time optimization in tool chains may influence library interface design.
Author Keywords: Compaction; Linker; Optimization; Performance
Index Keywords: Codes (symbols); Compaction; Data acquisition; Data flow analysis; Data storage equipment; Optimization; Performance; Program compilers; Real time systems; Semantics; Library codes; Link-time analyzes; Linkers; Program counters (PC); Computer science

Abstract: A 1.8V, 512Mbit Packet-based DRAM with 3.2Gbps/pin was designed for main memory of a game console and graphic application. To have lower power consumption and smaller area in clock generation and distribution, 3-row pad structure with reduced clock loading and PLL with loop zero from voltage offset are used. An analytical equation for estimating the input capacitance of pad with ODT (On-Die Termination) is also presented.

Title: Polymer/carbon nanotube composites: Challenges and opportunities
Source title: International SAMPE Technical Conference
Affiliations: Sch. of Poly., Text. and Fiber Eng., Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0295, United States; Faculty of Engineering, Okayama University, Okayama 700-8530, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, S., Sch. of Poly., Text. and Fiber Eng., Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0295, United States; Liu, T., Sch. of Poly., Text. and Fiber Eng., Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0295, United States; Sreekumar, T.V., Sch. of Poly., Text. and Fiber Eng., Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0295, United States, Faculty of Engineering, Okayama University, Okayama 700-8530, Japan; Uchida, T., Sch. of Poly., Text. and Fiber Eng., Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0295, United States; Zhang, X., Sch. of Poly., Text. and Fiber Eng., Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0295, United States; Park, Y.-B., Sch. of Poly., Text. and Fiber Eng., Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA 30332-0295, United States
Abstract: Due to their exceptional mechanical, physical, thermal, optical, and electrical properties, carbon nanotubes and especially single wall carbon nanotubes are playing a critical role in the development of high-performance polymer composites. Polymer/carbon nanotube composites are processed into films, fibers, and bulk composites with significant mechanical and physical property enhancements. Single wall carbon nanotubes have high specific surface area, which can be further increased in activated carbon/single wall carbon nanotube composites. Such composite systems are promising candidates for supercapacitor applications. While single wall carbon nanotubes offer outstanding opportunities in materials development, many of the predicted properties can be achieved only if the nanotubes are well dispersed, exfoliated, and oriented in the polymer systems of interest. Currently, research is in progress addressing these issues in conjunction with the processing and characterization of polymer/carbon nanotube composites.

Title: An injection locked, RF powered, telemetry IC in 0.25μm CMOS
Source title: IEEE Symposium on VLSI Circuits, Digest of Technical Papers

R.C., University of Michigan, EECS Building, 1301 Seal Avenue, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States
Abstract: This wireless transponder recovers power and a reference clock from an incident RF signal and returns data on a 900MHz carrier. A multi-stage voltage multiplier/rectifier converts the received low power RF signal to a useful DC voltage and stores the energy on a storage capacitor. The injection locking technique facilitates power efficient generation of a low phase noise 900MHz internal clock from the received 450MHz signal by employing a fully integrated low power LC oscillator. A fully integrated pseudo-differential power amplifier operating in class AB regime is used as the output stage of the system. The system dissipates an average of 5μA in standby mode and 1.1mA during active operation.

Authors: Ushamani M., Sreekumar K., Kartha C.S., Joseph R.
Title: Novel methylene blue sensitized photopolymers for holographic recording: A comparison
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Polymer Science, Cochin Univ. of Sci. and Technology, Cochin, Kerala, 682022, India; Department of Physics, Cochin Univ. of Sci. and Technology, Cochin, Kerala, 682022, India; Department of Applied Chemistry, Cochin Univ. of Sci. and Technology, Cochin, Kerala, 682022, India
Authors with affiliations: Ushamani, M., Department of Polymer Science, Cochin Univ. of Sci. and Technology, Cochin, Kerala, 682022, India; Sreekumar, K., Department of Applied Chemistry, Cochin Univ. of Sci. and Technology, Cochin, Kerala, 682022, India; Kartha, C.S., Department of Physics, Cochin Univ. of Sci. and Technology, Cochin, Kerala, 682022, India; Joseph, R., Department of Polymer Science, Cochin Univ. of Sci. and Technology, Cochin, Kerala, 682022, India
Abstract: Polymer matrices like PVC and a blend of PVA/PAA is introduced as new holographic media that cause red sensitivity with methylene blue. Unlike methylene blue sensitized polymers like PVA, PMMA, gelatin etc, the change of state occurring for methylene blue on laser irradiation on PVC matrix was found to be permanent. No recovery of dye on the irradiated spot was observed on storage. The outstanding properties of this material are its excellent optical clarity, insensitive to humidity, economical, ease of fabrication, absence of dark room storage etc. The recovery of dye in conventional MBPVA matrix can be delayed by blending PVA with PAA. Optimization of the ratio of PVA/PAA, the sensitizer concentration, pH, energy, diffraction efficiency measurements etc are done. pH is found to have a great influence on the recovery of the dye in this matrix. The effect of monomers in improving the diffraction efficiency on these dye doped polymer system is also evaluated. A comparative study is done on these polymer matrices and holographic gratings were recorded on these films from a He-Ne laser operating at 632.8 nm.

Authors: Lavian T., Mambretti J., Cutrell D., Cohen H., Merrill S., Durairaj R., Daspit P., Monga I., Naiksatam S., Figueira S., Gutierrez D., Hoang D., Travostino F.
Title: DWDM-RAM: A data intensive grid service architecture enabled by dynamic optical networks
Source title: 2004 IEEE International Symposium on Cluster Computing and the Grid, CCGrid 2004
Affiliations: Nortel Networks Labs.; iCAIR Northwestern University, United States; SCU, United States; Stanford University, United States; UT Sydney, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Lavian, T., Nortel Networks Labs.; Mambretti, J., iCAIR Northwestern University, United States; Cutrell, D., Nortel Networks Labs.; Cohen, H., Nortel Networks Labs.; Merrill, S., Nortel Networks Labs.; Durairaj, R., Nortel Networks Labs.; Daspit, P., Nortel Networks Labs.; Monga, I., Nortel Networks Labs.; Naiksatam, S., SCU, United States; Figueira, S., SCU, United States; Gutierrez, D., Stanford University, United States; Hoang, D., UT Sydney, Australia; Travostino, F., Nortel Networks Labs.
Abstract: Next generation applications and architectures (for example, Grids) are driving radical changes in the nature of traffic, service models, technology, and cost, creating opportunities for an advanced communications infrastructure to tackle next generation data services. To take advantage of these trends and opportunities, research communities are creating new architectures, such as the Open Grid Service Architecture (OGSA), which are being implemented in new prototype advanced infrastructures. The DWDM-RAM project, funded by DARPA, is actively addressing the challenges of next generation applications. DWDM-RAM is an architecture for data-intensive services enabled by next generation dynamic optical networks. It develops and demonstrates a novel architecture for new data communication services, within the OGSA context, that allows for managing extremely large sets of distributed data. Novel features move network services beyond notions of the network as a managed resource, for example, by including capabilities for dynamic on-demand provisioning and advance scheduling. DWDM-RAM encapsulates optical network resources (Lambdas, lightpaths) into a Grid Service and integrates their management within the Open Grid Service Architecture. Migration to emerging standards such as WS-Resource Framework (WS-RF) should be staright forward. In initial applications, DWDM-RAM targets specific data-intensive services such as rapid, massive data transfers used by large scale eScience applications, including: high-energy physics, geophysics, life science, bioinformatics, genomics, medical morphometry, tomography, microscopy imaging, astronomical and astrophysical imaging, complex modeling, and visualization.
Author Keywords: 10Gbs Lambda-switched networks; Data-intensive applications; DWDM; Dynamic wavelength provisioning; eScience; ODIN; OGSA; OGSI; Optical network resources; Scheduled Grid services

Authors: Tiwari M., Zhu Y., Chakrabarti C.
Title: Memory sub-banking scheme for high throughput turbo decoder
Source title: ICASSP, IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech and Signal Processing - Proceedings
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tiwari, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287, United States; Zhu, Y., Department of Electrical Engineering, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287, United States; Chakrabarti, C., Department of Electrical Engineering, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287, United States
Abstract: Turbo codes have revolutionized the world of coding theory with their superior performance. However, the implementation of these codes is both computationally and memory-intensive. Recently, the sliding window (SW) approach has been proposed as an effective means of reducing the decoding delay as well as the memory requirements of Turbo implementations. In this paper we present a sub-banked implementation of the SW-based approach that achieves high throughput, low decoding latency and reduced memory energy consumption. Our contributions include derivation of the optimal memory sub-banked structure for different SW configurations, study of the relationship between memory size, energy consumption and decoding latency for different SW configurations and study of the effect of number of sub-banks on the throughput and decoding latency of a given SW configuration. The theoretical study has been validated by SimpleScalar for a rate 1/3 MAP decoder.
Index Keywords: Decoding latency; Memory size; Sub-banking scheme; Turbo decoders; Algorithms; Buffer storage; Constraint theory; Encoding (symbols); Iterative methods; Recursive functions; Throughput; Turbo codes; Decoding

Authors: Anand M., Nightingale E.B., Flinn J.
Title: Ghosts in the machine: Interfaces for better power management
Source title: MobiSys 2004 - Second International Conference on Mobile Systems, Applications and Services
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Michigan, United States
Authors with affiliations: Anand, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Michigan, United States; Nightingale, E.B., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Michigan, United States; Flinn, J., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Michigan, United States
Abstract: We observe that the modularity of current power management algorithms often leads to poor results. We propose two new interfaces that pierce the abstraction barrier that inhibits device power management. First, an OS power manager allows applications to query the current power mode of I/O devices to evaluate the performance and energy cost of alternative strategies for reading and writing data. Second, we allow applications to disclose ghost hints that enable better power management in the presence of multiple devices. Adaptive applications issue ghost hints to device power managers when they are forced to use a poor I/O path because a device is not in an ideal power mode; such hints allow devices to implement proactive power management strategies that do not depend upon passive load observation. Using these new interfaces, we implement a middleware layer that supports adaptive disk cache management. On an iPAQ handheld running Linux, our cache manager reduces interactive response time for a Web browser by 27% and decreases total energy usage by 9%. For a mail reader, the cache manager decreases response time by 42% and energy use by 5%.
Author Keywords: Adaptive caching; Energy-awareness; Power management
Index Keywords: Adaptive caching; Bluetooth; Energy-awareness; Power management; Buffer storage; Computer aided manufacturing; Computer operating systems; Energy utilization; Input output programs; Interfaces (computer); Mobile computing; Servers; World Wide Web; Energy management

Authors: Xu J., Lee W.-C., Tang X.
Title: Exponential index: A parameterized distributed indexing scheme for data on air
Source title: MobiSys 2004 - Second International Conference on Mobile Systems, Applications and Services
Affiliations: Dept. of Computer Science, Hong Kong Baptist University, Kowloon Tong, Hong Kong; Dept. of Computer Sci. and Eng., Penn State University, University Park, PA 16801, United States; School of Computer Eng., Nanyang Technological Univ., Singapore 639798, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Xu, J., Dept. of Computer Science, Hong Kong Baptist University, Kowloon Tong, Hong Kong; Lee, W.-C., Dept. of Computer Sci. and Eng., Penn State University, University Park, PA 16801, United States; Tang, X., School of Computer Eng., Nanyang Technological Univ., Singapore 639798, Singapore
Abstract: Wireless data broadcast has received a lot of attention from industries and academia in recent years. Access efficiency and energy conservation are two critical performance concerns in a wireless data broadcast environment. To improve the efficiency of energy consumption on mobile devices, traditional disk-based indexing techniques such as B +-tree have been extended to index broadcast data on a wireless channel. However, existing designs are mostly based on centralized tree structures. Most of these indexing techniques are not flexible in the sense that the trade-off between access efficiency and energy conservation is not adjustable based on application specific requirements. We propose in this paper a novel parameterized index, called the exponential index, which can be tuned to optimize the access latency with the tuning time bounded by a given limit, and vice versa. The proposed index is very efficient because it facilitates replication naturally by sharing links in multiple search trees and thus minimizes storage overhead. Experimental results show that the exponential index not only achieves better performance than the state-of-the-art indexes but also enables great flexibility in trade-offs between access latency and tuning time.
Author Keywords: Data broadcast; Energy conservation; Index structure; Mobile computing
Index Keywords: Data broadcast; Index structure; Multiple search trees; Parameterized distributed indexing; Broadcasting; Data acquisition; Energy conservation; Indexing (of information); Optimization; Parameter estimation; Trees (mathematics); Tuning; Mobile computing

Title: Minimizing energy consumption in sensor networks using a wakeup radio
Source title: 2004 IEEE Wireless Communications and Networking Conference, WCNC 2004
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, Coordinated Science Laboratory, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, Coordinated Science Laboratory, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, United States
Authors with affiliations: Miller, M.J., Department of Computer Science, Coordinated Science Laboratory, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, United States; Vaidya, N.H., Department of Electrical Engineering, Coordinated Science Laboratory, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, United States
Abstract: For increasing the life of sensor networks, each node must conserve energy as much as possible. In this paper, we propose a protocol in which energy is conserved by amortizintwo-radiog the energy cost of communication over multiple packets. In addition, we allow sensors to control the amount of buffered packets since storage space is limited. To achieve this, a two-radio architecture is used which allows a sensor to "wakeup" a neighbor with a busy tone and send its packets for that destination. However, this process is expensive because all neighbors must awake and listen to the primary channel to determine who is the intended destination. Therefore, triggered wakeups on the primary channel are proposed to avoid using the more costly wakeup procedure. We present a protocol for efficiently determining how large the period for these wakeups should be such that energy consumption is minimized.
Index Keywords: Energy costs; Hardware complexity; Sensor networks; Wakeup signals; Code division multiple access; Communication channels (information theory); Computer science; Energy efficiency; Energy utilization; Estimation; Packet networks; Radio; Signal interference; Synchronization; Sensors

Authors: Ibrahim A., Parker M., Davis A.
Title: Energy efficient cluster co-processors
Source title: ICASSP, IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech and Signal Processing - Proceedings
Affiliations: School of Computing, University of Utah, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ibrahim, A., School of Computing, University of Utah, United States; Parker, M., School of Computing, University of Utah, United States; Davis, A., School of Computing, University of Utah, United States
Abstract: New 3G wireless algorithms require more performance than can be currently provided by embedded processors. ASICs provide the necessary performance but are costly to design and sacrifice generality. This paper introduces a clustered VLIW coprocessor approach that organizes the execution and storage resources differently than a traditional general-purpose processor or DSP. The execution units of the coprocessor are clustered and embedded in a rich set of communication resources. Fine grain control of these resources is imposed by a wide-word horizontal micro-code program. The advantages of this approach are quantified on a suite of six algorithms that are taken from both traditional DSP applications and from the new 3G cellular telephony domain. The result is surprising. The execution clusters retain much of the generality of a conventional processor while simultaneously improving performance by one to two orders of magnitude and by reducing energy-delay by three to four orders of magnitude when compared to a conventional embedded processor such as the Intel XScale.
Index Keywords: Cellular telephony; Co-processors; Programmability; Wireless algorithms; Algorithms; Application specific integrated circuits; CMOS integrated circuits; Codes (symbols); Cryptography; Program processors; Wireless telecommunication systems; Embedded systems

Authors: Liu T., Sadler C.M., Zhang P., Martonosi M.
Title: Implementing software on resource-constrained mobile sensors: Experiences with Impala and ZebraNet
Source title: MobiSys 2004 - Second International Conference on Mobile Systems, Applications and Services
Affiliations: Depts. of Electrical Engineering, Princeton University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liu, T., Depts. of Electrical Engineering, Princeton University, United States; Sadler, C.M., Depts. of Electrical Engineering, Princeton University, United States; Zhang, P., Depts. of Electrical Engineering, Princeton University, United States; Martonosi, M., Depts. of Electrical Engineering, Princeton University, United States
Abstract: ZebraNet is a mobile, wireless sensor network in which nodes move throughout an environment working to gather and process information about their surroundings. As in many sensor or wireless systems, nodes have critical resource constraints such as processing speed, memory size, and energy supply; they also face special hardware issues such as sensing device sample time, data storage/access restrictions, and wireless transceiver capabilities. This paper discusses and evaluates ZebraNet's system design decisions in the face of a range of real-world constraints. Impala - ZebraNet's middleware layer - serves as a light-weight operating system, but also has been designed to encourage application modularity, simplicity, adaptivity, and repairability. Impala is now implemented on ZebraNet hardware nodes, which include a 16-bit microcontroller, a low-power GPS unit, a 900MHz radio, and 4Mbits of non-volatile FLASH memory. This paper discusses Impala's operation scheduling and event handling model, and explains how system constraints and goals led to the interface designs we chose between the application, middleware, and firmware layers. We also describe Impala's network interface which unifies media access control and transport control into an efficient network protocol. With the minimum overhead in communication, buffering, and processing, it supports a range of message models, all inspired by and tailored to ZebraNet's application needs. By discussing design tradeoffs in the context of a real hardware system and a real sensor network application, this paper's design choices and performance measurements offer some concrete experiences with software systems issues for the mobile sensor design space. More generally, we feel that these experiences can guide design choices in a range of related systems.
Author Keywords: Event Handling; Middleware System; Network Communications; Operation Scheduling; Sensor Networks
Index Keywords: Event handling; Network communications; Operation scheduling; Sensor networks; Constraint theory; Data processing; Data storage equipment; Energy efficiency; Microcontrollers; Middleware; Network protocols; Performance; Radio transmission; Sensors; Throughput; Transceivers; Mobile telecommunication systems

Authors: Carlsson R., Kan C., Wikström M.
Title: Effects of coating process temperatures/times and latex viscoelasticity on binding strength
Source title: 2004 TAPPI Coating and Graphic Arts Conference and Exhibit
Affiliations: Dow Europe GmbH, Bachtobelstrasse 3, CH-8810 Horgen, Switzerland; Emulsion Polymers Research, Dow Chemical Company, Midland, MI 48640, United States; Korsnäs A.B., SE-801 81 Gävle, Sweden

Abstract: This study shows how the development of coating strength is influenced by latex viscoelasticity and processing temperatures/times during calendering, drying and storage. Four model latexes with different viscoelasticity are used in pilot coater scale evaluations. The results show that high calendering temperatures, high drying intensity and elevated storage temperatures, e.g. in jumbo reel, significantly can improve binding strength. A latex with better deformability at actual process conditions, seen as a low storage modulus, gave the improvement more easily.

Title: Compiler-directed data cache leakage reduction
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE Computer Society Annual Symposium on VLSI: Emerging Trends in VLSI Systems Design
Affiliations: Department of ECE, S. Illinois University Carbondale, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, W., Department of ECE, S. Illinois University Carbondale, United States
Abstract: Leakage energy reduction for caches has been the target of many recent research efforts. In this work, we propose a novel compiler directed approach to reduce the data cache leakage energy by exploiting the program behavior. The proposed approach is based on the observation that only a small portion of data are active at runtime and the program spends a lot of execution time in loops, so a large portion of data cache lines, which are not accessed by the loops, can be placed into leakage control mode to reduce leakage energy consumption. The experimental results show that the proposal approach is comparable to the pure hardware based approach in reducing data cache leakage energy.
Index Keywords: Compiler-directed leakage; Data cache; Granularity; Leakage energy; Benchmarking; Data acquisition; Data compression; Data processing; Graphic methods; Optimization; Program assemblers; Buffer storage

Title: WARM SRAM: A novel scheme to reduce static leakage energy in SRAM arrays
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE Computer Society Annual Symposium on VLSI: Emerging Trends in VLSI Systems Design
Affiliations: Electrical and Computer Engineering, Iowa State University, Ames, IA 50011, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gomathisankaran, M., Electrical and Computer Engineering, Iowa State University, Ames, IA 50011, United States; Tyagi, A., Electrical and Computer Engineering, Iowa State University, Ames, IA 50011, United States
Abstract: The increasing sub-threshold leakage current levels with newer technology nodes has been identified by ITRS as one of the major fundamental problems faced by the semiconductor industry. Concurrently, the expected performance improvement and functionality integration expectations drive the continued reduction in feature size. This results in ever-increasing power per unit area and the accompanying problem of heat removal and cooling. Portable battery-powered applications, fuelled by pervasive and embedded computing, have seen tremendous growth and have reached a point where battery energy and power density can't be increased further. This raises the computational throughput per watt target for the future technology nodes. SRAM arrays which are used widely as a system component, such as caches and register files, in both high-performance and portable systems, are getting to be dominant power consumers because of their large capacity and area. Hence any reduction in cache energy can result in considerable overall power reduction. In this paper, we propose a novel circuit technique using depletion mode devices, to reduce the static energy of SRAM array in an on-chip cache by 90% without any performance impact.
Index Keywords: Chip caches; Leakage energy; Multiplexors; Power reduction; Buffer storage; Client server computer systems; Computational methods; File editors; Leakage currents; Semiconductor materials; Static random access storage

Title: Gallium Nitride market poised for robust growth
Source title: Chemical Market Reporter
Authors with affiliations: Lerner, I.
Abstract: The growth in the gallium nitride (GaN) market which is currently valued at over $1 billion and is predicted to reach $4.5 billion by 2007 is discussed. According to the Tokyo-based market research firm Global Information Inc., the number of companies and research centers with GaN activity have increased from about 350 in 2000, to 477 by the first quarter of 2003. GaN is a wide bandgap semiconductor material used in optoelectronic, high-power and high-frequency devices. Wafers made of GaN are essential to laser diodes that emit ultraviolet light, which are viewed as the basis to the next-generation of DVD player/recorders and optical data-storage systems for computers.

Title: Trio of chip introductions solves contemporary clock issues
Source title: Electronic Design
Abstract: The development and features of three clock chips which includes MAX9489 network clock generator and MAX9486 are discussed. It is found that the MAX9489 has mulitple outputs and exhibits high performance with low jitter and minimum skew. The Dallas Semiconductor DS26502 building-integrated timing supply (BITS) clock-recovery circuit supports clock frequencies such as the 64-kHz timing interface and the 2048- and 6312-kHz Japanese synchronization interfaces. The MAX9486 clock chip which is designed for T1, E1, T3, E3 and ADSL/VDSL applications like line cards uses an external 17.664-MHz crystal and an 8-kHz input reference clock.

Abstract: The opto-electronic oscillator (OEO), which uses an optical energy storage element to achieve low phase noise, represents a paradigm shift for generating high quality microwave signals. Since its first demonstration of low phase noise potential ten years ago at JPL, the OEO has been steadily improving its phase noise performance, frequency stability, and robustness. Now the OEO has moved beyond the laboratory and entered into real world applications, ranging from aerospace to telecommunications to instrumentation.

Abstract: We propose a new instruction synthesis paradigm that falls between a general-purpose embedded processor and a synthesized application specific processor (ASP).
