Authors: Dhinsa K.K., Bailey C.J., Pericleous K.A.
Title: Turbulence modelling and it's impact on CFD predictions for cooling of electronic components
Source title: Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems -Proceedings of the Intersociety Conference
Affiliations: Ctr. Numer. Modelling/Proc. Anal., University of Greenwich, Old Royal Naval College, Greenwich, London, SE10 9LS, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Dhinsa, K.K., Ctr. Numer. Modelling/Proc. Anal., University of Greenwich, Old Royal Naval College, Greenwich, London, SE10 9LS, United Kingdom; Bailey, C.J., Ctr. Numer. Modelling/Proc. Anal., University of Greenwich, Old Royal Naval College, Greenwich, London, SE10 9LS, United Kingdom; Pericleous, K.A., Ctr. Numer. Modelling/Proc. Anal., University of Greenwich, Old Royal Naval College, Greenwich, London, SE10 9LS, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper will discuss Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) results from an investigation into the accuracy of several turbulence models to predict air cooling for electronic packages and systems. Also new transitional turbulence models will be proposed with emphasis on hybrid techniques that use the k - ε model at an appropriate distance away from the wall and suitable models, with wall functions, near wall regions. A major proportion of heat emitted from electronic packages can be extracted by air cooling. This flow of air throughout an electronic system and the heat extracted is highly dependent on the nature of turbulence present in the flow. The use of CFD for such investigations is fast becoming a powerful and almost essential tool for the design, development and optimization of engineering applications. However turbulence models remain a key issue when tackling such flow phenomena. The reliability of CFD analysis depends heavily on the turbulence model employed together with the wall functions implemented. In order to resolve the abrupt fluctuations experienced by the turbulent energy and other parameters located at near wall regions and shear layers a particularly fine computational mesh is necessary which inevitably increases the computer storage and run-time requirements. The PHYSICA Finite Volume code was used for this investigation. With the exception of the k - ε and k-ω models which are available as standard within PHYSICA, all other turbulence models mentioned were implemented via the source code by the authors. The LVEL, LVEL CAP, Wolfshtein, k-ε, k-ω, SST and kε/kl models are described and compared with experimental data.
Author Keywords: Flow Separation and Reattachment; Heat Transfer; Low Reynolds Number (Transitional) Flows; Thermal Management

Authors: Wirtz R., Zhao T., Jiang Y.
Title: Thermal and mechanical characteristics of a multi-functional thermal energy storage structure
Source title: Thermomechanical Phenomena in Electronic Systems -Proceedings of the Intersociety Conference
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, MS312, University of Nevada, Reno, Reno, NV 89557, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wirtz, R., Mechanical Engineering Department, MS312, University of Nevada, Reno, Reno, NV 89557, United States; Zhao, T., Mechanical Engineering Department, MS312, University of Nevada, Reno, Reno, NV 89557, United States; Jiang, Y., Mechanical Engineering Department, MS312, University of Nevada, Reno, Reno, NV 89557, United States
Abstract: Thermal Energy Storage (TES) sandwich-structures that combine the heat storage function with structural functionality are described. The structure consists of a Thermal Interface (TI) connected to a hollow plate lamination. Each laminate is a hollow aluminum plate having a series of mm-scale channels or compartments that are filled with Phase Change Material (PCM). Heat storage is via the latent heat of the PCM. A generalized thermal response model that is applicable to a wide range of channel geometrical configurations is described. The model couples the thermal response of the TI to that of the aluminum/PCM lamination. It gives rise to closed-form solutions for the spatial temperature distribution within the TES-volume. The temporal response of the system is easily obtained via numerical solution of two ordinary differential equations. Thermal analysis delineates geometrical configurations that have good thermal response characteristics. The mechanical properties of the laminated structure were determined experimentally. Four-point bending experiments were conducted using specimens made with three layers of hollow plates laminated using a structural adhesive. An energy method was developed to model the deformation and strength of the laminated structure. The energy method can correctly simulate the experimental results. Experiments and modeling indicate that these laminated structures have an excellent performance-to-weight ratio.
Index Keywords: Laminated structures; Liquid paraffin; Phase change material (PCM); Thermal energy storage (TES); Aluminum; Computational geometry; Crystal lattices; Deformation; Graphite; Heat transfer; Laminating machinery; Paraffins; Phase transitions; Porosity; Tensile testing; Thermal conductivity; Thermoanalysis; Energy storage

Authors: Biswas P., Choudhary V., Atasu K., Pozzi L., Ienne P., Dutt N.
Title: Introduction of local memory elements in instruction set extensions
Source title: Proceedings - Design Automation Conference
Affiliations: Center for Embedded Computer Systems, Sch. of Info. and Computer Science, University of California, Irvine, CA, United States; Processor Architecture Laboratory, Swiss Fed. Institute of Technology, Lausanne, Switzerland

Institute of Technology, Lausanne, Switzerland; Pozzi, L., Processor Architecture Laboratory, Swiss Fed. Institute of Technology, Lausanne, Switzerland; Ienne, P., Processor Architecture Laboratory, Swiss Fed. Institute of Technology, Lausanne, Switzerland; Dutt, N., Center for Embedded Computer Systems, Sch. of Info. and Computer Science, University of California, Irvine, CA, United States
Abstract: Automatic generation of Instruction Set Extensions (ISEs), to be executed on a custom processing unit or a coprocessor is an important step towards processor customization. A typical goal of a manual designer is to combine a large number of atomic instructions into an ISE satisfying microarchitectural constraints. However, memory operations pose a challenge for previous ISE approaches by limiting the size of the resulting instruction. In this paper, we introduce memory elements into custom units which result in ISEs closer to those sought after by the designers. We consider two kinds of memory elements for mapping to the specialized hardware: small hardware tables and architecturally-visible state registers. We devised a genetic algorithm to specifically exploit opportunities of introducing memory elements during ISE generation. Finally, we demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach by a detailed study of the variation in performance, area and energy in the presence of the generated ISEs, on a number of MediaBench, EEMBC and cryptographic applications. With the introduction of memory, the average speedup varied from 2.7X to 5X depending on the architectural configuration with a nominal area overhead. Moreover, we obtained an average energy reduction of 26% with respect to a 32-KB cache.

Title: Active RF pulse compression for accelerator applications

Abstract: Active RF pulse compression relies on use of a component in the RF circuit that can be switched from one state to another in a time much shorter than the desired RF pulse width. This paper reviews work wherein (a) the switching is accomplished using rapidly-ionized plasma tubes to detune a resonator that forms one reflector for an energy storage cavity, and (b) the switching is accomplished by rapidly switching the dielectric constant of low-loss ferroelectric elements in an energy storage cavity. Recent experiments to produce >50 MW compressed rf pulses at 11.4 GHz using plasma switches are described, while recent designs for ferroelectric switches are also described. The latter may have the advantage of permitting more than one switching during a single RF input pulse, thus allowing the efficiency to be greater than that for a single switching.

Title: A theory of magnetization reversal in nanowires
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Dept. of Mathematics, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States
Authors with affiliations: Maier, R.S., Dept. of Mathematics, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ 85721, United States
Abstract: Magnetization reversal in a ferromagnetic nanowire which is much narrower than the exchange length is believed to be accomplished through the thermally activated growth of a spatially localized nucleus, which initially occupies a small fraction of the total volume. To date, the most detailed theoretical treatments of reversal as a field-induced but noise-activated process have focused on the case of a very long ferromagnetic nanowire, i.e., a highly elongated cylindrical particle, and have yielded a reversal rate per unit length, due to an underlying assumption that the nucleus may form anywhere along the wire. But in a bounded-length (though long) cylindrical particle with flat ends, it is energetically favored for nucleation to begin at either end. We indicate how to compute analytically the energy of the critical nucleus associated with either end, i.e., the activation barrier to magnetization reversal, which governs the reversal rate in the low-temperature (Kramers) limit. Our treatment employs elliptic functions, and is partly analytic rather than numerical. We also comment on the Kramers prefactor, which for this reversal pathway does not scale linearly as the particle length increases, and tends to a constant in the low-temperature limit.

Abstract: Ytterbium only and erbium-ytterbium co-doped phosphate glass Double Clad (DC) cladding pumped Large Mode Area (LMA) core fibers are manufactured at Kigre by the "rod-in-tube" method. The ytterbium and erbium doping concentration levels in phosphate glass are as much as two orders of magnitude higher than the doping concentrations found in fused silica fiber manufactured by Modified Chemical Vapor Deposition (MCVD) method. The background loss of the fiber's core and cladding measured ∼ 0.01 dB/per cm at 1310nm. The measured absorption coefficient at 974 nm is 0.3 dB/per cm for the ytterbium-erbium co-doped fiber. Greater than 4.6 Watts CW laser output was demonstrated from the Er:Yb:glass fiber at 1535nm with a 37.4% slop efficiency and 36.3% optical efficiency. The Yb:glass fiber produced a maximum output power of 1.6 Watts in a 14cm gain length.

Title: A fast Reed-Solomon product-code decoder without redundant computations
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, KAIST, 373-1 Guseong-Dong, Yuseong-Gu, Deajeon 305-701, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Lee, H.-Y., Department of Electrical Engineering, KAIST, 373-1 Guseong-Dong, Yuseong-Gu, Deajeon 305-701, South Korea; Park, I.-C., Department of Electrical Engineering, KAIST, 373-1 Guseong-Dong, Yuseong-Gu, Deajeon 305-701, South Korea
Abstract: This paper presents a fast and low-power decoding scheme for Reed-Solomon Product-Code (RS-PC). To increase error correction capability of RS-PC, we need to repeat Reed-Solomon (RS) decoding several times for rows and columns. As the number of RS decodings increases, the execution time and the energy consumption also increase as well. In order to reduce unnecessary operations and memory accesses, we added two small memories to store data on whether the row or column is updated or not. In the next iteration, only the updated rows and columns are recalculated instead of the whole rows and columns. Based on the proposed scheme, we implemented a RS-PC decoder using UMC 0.25μm standard and memory cells. The working frequency is 133MHz at 2.5V. Experimental results show that the execution time is reduced by 48% in case of four iterations, and by 66% in case of six iterations.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computer simulation; Computer software; Data acquisition; Data processing; Data storage equipment; Energy utilization; Error correction; Error rate; Memory cells; Program Language Interface (PLI); Reed-Solomon (RS) codes; Decoding

Abstract: The application of adiabatic switching for driving high capacitive loads encountered on the column lines of fiat panel displays is investigated. A new digital-to-analog converter using stepwise charging is proposed to minimize power dissipation. Most of the energy stored on the charged column lines can be recovered. The proposed DAC is capable of driving the high capacitive load without any bias current. Therefore, both dynamic and static power dissipation are reduced to a large extent. Simulations of the proposed architecture are compared with a lower bound for the power dissipation based on a simplified model of a conventional implementation demonstrating the potential of the new approach.

Abstract: In this paper, a low power variable length code decoder with group-based scheme is proposed. It can save at most 70% power dissipation while maintaining the same throughput rate as the conventional one. This proposal mainly consists of look-up table (LUT) partitioning and group-based memory storing, where the former is used to reduce the power wasted on looking-up unnecessary code-words due to a large LUT, especially those code-words with low probability; the latter is used to reduce the storage space of VLC tables and maintain the flexibility of our hardware decoder.

Abstract: In this paper, we calculate the benefits of electrical isolation for intra-chip optical interconnects. We compare the delay and energy metrics of systems with intra-chip electrical and optical fanout, and from the results obtained, we conclude that optical fanout can be used to improve speeds in electrical fanout systems even at very short on-chip distances.

Abstract: Content addressable memories (CAMs) are very attractive for high-speed table lookups in modern network systems. This paper presents a low-power dual match line (ML) ternary CAM (TCAM) to address the power consumption issue of CAMs. The highly capacitive ML is divided into two segments to reduce the active capacitance and hence the power. We analyze possible cases of mismatches and demonstrate a significant reduction in power (up to 43%) for a small penalty in search speed (4%).

Authors: Agarwal D.N., Pamnani S.N., Qu G., Yeung D.
Title: Transferring performance gain from software prefetching to energy reduction
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Department, Inst. for Advanced Computer Studies, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, United States; Microprocessor Verification, AMD, M/S - 615, 5204 East Ben White Blvd, Austin, TX 78741, United States
Authors with affiliations: Agarwal, D.N., Microprocessor Verification, AMD, M/S - 615, 5204 East Ben White Blvd, Austin, TX 78741, United States; Pamnani, S.N., Microprocessor Verification, AMD, M/S - 615, 5204 East Ben White Blvd, Austin, TX 78741, United States; Qu, G., Electrical Engineering Department, Inst. for Advanced Computer Studies, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, United States; Yeung, D., Electrical Engineering Department, Inst. for Advanced Computer Studies, University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, United States
Abstract: Performance-enhancement techniques improve CPU speed, but at higher cost to other valuable system resources such as power and energy. We study this trade-off using software prefetching as the system performance-enhancement technique. We first demonstrate software prefetching provides an average 36% performance boost with 8% more energy consumption and 69% higher power on six memory-intensive benchmarks. However, when we combine prefetching with a (unrealistic) static voltage scaling technique, the performance gain afforded by prefetching can be traded off for savings in power/energy consumption. In particular, we observe a 48% energy saving when we slow down the system with prefetching so as to match the performance of the system without prefetching. This suggests a promising approach to build low power systems by transforming traditional performance-enhancement techniques into low power methods. We thus propose a real time dynamic voltage scaling (DVS) algorithm that monitors a system's performance and adapts the voltage level accordingly while maintaining the observed system performance. Our dynamic DVS algorithm achieves a 38% energy saving without any performance loss on our benchmark suite.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Benchmarking; Carrier communication; Computer simulation; Computer software; Computer software portability; Energy utilization; Imaging techniques; Storage allocation (computer); Clock frequency; Dynamic voltage scaling (DVS); Performance gain; Software prefetching; Wireless telecommunication systems

Authors: Mueller M., Wortmann A., Simon S., Kugel M., Schoenauer T.
Title: The impact of clock gating schemes on the power dissipation of synthesizable register files
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Hochschule Bremen, Flughafenallee 10, 28199 Bremen, Germany; Infineon Technologies AG, Otto-Hahn-Ring 6, 81789 Munich, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Mueller, M., Hochschule Bremen, Flughafenallee 10, 28199 Bremen, Germany; Wortmann, A., Hochschule Bremen, Flughafenallee 10, 28199 Bremen, Germany; Simon, S., Hochschule Bremen, Flughafenallee 10, 28199 Bremen, Germany; Kugel, M., Infineon Technologies AG, Otto-Hahn-Ring 6, 81789 Munich, Germany; Schoenauer, T., Infineon Technologies AG, Otto-Hahn-Ring 6, 81789 Munich, Germany
Abstract: In this paper, the power dissipation of synthesizable register files with respect to different clock gating schemes is examined. Clock gating is a well-known technique for power reduction of sequential circuits. Although different clock gating schemes exist, there is no fundamental difference in the power dissipation of sequential logic because the data input signals of disabled flip-flops do not change when the clock signal is disabled. However, it is shown here that in contrast to sequential logic the clock gating scheme has significant impact on the power dissipation of register files due to signal changes of the data input port. The major result of this work is that the power dissipation of register files can be reduced significantly, if a clock gating scheme different from that one usually recommended for sequential logic is applied.
Index Keywords: CMOS integrated circuits; Computer simulation; Data storage equipment; Logic gates; Mathematical models; Personal digital assistants; Synchronization; Clock gating; Hardware description language (HDL); Power dissipation; Register transfer level (RTL); Energy dissipation

Title: Parameterized SOC design for portable systems
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bhutoria, S., Department of Electrical Engineering, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287, United States; Chakrabarti, C., Department of Electrical Engineering, Arizona State University, Tempe, AZ 85287, United States
Abstract: Portable devices have ushered in the use of parameterizable SoC architectures that provide flexibility and applicability while remaining cost-effective. Platune provides a mechanism for designing such architectures by exploring a large configuration space to arrive at pareto-optimal configurations with respect to power. In this paper, we argue that the pareto-optimal configurations for portable devices have to be derived for battery performance and not for power or energy consumption. We illustrate through examples that the optimal configuration obtained by optimizing battery performance is quite different from those obtained by optimizing power or energy.

Authors: Patel K., Macii E., Poncino M.
Title: Energy-performance tradeoffs for the shared memory in multi-processor systems-on-chip
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Politecnico di Torino, Dipartimento di Automatica, Torino, Italy; Università di Verona, Dipartimento di Informatica, Verona, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Patel, K., Politecnico di Torino, Dipartimento di Automatica, Torino, Italy; Macii, E., Politecnico di Torino, Dipartimento di Automatica, Torino, Italy; Poncino, M., Università di Verona, Dipartimento di Informatica, Verona, Italy
Abstract: Accesses to the shared memory in multi-processor systems-on-chip represent a significant performance bottleneck and source of energy consumption, because of the synchronization of the accesses as well as of their relative "distance" from the processors. While multi-port memories are usually employed to solve performance issues, no standard solution exists for energy issues. In this work, we propose an architecture for the shared memory that is based on application-speficic partitioning, which offers various energy-performance tradeoffs. The shared address space of the application is split into two, non-overlapping subsets which are mapped onto two distinct memory blocks. By properly tuning the point at which the address space is split, various solutions can be achieved with different levels of energy/performance tradeoffs. Experiments on a set of parallel benchmarks show that it is possible to achieve solutions with energy-delay product savings ranging from 40 to 62% (50% on average) with respect to a conventional, non-partitioned architecture.
Index Keywords: Approximation theory; Bandwidth; Data acquisition; Data storage equipment; Data structures; Energy utilization; Problem solving; Simulators; Memory blocks; Monolithic Memory; Private memory (PM); Shared memory; Multiprocessing systems

Title: Quick takes: VAALCO Energy Inc...
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: Vaalco Energy Inc has completed the ET-5H development well in Etame field off Gabon. About 6400 bpd of oil flowed on test through a 48/64-in. choke to the floating production, storage, and offloading facility. The company plans to increase the production level until total field production exceeds 21,000 bpd of oil.

Title: Quick takes: A week-long fire at Duke Energy Gas Transmission's...
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: A week-long fire at Duke Energy Gas Transmission's Moss Bluff natural gas storage cavern No. 1 in Liberty County, TX, burned itself out 8/25/2004. Duke began installation of a new valve assembly the following afternoon. The fire consumed an estimated 6 bcf of gas.

Title: A high throughput limited search trellis decoder for convolutional code decoding
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Department, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, T., Electrical Engineering Department, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, NY, United States
Abstract: Due to the lack of operational parallelism and structured data storage/retrieval, limited search trellis decoding algorithms have been traditionally ruled out for applications demanding high throughput convolutional code decoding. Among various limited search algorithms, the T-algorithm performs breadth-first limited search and has good potential for parallel decoding. In this paper, we propose two techniques at the algorithm and VLSI architecture levels for the T-algorithm to improve the decoding parallelism and tackle the data storage/retrieval problem, which enables the high throughput path-parallel T-algorithm decoder VLSI implementation. This work provides a vehicle for exploiting the merits of the T-algorithm, i.e., low computational complexity that is adaptive to the channel distortion, in high throughput applications.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computational complexity; Data storage equipment; Decoding; Energy utilization; Nonbibliographic retrieval systems; Problem solving; Branch metric computation; Path extension; Path purge; Viterbi algorithm (VA); VLSI circuits

Title: Hilbert space techniques for reactive power compensation with limited current bandwidth
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Northeastern University, ECE Department, Boston, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lev-Ari, H., Northeastern University, ECE Department, Boston, United States; Stanković, A.M., Northeastern University, ECE Department, Boston, United States
Abstract: The paper formulates and solves an optimization problem related to reactive power compensation with limited current bandwidth. The current bandwidth limitation is essential for all practical compensators that are built around switching power converters. We use the Hilbert space terminology of [1] to formulate and solve the corresponding constrained optimization problem. It turns out that our solution generalizes some results from the literature. Under operating conditions that are prevalent in practice, our solution leads to a decomposition of reactive power into three components - a component that can be compensated without energy storage, a component that can be compensated when energy storage is available, and a component that can not be compensated at all because of the limited bandwidth of the compensator.
Author Keywords: Band-limited compensator; Hilbert space optimization; Reactive power compensation
Index Keywords: Active filters; Electric energy storage; Electric inverters; Electric loads; Harmonic analysis; Optimization; Band-limited compensators; Hilbert space optimization; Reactive power compensation; Electric power systems

Authors: Abbasian A., Hatami S., Afzali-Kusha A., Nourani M., Lucas C.
Title: Event-driven dynamic power management based on wavelet forecasting theory
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Dept., University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Texas, Dallas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Abbasian, A., Electrical Engineering Dept., University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran; Hatami, S., Electrical Engineering Dept., University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran; Afzali-Kusha, A., Electrical Engineering Dept., University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran; Nourani, M., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Texas, Dallas, United States; Lucas, C., Electrical Engineering Dept., University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran
Abstract: The goal of dynamic power management is to reduce power dissipation in system level by putting system components into different states. This paper proposes a wavelet based approach that models the device behavior precisely. In spite of conventional stochastic models, this method eliminates some impractical assumptions which were shortcoming for previous methods. The stationary behavior of devices and the use of a memoryless distribution for device modeling are some of the aforementioned assumptions that have been relaxed in our model. Additionally, wavelet model can capture the local information accurately. Furthermore this algorithm is adaptive. This method has two additional benefits; firstly according to the device application a suitable wavelet basis can be used. Secondly, it has a sparse time-scale representation indicating that only a few coefficients in their wavelet representation have to be estimated. The simulation results show 95% accuracy in desktop Hard Disk Drive (HDD) states prediction and power saving by a factor of 2.
Index Keywords: Dynamic power management (DPM); Hard disk drives (HDD); Power management (PM); Wavelet forecasting; Algorithms; Computational methods; Computer simulation; Energy dissipation; Energy utilization; Hard disk storage; Energy management

Authors: Lev-Ari H., Stanković A.M., Xu K., Perišić M.M.
Title: Hilbert space techniques for evaluating trade-offs in reactive power compensation
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Northeastern University, Department of Electrical Engineering, Boston, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lev-Ari, H., Northeastern University, Department of Electrical Engineering, Boston, United States; Stanković, A.M., Northeastern University, Department of Electrical Engineering, Boston, United States; Xu, K., Northeastern University, Department of Electrical Engineering, Boston, United States; Perišić, M.M., Northeastern University, Department of Electrical Engineering, Boston, United States
Abstract: The paper describes a set of Hilbert space-based analysis tools for reactive power compensation, and uses them to quantify the tradeoff between line losses and compensator cost. Our method is illustrated on two polyphase examples, one involving a resistive circuit, and the other involving a nonlinear circuit (diode bridge rectifier) which is often encountered in industrial practice. The paper also addresses the issue of an efficient (order-recursive) computational procedure for the considered class of compensators.
Author Keywords: Active filters; Energy storage; Hilbert space optimization; Reactive power compensation; Voltage sourced inverters
Index Keywords: Active filters; Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electric losses; Electric potential; Electric power distribution; Hilbert space optimization; Power harmonic matching (PHM); Reactive power compensation; Voltage sourced inverters; Reactive power

Title: Air products for three California hydrogen stations
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: Air Products' hydrogen fueling technologies have been chosen for three demonstration projects by the Califronia South Coast Air Quality Management District (AQMD) for fueling stations to be placed in Burbank, Riverside, and Santa Ana in 2005. Air Products will collaborate with Proton Energy Systems on two of the stations. In Burbank and Riverside, the Series 200™ integrated vehicle fueling system will provide storage and dispensing of hydrogen to the vehicle. Hydrogen will be provided to the fueling system from Proton's Hogen® 200 proton-exchange membrane electrolyzers. At Santa Ana, AQMD will use Air Products' HF-150 mobile hydrogen fueler.

Title: News: 2005 Honda FCX gains EPA, CARB certification
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: Honda's second-generation fuel cell vehicle, the 2005 Honda FCX incorporating the company's improved cold-start fuel cell stack has been certified by both the EPA and CARB for commercial use. The new hydrogen-powered FCX achieves a nearly 20% improvement in its EPA fuel economy rating and range and a 33% gain in peak power (80 vs. 60 kwe) on the 2004 model. The 2005 FCX achieved an EPA city/highway fuel efficiency rating of 62/51 mi/kg of fuel (mpkg) or 57 mpkg combined, and an EPA-rated driving range of 190 mi, compared to an EPA rating of 51/46 mpkg, and a range of 160 mi for the 2004 model. In terms of energy efficiency, 1 mpkg of hydrogen is almost equivalent to 1 mi/gal of gasoline. The vehicle has storage capacity for 156.6 L of compressed hydrogen at 350 bar.

Title: Rays of hope
Source title: HAC
Abstract: The possibility of using of photovoltaic process in converting sunlight energy into electricity is discussed. There are two primary applications for PV power systems such as off-grid and on-grid. The PV systems typically feed electricity back into utility grid when the on-site generation exceeds the building loads. Solar (PV) panels charge up batteries that store the energy, which is used to power fridges, lights, and other electrical devices.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Cost effectiveness; Electric substations; Electricity; Energy storage; Environmental impact; Gas emissions; Power generation; Project management; Remote sensing; Renewable energy resources; Building integrated PV (BIPV); Medium sized enterprises (SME); Network infrastructures; PV systems; Photovoltaic cells

Title: Fuel factors
Source title: Engineered Systems
Affiliations: Energywiz, Inc., New York, United States; New York Energy Buyers Forum
Authors with affiliations: Audin, L., Energywiz, Inc., New York, United States, New York Energy Buyers Forum
Abstract: Some of significant factors to understand energy usage by using regression analysis, are discussed. Many facilities consumes gas in heating line distribution losses, steam leaks, boiler pilot lights, and domestic hot water. Hospitals uses fuels to generate steam for sterilizers, prepare food in the cafeteria, and to keep a therapeutic swimming pool warm. A relationship between monthly fuel usage and heating degree-days (HDD) can be established by using Microsoft Excel by creating table of monthly data and two columns having fuel consumption and HDD data. Excel can draws a best-fit trendline for data points and calculate a linear mathematical formula. A formula can be inserted into Excel chart by clicking on he 'Chart' command and 'Add Trendline'. The formula can be used to calculate the CCF consumed for each HDD and value of CCF/month.
Index Keywords: Data points; Distribution losses; Domestic hot water; Energy usage; Heating degree-days; Mathematical formulas; Microsoft excel; Steam leaks; Canning; Directional drilling; Food preservation; Food processing; Fuels; Hard disk storage; Heating; Helium; Regression analysis; Spreadsheets; Water; Leakage (fluid)

Title: Novel solution for hydrogen storage
Source title: Chemistry World
Authors with affiliations: Nathan, S.
Abstract: The use of titanium as a solution for hydrogen storage in fuel cell technology is discussed. The use of sodium alantae can reversibly absorb hydrogen molecules in to its surface but only upto five percent hydrogen by weight. The doping of titanium on alanate makes the absorption and release of hydrogen more efficient. Titanium resides on the surface of sodium alanate as titanium aluminum compound rather than entering the bulk material.
Index Keywords: Absorption; Catalysts; Crystal lattices; Doping (additives); Fuel cells; Fuel storage; Hydrogen fuels; Sodium compounds; Titanium; Energy storage materials; Fuel cell technology; Hydrogen storage; Solid lattices; Hydrogen

Title: A strategic approach to high-reliability pipeline power applications
Source title: Pipeline and Gas Journal
Affiliations: Northern Power Systems, Waitsfield, VT, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brennan, M.F., Northern Power Systems, Waitsfield, VT, United States
Abstract: The strategic approach to high-reliability pipeline power applications is discussed. The budget allocation is given to pipeline power requirements after the Front End Engineering Design (FEED) stage. To meet the real-world concerns about the vulnerability of the world's oil and gas pipelines, many companies are taking pre-emptive steps to ensure the equipment has the critical load support, continuous power for running under all circumstances. To make decisions, oil and gas professionals and the suppliers need a better understanding of high-quality, ultra-reliable power. The process involves four main steps: assessing power requirements, assessing the site environment and resources, understanding all the pieces and putting them together.
Index Keywords: Economic loss; Front end engineering design (FEED); Pipeline power; Ultra-reliable power; Actuators; Electric rectifiers; Energy storage; Environmental impact; Photovoltaic effects; Project management; Remote sensing; Risk assessment; SCADA systems; Pipeline processing systems

Title: Portfolio analysis software helps guide utility planning
Source title: Pipeline and Gas Journal
Affiliations: NiSource, Inc., Merrillville, IN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Catron, H.A., NiSource, Inc., Merrillville, IN, United States; Monnig, T.M., NiSource, Inc., Merrillville, IN, United States
Abstract: The development of a portfolio analysis software for Columbia Gas of Kentucky (CKY), a local distribution company (LDC) subsidiary of NiSource, to guide utility planning, is discussed. The portfolio analysis was performed with the aid of the SENDOUT® Gas planning system from New Energy Associates. The CKY SENDOUT model is made up of three demand areas, three pipelines and one storage areas. The demand costs of the pipelines and storage options were a major driver in the results of the portfolio study. The study showed the demand costs needed to be educed significantly before the storage capacity become attractive.
Index Keywords: Columbia Gas of Kentucky (CO); Local distribution company (LDC); Storage services; Tennessee Gas Pipelines (TGP); Computer software; Cost accounting; Gas fuel storage; Gas pipelines; Gas supply; Mathematical models; Optimization; Risk assessment; Gas industry

Title: A global energy strategy begins with control
Source title: Control (Chicago, Ill)
Authors with affiliations: Lipták, B.
Abstract: The need for a gradual transition towards a clean and inexhaustible energy source is discussed. Building gigantic floating islands covered with solar-collectors and positioning them around the Equator is a solution. The solar energy can be used to make hydrogen from sea water and condense it into a liquid-slurry. Cryogenic tankers could be designed to distribute hydrogen-slurry to fuel/gas stations around the globe.
Index Keywords: Automation; Chimneys; Control systems; Cryogenics; Energy utilization; Filling stations; Fuel cells; Fuel storage; Gas generators; Gasoline; Hydrogen; Modernization; Petroleum refineries; Slurries; Thermal insulation; Energy road map; Hydrogen filling stations; Inexhaustible energy; Weatherproof; Process control

Title: M & A activity may be harbinger of things to come for LDCs
Source title: Pipeline and Gas Journal
Affiliations: JofreeEnergy
Authors with affiliations: Freedenthal, C., JofreeEnergy
Abstract: Local distribution companies (LDC), which are the last link in the chain bringing natural gas from the wellhead to the burnertip for the residential, commercial and the electric generating and industrial markets, are discussed. Natural gas supplies nearly 25% of all the energy used in the U.S. with an estimated total market of 66.4 million customers. LDC are either locally owned, municipal companies or publicly owned corporations that might own one or several LDC around the nation. Atmos and AGL are two of the nation's largest local utility companies and their planned mergers indicate their desire for growth and increased operations.
Index Keywords: Approximation theory; Electric generators; Gas fuel storage; Industrial management; Mergers and acquisitions; Pipelines; Signal theory; Brand name; Customer base; Industrial markets; Local distribution companies (LDC); Liquefied natural gas

Title: On the hydrogen on-board storage in graphite nanomaterials
Source title: ACS Division of Fuel Chemistry, Preprints
Affiliations: Clean Energy Research Institute, College of Engineering, University of Miami, Coral Gables, FL 33124, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nechaev, Y.S., Clean Energy Research Institute, College of Engineering, University of Miami, Coral Gables, FL 33124, United States, ; Veziroglu, T.N., Clean Energy Research Institute, College of Engineering, University of Miami, Coral Gables, FL 33124, United States
Abstract: There is the anomalous scattering and nonreproducibility of the known experimental data on the hydrogen gravimetric capability in carbon nanofibers and nanotubes, while there is a normal scattering for metallic hydrides. The main reasons of such a large difference in the results are related with a larger spectrum of the structure and sorption process peculiarities for the carbon nanomaterials, depending on regimes of their synthesis, pre-treatment and hydrogenation, etc. A discussion covers some new significant results on diffusion, sorption, and storage of hydrogen in graphites and novel carbon nanomaterials; fundamental and technological developments on using novel carbon nanomaterials in the field of hydrogen energy for vehicles; and optimizing and understanding the interaction between hydrogen and carbon materials.

Title: Chemical systems for hydrogen storage
Source title: ACS Division of Fuel Chemistry, Preprints
Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, Livermore, CA 94551, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thomas, G.J., Sandia National Laboratories, Livermore, CA 94551, United States
Abstract: Hydrogen storage systems for use in hydrogen-fueled vehicles will require high energy density and high specific energy to achieve comparable performance to conventional gasoline-fueled vehicles. A discussion on chemistry-based hydrogen storage methods, i.e., hydrogen storage materials, covers inherent limitations of hydrogen storage concepts; some of the specific chemical systems; and material performance relative to that required in storage applications.

Authors: Ashtiani A., Robinson F., Weber B.
Title: Think tanks
Source title: Hydrocarbon Engineering
Affiliations: CB and I, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ashtiani, A., CB and I, United States; Robinson, F., CB and I, United States; Weber, B., CB and I, United States
Abstract: The design features of an oil refinery installed in Papua New Guinea (PNG), which is being used as a role-model for large engineering procurement and construction projects in refinery tanking, is discussed. The 28 storage tanks are designed to store products such as crude oil, jet fuel and diesel, taking into account factors like product condition, vapor pressure and viscosity to maximize safety and minimize environmental hazards. Papua New Guinea being remotely located, logistical challenges are tackled by dividing the task into three phases. CB&I's Dubai office is involved in procurement of steel shipment to build tanks while other material purchases are divided between Jakarta and Perth offices.
Index Keywords: Energy utilization; Industrial economics; Oil fields; Personnel training; Petroleum engineering; Petroleum refineries; Project management; Viscosity; Construction projects; Oil reserves; Papua New Guinea; Refinery tanking; Storage tanks; Oil tanks

Title: Achieving separations and distributed production technical targets of the president's hydrogen fuel initiative
Source title: ACS Division of Fuel Chemistry, Preprints
Affiliations: Hyd., Fuel Cells,/Infra. Tech. Prog., Off. Ener. Efficiency/Renew. Ener., U.S Department of Energy, EE-2H, 1000 Independence Avenue, SW, Washington, D.C. 20585, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chalk, S., Hyd., Fuel Cells,/Infra. Tech. Prog., Off. Ener. Efficiency/Renew. Ener., U.S Department of Energy, EE-2H, 1000 Independence Avenue, SW, Washington, D.C. 20585, United States; Anderson, A., Hyd., Fuel Cells,/Infra. Tech. Prog., Off. Ener. Efficiency/Renew. Ener., U.S Department of Energy, EE-2H, 1000 Independence Avenue, SW, Washington, D.C. 20585, United States
Abstract: A discussion on the US President's hydrogen fuel initiative, which envisions a hydrogen economy that could have fundamental and dramatic benefits regarding energy security and the environment, covers DOE's new hydrogen separations and purification research, e.g., small-scale distributed reforming production of hydrogen from natural gas and/or liquid fuels at refueling stations, emphasizing on fuels produced from renewable biomass resources (ethanol, methanol, biomass pyrolysis oils, etc.); and the DOE's new advanced electrolysis systems research, including electrolyzer system design, renewable electric system interface, and grid interface with the focus on lowering capital costs and improving efficiency of system components including storage, power electronics, and other components.

Title: Chemical systems for hydrogen storage
Source title: ACS Division of Fuel Chemistry, Preprints
Affiliations: Sandia National Laboratories, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thomas, G.J., Sandia National Laboratories, United States
Abstract: Hydrogen storage systems for use in hydrogen-fueled vehicles will require high energy density and high specific energy to achieve comparable performance to conventional gasoline-fueled vehicles. This issue remains as one of the critical barriers to the development of fuel cell powered vehicles. A discussion covers chemistry-based hydrogen storage methods, i.e., hydrogen storage materials; storage materials, i.e., materials having reversible or nonreversible hydrogen behavior; issues which must be answered with adsorbed systems, e.g., hydrogen capacity, volumetric density, and hydrogen binding energies; alternative materials; limitations of hydrogen storage concepts; and specific chemical systems.

Title: Overview of hydrogen production
Source title: ACS Division of Fuel Chemistry, Preprints
Affiliations: National Renewable Energy Laboratory, 1617 Cole Blvd, Golden, CO 80401, United States
Authors with affiliations: Elam, C.C., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, 1617 Cole Blvd, Golden, CO 80401, United States; Evans, R.J., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, 1617 Cole Blvd, Golden, CO 80401, United States
Abstract: Hydrogen, like electricity, can be produced from many sources, including fossil fuels, renewable resources, and nuclear energy. The transition to a hydrogen economy will progress through the development and commercialization of a range of advanced technologies to produce, store, and use hydrogen. There are technical and economic hurdles to the implementation of hydrogen energy systems. The cost of hydrogen production from renewable resources (with low or no CO2 emissions) is not currently competitive with that of production from fossil feedstocks (with high CO2 emissions). Hydrogen can provide storage options for intermittent renewable technologies such as solar and wind. It can transform base-load technologies such as nuclear, geothermal, biomass, and hydro into load-following systems.

Authors: Bouza A., Petrovic J., Read C., Satyapal S., Milliken J.A.
Title: The national hydrogen storage project
Source title: ACS Division of Fuel Chemistry, Preprints
Affiliations: U.S. Department of Energy, Off. Hyd., Fuel Cells/Infra. Tech., 1000 Independence Ave. SW, Washington DC 20585, United States; Los Alamos National Laboratory, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bouza, A., U.S. Department of Energy, Off. Hyd., Fuel Cells/Infra. Tech., 1000 Independence Ave. SW, Washington DC 20585, United States; Petrovic, J., U.S. Department of Energy, Off. Hyd., Fuel Cells/Infra. Tech., 1000 Independence Ave. SW, Washington DC 20585, United States, Los Alamos National Laboratory, United States; Read, C., U.S. Department of Energy, Off. Hyd., Fuel Cells/Infra. Tech., 1000 Independence Ave. SW, Washington DC 20585, United States; Satyapal, S., U.S. Department of Energy, Off. Hyd., Fuel Cells/Infra. Tech., 1000 Independence Ave. SW, Washington DC 20585, United States; Milliken, J.A., U.S. Department of Energy, Off. Hyd., Fuel Cells/Infra. Tech., 1000 Independence Ave. SW, Washington DC 20585, United States
Abstract: The transition to a hydrogen economy with fuel cell-powered vehicles over the next few decades is crucial to energy security and environmental quality in the United States and around the world. This energy vision was put forward by President Bush in his January 2003 State of the Union address. A critical enabling technology for the development of hydrogen fuel cell-powered vehicles is the capability to have sufficient on-board hydrogen storage to enable > 300-mi driving range under the weight, volume, and cost constraints posed by customer expectations. Current vehicular hydrogen storage systems cannot meet this ultimate requirement. New materials and approaches are needed and that is why the DOE is proceeding with the implementation of a National Hydrogen Storage Project. A discussion covers the requirements for on-board hydrogen storage; current status of on-board hydrogen storage; and the National Hydrogen Storage Project.

Title: Meeting the fuels and energy policy challenge
Source title: ACS Division of Fuel Chemistry, Preprints
Affiliations: National Commission on Energy Policy, 1616 H Street, NW 6th Floor, Washington, DC 20006, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kodjak, D., National Commission on Energy Policy, 1616 H Street, NW 6th Floor, Washington, DC 20006, United States
Abstract: The attacks of September 11th, the California energy crisis, growing concern over global climate change, and the tremendous progress in new clean energy technologies all suggest a rapidly changing landscape of energy needs, vulnerabilities, and opportunities. The National Commission on Energy Policy intends to propose a series of near-term measures that are necessary to improve the nation's long-range energy position. These recommendations will be contained in the final report of the Commission scheduled for release in late 2004/early 2005. Issues under active consideration by the Commission, such as how to harness market forces towards multiple social ends; key energy technologies that deserve greater public and private investment; and how to ensure adequate future supplies of clean energy given current difficulties in siting new generating facilities, waste storage sites, pipelines, and transmission lines are presented.

Title: Hydrogen from biomass via pyrolysis: Relationships between yield of hydrogen and temperature
Source title: Energy Sources
Affiliations: Selçuk University, Department of Chemical Engineering, Campus-Konya, Turkey; Gazi University, Department of Chemical Engineering, Ankara, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Demirbaş, A., Selçuk University, Department of Chemical Engineering, Campus-Konya, Turkey; Arin, G., Gazi University, Department of Chemical Engineering, Ankara, Turkey
Abstract: Hydrogen is a sustainable, non-polluting source of energy that can be used in mobile and stationary applications. The use of hydrogen as an energy carrier or major fuel requires development in several industry segments including production, delivery, storage, conversion, and end-use. It is an obvious alternative to hydrocarbon fuels such as gasoline. Hydrogen can be produced through thermal, electrolytic, or photolytic processes applied to fossil fuels, biomass, or water. The yields of gaseous products from pyrolysis runs of the biomass samples increase with increasing pyrolysis temperature. The yield of hydrogen in gaseous products from the samples of hazelnut shell, cotton cocoon shell, tea factory waste, olive husk, beech wood and spruce wood increased from 34.0 to 54.8%, 22.1 to 41.0%, 28.9 to 47.8%, 36.0 to 50.6%, 31.5 to 48.3%, and 33.2 to 49.6%, respectively, while the final pyrolysis temperature increased from 650 to 1025 K. There is a relationship between the yield of hydrogen in a gaseous product from the biomass sample and pyrolysis temperature. The yield of hydrogen is a linear function of the pyrolysis temperature.
Author Keywords: Biomass; Pyrolysis; Temperature; Yield of hydrogen
Index Keywords: Biomass; Cotton; Fossil fuels; Gasoline; Hydrogen; Petrochemicals; Structure (composition); Temperature; Non-polluting source of energy; Thermolysis; Yield of hydrogen; Pyrolysis

Authors: Megahed O.A., Abdelmonem N.M., Nabil D.M.
Title: Thermal cracking of rapeseed oil as alternative fuel
Source title: Energy Sources
Affiliations: Fat and Oil Department, National Research Center, Cairo, Egypt; Chemical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Cairo University, Egypt; National Research Center, Fat and Oil Department, Tahrir St., Dakki, Cairo, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Megahed, O.A., Fat and Oil Department, National Research Center, Cairo, Egypt, National Research Center, Fat and Oil Department, Tahrir St., Dakki, Cairo, Egypt; Abdelmonem, N.M., Chemical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Cairo University, Egypt; Nabil, D.M., Chemical Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Cairo University, Egypt
Abstract: Rapeseed oil was pyrolyzed in the presence of about 2% of calcium oxide up to a temperature of 450°C. A pyrolytic oil was produced that was narrow of diesel fuel. From the studies of ASTM distillation, the volumetric percentage of liquid in the same boiling range for diesel fuel was equal to 61% of the pyrolytic oil. The heating value of pyrolytic oil was 41.3 MJ/kg, which is equivalent to 93% of heating value of diesel fuel. The flash point was 80°C which is higher than diesel. This makes the pyrolytic product safer during handling and storage than diesel. In addition, thermally decomposed rapeseed oil was tested on a diesel engine and compared to diesel. The thermal efficiency (ηth) and brake specific fuel consumption were improved. The concentration of nitrogen oxides are less in the case of the produced fuel, this, in turn, reduced the formation of smog due to the presence of colored NOx. Moreover, the absence of sulfur in the pyrolytic oil is another advantage to avoid corrosion problems.
Author Keywords: Alternative fuel; Cracking; Rapeseed oil
Index Keywords: Combustion; Corrosion prevention; Crack initiation; Crankcases; Diesel engines; Distillation; Energy efficiency; Environmental impact; Pyrolysis; Synthetic fuels; Rapeseed oil; Thermal cracking; Thermal efficiency; Vegetable oils

Title: UKCS need for innovative solutions
Source title: Petroleum Review
Authors with affiliations: Crook, J.
Abstract: The features of the BP-operated Clair platform and the prospects of UK Continental Shelf (UKCS) project are discussed. UKCS have oil fields with deep reserviors, with downhole pressures of more than 10,000 psi combined with high temperatures and impurities. A joint venture between BP and Sontrach has announced that it plans to supply the Isle of Grain terminal with enough LNG, from the year 2005, to provide 500mn cf of natural gas to the UK market. The security of national gas supply will also be boosted up by construction of additional gas storage sites, that will supplement the Rough offshore storage facility with several LNG storage sites.
Index Keywords: Contracts; Gas supply; High temperature effects; International trade; Liquefied natural gas; Natural gas well drilling; Offshore oil fields; Pressure control; Project management; BP (CO); Sontrach (CO); Star Energy (CO); UK Continental Shelf (UKCS) (CO); Petroleum industry

Title: Focus: Energy policy: France: IEA offers praise and advises caution
Source title: Petroleum Economist
Abstract: France's centralized energy policy has won praise from the International Energy Agency for its past success in ensuring supply security, reasonable prices, and low greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. However, the compliments are accompanied by advice on how to proceed in today's competitive, internationalized energy context. The report, France - 2004 Review, commends the government's moves toward the liberalization of electricity and gas markets, but sees problems in the still-dominant position of incumbent electricity and gas monopolies, Electricité de France and Gaz de France (GdF). For gas, the report considers that there are potential problems about non-discriminatory third-party access to the pipeline network, especially in the south of the country. The transport system is not completely separated from the commercial side of the gas business and access to storage sites is limited. GdF, which operates 13 of the country's 15 sites with 83% of the total 11 billion cu m of capacity, provides access only on a negotiated case-by-case basis. France is committed under the EU burden-sharing agreement to return GHG emissions to their 1990 level by the Kyoto protocol's 2008-2012 target. However, emissions from the transport and residential sectors are rising, while there is little scope for reduction because of the country's large share of emissions-free power generation, mainly from nuclear.

Title: Rehden gas storage - Well provided for with the largest natural gas storage in Western Europe
Source title: Oil Gas European Magazine
Affiliations: Wintershall AG, Kassel, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Wölfer, W.; Leunig, St., Wintershall AG, Kassel, Germany
Abstract: At the Rehden reservoir WINGAS stores the annual gas consumption for about two million homes. This means that WINGAS plays a major part in securing supplies for Germany and Europe, In connection with operating the MIDAL/ STEGAL/WEDAL/RHG/YAGAL pipeline system (Middle Germany Pipeline Link / Saxony-Thuringia Pipeline Link/ West German Pipeline Link / Rehden-Hamburg Gas Pipeline/ Yamal Pipeline Link) WINGAS- a joint venture of Wintershall AG and OAO Gazprom - is also running the largest gas storage facility in western Europe at the Rehden gas field. This field is located 60 km south of Bremen and has been operated by Wintershall AG since 1954. The development of this storage facility was executed in four stages. Start-up of the first stage took place in August 1993. The fourth stage has been in operation since August 1999. The facility currently has a working gas capacity of 4.2 billion m3. The technical concept of the storage plant-including horizontal wells, centrifugal compressors and gas dehydration units - along with plant safety and environmental protection measures are illustrated in this article.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Compressors; Dehydration; Energy utilization; Environmental protection; Gas industry; Gas pipelines; Gas supply; Horizontal wells; Laws and legislation; Natural gas; Natural gas fields; Safety factor; BASF (CO); Gas demand; Gas reservoirs; Wintershall AG (CO); Underground gas storage

Title: Antiproton Physics at GSI
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: LNF, Via E. Fermi 40, Frascati, 00044, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Gianotti, P., LNF, Via E. Fermi 40, Frascati, 00044, Italy
Abstract: A new facility for hadronic physics has been recently funded by the German Government. It is part of a major upgrade of the GSI accelerator complex presently running in Darmstadt. An intense, high momentum resolution antiproton beam, with momenta between 1.5 and 15 GeV/c, will be available at the High Energy Storage Ring (HESR), and the experimental activity will be carried out using a general purpose detector (PANDA), that will be built surrounding an internal target station installed at one of the two straight sections of the storage ring. The main characteristics of the new facility, the scientific program, and the design strategy of the PANDA detector are here presented. © 2004 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Modelli A., Visconti A., Bez R.
Title: Advanced flash memory reliability
Source title: 2004 International Conference on Integrated Circuit Design and Technology, ICICDT
Affiliations: STMicroelectronics, via Olivetti 2, 20041 Agrate, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Modelli, A., STMicroelectronics, via Olivetti 2, 20041 Agrate, Italy; Visconti, A., STMicroelectronics, via Olivetti 2, 20041 Agrate, Italy; Bez, R., STMicroelectronics, via Olivetti 2, 20041 Agrate, Italy
Abstract: With reference to the mainstream technology, the most relevant failure mechanisms that affect reliability of Flash memory are reviewed, showing the primary role played by tunnel oxide defects. The degradation of device performance induced by program/erase cycling is discussed, specifically for what concern the leakage that affect a very small fraction of memory cells after cycling. The dependence of the leakage on tunnel oxide thickness, number of cycles, and temperature is analyzed. The leakage current is explained by trap-assisted tunneling involving one, two or more traps, with decreasing occurrence probability. Finally, data are presented showing the robustness of scaled Flash memory to alpha particles and electromagnetic radiation.
Index Keywords: Dielectric materials; Electric potential; Electron tunneling; Energy transfer; Error correction; Field effect transistors; Leakage currents; Random access storage; Reliability; Statistical methods; Channel hot-electron (CHE); Floating gate (FG); Fowler-Nordheim (FN) tunneling; Trap-assisted tunneling (TAT); Flash memory

Authors: Lerav J.-L., Baggio J., Ferlet-Cavrois V., Flament O.
Title: Atmospheric neutron effects in advanced microelectronics, standards and applications
Source title: 2004 International Conference on Integrated Circuit Design and Technology, ICICDT
Affiliations: CEA-DIF, BP. 12, F-91680 Bruyeres-Le-Chatel, France
Authors with affiliations: Lerav, J.-L., CEA-DIF, BP. 12, F-91680 Bruyeres-Le-Chatel, France; Baggio, J., CEA-DIF, BP. 12, F-91680 Bruyeres-Le-Chatel, France; Ferlet-Cavrois, V., CEA-DIF, BP. 12, F-91680 Bruyeres-Le-Chatel, France; Flament, O., CEA-DIF, BP. 12, F-91680 Bruyeres-Le-Chatel, France
Abstract: Since the 80s it is known that Terrestrial Cosmic Rays, mainly reported as Atmospheric Neutrons, can penetrate the natural shielding of buildings, equipments and circuit package and induce Soft Errors in integrated circuits and Breakdown of power devices. The high-energy neutron fluxes of interest range between 10 particles/cm2/hour at sea level and 104 particles/cm 2/hour at typical airplanes flight altitude of 30000 feet, with modulation due to Solar Flares. In the 90s the phenomenon has pervaded as a consequence of the roadmap of electronic devices, especially downscaling of design rules, increase of signal bandwidth and increase of the size of DRAM and SRAM memory, standalone or embedded on processors and System-on-Chips. Failure-In-Time and Soft Error Rate became unacceptable. Test Standards and design solutions have been proposed to maintain reliability of commercial products and improve those used in special such as avionic computers. The paper describes the Atmospheric Neutron flux, the effects in the main classes of devices and specific cases such as neutron-induced single event upset observed in CMOS vs. CMOS/SOI and some mitigation issues. A model called CCPM (Critical Cross-Point Model) is proposed to provide critical graphs of technology node sensitivity along the scaling trend of CMOS.
Index Keywords: Atmospherics; Avionics; CMOS integrated circuits; Dynamic random access storage; Electric charge; Error analysis; Graph theory; Neutrons; Solar energy; Standards; Static random access storage; Charge collection; Electronic systems; Neutron effects; Neutron fluxes; Microelectronics

Title: Educating the North American public on the safety and security of LNG facilities
Source title: 2004 AIChE Spring National Meeting, Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Inst. for Energy, Law and Enterprise, University of Houston, United States
Authors with affiliations: Delano, F., Inst. for Energy, Law and Enterprise, University of Houston, United States; Foss, M.M., Inst. for Energy, Law and Enterprise, University of Houston, United States
Abstract: The technologies available to address the safety and security concerns regarding liquefied natural gas (LNG) import facilities in North America are discussed. The key LNG safety and security concerns include the possibility of a terrorist attack on LNG facilities, the costs of LNG security, and the decreased residential property values. The potential hazards that are associated with the LNG include cryogenic liquid, vapor clouds, explosion, terrorism, earthquakes, and maritime incidents. The effect of flammable vapor and thermal radiation hazards created by unconfined LNG spill on water from an LNG cargo release is also discussed. The specific safety and security features embedded in the LNG import terminals and LNG ships are also discussed.
Index Keywords: Energy security; Industrialization; Natural gas demand; Terrorism; Accident prevention; Codes (standards); Earthquakes; Environmental protection; Explosions; Feedstocks; Gas fuel storage; Hazardous materials spills; International trade; Liquefaction; Liquefied natural gas; Petrochemical plants; Petroleum industry; Regulatory compliance; Risk assessment; Gas industry

Authors: Kopasz J.P., Applegate D., Miller L., Liao H.K., Ahmed S.
Title: Unravelling the maze: Building an undustanding of diesel reforming through the use of simplified systems
Source title: 2004 AIChE Spring National Meeting, Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 South Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL 60439, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kopasz, J.P., Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 South Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL 60439, United States; Applegate, D., Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 South Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL 60439, United States; Miller, L., Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 South Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL 60439, United States; Liao, H.K., Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 South Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL 60439, United States; Ahmed, S., Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 South Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL 60439, United States
Abstract: Diesel and logistics fuels offer high energy storage in very convenient transportable forms. However, converting these fuels to hydrogen for use in a fuel cell has proven a difficult task. The task is made more difficult by the complex nature of the fuels, which makes following the chemistry close to impossible. By utilizing simplified mixtures, we are developing an understanding of diesel reforming and how factors such as H 2O:C and O 2:C ratios, temperature, and fuel composition affect the reactions. Intermediates in the oxidation and coke-forming reactions have been identified which allow us to follow the desired reactions as well as undesirable side reactions. Using the information from the simplified systems, we are then able to build up an understanding of the more complex real-world system.
Author Keywords: Autothermal reforming; Diesel; Dodecane
Index Keywords: Autothermal reforming; Coke-forming reactions; Diesel reforming; Dodecane; Coke; Energy storage; Fuel cells; Hydrogen; Oxidation; Reaction kinetics; Thermal effects; Diesel fuels

Authors: Streitman F., Ward M., Sweeney D., Heinerikson A., Deuth K.
Title: Meeting the information requirements of NESHAPs at Ash Grove Cement's Chanute plant
Source title: Conference Record - IEEE Cement Industry Technical Conference
Affiliations: Ash Grove Cement, United States; Trinity Consultants, United States
Authors with affiliations: Streitman, F., Ash Grove Cement, United States; Ward, M., Ash Grove Cement, United States; Sweeney, D., Ash Grove Cement, United States; Heinerikson, A., Trinity Consultants, United States; Deuth, K., Trinity Consultants, United States
Abstract: Ash Grove Cement Company's (Ash Grove's) Chanute, KS facility manufactures portland cement and recovers thermal energy from solid and liquid hazardous waste derived fuel. As a result, the facility is subject to six different National Emission Standards for Hazardous Air Pollutants (NESHAPs). These NESHAPs regulate air pollutant emissions from nearly all equipment at the facility including valves, flanges, storage tanks, storage bins, conveying systems, mills, kilns, etc. The facility is required to demonstrate continual compliance with these requirements through extensive recordkeeping, monitoring and reporting that is often unique to each individual piece of equipment and that cannot efficiently be achieved through historically used methods of notebook and pencil. Consequently, the facility was forced to develop an overall program for ensuring that all information would be generated, collected, processed, stored, and, if necessary, be made available for reporting. An overriding goal of the program development was to utilize existing systems whenever possible and practical. Consequently, all existing data collection and management systems in place at the facility were reviewed, including plant maintenance systems, plant operating systems, control systems, accounting systems, etc. to determine if the systems already possessed required information, or if they could be utilized to collect the information. Where gaps in information collection were identified, systems were modified or developed such that all information necessary could be collected and processed in an efficient manner. This paper will review the various information requirements of these regulations with a focus on how existing plant systems were utilized to collect and process the information required by these NESHAPs.
Index Keywords: Hazardous waste combustion; Interrelationships; Plant operating systems; Thermal energy; Air pollution control; Combustors; Control system analysis; Industrial emissions; Information analysis; Portland cement; Process control; Cement plants

Authors: Zhou S., Wood A., Boyapati K., Hawley M.C., Lee A., Kempel L.C.
Title: Epoxy/organoclay nanocomposites synthesized with thermal and microwave methods
Source title: Global Plastics Environmental Conference 2004 - Plastics: Helping Grow a Greener Environment, GPEC 2004
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhou, S., Department of Chemical Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824, United States; Wood, A., Department of Chemical Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824, United States; Boyapati, K., Department of Chemical Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824, United States; Hawley, M.C., Department of Chemical Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824, United States; Lee, A., Department of Chemical Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824, United States; Kempel, L.C., Department of Electrical Engineering, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824, United States
Abstract: Two epoxy/organoclay nanocomposites were synthesized in-situ with both thermal and microwave heating methods. The epoxy materials are diglycidyl ether of bisphenol A (DGEBA)/ m-phenylenediamine (mPDA) and DGEBA/ diethyltoluenediamine (Epi-cure W). Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) results revealed the coexistence of intercalated and exfoliated clay layers in both epoxy systems. In in-situ synthesis of nanocomposites, the clay interlayer distance increases with the progress of intragallery (i.e. interlayer) reaction, and suppressed by the extragallery reaction. Higher degree of exfoliation could be obtained for systems with higher diffusion rate into the clay interlayer. Microwaves improved the exfoliation for both epoxy nanocomposites, possibly because the direct absorption of microwave energy by the reactive molecules enhanced their diffusion into the clay interlayer. When mPDA was used as the cure agent, microwave cured nanocomposites had similar Tg and lower storage modulus compared with thermally cured nanocomposites. When Epi-cure W was used as the cure agent, microwave cured nanocomposites had higher Tg and similar storage modulus compared with thermally cured nanocomposites.
Index Keywords: Epoxy materials; Interlayers; Microwave energy; Organoclay; Amines; Clay; Diffusion; Dynamic mechanical analysis; Ethers; Glass transition; Heating; Microwaves; Phenols; Scanning electron microscopy; Synthesis (chemical); Transmission electron microscopy; X ray diffraction analysis; Nanostructured materials

Abstract: A processor core, originally designed in a 0.5μm Al process, is redesigned for a 0.13μm Cu process to create a dual-core processor with 1MB integrated L2 cache, offering an efficient performance to power ratio for compute-dense sever applications. Circuit design challenges, including negative bias temperature instability (NBTI), leakage, coupling noise and intra die process variation are discussed.

Source title: 5Th IEEE International Vacuum Electronics Conference, IVEC 2004
Affiliations: Diversified Technologies, Inc., 35 Wiggins Ave., Bedford, MA 01730, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kempkes, M.A., Diversified Technologies, Inc., 35 Wiggins Ave., Bedford, MA 01730, United States; Casey, J.A., Diversified Technologies, Inc., 35 Wiggins Ave., Bedford, MA 01730, United States; Roth, I.S., Diversified Technologies, Inc., 35 Wiggins Ave., Bedford, MA 01730, United States; Hawkey, T.J., Diversified Technologies, Inc., 35 Wiggins Ave., Bedford, MA 01730, United States; Gaudreau, M.P.J., Diversified Technologies, Inc., 35 Wiggins Ave., Bedford, MA 01730, United States
Abstract: The multiple applications of series solid-state switches to replace crowbars in a wide range of VED systems were presented. The solid-state switch provides a fast opening capability, which does not short the high voltage system, and provides much faster fault handling, and significantly lower deposited energy in the VED than conventional crowbar systems, improving VED reliability and lifetime. These switches also provide a nearly instantaneous return to operation for the VED, which improved VED performance in time critical applications, such as radar systems and industrial processes, where loss of RF output can have highly detrimental effects. An opening switch/crowbar system installed at Argonne National Laboratory was also showed.

Title: Progress on a gridded electron gun for a sheet beam klystron
Source title: 5Th IEEE International Vacuum Electronics Conference, IVEC 2004
Affiliations: Calabazas Creek Research, Inc., Saratoga, CA 95070-3753, United States
Authors with affiliations: Read, M.E., Calabazas Creek Research, Inc., Saratoga, CA 95070-3753, United States; Miram, G., Calabazas Creek Research, Inc., Saratoga, CA 95070-3753, United States; Jabotinski, V., Calabazas Creek Research, Inc., Saratoga, CA 95070-3753, United States; Ives, R.L., Calabazas Creek Research, Inc., Saratoga, CA 95070-3753, United States
Abstract: The development of a rectangular, gridded, thermionic electron gun for a sheet beam klystron was discussed. The thickness was constrained as it would in a normal, cylindrical symmetric klystron with a Pierce gun. The maximum electric field in oil and vacuum were 35 and 50 kV/cm, respectively. It was observed that as RF power is pushed to higher levels, space charge forces in the electron beam limit the amount of current that can be transmitted at a given voltage.

Title: Three-phase resonant DC converter for TWTs
Source title: 5Th IEEE International Vacuum Electronics Conference, IVEC 2004
Affiliations: Colorado Power Electronics, Inc., 200 Commerce Drive, Fort Collins, CO 80524, United States
Authors with affiliations: Drummond, G., Colorado Power Electronics, Inc., 200 Commerce Drive, Fort Collins, CO 80524, United States
Abstract: The three-phase resonant DC converter for travelling wave tubes (TWT) was discussed. The three-phase resonant converter transforms power smoothly and continuously so there is no need for extra filtering and stored energy. It was shown that the three-phase resonant converter topology has the lowest stored energy when compared to any unknown DC power converter topology. An additional advantage to the three-phase converter was its low input ripple, which behaves in the same manner as the output ripple, yielding unfiltered ripple current levels of 4.2% RMS. The three-phase resonant conversion is now the power converter of choice in the thin film plasma industry, where low stored energy is required.

Source title: Global Plastics Environmental Conference 2004 - Plastics: Helping Grow a Greener Environment, GPEC 2004
Affiliations: EREMA, France
Authors with affiliations: Horroks, M., EREMA, France
Abstract: EREMA designed their system to solve some of the problems related to conventional recycling systems. The concept behind the EREMA system is that material is fed directly via a conveyor into a large drum containing cutting knives. The majority of the energy used in cutting and heating created through friction is then used in the extrusion process. Conventional recycling systems are based on pre-cutting of recyclate, often with intermediate storage, followed by stuffing and cramming systems feeding into a standard extruder.
