Title: News in brief: LNG contract
Source title: European Chemical News
Abstract: Sakhalin Energy investment Co has awarded CB&I, a $50 million lump-sum contract to build an additional 100,000 cu m/yr LNG storage tank at the natural gas liquification plant and export terminal under construction at Prigorodnoye on Aniva Bay, Sakhalin Island, Russia. The Sakhalin LNG facility, the largest in the world, will have two trains producing 4.8 million ton/yr each at startup in 2007.

Title: INGAA: Delaying US pipeline expansions will cost consumers billions
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Authors with affiliations: Lorenzetti, M.
Abstract: The US can ill afford persistent opposition to new pipelines and natural gas storage, according to a new report sponsored by the Interstate Natural Gas Association of America (INGAA) in July 2004. The study, authored by Energy and Environmental Analysis, predicts hefty energy bills for residential and industrial gas customers if construction delays spurred by local opposition or bureaucratic red tape continue plaguing industry efforts. The INGAA report finds that a 2-yr delay in natural gas infrastructure construction will cost US gas consumers > $200 billion (in constant $2003) by 2020. INGAA anticipates that annual US natural gas consumption will rise to 30 tcf by the end of the next decade from the current 23 tcf level if gas supplies are developed. By 2020, volumes from traditional basins are likely to decline by > 3 tcf/yr to 16.2 tcf/yr, representing only 61% of North American production. LNG will also play a key role in managing demand. By 2020, US LNG imports could be 6600 bcf/yr, nearly a 30-fold increase from 2002. INGAA offers regulators and industry four specific options to help avoid what could be costly delays to the needed expansion of the US natural gas delivery system, i.e., regulators at state and federal levels should consider actions that attract capital to pipeline and storage projects; the gas industry should work with state and local officials to close the information gap on energy infrastructure projects; federal and state regulators should conduct in-depth regional analyses that explicitly consider the impact on consumers and economic development of decisions to prohibit or delay infrastructure; and homeland security and safety concerns, particularly regarding LNG, should be met with a balanced and informed evaluation of risk.

Title: Quick takes: Sonora Pacific Mexico, a subsidiary of Houston-based DKRW Energy LLC,...
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: Sonora Pacific Mexico has purchased 1500 acres of property at Puerto Libertad on the Gulf of California for its planned 1.3 bcf/day LNG regasification and storage terminal and pipelines. El Paso Corp has agreed to install pipelines to deliver 500 million cu ft/day of gas from the terminal to Sonora and Sinaloa states and 800 million cu ft/day through Nogales to El Paso's existing system in the southwestern US.

Title: Divide and conquer: On-chip hardware adjuncts accelerate MCUs
Source title: Electronic Design
Authors with affiliations: Wong, W.
Abstract: The various aspects of augmenting on-chip hardware for accelerating the performance of MCUs are discussed. Enhanced on-chip peripherals or assymetric multiprocessing helps optimize performance and power consumption, avoiding the need to resort to higher power processors. To reduce power, many MCUs can power down the processor while letting peripherals continue to operate. Intelligent on-chip peripherals, always in common with MCUs, are multiplying and gaining complexity as they infiltrate more intensive applications, and connectivity requirements are pushing features like authentication and encryption into hardware.

Title: Technology: Three US cities to trial hydrogen fueling projects
Source title: European Chemical News
Abstract: Air Products' hydrogen fueling technologies has been chosen by the California South Coast Air Quality Management District for three demonstration fueling projects. Hydrogen fueling stations will be opened in three cities across the US state during 2005. Air Products will collaborate with Proton Energy Systems on two of the fueling stations. Air Products' proprietary technology is designed to meet early vehicle fleet fueling requirements and provide flexibility in using hydrogen generated at the site, or delivered hydrogen integrated with storage and vehicle dispensing capabilities.

Authors: Kim I.-S., Woo S.-G., Cho H.-K., Han W.-S., Moon J.-T.
Title: Way of LEEPL technology to success in memory device application
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Process Development Team, Semiconductor R and D Center, SAMSUNG Electronics Co. Ltd., San#24, Nongseo-Ri, Giheung-Eup, Yongin-Shi, Gyunggi-Do, 449-711, South Korea

Ltd., San#24, Nongseo-Ri, Giheung-Eup, Yongin-Shi, Gyunggi-Do, 449-711, South Korea; Woo, S.-G., Process Development Team, Semiconductor R and D Center, SAMSUNG Electronics Co. Ltd., San#24, Nongseo-Ri, Giheung-Eup, Yongin-Shi, Gyunggi-Do, 449-711, South Korea; Cho, H.-K., Process Development Team, Semiconductor R and D Center, SAMSUNG Electronics Co. Ltd., San#24, Nongseo-Ri, Giheung-Eup, Yongin-Shi, Gyunggi-Do, 449-711, South Korea; Han, W.-S., Process Development Team, Semiconductor R and D Center, SAMSUNG Electronics Co. Ltd., San#24, Nongseo-Ri, Giheung-Eup, Yongin-Shi, Gyunggi-Do, 449-711, South Korea; Moon, J.-T., Process Development Team, Semiconductor R and D Center, SAMSUNG Electronics Co. Ltd., San#24, Nongseo-Ri, Giheung-Eup, Yongin-Shi, Gyunggi-Do, 449-711, South Korea
Abstract: Lithography for 65nm-node device is drawing a lot of attentions these days especially because lithography solution for this node is not clear and even tool makers tend to wait for the consensus in lithography roadmap to avoid the risk of erroneous amount of investment. Recently proposed concept of low energy electron-beam proximity-projection lithography (LEEPL)1,2 technology has already released its first production machine in 2003, which is being expected to cover the design rule down to 65nm-node and even smaller 3. Although production of semiconductor device has been pursuing optical lithography, without any optical technology that is proved as a convincing solution for 65nm node and below, we need to take account of all the candidates. So we made an investigation on LEEPL technology and evaluated beta and first production tool to see the feasibility of printing sub-70nm resolution and of optic-first mix-and-match overlay from a chip maker' s point of view. Two different kinds of stencil masks were fabricated for the evaluation, which are fabricated in SiC and Si membrane. The former mask is for sparse contact holes(C/H) and the latter for dense C/Hs. Beta-tool showed a good resolving power of sub-70nm sparse C/Hs of SRAM with negligibly small proximity effect. It implies that LEEPL does not require much effort for proximity correction comparing to that required in optical lithography, which is one of the biggest issues in low-k1. LEEPL also showed a good capability of optic-first mix-and-match overlay correction and this is the most stringent and important functionality for optic-first mix-and-match application. However random intra-membrane image placement(IP) error that is a little bit larger than the requirement for sub-70nm node was observed, which is interpreted to come from the larger stress of 100MPa in 3×3mm2 dry-etched SiC unit membrane. For dense C/Hs, we failed, to the contrary, to obtain any good quality of stencil masks for DRAM cell patterns because of e-beam proximity effect which is unavoidable in the reversed order of front-side forward direct writing and back-side later membrane formation. Pros and cons of LEEPL technology are discussed based on the evaluation results and estimation from the memory device standpoint. We also propose a novel concept of stencil mask that can be helpful in memory device application.
Author Keywords: Electron-beam; IP error; LEEPL; Low-k1; Mix-and-match; Overlay; Proximity-projection; Resolution
Index Keywords: Data storage equipment; Electron beams; Error analysis; Image processing; Masks; Membranes; Optical resolving power; Photolithography; Risk assessment; Scanning; Silicon; Silicon carbide; IP error; LEEPL; Low-k1; Mix-and-match; Overlay; Proximity-projection; Electron beam lithography

Title: Beaming down
Source title: Professional Engineering
Authors with affiliations: Wraige, H.
Abstract: The Diamond synchrotrons which cost 253 million £, and will be a third generation medium energy source facility, producing beams of very bright, highly focused light of different wavelengths is discussed. The diamond site covers an area equivalent to five football pitches, and the doughnet shaped building has an inner diameter of 230 meter and a circumference of 650 meter. The hard surfaces, required to meet the very tight technical specifications needed to retain the accuracy of the experiments. A shift is expected from mechanical and electrical engineering work on the building and accelerators to the beamline activities.

Authors with affiliations: Okoroanyanwu, U., AMD, M/S 78, 1-AMD Place, Sunnyvale, CA 94088, United States, IMEC vzw, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Stepanenko, N., Infineon Technologies, Dresden, Germany, IMEC vzw, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Vereecke, G., IMEC vzw, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Eliat, A., IMEC vzw, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Kocsis, M., IMEC vzw, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium, Intel Corporation, Santa Clara, CA, United States; Kang, Y.S., IMEC vzw, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium, Samsung, San#24 Nongseo Giheung, Yongin, Gyunggi 449-71, South Korea; Jonckheere, R., IMEC vzw, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Conard, T., IMEC vzw, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Ronse, K., IMEC vzw, Kapeldreef 75, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: Mask fabrication process, transportation, storage, and handling contribute to contamination of 157nm reticles and modified fused silica substrates, resulting in transmission loss. A stable VUV cleaning procedure for contaminated binary, alternating, and attenuated phase shift reticles has been developed. This cleaning procedure was verified by lithographic imaging on the 157nm ASML MS-VII exposure scanner. A point-to-point steady state dose transmission uniformity range across a batch of 25 wafers (the exposure conditions of which were equivalent to that of a 300 mm wafer, 26mm×33mm fields, 50mJ/cm 2) that were exposed with a modified fused silica substrate, was found to be <0.24% for a reticle that was cleaned prior to exposure using this VUV cleaning process. In-situ laser cleaning of contaminated mask substrates during exposure in the MS-VII resulted in 1% change in transmission at doses of up to 20 J/cm 2, above which transmission remains stable (<0.24% variation). The cleaning procedure involves exposing the contaminated reticle in the UVO Reticle Cleaning Station for 30 minutes, using a cleaning gas mixture of N2/O2=99%/1%. Transmission loss due to contamination within the clean room is limited to 1 -2 % and is reversible upon VUV cleaning. Flare levels of 3% were measured on contaminated reticle relative to a clean state of the same reticle. VUV cleaning is not only good for improving and maintaining stable mask transmission, but it is also good for preventing reticle contamination-induced flare. Contamination rate and contaminant type appear to be dependent on the storage environment of mask substrates and reticles. Typical contaminants included molecular acids (halogens, sulfur, sulfates), molecular bases (ammonia, amines), molecular condensables (hydrocarbons, alcohols, ketones, fatty acids, siloxanes, phthalate), molecular dopant (boron) and molecular metals (Ca, Mg, Al, Cu). Contamination of mask substrates appears to be through a competitive adsorption phenomenon, whereby low molecular weight species with high vapor pressure and low adsorption energies are over time replaced by large molecular weight ones with low vapor pressure and high adsorption energies.
Index Keywords: Attenuation; Chemical cleaning; Contamination; Fused silica; Imaging techniques; Light absorption; Light transmission; Lithography; Molecular weight; Phase shift; Ultraviolet radiation; Lithographic imaging; Mask substrates; Reticle cleaning sattions (RCS); Transmission losses; Optical materials

Authors: Rebane A., Drobizhev M., Karotki A., Dzenis Y., Spangler C.W., Gong A., Meng F.
Title: New two-photon materials for fast volumetric re-writable optical storage
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Dept. of Physics, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59717, United States; Dept. of Chemistry, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59717, United States; Lebedev Physics Institute, Leninsky Pr. 53, 119991, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Rebane, A., Dept. of Physics, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59717, United States; Drobizhev, M., Dept. of Physics, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59717, United States, Lebedev Physics Institute, Leninsky Pr. 53, 119991, Moscow, Russian Federation; Karotki, A., Dept. of Physics, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59717, United States; Dzenis, Y., Dept. of Physics, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59717, United States; Spangler, C.W., Dept. of Chemistry, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59717, United States; Gong, A., Dept. of Chemistry, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59717, United States; Meng, F., Dept. of Chemistry, Montana State University, Bozeman, MT 59717, United States
Abstract: We study reversible photo-tautomerization induced by simultaneous two-photon absorption (2PA) in tetrapyrrolic molecules as a potential re-writable mechanism for fast, high-density volumetric optical memory. We show that by illuminating Br-tetra-ethyl-porphyrin (Br-TEP) with 150-fs pulses in the near-IR wavelength range the molecule can be switched between two tautomer forms with distinct spectral absorption- and fluorescence signatures in a fully reversible manner. The 2PA cross section in the illumination wavelength range 775-810 nm is measured and the figure of merit, F= φ×σ2 ∼ 5×10-53 cm4 photon-1 s-1 is estimated for one of the tautomer forms of Br-TEP. Enhanced selectivity of 2PA-induced switching in the near-IR, with respect to one-photon excitation at the same transition energy is observed. We propose to overcome the limitation imposed by the small value of the 2PA cross section by introducing a new class of tetrapyrrolic molecules with greatly enhanced two-photon absorption efficiency. In this paper we present for the first time the structure and absorption properties of asymmetrical chlorin molecules with an attached 2PA-enhancing side group. Potential use of these new materials for high-density re-writable two-photon volumetric optical storage is discussed.
Author Keywords: Optical storage media; Photo-tautomerization; Tetrapyrrole molecules; Two-photon absorption
Index Keywords: Fluorescence; Infrared radiation; Light absorption; Optical materials; Optical recording; Photons; Polypyrroles; Optical storage media; Photo-tautomerization; Tetrapyrrole molecules; Two-photon absorption; Optical disk storage

Abstract: In this work, CMOS devices with very low leakage current(Ioff) are studied for Ultra Low Power (ULP) applications. The ULP is targeted for worst-case loff <0.5 pA/μ m. We used our 0.15um and 0.1 Sum base line process to optimize the Vt, LDD, pocket and S/D implant to reduce device GIDL, poly edge junction leakage, band to band leakage and DIBL. A ULP product, CMOS 1 Mbit SRAM with measured minimum standby current < 10 μ A were fabricated successfully.

Title: Sorting through the lore of phase mask options - Performance measures and practical commercial designs
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Displaytech, Inc., 2602 Clover Basin Drive, Longmont, CO 80503, United States
Authors with affiliations: O'Callaghan, M.J., Displaytech, Inc., 2602 Clover Basin Drive, Longmont, CO 80503, United States
Abstract: Phase masks are needed in Fourier-transform holographic data storage systems (HDS) to reduce the range of light intensities projected into the Fourier plane. The range of light intensities must match the dynamic range of the holographic storage medium and of the full HDS system. Descriptions, mathematical models, and tests of a variety of phase mask types have been reported in the literature: pixelated phase masks, non-pixelated phase masks, and axicons. Lacking, however, has been a systematic way of comparing the relative merits of phase mask types in order to make sound choices. To address this problem, performance criteria are proposed for both the Fourier plane and for the output image plane (e.g. the margin by which 1's can be distinguished from 0's). The criteria are useful both for comparisons and for design optimization. A new numerical model has been developed enabling quantitative comparisons to be made between the predicted performance of the various phase mask types. The model reported here enables more extensive investigations than could be carried out with previously reported models, including investigation of systems in which multiple bits of data are encoded by each pixel using light intensity modulation. The viability of using non-pixelated phase masks integrated with spatial light modulators is also examined. The use of non-pixelated (continuous random) phase masks instead of the more common pixelated phase masks would eliminate the need for costly precision lateral alignment, and integration eliminates the need for precise positioning in an image plane. These advantages would enable smaller, cheaper, high performance HDS optical systems.
Author Keywords: Holographic data storage; Phase mask; Spatial light modulator
Index Keywords: Axicons; Holographic data storage; Optical energy; Phase mask; Data storage equipment; Design; Fast Fourier transforms; Holography; Image analysis; Light amplifiers; Mathematical models; Optimization; Sorting; Light modulators

Abstract: Lifetimes of two-color nonvolatile holograms recorded in as-grown near-stoichiometric lithium tantalate crystals with different proton concentration were measured by extrapolating the high-temperature data. The dark decay time constants obey an Arrhenius dependence on absolute temperature and yield an averaged activation energy of 1.06 eV. Lifetimes of holograms in as-grown crystals depend on the proton concentration. The extrapolated lifetime of two-color holograms at room temperature in lithium tantalate without observable OH- absorption is longer than 50 years.

Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: New Glass Research Center, Nihon Yamamura Glass Co., Ltd., 2-1-18, Naruohama, Nishinomiya, 663-8142, Japan; Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Kobe University, 1-1, Rokkodai, Nada, Kobe 657-8501, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hashima, H., New Glass Research Center, Nihon Yamamura Glass Co., Ltd., 2-1-18, Naruohama, Nishinomiya, 663-8142, Japan; Konishi, A., New Glass Research Center, Nihon Yamamura Glass Co., Ltd., 2-1-18, Naruohama, Nishinomiya, 663-8142, Japan; Tanigami, Y., New Glass Research Center, Nihon Yamamura Glass Co., Ltd., 2-1-18, Naruohama, Nishinomiya, 663-8142, Japan; Shibata, D., Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Kobe University, 1-1, Rokkodai, Nada, Kobe 657-8501, Japan; Kawamoto, Y., Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Kobe University, 1-1, Rokkodai, Nada, Kobe 657-8501, Japan
Abstract: Rare earth-doped oxyfluoride glass of the 50SiO2 ·50PbF2 ·5ErF3 composition in molar ratio was developed. When the oxyfluoride glass is heat-treated at the first crystallization temperature, the glass gives the glass-ceramic in which rare earth-containing fluorite-type nanocrystals of about 20 nm in diameter uniformly precipitate in the glass matrices. The glass-ceramic is transparent to the naked eye like no heat-treated oxyfluoride glass. The glass-ceramic exhibits highly efficient upconversion luminescence under 800 and/or 980 nm laser light excitation. On the other hand, the oxyfluoride glass can be locally changed to glass-ceramic in the forms of dot, line, plane, letter, etc. by thermal energies generated from light absorption of various lasers. In the case of CO 2 laser irradiation the formation of such glass-ceramic occurs near the surface of glass. In the case of 800 or 980 nm irradiation by Ti:sapphire laser or laser diodes, on the other hand, the formation of such glass-ceramic occurs near the surface and/or inside of glass. The glass-ceramic parts can be easily read by upconversion luminescence under laser excitation. Therefore, the presently developed rare earth-doped oxyfluoride glass can be utilized as optical devices of the writing and reading memory, which can be utilized as specific devices for security information.
Author Keywords: CO2 laser; Laser diode; Nanocrystal; Optical memory; Oxyfluoride glass; Rare-earth element; Upconversion luminescence

Authors: Unni K.N.N., De Bettignies R., Dabos-Seignon S., Nunzi J.-M.
Title: The memory effect of a pentacene field effect transistor with a polarizable gate dielectric
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Lab. Proprietes Opt. Mat./Applic., UMR CNRS 6136, Université Angers, 2 Bd. Lavoisier, 49045 Angers Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Unni, K.N.N., Lab. Proprietes Opt. Mat./Applic., UMR CNRS 6136, Université Angers, 2 Bd. Lavoisier, 49045 Angers Cedex, France; De Bettignies, R., Lab. Proprietes Opt. Mat./Applic., UMR CNRS 6136, Université Angers, 2 Bd. Lavoisier, 49045 Angers Cedex, France; Dabos-Seignon, S., Lab. Proprietes Opt. Mat./Applic., UMR CNRS 6136, Université Angers, 2 Bd. Lavoisier, 49045 Angers Cedex, France; Nunzi, J.-M., Lab. Proprietes Opt. Mat./Applic., UMR CNRS 6136, Université Angers, 2 Bd. Lavoisier, 49045 Angers Cedex, France
Abstract: The nonvolatile transistor memory element is an interesting topic in organic electronics. In this case a memory cell consists of only one device where the stored information is written as a gate insulator polarization by a gate voltage pulse and read by the channel conductance control with channel voltage pulse without destruction of the stored information. Therefore such transistor could be the base of non-volatile non-destructively readable computer memory of extremely high density. Also devices with polarizable gate dielectrics can function more effectively in certain circuits. The effective threshold voltage Vt can be brought very close to zero, for applications where the available gate voltage is limited. Resonant and adaptive circuits can be tuned insitu by polarizing the gates. Poly(vinylidene fluoride), PVDF and its copolymer with trifluoroethylene P(VDF-TrFE) are among the best known and most widely used ferroelectric polymers. In this manuscript, we report new results of an organic FET, fabricated with pentacene as the active material and P(VDF-TrFE) as the gate insulator. Application of a writing voltage of -50 V for short duration results in significant change in the threshold voltage and remarkable increase in the drain current. The memory effect is retained over a period of 20 hours.
Author Keywords: Field effect transistor; Non-volatile memory; Organic semiconductor
Index Keywords: Dielectric materials; Electric insulators; Energy gap; Nonvolatile storage; Resonant circuits; Semiconducting organic compounds; Substrates; Thin film transistors; Thin films; Threshold voltage; Ferroelectric memory; Gate insulator polarization; Nonvolatile transistor memory; Organic electronics; Field effect transistors

Title: Synthetic fuels: A scenario for meeting China's auto fuel demands
Source title: Annual Fuels and Lubes Asia Conference and Exhibition
Affiliations: Volkswagen Group China, China
Authors with affiliations: Xu, H., Volkswagen Group China, China
Abstract: The increasing car population will have substantial environmental impacts especially in China's big cities. More stringent future exhaust emission standards require a better fuel quality and more effective emission control means in motor vehicles. The importance of measures to reduce fuel consumption and CO 2 emissions in the optimization of vehicle and powertrain concepts is also steadily growing. Securing a long-term supply of energy sources for the auto industry requires not only that existing fuel resources be utilized as economically as possible, but also that the energy sources used in fuel production be diversified in the medium and long term, including alternative and renewable resources in particular. Synthetic fuels can play a major role in this context in allowing a wide range of usable primary energy. High-quality, environmentally friendly synthetic diesel fuel produced from natural gases via GTL process is, e.g., sulfur and aromatics-free. In the second phase even biomass in many different forms can be used as primary energy for fuel production via a Bio-GTL process. Producing synthetic gas out of biomass and combining it with the Fischer-Tropsch process will create a CO 2 neutral energy source that reduces CO 2 emissions on a well-to-wheel base. If the problem on mobile hydrogen storage and infrastructure will be solved, fuel cell will not only supplement the modern-day internal combustion engine, but will supersede it as a means of vehicular propulsion. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 10th Annual Fuels and Lubes Asia Conference (Shanghai, China, 3/2-5/2004).

Title: MTBE proposal not expected to help pass energy bill
Source title: Chemical Market Reporter
Abstract: A proposal by Senator Ted Stevens for resolving a dispute over methyl tertiary butyl ether (MTBE) liability is discussed. The controversial issue is a major sticking point in the Senate, but limited liability for MTBE producers is strongly backed by House Republican leaders. Senator Stevens has floated the idea of creating a commission to settle legal claims stemming from MTBE drinking water contamination, relying partly on at least $2 billion left in an existing federally administered fund to control leaking underground storage tanks. MTBE has leaked from underground storage tanks into drinking water supplies across the country. The House legislation would exempt MTBE producers from lawsuits claiming the additive is a defective product.
Index Keywords: Defective products; Energy bill; Liability relief; Methyl tertiary butyl ether (MTBE); Contamination; Energy management; Ethers; Finance; Gasoline; Laws and legislation; Potable water; Water tanks; Chemical industry

Title: Build a charge pump with ultralow quiescent current
Source title: EDN
Affiliations: Maxim Integrated Products, Sunnyvale, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sutterlin, G., Maxim Integrated Products, Sunnyvale, CA, United States
Abstract: A charge-pump circuit that uses analog switches to achieve ultralow quiescent current is described. Charge pumps use an ac-coupling technique to transfer energy from a transfer capacitor to a storage capacitor. The circuit draws a maximum quiescent current of 6.9μA and offers a considerable improvement over off-the-shelf charge pumps. This circuit provides an alternative for designers seeking to implement a low-cost design without the use of inductors.
Index Keywords: Analog switches; Charge-pump circuits; Transfer capacitors; Ultralow quiescent currents; Capacitors; Electric currents; Electric inductors; Printed circuit design; Integrated circuits

Title: Heat wave
Source title: EDN
Authors with affiliations: Dipert, B.
Abstract: Innovative FPGA designs, which can moderate the escalating power problem at the expense of performance is discussed. Escalating power consumption is a phenomenon that is generic to any CMOS-based device that vendors manufacture on advanced near-and-less-than 100-nm-lithographies. Semiconductors are now at a point, with conventional silicon-dioxide process technology, at which ever-shrinking transistors dimensions have in effect run into a power-consumption brick wall. SRAM-based FPGAs, which use bipolar transistors not only for logic and embedded-memory-array functions, but also for chip-configuration.

Title: Quick takes: Woodside Energy Ltd...
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: Woodside Energy Ltd awarded a £93 million contract to AMEC PLC and Fluor Corp to provide detailed engineering, procurement, and construction management services for the 150,000 ton Enfield floating production, storage, and offloading (FPSO) vessel. The project is part of the $(Aust)1.5 billion development of deepwater Enfield oil field on permit WA-271-P about 40 km off Western Australia. First production from Enfield, which has oil reserves assessed at 145 million bbl, will start in 2006. The FPSO will have a capacity to process 100,000 bpd of oil and store 1 million bbl.

Title: Earth energy resources introduces Ophus process
Source title: Energy Processing/Canada
Abstract: The features of the Ophus process developed by Earth Energy Resources of Alberta are discussed. The process uses a proprietary catalyst to separate and upgrade extracted oil. The catalyst upgrades the hydrocarbon naturally, making the incremental and costly requirement fo an upgrading facility unnecessary. The pocess is suited for use where oilsand deposits are located and petoleum exploration and refining have left soil contaminated.
Index Keywords: Bituminous materials; Costs; Energy storage; Environmental protection; Extraction; Fuels; Hydrocarbons; Industrial economics; Production; Slurries; Earth Energy Resources (CO); Fuel sources; Oil refineries; Oilsands; Tailings

Title: Agitate your way to success
Source title: PPI Pulp and Paper International
Authors with affiliations: Skånberg, B.
Abstract: The role of agitation in reducing the pulp mill's energy consumption is discussed. Several processes that require pulp agitators, in a pulp mill are also described. The most common are dissolving, high consistency storage, low consistency storage, mixing and homogenization. For paper pulp, the degree of agitation can be divided into four types, which include very good agitation, good agitation, bottom clean and low-active uniformity. Best results are obtained if the volume is designed so that the height of the liquid is between 1.0-1.3 times the diameter of the tank.

Title: Getting it straight
Source title: Motion System Design

Abstract: The uses of hybrid core servomotors and its application in several components are discussed. These motors are useful as two-phase, open-loop linear steppers and as three-phase linear servomotors with closed-loop control. These motors propel loads in different ways and they vary the magnetic saturation created by the platen teeth to change reluctance. It is observed that their unique setup delivers conventional linear motor performance for the price of a toothed belt or ballscrew arrangement.

Title: Aerogel supercapacitors in power applications
Source title: Elektron
Affiliations: Cooper Electronic Technologies, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Likely, C., Cooper Electronic Technologies, United Kingdom
Abstract: Aerogel supercapacitors offer performance that falls between high energy, low power batteries and low energy, high power electrolytic capacitors. These supercapacitors have a much higher power density than batteries and also a much longer life cycle. In addition to pulse power applications, PowerStor supercapacitors can also be used for main, bridging and hold-up power. Near infinite cycle, very low leakage current, good low temperature performance and excellent power density provided by PowerStor supercapacitors make them ideal for supporting or replacing battery technologies.

Abstract: The Jones Island Wastewater Treatment Plant's optimization of secondary treatment to maximize its wet weather capacity is discussed. The plant's inline storage system has tremendously helped improved water quality in the Milwaukee metropolitan area. A common method to decrease secondary clarifier solids loading rates during peak wet weather flow events is to implement a step-feed system in aeration basins. A solids mass balance model was used to quantify the clarifier capacity increase achievable with an increased return activated sludge (RAS) concentration.

Title: Fuel cells on the farm?
Source title: Diesel Progress North American Edition
Abstract: A new Plug Power's LPG fuel cell system is installed, since February, 2004 at Wagner Farms, a dairy farm in Eagle Mills, NY. The fuel cell system installed is Plug Power's Genssys cogen unit, which is designed to provide heat and power. The 5 kW unit has been used to provide electricity and heat for the farm's milking parlor. The entire system has an ambient operating temperature range of zero to 105°F and noise emissions are less than 60 dB(A) at 1 m.

Title: Burning rubber
Source title: World Cement
Affiliations: BEUMER Maschinenfabrik GmbH/Co. KG, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Stöppel, R., BEUMER Maschinenfabrik GmbH/Co. KG, Germany
Abstract: The benefits of employing used tires and other waste solid fuels as means of energy in the cement manufacturing process are discussed. The technology developed by BEUMER for utilization of alternative fuels in the high temperature process of rotary kilns, that has proven its viability in a large number of installations supplied to the cement industry are also discussed. The methods that should be adopted for handling tires, and designing the storage area are also discussed. The construction groups that needs to be maintained for a complete installation for the use of scrap tires for kiln firing are elaborated.

Title: Developing gas in iceberg alley
Source title: Petroleum Review
Authors with affiliations: Crook, J.
Abstract: The Newfoundland offshore petroleum industry is studying ways to develop the massive gas reserves in iceberg alley. It is observed that a constant vigil is required to track icebergs, monitor ice sheets and forecast poor weather conditions. The White Rose field is operated by Husky Energy with partner Petro-Canada and is expected to be developed by means of a disconnectable floating production, storage and offloading (FPSO) vessel. The initial review of likely technologies by Husky indicates that a marine transportation using compressed natural gas/pressurized natural gas has potential.
Index Keywords: Gas reserves; Husky Energy (CO); Icebergs; Petro-Canada (CO); Buoys; Contracts; Cost effectiveness; Fog; Ice; Mergers and acquisitions; Offshore oil fields; Oil well completion; Petroleum industry; Sandstone; Offshore petroleum prospecting

Title: In brief: TIAX in DOE hydrogen storage project
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: TIAX has received a $1.5 million contract from the DOE as part of its Hydrogen Storage Grand Challenge. TIAX will evaluate the various storage technologies being pursued by DOE's Hydrogen Storage Centers of Excellence and other developers. TIAX will work with an industry team on regular evaluation of developments in the four categories of on-board hydrogen storage: compressed hydrogen, metal hydride, carbon-based materials, and chemical hydrogen storage. The team will compare the different approaches in terms of life-cycle costs, energy efficiency, and environmental impact, to help identify the most promising technology options and approaches for potential commercialization.

Title: All-electric, automated & super-efficient
Source title: Plastics Technology
Authors with affiliations: Knights, M.
Abstract: The success of designing of plant 47 for Delphi Connection systems in handling more different parts and materials and higher production volumes with fewer people and less inventory is discussed. The latest plant operates 24/7 to produce up to 1.4 billion parts a year that include automotive connector housings, clips, clamps, and related components. Each manufacturing cell has a press-side granulator with sensors to detect the presence of material that needs to be grounded. It was concluded that cross-contamination of materials is prevented through the use of a barcode matching system for the materials, machines and molds.
Index Keywords: Automated guided vehicles (AGV); Barcoad matching systems; Electric presses; Bar codes; Costs; Customer satisfaction; Electric energy storage; Electric machinery; Factory automation; Granulators; Hydraulic fluids; Injection molding; Inventory control; Investments; Product design; Resins; Thickness measurement; Throughput; Materials handling

Title: Ballard engines, Dynetek hydrogen storage for China-bound buses
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: Ballard Power Systems and Dynetek Industries will deliver heavy-duty 205 kwe fuel cell engines and 350 bar onboard hydrogen fuel storage systems, respectively, for the three fuel cell buses that DaimlerChrysler will deliver to China in 2005. The three buses will operate in Beijing as part of a 2-yr demonstration program, from late 2005 through 2007. The three buses in Beijing will complement the 33 Mercedez-Benz Citaro buses equipped with Ballard fuel cell engines and Dynetek hydrogen storage within the Clean Urban Transport for Europe program, the Ecological City Transport System in Iceland, and the Sustainable Transport Energy Program in Perth, Australia. Ballard has also delivered three engines to Gillig Corp in California for the Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority.

Authors: Gindl M., Reiterer A., Sinn G., Stanzl-Tschegg S.E.
Title: Effects of surface ageing on wettability, surface chemistry, and adhesion of wood
Source title: Holz als Roh - und Werkstoff
Affiliations: Institute of Physics and Materials Science, Christian-Doppler-Laboratory for Fundamentals of Wood Machining, BOKU-University of Natural Resources and Applied Life Sciences Vienna, Türkenschanzstr. 18, 1180 Vienna, Austria; Austrian Industrial Research Promotion Fund (FFF), Vienna, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Gindl, M., Institute of Physics and Materials Science, Christian-Doppler-Laboratory for Fundamentals of Wood Machining, BOKU-University of Natural Resources and Applied Life Sciences Vienna, Türkenschanzstr. 18, 1180 Vienna, Austria; Reiterer, A., Austrian Industrial Research Promotion Fund (FFF), Vienna, Austria; Sinn, G., Institute of Physics and Materials Science, Christian-Doppler-Laboratory for Fundamentals of Wood Machining, BOKU-University of Natural Resources and Applied Life Sciences Vienna, Türkenschanzstr. 18, 1180 Vienna, Austria; Stanzl-Tschegg, S.E., Institute of Physics and Materials Science, Christian-Doppler-Laboratory for Fundamentals of Wood Machining, BOKU-University of Natural Resources and Applied Life Sciences Vienna, Türkenschanzstr. 18, 1180 Vienna, Austria
Abstract: The effects of ageing on the surface chemistry, wettability and the surface free energy were determined according to the acid base theory using contact angle measurements and x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Time is a significant variable affecting wettability and adhesion. All measured surface parameters of the wood surface were storage time dependent. It could be demonstrated that the effect of ageing on the adhesion of a coating on the wood surface depends not only on the properties of the wood surface, but also on the chemical nature of the coating. Therefore, measurements on wettability without considering the time dependence of surface energy and, above all, its components, are not sufficient to assess effects of ageing on adhesion. © Springer-Verlag 2004.
Index Keywords: Aging of materials; Free energy; Parameter estimation; Surface chemistry; Wetting; X ray photoelectron spectroscopy; Acid base theory; Surface ageing; Wood adhesion; Wood coating; Wood preservation; Aging; Chemistry; Esca; Free Energy; Parameters; Surface Properties; Wetting; Wood Preservation; X Ray Spectroscopy

Title: Wireless light rail: ALSTOM's solutions
Source title: ZEV Rail Glasers Annalen
Affiliations: ALSTOM Transport, 48, rue Albert Dhalenne, 93482 Saint Ouen Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Lacôte, F.ALSTOM Transport, 48, rue Albert Dhalenne, 93482 Saint Ouen Cedex, France; Moskowitz, J.-P.ALSTOM Transport, 48, rue Albert Dhalenne, 93482 Saint Ouen Cedex, France
Abstract: A growing number of cities need public transport, to reduce congestion and to offer modern transport solutions. Light rail systems are a solution and enable to take into account aesthetic considerations (through the cancellation of the overhead line) and energy optimisation (through an energy storage systems). Different technologies allow to meet these new requirements: ground level power supply, on-board energy storage with batteries, supercapacitors or flywheels and on-board energy production where noemission energy can be provided by fuel cells and hydrogen. This article details different technologies and specific advantages of each solution, with a special focus on Bordeaux which has become the first city in the world to choose the ALSTOM Transport/Innorail system for ground level power supply of its new tramway lines. It also shows cuitent research and development projects and presents ALSTOM testing facilities.
Index Keywords: Innorail systems; Light rail systems; Public transports; Tramways; Capacitors; Electric batteries; Electric power systems; Energy storage; Fuel cells; Hydrogen; Modernization; Optimization; Overhead lines; Project management; Radio; Research and development management; Railroad transportation

Authors: Muljadi E., Butterfield C.P., Yinger R., Romanowitz H.
Title: Energy storage and reactive power compensator in a large wind farm
Source title: Collection of ASME Wind Energy Symposium Technical Papers AIAA Aerospace Sciences Meeting and Exhibit
Affiliations: National Renewable Energy Laboratory, 1617 Cole Blvd., Golden, CO 80401, United States; Southern California Edison, P.O. Box 800, Rosemead, CA 91770, United States; Oak Creek Energy Systems Inc., 14633 Willow Springs Rd., Mojave, CA 93501, United States
Authors with affiliations: Muljadi, E., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, 1617 Cole Blvd., Golden, CO 80401, United States; Butterfield, C.P., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, 1617 Cole Blvd., Golden, CO 80401, United States; Yinger, R., Southern California Edison, P.O. Box 800, Rosemead, CA 91770, United States; Romanowitz, H., Oak Creek Energy Systems Inc., 14633 Willow Springs Rd., Mojave, CA 93501, United States
Abstract: The size of wind farm power systems is increasing, and so is the number of wind farms contributing to the power systems network. The size of wind turbines is also increasing - from less than 1 MW a few years ago to the 2- to 3-MW machines being installed today and the 5-MW machines under development. The interaction of the wind farm, energy storage, reactive power compensation, and the power system network is being investigated. Because the loads and the wind farms' output fluctuate during the day, the use of energy storage and reactive power compensation is ideal for the power system network. Energy storage and reactive power compensation can minimize real/reactive power unbalances that can affect the surrounding power system. In this paper, we will show how the contribution of wind farms affects the power distribution network and how the power distribution network, energy storage, and reactive power compensation interact when the wind changes. We will also investigate the size of the components in relation to each other and to the power system.
Author Keywords: Energy storage; Induction generator; Power system; Reactive power compensator; Renewable energy; Static VAR compensator; Synchronous generator; Wind farm; Wind turbine

Title: This invention could go up in smoke
Source title: Professional Engineering
Authors with affiliations: Wilks, N.
Abstract: The various aspects of a cardboard-fuelled waste-to-energy generator for space heating invented by Ross Donovan are discussed. The innovation is in the design of the shredder and the control system, which ensures that only 2kg to 3 kg of cardboard is on the unit's conveyor belt feeding the burner as any one time. Once up to the working temperature of 83°C, the cardboard is burned at 85kg an hour to produce heat output of 300kW. The prototype proved its worth in spring 2003 when it fed its cardboard-fired heat into the existing gas-fired heating system at a nursery in Bedfordshire.
Index Keywords: Biomass; Carbon dioxide; Environmental impact; Fossil fuels; Gas fired boilers; Land fill; Product development; Project management; Regulatory compliance; Waste incineration; Business model; Shredder; Storage silos; Space heating

Title: Future memory technology including emerging new memories
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Microelectronics
Affiliations: Advanced Technology Development, Memory Division, Samsung Electronics Co., San #24, Nongseo-Ri, Kiheung-Eup, Yongin-City, Kyungki-Do, South Korea

Abstract: There have been concerns about how far we can extend the so far so successful conventional semiconductor memories such as DRAM, SRAM and Flash memory and what will be the future directions of memory development. In this article, we will review the key technical limits of conventional memory scaling and the directions to overcome the problem. In addition, we will review the technical challenges and opportunities of emerging new memories such as ferroelectric RAM (FRAM), magnetic RAM (MRAM) and phase change RAM (PRAM) which has been recently focused as candidates for ideal memory which can solve the problems of conventional memories.
Index Keywords: CMOS integrated circuits; Data reduction; Energy utilization; Flash memory; Phase changing circuits; Static random access storage; Technological forecasting; Cell arrays; Cell dimensions; Junction boundaries; Dynamic random access storage

Authors: Suratwala T.I., Campbell J.H., Miller P.E., Thorsness C.B., Riley M.O., Ehrmann P.R., Steele R.A.
Title: Phosphate laser glass for NIF: Production status, slab selection and recent technical advances
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, P.O. Box 808 L-491, Livermore, CA 94551, United States
Authors with affiliations: Suratwala, T.I., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, P.O. Box 808 L-491, Livermore, CA 94551, United States; Campbell, J.H., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, P.O. Box 808 L-491, Livermore, CA 94551, United States; Miller, P.E., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, P.O. Box 808 L-491, Livermore, CA 94551, United States; Thorsness, C.B., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, P.O. Box 808 L-491, Livermore, CA 94551, United States; Riley, M.O., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, P.O. Box 808 L-491, Livermore, CA 94551, United States; Ehrmann, P.R., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, P.O. Box 808 L-491, Livermore, CA 94551, United States; Steele, R.A., Lawrence Livermore Natl. Laboratory, P.O. Box 808 L-491, Livermore, CA 94551, United States
Abstract: The National Ignition Facility (NIF) at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory is a stadium-sized high-energy (1.8 megajoule) / high-peak power (500 terawatt) laser system, which will utilize over 3000 meter-size Nd-doped metaphosphate glasses as its gain media. The current production status, the selection criteria of individual slabs for specific beam line locations, and some recent technical advances are reviewed. The glass blanks are manufactured by a novel continuous glass melting process, and the finished slabs are then prepared by epoxy bonding a Cu-doped phosphate glass edge cladding and by advanced finishing techniques. To date, nearly 3400 slab equivalents have been melted, 2600 have been rough-cut to blanks, 1200 have been finished, and 144 have been installed in NIF. A set of selection rules, which are designed to optimize laser performance (e.g., maintain gain balance between beam lines and minimize beam walkoff) and to maximize glass lifetime with respect to Pt damage site growth, have been established for assigning individual slabs to specific beam line locations. Recent technical advances for amplifier slab production, which include: 1) minimizing surface pitting (hazing) after final finishing; 2) minimizing humidity-induced surface degradation (weathering) upon storage and use; and 3) preventing mounting-induced surface fractures upon installation, have contributed in improving the laser glass quality.
Author Keywords: High peak-power laser; Indentation fracture; National Ignition Facility; Phosphate laser glass; Surface pitting; Weathering
Index Keywords: High peak-power lasers; Indentation fracture; Laser glass; Amplifiers (electronic); Indentation; Installation; Laser beams; Optimization; Research laboratories; Semiconductor doping; Lasers

Title: An accurate ferroelectric capacitor model for signal slew rates from DC up to 800 MV/s
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Microelectronics

Abstract: In this paper an accurate ferroelectric capacitor model is presented which allows the modeling of ferroelectric capacitors for signal slew rates from DC up to 800 MV/s. This model completes the static hysteresis model based on Preisach theory, which is suitable for quasi static input voltage. The comparison of the simulation results show excellent agreement with measurement results under different conditions.

Title: Distributed generation as a solution for demand waiver heating loads
Source title: Papers - Rural Electric Power Conference
Affiliations: Minnkota Power Cooperative, Inc., Grand Forks, ND, United States; Transmiss. and Distribution Services, Cass County Elec. Cooperative, Inc., Fargo, ND, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hennes, M.L., Minnkota Power Cooperative, Inc., Grand Forks, ND, United States; Schmidt, B.J., Transmiss. and Distribution Services, Cass County Elec. Cooperative, Inc., Fargo, ND, United States
Abstract: Minnkota Power Cooperative (MPC) is a generation and transmission utility providing electric power to 11 distribution cooperatives and 12 municipal power agencies in eastern North Dakota and northwestern Minnesota. Cass County Electric Cooperative (CCEC) is a distribution cooperative member of MPC. In the mid 80's, MPC created a program whereby its member cooperatives could market electric heating energy without a demand charge in order to utilize excess energy production. As energy supplies have tightened up, this program was discontinued. The distribution cooperatives had to find a means to offset the electrical demand created by the heating loads which were added under this program and not included in the MPC load management program. In a joint effort, MPC and CCEC have worked to install ten diesel powered generation modules at the distribution level totaling 18.25 MW of peak electrical capacity. These units will be operated synchronously with the grid system during periods of peak electrical demand to offset the non-managed load created by the demand waiver heating program. This paper will detail some of the electrical and mechanical design and installation challenges and solutions for this project. Of special consideration for the project are the cold-weather climate conditions, design aspects for the interconnection, joint monitoring and control requirements, and operational guidelines incorporated into the completed project.
Index Keywords: Cass County Electric Cooperative (CCEC); Demand Waiver; Distributed Generation; Heating Loads; Minnkota power cooperative (MPC); Condition monitoring; Electric energy storage; Electric heating; Electric heating elements; Electric load management; Electric loads; Electric power distribution; Electric power utilization; Electric variables control; Electric power generation

Title: Quick takes: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners LP...
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners LP (KMP) will invest $650 million in 2004 on pipeline system expansion projects that include 70 mi of 20-in. new pipe replacing a 14-in. Concord-Sacramento, CA, pipeline. The $88 million project will be in service by yearend. The expansion is scheduled for completion by early 2006. KMP will add 600,000 bbl of storage capacity at the Carteret terminal in New York Harbor, a $19 million project. Affiliate Kinder Morgan Inc will complete in August 2004 its $33 million project to expand TransColorado pipeline firm transportation capacity to 425 million cu ft/day.

Title: Quick takes: Vaalco Energy Inc...
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: According to Vaalco Energy Inc, the Eavom-1 Avouma prospect exploration well flowed on test at a stabilized rate of 6600 bpd of oil of 37-38° gravity crude. The well now has flowlines tying it back to the Etame floating production, storage, and offloading system. Etame 5H production will start later in July 2004, increasing total production from Etame field to > 20,000 bpd of oil from the current 15,000 bpd.

Title: The new pumped-storage power station at Goldisthal
Source title: VGB PowerTech
Affiliations: Vattenfall Eur. Generation AG/Co. KG, Cottbus, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hassa, R., Vattenfall Eur. Generation AG/Co. KG, Cottbus, Germany; Bogenrieder, W., Vattenfall Eur. Generation AG/Co. KG, Cottbus, Germany
Abstract: After a construction period of six years, the 1,060MW cavern-type plant of Vattenfall Europe at Goldisthal in the Free State of Thuringia is finally in the process of starting-up. With the last pump-turbine unit entering commercial operation by early 2004, Vattenfall Europe will operate the (in terms of capacity and power output) largest pumped-storage plant in Germany and, at the same time, one of the most modem power stations in Europe. An overview of the project, the legal approval procedures and the construction as well as start-up phases is given. First operation experience is stated.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Laws and legislation; Project management; Reservoirs (water); Safety factor; Water levels; Cavern-type plants; Power stations; Pumped-storage plants; Electric power transmission networks

Title: Development and deployment of the in-tank remote viewing system for the ORNL melton valley storage tanks facility
Source title: Conference on Robotics and Remote Systems- Proceedings
Affiliations: Maverick Systems, Inc., 165 Woods Lane, Kingston, TN 37763, United States; TPG Applied Technology, 10330 Technology Dr., Knoxville, TN 37932, United States
Authors with affiliations: Armstrong, G.A., Maverick Systems, Inc., 165 Woods Lane, Kingston, TN 37763, United States; Burks, B.L., TPG Applied Technology, 10330 Technology Dr., Knoxville, TN 37932, United States
Abstract: A remote viewing system was needed for in-tank inspection at the ORNL Melton Valley Storage Tanks (MVST). ORNL has 8 tanks at the MVST facility that are used to store Liquid Low-Level Waste (LLLW) prior to processing in the TRU/Alpha waste treatment facility. Each tank has the capacity to store 50,000 gallons of liquid and sludge waste. The remote viewing system was needed to inspect tank conditions and to allow estimation of the volume of waste in the tanks prior to retrieval operations. The volume estimates utilized known fiducial markers internal to the tanks. The viewing system would have to penetrate a 3 inch riser to enter the tanks which are 61.5 feet long and 12 feet in diameter. The inspection required a remotely operated manipulator arm for deployment and a remotely operated viewing and lighting system. The manipulator arm would be required to penetrate the 3 inch riser which is 9.6 feet in length and then position the remote viewing system around occlusions in the tank (vertical risers) in the limited vapor space at the top of each tank. The inspection system was deployed in the MVST tanks during July and August of 2001. This paper discusses the design, fabrication, and deployment of the system.
Index Keywords: Liquid low level waste (LLLW); Occlusions; Remote viewing; Vapor spaces; Energy absorption; Fabrication; Image quality; Robotics; Tanks (containers); Waste disposal; Wastewater treatment; Remote sensing

Authors: Zhao Y., Selekwa M.F., Collins Jr. E.G.
Title: Multivalued fuzzy behavior control system for robot navigation: Computational and performance improvement
Source title: Conference on Robotics and Remote Systems- Proceedings
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Florida A and M University, Florida State University, Tallahassee, FL 32310, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhao, Y., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Florida A and M University, Florida State University, Tallahassee, FL 32310, United States; Selekwa, M.F., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Florida A and M University, Florida State University, Tallahassee, FL 32310, United States; Collins Jr., E.G., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Florida A and M University, Florida State University, Tallahassee, FL 32310, United States
Abstract: Multivalued fuzzy behavior control systems for robot navigation have demonstrated more system robustness against sensor and environmental uncertainty and changes in behavioral priorities than univalued fuzzy behavior control systems. However, a major concern for the implementation of multivalued systems is the computational burden associated with the fuzzy inference and defuzzification process. This paper presents a multivalued fuzzy behavior control system for robot navigation using singletons instead of fuzzy set consequences. The proposed implementation with singleton consequences greatly reduces the space required for data storage and speeds up the control computation while providing a simple way of fusing the behavioral commands. This paper also presents a genetic algorithm approach to improve the performance of the proposed fuzzy system with singleton consequences. The developed genetic fuzzy system obtains the optimal values of the singleton consequences for the heading control activity and speed control activity by minimizing the path length, the bending energy and navigation steps. Simulations results are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the obtained fuzzy navigation system.
Index Keywords: Fuzzy systems; Robot navigation; Computational methods; Computer simulation; Control systems; Data storage equipment; Fuzzy sets; Information analysis; Navigation; Robots; Robotics

Authors: Desbats P., Toubon H., Piolain G.
Title: Status of development of remote technologies applied to cogema spent fuel management facilities in france
Source title: Conference on Robotics and Remote Systems- Proceedings
Affiliations: CEA/LIST Robotics Department, Route du panorama, F-92265 Fontenay-aux-Roses, France; COGEMA Business Unit Treatment, R and D Dept., Montigny le Bretonneux, F-78182 Saint-Quentin-en-Yvelines, France; COGEMA - LA HAGUE, Development Department, 50444 Beaumont Hague Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Desbats, P., CEA/LIST Robotics Department, Route du panorama, F-92265 Fontenay-aux-Roses, France; Toubon, H., COGEMA Business Unit Treatment, R and D Dept., Montigny le Bretonneux, F-78182 Saint-Quentin-en-Yvelines, France; Piolain, G., COGEMA - LA HAGUE, Development Department, 50444 Beaumont Hague Cedex, France
Abstract: In the facilities of the end of the nuclear fuel cycle, like spent fuel storage pools, reprocessing plants, Plutonium-based fuel manufacturing plants or waste temporary storage units, materials handling must be carried out remotely, taking into account the nuclear radiations environment. In addition to the automation requirement, robotics equipments in the nuclear industry must be substituted to human operators in order to respect the ALARA principle. More over, remote technologies aim to improve the working conditions, as well as the quality of the work achieved by the operators. A few years ago, COGEMA started an ambitious Research and Development program in robotics and remote technologies applied to its spent fuel management facilities in France, with the aim to cover the requirements of the different plant life cycle steps. This program has been carried out in collaboration with the French Atomic Energy Agency (C.E.A) in charge of R&D. The paper summarizes the important remote technology developments that have been carried out by C.E.A. and now being transferred to COGEMA industrial group. The range includes the next generation of servo-manipulators, long range inspection tools and carriers, nuclear versions of industrial robots, radiation hardened robotics systems, as well as force-feedback master-slave generic control software for teleoperation. Some applications of these new remote technologies are presented in the paper : - rad-hard electronic modules for robotic equipments which are used by COGEMA in high radiating environment, - electrical manipulators for remote teleoperation with force-feedback for maintenance applications, - a 6 axes master arm for teleoperation of master-slave systems with force-feedback - generic control and supervision software for remote teleoperated systems. The results of the robotics development program carried out by COGEMA and C.E.A have been very valuable for the introduction of these new technologies in the nuclear industry. Innovative products and sub-systems can be integrated now in a large range of remote handling systems, thus optimizing the tools provided to the operators and improving their productivity as well as their safety.
Index Keywords: Automation; Computer software; Control systems; Fuel storage; Industrial research; Maintenance; Nuclear fuel reprocessing; Radiation hazards; Radioactive waste disposal; Remote control; Spent fuels; Electronic modules; Nuclear fuel cycle; Spent fuel storage pools; Teleoperation; Robotics

Title: Saw blade chatter detection and correction-developing the smart tooling concept for remote manipulation
Source title: Conference on Robotics and Remote Systems- Proceedings
Affiliations: Oak Ridge National Laboratory, P.O. Box 2008, Oak Ridge, TN 37831-6305, United States
Authors with affiliations: Noakes, M.W., Oak Ridge National Laboratory, P.O. Box 2008, Oak Ridge, TN 37831-6305, United States
Abstract: Cutting of metal structures is a regular need in decontamination and decommissioning (D&D) of contaminated Department of Energy facilities. Plasma torch cutting is efficient, but there are many cases and situations where it is not appropriate. Sometimes the fire hazard cannot be tolerated; sometimes it is more of a contaminant dispersal issue. Circular saws, band saws, and reciprocating saws are often the necessary tool of choice. Sawing is a complex action that is difficult to execute with remote manipulation without extensive task-specific fixturing of the tool to minimize blade chatter and binding. Extensive fixturing leads to the requirement for multiple tools for each minor variation of the task. This drives up the cost of remote tooling for a given D&D large-scale task, generates clutter and tool storage issues, impacts tool reliability due to complexity, and increases the required spare parts. This paper presents an investigation of the saw tool chatter issues, ways to detect chatter for the control system, and compensation methods that lead to a new approach to tooling use with remote manipulation-smart tooling.
Index Keywords: Remote manipulation; Saw blade chatter detection; Smart tooling concepts; Control systems; Fire hazards; Jamming; Low pass filters; Oscillations; Plasma torches; Radiation decontamination; Remote control

Authors: Skripnyuk V., Rabkin E., Estrin Y., Lapovok R.
Title: Equal channel angular pressing as a means of improving the hydrogen absorption/desorption properties of alloy ZK60
Source title: Ultrafine Grained Materials III
Affiliations: Department of Materials Engineering, Technion, Haifa 32000, Israel; Clausthal University of Technology, Materials Engineering and Technology, Agricolastrasse 6, Clausthal-Zellerfeld 38678, Germany; Monash University, Sch. of Phys./Materials Engineering, Clayton, Vic. 3800, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Skripnyuk, V., Department of Materials Engineering, Technion, Haifa 32000, Israel; Rabkin, E., Department of Materials Engineering, Technion, Haifa 32000, Israel; Estrin, Y., Clausthal University of Technology, Materials Engineering and Technology, Agricolastrasse 6, Clausthal-Zellerfeld 38678, Germany; Lapovok, R., Monash University, Sch. of Phys./Materials Engineering, Clayton, Vic. 3800, Australia
Abstract: In the present work, an attempt was undertaken to achieve an enhancement of the desorption rate of hydrogen in a Mg alloy by using equal channel angular pressing (ECAP) alone or in combination with high-energy ball milling (HEBM). The object of the study was the commercial magnesium alloy ZK60 (Mg-4.95 wt.%Zn-0.71 wt. % Zr). ECAP was shown to have a significant accelerating effect on the hydrogen absorption/desorption kinetics, comparable with or even exceeding that of HEBM. An interesting feature associated with combined ECAP/HEBM processing is the disappearance of pressure hysteresis with respect to hydrogen absorption/desorption. This hydrogenation behavior is explained in terms of the microstructure of bulk samples and the morphology of dehydrogenated powders as observed by high resolution scanning electron microscopy.
Author Keywords: Absorption/desorption; Equal channel angular pressing (ECA); High-energy ball milling (HEBM); Hydrogen storage; ZK60

Abstract: The proceedings contain 49 papers from the conference on Advanced Materials for Energy Conversion II. Authors: Kim H.-S., Ho-Lee, Kim J.-H., Kang Y.-M., Lee J.-Y.
Title: Hydrogen storage properties of multiwall carbon nanotubes grown in oxygen added PECVD
Source title: MPMD Fifth Global Innovations Proceedings, Surfaces and Interfaces in Nanostructured Materials and Trends in LIGA, Miniaturization, and Nanoscale Materials
Affiliations: Dept. of Mat. Sci. and Engineering, Korea Adv. Inst. of Sci./Technology, 373-1 Guseong-Dong, Yuseong-Gu, Daejeon, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Kim, H.-S., Dept. of Mat. Sci. and Engineering, Korea Adv. Inst. of Sci./Technology, 373-1 Guseong-Dong, Yuseong-Gu, Daejeon, South Korea; Ho-Lee, Dept. of Mat. Sci. and Engineering, Korea Adv. Inst. of Sci./Technology, 373-1 Guseong-Dong, Yuseong-Gu, Daejeon, South Korea; Kim, J.-H., Dept. of Mat. Sci. and Engineering, Korea Adv. Inst. of Sci./Technology, 373-1 Guseong-Dong, Yuseong-Gu, Daejeon, South Korea; Kang, Y.-M., Dept. of Mat. Sci. and Engineering, Korea Adv. Inst. of Sci./Technology, 373-1 Guseong-Dong, Yuseong-Gu, Daejeon, South Korea; Lee, J.-Y., Dept. of Mat. Sci. and Engineering, Korea Adv. Inst. of Sci./Technology, 373-1 Guseong-Dong, Yuseong-Gu, Daejeon, South Korea
Abstract: Hydrogen storage properties of the two kinds of multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) synthesized by microwave PECVD were evaluated. The first sample grown in CH4H2 reaction gas was curly shaped nanotubes with blocked nanoholes and closed caps and the next sample grown in CR 4t/H2/O2 reaction gas had less defective structure with connected holes and open caps. The hydrogen storage properties of the carbon nanotubes with these closed and open structures were compared by thermal desorption technique. Though the MWNTs with blocked and closed structure had two different desorption ranges such as 290-330 and about 420 K and evolved about 0.64 and 0.03 wt% of hydrogen respectively, the MWNTs with open structure evolved about 1.94 wt% of hydrogen at ambient temperature. The hydrogen desorption activation energy was also calculated. The obtained hydrogen desorption activation energy of MWNTs with closed and open structure at ambient temperature was -18.5 kJ/mol H2 and -16.5 kJ/mol H2, respectively. The activation energy of high temperature hydrogen desorption in MWNTs with closed structure was -124.4 kJ/mol H2. The hydrogen desorbed between 290 and 330 K was the hydrogen physi-sorbed in nano-hole and the hydrogen desorbed at about 420 K was that chemi-sorbed in defects of nanotubes.
Author Keywords: Adsorption; Hydrogen; Nanotube

Authors: Suda S., Iwase Y., Morigasaki N., Li Z.-P.
Title: Metal-hydrogen complex compounds as hydrogen storgae materials
Source title: Advanced Materials for Energy Conversion II
Affiliations: Kogakuin University, Dept. of Environmental Engineering, 2665-1, Nakano-machi, Hachioji-shi, Tokyo 192-0015, Japan; Mat. and Energy Research Institute, Tokyo (MERIT) Ltd., 1-1, Sawarabi-Daira, Chino-shi, Nagano-ken 361-0016, Japan

Abstract: A new production process of sodium borohydride (NaBH4) as a hydrogen storage material was developed by using sodium metaborate (NaBO 2) in which a simple reaction given as NaBO2 + 2Mg + 2H2 → NaBH4 + 2MgO took place at considerably high reaction rate by changing the system temperature dynamically. The process applies the transitional states of hydrogen at the extreme surface of Mg when it is hydrogenated and dehydrogenated by the constant rate of temperature change, dT/dt (°C/s). The rate of conversion is found significantly dependent on dT/dt and regulated by the oxidation level of Mg particles. Roles of protide (anionic hydrogen; H-) in Mg·(2H-) under transitional conditions, Mg + H2 → MgH2 → Mg ·(2H-), will be discussed with regard to the exchange reaction between NaBO2 and NaBH4.
Author Keywords: Hydrogen Storage; Metal-hydrogen complex; Sodium borohydride
Index Keywords: Complexation; Dehydrogenation; Energy storage; Negative ions; Rate constants; Sodium compounds; Surface properties; Thermal effects; Complex hydrides; Exchange reaction; Hydrogen storage materials; Metal-hydrogen complex; Hydrogen inorganic compounds

Title: Hydrogen storage-a critical challenge to the hydrogen economy
Source title: Advanced Materials for Energy Conversion II
Affiliations: Pac. Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA 99352, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jones, R.H., Pac. Northwest National Laboratory, Richland, WA 99352, United States
Abstract: Vehicle range on a single tank of hydrogen is critical for the economic viability of hydrogen fueled vehicles. A range of 500 kilometers is projected for economic viability and this requires the storage of at least 4 kg of H 2. Hydrogen storage concepts being considered and evaluated include: 1) compressed H 2, 2) liquid H 2, 3) bulk storage in hydrides, 4) surface adsorption on carbon and boron nitride nanotubes and 5) generation by chemical reaction of a hydride with water. Compressed H 2 tanks with a capacity of about 2 kg of H 2 stored at 350 bar of pressure have been certified while tanks with higher capacity stored at 700 bar are being developed. Liquidified H 2 tanks can store more H 2 in a vehicle than compressed H 2 but liquifying H 2 requires considerable energy and boil-off of the liquid H 2 is a concern, especially in enclosed spaces. Storage of H 2 in bulk hydrides or on the surface of carbon or boron nitride nanotubes are attractive because of the low pressures involved. Recent studies have shown that NaAlH 4 can be reversibly charged and discharged with H 2 hundreds of times but the capacity of this hydride material is only about one-half of that needed. Storage of H 2 on the surfaces of carbon nanotubes has shown great promise but verification of the storage capacities has not occurred. However, carbon nanotubes have the potential to store about 80% of the desired quantity of H 2 so it remains a viable storage material. Generation of H 2 by chemical reaction of a hydride such as LiH with water to produce H 2 is also attractive because of the significant amounts of H 2 that can be generated by this process. The key issues for this process of generating H 2 is the need to reprocess the reaction products and the cost associated with transportation and reprocessing this product. There are several options for storing hydrogen on-board a vehicle but considerable development work is needed before the hydrogen economy can be realized.
Author Keywords: Hydrogen economy; Hydrogen fuel; Hydrogen storage
Index Keywords: Boron nitride nanotubes; Hydrogen economy; Hydrogen fueled vehicles; Hydrogen storage; Adsorption; Carbon nanotubes; Chemical reactions; Compaction; Cost benefit analysis; Hydrides; Transportation; Hydrogen fuels

Authors: Joubert J.-M., Latroche M., Percheron-Guégan A.
Title: Intermetallic compounds for hydrogen gas storage: A review
Source title: Advanced Materials for Energy Conversion II
Affiliations: Lab. Chim. Metall. des Terres Rares, CNRS, 2-8 rue Henri Dunant, F-94320 Thiais Cedex, France

Abstract: Among the different possible solutions for the reduction of greenhouse effect, hydrogen has been proposed as a clean and efficient energy carrier. However, high capacity storage is still to be developed. Many metals, alloys and intermetallic compounds are able to store hydrogen gas. Such possibility is of interest in terms of safety, global yield and long time storage. However, to be suitable for applications, such compounds must present high capacity, good reversibility, fast reactivity and sustainability. In this paper, we will review on the thermodynamic properties of metal hydrides. Their solid-gas hydrogenation behaviour and the related absorption-desorption isotherm curves are examined as a useful criterion for the selection of suitable materials for applications. The paper emphasizes the possibility to reach given properties by convenient chemical substitutions of the compounds.
Author Keywords: Hydrogen storage; Intermetallic compounds; Metal hydrides
Index Keywords: Absorption; Alloys; Desorption; Greenhouse effect; Hydrides; Hydrogen; Hydrogenation; Isotherms; Nanostructured materials; Storage (materials); Thermodynamic properties; Borohydrides; Energy carriers; Hydrogen storage; Metal hydrides; Intermetallics

Authors: Cooper K.P., Jones III H.N., Pande C.S.
Title: Recent developments in superconducting materials for energy conversion
Source title: Advanced Materials for Energy Conversion II
Affiliations: Naval Research Laboratory, Mat. Science and Technology Division, Code 6325, 4555 Overlook Ave., S.W., Washington, DC 20375-5343, United States

Science and Technology Division, Code 6325, 4555 Overlook Ave., S.W., Washington, DC 20375-5343, United States; Pande, C.S., Naval Research Laboratory, Mat. Science and Technology Division, Code 6325, 4555 Overlook Ave., S.W., Washington, DC 20375-5343, United States
Abstract: Superconducting materials have the potential to revolutionize the Energy industry. The promise of superconductors is the generation, transmission, conversion and storage of energy with little or no loss. Significant progress has been made in the development of high temperature superconductors suitable for use at liquid nitrogen temperature. However, flux pinning and grain boundary "weak link" problems remain and better understanding and development of techniques to minimize the adverse effects are needed. The recently discovered superconductor, MgB2, while not a high temperature superconductor, has many attractive properties such as the absence of the "weak link" effect, low cost synthesis and operation at liquid hydrogen temperature. However, the synthesis of MgB2 is not trivial and several routes to its fabrication into wire form are being pursued. Many technical challenges in the development of these two classes of superconductors remain. Some of the challenges and opportunities in the development of these materials are discussed in this paper.
Author Keywords: Flux pinning; High temperature superconductor; Hot deformation; MgB 2; Superconductivity
Index Keywords: Cooling; Energy dissipation; Energy storage; Hydrogen; Magnesium compounds; Nitrogen; Superconductivity; Synthesis (chemical); Cooling technology; Energy-saving technology; Logic-electronics; Rotational energy; High temperature superconductors

Title: Electronic structure study of hydrogen storage materials
Source title: Advanced Materials for Energy Conversion II
Affiliations: Thermodyn./Phys.-Chim. Hydrures/O., Université Paris XI, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: Gupta, M., Thermodyn./Phys.-Chim. Hydrures/O., Université Paris XI, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France; Crivello, J.-C., Thermodyn./Phys.-Chim. Hydrures/O., Université Paris XI, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France
Abstract: First principles electronic structure studies can provide, at a microscopic level, an understanding of the modification of the most fundamental properties of the matrix on hydrogen uptake such as metal-insulator transitions, magnetism, superconductivity, as well as a basic understanding of the hydrogen storage properties relevant to applications. To illustrating the latter point, we present an investigation of the properties of the hydrogen storage Ni-substituted LaNi5 intermetallic compounds. The effects of mono substitutions of Ni by 3d elements (Mn, Fe, Co), an s - p element of the 3d series, Cu, as well as by s-p elements of the IIIA (Al) and IVA series (Si, Ge, Sn) for several substitution rates are presented. We discuss the trends observed in the electronic structure and the factors that control : the stability of the intermetallic and their corresponding hydrides and the maximum hydrogen absorption capacity. We found that besides the elastic effects associated to volume changes on Ni substitutions, chemical bonding effects and band filling effects play a crucial role in controlling the storage properties of the materials. We also analyze the effect of polysubstitutions at the Ni site in LaNi3.5Al0.25Mn0.5Co0.75, a composition close to that of an industrial compound of good electrochemical performances, and we discuss the results in light of thermodynamic and spectroscopic data.
Author Keywords: Electronic structure; Hydrides of intermetallic compounds; Hydrogen storage
Index Keywords: Chemical bonds; Cobalt; Electronic structure; Energy storage; Iron; Manganese; Metal insulator transition; Nickel; Substitution reactions; Band filling; Electronic effects; Hydrogen absorption; Hydrogen content; Hydrogen

Source title: Advanced Materials for Energy Conversion II
