Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: The MAN Nutzfahrzeuge Group in Germany has unveiled a newly developed low-floor scheduled-service bus with hybrid fuel-cell drive. The new generation MAN fuel cell bus combines a Ballard Xcellsis™ HY-80 fuel cell engine with a high-performance, high-power nickel metal hybrid battery as the energy storage unit. The HX-80 uses the proven Ballard Mark 902 PEM fuel cell module, which produces 68 kw net electric power. The hydrogen gas is stored at 350 bar in cylinders on the vehicle roof, and supplies a daily requirement with ≈ 39 kg, offering a range of over 300 km. The MAN fuel cell bus has been extensively tested by the German technical advisory organization TÜV, and approved for public transport authority operations, including parking in garages, without any restrictions.

Title: In brief: H2 R&D center for Japanese university
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: A new Japanese hydrogen energy R&D center is being established at Kyushu University, in a cooperative effort that also involves some 60 companies, as well as the Fukuoka prefectural government. Industrial participants include Toyota Motor, Nippon Steel, Nippon Oil, Nissan Motor, Matsushita Electrical Industrial, Hitachi, and Mitsubishi Corporation. The center will handle R&D and testing of a range of technologies from generation to storage, transportation, and use of hydrogen. It will be located at Kyushu University's new campus, expected to open in fiscal 2005 near the city of Fukuoka, on the southern island of Kyushu.

Title: In brief: US navy funding SOFC component R&D
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: The US Office Naval Research has awarded Ion America Corp, based in Mountain View, CA, a $2.7 million contract to develop advanced SOFC stack components for primary and regenerative stationary applications. Last September 2003, the National Energy Technology Laboratory in Golden, CO, entered into a cooperative agreement with Ion America to optimize and demonstrate a regenerative SOFC system. This project, for which DOE is providing $500,000 of the total $700,000 cost, will screen electrode materials for reversible fuel cell functionality. It will develop heat storage methods, initiate the design of a reversible SOFC stack, the test viable concepts using a breadboard system.

Title: New mass transit concept from Holland
Source title: Diesel Progress North American Edition
Authors with affiliations: Siuru, B.
Abstract: The features of a mass transit system by Advanced Public Transport systems BV of Holland is discussed. The system provides mass transit in areas that are not economically served by conventional trams, streetcars or light rail systems. The Phileas Advanced Public Transport (APT) has engineered a mass transit system by combining the advantages of rail-based systems with the flexibility and low investment costs of a bus system. The Phileas system uses a series electric-hybrid propulsion system powered by a Ford WSG 1068 engine. The engine operates at a constant speed for optimum efficiency, consuming 30% less fuel than an equivalent LPG bus.
Index Keywords: Magnetic plugs; Mass transit systems; Phileas Advanced Public Transport System (CO); Traffic lanes; Automotive industry; Costs; Electric motors; Energy storage; Energy utilization; Ground vehicles; Investments; Liquefied petroleum gas; Motor transportation; Sensors; Steering; Torque; Trolley cars; Vehicle wheels; Automotive engineering

Title: Successfully meeting and greeting
Source title: Fluid Power Journal
Authors with affiliations: Ramsey, L.
Abstract: The ten strategies for getting off to a good start are discussed. A day in the life of every business person is made up of a series of meetings and greetings. The strategies include: stand up when meeting someone, smile, make eye contact, introduce yourself immediately, include a statement about who you are when necessary, offer a firm handshake, learn how to make smooth introductions, know who the more important person is, pay attention to names when you meet people and use first names of people whom you have just met only after they give you permission. When one is confident of the rules for the critical initial encounters, he/she will have a solid start for long-term profitable relationships.
Index Keywords: Crushing; Energy storage; Industrial management; Professional aspects; Technical presentations; Business prospects; Eye contact; Facial expression; Profitable relationships; Strategic planning

Title: US utilities claim billions
Source title: Nuclear Engineering International
Authors with affiliations: Fabian, T.
Abstract: The US Department of Energy's (DoE) potential liability of billions of dollars from lawsuits brought by nuclear power producers is discussed. The nuclear power producers claim that they have suffered financial damage from the department's failure to accept spent fuel by congressionally mandated deadline. The generators are arguing that they are paying twice for spent fuel management. The lawsuit seeks to recoup costs for building dry storage facilities, reracking spent fuel pools and providing funds for the Private Fuel Storage LLC.
Index Keywords: Electricity; Energy policy; Finance; Industrial economics; Laws and legislation; Nuclear energy; Power generation; Power plants; Dry storage facility; Financial damage; Lawsuits; Spent nuclear fuels (SNF); US Department of Energy (DoE); Energy management

Title: High-level waste of time

Abstract: As Germany's nuclear industry generates a flow of decommissioning waste, the government has delegated the obligation of the final storage to its subordinate authority. The operations of the nuclear power generators are responsible for residual matters resulting from the use of nuclear energy. Thus, they are required to either reuse it in a non-polluting manner or dispose them as specified by the laws. The duration of the storage and the final repository open are assumed to be mainly determined by the capacity of the plant.

Abstract: We performed shock tube operations with a layer of diaphragm being ruptured by laser beam irradiation. Mylar or Cellophane was examined as the diaphragm material. It has been demonstrated that shock tube can be operated with this new technique. The absorbed energy depends on the material and thickness of the diaphragm and is an important control parameter.

Title: Scaling of losses in small IC AERO engines with engine size
Source title: AIAA Paper
Affiliations: Department of Aerospace Engineering, Univ. of Maryland at College Park, College Park, MD 20742, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cadou, C., Department of Aerospace Engineering, Univ. of Maryland at College Park, College Park, MD 20742, United States; Menon, S., Department of Aerospace Engineering, Univ. of Maryland at College Park, College Park, MD 20742, United States
Abstract: Losses in internal combustion engines being developed for small (< 5kg) unmanned air vehicles are expected to become increasingly important as the size of the engine is reduced. This is a direct consequence of the fact that the surface to volume ratio of these engines increases with decreasing engine size. The performance of three small IC engines ranging from ∼400g to ∼10g was evaluated on a small dynamometer in order to see how engine performance scales with size. A power law was found that relates engine power to engine mass. However, large variations in the fuel air ratios maintained by the engines fuel delivery systems prevented observation of any scaling of engine efficiency with size.
Index Keywords: Energy storage efficiency; Engine efficiency; Nitromethane; Computation theory; Mass transfer; Methanol; Mixtures; Propulsion; Torque; Internal combustion engines

Title: Quick takes: Vaalco Energy Inc...
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: Vaalco Energy Inc has cased the vertical portion of the Etame 5H development oil well off Gabon and will drill the horizontal portion following installation of flowlines and umbilicals to tie in the well and the next development well, Etame 6H, to the floating production, storage, and offloading facility moored in the field. First production, to start in August 2004, is expected to increase Etame field production to > 20,000 bpd of oil.

Authors: Donnelly F.W., Cousineau R.L., Horsley R.N.M.
Title: Hybrid technology for the rail industry
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Rail Transportation Division (Publication) RTD
Affiliations: RailPower Technologies Corp., 50 Fell Avenue, North Vancouver, BC V7P 3S2, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Donnelly, F.W., RailPower Technologies Corp., 50 Fell Avenue, North Vancouver, BC V7P 3S2, Canada; Cousineau, R.L., RailPower Technologies Corp., 50 Fell Avenue, North Vancouver, BC V7P 3S2, Canada; Horsley, R.N.M., RailPower Technologies Corp., 50 Fell Avenue, North Vancouver, BC V7P 3S2, Canada
Abstract: A new type of battery-dominant hybrid technology has been developed for the rail industry. Switcher locomotive service is characterized by highly variable power output use. This variability in demand is exploited to allow the use of a significantly smaller, fuel efficient, Tier 2 certified, low maintenance engine and generator combination to supply energy to the traction motors and to the application-engineered battery pack. In the last three years, a demonstrator vehicle, the Green Goat®, has been designed, tested, constructed and put into field trials for 18 months in various locations and types of service, with impressive (performance and operational) results. The design, concept, field trials results, as well as applications of the technology to other types of service, are discussed.
Index Keywords: Cost reduction; Duty cycles; Storage battery technology; Cost effectiveness; Electric batteries; Electric generators; Electric locomotives; Operations research; Railroad cars; Railroad yards and terminals; Railroads; Storage battery vehicles; Traction motors; Railroad transportation

Title: Time- and energy-efficient organization of objects in a broadcast environment
Source title: Proceedings - 2004 International Conference on Information and Communication Technologies: From Theory to Applications, ICTTA 2004

Abstract: Time- and energy-efficient organization of objects in a broadcast environment was discussed. The main advantage of broadcasting is the fact that it scales as the number of users increase, eliminating the need to multiplex the bandwidth among the users. Furthermore, broadcasting can be considered as additional storage. An object cannot be accessed until all the data prior to that object in sequence has been scanned.

Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Rail Transportation Division (Publication) RTD

Abstract: The applications of various technologies in traction power systems are discussed. The multi-function relays (MFR) are capable of replacing whole group of relays used for equipment protection and automated control. The thyristor controlled rectifiers (TCR) offers important benefit of regulated DC voltage at substation bus output. The flywheel-based energy storage system installed by LIRR is important innovation for experimental use.

Authors: Barclay J.A., Rowe A.M., Barclay M.A.
Title: Pressure Build-Up in LNG and LH2 Vehicular Cryogenic Storage Tanks
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Prometheus Energy Company, Bellevue, WA  98006, United States; Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Victoria, Victoria, BC  V8W 3P6, Canada; Department of Mechanical Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, State College, PA  18603, United States
Authors with affiliations: Barclay, J.A., Prometheus Energy Company, Bellevue, WA  98006, United States; Rowe, A.M., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Victoria, Victoria, BC  V8W 3P6, Canada; Barclay, M.A., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, State College, PA  18603, United States
Abstract: The use of LNG and LH2 as fuels in heavy duty vehicles is increasing steadily because cryogenic liquids provides superior volumetric and gravimetric energy densities compared to other means of on-board storage. Although several sizes and types of tanks exist, a typical vehicular storage tank has a volume of ∼400 liters (∼100 gallons). The pressure in the ullage space of a tank freshly filled is usually ∼0.25 MPa but may vary during use from ∼0.25 MPa (∼20 psig) to ∼0.92 MPa (∼120 psig). Cryogenic vehicular tanks are typically dual-walled, stainless steel vessels with vacuum and superinsulation isolation between the inner and outer vessel walls. The heat leaks into such tanks are measured as a percentage boil-off per day. For a storage tank of vehicular size range, the boil-off may be ∼ 1 % day, depending upon the cryogen and the quality of the tank. The corresponding heat leak into the cryogenic liquid vaporizes a certain amount of liquid that in turn increases the pressure in the tank which in turn significantly influences the properties of the cryogens. We have used a novel approach to calculate the increase in pressure of LNG and LH2 in a closed cryogenic vessel with a fixed heat leak as a function of time using real equations of state for the properties of the cryogens. The method and results for the time it takes for a freshly filled tank to increase in pressure from the filling pressure of ∼0.25 MPa to a venting pressure of ∼1.73 MPa are presented. © 2004 American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: Cryogenic liquids; Equations of state; Fuel storage; Heat engines; Cryogenic storage tank; Cryogenic vessel; Filling pressures; Gravimetric energy densities; Heavy duty vehicles; Increase in pressure; Pressure build up; Stainless steel vessels; Tanks (containers)

Authors: Hastings L.J., Hedayat A., Bryant C.B., Flachbart R.H.
Title: Liquid Hydrogen Zero-Boiloff Testing and Analysis for Long-Term Orbital Storage
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Alpha Technology Inc., Huntsville, AL  35801, United States; NASA Marshall Space Flight Center, Marshall Space Flight CenterAL  35812, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hastings, L.J., Alpha Technology Inc., Huntsville, AL  35801, United States; Hedayat, A., NASA Marshall Space Flight Center, Marshall Space Flight CenterAL  35812, United States; Bryant, C.B., NASA Marshall Space Flight Center, Marshall Space Flight CenterAL  35812, United States; Flachbart, R.H., NASA Marshall Space Flight Center, Marshall Space Flight CenterAL  35812, United States
Abstract: Advancement of cryocooler and passive insulation technologies in recent years has improved the prospects for zero-boiloff (ZBO) storage of cryogenic fluids. The ZBO concept involves the use of a cryocooler/radiator system to balance storage system incoming and extracted energy such that zero boiloff (no venting) occurs. A large-scale demonstration of the ZBO concept was conducted using the Marshall Space Flight Center (MSFC) multipurpose hydrogen test bed (MHTB) along with a commercial cryocooler unit. The liquid hydrogen (LH2) was withdrawn from the tank, passed through the cryocooler heat exchanger, and then the chilled liquid was sprayed back into the tank through a spray bar. The spray bar recirculation system was designed to provide destratification independent of ullage and liquid positions in a zero-gravity environment. The insulated MHTB tank, combined with the vacuum chamber conditions, enabled orbital storage simulation. ZBO was demonstrated for fill levels of 95%, 50%, and 25%. At each fill level, a steady-state boiloff test was performed prior to operating the cryocooler to establish the baseline heat leak. Control system logic based on real-time thermal data and ullage pressure response was implemented to automatically provide a constant tank pressure. A comparison of test data and analytical results is presented in this paper. © 2004 American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: Cooling; Cryogenic equipment; Cryogenic liquids; Digital storage; Flight control systems; Heat engines; Liquefied gases; Space flight; Tanks (containers); Analytical results; De-stratification; Extracted energies; Insulation technology; Liquid hydrogens; Marshall Space Flight Center; Pressure response; Recirculation systems; Hydrogen storage

Title: Study of Production Technology for Slush Hydrogen
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Hydrogen Energy Systems Dept. NEDO, 1-1-3 Higashi-Ikeburo, Toshima-ku, Tokyo, 170-6028, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ohira, K., Hydrogen Energy Systems Dept. NEDO, 1-1-3 Higashi-Ikeburo, Toshima-ku, Tokyo, 170-6028, Japan
Abstract: Slush hydrogen is a two-phase solid-liquid cryogenic fluid consisting of solid hydrogen particles in liquid hydrogen. Various applications are anticipated, including fuel for reusable space shuttles, coolant for cold neutron generation and for superconducting equipment, as well as the transport and storage of hydrogen as a clean energy source. This paper reports on the results of laboratory scale experiments involving three slush hydrogen production methods: the spray method, the freeze-thaw method, and the auger method. © 2004 American Institute of Physics.
Index Keywords: Cryogenics; Hydrogen production; Liquefied gases; Space shuttles; Clean energy sources; Liquid hydrogens; Production technology; Reusable space shuttles; Slush hydrogen; Solid hydrogen; Storage of hydrogen; Two-phase solid-liquid cryogenic fluid; Hydrogen storage

Title: Thermal Performance Testing of Glass Microspheres under Cryogenic Vacuum Conditions
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: NASA Kennedy Space Center, YA-C2-T, Kennedy Space CenterFL  32899, United States; Sierra Lobo, Inc., SLI-2, Kennedy Space CenterFL  32899, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fesmire, J.E., NASA Kennedy Space Center, YA-C2-T, Kennedy Space CenterFL  32899, United States; Augustynowicz, S.D., Sierra Lobo, Inc., SLI-2, Kennedy Space CenterFL  32899, United States
Abstract: A key element of space launch vehicles and systems is thermal insulation for cryogenic tanks and piping. Glass microspheres, or glass bubbles, represent an alternative insulation material for a number of applications. Composite materials and engineered thermal insulation systems are also being developed based on the use of glass bubbles as the main constituent material. Commonly used materials, such as spray-on foam insulation, or SOFI, for vehicle tanks and perlite powder for ground storage tanks, are targeted for replacement with the new-technology systems that use glass bubbles. Complete thermal characterization of the glass bubbles is the first step toward producing the engineering solutions required for the energy-efficient, low-maintenance cryogenic systems of the future. Thermal performance testing of the glass microsphere material was successfully completed at the Cryogenics Test Laboratory of NASA Kennedy Space Center. The test measurements were made at the full temperature difference (typical boundary temperatures of 78 kelvin [K] and 293 K) and included the full cold-vacuum pressure range. The results are reported in apparent thermal conductivity (k-value) and mean heat flux. © 2004 American Institute of Physics.

Title: A Summary of Liquid Hydrogen and Cryogenic Technologies in Japan's WE-NET Project
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Hydrogen Energy Systems Dept. NEDO, 1-1-3 Higashi-Ikebukuro, Toshima-Ku, Tokyo, 170-6028, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ohira, K., Hydrogen Energy Systems Dept. NEDO, 1-1-3 Higashi-Ikebukuro, Toshima-Ku, Tokyo, 170-6028, Japan
Abstract: The overall objective of the WE-NET (World Energy Network System) project is to construct clean energy systems using hydrogen as a medium, focusing on the development of technologies for hydrogen production, transport, storage and utilization. The project is promoted by NEDO under the auspices of the Japan's Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry. The research and development of Phase I (1993-1998) mainly involved ascertaining long-term goals. Based on the results of Phase I, Phase II (1999-2002) entailed promoting the steady introduction of hydrogen energy into society and proceeded with technical development leading to practical applications in the short and medium term such as the demonstration of hydrogen refueling stations for hydrogen fuel cell vehicles. The WE-NET project was successfully completed in 2002 and a new five-year hydrogen project was initiated from 2003. This report summarizes the major results achieved during the Phase I and II in the area of liquid hydrogen and cryogenic technologies, as well as describing related hydrogen projects. © 2004 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Arenius D., Chronis W., Creel J., Dixon K., Ganni V., Knudsen P.
Title: Cryogenic System for the Spallation Neutron Source
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility, 12000 Jefferson Avenue, Newport News, VA  23606, United States
Authors with affiliations: Arenius, D., Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility, 12000 Jefferson Avenue, Newport News, VA  23606, United States; Chronis, W., Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility, 12000 Jefferson Avenue, Newport News, VA  23606, United States; Creel, J., Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility, 12000 Jefferson Avenue, Newport News, VA  23606, United States; Dixon, K., Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility, 12000 Jefferson Avenue, Newport News, VA  23606, United States; Ganni, V., Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility, 12000 Jefferson Avenue, Newport News, VA  23606, United States; Knudsen, P., Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility, 12000 Jefferson Avenue, Newport News, VA  23606, United States
Abstract: The Spallation Neutron Source (SNS) is a neutron-scattering facility being built at Oak Ridge, TN for the US Department of Energy. The SNS accelerator linac consists of superconducting radio-frequency (SRF) cavities in cryostats (cryomodules). The linac cryomodules are cooled to 2.1 K by a 2300 watt cryogenic refrigeration system. As an SNS partner laboratory, Jefferson Lab is responsible for the installed integrated cryogenic system design for the SNS linac accelerator consisting of major subsystem equipment engineered and procured from industry. Jefferson Lab's work included developing the major vendor subsystem equipment procurement specifications, equipment procurement, and the integrated system engineering support of the field installation and commissioning. The major cryogenic system components include liquid nitrogen storage, gaseous helium storage, cryogen distribution transfer line system, 2.1-K cold box consisting of four stages of cold compressors, 4.5-K cold box, warm helium compressors with its associated oil removal, gas management, helium purification, gas impurity monitoring systems, and the supportive utilities of electrical power, cooling water and instrument air. The system overview, project organization, the important aspects, and the capabilities of the cryogenic system are described. © 2004 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Al-Karaki J.N., Ul-Mustafa R., Kamal A.E.
Title: Data aggregation in wireless sensor networks - Exact and approximate algorithms
Source title: IEEE Workshop on High Performance Switching and Routing, HPSR
Affiliations: Laboratory for Advanced Networks, Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Iowa State University, Ames, IA 50011, United States
Authors with affiliations: Al-Karaki, J.N., Laboratory for Advanced Networks, Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Iowa State University, Ames, IA 50011, United States; Ul-Mustafa, R., Laboratory for Advanced Networks, Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Iowa State University, Ames, IA 50011, United States; Kamal, A.E., Laboratory for Advanced Networks, Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Iowa State University, Ames, IA 50011, United States
Abstract: A fundamental challenge in the design of Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) is to maximize their lifetimes. Data aggregation has emerged as a basic approach in WSNs in order to reduce the number of transmissions of sensor nodes, and hence minimizing the overall power consumption in the network. In this paper, we study optimal data aggregation in WSNs. Data aggregation is affected by several factors such as the placement of aggregation points, the aggregation function, and the density of the sensors in the network. The determination of an optimal selection of aggregation point is thus extremely important. We present an exact as well as approximate algorithms to find the minimum number of aggregation points in order to maximize the network lifetime. Our algorithms use a fixed virtual wireless backbone that is built on top of the physical topology. We also study the tradeoffs between energy savings and the potential delay involved in the data aggregation process. Numerical results show that our approach provides substantial energy savings.
Index Keywords: Data aggregation; Local aggregators (LA); Physical parameters; Wireless sensor networks (WSN); Algorithms; Data acquisition; Energy storage; Linear programming; Network protocols; Power transmission; Routers; Sensors; Topology; Wireless telecommunication systems; Telecommunication networks

Title: Disposal of carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas, for pressure maintenance in a steam-based thermal process for recovery of heavy oil and bitumen
Source title: SPE International Thermal Operations and Heavy Oil Symposium Proceedings
Affiliations: Alberta Research Council, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Law, D.H.-S., Alberta Research Council, Canada
Abstract: The world is moving towards a carbon constrained economy and there would be pressure to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. The steam-based thermal processes are energy intensive and hence, high carbon dioxide (CO 2), a greenhouse gas (GHG), emissions. There are potentials for the reduction of CO 2 emissions by capturing and disposal of CO 2 for pressure maintenance during the later stage of these thermal operations. This paper describes the numerical investigation on the feasibility of using CO 2 for pressure maintenance during a steam-assisted gravity drainage (SAGD) wind-down process in an Athabasca bitumen reservoir in Northern Alberta, Canada. It is found that SAGD wind-down process with CO 2 injection is feasible although oil recovery performance is slightly sacrificed. The oil recovery performance during the wind-down period with pure CO 2 injection is slightly better than those with other gas injections such as flue gas (i.e., a mixture of nitrogen (N 2) and CO 2) and pure N 2 mainly because CO 2 acts as a solvent in reduction of the bitumen viscosity. From a GHG storage point of view, CO 2 storage capacity of approximately 2 × 10 7 sm 3 (or 37,244 tonne) in a single Athabasca-type SAGD pattern with dimensions of 100 m wide, 500 m long and 25 m thick can be achieved. CO 2 balance indicates that CO 2 stored during SAGD wind-down processes is less than the CO 2 emitted from steam generation during the initial SAGD period. However, "CO 2 credit" in the order of 10,000 tonne can still be claimed in a single SAGD pattern because using CO 2 as steam substitute during the wind-down process results in less CO 2 emission compared to continuously operating the SAGD process. Recently, numerical prediction in this study has been validated qualitatively by the experimental observations of SAGD pressure maintenance from a low-pressure/low-temperature CT experiment and a high-pressure/high-temperature 2-D experiment conducted at the Alberta Research Council (ARC).
Index Keywords: Greenhouse gases (GHG); Steam assisted drainage gravity (SAGD); Thermal processes; Additives; Carbon dioxide; Industrial emissions; Numerical methods; Particulate emissions; Pressure effects; Steam; Viscosity; Oil fields

Title: Economical and environmental aspects of heat pump system utilizing unused energy in aquarium
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Power Division (Publication) PWR
Affiliations: Department of Mathematics, Shimane University, 1060 Nishikawatsu, Matsue, Shimane 690-8504, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Okamoto, S., Department of Mathematics, Shimane University, 1060 Nishikawatsu, Matsue, Shimane 690-8504, Japan
Abstract: This paper introduces a heat pump system with a latent heat storage utilizing seawater installed in an aquarium. Heat from the seawater is collected and used as the heat source for the heat pump system. This maintains the indoor conditions at constant temperature and relative humidity. With regard to the heat pump system using low-temperature unutilized heat source, development is introduced on a heat source load responsive heat pump system, with combines a load variation responsive heat pump utilizing seawater with a latent heat (ice plus water slurry) storage system using nighttime electric power serving for electric power load leveling. The desired outcome would be to show that the costs of generating heat energy with the seawater-source heat pump are significantly less than those with the air-source heat pump and the oil-fired system. Additionally, the CO2 emissions for the seawater-source heat pump compare favourably as they maybe less than those for the other conventional assumed systems described.

Title: Quick takes: Duke energy gas transmission, Houston,...
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: Duke Energy Gas Transmission is expanding by 8 bcf the natural gas storage capacity at its Market Hub Partners' (MHP) Egan facility in Acadia Parish, LA. Egan has two existing 8 bcf caverns, and MHP anticipates to leach out a third like-sized cavern by mid-to-late 2006. Egan has a 12-mo injection-withdrawal cycle capability and > 1.2 bcf of current gas deliverability. MHP has also received approval to develop a salt dome storage facility in Copiah County, MS.

Source title: Electronic Design
Authors with affiliations: Allan, R.
Abstract: The attainment of precision trimming levels from 0.1% to 0.002% by low-cost CMOS electronically trimmable resistors is discussed. Resistor trimming is a method of optimizing sensor circuit performance for both discrete and monolithic IC sensors. The trimming resistor structure, suspended over the cavity, is heat-cycled for temperature coefficient of resistance (TCR) adjustments. Resistor pairs can also be trimmed and their TCRs matched, by placing an additional heating element on the chip.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; CMOS integrated circuits; Data storage equipment; Electric resistance; Energy dissipation; Heating; Lasers; Microelectromechanical devices; Microprocessor chips; Sensors; Silicon; Electrical signals; Nonvolatile memory; Rejustors; Resistor trimming; Resistors

Authors: Asadi G., Miremadi S.G., Zarandi H.R., Ejlali A.
Title: Evaluation of fault-tolerant designs implemented on SRAM-based FPGAs
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE Pacific Rim International Symposium on Dependable Computing
Affiliations: Department of Computer Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Asadi, G., Department of Computer Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Iran; Miremadi, S.G., Department of Computer Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Iran; Zarandi, H.R., Department of Computer Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Iran; Ejlali, A., Department of Computer Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Iran
Abstract: The technology of SRAM-based devices is sensible to Single Event Upsets (SEUs) that may be induced mainly by high energy heavy ions and neutrons. This paper presents a framework for the evaluation of fault-tolerant designs implemented on SRAM-based FPGAs using emulated SEUs. The SEU injection process is performed by inserting emulated SEUs in the device using its configuration bitstream file. An Altera FPGA, i.e. the Flex10K200, and the ITC'99 benchmark circuits are used to experimentally evaluate the method. The results show that between 32 to 45 percent of SEUs injected to the device propagate to the output terminals of the device.
Index Keywords: Commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS); Logic elements (LE); Programmable logic devices (PLD); Single event upsets (SEU); Benchmarking; Costs; Embedded systems; Fault tolerant computer systems; Input output programs; Neutrons; Servers; Static random access storage; Field programmable gate arrays

Title: Personal servers as digital keys
Source title: Proceedings - Second IEEE Annual Conference on Pervasive Computing and Communications, PerCom
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, University of Copenhagen, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Beaufour, A., Department of Computer Science, University of Copenhagen, Denmark; Bonnet, P., Department of Computer Science, University of Copenhagen, Denmark
Abstract: Personal servers are an attractive concept: People carry around a device that takes care of computing, storage and communication on their behalf in a pervasive computing environment. So far personal servers have mainly been considered for accessing personal information. In this paper, we consider personal servers in the context of a digital key system. Digital keys are an interesting alternative to physical key s for mail or good delivery companies whose employees access tens of private buildings every day. In this paper, we present a digital key system tailored for the current incarnation of personal severs, i.e., a Bluetooth-enabled mobile phone. We describe how to use Bluetooth for this application, we present a simple authentication protocol and we provide a detailled analysis of response time and energy consumption on the mobile phone.
Index Keywords: Bluetooth-enabled mobile phone; Digital keys; Personal servers; Cryptography; Energy utilization; Information retrieval; Mobile telecommunication systems; Network protocols; Personal digital assistants; Servers

Title: General interest: NGSA predicts summer natural gas markets will stay hot
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Authors with affiliations: Lorenzetti, M.
Abstract: According to the Natural Gas Supply Association (NGSA), there will be a tight balance between supply and demand over the next few months. Unlike in 2003, storage and production are expected to be less of a factor for cost run-ups this summer (2004). However, that will not be enough to offset a wave of higher overall energy costs among competing fuels. According to the NGSA-commissioned forecast, the US' overall demand will increase ≤ 3%, up from 49.5 bcf/day last summer (2003) to 51 bcf/day this summer. Imports will play an increasingly important role. LNG imports will increase 50% this summer, from 1.6 bcf/day last summer to 2.4 bcf/day. There will be slightly less Canadian gas delivered to the US because of higher demand; so overall imports will be flat.

Title: Using cache mapping to improve memory performance of handheld devices
Source title: 2004 IEEE International Symposium on Performance Analysis of Systems and Software
Affiliations: Department of Computer Sciences, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States
Authors with affiliations: Xu, R., Department of Computer Sciences, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States; Li, Z., Department of Computer Sciences, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN 47907, United States
Abstract: Processors such as the Intel StrongARM SA-1110 and the Intel XScale provide flexible control over the cache management to achieve better cache utilization. Programs can specify the cache mapping policy for each virtual page, i.e. mapping it to the main cache, the mini-cache, or neither. For the latter case, the page is marked as noncacheable. In this paper, we use memory profiling to guide such page-based cache mapping. We model the cache mapping problem and prove that finding the optimal cache mapping is NP-hard. We then present a heuristic to select the mapping. Execution time measurement shows that our heuristic can improve the performance from 1% to 22% for a set of test programs. As a byproduct of performance enhancement, we also save the energy by 4% to 28%.
Author Keywords: Cache bypass; Cache mapping; Handheld devices; Mini-cache; Multiple caches
Index Keywords: Cache bypass; Cache mapping; Handheld devices; Mini-cache; Multiple caches; Computer hardware; Computer science; Costs; Data reduction; Heuristic methods; Mapping; Program compilers; Storage allocation (computer); Cache memory

Authors: Munitz A., Dayan D., Pitchure D., Ricker R.
Title: Dynamic mechanical analysis of pure Mg and Mg AZ31 alloy
Source title: Magnesium Technology 2004
Affiliations: Nuclear Research Center-Negev, P. O. Box 9001, Beer-Sheeva 841900, Israel; Natl. Inst. of Std. and Technology, Metallurgy Division, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States
Authors with affiliations: Munitz, A., Nuclear Research Center-Negev, P. O. Box 9001, Beer-Sheeva 841900, Israel; Dayan, D., Nuclear Research Center-Negev, P. O. Box 9001, Beer-Sheeva 841900, Israel; Pitchure, D., Natl. Inst. of Std. and Technology, Metallurgy Division, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States; Ricker, R., Natl. Inst. of Std. and Technology, Metallurgy Division, Gaithersburg, MD 20899, United States
Abstract: Dynamic mechanical analyses were performed on pure Mg and Mg AZ31 alloy to study the impact of thermo-mechanical state and grain structure on the complex modulus (E*=E'+iE''). The storage modulus (E') of pure Mg was found to be 40.0±2.5 GPa and independent of grain size. A thermally activated loss modulus (E'') peak with an activation energy of 1.39±0.19 eV, which is very close to the activation energy of the self-diffusion of Mg (1.408 eV), was observed and attributed to a grain boundary relaxation mechanism. The temperature of this peak depends on orientation with respect to direction of solidification as well as on heat treatment. The behavior of Mg AZ31 alloy was similar to that of pure Mg. The storage modulus determined for this alloy was 42.0±2.5 GPa and it was independent of rolling direction. The thermally activated peak in Mg AZ31 was sharper and was observed at lower temperatures (167-174°C) with an activation energy of 1.68±0.04 eV.
Author Keywords: Dynamic mechanical analysis; Internal friction; Mg alloys; Young modulus
Index Keywords: Grain structures; Storage modulus; Strain amplitudes; Thermal activation; Activation energy; Automotive industry; Dynamic mechanical analysis; Elastic moduli; Energy dissipation; Grain boundaries; Grain size and shape; Heating; Internal friction; Magnesium printing plates; Relaxation processes; Residual stresses; Rolling; Solidification; Magnesium alloys

Title: Quick takes: The 2-year old firm...
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: The 2-yr-old firm DKRW Energy LLC of Houston, TX, plans to build an LNG terminal at Puerto Libertad on the Gulf of California in the state of Sonora, Mexico. DKRW subsidiary Sonora Pacific LNG has signed a cooperation agreement with the government of Sonora tentatively authorizing the purchase of uninhabited industrial land construction of a 1.3 bcf/day regasification and storage terminal is slated for middle 2005, with start-up expected in middle 2008. The proposed project includes distribution pipelines in Sonora, a proposed export pipeline through Nogales to interconnect with an El Paso Pipeline system east of Tucson, and possibly lines to serve the state of Sinaloa, according to Tom White, Sonora Pacific LNG managing partner.

Title: General interest: Long-term contracts vital in EU free gas market
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: Long-term supply contracts will play a more important role in the new EU free gas market than originally planned, according to London-based analyst Prospex Research Ltd. In a recently released report, such contracts would stifle competition in the EU's free gas market, scheduled for full opening to non-household gas consumers by July 2004 and for complete market opening by July 2007. However, gas supply security has become a growing concern because of Europe's increasing reliance on imported gas. Fifty percent of Europe's consumption will be imported by 2020 and long term contracts are now being viewed as "an essential part of European gas market". Gas demand in Europe has grown about 4%/yr since 1990, driven by increased use of gas-fired power generation, especially in combined-cycle gas turbine plants, and by industrial energy consumers switching from more-expensive and environmentally less-friendly fuels, e.g., oil and coal. In 2002, Europe's gas demand represented 24% of world gas consumption and the region produced enough gas to meet 67% of its requirements. However, all European gas production, except that of Norway, has passed its peak and is in decline. More than 50% of the gas Europe now uses crosses at least one national border via interconnections with the 187,000 km of gas transmission pipelines that traverse the region, most operated on a national basis within each country. The system links to production in the North Sea and to delivery pipelines from Algeria and Russia, which provide most of the EU's gas imports. Underground storage facilities, used to meet seasonal demand fluctuations, have capacity to hold 14% of Europe's total annual consumption. LNG volumes, which accounted for 10 % of imports in 2002, are expected to double or quadruple when currently planned receiving terminals, regasification facilities, and pipelines are in place.

Title: A 180mV FFT processor using subthreshold circuit techniques

Affiliations: Massachusetts Inst. of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wang, A., Massachusetts Inst. of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States; Chandrakasan, A., Massachusetts Inst. of Technology, Cambridge, MA, United States
Abstract: Minimizing energy requires scaling supply voltages below device thresholds. Logic and memory design techniques allowing subthreshold operation are developed and demonstrated. The fabricated 1024-point FFT processor operates down to 180mV using a standard 0 18μm CMOS logic process while using 155nJ/FFT at the optimal operating point.

Authors with affiliations: Warneke, B.A., University of California, Berkeley, CA, United States; Pister, K.S.J., University of California, Berkeley, CA, United States
Abstract: A 12pJ/instruction microcontroller with embedded SRAM designed specifically for use in mm 3 wireless sensor nodes is described. It features highly independent subsystems for sensor sampling, transmission, and receiving that maximize the datapath sleep time as well as 100nW integrated oscillators with rapid power-cycling. Designed in 0.25μm technology, the 0.38mm 2 core comsumes 5.9μW from a 1V supply when running at 500kHz.

Abstract: A single-chip solution for COMBO driver applications is presented. The approach features a multiple-word accessing mechanism to reduce SDRAM bandwidth requirement. After fabrication in 0.22μm 1P5M CMOS process, the proposed COMBO SoC supports a 16x DVD speed with 965mW power consumption.

Abstract: The proposals to construct a new hydrogen energy system on the scale of the power grid are discussed. U.S. costs alone are estimated at $200 billion to $500 billion. A new generation of nuclear reactors capable of generating temperatures high enough to break water's bond is also envisaged. Renewable hydrogen is envisioned as a means to transmit remote renewable resources to distant markets.

Title: A fast thermal activity interpreter for controlling chemical reaction hazards
Source title: Process Safety Progress
Affiliations: Fauske and Associates Inc., Burr Ridge, IL 60527, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fauske, H.K., Fauske and Associates Inc., Burr Ridge, IL 60527, United States
Abstract: A quick and inexpensive method to facilitate product control in assuring safe chemicals management in transportation and storage is introduced. Product safety measures related to large quantities of reactive chemicals require frequent measurements of thermal activity (TA) at low temperature in order to control the potential for contamination, etc., that can accelerate the reaction rate. The fast thermal activity interpreter (FTAI) instrument is designed to monitor chemical systems undergoing gaseous decomposition reactions with the capability of interpreting TAs of the order of 1 μ W/g or a self beat rate of the order of 10-5°C min-1. Recognizing the need for frequent sampling, the FTAI takes about 1 h to run an analysis. The FTAI concept provides an easy means for determining activation energies and rate laws of gaseous decomposition reactions at ambient temperature conditions and is also well suited to measure material oxidation or corrosion reaction rates involving oxygen consumption. © 2004 American Institute of Chemical Engineers.
Index Keywords: Activation energy; Contamination; Corrosion protection; Decomposition; Low temperature effects; Oxidation; Oxygen; Rate constants; Sampling; Thermal effects; Chemicals management; Product control; Thermal activity (TA); Accident prevention; chemical handling; chemical reaction; hazard; safety

Title: Minifab operations for SoC production
Source title: Solid State Technology
Affiliations: Sony Corp., Atsugi, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hattori, T., Sony Corp., Atsugi, Japan
Abstract: A growing trend of using minifab tools for system on chip (SoC) production is discussed. This trend in broadband-networked digital consumer electronics has led to shifts in semiconductor manufacturing toward shorter cycle-time minifab operations with step-by-step investments where single wafer processing is preferable. The minifab tools protects from overcapacity and enables to respond quickly to changing demand. In addition to its high-mix, low-volume mature and low-risk investment advantages, minifab manufacturing enables faster ramp-up times, shorter cycle times, and lower energy consumption and emission levels.
Index Keywords: Broadband networks; Charge coupled devices; Dynamic random access storage; Information technology; Investments; LSI circuits; Silicon on insulator technology; Videodisks; Capital expenditure; Single-wafer processing; Wet cleaning; Consumer electronics

Title: Indirect water heater mixing and control
Source title: HPAC Heating, Piping, AirConditioning Engineering
Affiliations: Gifford Fuel Saving Inc., New York, NY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gifford, H., Gifford Fuel Saving Inc., New York, NY, United States
Abstract: The installation of new device for heating system for making hot water is discussed using new wiring and mixing techniques. The control process of heating system prevent from overheating by using temperature sensor in an indirect water heater. The effective hot water storage and indirect water heaters have taping, where a return line is connected to the tank to avoid mixing the cold water on the bottom of the tank. The comfort and energy saving can be enhanced by designing a system that will never overheat domestic hot water.
Index Keywords: Cold water; Heating system; Temperature sensitivity; Water temperature; Accident prevention; Boilers; Combustion; Heat pump systems; Hot water heating; Process control; Sensors; Temperature control; Water heaters

Title: News: DOE announces $350m in H2 research projects
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: Spencer Abraham, US energy secretary, has announced $350 million in nationwide funding for research projects to establish a hydrogen economy, representing nearly one-third of President Bush's $1.2 billion commitment in research funding to bring hydrogen and fuel cell technology from the laboratory to the showroom. Including the industrial cost-share contribution, the total amount of research funding could reach > $575 million. Key research areas include National Hydrogen Storage Project; vehicle and infrastructure learning demonstrations; fuel cell research; and hydrogen education.

Title: News: Ballard, Heliocentris sign for education distribution
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: Ballard Power Systems has named Heliocentris Energy Systems as a distributor of its AirGen™ portable fuel cell generator and Nexa® fuel cell power module in North America and Europe. Under the agreement, Heliocentris will purchase AirGen and/or Nexa products over the next two years for incorporation into its product line for post-secondary institutions. Heliocentris will offer three packages: Ballard's Nexa power module with course material and Nexamon™ software; the AirGen™ portable fuel cell generator; and a complete package consisting of the Nexa power module, AirGen generator, course material and Nexamon software. The accompanying course material is appropriate for post-secondary training in fuel cells, and includes sections on fuel cell theory, hydrogen production, hydrogen storage and hydrogen safety, as well as an instructor's guide and slide handouts for students.

Title: In brief: Brazil, US agree hydrogen energy research collaboration
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: The US and Brazil have announced a collaborative effort to advance hydrogen sector research, development, and deployment activities. The effort will be launched by establishing a joint team of US and Brazilian officials and experts to develop a hydrogen energy technology roadmap for Brazil. The roadmap will consider possible pathways for future hydrogen production, storage, transfer, end-use technologies, safety codes and standards, and outreach.

Authors: Aa T.V., Jayapala M., Barat F., Deconinck G., Lauwereins R., Catthoor F., Corporaal H.
Title: Instruction buffering exploration for low energy VLIWs with instruction clusters
Source title: Proceedings of the Asia and South Pacific Design Automation Conference, ASP-DAC

Leuven, ESAT, Kasteelpark Arenberg 10, Heverlee, 3001, Belgium; Barat, F., K.U. Leuven, ESAT, Kasteelpark Arenberg 10, Heverlee, 3001, Belgium; Deconinck, G., K.U. Leuven, ESAT, Kasteelpark Arenberg 10, Heverlee, 3001, Belgium; Lauwereins, R., IMEC vzw, Kapeldreef 75, Heverlee, 3001, Belgium; Catthoor, F., IMEC vzw, Kapeldreef 75, Heverlee, 3001, Belgium; Corporaal, H., TU Eindhoven, Electrical Engineering, Den Dolech 2, 5612 AZ Eindhoven, Netherlands
Abstract: For multimedia applications, loop buffering is an efficient mechanism to reduce the power in the instruction memory of embedded processors. In particular, software controlled clustered loop buffers are energy efficient. However current compilers for VLIW do not fully exploit the potentials offered by such a clustered organization This paper presents an algorithm to explore what is the optimal loop buffer configuration and the optimal way to use this configuration for an application or a set of applications. Results for the MediaBench application suite show an additional 18% reduction (on average) in energy in the instruction memory hierarchy as compared to traditional nonclustered approaches to the loop buffer without compromising performance.
Index Keywords: Computer architecture; Computer software; Energy efficiency; Hierarchical systems; Interconnection networks; Multimedia systems; Program processors; Instruction clusters; Loop buffers; MediaBench; Memory hierarchy; Buffer storage

Title: Energy efficient code generation exploiting reduced Bit-width instruction set architectures (rISA)
Source title: Proceedings of the Asia and South Pacific Design Automation Conference, ASP-DAC
Affiliations: Center for Embedded Computer Systems, Sch. of Info. and Computer Science, University of California, Irvine, CA 92697-3425, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shrivastava, A., Center for Embedded Computer Systems, Sch. of Info. and Computer Science, University of California, Irvine, CA 92697-3425, United States; Dutt, N., Center for Embedded Computer Systems, Sch. of Info. and Computer Science, University of California, Irvine, CA 92697-3425, United States
Abstract: Energy consumption is emerging as a critical design concern for programmable embedded systems. Many Reduced Bit-width Instruction Set Architectures (rISA) (e.g., ARM Thumb) are being increasingly used to decrease code size. Previous work has explored energy savings in non-cached rISA architectures as a byproduct of code size reduction. In this paper we present an energy efficient code generation technique for rISA architectures, and furthermore explore energy savings for both cached and non-cached architectures. Our code generation technique uses profile information to find the most frequently executed parts of the program. By aggressively reducing code size on frequently executed parts, fewer fetches to instruction memory are incurred, thus reducing the power consumption of the instruction memory. We achieve an average 30% reduction in instruction memory energy consumption in cached systems, on a variety of benchmarks, as compared to non-rISA architectures.
Index Keywords: Benchmarking; Buffer storage; Codes (symbols); Computer hardware; Embedded systems; Energy utilization; Estimation; Large scale systems; Bit-width set architectures (rISA); Code sizes; Eenrgy savings; Instruction memory; Computer architecture

Authors: Shim H., Chang N., Pedram M.
Title: A compressed frame buffer to reduce display power consumption in mobile systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Asia and South Pacific Design Automation Conference, ASP-DAC
Affiliations: School of CSE, Seoul National University, 151-010, South Korea; Department of EE, University of Southern California, CA 90089, United States; Sch. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, Seoul National University, Shilim-dong, Kwanak-ku, Seoul, 151-010, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Shim, H., School of CSE, Seoul National University, 151-010, South Korea; Chang, N., School of CSE, Seoul National University, 151-010, South Korea, Sch. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, Seoul National University, Shilim-dong, Kwanak-ku, Seoul, 151-010, South Korea; Pedram, M., Department of EE, University of Southern California, CA 90089, United States
Abstract: Despite the limited power available in a battery-operated hand-held device, a display system must still have an enough resolution and sufficient color depth to deliver the necessary information. We introduce some methodologies for frame buffer compression that efficiently reduce the power consumption of display systems and thus distinctly extend battery life for hand-held applications. Our algorithm is based on a run-length encoding for on-the-fly compression, with a negligible burden in resources and time. We present an adaptive and incremental re-compression technique to maintain efficiency under frequent partial frame buffer updates. We save about 30% to 90% frame buffer activity on average for various hand-held applications. We have implemented an LCD controller with frame buffer compression occupying 1,026 slices and 960 flip-flops in a Xilinx Sprantan-II FPGA, which has an equivalent gate count of 65,000 gates. It consumes 30mW more power and 10% additional silicon space than an LCD controller without frame buffer compression, but reduces the power consumption of the frame buffer memory by 400m W.
Index Keywords: Buffer storage; Control equipment; Data compression; Energy utilization; Hand held computers; Liquid crystal displays; Microprocessor chips; Compressed frame buffer; Mobile systems; Power consumption; Mobile computing

Title: A static and dynamic energy reduction technique for I-Cache and BTB in embedded processors
Source title: Proceedings of the Asia and South Pacific Design Automation Conference, ASP-DAC
Affiliations: Dept. of Artificial Intelligence, Kyushu Institute of Technology, Japan; PRESTO, Japan Sci. and Technology Agency, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sato, H., Dept. of Artificial Intelligence, Kyushu Institute of Technology, Japan; Sato, T., Dept. of Artificial Intelligence, Kyushu Institute of Technology, Japan, PRESTO, Japan Sci. and Technology Agency, Japan
Abstract: Power consumption is becoming one of the most important constraints for embedded processor design in nano-meter-scale technologies. Especially, as the transistor supply voltage and threshold voltage are scaled down, leakage energy consumption is increased even when the transistor is not switching. This paper proposes to use the loop cache to reduce static energy consumption as well as dynamic one. We combine it with CMOS circuits having sleep mode, and thus instruction cache can go to sleep mode when the loop cache is active. Detailed simulation shows that we can reduce static energy consumed by I-cache by up to 37.9%. We also propose to apply the technique to branch target buffer, and its static and dynamic energy consumption is reduced by up to 40.4% and 40.7%, respectively.
Index Keywords: Embedded processors; Energy reduction; Power consumption; Target buffers; CMOS integrated circuits; Energy efficiency; Hierarchical systems; Leakage currents; Multimedia systems; Program processors; Threshold voltage; Buffer storage

Authors: Marwedel P., Wehmeyer L., Verma M., Steinke S., Helmig U.
Title: Fast, predictable and low energy memory references through architecture-aware compilation
Source title: Proceedings of the Asia and South Pacific Design Automation Conference, ASP-DAC
Affiliations: University of Dortmund, Germany; Kostal GmbH and Co KG, Lüdenscheid, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Marwedel, P., University of Dortmund, Germany; Wehmeyer, L., University of Dortmund, Germany; Verma, M., University of Dortmund, Germany; Steinke, S., Kostal GmbH and Co KG, Lüdenscheid, Germany; Helmig, U., University of Dortmund, Germany
Abstract: The design of future high-performance embedded systems is hampered by two problems: First, the required hardware needs more energy than is available from batteries. Second, current cache-based approaches for bridging the increasing speed gap between processors and memories cannot guarantee predictable real-time behavior. A contribution to solving both problems is made in this paper which describes a comprehensive set of algorithms that can be applied at design time in order to maximally exploit scratch pad memories (SPMs). We show that both the energy consumption as well as the computed worst case execution time (WCET) can be reduced by up to to 80% and 48%, respectively, by establishing a strong link between the memory architecture and the compiler.
Index Keywords: Computer hardware; Data storage equipment; Electric batteries; Energy utilization; Personal computers; Problem solving; Program compilers; Program processors; Memory size; Scratch pad memories (SPM); Virtual memory; Worst case execution times (WCET); Embedded systems

Title: The Rheological and mechanical performance of commercial uPVC formulations

Abstract: Rheological and mechanical analysis of a range of virgin, recycled, and pigmented uPVC formulations used in extruded profiles for conservatory roofing applications is reported. The shear viscosity, tensile properties and dynamic mechanical thermal properties of the various formulations were shown to be dependent on stabiliser type, thermal processing history and pigment concentration. Lead stabilised uPVCs were shown to have better impact properties than Ca/Zn stabilised compounds and slight differences in Tgs, storage modulii (E') were recorded for all formulations.

Title: LIGA for boomerang
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Central Microstructure Facility, Rutherford Appleton Laboratory, Chilton, Didcot, Oxon. OX11 OQX, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Lawes, R.A., Central Microstructure Facility, Rutherford Appleton Laboratory, Chilton, Didcot, Oxon. OX11 OQX, United Kingdom; Arthur, G.G., Central Microstructure Facility, Rutherford Appleton Laboratory, Chilton, Didcot, Oxon. OX11 OQX, United Kingdom
Abstract: Boomerang is a 3GeV synchrotron radiation accelerator, currently being constructed in the State of Victoria, Australia. The outline design of two beamlines, suitable for the fabrication of MEMS devices using the LIGA process, is presented, along with an estimate of the exposure doses throughout the resist. The most commonly used resist is PMMA, which requires a minimum dose of about 4500 J/cm3 for accurate microstructure definition. Exposure with such a dose, in resist thicknesses of several hundred microns, can take hours. Fortunately, SU-8 resist is becoming more widely used as the minimum dose required is about 35 J/cm3, leading to exposure times of only a few minutes. Although Boomerang will shorten exposure times due to its higher irradiance at the substrate, the full benefits may not be realizable due to excessive resist heating. Heating effects have been simulated and suggest that helium cooling will be essential if the glass transition temperature of the resist (100°C for PMMA, 50°C for SU-8) and thermal distortion of the mask are to be avoided. The parameters chosen in this study of the future performance of Boomerang have been inserted into a cost model. The model shows that Boomerang exposure can become competitive with other exposure methods, particularly where large quantities of devices with deep structures are required.
Index Keywords: Computer aided manufacturing; Computer simulation; Glass transition; Helium; Image quality; Lithography; Microelectromechanical devices; Microstructure; Photoresists; X rays; Beamlines; Boomerang; Storage ring energy; Thermal distortion; Synchrotron radiation

Authors: Cai L., Yu H., Gajski D.
Title: A novel memory size model for variable-mapping in system level design
Source title: Proceedings of the Asia and South Pacific Design Automation Conference, ASP-DAC
Affiliations: Ctr. for Embedded Computing Systems, University of California, Irvine, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cai, L., Ctr. for Embedded Computing Systems, University of California, Irvine, United States; Yu, H., Ctr. for Embedded Computing Systems, University of California, Irvine, United States; Gajski, D., Ctr. for Embedded Computing Systems, University of California, Irvine, United States
Abstract: It is pridicted that 70% of the chip area will be occupied by memories in future system-on-chips. The minimization of on-chip memory hence becomes increasingly important for cost, performance and energy consumption. This paper proposes a novel memory size model for algorithms which map the variables of a system behavior to memories of a system architecture. To our knowledge, it is the first memory estimation approach that analyzes the variable lifetime for the system behavior, which consists of hierarchically-modelled and concurrently-executed processes and contains variables with different sizes. Experimental results show that significant improvements can be achieved.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computer architecture; Costs; Data storage equipment; Energy utilization; Hierarchical systems; Knowledge acquisition; Optimization; Memory size model; System architecture; System level design; System on chip; Microprocessor chips

Title: Memory access driven storage assignment for variables in embedded system design
Source title: Proceedings of the Asia and South Pacific Design Automation Conference, ASP-DAC
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Adv. Info. Technol. Research Center, Korea Adv. Inst. of Sci./Technology, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Choi, Y., Department of Electrical Engineering, Adv. Info. Technol. Research Center, Korea Adv. Inst. of Sci./Technology, South Korea; Kim, T., Department of Electrical Engineering, Adv. Info. Technol. Research Center, Korea Adv. Inst. of Sci./Technology, South Korea
Abstract: It has been reported and verified in many design experiences that a judicious utilization of the page/burst access modes supported by DRAMs contributes a great reduction in not only the DRAM access latency but also DRAM's energy consumption. Recently, researchers showed that a careful arrangment of data variables in memory directly leads to a maximum utilization of the page/burst access modes for the variable accesses, but unfortunately, found that the problems are not tractable, consequently, resorting to simple (e.g., greedy) heuristic solutions to the problems. In this paper, to improve the quality of existing solutions, we propose a new storage assignement technique, called zone-alignment, for variables, which effectively exploits an efficient 0-1 ILP formulation and the temporal locality of variables' accesses in code.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computer architecture; Dynamic random access storage; Energy utilization; Heuristic methods; Optimization; Problem solving; Burst access modes; Memory access; Memory architecture; Embedded systems

Title: Display driver packaging: ACF reaching the limits?
Source title: Proceedings of the International Symposium and Exhibition on Advanced Packaging Materials Processes, Properties and Interfaces
Affiliations: Nokia, Itämerenkatu 11-13, 00180 Helsinki, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Savolainen, P., Nokia, Itämerenkatu 11-13, 00180 Helsinki, Finland
Abstract: There is a clear trend to transform the mobile phone to a wireless terminal including a number of visual functions. Consequently, the terminal has developed from voice-mainly device to a multifunctional device, serving the users' various needs. A key building block for attractive, easy to use terminals is relatively large, high-resolution color display. The display development is trying to keep the pace with requirements, and one of the bottlenecks is how to package and connect the driving circuitry including the display driver, energy management, memory etc., to the display device. Technologies to integrate the circuitry to the glass substrate are under development, but current and coming mass production displays still need technologies to interconnect the driver electronics to the display. Anisotropic Conductive Film offers a solution to this challenge but how long?

Abstract: In allusion to complexity of architecture environment and Real-time simulation of architecture acoustics, a parallel radiosity algorithm was developed. The distribution of sound energy in scene is solved with this method. And then the impulse response between sources and receivers at frequency segment, which are calculated with multi-process, are combined into whole frequency response. The numerical experiment shows that parallel arithmetic can improve the acoustic simulating efficiency of complex scene.

Authors: Vivekanandarajah K., Srikanthan T., Bhattacharyya S.
Title: Decode filter cache for energy efficient instruction cache hierarchy in super scalar architectures
Source title: Proceedings of the Asia and South Pacific Design Automation Conference, ASP-DAC
Affiliations: Ctr. for High Perf. Embedded Systems, School of Computer Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Vivekanandarajah, K., Ctr. for High Perf. Embedded Systems, School of Computer Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore; Srikanthan, T., Ctr. for High Perf. Embedded Systems, School of Computer Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore; Bhattacharyya, S., Ctr. for High Perf. Embedded Systems, School of Computer Engineering, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore 639798, Singapore
Abstract: The power consumption of microprocessors has been increasing in step with the complexity of each progressive generation. In general purpose processors, this is primarily attributed to the high energy consumption of fetch and decode circuitry, pursuant to the high instruction issue rate required of these high performance processors. Predictive Decode Filter Cache (DFC) has been shown to be effective in reducing the fetch and decode energy consumed by the instruction cache hierarchy of inorder single issue processors. In this paper we propose the architectural level enhancements to facilitate the incorporation of the DFC in wide issue superscalar processors for an energy efficient memory hierarchy. Extensive simulations on the modified superscalar architecture shows that the use of the (predictor based) DFC results in an average reduction of 17.33% and 25.09% fetch energy reduction in L1 cache along with 37.2% and 46.6% reduction in number of decodes for 64 and 128 instruction DFC respectively. This fetch and decode energy savings are achieved with minimal reduction in the average Instruction Per Cycle (IPC) of 0.54% and 0.73% for 64 and 128 instruction DFC for the selected set of spec2000 benchmarks.
Index Keywords: Decode filter cache (DFC); Decoded instruction cache; Power optimization; Super scalar architectures; Benchmarking; Computational complexity; Decoding; Energy efficiency; Microprocessor chips; Optimization; Shift registers; Buffer storage

Abstract: The findings on hydrogen production from a recent DOE sponsored workshop on hydrogen production, storage, and use were presented. The development of large scale, cost-effective, and sustainable hydrogen production methods poses many technical challenges. Basic research needs in the context of the scale of the problem, current methods of hydrogen production and the timeline for implementation of hydrogen as an energy currency for transportation, and other uses were considered. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 227th ACS National Meeting (Anaheim, CA 3/28/2004-4/1/2004).

Title: Considerations in the design and application of solid oxide fuel cell energy systems in residential markets
Source title: ASHRAE Transactions

Prof. Devlopment, University of Wisconsin, Madison, United States; Industrial Refrigeration Consortium, Madison, WI, United States

Prof. Devlopment, University of Wisconsin, Madison, United States, Industrial Refrigeration Consortium, Madison, WI, United States
Abstract: This paper examines aspects of fuel cell system design for application in stationary residential markets. The development of fuel cell systems for sub-10 kW stationary applications involves consideration of sizing, fuel processing, operating point selection, fuel cell operating capabilities, system integration, and load management strategies. Each of these considerations is discussed, and strategies are presented for matching the electrical and thermal energy demands of a residence with a solid oxide fuel cell power system. Efficiency considerations for configuring fuel cell, DC-to-AC inverter, and electrical energy storage components for conditioning of DC power generated by the fuel cell stack are also given. Recommendations are made on the potential opportunities for solid oxide fuel cells in small-scale stationary power applications.

Title: Impact of modeling accuracy on predictive optimal control of active and passive building thermal storage inventory
Source title: ASHRAE Transactions
Affiliations: Dept. of Architectural Engineering, University of Nebraska, Lincoln, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liu, S., Dept. of Architectural Engineering, University of Nebraska, Lincoln, United States; Henze, G.P., Dept. of Architectural Engineering, University of Nebraska, Lincoln, United States
Abstract: This paper evaluates the impact of modeling accuracy on the model-based closed-loop predictive optimal control of both passive building thermal capacitance and active thermal energy storage (TES) systems to minimize utility cost. The following guidelines have been derived: for an internal heat gain-dominated commercial building, the deviation of building geometry and zoning from the reference building only marginally affects the optimal control strategy; reasonable simplifications are acceptable without loss of cost savings potential. Building construction characteristics determine the building passive thermal storage capacity. Zone temperature setpoints are affected more than TES operation by this construction mismatch, and a loss of cost savings potential is. found in some cases. It is advisable to make sure the construo tion material is well modeled. Zone temperature setpoint profiles and TES performance are strongly affected by mismatches in internal heat gains, especially when they are underestimated. Since they are a key factor determining the building cooling load, efforts should be invested to keep the internalgain mismatch as small as possible. Efficiencies of the building energy systems have no direct impact on building cooling load, but they affect both zone temperature setpoints and active TES operation because of the coupling of the base chiller and the TES chiller. Relative efficiencies of the base and TES chillers will determine the balance of operation of the two chillers. Mismatch in this category may be significant. To avoid critical modeling mismatch, system identification- techniques may be useful in improving the modeling process.
Index Keywords: Ice storage; Plant energy efficiency; Thermal energy storage (TES); Utility rate structures; Buildings; Computer simulation; Cooling; Cost effectiveness; Heat storage; Mathematical models; Optimization; Temperature measurement; Predictive control systems

Authors: Park J.-W., Kim C.-G., Lee J.-H., Kim S.-D.
Title: An energy efficient cache memory architecture for embedded systems
Source title: Proceedings of the ACM Symposium on Applied Computing
Affiliations: CS, Yonsei University, 134, Shinchon-dong, Seoul, 120-749, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Park, J.-W., CS, Yonsei University, 134, Shinchon-dong, Seoul, 120-749, South Korea; Kim, C.-G., CS, Yonsei University, 134, Shinchon-dong, Seoul, 120-749, South Korea; Lee, J.-H., CS, Yonsei University, 134, Shinchon-dong, Seoul, 120-749, South Korea; Kim, S.-D., CS, Yonsei University, 134, Shinchon-dong, Seoul, 120-749, South Korea
Abstract: This paper proposes a modified two-way set associative cache for embedded systems to reduce the energy consumption. For this goal, the proposed cache, called SSA (selective-way-access skewed associative) cache, equips with a way-selecting mechanism controlled by skewing function and small table lookup, which also has the reconfigurable ability to be converted to one direct mapped cache on a specific application. The skewing mechanism including differentiated mapping function for each cache set, and specialized replacement policy enables the perfect speculation in way-selection and decreases conflict misses. Consequently, the proposed cache effectively achieves the energy reduction without any performance degradation. Additional delay of a small table look-up for the way selection can be hidden partly and multiplexer delay in critical path can be removed totally, such that overall cache access time becomes almost same as that of conventional set associative cache. The simulation result shows that the proposed cache structure reduces energy consumption up to 30∼55% over conventional set associative cache and up to 25∼30% over previous way-prediction caches. Furthermore, the software controlled reconfigurable architecture brings flexibility with the proposed cache to operate as direct mapped cache or way selecting cache based on given application adaptively.
Author Keywords: Embedded system; Low power cache; Memory hierarchy; Selective way access; Skewed associativity
Index Keywords: Buffer storage; Energy utilization; Hierarchical systems; Mapping; Multiplexing; Problem solving; Program processors; Low power cache; Memory hierarchy; Selective way access; Skewed associativity; Embedded systems

Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: Data on API imports of crude (Canadian and other foreign) and products, i.e., total motor gasoline, motor gasoline blending component, distillate, residual, jet fuel (naphtha and kerosene), LPG, unfinished oils, and other products, for Districts 1-5 as of 5/7/2004 and 5/14/2004, as well as for the US as of 5/15/2003, 5/7/2004, and 5/14/2004 are tabulated. Data on refinery operations, e.g., total refinery input, crude runs, input to crude stills, operable capacity, and percent operated, as well as refinery output of total motor gasoline, jet fuels (naphtha and kerosene), and fuel oils (distillate and residual) for Districts 1-5 as of 5/14/2004 are also presented. Data on crude oil and lease condensate production as of 5/14/2004 are compared with the data on 5/16/2003. Energy Information Administration also presented data on US natural gas storage as of 4/30/2004 and 5/7/2004. A comparison of the data on world oil balance between 2002 and 2003 are tabulated. Data on OECD net oil imports and OECD total gross imports from OPEC in January 2003, November 2003, December 2003, and January 2003 are also tabulated. DOE Monthly Energy Review reports the US petroleum imports from source country, e.g., Algeria, Kuwait, Angola, Canada, and other OPEC and non-OPEC members, from January 2004 to February 2004.

Authors: Todorovic M.H., Palma L., Enjeti P.
Title: Design of a wide input range DC-DC converter with a robust power control scheme suitable for fuel cell power conversion
Source title: Conference Proceedings - IEEE Applied Power Electronics Conference and Exposition - APEC
Affiliations: Pwr. Electron./Fuel Cell Pwr. C.L., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843-3128, United States
Authors with affiliations: Todorovic, M.H., Pwr. Electron./Fuel Cell Pwr. C.L., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843-3128, United States; Palma, L., Pwr. Electron./Fuel Cell Pwr. C.L., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843-3128, United States; Enjeti, P., Pwr. Electron./Fuel Cell Pwr. C.L., Department of Electrical Engineering, Texas A and M University, College Station, TX 77843-3128, United States
Abstract: In this paper analysis and design of a wide input range DC-DC converter is proposed along with a robust power control scheme. The proposed converter and its control is designed to be compatible to a fuel cell power source, which exhibits 2:1 voltage variation as well as a slow transient response. The proposed approach consists of two stages: a conventional boost converter stage cascaded with a current-fed two-inductor boost converter topology, which has a higher voltage gain and isolation from the input source. The function of the first boost converter stage is to maintain a constant voltage at the input of the cascaded DC-DC converter to ensure optimal performance characteristics with high efficiency. At the output of the first boost converter a battery or ultracapacitor energy storage is connected to take care of the fuel cell slow transient response (200 watts/min). The robust features of the proposed control system ensure a constant output DC voltage for a variety of load fluctuations, thus limiting the power being delivered by the fuel cell during a load transient. Moreover, the proposed configuration simplifies the power control management and can interact with the fuel cell controller. The simulation results and the preliminary experimental results confirm the feasibility of the proposed system.
Index Keywords: dc-dc converters; Power control management; Switching frequency; Switching losses; Algorithms; Computer simulation; Electric energy storage; Electric loads; Electric network topology; Electric potential; Electric switches; Electric transformers; Fuel cells; Maintenance; Power control; Waveform analysis; Electric converters
