Abstract: Nowadays X-ray sources based on storage rings with low beam energy and Compton scattering of intense laser beams are under development in several laboratories. An international cooperative project of an advanced X-ray source of this type at the Kharkov Institute of Physics and Technology (KIPT) is described. The status of the project is reviewed. The design lattice of the storage ring and calculated X-ray beam parameters are presented. The results of numerical simulation carried out for proposed facility show a peak spectral X-ray intensity of about 1014 can be produced. © 2004 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Lohmann M., Dix W.-R., Metge J., Reime B.
Title: Instrumentation for diffraction enhanced imaging experiments at HASYLAB
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestr. 85, Hamburg, D-22603, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Lohmann, M., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestr. 85, Hamburg, D-22603, Germany; Dix, W.-R., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestr. 85, Hamburg, D-22603, Germany; Metge, J., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestr. 85, Hamburg, D-22603, Germany; Reime, B., Hamburger Synchrotronstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestr. 85, Hamburg, D-22603, Germany
Abstract: The new X-ray radiography imaging technique, named diffraction enhanced imaging (DEI), enables almost scatter free absorption imaging, the production of the so-called refraction images of a sample. The images show improved contrast compared to standard imaging applications. At the HASYLAB wiggler beamline W2 at the 2nd-generation storage ring DORIS a 5cm wide beam with an adjustable energy between 10 and 70keV is available. A Si [111] pre-monochromator is used followed by the main monochromator using the (111) or the (333)-reflection. Visualization of fossils, detecting internal pearl structures, monitoring of bone and cartilage and documentation of implant healing in bone are application examples at HASYLAB. © 2004 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Song Y.F., Chang C.H., Liu C.Y., Huang L.J., Chang S.H., Chuang J.M., Chung S.C., Tseng P.C., Lee J.F., Tsang K.L., Liang K.S.
Title: X-ray beamlines on a superconducting wavelength shifter
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Song, Y.F., National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Chang, C.H., National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Liu, C.Y., National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Huang, L.J., National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Chang, S.H., National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Chuang, J.M., National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Chung, S.C., National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Tseng, P.C., National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Lee, J.F., National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Tsang, K.L., National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan; Liang, K.S., National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, 30077, Taiwan
Abstract: A Superconducting Wavelength Shifter (SWLS) insertion device with peak field of 6 Tesla has been installed in the Taiwan Light Source (TLS) storage ring to increase the critical energy of the radiation spectrum from 2 keV to 9 keV. We are constructing three hard X-ray beamlines BL01A, BL01B and BL01C to utilize the photon source generated by this insertion device. The beamline BL01B is a DCM X-ray beamline with a toroidal focusing mirror, which provides monochromatic photon beams with energies from 5 keV to 20 keV for X-ray scattering experiments. At the sample position, the expected photon flux is about 7×1011 photon/sec/200mA with an average energy resolution (ΔE/E) of 1×10-3 and the focused beam size is about 1 mm × 0.4 mm. The beamline BL01C is a standard DCM X-ray beamline with both collimating and focusing mirrors, which will deliver monochromatic photon beams with energy ranging from 6 keV to 33 keV for EXAFS and powder diffraction. At the sample position, the expected photon flux is 1×1011 photon/sec /200mA with an average energy resolution (ΔE/E) of 1.6×10-4 and the focused beam size is about 0.9 mm × 0.2 mm. The beamline BL01A is a white-light beamline reserved for other applications. Both BL01A and BL01B beamlines have been constructed and are in commissioning. An average photon flux of 3×1011 photon/sec has been obtained at beamline BL01B. © 2004 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Shoji Y., Hisao S., Matsubara T., Asaka T., Suzuki S., Kawashima Y.
Title: RF synchronized injection from SPring-8 linac to NewSUBARU storage ring
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: NewSUBARU/SPring-8, LASTI, Himeji Institute of Technology, 1-1-2 Kouto, Kamigori, Hyogo, 678-1205, Japan; SPring-8, JASRI, 1-1-1 Kouto, Mikazuki, Hyogo, 679-5198, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Shoji, Y., NewSUBARU/SPring-8, LASTI, Himeji Institute of Technology, 1-1-2 Kouto, Kamigori, Hyogo, 678-1205, Japan; Hisao, S., NewSUBARU/SPring-8, LASTI, Himeji Institute of Technology, 1-1-2 Kouto, Kamigori, Hyogo, 678-1205, Japan; Matsubara, T., NewSUBARU/SPring-8, LASTI, Himeji Institute of Technology, 1-1-2 Kouto, Kamigori, Hyogo, 678-1205, Japan; Asaka, T., SPring-8, JASRI, 1-1-1 Kouto, Mikazuki, Hyogo, 679-5198, Japan; Suzuki, S., SPring-8, JASRI, 1-1-1 Kouto, Mikazuki, Hyogo, 679-5198, Japan; Kawashima, Y., SPring-8, JASRI, 1-1-1 Kouto, Mikazuki, Hyogo, 679-5198, Japan
Abstract: This paper confirms the occurrence of RF synchronized injection from SPring-8 Linac to the NewSUBARU storage ring. NewSUBARU is a 1.5 GeV storage ring with injection energy of 1.0 GeV. Besides the 1.5 GeV user mode, the ring is often operated at 1.0 GeV for EUV users with the so-called top-up injection mode. In this experiment, we use a new synchronization method developed at SPring-8, wherein an instantaneous synchronization between NewSUBARU RF (500 MHz) and Linac RF (2856 MHz) enables a buckets-to-bucket beam transfer. This is one of the key technologies of top-up operations in a storage ring that uses a linac as an injector. The RF clock and timing trigger signal are sent to the Linac from NewSUBARU, and this clock is used to delay units in order to maintain good synchronicity. This works as a standard because it has a system to compensate for transfer-time drift. The arbitrary waveform generator is another key module. It produces a clock 1/32 of that of the Linac RF using the NewSUBARU RF clock. With this system, we eliminated beam loss at the injection due to spillage from the ring RF bucket. © 2004 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Nazmov V., Reznikova E., Boerner M., Mohr J., Saile V., Snigirev A., Snigireva I., DiMichiel M., Drakopoulos M., Simon R., Grigoriev M.
Title: Refractive lenses fabricated by deep SR lithography and LIGA technology for X-ray energies from 1 keV to 1 MeV
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Institut für Mikrostrukturtechnik / Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe GmbH, Karlsruhe, 76021, Germany; ESRF, BP-220, Grenoble Cedex, France; Institut für Synchrotron Strahlung / Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe GmbH, Karlsruhe, 76021, Germany; IMT RAS, Chernogolovka, 142432, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Nazmov, V., Institut für Mikrostrukturtechnik / Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe GmbH, Karlsruhe, 76021, Germany; Reznikova, E., Institut für Mikrostrukturtechnik / Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe GmbH, Karlsruhe, 76021, Germany; Boerner, M., Institut für Mikrostrukturtechnik / Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe GmbH, Karlsruhe, 76021, Germany; Mohr, J., Institut für Mikrostrukturtechnik / Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe GmbH, Karlsruhe, 76021, Germany; Saile, V., Institut für Mikrostrukturtechnik / Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe GmbH, Karlsruhe, 76021, Germany; Snigirev, A., ESRF, BP-220, Grenoble Cedex, France; Snigireva, I., ESRF, BP-220, Grenoble Cedex, France; DiMichiel, M., ESRF, BP-220, Grenoble Cedex, France; Drakopoulos, M., ESRF, BP-220, Grenoble Cedex, France; Simon, R., Institut für Synchrotron Strahlung / Forschungszentrum Karlsruhe GmbH, Karlsruhe, 76021, Germany; Grigoriev, M., IMT RAS, Chernogolovka, 142432, Russian Federation
Abstract: SU-8 polymer and Nickel were used to manufacture planar high aspect ratio X-ray refractive lenses by the LIGA process (Deep X-ray lithography, electroforming). The exposure of PMMA and highly sensitive SU-8 resist layers were carried out at the ANKA storage ring, Karlsruhe. Lenses of either round, segment or quasi-parabolic (kinoform) profiles have been designed, fabricated and tested at the ESRF and at the ANKA synchrotron sources with X-ray energies ranging from 12 to 55 keV. The SU-8 polymer lenses tested at ESRF showed an uniform focal line spot with FWHM of appr. 0.32 μm and gains in the range of 320. The characteristics did not alter after an absorbed dose of 2 MJ/cm3. Lenses fabricated from electroplated Ni, 320 μm thick, were tested at a photon energy of 212 keV. In this case the uniform focal line spot was about 5 μm. © 2004 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Pohl M., Kleineberg U., Heinzmann U.
Title: Transmission photoelectron microscopy of diatoms at the multilayer monochromator beamline U125-1/ML at BESSY II
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: University of Bielefeld, Faculty of Physics, Universitaetsstr. 25, Bielefeld, D-33615, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Pohl, M., University of Bielefeld, Faculty of Physics, Universitaetsstr. 25, Bielefeld, D-33615, Germany; Kleineberg, U., University of Bielefeld, Faculty of Physics, Universitaetsstr. 25, Bielefeld, D-33615, Germany; Heinzmann, U., University of Bielefeld, Faculty of Physics, Universitaetsstr. 25, Bielefeld, D-33615, Germany
Abstract: A new setup for Transmission Photoelectron Microscopy (T-PEEM) at the 3rd generation Berlin electron storage ring BESSY II is reported and initial results on imaging of dried diatom algae immobilized on a thin silicon membrane are described. The T-PEEM images recorded at a photon energy of 95 eV display a spatial resolution of better than 65 nm. Furthermore spectroscopic imaging is enabled by tuning the illuminating photon energy in the vicinity of x-ray absorption edges. © 2004 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Bao X., Lin M., Koh H.Z., Zhang Q.
Title: Preparation of iron oxide and iron oxide/silicon oxide nanoparticles via water-in-oil microemulsion
Source title: Ceramic Transactions
Affiliations: Inst. of Poly. Technol./Mat. Eng., Loughborough University, Loughborough, Leics. LE11 3TU, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Bao, X., Inst. of Poly. Technol./Mat. Eng., Loughborough University, Loughborough, Leics. LE11 3TU, United Kingdom; Lin, M., Inst. of Poly. Technol./Mat. Eng., Loughborough University, Loughborough, Leics. LE11 3TU, United Kingdom; Koh, H.Z., Inst. of Poly. Technol./Mat. Eng., Loughborough University, Loughborough, Leics. LE11 3TU, United Kingdom; Zhang, Q., Inst. of Poly. Technol./Mat. Eng., Loughborough University, Loughborough, Leics. LE11 3TU, United Kingdom
Abstract: A new water-in-oil (W/O) reverse microemulsion system was developed to prepare silica-coated iron oxide nanoparticles, where Igepal CO-520 was used as the surfactant and cyclohexane as the oil phase. As a comparison, coprecipitation method was also employed to synthesize the nanoparicles with hydrothermal posttreatment to enhance the crystallinity of the iron oxide nanoparticles. The iron oxide nanoparticles prepared via the microemulsion and co-precipitation at ambient temperature are magnetite (Fe3O 4) and have poor crystallinity with the size of 5-10nm and 10-20nm, respectively. The iron oxide particles via microemulsion grew in size to ∼60nm after hydrothermal treatment at 200°C and transformed to hematite (α-Fe2O3) at 140°C. Large size distribution (14-180nm) was observed for nanoparticles prepared by coprecipitation after post-hydrothermal treatment at 200°C and maghemite (γ-Fe 2O3) phase was formed at 140°C - 160°C and transformed into the hematite at 200°C. Silicon oxide coated iron oxide nanocomposites were also synthesized in-situ by ammonia-catalyzed tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) hydrolysis and condensation after forming the iron oxide nanoparticles in the microemulsion system. TEM with EDS showed that the iron oxides were coated by a thin layer of silica.
Index Keywords: Catalysis; Energy dispersive spectroscopy; Hydrolysis; Hydrothermal synthesis; Magnetic recording; Magnetic storage; Magnetite; Microemulsions; Silica; Surface active agents; Transmission electron microscopy; Water; Coprecipitation; Water-in-oil microemulsions; Nanostructured materials

Title: Government & policy concentrates: $350 million in hydrogen R & D grants issued
Source title: Chemical and Engineering News
Abstract: Thirty lead organizations and over 100 partners were selected to receive $350 million in DOE grants for hydrogen-related R&D. Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham made the announcements on a national tour in the last week of April 2004, saying the funding is a significant "down payment" on the President's $1.2 billion commitment to hydrogen R&D. The hydrogen storage research will be overseen by three hydrogen centers of excellence at Los Alamos National Laboratory, Sandia National Laboratories, and the National Renewable Energy Laboratory. The $190 million vehicle demonstration grants go primarily to automakers that are expected to match the funds.

Authors: Der Minassians A., Aschenbach K.H., Sanders S.R.
Title: Low-cost distributed solar-thermal-electric power generation
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: EECS Department, UC Berkeley, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; 341 Cory Hall, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; 565 Cory Hall, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Der Minassians, A., EECS Department, UC Berkeley, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States, 341 Cory Hall, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Aschenbach, K.H., EECS Department, UC Berkeley, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States, 341 Cory Hall, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Sanders, S.R., EECS Department, UC Berkeley, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States, 565 Cory Hall, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: Due to their high relative cost, solar electric energy systems have yet to be exploited on a widespread basis. It is believed in the energy community that a technology similar to photovoltaic (PV), but offered at about $1/W would lead to widespread deployment at residential and commercial sites. This paper addresses the investigation and feasibility study of a low-cost solar thermal electricity generation technology, suitable for distributed deployment. Specifically, we discuss a system based on nonimaging solar concentrators, integrated with free-piston Stirling engine devices incorporating integrated electric generation. We target concentrator-collector operation at moderate temperatures, in the range of 125°C to 150°C. This temperature is consistent with use of optical concentrators with concentration ratios on the order of 1-2. These low ratio concentrators admit wide angles of radiation acceptance and are thus compatible with no diurnal tracking, and no or only a few seasonal adjustments. Thus, costs and reliability hazards associated with tracking hardware systems are avoided. Further, we note that in the intended application, there is no shortage of incident solar energy, but rather it is the capital cost of the solar-electric system that is most precious. Thus, we outline a strategy for exploiting solar resources in a cost constrained manner. The paper outlines design issues, and a specific design for an appropriately dimensioned free-piston Stirling engine. Only standard low-cost materials and manufacturing methods are required to realize such a machine.
Author Keywords: Solar Thermal Collectors; Solar Thermal Electricity; Stirling Engine
Index Keywords: Costs; Electric energy storage; Energy efficiency; Photovoltaic effects; Solar energy; Solar radiation; Stirling engines; Solar thermal collectors; Solar thermal electricity; Solar collectors

Title: Full spectral imaging: A revisited approach to remote sensing
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, EOS Program Office, Code 420, Greenbelt, MD 20771, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bolton, J.F., NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, EOS Program Office, Code 420, Greenbelt, MD 20771, United States
Abstract: Current optical remote sensing instrument technology allows the acquisition and digitization of all of the reflected energy (light) across the full spectral range of interest. The current method for acquiring, transmitting, and processing this data is still based on the "multi-band" approach that has been used for the past thirty years. This approach was required due to limitations imposed by early instrument technology. This paper will present generalized concepts for acquiring, pre-processing, transmitting, and extracting information from full-spectral, remotely sensed data. The goal of the paper is to propose methods for changing from the current "bytes-per-band" approach to the "spectral curve" approach. The paper will describe how the Full Spectral Imaging (FSI) approach has the potential to greatly simplify instrument characterization and calibration and to significantly reduce data transmission and storage requirements. I will suggest how these improvements may be accomplished with no loss of remotely sensed information.
Author Keywords: Calibration; Characterization; Data compression; Data processing; Hyperspectral imaging; Information theory; Remote sensing
Index Keywords: Calibration; Characterization; Data acquisition; Data compression; Data processing; Information theory; Light reflection; Monochromators; Optical resolving power; Remote sensing; Hyperspectral imaging; Spatial resolution; Imaging techniques

Title: Go with the flow
Source title: Chemical Engineer
Affiliations: Ajax Equipment, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: McGee, E., Ajax Equipment, United Kingdom
Abstract: The methods for handling flow problems in hoppers by using novel geometry and inserts are discussed. Production suffers from unreliable flow and the hopper may need taking offline for repair and cleaning more frequently which is considered as a costly and disruptive exercise. Mass flow hoppers provide the advantage of securing reliable flow through smaller outlet sizes. A new installation at a manufacturer involves replacing two battered non-mass flow hoppers with new units incorporating inverted v-shaped flow inserts. This created a hopper that gave a better drawdown pattern, preventing material build-up to maximize the hopper's live storage capacity whilst avoiding variable residence periods of storage.

Title: An optimized pretreatment and whitening concept
Source title: ATA Journal
Abstract: Ciba® SMART WHITE, suitable for both 100% cellulose and its blends, combines bleaching and whitening in a single stage and gives optimum white effects. The process which is performed under atmospheric conditions and at high temperature, does not affect Ciba® UVITEX® brighteners. The special detergent, dispersing and emulsifying actions of Ciba® TINOCLARITE® WIN ensures the removal of oily and greasy impurities. This gives high level of optical whites and makes it ideal for elastane-containing blends. The isothermal neutralization with a multifunctional cracking and core neutralization agent, Ciba® INVATEX® AC, during rinsing process, reduces the yellowing of the fabric during drying/finishing heat process and storage. The saving of time, energy, and water makes the use of Ciba® SMART WHITE process a wise choice for textile mills.

Title: A forward looking company
Source title: Nuclear Plant Journal

Authors with affiliations: Christian, D.A., Dominion Generation, United States, Dominion Generation, Dominion Resources, United States
Abstract: Dominion Energy's, a large fully integrated energy company with energy and gas services, is discussed. The company pay attention to global shaping forces that may determine energy choices in the future. Dominion is in the coal business, the LNG business, the nuclear power business, the nuclear power business, hydro plants, natural gas storage and exploration & production. The Consortium that Dominion have formed submitted a proposal to the U.S. DOE in March 2004 to helping to define a path that could validate the Combined Operating License process and identify barriers there may be to future construction of NPPs in the US. Dominion has an initiative called PowerStart, that describe the career paths that are available in nuclear power.

Title: Getting into hot water over tax breaks
Source title: HAC
Affiliations: Andrews Water Heaters, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yunnie, P., Andrews Water Heaters, United States
Abstract: The issues related to the policy of government on energy consumption by water heating are discussed. Water heating is a prime energy user in sports and leisure centers, and other commercial places. Gas-fired water heaters are launched that are recognized under the government's enhanced capital allowance (ECA) scheme. They offer non-storage high recovery, condensing and wall hung continuous flow units, all adding flexibility of gas water heaters. The gas heater uses copper or stainless steel finned tube heat exchanger, with an output of of 1002 kW and 19400 litres per hour recovery which makes it suitable to be installed in hospitals, hotels and other large applications.

Title: Fuels & fueling: Changes in midstream
Source title: National Petroleum News
Authors with affiliations: Bennett, S.
Abstract: The terminal industry is undergoing consolidation. Companies, e.g., Kinder Morgan Energy Partners LP, Valero LP, and Magellan Midstream Partners, are acquiring terminals and pipelines to be more competitive. For example, Valero LP has made a number of acquisitions, and it has a network that includes 4100 mi of crude oil and refined products pipelines, 18 refined product terminals with 170 tanks that have storage capacity of 3.9 million bbl, and 8 storage facilities with 73 crude oil storage tanks that have a storage capacity of 14.4 million bbl. A key reason terminals are available for acquisition is that major oil firms, e.g., Chevron Texaco and Shell, are divesting themselves of midstream assets. Economic factors and a bounty of public and private equity investment funds are also driving the consolidation of ownership in terminals. The consolidation has led to wholesalers and retailers evaluating alternate supply and terminaling options, which consist of obtaining pipeline space, purchasing supply in bulk from merchant refiners and shipping their own barrels to support their demand, etc. Retailers should reassess whether or not it makes sense to be branded. Retailers and jobbers should establish relationships with terminal operators in their locale, and understand the economics of supply.

Title: Side-by-side test verifies VFD energy savings
Source title: HPAC Heating, Piping, AirConditioning Engineering
Affiliations: Yaskawa Electric America Inc., United States
Authors with affiliations: Phillips, J., Yaskawa Electric America Inc., United States
Abstract: The HVAC installations with variable frequency AC drives that provide an effective method of achieving energy saving and lower maintenance costs are analyzed. Return air temperature and AHU power usage for each floor were logged at five minute intervals during the test. A reduction of nearly 72 percent in energy consumption on the floor was achieved where the variable frequency drives (VFD) was installed. VFD also helps in cutting maintenance costs through their ability to deliver 'soft' starts and stops.
Index Keywords: Air handling unit; Air volume system; Energy saving; Variable frequency; Automatic testing; Buildings; Cooling; Costs; Energy storage; Energy utilization; Maintenance; Monitoring; Speed; Variable speed drives; Air conditioning

Title: Give your compressors a boost
Source title: Chemical Processing
Affiliations: Air Science Engineering, United States; Air Science Engineering, Division of Enpro Industries, Chandler, AZ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Smith, D.E., Air Science Engineering, United States, Air Science Engineering, Division of Enpro Industries, Chandler, AZ, United States
Abstract: The dynamics of a compressor, and to improve the efficiency while reducing the operating costs of a compressed air system are discussed. Control on each compressor use pressure to manage volume output, and prevent compressor damage. Compressor controls adjust airflow on pressure changes, and so the location at which each compressor monitors pressure becomes critical to understand its response, and performance. The use of pressure flow controllers in systems with variable air demand, would provide additional energy savings. In addition, if the control bands are not adjusted to maintain the existing header or storage pressure, the energy consumption may increase due to higher pressures.

Title: What's new in production: CO2-based EOR in the UK
Source title: World Oil
Authors with affiliations: Snyder, R.E.
Abstract: A DTI report, "Implementing a demonstration of Enhanced Oil Recovery (EOR) using carbon dioxide", was published in early April 2004. The report fulfills DIT's commitment in the Energy White Paper to "set up an urgent detailed implementation plan with developers and oil producers to establish what needs to be done to get a demonstration project going". The main conclusions from the report are: under existing current market conditions, there is little interest in CO2-based EOR among North Sea oil producers; CO-based EOR remains a potential option for demonstrating CO2 capture and storage (CCS), which is central to development of near-zero emissions fossil fuel combustion plants; and DTI is reviewing its strategy for development of a near-zero emission fossil fuel plant, and CO2-based EOR will be further considered within this strategy. CCS is attracting much international interest as a technique for making major reductions in CO2 greenhouse gas emissions while continuing to use fossil fuels.

Title: Direct-write laser processing creates tiny electrochemical systems

Abstract: The advances in integration and processing techniques, which have reduced the size of microelectronic and microelectromechanical devices are discussed. Laser direct-write can fabricate micro power systems which are compatible with these microdevices. Laser direct-write processes provide a general set of processing tools that can rapidly prototype and fabricate these different electrochemical energy storage components. These ambient and low-temperature techniques can provide fully embedded solutions, which enable integrated power sources within most types of rigid and flexible substrates.

Title: Technology today: Low cost for green tyres
Source title: Process Engineering
Abstract: New developments in the manufacture of silane could lead to the production of tires which are safer for drivers and less damaging to the environment. Researchers at Dow Corning's sites in Barry, South Wales, and in Midland, MI, have found a catalyst that can make silane far more affordable. Dow Corning's team has now found that phase transfer catalysis can reduce the cost of making silanes. The new process is faster and more efficient than the existing processes. It is more environmentally friendly, as it requires no salt filtration or hazardous solvents, solvent storage, recovery or treatment. The energy saving from using these "green" tires is striking, according to Martin Harvey of Dow Corning's Materials Manufacturing Industries division. When comparing the amount of CO2 released in the manufacturing process with the amount saved during the life of the tires, the benefit is that for every ton of CO2 produced in making the sulphidosilane, 250 ton of CO2 are saved in reduced fuel consumption. This has the potential to have significant environmental and cost benefits around the world.

Title: Future prospects
Source title: Print and Paper Europe
Abstract: The developing technologies in the print and paper industry are discussed. ArjoWiggins Carbonless Papers has launched I-Paper in collaboration with PaperGate Systemintegration which combines the functionality of a multipart business form with magnetic data storage. The DataLase, a new generation coding, marking and printing technique, combines chemistry, substrate conversion and laser energy to print images at high speeds. The DataLase can be used for a number of application including coding and dating products and even security marking.

Title: News: Greenlight test stations for GM, Hydrogenics electrolyzer for NRC
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: Greenlight Power Technologies has fulfilled an order from GM for six proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell test stations. The 12-kw H-series FCATS™ fuel cell automated test stations were delivered to GM's Fuel Cell R&D facility in Honeoye Falls, NY. Greenlight's fuel cell testing systems provide high-precision instrumentation, combined with full-featured software and automation. Its FCATS G500 PEM test station combines the best features from Greenlight's and Hydrogenics' previous testing systems. Hydrogenics will also supply a HyLyzer electrolyzer to the National Research Council of Canada for an advanced renewable energy installation at the NRC Institute for Fuel Cell Innovation in Vancouver. The unit will be capable of producing 1.9 kg/day of pure hydrogen from solar-powered electrolysis of water. The hydrogen produced will be compressed into storage containers for the institute's backup power system.

Title: Technical Information Center: Energy technologies
Source title: Power
Abstract: ChevronTexaco uses gasification technology, which converts low-value materials, like refinery residue, into clean synthesis gas. The company develops and commercializes advanced energy technologies, including fuel cells, photovoltaics, advanced batteries, and hydrogen storage.

Authors: Vanderwyst A., Beyer J., Passow C., Paulson A., Rowland C.
Title: Power generation and energy usage in a pressurized Mars rover
Source title: Science and Technology Series
Affiliations: Univ. of Michigan Mars Rover Team, F-XB Bldg. 1320 Beal Avenue, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Vanderwyst, A., Univ. of Michigan Mars Rover Team, F-XB Bldg. 1320 Beal Avenue, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Beyer, J., Univ. of Michigan Mars Rover Team, F-XB Bldg. 1320 Beal Avenue, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Passow, C., Univ. of Michigan Mars Rover Team, F-XB Bldg. 1320 Beal Avenue, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Paulson, A., Univ. of Michigan Mars Rover Team, F-XB Bldg. 1320 Beal Avenue, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Rowland, C., Univ. of Michigan Mars Rover Team, F-XB Bldg. 1320 Beal Avenue, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States
Abstract: Long distance Mars surface exploration by human crews requires pressurized rovers. Rover power generation and energy storage are major logistical issues since fuel storage capacity limits maximum travel range, and fuel is the single largest component by volume in a rover. This study estimates power and energy requirements for a 3-person, 1000 km round-trip vehicle, and compares power and energy source options based on current and near-future technology. Fuel cells are selected as the optimal power source based on durability, flexibility, maintainability, scalability, redundancy, and size. Hydrocarbon fuels are chosen over hydrogen, based on storage volume limitations.

Title: Quick Takes: Husky Energy Inc., Calgary, has received...

Abstract: Husky Energy Inc has received the 940,000 bbl SeaRose floating production, storage, and offloading (FPSO) vessel for White Rose oil field off Newfoundland and Labrador. The company expects first oil from White Rose field in late 2005 or early 2006, with peak oil production expected to reach 92,000 bpd. The completed FPSO is scheduled to sail to White Rose field in the last quarter of 2005.

Title: Search for synergies
Source title: Chemical Market Reporter
Authors with affiliations: Tanaka, S.
Abstract: Sumitomo Chemical's research and development (R&D) effort is focusing on synergies between core technologies. These include areas such as catalysts, precision processing of polymers, functional dyestuffs and pigments, control of crystal structure, calcinations, biotechnology, and chiral technology. The key targets for R&D efforts have been defined in line with this technology portfolio and with the company's longer-term, strategic road map. Resources will be focused on fields such as energy, IT-related chemicals, life sciences, and bulk chemistry. The goal is to create a culture of constant technological innovation which yields scientific breakthroughs and supports development of these into future core businesses.

Authors: Galaup J.-P., Fraigne S., Le Gouët J.-L., Likforman J.-P., Joffre M.
Title: Ultrafast time reversal mirror at 800 nm based on photosensitive naphthalocyanine doped solids
Source title: Femtochemistry and Femtobiology: Ultrafast Events in Molecular Science
Affiliations: Laboratoire Aimé Cotton, CNRS, Université Paris-Sud, Bât 505, Orsay cedex, 91405, France; Laboratoire d'Optique et Biosciences, Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau cedex, 91128, France
Authors with affiliations: Galaup, J.-P., Laboratoire Aimé Cotton, CNRS, Université Paris-Sud, Bât 505, Orsay cedex, 91405, France; Fraigne, S., Laboratoire Aimé Cotton, CNRS, Université Paris-Sud, Bât 505, Orsay cedex, 91405, France; Le Gouët, J.-L., Laboratoire Aimé Cotton, CNRS, Université Paris-Sud, Bât 505, Orsay cedex, 91405, France; Likforman, J.-P., Laboratoire d'Optique et Biosciences, Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau cedex, 91128, France; Joffre, M., Laboratoire d'Optique et Biosciences, Ecole Polytechnique, Palaiseau cedex, 91128, France
Abstract: Usual techniques for producing high-energy ultrashort pulses use the chirped pulse amplification (CPA) scheme, in which a combination of gratings and reflective optics to realize the stretching, amplification and compression stages are employed. This chapter presents a different approach based on the use of persistent spectral hole burning (PSHB) materials, which can be programmed to combine the roles usually played by the dispersive components and the modulator arrays. A PSHB material is nonpixelated and potentially offers a larger number of addressable points. The shaping process includes two steps: first, engraving a coherent spectral filter with an accumulated storage interferometric procedure, followed with the use of this filter to shape a probe pulse. Modifying the phase of an ultra short laser pulse or correcting a phase change implies that one is able to measure this phase. The spectral interferometry (SI) technique that perfectly suits ultra-short pulses is expected to be the ideal tool: A reference pulse is sent through the device, and the output pulse and a portion of the incident reference pulse are made to frequency beat on the entrance slit of a spectrometer. The resulting spectrogram provides the required information. The chapter adapts the SI technique for measuring the amplitude and phase of photon echo signals produced by diffraction of femtosecond pulses on a spectral hologram, therefore, demonstrating the pulse shaping and time reversal potentialities of our naphthalocyanine based photosensitive material. © 2004 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Absorption spectra; Electromagnetic pulse; Interferometry; Light sensitive materials; Photons; Photosensitivity; Ultrafast lasers; Ultrashort pulses; Chirped pulse amplifications; Compression stages; Dispersive components; High energy ultrashort pulse; Persistent spectral hole burning; Photosensitive materials; Spectral interferometry; Time reversal mirrors; Pulse shaping

Title: The new Radioactive Ion Beam Facility at GSI
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, Darmstadt, D-64291, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Weick, H., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, Darmstadt, D-64291, Germany
Abstract: The new radioactive ion beam facility is planned as part of the project of a new international accelerator facility. These new accelerators shall serve several user communities from different fields of physics, namely nuclear structure and nuclear astrophysics, hadron studies with antiprotons, investigations of compressed nuclear matter, compressed macroscopic matter in plasmas, atomic and applied physics. The existing GSI accelerators will be extended by two new synchrotrons SIS 100 and SIS 300 for high intensity and higher energy primary beams of protons and heavy ions. Radioactive ion beams will be produced and separated in-flight with a new fragment separator called Super-FRS providing fragments to three experimental areas: fast in flight beams, slowed down or stopped rare isotopes and radioactive ions stored in one of the new storage rings CR and NESR. © 2004 American Institute of Physics.

Title: The Hydrogen Economy: Myth or Possible Reality?
Source title: Chemical Market Reporter
Abstract: The efforts of US and the European Union (EU) to achieve the goals of hydrogen economy are discussed. The goal of the Department of Energy (DoE) initiative is to move the technology curve forward enough that commercialization of hydrogen-powered fuel cells, hydrogen infrastructure and advanced automotive technologies is possible. In January 2004, EU has launched the European Hydrogen and Fuel Cell Technology Platform, whose task is to draft a blueprint from fossil fuel-based economy to hydrogen-based economy. A move to hydrogen-based economy would require achieving both technological and cost objectives in production, storage of hydrogen, and its subsequent conversion into making electricity.

Title: Quick Takes: PPM Energy Inc. - Formerly Portland...
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: PPM Energy Inc commenced the development of its $74 million Waha Hub and salt cavern natural gas storage facility in West Texas. The facility will be developed in three phases during the next 6 yr, with the first phase due to become operational by 2006. The 7.2 bcf storage site, located near a major trading hub with good pipeline access, was part of the assets PPM acquired in December 2002 to expand its natural gas storage business.
