Title: Aspects of nonlinear magnetohydrodynamics in the solar corona
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Fisica, Università di Pisa, Pisa, Italy; Istituto Nazionale di Fisica della Materia, Sez. A, Università di Pisa, Pisa, Italy; Dipartimento di Astronomia e Scienza Dello Spazio, Università di Firenze, Firenze, Italy; Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC  20375, United States
Authors with affiliations: Einaudi, G., Dipartimento di Fisica, Università di Pisa, Pisa, Italy, Istituto Nazionale di Fisica della Materia, Sez. A, Università di Pisa, Pisa, Italy; Rappazzo, A.F., Dipartimento di Fisica, Università di Pisa, Pisa, Italy, Istituto Nazionale di Fisica della Materia, Sez. A, Università di Pisa, Pisa, Italy; Velli, M., Istituto Nazionale di Fisica della Materia, Sez. A, Università di Pisa, Pisa, Italy, Dipartimento di Astronomia e Scienza Dello Spazio, Università di Firenze, Firenze, Italy; Dahlburg, R.B., Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC  20375, United States
Abstract: The solar corona is structured by the dynamics of plasmas and magnetic fields, which, at the global scales of coronal loops, prominences and helmet streamers may be described by magnetohydrodynamics. Here we will discuss the importance and role of nonlinear interactions both in the heating of the solar corona, which relies on the transfer, storage and dissipation of the mechanical energy present in photospheric motion, and in the acceleration of the slow solar wind above helmet streamers. In the first example, nonlinear interactions including the coupling of coronal magnetic fields to the velocity field and emerging flux through the photosphere determine both the rate of heating and the resulting coronal topology. In the second example, linear resistive instabilities in develop nonlinearly to accelerate plasmoids into the slow wind. Once plasmoids are generated, the melon-seed force due to the overall magnetic field radial gradients is followed using an Expanding Box Model. © 2004 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Nigro G., Malara F., Carbone V., Veltri P.
Title: A coronal loop RMHD shell model for turbulence generated nanoflares
Source title: AIP Conference Proceedings
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Fisica, Università della Calabria, Unità di Cosenza, Arcavacata di Rende, I-87030, Italy; Istituto Nazionale di Fisica della Materia, Unità di Cosenza, Arcavacata di Rende, I-87030, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Nigro, G., Dipartimento di Fisica, Università della Calabria, Unità di Cosenza, Arcavacata di Rende, I-87030, Italy, Istituto Nazionale di Fisica della Materia, Unità di Cosenza, Arcavacata di Rende, I-87030, Italy; Malara, F., Dipartimento di Fisica, Università della Calabria, Unità di Cosenza, Arcavacata di Rende, I-87030, Italy, Istituto Nazionale di Fisica della Materia, Unità di Cosenza, Arcavacata di Rende, I-87030, Italy; Carbone, V., Dipartimento di Fisica, Università della Calabria, Unità di Cosenza, Arcavacata di Rende, I-87030, Italy, Istituto Nazionale di Fisica della Materia, Unità di Cosenza, Arcavacata di Rende, I-87030, Italy; Veltri, P., Dipartimento di Fisica, Università della Calabria, Unità di Cosenza, Arcavacata di Rende, I-87030, Italy, Istituto Nazionale di Fisica della Materia, Unità di Cosenza, Arcavacata di Rende, I-87030, Italy
Abstract: A model based on the use of shell technique in the wave vector space and applied to reduced MHD equations (RMHD) is presented. The model is used to describe injection, due to footpoint motions, storage and dissipation of MHD turbulence in coronal loops. It is shown that energy injected is efficiently stored in the loop where a significant level of magnetic and velocity fluctuations is obtained. Nonlinear interactions among these fluctuations give rise to an energy cascade towards smaller scales where energy is dissipated in an intermittent fashion. The statistical analysis performed on the intermittent dissipative events compares well with all observed properties of nanoflare emission statistics. © 2004 American Institute of Physics.

Title: Quick Takes: Woodside Energy Ltd. will invest...
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: Woodside Energy Ltd will invest $(Aust)1.48 billion on permit WA-271-P off Western Australia. Enfield, 40 km northwest of Western Australia's North West Cape, has reserves of > 125 million bbl of oil. The development would have an initial output of 100,000 bpd of oil and would provide growth potential through a tieback of nearby discoveries, e.g., Laverda field. The development will include five production wells, six water injection wells, and flowlines to a 900,000 bbl floating production, storage, and offloading vessel.

Title: Navy League: General Atomics wins USN's future catapult contract
Source title: Jane's Defence Weekly
Authors with affiliations: Brown, N.
Abstract: The US Naval Air Warfare Center has selected General Atomics' version of the Electromagnetic Aircraft Launch System (EMALS). Designed for the USN's future CVN-21 aircraft carrier, four EMALS launchers will be fitted in place of steam catapults. The trials involved the testing of full-scale EMALS equipment, including energy storage and power conversion systems. It is stated that the EMALS system is more controllable than a steam launchers.
Index Keywords: Air-to-air refuellers; Airbus (CO); Boeing (CO); Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF); Tankers; Air transportation; Airports; Contracts; Decision making; Fighter aircraft; Military operations; Transport aircraft; Aircraft fueling

Title: EI aviation contract awarded to Air BP
Source title: Petroleum Review
Abstract: The Energy Institute (EI) has awarded a £100,000 contract to Air BP for aviation fuel filtration research in 2004. The contract covers the design and construction of a filter conditioning of facility, and its installation and operation at O'Hare International Airport, Chicago. O'Hare has been identified as the ideal location for the fcaility as it will be installed in the fuel farm and connected to a loop of the hydrant system returning fuel to storage. When operational, the conditioning facility will enable a series of 'conditioning experiments' to be performed on filter monitors, which can then be removed for analysis.
Index Keywords: Air BP (CO); Aviation fuel; Filtration equipment; Airports; Contracts; Costs; Filtration; Hydrants; Project management; Aviation

Title: Basics of power management equipment
Source title: Plant Engineering (Barrington, Illinois)
Authors with affiliations: Smith, J.
Abstract: Various aspects of a successful power management plan were discussed to analyze the amount of electrical energy utilization and the costs of utilization. It is suggested that a good power management decisions require accurate measurements and proper data analysis. Electrical power monitoring provides the ability to measure all aspects of power quality and record them in appropriate detail. The important part of power management and monitoring is ensuring that incoming power is available. It is stated that a well-executed power management plan along with useful data and power system best practices helps to minimize cost while maximizing power quality.
Index Keywords: Cost benefit analysis; Decision making; Digital signal processing; Electric energy storage; Electric load management; Electric potential; Electric power plant equipment; Electric power systems; Harmonic distortion; Reactive power; Waveform analysis; Digital monitors; Electric Power management; Rear view mirrors; Voltage fluctuations; Electric power utilization

Authors: Deluga G.A., Salge J.R., Schmidt L.D., Verykios X.E.
Title: Scientific highlights in life sciences...Hydrogen from ethanol by autothermal reforming
Source title: Chemie-Ingenieur-Technik
Authors with affiliations: Deluga, G.A.; Salge, J.R.; Schmidt, L.D.; Verykios, X.E.
Abstract: Ethanol and ethanol-water mixtures were converted directly into H2 with ∼ 100% selectivity and > 95% conversion by catalytic partial oxidation, with a residence time on rhodium-ceria catalysts of < 10 msec. Rapid vaporization and mixing with air with an automotive fuel injector were performed at temperatures low enough and times fast enough that homogeneous reactions producing carbon, acetaldehyde, ethylene, and total combustion products can be minimized. This process has great potential for low-cost H2 generation in fuel cells for small portable applications where liquid fuel storage is essential and where systems must be small, simple, and robust. The use of ethanol-water mixtures for hydrogen production offers energy savings during the fermentative manufacturing and processing of ethanol, where most of the energy used for production is consumed for removal of water. Utilization of the hydrogen in a PEM fuel cell requires the reduction of CO to < 10 ppm. This is an abstract of an article that originally appeared in Science vol. 303, pp 993-97 (2004).

Title: Minatom replaced
Source title: Nuclear Engineering International
Authors with affiliations: Perera, J.
Abstract: The abolishment of Russia's Ministry of Atomic Energy and the establishment of Russian Federal Atomic Energy Agency (AEA) in its place is discussed. The changes are a part of the major restructuring of the government. Responsibility of the law enforcement, provision of state services and property management of Russian Federation Ministry of Atomic Energy, forms a part of the functions of AEA. The department will honour all the commitments of the Ministry of Atomic Energy.
Index Keywords: Aerospace industry; Law enforcement; Public policy; Radioactive materials; Societies and institutions; Atomic energy agency (AEA); Federal nuclear regulatory authority (FNRA); Nuclear storage facilities; Property management; Nuclear energy

Title: Innovative Office Air Conditioning With Thermal Storage
Source title: HPAC Heating, Piping, AirConditioning Engineering
Affiliations: H.T. Lyons, Allentown, PA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bracy, R., H.T. Lyons, Allentown, PA, United States
Abstract: A project involving the designing of a central air handling system for a new PPL Corp. office building in Allentown, Pa., USA, is discussed. A low-temperature air distribution system was selected in order to reduce the space required for the ductworks. It was also decided to fit the retail spaces in the building with their own air handlers which would be supplied from the central chilled-water system. The chiller plant, which has been operating for over a year, has been found to be flexible, energy-efficient, operator-friendly, and environmentally sound.
Index Keywords: Air handling systems; Building energy models; Chiller plants; Ductworks; Air conditioning ducts; Energy efficiency; Maintenance; Office buildings; Problem solving; Project management; Pumps; Refrigeration; Air conditioning

Title: Flywheel technology helps life spring eternal for battery systems
Source title: EC and M: Electrical Construction and Maintenance
Affiliations: Active Power, Austin, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Richey, S., Active Power, Austin, TX, United States
Abstract: From a reliability perspective, it's important to know that the predominant failure mode of valve-regulated lead-acid (VRLA) batteries is open circuit, which means that a single-cell failure causes loss of all battery back-up capability. Adding a flywheel energy storage system (FESS) in parallel with batteries provides a redundant UPS energy source that gives sufficient backup time to ride through most power disturbances or to transfer to standby generators.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Flywheels; Reliability; Service life; Uninterruptible power systems; Battery life extension; Flywheel energy storage system; Valve-regulated lead acid batteries; Lead acid batteries

Title: News: CSA America selected to develop hydrogen storage standards
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: CSA America, the developer of US standards for gas equipment, fuel cells and related energy sectors, has entered into an agreement with the DOE's National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) in Golden, CO, to create new standards relating to the storage and dispensing of hydrogen. The first drafts of the new standards for North America are expected by September 2004. The final standards will be developed and proposed as American National Standards.

Title: Powertrain performance: A vision of the near future
Source title: Engineering Technology
Abstract: The design of a hybrid automobile, M-Class Hyper, by DaimlerChrysler is described. The electric motor for the car's 2.7-litre CDI diesel engine is integrated into the powertrain and take no additional space. The latest powertrain design eliminates the need for a generator or starter and makes it lighter and cost effective. In comparison to pervious hybrid models, the regenerative power, which is the electrical energy recovered from the vehicle's kinetic energy per time unit, is twice as much.
Index Keywords: Automobile engines; Automobile fuel tanks; Automobile steering equipment; Diesel engines; Electric batteries; Electric control equipment; Electric motors; Energy conversion; Energy storage; Fuel consumption; Powertrain; Regenerative powers; Automobile manufacture

Title: In Brief: National Academies' report dissects prospects for US hydrogen economy
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: A transition to hydrogen as a major fuel in the next 50 yr could significantly change the US's energy economy, but major technical, economic and infrastructure barriers need to be overcome, according to a new DOE-sponsored report from the National Academies' National Academy of Engineering and National Research Council. Meeting the aim of President Bush's hydrogen initiative, to make the use of hydrogen-powered vehicles practical and cost-effective by 2020, would require overcoming many hurdles. The report foresees a likely transition stage where hydrogen is produced on a small scale using natural gas or electricity, but this would require a sharp reduction in production costs for small units. The report points out that while natural gas would probably be the most cost-effective source of hydrogen, its long-term use for this purpose would not increase the nation's energy independence. The report also highlights the need to develop significantly cheaper and more reliable fuel cells, along with safer systems for transporting, storing, and handling hydrogen in a consumer setting. The committee reviewed DOE's research, development and demonstration plan for hydrogen, and was impressed by its thoroughness and the progress made so far. The DOE program should also accelerate development and early evaluation of carbon capture and storage technologies, to enable large-scale production of hydrogen from coal without significant CO2 emissions.

Title: Solar-powered motor runs on 10 nA
Source title: EDN
Authors with affiliations: Novotill, S.
Abstract: Designs for solar-powered applications with low-duty-cycle requirements can often rely on capacitors for energy storage in place of less reliable batteries. When the circuits have low leakage currents and trigger-current requirements, it can run the motor on 10 nA of current if one use a low-leakage energy-storage capacitor. The 1N4007 diodes take the place of pullup and pulldown resistors, and the diodes bypass the leakage current of the transistors and LED. One can use 10-MΩ resistors in place of 1N4007 diodes to improve noise immunity if one does not less-than-1-μA operation.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Diodes; Electric batteries; Energy storage; Leakage currents; Light emitting diodes; Resistors; Noise immunity; Pulldown resistors; Trigger-current requirements; Solar energy

Title: Market Hotline: US gas market complexity fogging outlook
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Authors with affiliations: Williams, B.
Abstract: US natural gas market dynamics are getting to be almost as complicated as those for oil. Another strong year of LNG imports into the US will partially offset the price pressures caused by rising production costs, according to Energy Security Analysis Inc (ESAI). ESAI expects US LNG imports to top 700 bcf in 2004 vs. 500 bcf in 2003, which in turn was double 2002 levels. With landed LNG costs coming in at $2.50-2.75/million Btu, domestic producers face a tough new competitor. At the same time, US production costs are likely to rise 2-3%/quarter the rest of 2004. Gas storage is likely to end the heating season at near 1 tcf, as warmer weather appears to be the end-of-season trend. That usually would presage a slump in prices. But after adjusting for weather, working gas storage levels suggest a tightening of the supply-demand balance since January, owing to distillate prices exceeding those for gas and a return of as much as 1.7 bcf/day of industrial gas demand vs. 2003.

Title: The solar greenhouse; technology for low energy consumption
Source title: Acta Horticulturae
Affiliations: Wageningen University, Department of Agrotechnology and Food Science, Institute of Environmental and Agricultural Engineering (IMAG), P.O. Box 43, 6700 AA Wageningen, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Bot, G.P.A., Wageningen University, Department of Agrotechnology and Food Science, Institute of Environmental and Agricultural Engineering (IMAG), P.O. Box 43, 6700 AA Wageningen, Netherlands
Abstract: High energy consumption is still an obstacle for sustainable greenhouse production. Therefore reduction of absolute energy consumption has high priority. In the Solar Greenhouse project, the ultimate goal is to develop a greenhouse system with a fully sustainable energy supply. The first step in the project is to decrease greenhouse energy demand substantially. Therefore, new covering materials have to be developed enabling the combination of high insulation with high light transmittance. New flexible or rigid plastic materials with geometry designed for high light transmittance are promising. Also coating of glass is promising. In connection to improved insulation, the greenhouse itself and its climate conditioning has to be redesigned. Active, energy friendly dehumidification has to be developed. Progress on this field is reported. On a year round base, sustainable solar energy is sufficient to cover the low heat demand of well-insulated greenhouses, even in North Western Europe. Long term energy storage in aquifers can link available surplus of sustainable energy in summer with energy demand in winter. Then energy is available at low temperature levels, so a heat pump has to be applied. From crop science, insight is given in potentials of a crop to integrate temperature. In this way the overall heat demand of a greenhouse can be decreased too. Crop tolerance has to be quantified to exploit it in control strategies. In these strategies, costs and benefits can be optimised applying optimal control theory. The implementation of models is essential in greenhouse climate control enabling the prediction of systems behaviour. The accuracy of the models can be improved by updating and tuning them through actual greenhouse climate and crop measurements. Therefore crop (soft) sensors have to be developed enabling phytomonitoring. © ISHS.
Author Keywords: Dehumidification; Energy saving; Energy storage; Optimal control; Solar greenhouse; Sustainable greenhouse systems

Title: Fuel-cell fantasy
Source title: Professional Engineering
Authors with affiliations: Tayler, C.
Abstract: [No abstract available]
Index Keywords: Energy efficiency; Fuel cells; Hydrogen; Oxygen; Vehicles; Hydrogen mines; Hydrogen storage; Electric power generation

Title: Quick Takes: McMoRan Exploration Co. subsidiary Freeport-McMoran Energy LLC...
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: Freeport-McMoRan Energy LLC has filed application with the USCG for authorization to develop a $440 million, deepwater LNG receiving terminal at its Main Pass energy hub. The 1 bcf/day deepwater LNG port would be accompanied by onsite storage in several 2 mi dia subsea salt caverns to be leached at the site, enabling the proposed facility to have an aggregate deliverability of 2.5 bcf/day, including deliveries from storage.

Title: Iraq's oil exports rise via northern, southern pipelines
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Authors with affiliations: Watkins, E.
Abstract: Iraq has begun to increase its potential to export crude oil, with the long-awaited delivery of oil now under way via the country's northern pipeline system along with new and expanded transport facilities serving the country's southern fields Iraq's northern export pipeline system, which extends from the fields at Kirkuk to the Turkish port of Ceyhan on the Mediterranean, began pumping on 3/1/2004 some 300,000 bpd of oil vs. the 900,000 bpd it transported last March before the outbreak of the US-led war. Exports from Ceyhan could resume by middle of March 2004, depending on the amount of crude pumped through the pipeline as well as the amount already at the Turkish port, which has a storage capacity of 9 million bbl. During a test held last February 2004, 400,000-450,000 bpd of oil was shipped via the line; estimates of oil already on hand at Ceyhan are 2-4 million bbl. Meanwhile, Kuwait's Energy Indersecretary Issa al-Oun announced that his country has agreed to export 250,000 bpd of Iraqi oil through its terminals. According to Al-Oun, Kuwait and Iraq have formed a technical team to study the possibility of establishing a pipeline with a capacity to export ≤ 1 million bpd of Iraqi crude through Kuwaiti terminals.

Title: Use a microcontroller to design a boost converter
Source title: EDN
Affiliations: Microchip Technology, Chandler, AZ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fosler, R., Microchip Technology, Chandler, AZ, United States
Abstract: The programming capability of a microcontroller acts as an added benefit in power-supply designs. It works when MOSFET,Q, turns on, the current flowing through the inductor, L, begins to ramp up linearly resulting in energy storage in the inductor. The control circuit takes many forms, especially if a device such as the PIC16C782 microcontroller is picked up. This device integrates a built-in analog peripheral set, diverse analog visibility, and a mixed-signal PWM block.
Index Keywords: Control circuit; PIC16C782 microcontroller; Power-supply designs; Analog to digital conversion; Electric inductors; Electric power systems; Energy storage; MOSFET devices; Networks (circuits); Product design; Pulse width modulation; Signal processing; Microcontrollers

Title: Feeling the pinch
Source title: Engineered Systems
Affiliations: Energywiz, Inc., New York, United States
Authors with affiliations: Audin, L., Energywiz, Inc., New York, United States
Abstract: Endusers of natural gas resources in the US are being adversely affected by increasing prices of natural gas, despite successful efforts at refilling natural gas storage. The National Petroleum Council (NPC), reviewed its study, 'Balancing Natural Gas Policy - Fueling the Demands of a Growing Economy' that states that endusers of natural gas resources in the country need to adapt themselves according to changing circumstances, to overcome the problem. NPC revealed in its study that a significant change in the natural gas supply/demand balance has contributed to higher energy prices. It states that the problem has emerged, due to certain distinctions between natural gas supply and demand policies. The findings of the NPC study also suggest that the ability of refilling storage, to last for a year, will be unable to meet the existing requirements of endusers.
Index Keywords: Energy pricing; National Petroleum Council; Natural gas policy; Natural gas resources; Natural gas supplies; Natural-gas storage; Supply/demand balance; Competition; Economics; Energy resources; Gas industry; Gases; Natural gas; Natural gas deposits; Gas supply

Title: News. Panorama 2004: The petroleum market in 2003 and prospects to 2030-2050 [Actualités. Panorama 2004. Le marché pétrolier en 2003. Perspectives à 2030-2050]
Source title: Petrole et Techniques
Affiliations: Institut Francais du Pétrole, France
Authors with affiliations: Appert, O., Institut Francais du Pétrole, France
Abstract: A report covers the lecture on the petroleum market in 2003 by O. Appert (IFP) at the IFP Panorama 2004 on energy, oil, natural gas, the automobile, and the environment (Paris and Lyons 1/27/2004 and 2/5/2004). The discussion covers the oil market in 2003 as an unusual combination of economic factors; petroleum year of 2003 as starting under the influence of the US gas market; consumption supported by growth in China and gas/oil substitutions; destabilization of a number of large oil producers; OPEC as situated between pragmatism and voluntarism; stress without precedent with respect to the oil stocks in the US; volatility of prices amplified by speculative funds; year 2003 as experiencing the most elevated prices of crude oil; return of Russia to the international oil scene; Russia a first rate oil exporter; oil industry in constant mutation in Russia; and prospects. The discussion covers prospects to 2030-2050 in terms of facing convergence of the principal scenarios from 2000-2030, with uncertainties remaining; uncertainty on the cadence of increase in demand for oil; on the measures to be taken in the struggle against climate change; in the supply of oil; in the amount of reserves and resources of oil that can be mobilized; in the development of alternative energies; and in mobilization of investments needed to maintain and develop the production of oil and gas; and permanent interest in the prospects for energy. The quasi totality of energy needed to operate the transport sector has been assured by oil (98%). Options to this use are being explored. Conventional motors are being tested with new modes of combustion, HCCI (homogeneous combustion for diesel) and CAI (controlled auto inflammation for gasoline). Conventional fuels but with different specifications are applied to them. There are conventional engines using alternative fuels. There are the electric motor, thermal/electric hybrid system, fuel cell/H 2 system, ensemble of biofuels, NGV, LPG, and DME fuels, and fuels from synthesis gas (gas to liquid, coal to liquid, and biomass to liquid). Solutions of most interest are hybrid systems. Biofuels are of interest but their massive use raises the problem of finding sufficient land to develop them and their high cost. The cost per ton of CO 2 avoided is estimated at €200-300. The fuel cell/H 2 route still requires technical and cost improvements. Per kilometer, the cost of H 2 is higher than of gasoline or diesel, namely, four to five times more. H 2 stored on a vehicle has to be reduced in cost by 50-100 times. For an equivalent vehicle, the cost of H 2 storage is €5000-25,000/ vehicle vs. €125 for a traditional vehicle. The fuel cell costs €225,000 vs. internal combustion engine at €2000-3500.

Title: News. Concluding remarks at the AFG/GdF "Italian Gas Market" Conference of January 29, 2004 [Actualités. Conclusion de François Ravel]
Source title: Petrole et Techniques
Affiliations: Association Française du Gaz
Authors with affiliations: Ravel, F., Association Française du Gaz
Abstract: The Italian gas market is a landmark that the French gas industry follows with interest at a time when the liberalization of the energy markets of Europe seems to accelerate on the European continent. With its 70 billion cu m/yr of gas consumption, Italy is the largest market on the continent that is as advanced in its structures, its path to opening to competition (after the UK that started in the 1990s). Italy has a regulatory authority since 1997 but France formally only for a year. Italy, in its gas law of 5/23/2000 opens all its markets from 1/1/2003. At the same time, France opened 20% of its market and expects to open all its markets in 2007. Since 2001 Italy applies access of third parties to the regulated transport system with, for the high pressure national system, a rate structure of entrance/exit to a single zone. Since 2000, the transport was separated juridically from the commerce of Eni and Eni now has possession of ≤ 60% of its subsidiary Snam Rete Gas. In France, the juridical separation between transport and commerce is expected this year. The access of third parties to storage is in place in Italy since 2002, the access of third parties to LNG terminals since 2001. In retail and in practice, the situation of the opening of the Italian market is more contrasted. The infrastructure and imports are saturated and controlled by a dominant player. The priorities to access of the transport system favor the holders of long term contracts. The access to storage is reserved in terms of priority to the supplier of the residential sector. About 15% of the volumes of the industrial sector in Italy changed suppliers between 2000 and 2002 and 18% in France at mid 2003. France consumes about 67% of its gas in industry and commerce (other than generation of electricity) and the other 33% in residential use. In Italy, about 33% goes to industry and commerce, 33% residential, and 33% for electricity generation. The importance of the sector of the generation of electricity is generally an essential asset in the opening of the gas market to competition as already seen in the UK.

Title: News. The "sequestration" of carbon dioxide. A general view [Actualités. La «séquestration» du CO 2. Une vue générale]
Source title: Petrole et Techniques
Affiliations: Institut Francais du Pétrole, France
Authors with affiliations: Le Thiez, P., Institut Francais du Pétrole, France; Rojey, A., Institut Francais du Pétrole, France
Abstract: A discussion with respect to sequestration of CO 2 covers the stakes involved; possible solutions to achieve sequestration; a promising approach, i.e., the capture and storage underground geologically of CO 2; and the present situation and prospects for the future. Scenarios established by the International Panel on Climate Change show that the CO 2 level in the atmosphere of 360 ppm as of now could, in the absence of countermeasures, exceed 1000 ppm between now and the end of the century, with significant risks of changing the climate. The generation of electricity (39%), industry (22%), and transport (23%) provide the main anthropogenic emissions of CO 2. To limit them, three actions are envisaged, i.e., reducing the consumption of energy; starting to use fuels emitting less CO 2 per unit of energy produced; and capturing and storing CO 2 (sequestration). The capture of CO 2 from combustion smoke can be made using known principles. Solvent scrubbing is applied using especially amines such as monoethanolamine used also in treating natural gas. These installations present the inconvenience of cumbersome and costly installation that consume significant amounts of energy that can lead in some instances to doubling the amount of necessary energy. Also, these facilities work under slightly favorable conditions of large volumes of smoke at low pressure and with low concentrations of CO 2 in the smoke. That is why other options are considered. In one option for a new facility the fuel can be converted into synthesis gas by steam reforming of natural gas or by partial oxidation in oxygen. The CO in the mixture reacts with water in the water gas shift conversion to produce CO 2 and hydrogen. The CO 2 is then separated neatly by capture before combustion and the hydrogen can be used to produce energy (electricity and heat) without CO 2 emissions. The other option is to combust the fuel in pure oxygen yielding products of combustion with CO 2 in high concentration, making it easy to separate the CO 2 from water vapor with which it is mixed. The three main options to separate out CO 2 are absorption by chemical solvents or physically or chemically/physically; adsorption on solid adsorbents; separation membranes; and cryogenically. The capture and sequestration geologically of CO 2 is a new option that could contribute to the future significantly in the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.

Title: News. The liberalization of the Italian gas market: Present situation and prospects [Actualités. La libéralisation du marché gazier Italien: Situation actuelle et perspectives]
Source title: Petrole et Techniques
Affiliations: Auto. per l'Ener. elect. e il Gas
Authors with affiliations: d'Angelo, F., Auto. per l'Ener. elect. e il Gas
Abstract: A resumé by P. LePrince is provided of the lecture of A. Ferrari on the liberalization of the Italian gas market. The resumé is provided in terms of introduction; the natural gas situation in Italy; the distribution system; the legislative framework; the results; and conclusion. The natural gas market in Italy is characterized by the dominant role of the Eni company at all levels of the gas chain; by the fragmented distribution involving over 700 local players that divide up the retail market; and by the prices higher than the European average despite surveillance of wholesale prices at the level of large consumers and despite the rates regulated at the level of the residential and commercial consumers. Total natural gas consumption in Italy in 2002 was 70 billion cu m. The growth rate is 4%/yr, due largely to a strong demand for electrical energy. Parallel to this demand, the domestic production of gas, which peaked in 1994-1996 (20 billion cu m) decreases steadily (14.1 billion cu m in 2002-2003). Resorting to imports is an increasing necessity. Imports are assured from countries outside of the EU. The distribution system in Italy resides in 30,400 km of gas pipelines and storage capacity of 12.2 billion cu m in depleted fields. There are four transport companies on Italian soil of which SNAM Rete Gas controls over 96% of the system. There is now a regulatory authority that encourages commercial competition; protects the end consumer; watches over a just return on invested capital; promotes new investments; and studies improving the efficiency and quality of service to the consumer. The "regulator" takes all the necessary steps to assure a gradual transition to the free market. Its concerns include rules and economic criteria and applicable rates to the diverse links in the gas chain (transport, access to storage, capillary distribution, and access to LNG terminals, for example). These actions have provided for less fragmentation in distribution and retail sales; appearance of new operators in the gas chain; 15% of consumers changing their main supplier in the industrial sector; low rates for transport and storage; increase in transport and storage capacity; and over 5% of short term import contracts. Despite the results of this policy of progressive liberalization, there remain obstacles such as congestion of international pipelines, the lack of new investments from new operators, and lack of visibility on the future of electricity. In terms of a unified European market, progress in the regulatory system remains to be made such as reinforced coordination among the regulatory bodies of the EU and development of hubs.

Title: News. Underground "sequestration" of carbon dioxide. Future options [Actualités. La «séquestration» souterraine du CO2. Les options d'avenir]
Source title: Petrole et Techniques
Affiliations: IFP
Authors with affiliations: LePrince, P., IFP
Abstract: From 2000 to 2030, according to O. Appert (IFP), CO2 emissions could increase by 70% to attain 70 billion ton/yr if no action is taken to reduce them. A first solution is the use of fuels with low carbon content. A second solution is to capture CO2 produced by energy producers and to inject the CO2 into appropriate geological formations. According to A. Pilavachi (European Commission), the European policy to reduce greenhouse gas warming of the planet involves the use of renewable energy, capture and sequestration of CO2, and improvement of energy yields. Projects now underway include AZEP - new chemical capturing process - Alstom; Grace - CO2 capture in the refinery BP; GETSCO - study of the potential of sequestration - GEUS of Denmark; CO2 STORE study of underground CO2 storage reservoirs - Statoil; NASCENT - study of the mechanisms of CO2 retention in reservoirs - British Geological Survey; RECOPOL - storage of CO2 in coal mines TNO (The Netherlands); WEYBURN behavior of CO2 in assisted recovery in the Weyburn field British Geological Survey; SACS 2 - behavior of CO2 injected in the Sleipner field - Statoil; and CO2 NET - thematic network on CO2 SHE Technology Initiative. Other projects are starting. B. Berger (Statoil); A. Rojey (IFP); and C. Feuillac (BRGM) examined the stakes of sequestration of CO2. J. Labeyrie (ADEME) discussed the orientations and major challenges. P. Le Thiez (IFP) described the techniques of sequestration in different types of underground storage. N. P. Christensen (GEUS) made an inventory of potential storage sites in Europe. I. Ritsema (TNO) presented views on the long term behavior of underground storage and the risks that they can present. P. Freund (IEA Greenhouse Gas R&D Program) summarized present techniques and future prospects, and E. Freund (IFP) insisted on the necessity to engage this subject in terms of R&D programs cooperatively in Europe and the world.

Title: News. Carbon dioxide storage. The GCEP of Stanford University [Actualités. Stockage du CO2. Le projet GCEP de l'université de Stanford]
Source title: Petrole et Techniques
Affiliations: Schlumberger
Authors with affiliations: Labadens, A., Schlumberger
Abstract: CO2 storage is an area of research of Stanford University and its industrial partners in the framework of the GCEP (Global Climate and Research Project). Since January 2003, Stanford University manages the GCEP with the support of four international companies, ExxonMobil, General Electric, Schlumberger, and Toyota for a total of $225 million over 10 yr. The GCEP brings together the world of scientific research and engineering of universities and industry. Its goal is to develop new technologies that can be commercialized allowing the generation of energy with a low emission of greenhouse gases. Diversity of energy sources is an essential element of this project because it is improbable that only one source of energy will respond to all future demands. Since its creation, the GCEP has concentrated on the geological sequestration of CO2, the integrated evaluation of technological options, the production and use of hydrogen, and advanced combustion. The integrated evaluation of technological options relates to a system of analysis with mathematical models that can be used continuously to evaluate technological options of energy sources with low greenhouse gas emissions. The hydrogen project relates to the production of hydrogen by genetic photosynthesis using the sun as the main source of energy. Other research relates to the manufacture of the "film" for high output fuel cells. The advanced combustion project relates to the development of systems of combustion much more efficient seeking to reduce the emissions of CO2 in the use of fossil fuels.

Title: News. Reduction of carbon dioxide emissions: The responses of the French Institute of Petroleum [Actualités. Réduction des émissions de CO2: Les réponses de l'Institut Franćais du Pétrole]
Source title: Petrole et Techniques
Authors with affiliations: Salles, E.
Abstract: With the prospect of continuous growth in energy consumption tied to world economic growth, the struggle against the greenhouse effect by the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions in the atmosphere constitutes a major engineering challenge in coming years. For the hydrocarbons, the goals include the reduction of energy consumption, notably by engines, by the progressive use of fossil fuels with lower carbon content and by non-fossil fuels low in carbon, and by the capture and sequestration of CO2. Institut Français du Pétrole (IFP) is involved nationally and internationally all along the petroleum chain in these three areas. In transport, the manufacturers have taken on CO2 emissions reduction from 140 g/km in 2008 to 120 g/km in 2012. IFP works on the optimal design of gasoline and diesel engines, on new modes of combustion such as homogeneous combustion to reconcile higher performance with very low emission levels. With respect to alternative fuels, the most interesting avenues appear to be NGV (natural gas vehicles), biofuels, and, in the long term, hydrogen, despite the obstacles to its development. In making a CO2 balance for the different types of fuels, it is important to make a complete analysis of the life cycle from the well to the wheel, taking into account the ensemble of the steps of production and use of the fuel. It is thus for example that the use of hydrogen, seemingly satisfactory, can be penalizing if its production is accompanied by elevated emissions of CO2. The capture and sequestration of CO2 underground is a promising solution in terms of the impact of carbon dioxide emissions. However, the problems to overcome are significant. It is a question of being able to store significant amounts of CO2, to reduce the costs, still high, and to be able to guarantee the security and integrity of the storage in the long term. CO2 can be stored in exhausted oil and gas fields, in deep saline aquifers, and in non exploited coal veins. The storage potential for depleted oil and gas fields is 920 billion ton. In the case of saline aquifers, it seems to be 400-10,000 billion ton. In coal veins, the potential is 5-150 billion ton. These estimates are to be compared with annual CO2 emissions that are now 23 billion ton.

Title: Wind power body makes waves
Source title: Chemical Engineer
Abstract: The efforts made by British Wind Energy Association (BWEA) to champion the emrging wave and tidal power sector and bringing wind farms to the UK countryside are discussed. At the wave and tidal conference in Bristol in February 2004, the UK energy minister Stephen Timms, also extended support and underlined the government's continued commitment to the renewables sector. Wind power is seen as a major cornerstone in the quest to slow climate change through carbon emissions reductions. Germany has the largest installed wind capacity in Europe and in 2003, the overall output from wind turbines was 30% down on previous years because of fine summer weather.
Index Keywords: Carbon; Cost effectiveness; Energy policy; Energy utilization; Fossil fuels; Fuel cells; Project management; Renewable energy resources; Technical presentations; Tidal power; Weather forecasting; Wind turbines; Power storage; Wind farms; Wind power

Title: A better time now to consider new reactors
Source title: Nuclear Plant Journal
Affiliations: Exelon Nuclear, United States
Authors with affiliations: Crane, C., Exelon Nuclear, United States
Abstract: The views of Christopher Crane, President and Chief Nuclear Officer, Exelon Nuclear, on new reactors are presented. He thinks that the new reactors must be economically competitive as compared to other base load generation alternatives. For high level waste disposal the Seceretary of Energy and the Congress have recommended and approved a license application to the U.S. Nuclear Power Regulatory Commission(NRC) for the storage and disposal of spent fuel and high level waste at the Yucca Mountain site. Attracting initial investors to demonstrate successfully the new regulatory process and plant construction will significantly reduce the risk for follow on investors.
Index Keywords: Capital investors; High level waste; Regulatory process; Economic and social effects; Laws and legislation; Nuclear energy; Nuclear industry; Nuclear reactor licensing; Radioactive waste disposal; Nuclear power plants

Title: Heading toward hydrogen
Source title: Energy (Norwalk, Connecticut)
Authors with affiliations: Uhrig, R.E.
Abstract: The benefits of using Hydrogen as a transportation fuel are discussed. Hydrogen is proposed to be used as a transportation energy fuel, since as an energy resource, it can be converted into electricity for transportation using fuel cells. The other benefits of using Hydrogen as fuel include the reduction of pollutants and greenhouse gases being emitted into the atmosphere by transportation vehicles. The thermo-chemical water-splitting method for the production of Hydrogen is also discussed. It is pointed out that a nuclear-assisted plasma technique, can effect positively the infrastructure for storage, transportation, and distribution of this liquid fuel.
Index Keywords: Chemical industry; Combustion equipment; Electrolysis; Energy management; Energy resources; Energy utilization; Feedstocks; Fertilizers; Fuel cells; Methane; Natural gas; Power generation; Regulatory compliance; Thermal conductivity; Thermodynamics; Transportation; Endothermic reactions; Hydrocarbon fuels; Transportation energy; Transportation vehicles; Hydrogen

Title: Top of the news: United States and Japan team on alternative-fuel research
Source title: National Petroleum News
Abstract: In January 2004, US Secretary of Energy Spencer Abraham and Goji Sakamoto, senior vice minister of economy, trade, and industry for Japan, signed a joint statement of intent to pursue precompetitive R&D in the field of fuel cell and hydrogen technologies. Following the signature of the joint statement, the two countries intend to bring together appropriate officials and technical experts to participate in workshops and seminars, and exchange experts, and share information on current policies, technological programs, and developments in the area of fuel cells and hydrogen production, storage, and transport technologies. The use of hydrogen as an energy carrier offers several important advantages relative to exiting systems.

Title: Basic research needs in hydrogen production for a hydrogen energy economy
Source title: ACS Division of Fuel Chemistry, Preprints
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, 152 Davey Laboratory, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Dept. of Molec. Genet./Cell Biology, University of Chicago, 1103 E. 57th St, Chicago, IL 60637, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mallouk, T.E., Department of Chemistry, 152 Davey Laboratory, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Mets, L., Dept. of Molec. Genet./Cell Biology, University of Chicago, 1103 E. 57th St, Chicago, IL 60637, United States
Abstract: Hydrogen production from a recent DOE sponsored workshop on hydrogen production, storage, and use was presented. The development of large scale, cost-effective, and sustainable hydrogen production methods poses many technical challenges. Basic research needs in the context of the scale of the problem, current methods of hydrogen production, and the timeline for implementation of hydrogen as an energy currency for transportation and other uses were described.

Title: Novel zero-CO2 emission technology of catalytic production of hydrogen and aromatics from methane and biogas for fuel cell society
Source title: ACS Division of Fuel Chemistry, Preprints
Affiliations: Catalysis Research Center, Hokkaido University, Sapporo 001-0021, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ichikawa, M., Catalysis Research Center, Hokkaido University, Sapporo 001-0021, Japan
Abstract: A discussion covers a "cyclohexane/decalin hi-way" concept for 21st century sustainable hydrogen energy from CH4 and biogas for a fuel cell society; novel catalytic technology for direct CH4 (biogas) reforming towards hydrogen and organic hydrides; and hydrogen storage and supply to fuel cell systems using organic hydrides.

Title: Theoretical perspective on improving kinetics in Mg hydrogen storage
Source title: ACS Division of Fuel Chemistry, Preprints
Affiliations: Accelrys Inc., 9685 Scranton Rd, San Diego, Ca 92121, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liang, J.-J., Accelrys Inc., 9685 Scranton Rd, San Diego, Ca 92121, United States; Khosrovani, N., Accelrys Inc., 9685 Scranton Rd, San Diego, Ca 92121, United States
Abstract: Magnesium, forming ionic, transparent MgH2-containing 7.6 mass % hydrogen, is among those that are most-promising in hydrogen-storage materials for mobile applications. Density functional theories method was used to look at hydrogen dissociation on both unmodified- and transition metal modified-Mg 100 surface. Energy barrier, surface sorption energy, and surface diffusion barrier were studied. Hydrogen dissociations on unmodified Mg 100 surface were deactivated, with barriers around 92 kJ/mole. When doped with transition metals, the dissociation barrier could be lowered, in some cases to the extent of being unactivated. Pd doping was the most promising, based on the considerations of the activation barrier, energy requirement for reverse (desorption) process, and surface diffusion barrier.

Title: Solar water heater with thermosyphon circulation
Source title: Appropriate Technology
Affiliations: Ökozentrum Langenbruck, Ctr. Appropriate Technol./Soc. Ecol., Langenbruck CH-4438, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Sitzmann, B., Ökozentrum Langenbruck, Ctr. Appropriate Technol./Soc. Ecol., Langenbruck CH-4438, Switzerland
Abstract: In comparison to conventional hot-water heating systems, solar water heaters (SWH) can represent an alternative with moderate costs in countries with high energy costs and sufficient irradiation. The circulation of the heat carrying fluid in the SWH described here is effected by the difference of density between the warmer liquid in the solar panel and the colder liquid in the storage tank. Therefore, no electrical pumps or control equipment are needed. Due to their simple nature, SWH can be produced by local craftsmen, so investment costs can be reduced and they can become a cost-effective alternative to conventional hot-water tanks. SWH are used mainly in hospitals and hotels in developing countries. However there are also market opportunities in urban surroundings with increasing standard of living. Projects with SWH in Zimbabwe [1] and Puerto Rico [3]have already shown successful implementation and a stable market conditions for the heaters. At present Ōkozentrum Langenbruck is working with partners in Eritrea in setting up the local production of SWH.
Index Keywords: appropriate technology; solar power; Africa; Atlantic islands; Atlantic Ocean; Caribbean Islands; East Africa; Eritrea; Greater Antilles; Puerto Rico; Southern Africa; Sub-Saharan Africa; Zimbabwe

Title: Kinder Morgan Leading Way In Moving Gas From Rockies
Source title: Pipeline and Gas Journal
Authors with affiliations: Share, J.
Abstract: The growth of Kinder Morgan Inc. in the natural gas transmission and distribution business after the merger with KN Energy is discussed. Most of the Kinder Morgan's natural gas portfolio revolves around new or expanded pipelines coming out of the Rocky Mountain basins, supplying fuel to markets in the Southwest and Mid-Continent. According to the National Petroleum Council study on natural gas, there are going to be pipelines with supply constraints without Rocky Mountain gas. The study indicates potential for Rocky Mountain production could double over the next seven years if it continues to grow at the same historical rate of 10% annually.
Index Keywords: Drilling; Energy policy; Environmental impact; Industrial economics; Investments; Job analysis; Laws and legislation; Mergers and acquisitions; Natural gas transportation; Project management; Kinder Morgan Inc. (CO); Natural gas storage; Natural gas pipelines

Authors: LaBar M.P., Shenoy A.S., Simon W.A., Campbell E.M.
Title: Introducing the GT-MHR
Source title: Nuclear Engineering International
Affiliations: General Atomics, 3550 General Atomics Court, San Diego, CA 92121-1122, United States
Authors with affiliations: LaBar, M.P., General Atomics, 3550 General Atomics Court, San Diego, CA 92121-1122, United States; Shenoy, A.S., General Atomics, 3550 General Atomics Court, San Diego, CA 92121-1122, United States; Simon, W.A., General Atomics, 3550 General Atomics Court, San Diego, CA 92121-1122, United States; Campbell, E.M., General Atomics, 3550 General Atomics Court, San Diego, CA 92121-1122, United States
Abstract: The development and advantages of a gas turbine-modular helium reactor (GT-MHR) in a joint Russia-USA programme are discussed. The GT-MHR meets the 'Generation IV' nuclear programme goals, including passive safety, competitive economics, enhanced proliferation resistance and improved waste disposal characteristics. The Brayton cycle gas turbine (GT) energy conversion system for producing electricity results in a net plant efficiency of approximately 48%. The GT-MHR spent fuel is ideally suited for both long-term storage and permanent disposal in a repository and its high thermal efficiency and burnup capability results in reduced environmental impacts.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Brayton cycle; Coolants; Electricity; Energy conversion; Gas turbines; Graphite; Heat exchangers; Helium; Magnetic bearings; Radioactive waste disposal; Reactor cores; Recuperators; Spent fuels; Gas-turbine-modular helium reactors (GT-MHR); Thermal discharges; Gas cooled reactors

Title: Blue laser diodes are grown by MBE
Source title: Laser Focus World
Authors with affiliations: Marx, B.
Abstract: The development of blue-violet laser diodes by molecular-beam epitaxy (MBE) is discussed. The devices, based on nitride semiconductors, are developed to comply with the Blu-ray standard for next-generation DVD storage and video applications. A 450-nm-emitting laser diode is fabricated by MBE, a process that increases control of growth. The blue laser diode developed by MBE offer significant reduction in the consumption of source material, which can in turn have implications for laser production costs and in reducing the environmental impact of the production method.
Index Keywords: Continuous wave lasers; Costs; Fabrication; Managers; Metallorganic chemical vapor deposition; Molecular beam epitaxy; Reflection high energy electron diffraction; Sapphire; Semiconducting indium compounds; Semiconductor quantum wells; Standards; Videodisks; Blue laser diodes; Production costs; Semiconductor lasers

Title: Where courage is present
Source title: Nuclear Engineering International
Authors with affiliations: Gordon, J.
Abstract: A round table conference was held in London, UK on 13 February, 2004 to discuss the problem of technetium-99 (Tc-99) discharges from the Sellafield reprocessing plant. Tc-99 is a fission product liberated from spent Magnox fuel during reprocessing and the Thorp reprocessing facility at Sellafield catches 99% of Tc-99 it produces and vitrifies it for long-term storage along with other high-level wastes. Though it is nor harmful for human health, the concentrations have increased 18-fold since 1996. BNFL has proposed that the addition of the precipitation agent tetraphenylphosphonium bromide (TPP) to the liquid medium active concentrate (MAC) to extract Tc-99.
Index Keywords: Bromine compounds; Health; Nuclear energy; Nuclear fuel reprocessing; Nuclear industry; Nuclear power plants; Spent fuels; Strontium; Technical presentations; Vitrification; Medium active concentrate (MAC); Seaweed industry; Technetium

Title: Early riser
Source title: International Water Power and Dam Construction
Abstract: The Gitaru hydro power station is located on the Tana river, about 160km north-east of the Kenyan capital, Nairobi. The Gitaru reservoir is relatively small, with long-term storage being provided by the upstream Kamburu and Masinga reservoirs. Owned and operated by Kenya Electricity Generation Company Ltd. (KenGen), the plant with its two Voith Siemens Hydro 72.5 MW vertical Francis units, began commercial operation in 1978. In this initial phase, the civil design and construction had already made provisions for a third unit. Nevertheless, it was not until the second half of the 1990s, when Kenya's electricity demand began to exceed supply, that the decision to install additional generating capacity was taken. The Gitaru machines are among the largest hydro generating units in the Kenyan grid and, while the third machine would provide additional energy during the rainy season, it would give year-round peaking power and increase KenGen's operational flexibility. Once the decision had been made, KenGen acted quickly to secure this additional capacity.
Index Keywords: Civil engineering; Dams; Decision making; Electric load management; Electric power generation; Electricity; Hydroelectric power; Rain; Reservoirs (water); Structural design; Water power; Operational flexibility; Hydroelectric power plants; hydroelectric power plant; power generation; reservoir; water resource; energy and power technology; hydroelectric power plant; power generation; reservoir; Africa; East Africa; Kenya; Sub-Saharan Africa; Tana River

Title: All Wrapped Up
Source title: World Cement
Affiliations: Lachenmeier A/S, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Kristensen, A.H., Lachenmeier A/S, Denmark
Abstract: The factors considered while choosing a pallet wrapping method are discussed. In order to protect the packages and to stabilize the load for shipping, handling and storage, pallets loaded with cement need to be wrapped properly. The costs of the wrapping equipment and the wrapping itself should be considered while choosing a pallet wrapping method. The factors that should be considered include, customer preferences, the branding and marketability of the wrapped products, required labor, energy and capacity.
Index Keywords: Cements; Costs; Customer satisfaction; Freight transportation; Marketing; Pallets; Storage (materials); Warehouses; Branding; Pallet wrapping; Packaging

Title: Total System Solutions
Source title: World Cement
Affiliations: Inbulk Technologies, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Thomson, B., Inbulk Technologies, United Kingdom
Abstract: The collaboration between Clyde Materials Handling and sister company, InBulk Technologies, to provide improved material handling services to the cement industry is discussed. A combination of Clyde's 'DensPhase' pneumatic conveying systems and InBulk's ISO-Veyors, offer the ideal solution for cement companies wishing to improve production. The combination maximize production efficiency and capability, and implement greater project flexibility. The collaboration also provides cost-effective service to their customer, with fast delivery times, all with minimum effect on the environment.
Index Keywords: Cement plants; Construction industry; Cost effectiveness; Energy efficiency; Materials handling; Pipelines; Pneumatic conveyors; Project management; Railroads; Storage (materials); Bulk materials; Rail networks; Cement industry

Title: Global Business Systems
Source title: World Cement
Affiliations: Yokogawa, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Brown, A., Yokogawa, Australia
Abstract: The use of the Exaquantum plant information management system (PIMS) at Blue Circle Southern Cement's Malden plant, Australia is discussed. The use of the system is to analyze the plant and review overall equipment effectiveness. The importance of the combined package of the Yokogawa distributed control system (DCS) and the Exaquantum PIMS is that complete, one-stop solutions can be provides to plant operators wishing to build new or refurbish to world-class standards. The systems developers must examine the real needs of plant operators and create responsive and best-fit solutions while designing world-class PIMS.
Index Keywords: Data processing; Data storage equipment; Database systems; Decision making; Distributed parameter control systems; Energy utilization; Enterprise resource planning; Graphical user interfaces; Information management; Personnel training; Planning; Standards; Statistical process control; Integrated information systems (IIS); Plant information management systems (PIMS); Cement plants

Title: 5-quark baryon Θ+ and related topics of SPring-8
Source title: Acta Physica Polonica B
Affiliations: RCNP, Osaka University, Ibaraki, Osaka 567-0047, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kohri, H., RCNP, Osaka University, Ibaraki, Osaka 567-0047, Japan
Abstract: 5-quark baryon Θ+ with S = +1 was discovered in photoproduction from the neutron in 12C at LEPS of SPring-8. A Gaussian significance was 4.6σ. The mass and width of the Θ+ were 1.54 ± 0.01 GeV/c2 and smaller than 25 MeV/c2, respectively. Recent results from other experiments confirmed the existence of the Θ+. The Θ+ can be interpreted as a molecular meson-baryon resonance or alternatively as an exotic five quark state (uudds̄). Photon beam asymmetries for the p(γ, K+)Λ and p(γ, K+)Σ0 reactions were measured at Eγ = 1.5-2.4 GeV and 0.6 < cos(θK+c.m.) < 1.0 by using linearly polarized photon beam. The measured asymmetries are positive and gradually increase with rising photon energy. There is no theoretical prediction which perfectly reproduces the measurements. Including the new results in the development of theoretical models is crucial for understanding the reaction mechanism and to test the presence of missing resonances.
Index Keywords: Mathematical models; Particle spectrometers; Resonance; Storage rings; Baryon; Linearly polarized photon beam; Molecular meson-baryon resonance; Photon energy; Photoproduction; Elementary particles

Title: Hypernuclear physics projects with PANDA at GSI
Source title: Acta Physica Polonica B
Affiliations: Gesell. fur Schwerionenforschung, Postfach 110552, 64220 Darmstadt, Germany; Institut für Kernphysik, Universität Mainz, Mainz, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Saitoh, T.R., Gesell. fur Schwerionenforschung, Postfach 110552, 64220 Darmstadt, Germany; Pochodzalla, J., Institut für Kernphysik, Universität Mainz, Mainz, Germany
Abstract: Studies of ΛΛ-double-hypernuclei and Ω-atoms by means of γ-ray spectroscopy with Ge detectors represent a unique tool to investigate Y N and YY interaction and to measure the only directly observable quadrupole moment of a hadron. These challenging experiments will be performed by the PANDA collaboration (Proton ANtiproton at DArmstadt) at the High Energy Storage Ring (HESR) of the future GSI facility. For the ΛΛ double-hypernuclear γ-ray spectroscopy, a rate of several hundreds γ-ray events per day is expected.
Index Keywords: Atoms; Gamma rays; Germanium; Protons; Spectroscopy; Gamma ray spectroscopy; Germanium detectors; Hadron; High energy storage ring; Hypernuclei; Nuclear physics

Title: Ethanol Powers Fuel Cell
Source title: Industrial Bioprocessing
Abstract: The use of ethanol in producing hydrogen through a clean process is discussed. Ethanol can be manufactured from renewable raw materials, and then converted into hydrogen than can be oxidized in a fuel cell to supply power. The method does not generates greenhouse gases unlike the conventional manner of producing hydrogen which produces harmful gases. The method uses a fuel injector to rapidly vaporize ethanol and it converts the materials into hydrogen by partial oxidation.
Index Keywords: Catalysts; Electric power generation; Ethanol; Gas fuel storage; Greenhouse effect; Hydrogen; Ion exchange membranes; Oxidation; Patents and inventions; Electric energy; Proton exchange membranes (PEM); Fuel cells; Catalysts; Ethanol; Fuel Cells; Greenhouse Gases; Hydrogen; Oxidation; Power Generation

Title: Tool Tweaks Algorithms For Low-Power Operation
Source title: Electronic Design
Authors with affiliations: Maliniak, D.
Abstract: The performance of digital systems and the algorithms that control memory accesses were studied. PowerEscape's products provide source-code-level feedback to tune algorithms for power and performance for a given memory architecture. PowerEscape Analyzers examines ANSI C algorithms and provides reports on memory accesses and the memory subsystem. The results enable designers to optimize both their source code and memory subsystems for lower power.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computer architecture; Computer software; Data storage equipment; Energy utilization; Problem solving; Memory architectures; Memory subsystems; Power electronics

Title: In Brief: Dynetek hydrogen storage systems for Australian bus demo
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: Dynetek Industries has won a contract to supply three on-board hydrogen fuel storage systems for Mercedes-Benz Citaro fuel cell buses bound for Perth, Western Australia. The certified 350 bar hydrogen fuel storage systems will be delivered in the first quarter of 2004. Dynetek continues to partner Ballard Power Systems, which is providing its latest-generation heavy-duty fuel cell engines to EvoBus for integration into the Citaro buses. The Perth buses will operate for a 2-yr demonstration program as part of the Transperth public transport system, within the city's Sustainable Transport Energy Program.

Title: News: Expanded team for marine H2 technology
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: Texaco Ovonic Hydrogen Systems (TOHS) will provide its developmental metal hydride hydrogen storage system to HaveBlue for inclusion in the latter's X/V-1 marine hydrogen fuel technology demonstration program. HaveBlue has developed and patented a propulsion and power generation system that produces renewable hydrogen from purified sea water using clean energy power sources, e.g., solar panels, wind generators, and regenerative electric drive motors. The firm believes that sailing yachts are the perfect early adopter of hydrogen as a transportation fuel, and has teamed with Catalina yachts to build its first full-scale technology demonstrator, the X/V-1. The TOHS system will provide a means to store the hydrogen produced by HaveBlue's system in a safe, solid form aboard the modified yacht. TOHS's storage systems offer several advantages over conventional hydrogen storage methods, e.g., environmentally friendly components, higher performance, greater hydrogen capacity, higher performance, and better absorption and desorption.

Title: Obsolete!
Source title: Dr. Dobb's Journal
Authors with affiliations: Nisley, E.
Abstract: A comparison of processor performance and system throughput, and the prospects of future embedded systems are discussed. The number of active devices on an LSI chip doubles every 18 months, which works out to a factor of 11 every five years. It is proposed that faster processor clocks and deeper pipelines lose to relatively slow memory and frequent branches in program logic. It is found that system performance depends more on the amount and speed of RAM, both cache and bulk, than on the CPU's internal clock frequency.
Index Keywords: Mobile graphics; Power management; Processor performance; Buffer storage; CMOS integrated circuits; Computer architecture; Computer graphics; Energy dissipation; Liquid crystal displays; Microprocessor chips; Personal computers; Security systems; Semiconductor device manufacture; Embedded systems

Authors: Rand D.A.J., Garche J., Moseley P.T., Parker C.D.
Title: Valve-Regulated Lead-Acid Batteries
Source title: Valve-Regulated Lead-Acid Batteries
Affiliations: CSIRO Energy Technology, Bayview Avenue, Clayton South, VIC  3169, Australia; Center for Solar Energy and Hydrogen Research (ZSW), Electrochemical Energy Storage and Energy Conversion Division, Baden-Württemberg Helmholtzstr. 8, Ulm, D-89081, Germany; International Lead Zinc Research Organization, Inc., 2525 Meridian Parkway Suite 100, Durham, NC  27713, United States; International Lead Zinc Research Organization, Inc., PO Box 12036, Research Triangle Park, NC  27709-2036, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rand, D.A.J., CSIRO Energy Technology, Bayview Avenue, Clayton South, VIC  3169, Australia; Garche, J., Center for Solar Energy and Hydrogen Research (ZSW), Electrochemical Energy Storage and Energy Conversion Division, Baden-Württemberg Helmholtzstr. 8, Ulm, D-89081, Germany; Moseley, P.T., International Lead Zinc Research Organization, Inc., 2525 Meridian Parkway Suite 100, Durham, NC  27713, United States; Parker, C.D., International Lead Zinc Research Organization, Inc., PO Box 12036, Research Triangle Park, NC  27709-2036, United States
Abstract: For many decades, the lead-acid battery has been the most widely used energy-storage device for medium- and large-scale applications (approximately 100Wh and above). In recent years, the traditional, flooded design of the battery has begun to be replaced by an alternative design. This version - the valve-regulated lead-acid (VRLA) battery - requires no replenishment of the water content of the electrolyte solution, does not spill liquids, and can be used in any desired orientation. Since the VRLA battery operates in a somewhat different manner from its flooded counterpart, considerable technological development has been necessary to meet the exacting performance requirements of the full range of applications in which rechargeable batteries are used. The valve-regulated design is now well established in the industrial battery sector, and also appears set to be adopted widely for automotive duty. This book provides a comprehensive account of VRLA technology and its uses. In the future, all industrial processes - including the manufacture of batteries - will be required to conform to the conventions of sustainability. Accordingly, the crucial areas of the environmental impact associated with the production and use of VRLA batteries and the recycling of spent units are also treated thoroughly. Valve-Regulated Lead-Acid Batteries gives an essential insight into the science that underlies the development and operation of VRLA batteries and is a comprehensive reference source for those involved in the practical use of the technology in key energy-storage applications. © 2004 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Corrosion; Electric batteries; Electrolytes; Environmental impact; Floods; Secondary batteries; Sustainable development; Virtual storage; Development and operations; Electrolyte solutions; Energy storage applications; Industrial processs; Large-scale applications; Performance requirements; Technological development; Valve regulated lead acid batteries; Lead acid batteries

Title: Battery Energy-Storage Systems for Power-Supply Networks
Source title: Valve-Regulated Lead-Acid Batteries
Affiliations: International Lead Zinc Research Organization, Inc., PO Box 12036, Research Triangle Park, NC  27709-2036, United States; Center for Solar Energy and Hydrogen Research (ZSW), Electrochemical Energy Storage and Energy Conversion Division, Baden-Württemberg Helmholtzstr. 8, Ulm, D-89081, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Parker, C.D., International Lead Zinc Research Organization, Inc., PO Box 12036, Research Triangle Park, NC  27709-2036, United States; Garche, J., Center for Solar Energy and Hydrogen Research (ZSW), Electrochemical Energy Storage and Energy Conversion Division, Baden-Württemberg Helmholtzstr. 8, Ulm, D-89081, Germany
Abstract: This chapter discusses the application and benefits of large-scale battery energy-storage systems (BESS) in electricity power-supply networks. The great majority of systems deployed have been BESS designs based on lead-acid technology. Computer-based, power-electronic control systems are creating a growing demand for reliable, high-quality electrical power that can be available via energy storage systems. This trend favours a growing number of BESS applications. Most BESS applications require the four-quadrant operation that is the ability of the ac side to both absorb and deliver both volt-ampere reactive (VAR) and watt. This capacity is provided by the back diodes that parallel the power switches and controls on the firing angles of the power switches. Many electric utility companies world over are successfully using BSESs for power supply. Crescent Electric Membership Corporation, Statesville, NC, the United States is using a 500 kW, 500 kWh BESS as a peak-shaving facility since July 1987 to reduce demand charges paid to their supplying utility. The battery consists of a single string of 324 cells configured six cells per module. These are flooded, deep-cycle cells with lead-antimony grids. The BESS at the GNB lead smelting and recycling center in Vernon is foremost an uninterruptable power supply (UPS) system that serves an essential purpose at an environmentally sensitive facility. The recycling centre is located about 16km south-east of downtown Los Angeles, and it recycles about ten million lead-acid batteries annually. The PQ2000 is another BESS that is designed to meet the growing market demand for high quality, reliable power for industrial and utility applications. It is primarily a rapid reserve resource that temporarily substitutes for the utility supply in the event of a power-line anomaly and, subsequently, returns the load to utility service excitation when the service returns to normal. © 2004 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Title: Plains Exploration to acquire Nuevo Energy
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: Plains Exploration & Production Co has agreed to acquire Nuevo Energy Co in a stock transaction valued at $945 million. In downstream and midstream news: Valero Energy Corp has agreed to buy the 315,000 bpd Aruba refinery and related operations from El Paso Corp for $465 million; Kinder Morgan Energy Partners LP has agreed to buy seven refined petroleum products terminals in the Southeast US from ExxonMobil Corp, the terminals have a combined storage capacity of 3.2 million bbl for gasoline, jet fuel, and diesel.

Title: Disempowered
Source title: Engineer
Authors with affiliations: Lee, A.
Abstract: Utilities giant RWE has ceased investments in the Regenesys energy storage system. Regenysys was designed to act as an 'electricity warehouse', allowing power to be stored when usage is low and released into the network at times of peak demand. It also offered a potential bulwark against unexpected failures of the national power network by piping emergency electricity to local users while supplies are restored. The regenerative cell technology was a breakthrough in energy research and was under development for 15 years at a total cost approaching £100m. RWE's decision has raised wider questions over the commercial viability of energy storage.
Index Keywords: Emergency electricity; Regenerative cell technology; Costs; Decision making; Electric power generation; Electric power systems; Electric utilities; Intellectual property; Investments; Plant shutdowns; Project management; Renewable energy resources; Sales; Strategic planning; Telecommunication services; Electric energy storage

Title: New frontiers of hydrogen energy systems
Source title: Biohydrogen III: Renewable Energy System by Biological Solar Energy Conversion
Affiliations: Yokohama National University, 4-8-15 Inamuragasaki, Kamakura, Kanagawa, 248-0024, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ohta, T., Yokohama National University, 4-8-15 Inamuragasaki, Kamakura, Kanagawa, 248-0024, Japan
Abstract: There is an increasing trend of using non-pollutant energy systems that utilize hydrogen (H2), and such a trend would result in a shortage of H2 supply in the 21st century. Therefore, new frontiers of H2 energy systems will be those hydrogen production systems that use renewable energy resources. This chapter discusses the principles for H2 utilization systems as well as examples of new frontiers in this field. The technologies for H2 storage will play an important in H2 systems. Pressure steel vessels and liquefaction are the traditional ways of storing H2, but pressure steel vessels are heavy and liquefaction is expensive. The chapter reviews some promising storage methods such as the single walled carbon nanotubes (SWNT) method and H2 storage by pressurized carbon polymers (PCP). In each area of H2 energy systems, biohydrogen technologies will play important roles because they are the traditional, effective, and safe conversion and storage methods of solar energy. A promising aspect in H2 production systems using renewable energy sources is bubble fusion, which is introduced in the chapter. © 2004 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Carbon; Energy resources; Hydrogen production; Liquefaction; Single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCN); Solar energy; Yarn; Bubble fusion; Carbon polymers; Energy systems; H2 production; Hydrogen energy systems; Hydrogen production systems; Renewable energy source; Utilization systems; Renewable energy resources

Title: Using gravity to get off the ground
Source title: Machine Design
Authors with affiliations: Mraz, S.J.
Abstract: The development of an aircraft which could climb like a balloon and fly like a glider was discussed. It was observed that the plane won't need any fossil fuel and would possess unlimited range. The high-aspect-ratio wings give the plane a glide ratio in the range of 40:1 which let it glide 40 miles forward for every mile it falls vertically. The turbines were expected to be four times more efficient than bladed horizontal-axis versions. It was stated that the craft would use compressed air to rise and fall in water and would use hydroturbines to extract energy from the water it moves through.

Abstract: The design that could reduce the energy consumption and operating costs for a pneumatic system was described. Modern pneumatic control provides simple, direct, modular links to all standard fieldbus protocols. The low-cost components control individual cylinder pressure and eliminate energy waste. It was shown that the development of decentralized fieldbuses for pneumatic-valve manifolds reduces the distance between valve and cylinders.

Source title: Chemical Week
Authors with affiliations: Wood, A.
Abstract: Scientists from the University of Minnesota have developed a reactor with commercial potential to make hydrogen for fuel cells from ethanol. This reactor, if proven, would be the first to make hydrogen from a renewable resource rather than from hydrocarbons, or methanol. The process has potential for low cost hydrogen generation in fuel cells for small portable applications where liquid fuel storage is essential. The process is competitive at current ethanol prices, and it could use cheaper ethanol that has not been dehydrated for use as a fuel.

The 2003 energy policy initiates conducting surveys of natural gas production and on-system liquefied natural gas storage.

The regenerative braking brake pedal starts with electric vehicle which is carried in hybrid cars. The fundamental building block of Advanced Technology Partial Zero Emission Vehicle (AT-PZEV) is clean gasoline with perfect infrastructure, reasonable cost and catalytic technology to produce zero tailpipe emissions. The combination of electric car with natural gas gives home refueling clean gasoline hybrid car providing fundamental strategy to AT-PZEV.

The company's involvement in the business came after consultants for Malaysia's new international airport in Kuala Lumpur recommended the Pu-insulated products as they save energy and have good appearance. The utilization of the proven melt conditioning (MC) concept in the light of four-reactor/solid-state polycondensation (SSP) process and the two-reactor/ melt to resin/injection molding process is discussed.
