The website, www.netregs.gov.uk, has been developed by the Environment Agency, the Scottish Environment Protection Agency and the Environment and Heritage Service (Northern Ireland) in conjunction with the DTI's Small Business Service. The website includes general guidelines that apply to most businesses and sector specific advices. The guidelines for at least 100 industry setors are expected to be online by March 2004.

Title: Proton awarded SBIR contracts, completes acquisition
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: The award of a Phase 2-Small Business Innovative Research (SBIR) contract by Nasa to Connecticut-based Proton Energy Systems is discussed. The contract was aimed at development of regenerative fuel cell technology for unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV). The demonstration of the possibility of using fuel cells in high altitude airship is also elaborated.

Title: Chaerophyllum bulbosum: A new vegetable interesting for Its root carbohydrate reserves
Source title: Acta Horticulturae
Affiliations: Unité de Recherche en Génie Biologique Appliqué à l'Horticulture, Inst. National d'Horticulture, 2 rue Le Nôtre, 49045 Angers Cedex 01, France; Unité de Rech. sur les Polysaccharides leurs Organisations et Interactions, Inst. National de la Rech. Authors with affiliations: Ayala Garay, O.J., Unité de Recherche en Génie Biologique Appliqué à l'Horticulture, Inst. National d'Horticulture, 2 rue Le Nôtre, 49045 Angers Cedex 01, France; Briard, M., Unité de Recherche en Génie Biologique Appliqué à l'Horticulture, Inst. National d'Horticulture, 2 rue Le Nôtre, 49045 Angers Cedex 01, France; Péron, J.Y., Unité de Recherche en Génie Biologique Appliqué à l'Horticulture, Inst. National d'Horticulture, 2 rue Le Nôtre, 49045 Angers Cedex 01, France; Planchot, V., Unité de Rech. sur les Polysaccharides leurs Organisations et Interactions, Inst. National de la Rech. Agron., Rue de Géraudière BP 71627, 44316 Nantes Cedex 3, France
Abstract: Tuberous-rooted chervil (Chaerophyllum bulbosum L.) belongs to the Apiaceae family. Its root, very rich in carbohydrate reserves, is edible as a vegetable. To bring this species closer to commercialisation with the aim of enhancing the diversification of vegetable crops, a research program was initiated. One of the objectives was to characterise the root reserves. The present paper gives the results of starch and sucrose evaluation. The root starch content at harvest time was very high (37 % dry matter, containing 76 % starch). Because this rate is exceptional for a species cultivated under a temperate climate, C. bulbosum could be a good option for diversification of starch sources under this climate. Results of a physical and chemical characterisation of the starch are discussed in this way. A two-month period of cold storage (4 °C), necessary to reach the consumable stage, resulted in a dramatic change of the carbohydrate composition. After this period sucrose content reached 25 % of root dry matter (DM). Sucrose and starch (35 % of root DM) were the two major components. The combination of these two high rates in a single organ, uncommon for a vegetable, reveals the great interest of tuberous-rooted chervil for the human diet. It is, indeed, a very tasty edible root combining a very rapidly digested sugar with a more slowly digestable one, resulting in long-term availability of energy. In conclusion, as it can be used for both industrial starch production and food production, C. bulbosum offers a good opportunity to diversify horticultural crops.
Author Keywords: Cold-sweetening; Diversification; Starch properties; Tuberous-rooted chervil

Title: Watching the waste line
Source title: Engineer
Authors with affiliations: Knight, H.
Abstract: The UK'S nuclear industry has teamed up with a number of universities to form a national network to investigate new storage and testing technologies for the safer disposal of radioactive waste. Researchers plan to investigate the development of alternative storage materials, improved testing facilities and technologies for the remote monitoring of underground repositories. The UK Atomic Energy Authority has embarked on a multi-million pound 20-year programme to retrieve intermediate level waste from thousands of steel cans which have corroded and collapsed since they were deposited in the 1950s at Harwell in Oxfordshire. Glass, ceramic and cement materials are investigated for their suitability for the long-term storage of the industry's legacy waste.

Title: Hydrogen Could Fuel the Digital Electrical Grid
Source title: Electronic Design
Affiliations: Ctr. Elec./Hydrogen Technol./Syst., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, United States
Authors with affiliations: Turner, J.A., Ctr. Elec./Hydrogen Technol./Syst., National Renewable Energy Laboratory, United States
Abstract: The use of hydrogen for generating electricity and power is discussed. The coupling of Internet communications, solar cells, hydrogen, and fuel cells together make up for an integrated, interconnected digital electrical grid. The supplying of the photovoltaic panels produced hydrogen to the fuel cells generate electricity. The off-peak power purchased from the grid can used to electrolyze water which further produces hydrogen. The hydrogen helps in providing energy storage, fueling of hydrogen-powered fuel-cell vehicles, and aids in merging the electrical grid with the transportation-fueling infrastructure.

Title: Company news: EC approves Statoil's Algeria acquisitions from BP
Source title: Oil and Gas Journal
Abstract: The European Commission has approved Statoil ASA's $750 million agreement to acquire 49% of BP PLC's interest in the Salah dry gas project and 50% of its interest in In Amenas gas condensate field. In other upstream news: Chesapeake Energy Corp announced three transactions in which it will pay a total of $510 million for oil and gas assets in the US Midcontinent, Permian basin, and the onshore Gulf Coast. Taking these pending transactions into account, Chesapeake already increased its 2004 production forecast. The transactions will enable the company to produce 890 million cfe/day compared with its initial 2004 production forecast of 820 million cfe/day. According to Chesapeake, 89% of its anticipated 2004 production is gas with 11% from oil and NGL. In midstream news: Enbridge Energy Partners LP agreed to acquire crude oil pipeline and storage systems from Shell Pipeline Co LP and Shell Oil Products US for $131 million. The assets being acquired serve refineries in the Midcontinent from the Cushing, OK, hub and consist of 615 mi of active crude oil pipelines and 9.5 million bbl of storage capacity. Assets being acquired include the 433 mi, 170,000 bpd crude oil Ozark pipeline that extends from Cushing to Wood River, IL; 58.8% interest in the 135 mi Osage pipeline, and associated 1.2 million bbl storage terminal.

Abstract: It has been proposed that biodiesel liquids be used as a blending stock for middle distillate ground transportation fuels by the military. The U.S. Navy is considering allowing up to 20% biodiesel to be added as a blending stock to petroleum diesel fuels. It is important for operational consideration to look at the many problems this could present. Among the more important considerations are storage stability, filterability, fuel compatibility, oxidative stability, and induced instability reactions.

Institute, 7700 Sandholdt Road, Moss Landing, CA 95039, United States; Haugan, P.M., University of Bergen, Allegaten 70, N-5007 Bergen, Norway; Johannessen, T., University of Bergen, Allegaten 70, N-5007 Bergen, Norway; Bellerby, R.G.J., University of Bergen, Allegaten 70, N-5007 Bergen, Norway
Abstract: The storage of liquid CO2 on the ocean floor, one of the promising measures to mitigate global warming, requires >3500 meters depth for a gravitationally stable storage, breakthrough technology and a reasonable cost to realize, although it has many advantages such as a sequestration term longer than 2000 years. The National Maritime Research Institute (NMRI) conducted several joint field experiments with the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute (MBARI) since 1999 under the auspice of the New Energy and Industrial Technology Development Organization (NEDO), and proposed the improved CO2 Sending Method for Ocean Storage (CUSMOS), in which CO 2 is released into 200 meters depth as a slurry mass (mixture of dry ice and cold liquid CO2). Since 2002, under the NEDO Grant, the NMRI started a new international joint research, OACE, Ocean Abyssal Carbon Experiment, with the MBARI and the University of Bergen (UoB), in order to accumulate the basic data on the long-term stability of stored CO2 and the environmental effects around a storage site.

Abstract: The partial oxidation of methane was studied on Pt/Al2O 3, Pt/Ce-ZrO2 and Pt/Ce-ZrO2/Al 2O3 catalysts. The oxygen transfer capacity of the samples and the degree of coverage of the alumina surface were evaluated by oxygen storage capacity (OSC) and infrared spectroscopy of adsorbed CO2, respectively. Pt/Ce0.75Zr0.25O2 catalyst was more active and stable than Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/Ce 0.75Zr0.25O2/Al2O3 catalysts on partial oxidation of methane. These results were explained by the high oxygen storage/release capacity of Pt/Ce0.75Zr 0.25O2 catalyst, which allowed a removal of carbonaceous deposits from the active sites. Pt/Ce0.75Zr0.25O 2/Al2O3 catalyst also presented a high oxygen exchange capacity. However, this sample deactivated during the reaction. The low degree of coverage of alumina surface obtained for this catalyst avoided the occurrence of the redox mechanism of carbon removal.

Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Natl. Laboratory, Berkeley, United States; BGR Ba. F. Geowissens./Rohstoffe, Hannover, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Rebscher, D., Lawrence Berkeley Natl. Laboratory, Berkeley, United States; May, F., BGR Ba. F. Geowissens./Rohstoffe, Hannover, Germany
Abstract: The CO2-enhanced gas recovery (CO2-EGR) potential of German Rotliegend gas fields within the EC-supported R&D CO2STORE was assessed. The CO2 migration within a layered reservoir resembling conditions of the Altmark fields was simulated generically. The Altmark was chosen because the fields are depleted and the CO2 storage capacity, estimated to be equivalent to the cumulated volume of natural gas produced from the reservoirs, would be enough to take up the amount of CO2 produced during the service lifetime of a modern lignite fired power plant such as the one at Schwarze Pumpe in the Lausitz. The discussion covers introduction; Altmark CO2-EGR simulation (geological model, injection concept, numerical simulator and fluid properties, and results); and perspective. The generic simulations provide preliminary results that may be useful for further simulations of fractured Rotliegend reservoirs. The numerical models indicate that the reservoir pressure can be maintained with CO2 during natural gas production. The produced natural gas quality will remain unaffected by CO2 injection for several years. Permeable sandstone layers facilitate the lateral breakthrough of CO2 from injection to production wells. The retardation of this CO2 breakthrough to optimize EGR is a reservoir engineering challenge. Despite efforts to change the energy supply to renewable sources, fossil fuels will be necessary for a sustained period to meet the German energy demand. Because of the forthcoming trading in emissions there is growing interest in underground storage options for CO2 in Europe now. The storage capacity for CO2 in gas fields is an estimated 2.5 billion ton. This would suffice to take up 10% of the present industrial emissions in the next 50 yr. Thus, gas fields could contribute significantly to reduce CO2 emissions in Germany. To optimize the benefits of EGR and CO2 storage, two injection strategies may be applied consecutively. For example, CO2 pattern flooding can be used to increase gas production until CO2 breakthrough deteriorates the produced natural gas quality, and CO2 can be injected through few horizontal wells that are highly injectable after sealing surplus production and injection wells.

Authors: Liu H., Liu B., Yuan D.
Title: Dynamic characteristics analysis of flexible mechanism using three parameters damping model
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Biennial Conference on  Engineering Systems Design and Analysis, ESDA 2004
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Xi'an University of Technology, Xi'an 710048, China
Authors with affiliations: Liu, H., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Xi'an University of Technology, Xi'an 710048, China; Liu, B., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Xi'an University of Technology, Xi'an 710048, China; Yuan, D., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Xi'an University of Technology, Xi'an 710048, China
Abstract: In this paper, a practical structural damping model for the dynamic analysis of damping alloy is presented. The differential equations of the beam element with three parameters representing stiffness and damping characteristics are deduced through the three parameters constitution and the virtual work principle. By means of the Kineto-Elastodynamic theory, the established element dynamic equations are assembled into the system dynamic equations of flexible linkage mechanism. In order to solve the high order differential equations with time-varying coefficients, a closed form numerical algorithm is constructed. Lastly, an example of a four-bar elastic linkage mechanism is given to show the effectiveness of the proposed method in studying dynamic characteristics of structure containing damping alloy components.
Author Keywords: Damping alloy; Flexible linkage mechanism; State space method; Three parameters
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Elastic moduli; Electrodynamics; Laplace transforms; Mathematical models; Parameter estimation; State space methods; Structural design; Vibration control; Viscoelasticity; Damping alloys; Energy storage module; Flexible linkage; Laplace transformation; Structure damping; Damping

Authors: Cavallo E., Filaretov V.F., Michelini R.C., Ukymets D.A.
Title: Path guidance and attitude control of a vectored thruster AUV
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Biennial Conference on  Engineering Systems Design and Analysis, ESDA 2004
Affiliations: Università di Genova, DIMEC, 16145 Genova, Italy; Inst. for Automat. and Contr. Proc., 10 Pushkinskaya Str., Vladivostok, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Cavallo, E., Università di Genova, DIMEC, 16145 Genova, Italy; Filaretov, V.F., Inst. for Automat. and Contr. Proc., 10 Pushkinskaya Str., Vladivostok, Russian Federation; Michelini, R.C., Università di Genova, DIMEC, 16145 Genova, Italy; Ukymets, D.A., Inst. for Automat. and Contr. Proc., 10 Pushkinskaya Str., Vladivostok, Russian Federation
Abstract: The study deals with developing small and cheap autonomous underwater vehicles, AUV, entrusted of extended manoeuvrability for surveying and docking missions, with accurate of path tracking and attitude keeping, capable of travelling at low speed, down to proper depth, to carry out the given tasks with proper autonomy and without relevant impact on the surroundings. The to day available AUVs, generally, make use of several propellers, distributed around the body, to achieve the desired mobility with full attitude control. The solution requires the closure of multiple loops between sensors and actuators, highly cross-coupled and dependent on dynamics non-linearity and marine surroundings disturbances. The prospected solution considers a properly shaped vehicle, to grant minimal drag for lowering power consumption. A single rear propeller has in charge propulsion and manoeuvring. The propeller can be oriented around two axes, say, pitch (for heaving) and yaw (for veering); the screw (hydrodynamic) torque is balanced by variable tilt fins, either, by counter-rotating vanes. A three degrees of freedom parallel kinematics robotic wrist provides joint path-and-attitude selection and twist compensation, by driving the propeller assembly through three independent actuations. The build-up makes use of a duct-restricted propeller, with externally driven pitch-and-yaw bending and twist to counter-act the screw torque by reactive fins, either, continuous rotation. The balancing wile assures best performance, in the reactive mode, during steady surveying missions, while the local hover or docking is better accomplished by active counter-rotation. The paper discusses the basic design steps by example manoeuvres carried with virtual checks on a digital mock-up.
Index Keywords: Bending (deformation); Data acquisition; Energy utilization; Hydrodynamics; Motion planning; Oceanography; Propellers; Torque; Tracking (position); Actuations; Attitude control; Manoeuvrability; Power storage; Remotely operated vehicles

Authors: Feola M., Martini F., Ubertini S.
Title: Evaluating the performances of advanced powertrains
Source title: Proceedings of the 7th Biennial Conference on  Engineering Systems Design and Analysis, ESDA 2004
Affiliations: University of Rome Tor Vergata, Via del Politecnico, 1, 00133 Roma, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Feola, M., University of Rome Tor Vergata, Via del Politecnico, 1, 00133 Roma, Italy; Martini, F., University of Rome Tor Vergata, Via del Politecnico, 1, 00133 Roma, Italy; Ubertini, S., University of Rome Tor Vergata, Via del Politecnico, 1, 00133 Roma, Italy
Abstract: Over the last few decades a tremendous effort has been made to reduce road vehicles engines contribution to air pollution and fuel consumption. Due to the more stringent limits imposed by governments, various manufacturers started working in the incorporation of alternative powertrain configurations, such as pure electric vehicles (EV), hybrid electric vehicles (HEV) and fuel cell vehicles (FCV), in the automotive consumer market. In order to appreciate the advantages and disadvantages of these new vehicles over conventional vehicles a comparison must be performed in terms of efficiency and pollutant emissions. However, hybrid vehicles comprise many components with at least two different energy conversion devices (i.e. internal combustion engine and electric machine) drawing energy from at least two different energy storage devices (i.e. fuel tank and battery). In recent times, many hybrid propulsion system configurations have emerged and many others can be imagined comprising multiple reversible and irreversible energy paths. Therefore, considering that in a hybrid vehicle at least two different forms of energy (i.e. fuel chemical energy and electricity) are consumed, fuel consumption alone is no more sufficient to give a measure of the effectiveness of a hybrid propulsion system. This paper presents a first attempt to give a general mathematical form of the traction energy, the global efficiency and the specific fuel consumption of a hybrid electric vehicle that recovers as particular cases the thermal vehicle and the series hybrid electric vehicle. To evaluate the efficiency of the generic propulsion system the complete process from fuel energy and electricity to power available at the wheels is considered. The introduced concept of equivalent fuel consumption can be the basis for the comparison between road vehicles whatever the powertrain is pure thermal or hybrid. In order to get a better understanding of the mathematical analysis and its potential effectiveness some numerical simulations of hybrid vehicles virtual prototypes are performed through a suitable simulation model. The aim of the present analysis is to provide an instrument that allows a quick evaluation of the performances of hybrid electric vehicles.
Index Keywords: Combustion; Computer simulation; Diesel engines; Electric traction; Gasoline; Torque; Gasoline thermal engines; Hybrid electric vehicles (HEV); Hybrid propulsion systems; Electric vehicles

Title: Design of a fuzzy model-based controller for a drum boiler-turbine system
Source title: Applied Computational Intelligence - Proceedings of the 6th International FLINS Conference
Affiliations: Lab. d'Automatique Appliquée, F.H.C., Univ. de Boumerdés, 35000 Boumerdès, Algeria
Authors with affiliations: Habbi, A., Lab. d'Automatique Appliquée, F.H.C., Univ. de Boumerdés, 35000 Boumerdès, Algeria; Zelmat, M., Lab. d'Automatique Appliquée, F.H.C., Univ. de Boumerdés, 35000 Boumerdès, Algeria
Abstract: This paper addresses the design of a fuzzy control system for a drum boiler-turbine-generator unit. In the design procedure, a dynamic fuzzy augmented system is suggested for the nonlinear boiler-turbine plant to deal with its non-minimum phase behavior. The fuzzy control system is synthesized from a local concept viewpoint on the issue of the optimal control theory. The good performance of the designed fuzzy control system is shown by simulations in various conditions.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Control equipment; Electric energy storage; Materials balance; Optimal control systems; Perturbation techniques; Power generation; Power plants; Steam turbines; Turbogenerators; Water levels; Cycle power plants; Drum boiler-turbine generators (BTG); Fuzzy control systems; Thermal energy; Fuzzy control

Title: From self-organization to evolution of RNA molecules: The origin of biological information
Source title: Solid State Phenomena
Affiliations: Inst. Theor. Chem./Molec. S., Universität Wien, Währingerstraße 17, A-1090 Wien, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Schuster, P., Inst. Theor. Chem./Molec. S., Universität Wien, Währingerstraße 17, A-1090 Wien, Austria
Abstract: Autocatalytic chemical reactions may lead to spatio-temporal patterns if processed under non-equilibrium conditions. The patterns disappear when the conditions change and information stored in these non-equilibrium structures is lost since precise reconstructions are impossible. Replication of molecules, in particular of polynucleotides RNA or DNA, is an autocatalytic process too. The storage of information in polynucleotide sequences, however, allows for reconstruction of the molecules under suitable conditions. Conservation of information in polymer sequences constitutes the basic difference between chemical and biological self-organization. Evolution of RNA molecules is considered as pattern formation in sequence space, which manifests itself as another pattern in the space of minimum-free-energy structures. In addition, optimization of RNA structures and properties is visualized as an evolutionary trial-and-error process. This process can be interpreted as a simple form of learning at the level of ensembles or populations of molecules. Evolutionary optimization of RNA molecules occurs in steps: Short adaptive periods are interrupted by long epochs of quasi-stationarity during which the mean replication rate of the populations is essentially constant. Understanding of evolution is largely facilitated through consideration of sequence-structure relation as a many-to-one or non-invertible mapping from sequence space into structure space. Neutrality of sequences with respect to structure formation is highly relevant for evolutionary optimization on rugged fitness landscapes.
Author Keywords: Evolution; Information; Learning; Neutral networks; Optimization; Quasispecies; RNA
Index Keywords: Chemical reactions; Computer simulation; Concentration (process); Free energy; Kinetic theory; Mathematical models; Molecular biology; Mutagenesis; Neural networks; Optimization; Evolution; Flow reactors; Quasispecies; Self-organization systems; RNA

Title: A new passivity property of linear RLC circuits with application to power shaping stabilization
Source title: Proceedings of the American Control Conference
Affiliations: Lab. des Signaux et Systèmes, Supelec, Plateau du Moulon, 91192, Gif-sur-Yvette, cedex, France
Authors with affiliations: García-Canseco, E., Lab. des Signaux et Systèmes, Supelec, Plateau du Moulon, 91192, Gif-sur-Yvette, cedex, France; Ortega, R., Lab. des Signaux et Systèmes, Supelec, Plateau du Moulon, 91192, Gif-sur-Yvette, cedex, France
Abstract: In this paper we characterize the linear RLC networks for which passivity is preserved even if we take as port variables (vs,-d/dt i s) and/or (d/dt vs, is) instead of the classical variables (vs, is) representing the external port voltage and current, respectively. This characterization is given in terms of an order relationship between the average electric and magnetic energies stored in the circuit. We apply this result to the problem of power shaping stabilization, a methodology recently proposed as an alternative to the more standard energy-shaping technique.
Author Keywords: Passivity; Passivity-based control; RLC circuits; Stabilization
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Circuit theory; Closed loop control systems; Control theory; Electric energy storage; Large scale systems; Linear systems; Parameter estimation; Problem solving; Stabilization; Electromagnetic coupling; Passivity; Passivity-based control; RLC circuits; Networks (circuits)

Authors: Voršič J., Hanžič A., Horvat M., Škerbinek G.
Title: Possibilities of fulfilment the kyoto targets with increased share of dispersed generation in the energy system
Source title: Proceedings of the Mediterranean Electrotechnical Conference - MELECON
Affiliations: Univerza v Mariboru, Fakulteta za Elektrotehniko, Maribor, Slovenia; Elektro Maribor, Maribor, Slovenia; Ener. Agy. of the Rep. of Slovenia, Maribor, Slovenia
Authors with affiliations: Voršič, J., Univerza v Mariboru, Fakulteta za Elektrotehniko, Maribor, Slovenia; Hanžič, A., Univerza v Mariboru, Fakulteta za Elektrotehniko, Maribor, Slovenia; Horvat, M., Elektro Maribor, Maribor, Slovenia; Škerbinek, G., Ener. Agy. of the Rep. of Slovenia, Maribor, Slovenia
Abstract: Slovenia is 10-times poorer with conventional energy sources than other countries of the world. Only exploitation of coal in the regions of Velenje and Zasavje is economically justifiable. Unfortunately, coal in these two regions is environmentally problematic, and reserves are sufficient only for about 40 years of exploitation. Reserves of uranium are bigger, but their exploitation is environmentally questionable and economically not viable. Slovenia has, because of its pre-Alpine geographical location, rather high amount of annual precipitation, which gives possibilities for exploitation of hydropower potential, solar energy and biomass. EU countries have ratified the Kyoto Protocol, in which they took over obligation to reduce greenhouse gas emissions for 8 % in the commitment period 2008-2012. In order to fulfil the Kyoto targets it will be necessary to restructure the sectors of energy supply, industry and transport. The costs of emission reduction should not exceed the purpose of investment into cleaner environment and exploitation of additional energy. The most important options for fulfilment of these commitments are exploitation of renewables and simultaneous production of heat and electricity (CHP). Nevertheless, before construction of power plants for electricity production from renewables or CHP plants, it is necessary to investigate their economic justifiability and impact on the environment. In this process it is necessary not to forget the process of electricity market opening, which reached the Western Europe at the end of last millennium, and is now irrepressibly spreading towards the east and is increasingly becoming (cruel!) reality in our country.
Index Keywords: Coal; Electric energy storage; Electric potential; Electric power plants; Embedded systems; Environmental impact; Greenhouse effect; Investments; Energy supply; Greenhouse gases (GHG); Kyoto targets; Electrical engineering

Title: Time-dependent compositional and morphology change of YBa 2Cu3O7-x semisolid phase
Source title: Key Engineering Materials
Affiliations: University of Missouri-Rolla, Ceramic Engineering Department, Rolla, MO 65401, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jongprateep, O., University of Missouri-Rolla, Ceramic Engineering Department, Rolla, MO 65401, United States; Dogan, F., University of Missouri-Rolla, Ceramic Engineering Department, Rolla, MO 65401, United States
Abstract: Microstructural development of platinum doped YBa2Cu 3O7-x (Y123) semisolid melt, such as the loss of the liquid phase, morphology and size of Y2BaCuO5 (Y211) particles, has been studied using samples held for different duration time at 1050°C and quenched to the room temperature. Depletion of the liquid phase decreased as a function of the holding time while the width of acicular Y211 particles in the melt increased. Time dependent liquid loss from the semisolid melt was attributed to the capillary forces which were affected by the size of Y211 particles dispersed in the liquid phase. These observations may have important implications for the growth of large superconducting Y123 melt textured single crystals and their microstructural control.
Author Keywords: Liquid phase; Oxide superconductors; Semisolid melt; Y2BaCuO5; YBa2Cu 3O7-x
Index Keywords: Doping (additives); Energy storage; Melting; Microstructure; Morphology; Oxide superconductors; Phase composition; Reaction kinetics; Single crystals; Liquid phases; Semisolid melts; Y2BaCuO5; YBa2Cu3O7-x; Yttrium barium copper oxides

Authors: Park W.-S., Na W.-W., Kim S.-K., Choi Y.-M.
Title: Application of nondestructive testing technique for safeguards inspection
Source title: Key Engineering Materials
Affiliations: Technol. Center for Nuclear Control, Korea Atom. Ener. Research Institute, Dukjin-dong 150, Yusong-gu, Daejeon 305-354, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Park, W.-S., Technol. Center for Nuclear Control, Korea Atom. Ener. Research Institute, Dukjin-dong 150, Yusong-gu, Daejeon 305-354, South Korea; Na, W.-W., Technol. Center for Nuclear Control, Korea Atom. Ener. Research Institute, Dukjin-dong 150, Yusong-gu, Daejeon 305-354, South Korea; Kim, S.-K., Technol. Center for Nuclear Control, Korea Atom. Ener. Research Institute, Dukjin-dong 150, Yusong-gu, Daejeon 305-354, South Korea; Choi, Y.-M., Technol. Center for Nuclear Control, Korea Atom. Ener. Research Institute, Dukjin-dong 150, Yusong-gu, Daejeon 305-354, South Korea
Abstract: In safeguards inspection, various nondestructive test techniques are used. For a long time, nondestructive assay based on radiation measurement such as gamma and neutron measurement have been used for nuclear material verification. However, due to physical access and radiological environment restrictions in verifying nuclear material, other nondestructive testing techniques are used for safeguards inspection purposes. At Wolsong nuclear power plants, spent nuclear fuel bundles are stored at spent fuel storage bay. Typically, tens of thousands of spent nuclear fuel bundles are densely stored under water. For safeguards inspection, those bundles are item counted, identified by serial numbers, and verified by nondestructive assay. In doing these activities, underwater camera and gamma radiation detectors are being used. However, due to narrow space between bundles and high radiation area, some of bundles are inaccessible. Recently, to overcome those restriction, ultrasonic and microwave techniques are introduced. Although laboratory test was successful, field test at Wolsong nuclear power plants showed that further development is necessary.
Author Keywords: CANDU Reactor Inspection Equipment; NDT for Safeguards; Safeguards Inspection Equipment
Index Keywords: Detectors; Fuel storage; Gamma rays; Nuclear energy; Nuclear materials safeguards; Reactor refueling; Canada Deuterium Uranium (CANDU) Reactor Inspection Equipment; International Atomic Energy Agnecy (IAEA); NDT for Safeguards; Safeguards Inspection Equipment; Nondestructive examination

Title: Ultrasonic monitoring technique for icing and flow in a duct
Source title: Key Engineering Materials
Affiliations: School of Mechanical Engineering, Pusan National University, Busan, South Korea; Sch. of Automot. and Mech. Eng., Inje University, Kimhae, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Cho, Y., School of Mechanical Engineering, Pusan National University, Busan, South Korea; Kim, M., Sch. of Automot. and Mech. Eng., Inje University, Kimhae, South Korea
Abstract: Transient freezing of laminar water flow in a square duct was investigated experimentally while varying the temperature and flow rate of the water and the temperature of the brine. In addition, the use of ultrasonic waves to monitor the freezing and flow in the duct was explored. There was excellent agreement between the ultrasonic data and data obtained using a conventional flow measurement technique in determining the thickness of the ice layer and flow velocity. Ultrasonic waves can be used to measure the growth of an ice layer and flow velocity in a duct.
Author Keywords: Flow rate; Freezing; Phase change; Transducer; Ultrasonic wave
Index Keywords: Brines; Doppler effect; Ducts; Freezing; Ice; Solidification; Ultrasonic waves; Water; Cold energy storage; Copper plates; Flow rate; Transient-time method; Ultrasonic testing

Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners...
Source title: Petroleum Economist
Abstract: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners has agreed to acquire seven refined petroleum products terminals in the southeast from ExxonMobil. The terminals, in Mississippi, Tennessee, North Carolina, and Virginia, have a combined storage capacity of ∼ 3.2 million bbl for gasoline, jet fuel, and diesel. All seven terminals are connected to the Plantation Pipe Line system, which is 51% owned by Kinder Morgan.

Title: News: SiGEN takes Scotland into hydrogen era
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: siGEN has received a $335,000 contract from the Unst Partnership in the Shetland Isles for the installation of a renewable energy, hydrogen production, and fuel cell project on the UK's most northerly populated island. The Unst Partnership developed the PURE (Promoting Unst Renewable Energy) project with assistance and technical support from siGEN. The project will install two wind turbines, an electrolyzer, hydrogen storage facilities, and a 5 kwe fuel cell system into the Hagdale Business Park on Unst. siGEN will also act as a host company for a knowledge transfer program with a Scottish university. The PURE project aims to show how hydrocarbons could be progressively displaced by locally produced hydrogen from local renewable energy sources. Another goal of the project is to break energy dependence on international oil markets, while offering employment opportunities that may help stem the loss of young people from remote communities.

Title: Projects: DEGT expands gas storage facility
Source title: Pipeline and Gas Journal
Abstract: Duke Energy Gas Transmission (DEGT) is expanding by 8 bcf the natural gas storage capacity at its Market Hub Partners' (MHP) Egan facility in Acadia Parish, LA. DEGT and MHP are increasing the working gas storage capacity at Egan from 16 to 24 bcf. By mid-to-late 2006, it is projected that Egan's two existing 8 bcf caverns will be joined by a third like-sized cavern. MHP drilled the pilot hole into the Egan-area underground salt dome formation in 2004 as part of the expansion. DEGT and MHP are utilizing Solution Mining Under Gas (SMUG) technology to quickly bring additional capacity to the marketplace without interruption of service. The SMUG technique uses specially designed wellheads and leaching equipment to flush salt from the caverns. The components can switch from injecting fresh water and withdrawing the salt-concentrated brine to injecting and withdrawing natural gas.

Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Sempra Energy Global Enterprises...
Source title: Petroleum Economist
Abstract: Sempra Energy Global Enterprises plans to construct and operate the Pine Prairie Energy Center gas-storage facility in Evangeline Parish, LA. The facility, which should begin operating by the fourth quarter of 2005, will be near Henry Hub, the nation's largest gas-trading center. Pine Prairie will have three salt caverns with a total working capacity of 24 bcf of natural gas, enabling maximum injections of 1.2 bcf/day and maximum withdrawals of 2.4 bcf/day.

Title: News: Proton awarded SBIR contracts, completes acquisition
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: Proton Energy Systems has been awarded a Phase 2 Small Business Innovative research (SBIR) contract by NASA to develop regenerative fuel cell technology for unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV), as well as a SBIR Phase 1 contract from the US Army Missile Defense Agency. The firm has also completed its previously announced acquisition of Northern Power Systems. The objective of the NASA Phase 2 contract is to demonstrate the feasibility of producing and operating lightweight unitized regenerative fuel cell hardware for aerospace applications. Proton's regenerative PEM fuel cell design features its commercial hydrogen generator, which is capable of generating its own hydrogen at pressure and converting the stored hydrogen to electric power when needed. NASA's ultimate design objective, based on the Phase 2 work, is to fill a need for very high-energy-density energy storage systems for UAV for terrestrial observation and earth science.

Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Duke Energy Gas Transmission plans to...
Source title: Petroleum Economist
Abstract: Duke Energy Gas Transmission plans to expand the gas storage capacity of its Market Hub Partners' Egan facility by 8 bcf. The facility is in Acadia Parish, LA.

Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Valero Energy has paid...
Source title: Petroleum Economist
Abstract: Valero Energy has paid $2.8 billion in cash, equity, and assumed debt for a pipeline and terminal network from Kaneb. The purchase doubles the size of Valero, making it the largest US terminal operator, with 85 million bbl of storage at 101 locations.

Title: Projects: NUI-Duke energy hold open season
Source title: Pipeline and Gas Journal
Abstract: NUI Corp and Duke Energy's interstate natural gas transmission unit held a month-long open season for shippers interested in reserving firm gas storage capacity at the company's facility in Saltville, VA. On offer is 1 bcf of capacity. As the only such facility in the mid-Atlantic region, it is strategically positioned on Duke Energy Gas Transmission's East Tennessee Natural Gas interstate pipeline system and its completed Patriot extension. NUI and DEGT are developing a projected 12 bcf of natural gas storage capacity at Saltville in two phases. The facility is managed by Virginia Gas Pipeline Co.

Title: News in brief: North America: United States: McMoRan Exploration subsidiary...
Source title: Petroleum Economist
Abstract: Freeport-McMoRan Energy plans to develop a $440 million LNG receiving terminal at its Main Pass energy hub, about 37 mi east of Venice, LA, in the Gulf of Mexico. The proposed terminal would be able to receive and process 1 bcf/day of LNG and is being designed to accommodate future expansions. Aggregate peak deliverability form the proposed terminal, including deliveries from storage, would total 2.5 bcf/day.

Title: Australia: Howard government backs geosequestration
Source title: Chemical Engineer
Abstract: The Howard government's energy statement focuses on research into geosequestration but critics claim the Australian government has failed to adequately support the development of clean energy solutions. The government will provide $(Aust)500 million starting in 2006 for industry-led projects to lower Australia's greenhouse emissions. The funding will support technologies that have the potential to reduce greenhouse emissions by ≥ 2% and be commercially available between 2020 and 2030. The energy statement cited coal-fired electricity generation with geosequestration, the storage of CO2 in geological formation, as a key technology to be developed. Peter Cook, CEO of Cooperative Research Center for Greenhouse Gas Technologies, welcomed the government's interest in geosequestration. The process involves the capture, separation, transport, and injection of CO2 into geological structures at depths of ≥ 800 m. The government statement provides $(Aust)100 million for the development of renewable technologies and $(Aust)75 million to support "solar cities" trials.

Title: Analysis: Wind power bodymakes waves
Source title: Chemical Engineer
Abstract: British Wind Energy Association was in the South West to mark the start of a long campaign to champion the emerging wave and tidal power sector, after 25 yr helping to bring wind farms to the UK countryside. Based on comparable European installations, the investment needed to reach the UK government's 10% target of electric power by 2010 is likely to be £20-23 billion. With regard to lifecycle terms, wind generators to not reduce the CO2 to any significant degree when the emissions from the complete power supply system are considered. The government is advised to work on other technological means, e.g., CO2 capture with storage and fuel cell application, to promote improvements in energy efficiency and encourage robust methods of saving energy with guaranteed CO2 reduction. However, years of distortion and non-market aligned subsidies have severely curtailed the country's renewable potential.

Title: News in brief: Western Europe: Norway: A plan for development...
Source title: Petroleum Economist
Abstract: A plan for development and operation (PDO) for the Alvheim field, west of Heimdal, was submitted to Norway's petroleum and energy ministry by Marathon, ConocoPhillips, and Lundin. The companies will use a floating production, storage, and offloading vessel to process crude from five subsea drilling centers. Production will start in early 2007 with over 70,000 bpd flowing at peak, from reserves of 180 million boe. The Alvheim group has reached an agreement to tie-in the Hydro-operated Klegg discovery, subject to PDO approval, raising reserves to be tapped by the development to 200-250 million boe.

Title: DTE Energy plans Michigan hydrogen technology park
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: DTE Energy of Michigan is planning to build a multi-use hydrogen energy pilot project in nearby Southfield. The project will create hydrogen from regular water, for use in onsite Plug Power PEM fuel cell power generators and to refuel FCV. DTE Energy is partnering with the DOE, the state of Michigan and the city of Southfield to develop, build and operate the project, which will also include onsite hydrogen production using renewable biomass and solar power, hydrogen storage, and distribution. The $3 million, 5-yr pilot project will result in a system capable of delivering 100 Mw hr/yr of electricity, enough to power power a small office park or about 20 homes, and enough compressed hydrogen to fuel three vehicles/day.

Title: Projects: Cheniere energy selects LNG tank subcontractor
Source title: Pipeline and Gas Journal
Abstract: Cheniere Energy Inc has selected Mitsubishi Heavy Industries and Matrix Service Co as the LNG tank subcontractor for its Sabine Pass and Corpus Christi LNG receiving terminals. The work will entail engineering and construction of three 160,000 ton single containment storage tanks at each site. Construction of the LNG receiving terminals is expected to start in the first quarter of 2005, subject to receipt of construction permits by the end of 2004. Each plant is designed to have an initial natural gas processing capacity of 2.6 bcf/day.

Title: Leader: Running on empty
Source title: Petroleum Economist
Abstract: According to the International Energy Agency (IEA), rising demand from storage companies in areas of rapidly growing oil consumption has added to the momentum of oil-demand growth. OPEC's spin is that the world is well supplied with oil and that US refiners have fine-tuned their operations over the years to the point that higher oil inventories are no longer necessary. There is a body of evidence to show that OPEC is true to its word in releasing new volumes to the market in light of the May 2004 price spike and the cartel's subsequent decision to sanction a 2 million bpd quota increase. The organization's crude supply averaged 28.6 million bpd in June 2004, according to IEA, an increase of 0.635 million bpd from May, despite a 325,000 bpd reduction from Iraq because of the sabotage of oil facilities. Robert Esser, a director of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, predicted that global oil production will expand by 20 million bpd during the 2004-2010 period, compared with an increase of 10 million bpd for 1995-2003. If much of that additional supply is directed at the growing Asian economies, then the steady build-up of storage capacity could help re-establish a supply/demand equilibrium, which should encourage more stable (and lower) global crude prices. That is potentially a win-win scenario for producers and consumers.

Title: News: Canadian government boosts funding for Stuart energy station
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: Stuart Energy Systems was awarded an additional $1.07 million in Canadian government funding to expand the scope of its Hydrogen Energy Station (HES) development project. The funding will support the company's development of hydrogen backup power generators and other hydrogen-related systems. As part of the HES project, Stuart Energy has developed technology that generated clean hydrogen for vehicle fueling. The latest investment, through Technology Partnerships Canada, was part of a project amendment that will allow Stuart Energy to adapt this hydrogen generation technology for use in hydrogen back-up power generators and hydrogen-based storage systems utilizing renewable energy sources like wind and solar power. The HESfp, with both fueling and power capabilities, comprises five modules, i.e. water electrolysis-based hydrogen generation, compression, high-pressure storage, hydrogen fuel dispensing, and power generation.

Title: News in brief: North America: United States: El Paso is slashing...
Source title: Petroleum Economist
Abstract: El Paso is slashing its stake in Enterprise Products Partners from 50 to 9.9% for $370 million in cash as part of its program to dispose of assets and raise capital. The asset sell-off has now reached $3.4 billion, $0.5 billion short of the upper limit target by the end of 2005. Enterprise in partnership with GulfTerra Energy will operate in several in several North American basins, with 30,000 mi of pipeline, gas and liquids processing plants, 23 bcf of gas storage capacity, and six offshore hub platforms in the Gulf of Mexico.

Title: News in brief: Asia and Australasia: Australia: Woodside Energy is to...
Source title: Petroleum Economist
Abstract: Woodside Energy will invest $1.14 billion in the development of the 125 million bbl Enfield oilfield in the WA-271-P permit offshore Western Australia. First oil is expected by fourth quarter 2006, with initial output of 100,000 bpd. Nearby discoveries, e.g., Laverda, will be tied back to Enfield to raise output. The development will include five production wells, which will produce to a floating production, storage and offshore facility (FPSO) moored in 400 m of water, six water-injection wells and two gas-injection wells to return produced gas not needed for fuel to the reservoir. Storage capacity of the FPSO will be 0.9 million bbl, which will be discharged to trading tankers with a capacity of ∼ 0.55 million bbl. Woodside holds 100% of the permit and is the operator.

Title: Evaluation of pulsed plasma thruster micropulsing
Source title: 40th AIAA/ASME/SAE/ASEE Joint Propulsion Conference and Exhibit
Affiliations: QSS Group, Inc., NASA Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; MS: 301-3, 21000 Brookpark Road, United States
Authors with affiliations: Arrington, L., QSS Group, Inc., NASA Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States, MS: 301-3, 21000 Brookpark Road, United States
Abstract: This paper evaluates the concept of pulsed plasma thruster (PPT) micropulsing. Micropulsing was a premise behind a power processing unit (PPU) and an energy storage unit (ESU) design that for certain mission profiles, it was advantageous to operate a PPT at lower energy but higher frequency rather than at a higher energy but lower frequency. This premise allows for reductions in the ESU volume and mass without paying a penalty in thrust. To complete the evaluation, an independent spark plug initiation unit, a high voltage power supply and a variety of mica foil capacitors at 2.6, 5, 10 and 20 μF were used to conduct a series of tests on a single PPT to map performance levels of thrust, impulse bit, efficiency and specific impulse over a comparable power range. Testing at NASA Glenn Research Center was conducted with breadboard PPT hardware. The test results showed that operating in the lower energy ESU micropulsing mode produced similar thrust levels to a higher energy ESU operating at high power level. Further testing however showed a reduction in specific impulse and efficiency when the smaller capacitances were used at the highest power levels. This would require more fuel mass for a mission that was predominately high power, potentially negating the ESU mass savings. Therefore, micropulsing is advantageous where most of a mission profile occurs at low power, but retains the ability to conduct high thrust maneuvers when necessary. © 2004 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Impulse testing; Mica; NASA; Plasma devices; Propulsion; Energy storage unit; High power level; High voltage power supply; Higher frequencies; Lower frequencies; Performance level; Power processing units; Specific impulse; Pulsed plasma thrusters

Authors: Fales R., Lee C.-K.C., Savio F.
Title: An innovative floating LNG vessel
Source title: SNAME 14th Offshore Symposium
Affiliations: ABB Lummus Global - Floating Production Systems, Houston, TX, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fales, R., ABB Lummus Global - Floating Production Systems, Houston, TX, United States; Lee, C.-K.C., ABB Lummus Global - Floating Production Systems, Houston, TX, United States; Savio, F., ABB Lummus Global - Floating Production Systems, Houston, TX, United States
Abstract: Large quantities of gas are associated with the development of offshore oil and gas fields and companies are faced with many challenges in handling these gas reserves. In deepwater remote areas there is generally no existing infrastructure to allow the gas to be sent to the market and many host countries are requiring companies not to flare gas. Some countries have built large facilities to turn the gas into LNG; for example, Nigeria, Algeria, Indonesia and Qatar, and these facilities have been based on large base loads. Typical LNG train sizes have been in the range of 3.0 million tonnes a year with a minimum entry-level production rate being 0.5 BCF/Day or higher. This threshold is too high for offshore oil fields with a more typical peak production of 100,000 to 300,000 BPD of oil and up to 250 MMSCFD of produced gas. A concept has been developed for the exploitation of associated and stranded gas resources using a Floating LNG facility that can be moored in deepwater next to an oil production facility. The system is based on a patented turbo expander process that was developed by ABB Randall Gas Technology to liquefy natural gas streams and is called NicheLNGSM. The system uses no intermediate liquids for cooling and has a very low equipment count. This Floating LNG system is based on the storage of product in a vessel similar to a typical LNG tanker with the NicheLNG process located on the deck. Gas streams can be either preconditioned, i.e., NGLs removed, dehydrated, and contaminants removed or these operations can be done on the Floating LNG. This Floating LNG system is viable for development of stranded gas in the 0.5 to 3.0 TCF range with production rates from 75 to 300 MMSCFD. This paper will detail the work done by ABB in the development of the Floating NicheLNG vessel. The principle focus of the paper will be on the marine aspects of this development including selection of containment system, mooring and offloading concepts. Global performance analysis was used to establish criteria for the topside design and to determine loadings for off-take. A description of the liquefaction process is included. The results of the risk assessment carried out covering the overall scheme will be included. © 2004 SNAME 14th Offshore Symposium. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Commerce; Energy resources; Gas industry; Gases; Liquefied natural gas; Natural gasoline plants; Offshore gas fields; Offshore oil fields; Offshore oil well production; Oil field development; Patents and inventions; Petroleum industry; Proven reserves; Risk assessment; Risk management; Containment systems; Gas technologies; Global performance; Host countries; Level productions; Liquefaction process; Offshore oil and gas fields; Production rates; Floating liquefied natural gas

Authors: Kell J., Tyrer J., Higginson R., Thomson R., Jones J., Noden S.
Title: Computer generated holographic optics used in laser powder fusion
Source title: ICALEO 2004 - 23rd International Congress on Applications of Laser and Electro-Optics, Congress Proceedings
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering, Loughborough University, Leics, LE11 3TU, United Kingdom; Institute of Polymer and Materials Technology, Loughborough University, Leics, LE11 3TU, United Kingdom; Laser Optical Engineering, PO Box 6321, Loughborough, LE11 3XZ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Kell, J., Mechanical Engineering, Loughborough University, Leics, LE11 3TU, United Kingdom; Tyrer, J., Mechanical Engineering, Loughborough University, Leics, LE11 3TU, United Kingdom; Higginson, R., Institute of Polymer and Materials Technology, Loughborough University, Leics, LE11 3TU, United Kingdom; Thomson, R., Institute of Polymer and Materials Technology, Loughborough University, Leics, LE11 3TU, United Kingdom; Jones, J., Laser Optical Engineering, PO Box 6321, Loughborough, LE11 3XZ, United Kingdom; Noden, S., Laser Optical Engineering, PO Box 6321, Loughborough, LE11 3XZ, United Kingdom
Abstract: Conventional laser cladding systems use a focussing nozzle to direct the beam to the work piece, and by using either blown or pre placed powder, they are able to fuse the powder to the substrate. The shortfall of this process is that, once sectioned, a parabolic transverse profile is seen. This is due to the Gaussian irradiance distribution of the beam and no conventional optics can remedy the problem. Diffractive optical elements, however, can be designed for each process. Models of thermal conduction in the powder and the substrate can be utilised to produce a diffractive optical element specific to this operation. This enables a rectangular spot with a semi-idealised intensity cross section to be delivered to the work piece, reorganising 90% of the 1.2kW CO2 laser beam. When the diffractive optical element is applied to the laser cladding process, the resultant transverse clad profile is uniformly rectangular with a lack of 'shoulder rounding'. The laser cladding operation produced complex microstructures, which could not be satisfactorily categorised with optical microscopy. This lead to the simplification of the process by removing the powder. Autogenous bead on plate laser welds have therefore been manufactured, using both conventional optics and diffractive optical elements, in order to determine the solidification microstructure of 316L stainless steel. Optical microscopy, electron back-scatter diffraction (EBSD), energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), have been employed to assist in the characterisation of the complex microstructures produced.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide lasers; Computer generated holography; Density (optical); Diffractive optical elements; Energy dispersive spectroscopy; Laser beams; Laser cladding; Microstructure; Optical data storage; Optical microscopy; 316 L stainless steel; Complex microstructures; Conventional lasers; Electron back scatter diffraction; Energy dispersive spectroscopies (EDS); Irradiance distribution; Laser-cladding process; Solidification microstructures; Gaussian beams

Authors: Sakikawa M., Atsumi Y., Kubouchi A., Matsumura K., Endo T., Yoshida S.
Title: Development of seawater exchange system using thermal energy and metal hydride actuator
Source title: Asian and Pacific Coasts, 2003 - Proceedings of the 2nd International Conference
Affiliations: Researcher of Port and Harbor Engineering Division, Civil Engineering Research Institute of Hokkaido, Hiragishi 1-3-1-34, Toyohira-ku, Sapporo, 062-8602, Japan; Research and Development Department, Hokkaido Industrial Technology Center, 379, kikyou-cho, Hakodate, 041-0801, Japan; Numerical Analysis Section, Nippon Data Service Co Ltd, N16E19, Higashi-ku, Sapporo, 065-0016, Japan; Physical Fluid Dynamics Lab., Hokkaido University, N13W8 Kita-ku, Sapporo, 060-8628, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sakikawa, M., Researcher of Port and Harbor Engineering Division, Civil Engineering Research Institute of Hokkaido, Hiragishi 1-3-1-34, Toyohira-ku, Sapporo, 062-8602, Japan; Atsumi, Y., Researcher of Port and Harbor Engineering Division, Civil Engineering Research Institute of Hokkaido, Hiragishi 1-3-1-34, Toyohira-ku, Sapporo, 062-8602, Japan; Kubouchi, A., Researcher of Port and Harbor Engineering Division, Civil Engineering Research Institute of Hokkaido, Hiragishi 1-3-1-34, Toyohira-ku, Sapporo, 062-8602, Japan; Matsumura, K., Research and Development Department, Hokkaido Industrial Technology Center, 379, kikyou-cho, Hakodate, 041-0801, Japan; Endo, T., Numerical Analysis Section, Nippon Data Service Co Ltd, N16E19, Higashi-ku, Sapporo, 065-0016, Japan; Yoshida, S., Physical Fluid Dynamics Lab., Hokkaido University, N13W8 Kita-ku, Sapporo, 060-8628, Japan
Abstract: Seawater exchange is being considered as a measure against deterioration of water quality and freezing, which are becoming problems in harbors and fishing ports. It is therefore desirable to develop a seawater exchange system with low running cost to put these systems into practical use. At the same time, development and use of new energy sources such as renewable energy have become much more common in recent years due to concerns about the global environment. Hydrogen is a clean energy source that can replace fossil fuels. Metal hydride (MH) has been studied as a method for storage of hydrogen. The MH actuator is being developed as a method for directly obtaining a mechanical force using hydrogen pressure generated by a temperature difference applied to a MH. In this study, a seawater-pumping device was produced experimentally using a MH actuator. We acknowledge the performance and characteristics in a laboratory test and examine its practical application. © 2004, World Scientific. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Metal Hydride; Seawater Exchange; Thermal Energy

Authors: Ishikawa T., Sasaki S., Manabe K., Hermance D., Voshida H.
Title: Development of fuel-cell hybrid system
Source title: IFAC Proceedings Volumes (IFAC-PapersOnline)
Affiliations: Electric and Hybrid Vehicle Engineering Div., Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan; Environmental Engineering Div., Toyota Technical Center, USA, Inc., United States; Toyota Communication Systems Corporation, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ishikawa, T., Electric and Hybrid Vehicle Engineering Div., Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan; Sasaki, S., Electric and Hybrid Vehicle Engineering Div., Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan; Manabe, K., Environmental Engineering Div., Toyota Technical Center, USA, Inc., United States; Hermance, D., Environmental Engineering Div., Toyota Technical Center, USA, Inc., United States; Voshida, H., Toyota Communication Systems Corporation, United States
Abstract: Toyota Motor Corporation started the development of fuel cell vehicle in 1992, and the company began leasing a new generation fuel cell vehicle the FCHV(Fuel Cell Hybrid Vehicle) in December 2002. The FCHV's system is designed to improve the efficiency and aims for high responsiveness when the vehicle is in a transitional state. In much the same way as most electric vehicles and the gasoline powered hybrid "Prius", the energy the traction motor creates during braking can be used to regenerate the secondary battery. The fuel cell and traction motor inverter are connected directly, with the secondary battery connected through the DC/DC converter to the fuel cell in parallel. The efficiency of the FCHV has the ability to be approximately 3 times greater than the conventional internal combustion engine (ICE) powered vehicle. In 2003, Toyota developed the highly efficient next-generation FCHV. The system uses a lithium battery, the optimum power storage device for the characteristics of the fuel cell system, and a highly efficient half bridge converter circuit. The change to a lighter secondary battery and the reduction of converter losses make it possible to improve the fuel economy by 4% over the current Toyota FCHV. This paper describes the circumstances of fuel cell vehicle development in Toyota and the overview of Toyota FCHV's system control and next-generation FCFlV's system. Copyright © IFAC Mechatronic Systems, Sydney, Australia, 2004.
Author Keywords: Efficiency; Fuel-cell; Hybrid; Power storage device
