Abstract: In this paper, a kind of novel high-temperature phase change thermal energy storage heater was developed. It can shift electricity from peak periods to off peak periods to provide significant economic benefit. A series of experiments were carried out to test the heat charge and discharge performance of this kind of heater. The results showed that: (1) With high heat of fusion and thermal conductivity, AlSil2 is suitable heat storage medium; (2) The heat storage ratio of the heater increases with increasing heating power; (3) During the phase change process, the heater can provide stable heat discharge rate and meet the demand of thermal comfort; (4) The high-temperature phase change thermal energy storage heater is potential for domestic space heating with high heat storage ratio and small size. Title: Automating the transition between sensorless motor control methods for the NASA Glenn Research Center flywheel energy storage system
Source title: Collection of Technical Papers - 2nd International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Ohio Aerospace Institute, Cleveland, OH 44142, United States; NASA Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States; Lewis' Educational and Research Collaborative Internship Program, United Kingdom; Advanced Electrical Systems, MS333-2
Authors with affiliations: Fehrmann, E.A., Ohio Aerospace Institute, Cleveland, OH 44142, United States, Lewis' Educational and Research Collaborative Internship Program, United Kingdom; Kenny, B.H., NASA Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH 44135, United States, Advanced Electrical Systems, MS333-2
Abstract: The NASA Glenn Research Center (GRC) has been working to advance the technology necessary for a flywheel energy storage system for the past several years. Flywheels offer high efficiency, durability, and near-complete discharge capabilities not produced by typical chemical batteries. These characteristics show flywheels to be an attractive alternative to the more typical energy storage solutions. Flywheels also offer the possibility of combining what are now two separate systems in space applications into one: energy storage, which is currently provided by batteries, and attitude control, which is currently provided by control moment gyroscopes (CMGs) or reaction wheels. To date, the NASA GRC research effort has produced the control algorithms necessary to demonstrate flywheel operation up to a rated speed of 60,000 RPM and the combined operation of two flywheel machines to simultaneously provide energy storage and single axis attitude control. Two position-sensorless algorithms are used to control the motor/generator, one for low (0 to 1200 RPM) speeds and one for high speeds. The algorithm allows the transition from the low speed method to the high speed method, but the transition from the high to low speed method was not originally included. This leads to a limitation in the existing motor/generator control code that does not allow the flywheels to be commanded to zero speed (and back in the "negative" speed direction) after the initial startup. In a multi-flywheel system providing both energy storage and attitude control to a spacecraft, speed reversal may be necessary.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Automation; Durability; Feedback; Flywheels; Gyroscopes; Spacecraft; Attitude control; Control momentum gyroscopes (CMG); Flywheel controllers; Flywheel enery storage systems; Energy storage

Title: G2 flywheel module design
Source title: Collection of Technical Papers - 2nd International Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: University of Toledo, NASA Glenn Research Center, Brookpark, OH 44135, United States; QSS Group, Inc., NASA Glenn Research Center, Brookpark, OH 44135, United States; Structural Mechanics and Dynamics Branch, MS 49-8, 21000 Brookpark Road, United States; Space Power and Propulsion Test Engineering Branch, MS 333-1, 21000 Brookpark Road, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jansen, R.H., University of Toledo, NASA Glenn Research Center, Brookpark, OH 44135, United States, Structural Mechanics and Dynamics Branch, MS 49-8, 21000 Brookpark Road, United States; Dever, T.P., QSS Group, Inc., NASA Glenn Research Center, Brookpark, OH 44135, United States, Space Power and Propulsion Test Engineering Branch, MS 333-1, 21000 Brookpark Road, United States
Abstract: Design of a flywheel module, designated the G2 module, is described. The G2 flywheel is a 60,000 RPM, 525 W-hr, 1kW system designed for a laboratory environment; it will be used for component testing and system demonstrations, with the goal of applying flywheels to aerospace energy storage and integrated power and attitude control (IPACS) applications. G2 has a modular design, which allows for new motors, magnetic bearings, touchdown bearings, and rotors to be installed without a complete redesign of the system. This design process involves several engineering disciplines, and requirements are developed for the speed, energy storage, power level, and operating environment. The G2 rotor system consists of a multilayer carbon fiber rim with a titanium hub on which the other components mount, and rotordynamics analysis is conducted to ensure rigid and flexible rotor modes are controllable or outside of the operating speed range. Magnetic bearings are sized using 1-D magnetic circuit analysis and refined using 3-D finite element analysis. The G2 magnetic bearing system was designed by Texas A&M and has redundancy which allows derated operation after the loss of some components, and an existing liquid cooled two pole permanent magnet motor/generator is used. The touchdown bearing system is designed with a squeeze film damper system allowing spin down from full operating speed in case of a magnetic bearing failure. The G2 module will enable module level demonstrations of component technology, and will be used be a key building block in system level attitude control and IPACS demonstrations. Copyright © 2004 by the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc.
Index Keywords: Aerospace engineering; Carbon fibers; Damping; Energy storage; Magnetic circuits; Multilayers; Rotors; Aerospace energy storage; Glenn Research Center (GRC); Integrated Power and Attitude Control System (IPACS); Mass savings; Flywheels

Title: Numerical simulation of axisymmetric supersonic screech tones
Source title: Collection of Technical Papers - 10th AIAA/CEAS Aeroacoustics Conference
Affiliations: Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Beijing, 100083, China; School of Jet Propulsion, China
Authors with affiliations: Li, X.D., Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Beijing, 100083, China, School of Jet Propulsion, China; Gao, J.H., Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Beijing, 100083, China, School of Jet Propulsion, China
Abstract: Despite the advances in screech research during the past few decades, it is still a challenge task to predict the screech amplitude and to understand the underlying nonlinear mechanism in detail. In this paper an axisymmetric computational aeroacoustic procedure is developed to predict the axisymmetric supersonic screech tones. The axisymmetric Navier-Stokes equations and the two equations standard k - ε turbulence model modified by Turpin & Troyes are solved in the generalized curvilinear coordinate system. A generalized wall function is applied in the nozzle exit wall region. The dispersion-relation- preserving scheme is applied for space discretization. The 2N storage low-dissipation and low-dispersion Runge-Kutta scheme is employed for time integration. Much attention is paid to far field boundary conditions and turbulence model. The underexpanded axisymmetric supersonic jet screech tones are simulated over the Mach number from 1.05 to 1.2. Numerical results are presented and compared with the experimental data by other researchers. It is demonstrated that the axisymmetric jet screech tones can be simulated correctly and the modes jumping can be captured. The receptivity process is presented in a screech cycle, and the mechanism of instability waves generation is analyzed. Finally, the phenomena of shock motions are analyzed, and its relationship with the screech tones is discussed.
Index Keywords: Boundary conditions; Jets; Kinetic energy; Laminar flow; Mathematical models; Navier Stokes equations; Problem solving; Runge Kutta methods; Turbulence; Viscosity; Kronecker symbols; Laminar viscosity; Space discretization; Supersonic screech tones; Supersonic aircraft

Authors: Gedik B., Singh A., Liu L.
Title: Energy efficient exact kNN search in wireless broadcast environments
Source title: GIS: Proceedings of the ACM International Symposium on Advances in Geographic Information Systems
Affiliations: Georgia Institute of Tech., United States
Authors with affiliations: Gedik, B., Georgia Institute of Tech., United States; Singh, A., Georgia Institute of Tech., United States; Liu, L., Georgia Institute of Tech., United States
Abstract: The advances in wireless communication and decreasing costs of mobile devices have enabled users to access desired information at any time. Coupled with positioning technologies like GPS, this opens up an exciting domain of location based services, allowing a mobile user to query for objects based on its current position. Main bottlenecks in such infrastructures are the draining of power of the mobile devices and the limited network bandwidth available. To alleviate these problems, broadcasting spatial information about relevant objects has been widely accepted as an efficient mechanism. An important class of queries for such an infrastructure is the k-nearest neighbor (kNN) queries, in which users are interested in closest objects to their position. In this paper, we describe mechanisms to perform exact kNN search on conventional sequential-access R-trees, and optimize established kNN search algorithms. We also propose a novel use of histograms for guiding the search and derive analytical results on maximum queue size and node access count. In addition, we discuss the effects of different broadcast organizations on search performance and challenge the traditional use of Depth-First (df s) organization. We also extend our mechanisms to support kNN search with non-spatial constraints. While we demonstrate our ideas using a broadcast index, they are equally applicable to any kind of sequential access medium like tertiary tape storage. We validate our mechanisms through an extensive experimental analysis and present our findings. Copyright 2004 ACM.
Author Keywords: Air Indexes; K-Nearest Neighbor Search; Wireless Data Broadcast
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Bandwidth; Cost effectiveness; Data communication systems; Indexing (of information); Queueing networks; Telecommunication services; Air indexes; Distributed databases; K-nearest neighbor search; Wireless data broadcast; Wireless telecommunication systems

Title: Compliant mechani

Abstract: This paper explores the use of compliant mechanisms or flexible beams in vehicle suspension systems. An example of a compliant suspension mechanism is the leaf spring suspension commonly found on trucks. New concepts are developed through rigid-body replacement synthesis and other methods with the objective of improving wheel control. The compliant A-arm is discussed and shown to be a promising concept for further research based on FEA results and other comparisons. The A-Arm concept performs well in controlling wheel deflections and has low stress values in response to control forces when compared to other compliant concepts considered and leaf spring configurations. The A-Arm uses less space than than the other compliant concepts considered and the potential cost of manufacture and assembly is potentially equal to current leaf spring congifurations. Title: Preliminary design and simulation of a pneumatic, stored-energy, hybrid orthosis for gait restoration
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, The Fluid Power and Systems Technology Division, FPST
Affiliations: University of Minnesota, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Minneapolis, MN 55439, United States
Authors with affiliations: Durfee, W.K., University of Minnesota, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Minneapolis, MN 55439, United States; Rivard, A., University of Minnesota, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Minneapolis, MN 55439, United States
Abstract: Loss of mobility due to lower limb paralysis is a common result of thoracic level spinal cord injury (SCI). Functional electrical stimulation (FES) can restore primitive gait in the vicinity of a wheelchair by using electrical stimulation to generate muscle contractions. A new concept for FES-assisted gait is presented that combines electrical stimulation with an orthosis that contains a fluid power system to store and transfer energy during the gait cycle. The Energy Storage Orthosis (ESO) can be driven through a complete gait cycle using only stimulation of the quadriceps muscles. The conceptual design of the ESO was completed and implemented in a dynamic simulation model and in a benchtop prototype for engineering measurements. No studies were conducted with human subjects. The results demonstrate the potential of the ESO concept and the validity of the simulation model as a means for designing the system. Copyright © 2004 by ASME.

Title: Composite Flywheel Rotor Technology Development Overview

Abstract: A Phase I & II Small Business Innovative Research contract awarded to Think Composites by the Air Force Research Laboratory undertook the task of analyzing and optimizing flywheel rotor designs, and obtaining spin test data for model verification and design improvement Several designs were explored, manufactured, and tested with the "soft-core" flywheel rotor concept showing great promise. This paper gives an overview of the flywheel energy storage system, additionally soft core composite rotor design, rotor analysis, rotor fabrication, spin testing, and durability analysis (life prediction) is discussed.

Title: Cool Thinking: Unlocking earth's energy
Source title: Refocus
Affiliations: NUJ, de Garf 2, 6581 SK, Malden, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Holdsworth, B., NUJ, de Garf 2, 6581 SK, Malden, Netherlands
Abstract: The developments in earth and ground water thermal energy storage in the Netherlands and the UK are discussed. At the beginning of 2003, over 200 Aquifer Thermal Energy Storage (ATES) projects had been installed across the Netherlands. The ATES system used at Eindhoven University is a method by which heat is collected from campus buildings in the summer, and then stored in an area of the aquifers. In the UK, London-based Fulcrum Consulting is working in conjunction with Dutch-based IF Tech. International to provide a low CO 2 energy solution for a low-impact, high-quality, 128 apartment Westway Beacons housing project in Acton, London.

Source title: Refocus

Authors with affiliations: Bales, C., Högskolan Dalarna, Solar Energy Research Center, S-78188 Borlänge, Sweden; Furbo, S., Department of Civil Engineering, Technical University of Denmark, DK-2800 Lyngby, Denmark
Abstract: The solar thermal cost reduction measures planned for Nordic countries to increase the acceptance of the technology in the region are discussed. One way to reduce the energy costs of solar heating systems is based on rationalization effects due to large scale production, while the alternative is to improve the performance/cost ratio of solar heating systems by developing improved systems. Installing a solar heating system, including a boiler unit, in a house can provide several advantages including reduced costs. As the system is designed as a whole, it is easier to optimize overall system performance, making the different components work together, allowing further reduction in energy costs as well as emissions.

Authors: Pisharath J., Choudhary A., Kandemir M.
Title: Energy management schemes for memory-resident database systems
Source title: International Conference on Information and Knowledge Management, Proceedings
Affiliations: Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60208, United States; Department of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pisharath, J., Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60208, United States; Choudhary, A., Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60208, United States; Kandemir, M., Department of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States
Abstract: With the tremendous growth of system memories, memory-resident databases are increasingly becoming important in various domains. Newer memories provide a structured way of storing data in multiple chips, with each chip having a bank of memory modules. Current memory-resident databases are yet to take full advantage of the banked storage system, which offers a lot of room for performance and energy optimizations. In this paper, we identify the implications of a banked memory environment in supporting memory-resident databases, and propose hardware (memory-directed) and software (query-directed) schemes to reduce the energy consumption of queries executed on these databases. Our results show that high-level query-directed schemes (hosted in the query optimizer) better utilize the low-power modes in reducing the energy consumption than the respective hardware schemes (hosted in the memory controller), due to their complete knowledge of query access patterns. We extend this further and propose a query restructuring scheme and a multi-query optimization. Queries are restructured and regrouped based on their table access patterns to maximize the likelihood that data accesses are clustered. This helps increase the inter-access idle times of memory modules, which in turn enables a more effective control of their energy behavior. This heuristic is eventually integrated with our hardware optimizations to achieve maximum savings. Our experimental results show that the memory energy reduces by 90% if query restructuring method is applied along with basic energy optimizations over the unoptimized version. The system-wide performance impact of each scheme is also studied simultaneously. Copyright 2004 ACM.
Author Keywords: Database; DRAM; Energy; Hardware energy scheme; Multiquery optimization; Power consumption; Query-directed energy management
Index Keywords: Computer hardware; Computer software; Data reduction; Data storage equipment; Dynamic random access storage; Energy management; Energy utilization; Query languages; Energy; Hardware energy scheme; Multi-query optimization; Power consumption; Query-directed energy management; Database systems

Title: News: Hydrogenics in ultra-capacitor collaboration, launches commercialization initiative
Source title: Fuel Cells Bulletin
Abstract: Maxwell Technologies has formed a strategic alliance with Hydrogenics to accelerate the integration of ultracapacitor and fuel cell technologies. Hydrogenics will integrate Maxwell's Boostcap® ultracapacitors into its fuel cell power systems to optimize system performance, cost, and longevity. Paired with fuel cells in stop/go mobility applications, such as forklifts, ultracapacitors provide burst power for lifting and acceleration, and enable regenerative braking. Hydrogenics has also launched a new business initiative to develop fuel cell-based power trains for "off-road" light vehicles. OEM and component providers for hydrogen or energy storage, power conditioning, traction controllers and drives, and fuel cell components are being targeted to partner in developing a range of such vehicles in the sub-automotive power range, typically < 50 kw of electric power.

Title: Iron metabolism and the IRE/IRP regulatory system: An update
Source title: Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences
Affiliations: Sir Mortimer B. Davis Jewish Gen. H., Department of Medicine, McGill University, Montreal, Que., Canada; Lady Davis Inst. for Med. Research, Sir Mortimer B. Davis Jewish Gen. H., 3755 Cote-Ste-Catherine Road, Montreal, Que. H3T 1E2, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Pantopoulos, K., Sir Mortimer B. Davis Jewish Gen. H., Department of Medicine, McGill University, Montreal, Que., Canada, Lady Davis Inst. for Med. Research, Sir Mortimer B. Davis Jewish Gen. H., 3755 Cote-Ste-Catherine Road, Montreal, Que. H3T 1E2, Canada
Abstract: Cellular iron homeostasis is accomplished by the coordinated regulated expression of the transferrin receptor and ferritin, which mediate iron uptake and storage, respectively. The mechanism is posttranscriptional and involves two cytoplasmic iron regulatory proteins, IRP1 and IRP2. Under conditions of iron starvation, IRPs stabilize the transferrin receptor and inhibit the translation of ferritin mRNAs by binding to "iron responsive elements" (IREs) within their untranslated regions. The IRE/IRP system also controls the expression of additional IRE-containlng mRNAs, encoding proteins of iron and energy metabolism. The activities of IRP1 and IRP2 are regulated by distinct posttranslational mechanisms in response to cellular iron levels. Thus, in iron-replete cells, IRP1 assembles a cubane iron-sulfur cluster, which prevents IRE binding, while IRP2 undergoes proteasomal degradation. IRP1 and IRP2 also respond, albeit differentially, to iron-independent signals, such as hydrogen peroxide, hypoxia, or nitric oxide. Basic principles of the IRE/IRP system and recent advances in understanding the regulation and the function of IRP1 and IRP2 are discussed.

Title: Tank volume measurement systems: Volume measurement uncertainty analysis
Source title: Proceedings of the Biennial International Pipeline Conference, IPC
Affiliations: Sinai Engineering Corporation, 4656A 99 Street, Edmonton, Alta. T6E 5H5, Canada; Enbridge Pipelines Inc., 10201 Jasper Avenue, Edmonton, Alta. T5J 2J9, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Oracheski, J.D., Sinai Engineering Corporation, 4656A 99 Street, Edmonton, Alta. T6E 5H5, Canada; Rausch, N., Enbridge Pipelines Inc., 10201 Jasper Avenue, Edmonton, Alta. T5J 2J9, Canada
Abstract: Enbridge Inc. operates the world's longest crude oil and products pipeline system. The company owns and operates Enbridge Pipelines Inc. (the Canadian portion of the Enbridge crude oil mainline) and a variety of affiliated pipelines in Canada and the United States, including Enbridge Energy Partners, L.P. that operates the Lakehead Pipeline System in the United States. Much of the main pipeline system has been in operation for over 55 years. The mainline system is comprised of approximately 15,000 kilometers (9000 miles) of pipeline, 3 million barrels of cavern storage and 3.7 million barrels of tankage (352 tanks) which collectively are integral to transporting more than 2.2 million barrels per day of crude oil and refined products. Enbridge's measurement needs and practices have continuously evolved, with radar gauging on tanks becoming the standard over the past few years. This paper discusses a number of issues associated with the accuracy of volume measurements in upright, cylindrical petroleum product storage tanks with floating roofs. It includes the analysis and discussion of the process of determining tank volumes and the overall accuracy of a tank volume measurement system. It also includes a discussion of the influence and relevance of each measurement variable on the overall accuracy of tank volume measurements, in order to provide pipeline operators with some insight into determining which variables are most important to the process of tank volume measurement. Finally, it discusses issues regarding tank volume measurement system accuracy, as opposed to overall tank volume measurement accuracy. The focus of this paper is not on the uncertainty analysis process itself, but rather on understanding the results of the uncertainty analysis performed for tank volume measurement systems. Copyright © 2004 by ASME.

Title: Focus: Refining and marketing: Canada: LNG proposals flood in
Source title: Petroleum Economist
Abstract: In recent months, Irving Oil, Anadarko, a partnership of Gaz Metropolitain, Enbridge and Gaz de France, and a joint venture between TransCanada and Petro-Canada have joined the line-up of LNG import projects targeting start-up this decade, many of them chasing customers in the US. Irving obtained regulatory approvals for a terminal in New Brunswick, Anadarko bought a plant from Access Northeast Energy for a plant in Nova Scotia, and the two partnerships launched rival plans for facilities in Quebec. Keltic Petrochemicals plans a combined petrochemicals and LNG facility, while Statia Terminals Canada is considering a plant. According to analyst Martin King, the economic outlook is strong, with little chance that LNG will flood the market, pushing prices to the levels seen in the 1990s. Although concerns about the security and environmental risks posed by LNG facilities are muted in Canada, the same opposition that drove TransCanada away from two projects in Maine is building strength. Among the line-up for Canada are TransCanada and Petro-Canada's proposed 2009 start-up of a plant near Riviere-du-Loup, Quebec, which would have a capacity of 0.5 bcf/day and two storage tanks with 6.8 bcf total capacity; Irving Oil's construction of the 1 bcf/day Bear Head project; Keltic Petrochemicals' hiring of Stone & Webster Engineering for front-end engineering and WestLB as financial adviser for its proposed petrochemicals/LNG plant at Goldboro, Nova Scotia; etc.

Authors: Qian J., Wang K., Zhang J., Qiu D.
Title: Pipelining of viscous waxy crude with the pour-point-depressant beneficiation: Successful experience in the Lu-ning pipeline
Source title: Proceedings of the Biennial International Pipeline Conference, IPC
Affiliations: University of Petroleum, SINOPEC Pipeline Transp./Storage Co., Beijing, China; SINOPEC Pipeline Transp./Storage Co., China; University of Petroleum, Beijing, China
Authors with affiliations: Qian, J., University of Petroleum, SINOPEC Pipeline Transp./Storage Co., Beijing, China; Wang, K., SINOPEC Pipeline Transp./Storage Co., China; Zhang, J., University of Petroleum, Beijing, China; Qiu, D., SINOPEC Pipeline Transp./Storage Co., China
Abstract: The Lu-Ning Pipeline in the eastern China, 655.37 km long and 720 mm O.D., transports viscous Shengli waxy crude with a wax content of ca 15.24%(wt), a density of 922 kg/m3 at 20°C, a gel point of 24°C, and a viscosity of 3210 mPa·s at 25°C. It was designed as a hot oil pipeline. In the mid 1990's, with decreasing of the crude throughput, the fuel consumption for pipelining per ton of crude increased dramatically. For reducing fuel consumption, the technology of pour-point-depressant (PPD) beneficiation was adopted. Great success was achieved. With a PPD dosage of 50 ppm and a beneficiating temperature of 60°C at the initial pumping station, the gel point of the crude was reduced by 16°C, and the viscosity at 25°C was reduced by 87%. As a result, the crude temperature at the inlet of the intermediate heating stations was lowered from 34°C to 27∓1°C. This resulted in annual 17200 tons of fuel oil saving. Thanks to improvement of the crude flow properties, running heating stations were reduced from twelve before using the PPD to only one(the initial station) in summer, seven in winter, and two to five in spring and autumn depending on ground temperature. This was the pipeline with the longest distance, the largest diameter, the largest throughput and the most running pumping stations in China that ever used the PPD-beneficiation technology. We believe that experiences gained from this pipeline and other pipelines operated by the SINOPEC Pipeline Transport and Storage Company will be helpful to safe and economical operation of hot waxy crude pipelines. Copyright © 2004 by ASME.

Title: Computational studies of boron/nitrogen and aluminum/nitrogen compounds for chemical hydrogen storage
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Fundamental Science Division, Pac. Northwest National Laboratory, 902 Battelle Blvd., MS K1-96, United States; Chemistry, PNNL, POB 999, MS#K2-57, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gutowski, M., Fundamental Science Division, Pac. Northwest National Laboratory, 902 Battelle Blvd., MS K1-96, United States; Autrey, T., Chemistry, PNNL, POB 999, MS#K2-57, United States
Abstract: DOE Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy recently proposed a Grand Challenge for on-board Hydrogen Storage. To meet the target of the long-term DOE volumetric (0.09 kg H2/kg) and energy density (3 kwh/kg) targets, further development and understanding of hydrogen storage materials will require substantial new research effort and the discovery of new hydrogen storage materials. Computational approaches were used to examine the thermodynamics of two potential hydrogen storage systems, NHxBHx and NHxAlHx (x = 1-4). Both materials could potentially meet the long-term DOE requirements for volumetric and energy density requirements with a potential of 0.24 kg H2/kg and 0.19 kg H2/kg, respectively. Theoretical calculations predicted that hydrogen loss is the thermodynamically favored pathway over B-N or Al-N bond scission. However, the loss of hydrogen from the NHxBHx series of compounds was less exothermic than the loss of hydrogen from the NHxAlHx series of compounds. This could be an important economic factor to consider for potential on-board or off-board recycle. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 227th ACS National Meeting (Anaheim, CA 3/28/2004-4/1/2004).

Title: Hydrogen storage issues in a new hydrogen economy
Source title: ACS National Meeting Book of Abstracts
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Virginia Commonwealth University, 1020 W. Main Street, Richmond, VA 23284-2000, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jena, P., Department of Physics, Virginia Commonwealth University, 1020 W. Main Street, Richmond, VA 23284-2000, United States
Abstract: The limited supply of fossil fuels, its adverse effect on the environment, and growing worldwide demand for energy has necessitated the search for new and clean sources of energy. The possibility of using hydrogen to meet this growing energy need has rekindled interest in the study of safe, efficient, and economical storage of hydrogen. Unfortunately, the current methods for storing hydrogen as a compressed gas or liquid do not meet the industry requirements. An alternate method for hydrogen storage involves metal hydrides. A novel approach for hydrogen storage is to combine the favorable kinetics and thermodynamics of conventional metal hydrides with that of the large hydrogen storing capacity of organic molecules, e.g., CH4. Although alanates, with the chemical composition [Mn+ (AlH4)n-, M = Li, Na, K, Mg], belong to this class, the desorption temperature of hydrogen in these materials is rather high. It was recently discovered that doping of Ti-based catalyst in NaAlH4 can significantly lower the hydrogen desorption temperature. Using first principles calculations, a molecular level understanding of the role of titanium in lowering the hydrogen desorption temperature in NaAlH4 and LiBH4 was provided. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 227th ACS National Meeting (Anaheim, CA 3/28/2004-4/1/2004).

Authors: Mattern N., Kühn U., Sakowski J., Neuefeind J., Eckert J.
Title: Structure of Zr52Ti5Cu18Ni 15Al10 Bulk Metallic Glass at Elevated Temperatures
Source title: Materials Science Forum
Affiliations: Inst. Festkorper/Werkstofforsch., POB 270016, DE-01171 Dresden, Germany; Department of Physics, Rostock University, DE-18051 Rostock, Germany; HASYLAB, DESY, Notkestr. 85, DE-22603 Hamburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Mattern, N., Inst. Festkorper/Werkstofforsch., POB 270016, DE-01171 Dresden, Germany; Kühn, U., Inst. Festkorper/Werkstofforsch., POB 270016, DE-01171 Dresden, Germany; Sakowski, J., Department of Physics, Rostock University, DE-18051 Rostock, Germany; Neuefeind, J., HASYLAB, DESY, Notkestr. 85, DE-22603 Hamburg, Germany; Eckert, J., Inst. Festkorper/Werkstofforsch., POB 270016, DE-01171 Dresden, Germany
Abstract: The glass transition and the phase formation during crystallization of the Zr52Ti5Cu18Ni15Al10 bulk metallic glass were followed in situ by high-temperature X-ray diffraction using synchrotron radiation at the high energy beam-line BW5 (λ = 0. 01040 nm) at the storage ring DORIS (HASYLAB, Hamburg). The experimental set-up enables to record intensities in transmission up to scattering vectors q of 200 nm-1 with a measuring time of 20 s per diagram. The crystallization starts with the formation of an extremely fine nanostructure followed by the transformation into tetragonal NiZr2-type crystals plus an unknown phase. Both phases are metastable and transform at about 1123 K into the stable equilibrium phases. The temperature dependence of the structure factor S(q) of the glass can be well described within the framework of the Debye theory. At the glass transition the first derivative dS(q)/dT changes. A Debye temperature Θ = 412 K was estimated for the glassy, and Θ = 162 K for the liquid state of the Zr52Ti5Cu18Ni 15Al10 alloy. The short-range order of the glass, of the supercooled liquid state, and of the equilibrium melt at T= 1193 K is found to be quite similar.

Authors: Westervelt E.R., Schmledeler J.P., Washington G.
Title: Variable transmission compliance with an MR damper
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Aerospace Division (Publication) AD
Affiliations: Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, Ohio State University, Columbus, OH 43202, United States
Authors with affiliations: Westervelt, E.R., Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, Ohio State University, Columbus, OH 43202, United States; Schmledeler, J.P., Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, Ohio State University, Columbus, OH 43202, United States; Washington, G., Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, Ohio State University, Columbus, OH 43202, United States
Abstract: This paper presents a novel transmission design that consists of a parallel combination of an MR damper and a compliant element together acting in series with an actuator. By adjusting the magnetic field to vary the amount of damping, the transmission can be switched between compliant and effectively rigid modes. Transmission compliance between an actuator and its load has several benefits; It enables (1) storage of elastic energy to improve efficiency, (2) filtering of shocks acting on the load that would otherwise be transmitted to the actuator, and (3) facilitation of force control by converting it to a position control problem. Despite these benefits, the design objective for most robotic systems remains to minimize transmission compliance to improve transmission bandwidth, improving the ability to control the position of the load with high precision. With the new transmission presented in this paper, compliance becomes a tunable quantity allowing joint stiffness to be optimized based upon the task requirements. Copyright © 2004 by ASME.

Authors: Prangnell P.B., Bowen J.R., Berta M., Apps P.J., Bate P.S.
Title: Stability of ultra-fine 'Grain structures' produced by severe deformation
Source title: Materials Science Forum
Affiliations: Manchester Materials Science Centre, University of Manchester, Grosvenor St, Manchester, M1 7HS, United Kingdom; Mat. Res. Dept. Risø Natl. L., P.O. Box 49, DK-4000 Roskilde, Denmark

L., P.O. Box 49, DK-4000 Roskilde, Denmark; Berta, M., Manchester Materials Science Centre, University of Manchester, Grosvenor St, Manchester, M1 7HS, United Kingdom; Apps, P.J., Manchester Materials Science Centre, University of Manchester, Grosvenor St, Manchester, M1 7HS, United Kingdom; Bate, P.S., Manchester Materials Science Centre, University of Manchester, Grosvenor St, Manchester, M1 7HS, United Kingdom
Abstract: Severe deformation techniques allow metallic alloys to be deformed to ultra-high plastic strains, without any geometrical change to the work piece. They thus offer potential for the cheap production of submicron grained materials, in a bulk form. After processing severely deformed materials do not have conventional, idealized, grain structures, contain significant fractions of low angle boundaries, and are often heterogeneous. Due to their high stored energy, they are unstable on annealing and in most cases can be thought of as continuously recrystallizing. However, locally discontinuous behaviors are often observed, due to the retained less mobile low angle boundaries, as well as abnormal grain growth at elevated temperatures. Monte-Carlo-Potts models have been used to show the sensitivity of the annealing behavior to the initial starting structure present after deformation. The effect of coarse (~1μm) particles and fine dispersoid particles are also discussed. © 2004 Trans Tech Publications, Switzerland.

Title: Evaluation of stored energy in cold-rolled if steels from EBSD data and its application to recrystallization modeling
Source title: Materials Science Forum

Abstract: This study has been conducted to evaluate the orientation-dependent stored energy of deformed grains from the data measured using electron back-scattered diffraction (EBSD) analysis. The stored energy in deformed grains is an important term as a driving force for static recrystallization of cold-rolled steels. Subgrain method based on subgrain structure is used for quantitative analysis of the stored energy developed in cold-rolled interstitial free (IF) steels to a reduction of 80%. The orientation dependent stored energy term was used in Monte Carlo technique to simulate static recrystallization of IF steels. © 2004 Trans Tech Publications, Switzerland.

Abstract: Wire-drawn copper has been investigated with Electron Back Scattered Diffraction technique in a Scanning Electron Microscope after deformation by wire-drawing. In this paper, we show how to get qualitative informations about the deformation inhomogeneities related to the stored energy distribution, from the analysis of the quality index. Furthermore, the microstructural analysis hi the wire diameter is completed using the quality index distribution approach. A relation between diameter of the wire and stored energy distribution is then qualitatively set. In order to validate the proposed method, the EBSD data are compared with the stored energy values obtained from neutron diffraction measurements. © 2004 Trans Tech Publications, Switzerland.

Creation Hatchery Center, Tohoku University, 10 Aza Aoba, Aoba, Sendai, Miyagi, 980-8579, Japan
Abstract: An image recognition processor utilizing phase only correlation (POC) algorithm is proposed. Arithmetic logical unit (ALU) in this processor can be re-configured dynamically. By arranging POC algorithm to the form suitable for reconfigurable computing, the proposed processor can perform two-dimensional 512×512 pixels image recognition within 105.2msec and 310.9mW. This power consumption is 11.3 times lower than that of a previously reported work with same execution time. ©2004 IEEE.

Title: Research & technology: Leaves inspire fuel cells
Source title: Process Engineering
Abstract: Fuel cell design is a matter almost as pressing as hydrogen storage. If the cells are to power a car, they need to produce as much power as possible, and this is dictated by the way that hydrogen and oxygen flow through the cell. Morgan Fuel Cell has taken a leaf from nature's book to create a design that can boost the power output from a cell by 16%. The design focuses on the bipolar plates, which perform two functions in fuel cells. They conduct electrical energy within the cell, and also channel the flow of hydrogen and oxygen to ensure that the electrodes have an adequate supply of both gases. Morgan's researchers have copied the structure of leaves and animal lungs to optimize the flow of gases.

Authors: Kim N.S., Flautner K., Blaauw D., Mudge T.
Title: Single-VDD and single-VT super-drowsy techniques for low-leakage high-performance instruction caches
Source title: Proceedings of the 2004 International Symposium on Lower Power Electronics and Design, ISLPED'04
Affiliations: Intel Corp.; ARM Ltd., United Kingdom; University of Michigan, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kim, N.S., Intel Corp.; Flautner, K., ARM Ltd., United Kingdom; Blaauw, D., University of Michigan, United States; Mudge, T., University of Michigan, United States
Abstract: In this paper, we present a circuit technique that supports a super-drowsy mode with a single-VDD. In addition, we perform a detailed working set analysis for various cache line update policies for placing lines in a drowsy state. The analysis presents a policy for an instruction cache and shows it is as good as or better than more complex schemes proposed in the past. Furthermore, as an alternative to using high-threshold devices to reduce the bitline leakage through access transistors in drowsy caches, we propose a gated bitline precharge technique. A single threshold process is now sufficient. The gated precharge employs a simple but effective predictor that almost completely hides any performance loss incurred by the transitions between sub-banks. A 64-entry predictor with 3 bits per entry reduces the run-time increase by 78%, which is as effective as previous proposals that used content addressable predictors with 40 bits per entry. Overall, the combination of the proposed techniques reduces the leakage power by 72% with negligible (0.4%) run-time increase.
Author Keywords: Leakage current; Low power

Authors: Mamidipaka M., Khouri K., Dutt N., Abadir M.
Title: Analytical models for leakage power estimation of memory array structures
Source title: Second IEEE/ACM/IFIP International Conference on Hardware/Software Codesign and Systems Synthesis, CODES+ISSS 2004
Affiliations: Center for Embedded Computer Systems, University of California, Irvine, Irvine, CA 92697, United States; Global Strategy Fut. Tools and Meth., Freescale/Motorola Inc., Austin, TX 78729, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mamidipaka, M., Center for Embedded Computer Systems, University of California, Irvine, Irvine, CA 92697, United States; Khouri, K., Global Strategy Fut. Tools and Meth., Freescale/Motorola Inc., Austin, TX 78729, United States; Dutt, N., Center for Embedded Computer Systems, University of California, Irvine, Irvine, CA 92697, United States; Abadir, M., Global Strategy Fut. Tools and Meth., Freescale/Motorola Inc., Austin, TX 78729, United States
Abstract: There is a growing need for accurate power models at the system level. Memory structures such as caches, Branch Target Buffers (BTBs), and register files occupy significant area in contemporary SoC designs and are the main contributors to system leakage power dissipation. Existing models for leakage power estimation in array structures typically use coefficients derived from elaborate SPICE simulations. However, these methodologies are not applicable to array designs in a newer technology, that require power estimates early in the design cycle. In this paper, we propose analytical models for array structures that are based only on high level design parameters. Assuming typical circuit implementation styles, we identify the transistors that contribute to the leakage power in each array sub-circuit and develop models as a function of the operation (read/write/idle) on the array and organizational parameters of the array. The developed models are validated by comparing their estimates against the leakage power measured using SPICE simulations on industrial array designs belonging to the e5001 processor core. The comparison shows that the models are accurate with an error margin of less than 21.5% and thus can be used in high-level power-performance exploration. Interestingly, in array designs with dual threshold voltage technology, we observed that contrary to the general expectation, the array memory core contributes to just 9% and the address decoder contributes to as much as 62% of the total leakage power.
Author Keywords: Estimation; Leakage power; Srams
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Computer architecture; Energy efficiency; Estimation; Mathematical models; Optimization; Threshold voltage; Combinational logic; Leakage power; Memory array structures; Power dissipation; Static random access storage

Authors: Wu C.-H., Kuo T.-W., Yang C.-L.
Title: Energy-efficient flash-memory storage systems with an interrupt-emulation mechanism
Source title: Second IEEE/ACM/IFIP International Conference on Hardware/Software Codesign and Systems Synthesis, CODES+ISSS 2004
Affiliations: Dept. of Comp. Sci. and Info. Eng., National Taiwan University, Taipei, 106, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Wu, C.-H., Dept. of Comp. Sci. and Info. Eng., National Taiwan University, Taipei, 106, Taiwan; Kuo, T.-W., Dept. of Comp. Sci. and Info. Eng., National Taiwan University, Taipei, 106, Taiwan; Yang, C.-L., Dept. of Comp. Sci. and Info. Eng., National Taiwan University, Taipei, 106, Taiwan
Abstract: One of the emerging critical issues for flash-memory storage systems, especially on the implementations of many embedded systems, is on its programmed I/O nature for data transfers. Programmed-I/O-based data transfers might not only result in the wasting of valuable CPU cycles of microprocessors but also unnecessarily consume much more energy from batteries. This paper presents an interrupt-emulation mechanism for flash-memory storage systems with an energy-efficient management strategy. We propose to revise the waiting function in the Memory-Technology-Device (MTD) layer to relieve the microprocessor from busy waiting and to reduce the energy consumption of the system. We show that energy consumption could be significantly reduced with good saving on CPU cycles and minor delay on the average response time in the experiments.

Authors: Pettis N., Cai L., Lu Y.-H.
Title: Dynamic power management for streaming data
Source title: Proceedings of the 2004 International Symposium on Lower Power Electronics and Design, ISLPED'04
Affiliations: Sch. of Elec. and Comp. Engineering, Purdue University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pettis, N., Sch. of Elec. and Comp. Engineering, Purdue University, United States; Cai, L., Sch. of Elec. and Comp. Engineering, Purdue University, United States; Lu, Y.-H., Sch. of Elec. and Comp. Engineering, Purdue University, United States
Abstract: This paper presents a method that uses data buffers to smoothen request variations and to create long idleness for power management. This method considers the power consumed by the buffers and assigns an energy penalty for buffer underflow. Our approach provides analytic formulas for calculating the optimal buffer sizes and the amount of data to store in the buffers. We use video prefetching as a case study and obtain power savings of more than 74% for MPEG-1 and 34% for MPEG-2 videos.

Authors: Mallik A., Wildrick M.C., Memik G.
Title: Design and implementation of correlating caches
Source title: Proceedings of the 2004 International Symposium on Lower Power Electronics and Design, ISLPED'04
Affiliations: Dept. of Elec. and Comp. Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60208, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mallik, A., Dept. of Elec. and Comp. Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60208, United States; Wildrick, M.C., Dept. of Elec. and Comp. Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60208, United States; Memik, G., Dept. of Elec. and Comp. Engineering, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60208, United States
Abstract: We introduce a new cache architecture that can be used to increase performance and reduce energy consumption in Network Processors. This new architecture is based on the observation that there is a strong correlation between different memory accesses. In other words, if load X and load Y are two consecutively executed load instructions, the offset between the source addresses of these instructions remain usually constant between different iterations. We utilize this information by building a correlating cache architecture. This architecture consists of a Dynamic Correlation Extractor, a Correlation History Table, and a Correlation Buffer. We first show simulation results investigating the frequency of correlating loads. Then, we evaluate our architecture using SimpleScalar/ARM. For a set of representative applications, the correlating cache architecture is able to reduce the average data access time by as much as 52.7% and 36.1% on average, while reducing the energy consumption of the caches by as much as 49.2% and 25.7% on average.

Title: Constant-load energy recovery memory for efficient high-speed operation
Source title: Proceedings of the 2004 International Symposium on Lower Power Electronics and Design, ISLPED'04
Affiliations: Adv. Comp. Architecture Laboratory, Dept. of Elec. Eng. and Comp. Sci., University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kim, J., Adv. Comp. Architecture Laboratory, Dept. of Elec. Eng. and Comp. Sci., University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Papaefthymiou, M.C., Adv. Comp. Architecture Laboratory, Dept. of Elec. Eng. and Comp. Sci., University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States
Abstract: This paper proposes a constant-load SRAM design for highly efficient recovery of bit-line energy with a resonant power-clock supply. For each bit-line pair, the proposed SRAM includes a dummy bit-line of sufficient capacitance to ensure that the memory array presents a constant capacitive load to the power-clock, regardless of data or operation. Using a single-phase power-clock waveform, read and write operations are performed with single-cycle latency. The efficiency of the proposed SRAM has been assessed through simulations of 128×256 arrays with 0.25μm process parameters and a 42/58 write/non-write access pattern. Assuming lossless power-clock generation, the proposed SRAM dissipates 37% less power than its conventional counterpart at 400MHz/2.5V. When the overhead of power-clock generation is included, the proposed SRAM dissipates at least 27% less power than conventional SRAM.
Author Keywords: Adiabatic circuitry; Cache memories; Charge recovery; Low-energy design; Low-power computing; On-chip memories

Title: A loop accelerator for low power embedded VLIW processors
Source title: Second IEEE/ACM/IFIP International Conference on Hardware/Software Codesign and Systems Synthesis, CODES+ISSS 2004
Affiliations: School of Computing, University of Utah, Salt Late City, UT 84112, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mathew, B., School of Computing, University of Utah, Salt Late City, UT 84112, United States; Davis, A., School of Computing, University of Utah, Salt Late City, UT 84112, United States
Abstract: The high transistor density afforded by modern VLSI processes have enabled the design of embedded processors that use clustered execution units to deliver high levels of performance. However, delivering data to the execution resources in a timely manner remains a major problem that limits ILP. It is particularly significant for embedded systems where memory and power budgets are limited. A distributed address generation and loop acceleration architecture for VLIW processors is presented. This decentralized on-chip memory architecture uses multiple SRAMs to provide high intra-processor bandwidth. Each SRAM has an associated stream address generator capable of implementing a variety of addressing modes in conjunction with a shared loop accelerator. The architecture is extremely useful for generating application specific embedded processors, particularly for processing input data which is organized as a stream. The idea is evaluated in the context of a fine grain VLIW architecture executing complex perception algorithms such as speech and visual feature recognition. Transistor level Spice simulations are used to demonstrate a 159x improvement in the energy delay product when compared to conventional architectures executing the same applications.
Author Keywords: Embedded systems; Low power design; VLIW

Authors: Verma M., Wehmeyer L., Marwedel P.
Title: Dynamic overlay of scratchpad memory for energy minimization
Source title: Second IEEE/ACM/IFIP International Conference on Hardware/Software Codesign and Systems Synthesis, CODES+ISSS 2004
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science XII, University of Dortmund, 44225 Dortmund, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Verma, M., Department of Computer Science XII, University of Dortmund, 44225 Dortmund, Germany; Wehmeyer, L., Department of Computer Science XII, University of Dortmund, 44225 Dortmund, Germany; Marwedel, P., Department of Computer Science XII, University of Dortmund, 44225 Dortmund, Germany
Abstract: The memory subsystem accounts for a significant portion of the aggregate energy budget of contemporary embedded systems. Moreover, there exists a large potential for optimizing the energy consumption of the memory subsystem. Consequently, novel memories as well as novel algorithms for their efficient utilization are being designed. Scratchpads are known to perform better than caches in terms of power, performance, area and predictability. However, unlike caches they depend upon software allocation techniques for their utilization. In this paper, we present an allocation technique which analyzes the application and inserts instructions to dynamically copy both code segments and variables onto the scratchpad at runtime. We demonstrate that the problem of dynamically overlaying scratchpad is an extension of the Global Register Allocation problem. The overlay problem is solved optimally using ILP formulation techniques. Our approach improves upon the only previously known allocation technique for statically allocating both variables and code segments onto the scratchpad. Experiments report an average reduction of 34% and 18% in the energy consumption and the runtime of the applications, respectively. A minimal increase in code size is also reported.
Author Keywords: Dynamic allocation; Overlay; Scratchpad
Index Keywords: Buffer storage; Computational complexity; Encoding (symbols); Energy utilization; Optimization; Performance; Resource allocation; Dynamic allocation; Overlay; Predictability; Scratchpad; Embedded systems

Authors: Park C., Kang J.-U., Park S.-Y., Kim J.-S.
Title: Energy-aware demand paging on NAND flash-based embedded storages
Source title: Proceedings of the 2004 International Symposium on Lower Power Electronics and Design, ISLPED'04
Affiliations: Memory Division, Samsung Electronics Co., South Korea; Computer Science Division, Korea Adv. Inst. Sci. and Technol., South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Park, C., Memory Division, Samsung Electronics Co., South Korea; Kang, J.-U., Computer Science Division, Korea Adv. Inst. Sci. and Technol., South Korea; Park, S.-Y., Computer Science Division, Korea Adv. Inst. Sci. and Technol., South Korea; Kim, J.-S., Computer Science Division, Korea Adv. Inst. Sci. and Technol., South Korea
Abstract: The ever-increasing requirement for high-performance and huge-capacity memories of emerging embedded applications has led to the widespread adoption of SDRAM and NAND flash memory as main and secondary memories, respectively. In particular, the use of energy consuming memory, SDRAM, has become burdensome in battery-powered embedded systems. Intuitively, though demand paging can be used to mitigate the increasing requirement of main memory size, its applicability should be deliberately elaborated since NAND flash memory has asymmetric operation characteristics in terms of performance and energy consumption. In this paper, we present energy-aware demand paging technique to lower the energy consumption of embedded systems considering the characteristics of interactive embedded applications with large memory footprints. We also propose a flash memory-aware page replacement policy that can reduce the number of write and erase operations in NAND flash memory. With real-life workloads, we show the systemwide Energy Delay can be reduced by 15∼30% compared to the traditional shadowing architecture.
Author Keywords: Demand paging; Embedded storages; Embedded systems; Flash memory; NAND; Page replacement; Virtual memory

Title: Impact of technology scaling on energy aware execution cache-based microarchitectures
Source title: Proceedings of the 2004 International Symposium on Lower Power Electronics and Design, ISLPED'04
Affiliations: Carnegie Mellon University, 5000 Forbes Ave, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States
Authors with affiliations: Talpes, E., Carnegie Mellon University, 5000 Forbes Ave, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States; Marculescu, D., Carnegie Mellon University, 5000 Forbes Ave, Pittsburgh, PA 15213, United States
Abstract: Reducing total power consumption in high performance microprocessors can be achieved by limiting the amount of logic involved in decoding, scheduling and executing each instruction. One of the solutions to this problem involves the use of a microarchitecture based on an Execution Cache (EC) whose role is to cache already done work for later reuse. In this paper, we explore the design space for such a microarchitecture, looking at how the cache size, associativity and replacement algorithm affect the overall performance and power efficiency. We also look at the scalability of this solution across next process generations, evaluating the energy efficiency of such caching mechanisms in the presence of increasing leakage power. Over a spectrum of SPEC2000 benchmarks, an average of 35% energy reduction is achieved for technologies ranging from 130nm to 90nm and 65nm, at the expense of a negligible performance hit.
Author Keywords: Design; Measurement; Performance
Index Keywords: Buffer storage; Decoding; Energy dissipation; Energy efficiency; Microprocessor chips; Scheduling; Transistors; Leakage power; Microarchitecture; Power consumption; Power efficiency; Computer architecture

Authors: Krishna R., Mahlke S., Austin T.
Title: Memory system design space exploration for low-power, real-time speech recognition
Source title: Second IEEE/ACM/IFIP International Conference on Hardware/Software Codesign and Systems Synthesis, CODES+ISSS 2004
Affiliations: Advanced Computer Architecture Lab., University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States
Authors with affiliations: Krishna, R., Advanced Computer Architecture Lab., University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Mahlke, S., Advanced Computer Architecture Lab., University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States; Austin, T., Advanced Computer Architecture Lab., University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, United States
Abstract: The recent proliferation of computing technology has generated new interest natural I/O interface technologies such as speech recognition. Unfortunately, the computational and memory demands of such applications currently prohibit their use on low-power portable devices in anything more than their simplest forms. Previous work has demonstrated that the thread level concurrency inherent in this application domain can be used to dramatically improve performance with minimal impact on overall system energy consumption, but that such benefits are severely constrained by memory system bandwidth. This work presents a design space exploration of potential memory system architectures. A range of low-power memory organizations are considered, from conventional caching to more advanced system-on-chip implementations. We find that, given architectures able to exploit concurrency in this domain, large L2 based cache hierarchies and high bandwidth memory systems employing data stream partitioning and on-chip embedded DRAM and ROM technologies can provide much of the performance of idealized memory systems without violating the power constraints of the low-power domain.
Author Keywords: Performance Design
Index Keywords: Application specific integrated circuits; Bandwidth; Computer architecture; Concurrency control; Dynamic random access storage; Energy efficiency; Input output programs; Real time systems; Speech recognition; Chip multiprocessor (CMP); Data stream partitioning; Design space exploration; Multithreading (MT); Systems analysis

Title: Memory-aware energy-optimal frequency assignment for dynamic supply voltage scaling
Source title: Proceedings of the 2004 International Symposium on Lower Power Electronics and Design, ISLPED'04
Affiliations: Sch. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, Seoul National University, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Cho, Y., Sch. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, Seoul National University, South Korea; Chang, N., Sch. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, Seoul National University, South Korea
Abstract: Dynamic supply voltage scaling (DVS) is one of the best ways to reduce the energy consumption of a device when there is a super-linear relationship between energy and supply voltage, and a pseudo-linear relationship between delay and supply voltage. However, most DVS schemes scale the clock frequency of the supply-voltage-clock-scalable (SVCS) CPU only and do not address the energy consumption of the memory. The memory is generally non-supply-voltage-scalable (NSVS), but its energy consumption is variable to its clock frequency and the total execution time. Thus, DVS for an SVCS CPU cannot achieve an optimal system-wide energy saving without consideration of the memory, as far as it is controlled by an SVCS CPU. We introduce an energy-optimal frequency assignment, for both an SVCS CPU and a synchronous NSVS memory, which optimizes the system-wide energy consumption. We derive the energy-optimal clock frequencies for an SVCS CPU and a synchronous NSVS memory, as a function of the number of processor clock cycles, the number of memory accesses and the hardware energy model. Our technique modifies the frequency assignment of the CPU and the memory used in previous DVS schemes, which ignore the memory energy. It enables the system-wide energy-optimal settings and achieves additional 50% energy reduction over previous DVS schemes. This technique can also be applicable to synchronous NSVS peripheral devices.
Author Keywords: Low power; Memory system; SDRAM
Index Keywords: CMOS integrated circuits; Electric potential; Energy utilization; Logic devices; Mathematical models; Optimization; Problem solving; Space division multiple access; Theorem proving; Dynamic supply voltage scaling (DVS); Low power; Memory system; Supply-voltage-clock-scalable (SVCS); Data storage equipment

Authors: Hung W., Xie Y., Vijaykrishnan N., Kandemir M., Irwin M.J., Tsai Y.
Title: Total power optimization through simultaneously multiple-VDD multiple-VTH assignment and device sizing with stack forcing
Source title: Proceedings of the 2004 International Symposium on Lower Power Electronics and Design, ISLPED'04
Affiliations: Embedded and Mobile Comp. Des. Ctr., Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hung, W., Embedded and Mobile Comp. Des. Ctr., Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Xie, Y., Embedded and Mobile Comp. Des. Ctr., Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Kandemir, M., Embedded and Mobile Comp. Des. Ctr., Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Irwin, M.J., Embedded and Mobile Comp. Des. Ctr., Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Tsai, Y., Embedded and Mobile Comp. Des. Ctr., Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States
Abstract: In this paper, we present an algorithm for the minimization of total power consumption via multiple VDD assignment, multiple VTH assignment, device sizing and stack forcing, while maintaining performance requirements. These four power reduction techniques are properly encoded in genetic algorithm and evaluated simultaneously. The overhead imposed by the insertion of level converters is also taken into account. The effectiveness of each power reduction mechanism is verified, as are the combinations of different approaches. Experimental results are given for a number of 65 nm benchmark circuits that span typical circuit topologies, including inverter chains, SRAM decoders, multiplier and a 32bit carry adders. From the experimental results, we show that the combination of four low power techniques is the effective way to achieve low power budget.

Authors: Zhang C., Vahid F., Yang J., Najjar W.
Title: A way-halting cache for low-energy high-performance systems
Source title: Proceedings of the 2004 International Symposium on Lower Power Electronics and Design, ISLPED'04
Affiliations: Dept. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, University of California, United States; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of California, Riverside, United States; Center for Embedded Computer Systems, UC Irvine, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, C., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of California, Riverside, United States; Vahid, F., Dept. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, University of California, United States, Center for Embedded Computer Systems, UC Irvine, United States; Yang, J., Dept. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, University of California, United States; Najjar, W., Dept. of Comp. Sci. and Engineering, University of California, United States
Abstract: Caches contribute to much of a microprocessor system's power and energy consumption. We have developed a new cache architecture, called a way-halting cache, that reduces energy while imposing no performance overhead. Our way-halting cache is a four-way set-associative cache that stores the four lowest-order bits of all ways' tags into a fully associative memory, which we call the halt tag array. The lookup in the halt tag array is done in parallel with, and is no slower than, the set-index decoding. The halt tag array pre-determines which tags cannot match due to their low-order four bits mismatching. Further accesses to ways with known mismatching tags are then halted, thus saving power. Our halt tag array has an additional feature of using static logic only, rather than dynamic logic used in highly associative caches. We provide data from experiments on 17 benchmarks drawn from MediaBench and Spec 2000, based on our layouts in 0.18 micron CMOS technology. On average, 55% savings of memory-access related energy were obtained over a conventional four-way set-associative cache. We show that energy savings are greater than previous methods, and nearly twice that of highly-associative caches, while imposing no performance overhead and only 2% cache area overhead.
Author Keywords: Cache design; Low power techniques
Index Keywords: Benchmarking; CMOS integrated circuits; Decoding; Digital circuits; Energy dissipation; Energy utilization; Microprocessor chips; Power electronics; Static random access storage; Cache design; Low power techniques; Power consumption; Way-halting cache; Cache memory

Authors: Yu L., Munghor L.A., Yi P., Teng H.
Title: Simulation-based evaluation of electronic energy storage devices in buses for reducing emissions
Source title: Transportation Research Record
Affiliations: Department of Transportation Studies, Texas Southern University, 3100 Cleburne Avenue, Houston, TX 77004, United States; Beijing Jiaotong University, China; Office of Institutional Research, Houston Community College System, 3100 Main Street, Houston, TX 77002, United States; Department of Civil Engineering, University of Akron, Akron, OH 44325-3905, United States; Department of Civil Engineering, University of Virginia, Thornton Hall, 351 McCormick Road, Charlottesville, VA 22904-4742, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yu, L., Department of Transportation Studies, Texas Southern University, 3100 Cleburne Avenue, Houston, TX 77004, United States, Beijing Jiaotong University, China; Munghor, L.A., Office of Institutional Research, Houston Community College System, 3100 Main Street, Houston, TX 77002, United States; Yi, P., Department of Civil Engineering, University of Akron, Akron, OH 44325-3905, United States; Teng, H., Department of Civil Engineering, University of Virginia, Thornton Hall, 351 McCormick Road, Charlottesville, VA 22904-4742, United States
Abstract: Emerging concerns about emissions and increasing energy costs have led to interest in developing and applying electronic devices for energy storage (popularly known as flywheel batteries or simply flywheels) in transportation applications to recover the energy used in braking rather than dissipating it as heat. Each time a vehicle stops, its kinetic energy is dissipated as heat. Fuel is then used to accelerate the vehicle again. A flywheel energy storage device that stores the braking energy and then reuses it for acceleration has the potential to improve fuel economy and reduce pollution. It is important to evaluate the application of this technology in transit buses to assess better any need for increased development. A three-step computer simulation is used to evaluate the reduced emissions of carbon monoxide (CO), hydrocarbon (HC), and nitrogen oxides (NOx) in a flywheel-equipped bus. First, drive cycles over which buses operate are specified. Second, because flywheel energy storage reduces the effects of acceleration and deceleration to the engine, the emissions models (which are sensitive to acceleration and deceleration modes) are identified and selected. Finally, emissions are computed and compared with emissions for a bus without a flywheel. Results indicate conceptually that the flywheel application reduces acceleration effects, which in turn significantly reduce emissions. It is therefore strongly recommended that the flywheel energy storage device be further researched for transportation applications.
Index Keywords: Acceleration; Carbon dioxide; Computer simulation; Electronic equipment; Energy storage; Flywheels; Fuel consumption; Hydrocarbons; Mathematical models; Nitrogen oxides; Rapid transit; Electronic storage devices; Emission models; Mobile source emission factor models; National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST); Buses

Authors: Ogden R.G., Kendrick C.C., Walliman N.S.R.
Title: Modelling of enhanced passive and conventional cooling systems
Source title: Building Research and Information
Affiliations: School of Architecture, Oxford Brookes University, Headington, Oxford OX3 0BP, United Kingdom; Steel Construction Institute, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Ogden, R.G., School of Architecture, Oxford Brookes University, Headington, Oxford OX3 0BP, United Kingdom, Steel Construction Institute, United Kingdom; Kendrick, C.C., School of Architecture, Oxford Brookes University, Headington, Oxford OX3 0BP, United Kingdom; Walliman, N.S.R., School of Architecture, Oxford Brookes University, Headington, Oxford OX3 0BP, United Kingdom
Abstract: This study modelled a recently completed typical steel-framed speculative office development in the UK. It investigated the comparative performance of the building for various servicing regimes. These included natural and mechanical ventilation, two types of active fabric energy storage (FES) system (AirDeck and AirCore), air-conditioning (a conventional all-air system and chilled ceiling with mechanical ventilation), and mixed-mode solutions combining some of the above approaches. The assessment covered both summer and winter (heating) performance. The main objective was to evaluate overall performance of these systems in terms of thermal comfort and energy use and to compare the findings with more conventional servicing options for the same building. The study demonstrates that active FES can enhance thermal comfort while reducing energy use and emissions. In comparison with conventionally and naturally ventilated systems, the studied FES systems reduced temperature excess hours and peak temperatures, supplied cooler air as a result of overnight cooling, and reduced chiller consumption and boiler ratings as well as emissions. The annual operating costs of these active FES systems increase energy costs by only 13% over that of the naturally ventilated option. The mixed-mode solutions reduce them by over 35% when compared with ail-mechanically cooled alternatives.
Author Keywords: Air-conditioning; Conventional cooling; Dynamic thermal simulation; Fabric energy storage; Mechanical ventilation; Natural ventilation; Office buildings; Steel-framed buildings
Index Keywords: Conventional cooling systems; Dynamic thermal simulation; Fabric energy storage; Mechanical ventilation; Steel framed buildings; Air conditioning; Computer simulation; Cooling systems; Costs; Energy storage; Mathematical models; Particulate emissions; Structural frames; Thermal effects; Ventilation; Office buildings

Title: Technology. Reduction of carbon dioxide emissions. The IFP responses [Technologie. Réduction des émissions de CO2: Les résponses IFP]
Source title: Petrole et Gaz Informations
Abstract: With the prospect of continuous growth in the consumption of energy tied to world economic growth, the struggle against the greenhouse effect by the reduction of the emissions of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere is a major technological challenge for years to come. For the hydrocarbons (petroleum and gas), these goals relate to the reduction in the consumption of energy, notably in the area of engines, by the progressive replacement of fossil fuels, rich in carbon, by energies, fossil or not, of a lesser content of carbon, and also by the capture and sequestration of CO2. Well known nationally and internationally and having the required key competencies all along the petroleum chain, the IFP intervenes in these three areas. In the area of transportation, the manufacturers have engaged themselves to reduce CO2 emissions to 140 g/km in 2008 and perhaps to 120 g/km in 2012. The difficulty consists of reconciling the increase in efficiency with the increasingly severe specifications relating to the reduction of regulated pollutant emissions. IFP works on optimizing engine design, ignition and diesel, new combustion modes, homogeneous combustion that is expected to reconcile high engine combustion efficiencies with the very low emissions of pollutants. With respect to alternative fuels, the paths that seem to be the most interesting are CNG, bio fuels, and in the long term, hydrogen, even if the obstacles to its use in transportation are now considerable. The discussion also covers the capture and sequestration of CO2 below ground as the most promising; the transport of CO2 in liquid phase; and the methods of underground storage of CO2.

Authors: Shin S., Forte A.G., Rawat A.S., Schulzrinne H.
Title: Reducing MAC layer handoff latency in IEEE 802.11 wireless LANs
Source title: MobiWac'04 - Proceedings of the Second International Workshop on Mobility Management and Wireless Access Protocols
Affiliations: Columbia University, United States; New York University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Shin, S., Columbia University, United States; Forte, A.G., Columbia University, United States; Rawat, A.S., New York University, United States; Schulzrinne, H., Columbia University, United States
Abstract: With the growth of IEEE 802.11-based wireless LANs, VoIP and similar applications are now commonly used over wireless networks. Mobile station performs a handoff whenever it moves out of the range of one access point (AP) and tries to connect to a different one. This takes a few hundred milliseconds, causing interruptions in VoIP sessions. We developed a new handoff procedure which reduces the MAC layer handoff latency, in most cases, to a level where VoIP communication becomes seamless. This new handoff procedure reduces the discovery phase using a selective scanning algorithm and a caching mechanism. Copyright 2004 ACM.
Author Keywords: Fast Handoff; IEEE 802.11; Selective scanning

Authors: Cress C.C., Yang S.J., Sudit M.
Title: Energy efficient data retrieval for networked multi-mode wireless sensors
Source title: PE-WASUN'04 - Proceedings of the First ACM International Workshop on Performance Evaluation of Wireless Ad Hoc, Sensor, and Ubiquitous Networks
Affiliations: Microsystems Engineering, Rochester Inst. Technology, United States; Computer Engineering, Rochester Inst. Technology, United States; Industrial and System Eng., Rochester Inst. Technology, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cress, C.C., Microsystems Engineering, Rochester Inst. Technology, United States; Yang, S.J., Computer Engineering, Rochester Inst. Technology, United States; Sudit, M., Industrial and System Eng., Rochester Inst. Technology, United States
Abstract: This paper develops a mixed-integer programming model to maximize the total data retrieved via a wireless sensor networks, subject to the practical network and individual multi-mode sensor constraints. The model is different from existing ones in that it accounts for the buffer usage over time and the energy spikes incurred due to transitions between the operational modes. Heuristic procedures are developed for solving the NP-Hard problem. Simulation results exhibit that good performance can be achieved when the routing and MAC decisions are made based on individual sensors' buffer content and residual energy.

Title: Thermal diffusion of Helium and volatil fission products in UO2 and zirconolite nuclear ceramics
Source title: Materials Research Society Symposium Proceedings
Affiliations: CEA VALRHO DEN, DTCD, SECM/LMPA, BP 17171, 30207 Bagnols sur Cèze Cedex, France; CEA SACLAY DEN, DMN, SRMP, 91191Gif-sur-Yvette Cedex, France; CNRS Meudon-Bellevue, Place A.Briand, 92195 Meudon, France; CEA SACLAY DEN, DMN, SRMA, 91191Gif-sur-Yvette Cedex, France
